So this is a computer program.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
Booted up in a cell, the program would execute,

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958
and it could result in this person;

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:35.958
or with a small change, it could result in this person;

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
or another small change, this person;

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:40.958
or with a larger change, this dog,

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958
or this tree, or this whale.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:44.958
So now, if you take this metaphor

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:46.958
[of] genome as program seriously,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
you have to consider that Chris Anderson

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
is a computer-fabricated artifact, as is Jim Watson,

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:54.958
Craig Venter, as are all of us.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
And in convincing yourself that this metaphor is true,

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.958
there are lots of similarities between genetic programs

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:01.958
and computer programs that could help to convince you.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
But one, to me, that's most compelling

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:06.958
is the peculiar sensitivity to small changes

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:09.958
that can make large changes in biological development -- the output.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
A small mutation can take a two-wing fly

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:12.958
and make it a four-wing fly.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:16.958
Or it could take a fly and put legs where its antennae should be.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
Or if you're familiar with "The Princess Bride,"

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
it could create a six-fingered man.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
Now, a hallmark of computer programs

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
is just this kind of sensitivity to small changes.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
If your bank account's one dollar, and you flip a single bit,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
you could end up with a thousand dollars.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
So these small changes are things that I think

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
that -- they indicate to us that a complicated computation

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:38.958
in development is underlying these amplified, large changes.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:44.958
So now, all of this indicates that there are molecular programs underlying biology,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:48.958
and it shows the power of molecular programs -- biology does.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:50.958
And what I want to do is write molecular programs,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
potentially to build technology.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:53.958
And there are a lot of people doing this,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
a lot of synthetic biologists doing this, like Craig Venter.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
And they concentrate on using cells.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
They're cell-oriented.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
So my friends, molecular programmers, and I

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
have a sort of biomolecule-centric approach.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:07.958
We're interested in using DNA, RNA and protein,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:10.958
and building new languages for building things from the bottom up,

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:11.958
using biomolecules,

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
potentially having nothing to do with biology.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:18.958
So, these are all the machines in a cell.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
There's a camera.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:21.958
There's the solar panels of the cell,

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
some switches that turn your genes on and off,

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:26.958
the girders of the cell, motors that move your muscles.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
My little group of molecular programmers

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:32.958
are trying to refashion all of these parts from DNA.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
We're not DNA zealots, but DNA is the cheapest,

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
easiest to understand and easy to program material to do this.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
And as other things become easier to use --

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
maybe protein -- we'll work with those.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
If we succeed, what will molecular programming look like?

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
You're going to sit in front of your computer.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:48.958
You're going to design something like a cell phone,

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
and in a high-level language, you'll describe that cell phone.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
Then you're going to have a compiler

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:53.958
that's going to take that description

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
and it's going to turn it into actual molecules

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
that can be sent to a synthesizer

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
and that synthesizer will pack those molecules into a seed.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
And what happens if you water and feed that seed appropriately,

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
is it will do a developmental computation,

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
a molecular computation, and it'll build an electronic computer.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
And if I haven't revealed my prejudices already,

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
I think that life has been about molecular computers

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
building electrochemical computers,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
building electronic computers,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
which together with electrochemical computers

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
will build new molecular computers,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
which will build new electronic computers, and so forth.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:25.958
And if you buy all of this,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
and you think life is about computation, as I do,

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
then you look at big questions through the eyes of a computer scientist.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:34.958
So one big question is, how does a baby know when to stop growing?

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
And for molecular programming,

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
the question is how does your cell phone know when to stop growing?

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:39.958
(Laughter)

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
Or how does a computer program know when to stop running?

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
Or more to the point, how do you know if a program will ever stop?

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
There are other questions like this, too.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
One of them is Craig Venter's question.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
Turns out I think he's actually a computer scientist.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.958
He asked, how big is the minimal genome

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
that will give me a functioning microorganism?

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
How few genes can I use?

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
This is exactly analogous to the question,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:01.958
what's the smallest program I can write

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
that will act exactly like Microsoft Word?

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:04.958
(Laughter)

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:08.958
And just as he's writing, you know, bacteria that will be smaller,

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:09.958
he's writing genomes that will work,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
we could write smaller programs

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
that would do what Microsoft Word does.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
But for molecular programming, our question is,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:19.958
how many molecules do we need to put in that seed to get a cell phone?

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
What's the smallest number we can get away with?

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
Now, these are big questions in computer science.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
These are all complexity questions,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
and computer science tells us that these are very hard questions.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
Almost -- many of them are impossible.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
But for some tasks, we can start to answer them.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:33.958
So, I'm going to start asking those questions

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
for the DNA structures I'm going to talk about next.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
So, this is normal DNA, what you think of as normal DNA.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
It's double-stranded, it's a double helix,

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
has the As, Ts, Cs and Gs that pair to hold the strands together.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
And I'm going to draw it like this sometimes,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
just so I don't scare you.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
We want to look at individual strands and not think about the double helix.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
When we synthesize it, it comes single-stranded,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
so we can take the blue strand in one tube

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
and make an orange strand in the other tube,

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
and they're floppy when they're single-stranded.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
You mix them together and they make a rigid double helix.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
Now for the last 25 years,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
Ned Seeman and a bunch of his descendants

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
have worked very hard and made beautiful three-dimensional structures

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
using this kind of reaction of DNA strands coming together.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
But a lot of their approaches, though elegant, take a long time.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
They can take a couple of years, or it can be difficult to design.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
So I came up with a new method a couple of years ago

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:24.958
I call DNA origami

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
that's so easy you could do it at home in your kitchen

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
and design the stuff on a laptop.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
But to do it, you need a long, single strand of DNA,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
which is technically very difficult to get.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
So, you can go to a natural source.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
You can look in this computer-fabricated artifact,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
and he's got a double-stranded genome -- that's no good.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
You look in his intestines. There are billions of bacteria.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
They're no good either.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
Double strand again, but inside them, they're infected with a virus

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.958
that has a nice, long, single-stranded genome

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
that we can fold like a piece of paper.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:52.958
And here's how we do it.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:53.958
This is part of that genome.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
We add a bunch of short, synthetic DNAs that I call staples.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:06:00.958
Each one has a left half that binds the long strand in one place,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
and a right half that binds it in a different place,

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
and brings the long strand together like this.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
The net action of many of these on that long strand

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
is to fold it into something like a rectangle.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
Now, we can't actually take a movie of this process,

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
but Shawn Douglas at Harvard

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
has made a nice visualization for us

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:20.958
that begins with a long strand and has some short strands in it.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:24.958
And what happens is that we mix these strands together.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
We heat them up, we add a little bit of salt,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
we heat them up to almost boiling and cool them down,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:29.958
and as we cool them down,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
the short strands bind the long strands

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
and start to form structure.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
And you can see a little bit of double helix forming there.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
When you look at DNA origami,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
you can see that what it really is,

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:43.958
even though you think it's complicated,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
is a bunch of double helices that are parallel to each other,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
and they're held together

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
by places where short strands go along one helix

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
and then jump to another one.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
So there's a strand that goes like this, goes along one helix and binds --

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
it jumps to another helix and comes back.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
That holds the long strand like this.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
Now, to show that we could make any shape or pattern

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
that we wanted, I tried to make this shape.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
I wanted to fold DNA into something that goes up over the eye,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
down the nose, up the nose, around the forehead,

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
back down and end in a little loop like this.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
And so, I thought, if this could work, anything could work.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
So I had the computer program design the short staples to do this.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
I ordered them; they came by FedEx.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
I mixed them up, heated them, cooled them down,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:27.958
and I got 50 billion little smiley faces

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
floating around in a single drop of water.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
And each one of these is just

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:35.958
one-thousandth the width of a human hair, OK?

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
So, they're all floating around in solution, and to look at them,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
you have to get them on a surface where they stick.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
So, you pour them out onto a surface

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
and they start to stick to that surface,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
and we take a picture using an atomic-force microscope.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
It's got a needle, like a record needle,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
that goes back and forth over the surface,

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
bumps up and down, and feels the height of the first surface.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
It feels the DNA origami.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
There's the atomic-force microscope working

00:07:58.958 --> 00:07:59.958
and you can see that the landing's a little rough.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
When you zoom in, they've got, you know,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:02.958
weak jaws that flip over their heads

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
and some of their noses get punched out, but it's pretty good.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
You can zoom in and even see the extra little loop,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
this little nano-goatee.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
Now, what's great about this is anybody can do this.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:16.958
And so, I got this in the mail about a year after I did this, unsolicited.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
Anyone know what this is? What is it?

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
It's China, right?

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
So, what happened is, a graduate student in China,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
Lulu Qian, did a great job.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
She wrote all her own software

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
to design and built this DNA origami,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
a beautiful rendition of China, which even has Taiwan,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
and you can see it's sort of on the world's shortest leash, right?

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
(Laughter)

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:39.958
So, this works really well

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
and you can make patterns as well as shapes, OK?

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
And you can make a map of the Americas and spell DNA with DNA.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
And what's really neat about it --

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
well, actually, this all looks like nano-artwork,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:52.958
but it turns out that nano-artwork

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
is just what you need to make nano-circuits.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
So, you can put circuit components on the staples,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
like a light bulb and a light switch.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
Let the thing assemble, and you'll get some kind of a circuit.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
And then you can maybe wash the DNA away and have the circuit left over.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
So, this is what some colleagues of mine at Caltech did.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
They took a DNA origami, organized some carbon nano-tubes,

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
made a little switch, you see here, wired it up,

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
tested it and showed that it is indeed a switch.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
Now, this is just a single switch

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:20.958
and you need half a billion for a computer, so we have a long way to go.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
But this is very promising

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:27.958
because the origami can organize parts just one-tenth the size

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:28.958
of those in a normal computer.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
So it's very promising for making small computers.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
Now, I want to get back to that compiler.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
The DNA origami is a proof that that compiler actually works.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
So, you start with something in the computer.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
You get a high-level description of the computer program,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
a high-level description of the origami.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
You can compile it to molecules, send it to a synthesizer,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:49.958
and it actually works.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:53.958
And it turns out that a company has made a nice program

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
that's much better than my code, which was kind of ugly,

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:56.958
and will allow us to do this in a nice,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
visual, computer-aided design way.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:00.958
So, now you can say, all right,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
why isn't DNA origami the end of the story?

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
You have your molecular compiler, you can do whatever you want.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
The fact is that it does not scale.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
So if you want to build a human from DNA origami,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
the problem is, you need a long strand

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
that's 10 trillion trillion bases long.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
That's three light years' worth of DNA,

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
so we're not going to do this.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
We're going to turn to another technology,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
called algorithmic self-assembly of tiles.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
It was started by Erik Winfree,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:26.958
and what it does,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:30.958
it has tiles that are a hundredth the size of a DNA origami.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
You zoom in, there are just four DNA strands

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
and they have little single-stranded bits on them

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
that can bind to other tiles, if they match.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
And we like to draw these tiles as little squares.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
And if you look at their sticky ends, these little DNA bits,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
you can see that they actually form a checkerboard pattern.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
So, these tiles would make a complicated, self-assembling checkerboard.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
And the point of this, if you didn't catch that,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
is that tiles are a kind of molecular program

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
and they can output patterns.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
And a really amazing part of this is

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
that any computer program can be translated

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
into one of these tile programs -- specifically, counting.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
So, you can come up with a set of tiles

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
that when they come together, form a little binary counter

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
rather than a checkerboard.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
So you can read off binary numbers five, six and seven.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
And in order to get these kinds of computations started right,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
you need some kind of input, a kind of seed.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
You can use DNA origami for that.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
You can encode the number 32

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
in the right-hand side of a DNA origami,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
and when you add those tiles that count,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
they will start to count -- they will read that 32

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
and they'll stop at 32.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
So, what we've done is we've figured out a way

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
to have a molecular program know when to stop going.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
It knows when to stop growing because it can count.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
It knows how big it is.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
So, that answers that sort of first question I was talking about.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
It doesn't tell us how babies do it, however.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:53.958
So now, we can use this counting to try and get at much bigger things

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:54.958
than DNA origami could otherwise.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
Here's the DNA origami, and what we can do

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
is we can write 32 on both edges of the DNA origami,

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
and we can now use our watering can

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:06.958
and water with tiles, and we can start growing tiles off of that

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
and create a square.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
The counter serves as a template

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
to fill in a square in the middle of this thing.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:14.958
So, what we've done is we've succeeded

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
in making something much bigger than a DNA origami

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
by combining DNA origami with tiles.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
And the neat thing about it is, is that it's also reprogrammable.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.958
You can just change a couple of the DNA strands in this binary representation

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
and you'll get 96 rather than 32.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
And if you do that, the origami's the same size,

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:37.958
but the resulting square that you get is three times bigger.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:39.958
So, this sort of recapitulates

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
what I was telling you about development.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
You have a very sensitive computer program

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
where small changes -- single, tiny, little mutations --

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
can take something that made one size square

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
and make something very much bigger.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
Now, this -- using counting to compute

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
and build these kinds of things

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
by this kind of developmental process

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:04.958
is something that also has bearing on Craig Venter's question.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
So, you can ask, how many DNA strands are required

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
to build a square of a given size?

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:13.958
If we wanted to make a square of size 10, 100 or 1,000,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
if we used DNA origami alone,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
we would require a number of DNA strands that's the square

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
of the size of that square;

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
so we'd need 100, 10,000 or a million DNA strands.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
That's really not affordable.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
But if we use a little computation --

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
we use origami, plus some tiles that count --

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
then we can get away with using 100, 200 or 300 DNA strands.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:38.958
And so we can exponentially reduce the number of DNA strands we use,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
if we use counting, if we use a little bit of computation.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
And so computation is some very powerful way

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
to reduce the number of molecules you need to build something,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
to reduce the size of the genome that you're building.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
And finally, I'm going to get back to that sort of crazy idea

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
about computers building computers.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
If you look at the square that you build with the origami

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
and some counters growing off it,

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
the pattern that it has is exactly the pattern that you need

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:04.958
to make a memory.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
So if you affix some wires and switches to those tiles --

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
rather than to the staple strands, you affix them to the tiles --

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
then they'll self-assemble the somewhat complicated circuits,

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
the demultiplexer circuits, that you need to address this memory.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
So you can actually make a complicated circuit

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
using a little bit of computation.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
It's a molecular computer building an electronic computer.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
Now, you ask me, how far have we gotten down this path?

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
Experimentally, this is what we've done in the last year.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
Here is a DNA origami rectangle,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
and here are some tiles growing from it.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
And you can see how they count.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:48.958
One, two, three, four, five, six, nine, 10, 11, 12, 17.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:52.958
So it's got some errors, but at least it counts up.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:53.958
(Laughter)

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
So, it turns out we actually had this idea nine years ago,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
and that's about the time constant for how long it takes

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
to do these kinds of things, so I think we made a lot of progress.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
We've got ideas about how to fix these errors.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
And I think in the next five or 10 years,

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
we'll make the kind of squares that I described

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
and maybe even get to some of those self-assembled circuits.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:14.958
So now, what do I want you to take away from this talk?

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
I want you to remember that

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.958
to create life's very diverse and complex forms,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
life uses computation to do that.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:26.958
And the computations that it uses, they're molecular computations,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
and in order to understand this and get a better handle on it,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
as Feynman said, you know,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
we need to build something to understand it.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
And so we are going to use molecules and refashion this thing,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
rebuild everything from the bottom up,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
using DNA in ways that nature never intended,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
using DNA origami,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
and DNA origami to seed this algorithmic self-assembly.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
You know, so this is all very cool,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:50.958
but what I'd like you to take from the talk,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
hopefully from some of those big questions,

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
is that this molecular programming isn't just about making gadgets.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
It's not just making about --

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
it's making self-assembled cell phones and circuits.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
What it's really about is taking computer science

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
and looking at big questions in a new light,

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
asking new versions of those big questions

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
and trying to understand how biology

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
can make such amazing things. Thank you.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:18.958
(Applause)

title: Our next giant leap
transcript: My mission in life since I was a kid was, and is, to take the rest of you into space. It's during our lifetime that we're going to take the Earth, take the people of Earth and transition off, permanently. And that's exciting. In fact, I think it is a moral imperative that we open the space frontier. You know, it's the first time that we're going to have a chance to have planetary redundancy, a chance to, if you would, back up the biosphere. And if you think about space, everything we hold of value on this planet — metals and minerals and real estate and energy — is in infinite quantities in space.In fact, the Earth is a crumb in a supermarket filled with resources. The analogy for me is Alaska. You know, we bought Alaska. We Americans bought Alaska in the 1850s. It's called Seward's folly. We valued it as the number of seal pelts we could kill. And then we discovered these things — gold and oil and fishing and timber — and it became, you know, a trillion-dollar economy, and now we take our honeymoons there. The same thing will happen in space. We are on the verge of the greatest exploration that the human race has ever known.We explore for three reasons, the weakest of which is curiosity. You know, it's funded NASA's budget up until now. Some images from Mars, 1997. In fact, I think in the next decade, without any question, we will discover life on Mars and find that it is literally ubiquitous under the soils and different parts of that planet.The stronger motivator, the much stronger motivator, is fear. It drove us to the moon. We — literally in fear — with the Soviet Union raced to the moon. And we have these huge rocks, you know, killer-sized rocks in the hundreds of thousands or millions out there, and while the probability is very small, the impact, figured in literally, of one of these hitting the Earth is so huge that to spend a small fraction looking, searching, preparing to defend, is not unreasonable.And of course, the third motivator, one near and dear to my heart as an entrepreneur, is wealth. In fact, the greatest wealth. If you think about these other asteroids, there's a class of the nickel iron, which in platinum-group metal markets alone are worth something like 20 trillion dollars, if you can go out and grab one of these rocks. My plan is to actually buy puts on the precious metal market, and then actually claim that I'm going to go out and get one. And that will fund the actual mission to go and get one. But fear, curiosity and greed have driven us. And for me, this is — I'm the short kid on the right. This was — my motivation was actually during Apollo.And Apollo was one of the greatest motivators ever. If you think about what happened at the turn of — early 1960s, on May 25, JFK said, "We're going to go to the moon." And people left their jobs and they went to obscure locations to go and be part of this amazing mission. And we knew nothing about going to space. We went from having literally put Alan Shepard in suborbital flight to going to the moon in eight years, and the average age of the people that got us there was 26 years old. They didn't know what couldn't be done. They had to make up everything. And that, my friend, is amazing motivation. This is Gene Cernan, a good friend of mine, saying, "If I can go to the moon" — this is the last human on the moon so far — "nothing, nothing is impossible." But of course, we've thought about the government always as the person taking us there.But I put forward here, the government is not going to get us there. The government is unable to take the risks required to open up this precious frontier. The shuttle is costing a billion dollars a launch. That's a pathetic number. It's unreasonable. We shouldn't be happy in standing for that. One of the things that we did with the Ansari X PRIZE was take the challenge on that risk is OK, you know. As we are going out there and taking on a new frontier, we should be allowed to risk. In fact, anyone who says we shouldn't, you know, just needs to be put aside, because, as we go forward, in fact, the greatest discoveries we will ever know is ahead of us. The entrepreneurs in the space business are the furry mammals, and clearly the industrial-military complex — with Boeing and Lockheed and NASA — are the dinosaurs. The ability for us to access these resources to gain planetary redundancy — we can now gather all the information, the genetic codes, you know, everything stored on our databases, and back them up off the planet, in case there would be one of those disastrous situations.The difficulty is getting there, and clearly, the cost to orbit is key. Once you're in orbit, you are two thirds of the way, energetically, to anywhere — the moon, to Mars. And today, there's only three vehicles — the U.S. shuttle, the Russian Soyuz and the Chinese vehicle — that gets you there. Arguably, it's about 100 million dollars a person on the space shuttle. One of the companies I started, Space Adventures, will sell you a ticket. We've done two so far. We'll be announcing two more on the Soyuz to go up to the space station for 20 million dollars. But that's expensive and to understand what the potential is —(Laughter) —it is expensive. But people are willing to pay that! You know, one — we have a very unique period in time today. For the first time ever, we have enough wealth concentrated in the hands of few individuals and the technology accessible that will allow us to really drive space exploration. But how cheap could it get? I want to give you the end point. We know — 20 million dollars today, you can go and buy a ticket, but how cheap could it get?Let's go back to high school physics here. If you calculate the amount of potential energy, mgh, to take you and your spacesuit up to a couple hundred miles, and then you accelerate yourself to 17,500 miles per hour — remember, that one half MV squared — and you figure it out. It's about 5.7 gigajoules of energy. If you expended that over an hour, it's about 1.6 megawatts. If you go to one of Vijay's micro-power sources, and they sell it to you for seven cents a kilowatt hour — anybody here fast in math? How much will it cost you and your spacesuit to go to orbit? 100 bucks. That's the price-improvement curve that — we need some breakthroughs in physics along the way, I'll grant you that.(Laughter)But guys, if history has taught us anything, it's that if you can imagine it, you will get there eventually. I have no question that the physics, the engineering to get us down to the point where all of us can afford orbital space flight is around the corner. The difficulty is that there needs to be a real marketplace to drive the investment. Today, the Boeings and the Lockheeds don't spend a dollar of their own money in R&D. It's all government research dollars, and very few of those. And in fact, the large corporations, the governments, can't take the risk. So we need what I call an exothermic economic reaction in space. Today's commercial markets worldwide, global commercial launch market? 12 to 15 launches per year. Number of commercial companies out there? 12 to 15 companies. One per company. That's not it. There's only one marketplace, and I call them self-loading carbon payloads. They come with their own money. They're easy to make. It's people. The Ansari X PRIZE was my solution, reading about Lindbergh for creating the vehicles to get us there.We offered 10 million dollars in cash for the first reusable ship, carry three people up to 100 kilometers, come back down, and within two weeks, make the trip again. Twenty-six teams from seven countries entered the competition, spending between one to 25 million dollars each. And of course, we had beautiful SpaceShipOne, which made those two flights and won the competition. And I'd like to take you there, to that morning, for just a quick video.(Video) Pilot: Release our fire.Richard Searfoss: Good luck.(Applause)RS: We've got an altitude call of 368,000 feet.(Applause)RS: So in my official capacity as the chief judge of the Ansari X PRIZE competition, I declare that Mojave Aerospace Ventures has indeed earned the Ansari X PRIZE.(Applause)Peter Diamandis: Probably the most difficult thing that I had to do was raise the capital for this. It was literally impossible. We went — I went to 100, 200 CEOs, CMOs. No one believed it was done. Everyone said, "Oh, what does NASA think? Well, people are going to die, how can you possibly going to put this forward?" I found a visionary family, the Ansari family, and Champ Car, and raised part of the money, but not the full 10 million.And what I ended up doing was going out to the insurance industry and buying a hole-in-one insurance policy. See, the insurance companies went to Boeing and Lockheed, and said, "Are you going to compete?" No. "Are you going to compete?" No. "No one's going to win this thing." So, they took a bet that no one would win by January of '05, and I took a bet that someone would win.(Applause)So — and the best thing is they paid off and the check didn't bounce.(Laughter)We've had a lot of accomplishments and it's been a tremendous success. One of the things I'm most happy about is that the SpaceShipOne is going to hang in Air and Space Museum, next to the Spirit of St. Louis and the Wright Flyer. Isn't that great? (Applause) So a little bit about the future, steps to space, what's available for you. Today, you can go and experience weightless flights. By '08, suborbital flights, the price tag for that, you know, on Virgin, is going to be about 200,000. There are three or four other serious efforts that will bring the price down very rapidly, I think, to about 25,000 dollars for a suborbital flight. Orbital flights — we can take you to the space station.And then I truly believe, once a group is in orbit around the Earth — I know if they don't do it, I am — we're going to stockpile some fuel, make a beeline for the moon and grab some real estate.(Laughter)Quick moment for the designers in the audience. We spent 11 years getting FAA approval to do zero gravity flights. Here are some fun images. Here's Burt Rutan and my good friend Greg Meronek inside a zero gravity — people think a zero gravity room, there's a switch on there that turns it off — but it's actually parabolic flight of an airplane. And turns out 7-Up has just done a little commercial that's airing this month. If we can get the audio up?(Video) Narrator: For a chance to win the first free ticket to space, look for specially marked packages of Diet 7-Up. When you want the taste that won't weigh you down, the only way to go is up.PD: That was filmed inside our airplane, and so, you can now do this. We're based down in Florida. Let me talk about the other thing I'm excited about. The future of prizes. You know, prizes are a very old idea. I had the pleasure of borrowing from the Longitude Prize and the Orteig Prize that put Lindbergh forward. And we have made a decision in the X PRIZE Foundation to actually carry that concept forward into other technology areas, and we just took on a new mission statement: "to bring about radical breakthroughs in space and other technologies for the benefit of humanity." And this is something that we're very excited about. I showed this slide to Larry Page, who just joined our board.And you know, when you give to a nonprofit, you might have 50 cents on the dollar. If you have a matching grant, it's typically two or three to one. If you put up a prize, you can get literally a 50 to one leverage on your dollars. And that's huge. And then he turned around and said, "Well, if you back a prize institute that runs a 10 prize, you get 500 to one." I said, "Well, that's great." So, we have actually — are looking to turn the X PRIZE into a world-class prize institute. This is what happens when you put up a prize, when you announce it and teams start to begin doing trials. You get publicity increase, and when it's won, publicity shoots through the roof — if it's properly managed — and that's part of the benefits to a sponsor. Then, when the prize is actually won, after it's moving, you get societal benefits, you know, new technology, new capability. And the benefit to the sponsors is the sum of the publicity and societal benefits over the long term. That's our value proposition in a prize.If you were going to go and try to create SpaceShipOne, or any kind of a new technology, you have to fund that from the beginning and maintain that funding with an uncertain outcome. It may or may not happen. But if you put up a prize, the beautiful thing is, you know, it's a very small maintenance fee, and you pay on success. Orteig didn't pay a dime out to the nine teams that went across — tried to go across the Atlantic, and we didn't pay a dime until someone won the Ansari X PRIZE. So, prizes work great. You know, innovators, the entrepreneurs out there, you know that when you're going for a goal, the first thing you have to do is believe that you can do it yourself. Then, you've got to, you know, face potential public ridicule of — that's a crazy idea, it'll never work. And then you have to convince others, so that they can, in fact, help you raise the funds, and then you've got to deal with the fact that you've got government bureaucracies and institutions that don't want you to move those things forward, and you have to deal with failures. What a prize does, what we've experienced a prize doing, is literally help to short-circuit or support all of these things, because a prize credentials the idea that this is a good idea. Well, it must be a good idea. Someone's offering 10 million dollars to go and do this thing.And each of these areas was something that we found the Ansari X PRIZE helped short-circuit these for innovation. So, as an organization, we put together a prize discovery process of how to come up with prizes and write the rules, and we're actually looking at creating prizes in a number of different categories. We're looking at attacking energy, environment, nanotechnology — and I'll talk about those more in a moment. And the way we're doing that is we're creating prize teams within the X PRIZE. We have a space prize team. We're going after an orbital prize.We are looking at a number of energy prizes. Craig Venter has just joined our board and we're doing a rapid genome sequencing prize with him, we'll be announcing later this fall, about — imagine being able to sequence anybody's DNA for under 1,000 dollars, revolutionize medicine. And clean water, education, medicine and even looking at social entrepreneurship. So my final slide here is, the most critical tool for solving humanity's grand challenges — it isn't technology, it isn't money, it's only one thing — it's the committed, passionate human mind.(Applause)

And for me, this is -- I'm the short kid on the right.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:43.958
This was -- my motivation was actually during Apollo.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:45.958
And Apollo was one of the greatest motivators ever.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:51.958
If you think about what happened at the turn of -- early 1960s,

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:55.958
on May 25, JFK said, "We're going to go to the moon."

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
And people left their jobs and they went to obscure locations

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
to go and be part of this amazing mission.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
And we knew nothing about going to space.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
We went from having literally put Alan Shepard in suborbital flight

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
to going to the moon in eight years,

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:14.958
and the average age of the people that got us there was 26 years old.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:15.958
They didn't know what couldn't be done.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
They had to make up everything.

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
And that, my friend, is amazing motivation.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
This is Gene Cernan, a good friend of mine, saying,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:27.958
"If I can go to the moon" -- this is the last human on the moon so far --

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
"nothing, nothing is impossible." But of course,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:34.958
we've thought about the government always as the person taking us there.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:38.958
But I put forward here, the government is not going to get us there.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:43.958
The government is unable to take the risks required to open up this precious frontier.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
The shuttle is costing a billion dollars a launch.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
That's a pathetic number. It's unreasonable.

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.958
We shouldn't be happy in standing for that.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
One of the things that we did with the Ansari X PRIZE

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:57.958
was take the challenge on that risk is OK, you know.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
As we are going out there and taking on a new frontier,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
we should be allowed to risk.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
In fact, anyone who says we shouldn't, you know,

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:09.958
just needs to be put aside, because, as we go forward,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:13.958
in fact, the greatest discoveries we will ever know is ahead of us.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
The entrepreneurs in the space business are the furry mammals,

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
and clearly the industrial-military complex --

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:22.958
with Boeing and Lockheed and NASA -- are the dinosaurs.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
The ability for us to access these resources

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
to gain planetary redundancy --

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
we can now gather all the information, the genetic codes,

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
you know, everything stored on our databases,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
and back them up off the planet,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:38.958
in case there would be one of those disastrous situations.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:43.958
The difficulty is getting there, and clearly, the cost to orbit is key.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
Once you're in orbit, you are two thirds of the way, energetically, to anywhere --

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
the moon, to Mars. And today,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:53.958
there's only three vehicles -- the U.S. shuttle, the Russian Soyuz

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
and the Chinese vehicle -- that gets you there.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:05:00.958
Arguably, it's about 100 million dollars a person on the space shuttle.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
One of the companies I started, Space Adventures, will sell you a ticket.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:07.958
We've done two so far. We'll be announcing two more on the Soyuz

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
to go up to the space station for 20 million dollars.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:14.958
But that's expensive and to understand what the potential is --

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
(Laughter) --

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
it is expensive. But people are willing to pay that!

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
You know, one -- we have a very unique period in time today.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
For the first time ever, we have enough wealth

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
concentrated in the hands of few individuals

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
and the technology accessible

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:32.958
that will allow us to really drive space exploration.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:36.958
But how cheap could it get? I want to give you the end point.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
We know -- 20 million dollars today, you can go and buy a ticket,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
but how cheap could it get?

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:41.958
Let's go back to high school physics here.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:45.958
If you calculate the amount of potential energy, mgh,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
to take you and your spacesuit up to a couple hundred miles,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:52.958
and then you accelerate yourself to 17,500 miles per hour --

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:56.958
remember, that one half MV squared -- and you figure it out.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:06:00.958
It's about 5.7 gigajoules of energy.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:05.958
If you expended that over an hour, it's about 1.6 megawatts.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
If you go to one of Vijay's micro-power sources,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
and they sell it to you for seven cents a kilowatt hour --

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
anybody here fast in math?

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:16.958
How much will it cost you and your spacesuit to go to orbit?

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:20.958
100 bucks. That's the price-improvement curve that --

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
we need some breakthroughs in physics along the way,

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
I'll grant you that.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:26.958
(Laughter)

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:30.958
But guys, if history has taught us anything,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
it's that if you can imagine it, you will get there eventually.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
I have no question that the physics,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
the engineering to get us down to the point

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:43.958
where all of us can afford orbital space flight is around the corner.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:48.958
The difficulty is that there needs to be a real marketplace to drive the investment.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:52.958
Today, the Boeings and the Lockheeds don't spend a dollar

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
of their own money in R&D.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
It's all government research dollars, and very few of those.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
And in fact, the large corporations,

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
the governments, can't take the risk.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
So we need what I call an exothermic economic reaction in space.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:09.958
Today's commercial markets worldwide, global commercial launch market?

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
12 to 15 launches per year.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
Number of commercial companies out there? 12 to 15 companies.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:18.958
One per company. That's not it. There's only one marketplace,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
and I call them self-loading carbon payloads.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
They come with their own money. They're easy to make.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.958
It's people. The Ansari X PRIZE was my solution,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:32.958
reading about Lindbergh for creating the vehicles to get us there.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
We offered 10 million dollars in cash for the first reusable ship,

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
carry three people up to 100 kilometers,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
come back down, and within two weeks, make the trip again.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
Twenty-six teams from seven countries entered the competition,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
spending between one to 25 million dollars each.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
And of course, we had beautiful SpaceShipOne,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:53.958
which made those two flights and won the competition.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
And I'd like to take you there, to that morning,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
for just a quick video.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
(Video) Pilot: Release our fire.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:24.958
Richard Searfoss: Good luck.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:31.958
(Applause)

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:47.958
RS: We've got an altitude call of 368,000 feet.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:48.958
(Applause)

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
RS: So in my official capacity as the chief judge

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
of the Ansari X PRIZE competition,

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
I declare that Mojave Aerospace Ventures

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
has indeed earned the Ansari X PRIZE.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
(Applause)

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
Peter Diamandis: Probably the most difficult thing that I had to do

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
was raise the capital for this. It was literally impossible.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:11.958
We went -- I went to 100, 200 CEOs, CMOs.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
No one believed it was done. Everyone said, "Oh, what does NASA think?

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
Well, people are going to die,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
how can you possibly going to put this forward?"

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
I found a visionary family, the Ansari family, and Champ Car,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
and raised part of the money, but not the full 10 million.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:27.958
And what I ended up doing was going out to the insurance industry

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
and buying a hole-in-one insurance policy.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
See, the insurance companies went to Boeing and Lockheed,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
and said, "Are you going to compete?" No.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
"Are you going to compete?" No. "No one's going to win this thing."

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:40.958
So, they took a bet that no one would win by January of '05,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:44.958
and I took a bet that someone would win.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:45.958
(Applause)

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:51.958
So -- and the best thing is they paid off and the check didn't bounce.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:52.958
(Laughter)

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
We've had a lot of accomplishments

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
and it's been a tremendous success.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:02.958
One of the things I'm most happy about is that the SpaceShipOne

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
is going to hang in Air and Space Museum,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
next to the Spirit of St. Louis and the Wright Flyer.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:11.958
Isn't that great? (Applause)

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:15.958
So a little bit about the future, steps to space, what's available for you.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958
Today, you can go and experience weightless flights.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:23.958
By '08, suborbital flights, the price tag for that, you know, on Virgin,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
is going to be about 200,000.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
There are three or four other serious efforts that will bring the price down very rapidly,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
I think, to about 25,000 dollars for a suborbital flight.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
Orbital flights -- we can take you to the space station.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:38.958
And then I truly believe, once a group is in orbit around the Earth --

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
I know if they don't do it, I am --

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
we're going to stockpile some fuel,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
make a beeline for the moon and grab some real estate.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:46.958
(Laughter)

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
Quick moment for the designers in the audience.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:53.958
We spent 11 years getting FAA approval to do zero gravity flights.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
Here are some fun images. Here's Burt Rutan

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:59.958
and my good friend Greg Meronek inside a zero gravity --

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
people think a zero gravity room,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
there's a switch on there that turns it off --

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
but it's actually parabolic flight of an airplane.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:10.958
And turns out 7-Up has just done a little commercial that's airing this month.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
If we can get the audio up?

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:16.958
(Video) Narrator: For a chance to win the first free ticket to space,

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:20.958
look for specially marked packages of Diet 7-Up.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
When you want the taste that won't weigh you down,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
the only way to go is up.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:29.958
PD: That was filmed inside our airplane, and so, you can now do this.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
We're based down in Florida.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
Let me talk about the other thing I'm excited about.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:37.958
The future of prizes. You know, prizes are a very old idea.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
I had the pleasure of borrowing from the Longitude Prize

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
and the Orteig Prize that put Lindbergh forward.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
And we have made a decision in the X PRIZE Foundation

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:50.958
to actually carry that concept forward into other technology areas,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
and we just took on a new mission statement:

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
"to bring about radical breakthroughs in space

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
and other technologies for the benefit of humanity."

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
And this is something that we're very excited about.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
I showed this slide to Larry Page, who just joined our board.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
And you know, when you give to a nonprofit,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
you might have 50 cents on the dollar.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
If you have a matching grant, it's typically two or three to one.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:16.958
If you put up a prize, you can get literally a 50 to one leverage on your dollars.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
And that's huge. And then he turned around and said,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:22.958
"Well, if you back a prize institute that runs a 10 prize, you get 500 to one."

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
I said, "Well, that's great."

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
So, we have actually -- are looking to turn the X PRIZE

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
into a world-class prize institute.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
This is what happens when you put up a prize,

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:37.958
when you announce it and teams start to begin doing trials.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
You get publicity increase, and when it's won,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
publicity shoots through the roof -- if it's properly managed --

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:46.958
and that's part of the benefits to a sponsor.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Then, when the prize is actually won, after it's moving,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:54.958
you get societal benefits, you know, new technology, new capability.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
And the benefit to the sponsors

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
is the sum of the publicity and societal benefits over the long term.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
That's our value proposition in a prize.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
If you were going to go and try to create SpaceShipOne,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
or any kind of a new technology,

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
you have to fund that from the beginning

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
and maintain that funding with an uncertain outcome.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
It may or may not happen. But if you put up a prize,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
the beautiful thing is, you know, it's a very small maintenance fee,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
and you pay on success.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
Orteig didn't pay a dime out to the nine teams that went across --

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
tried to go across the Atlantic,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
and we didn't pay a dime until someone won the Ansari X PRIZE.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
So, prizes work great.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
You know, innovators, the entrepreneurs out there,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
you know that when you're going for a goal,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
the first thing you have to do is believe

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
that you can do it yourself.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
Then, you've got to, you know, face potential public ridicule

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
of -- that's a crazy idea, it'll never work.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
And then you have to convince others,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
so that they can, in fact, help you raise the funds,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
and then you've got to deal with the fact that you've got government bureaucracies

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
and institutions that don't want you to move those things forward,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
and you have to deal with failures. What a prize does,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
what we've experienced a prize doing,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:02.958
is literally help to short-circuit or support all of these things,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
because a prize credentials the idea that this is a good idea.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
Well, it must be a good idea.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
Someone's offering 10 million dollars to go and do this thing.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
And each of these areas was something that we found

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:17.958
the Ansari X PRIZE helped short-circuit these for innovation.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
So, as an organization, we put together a prize discovery process

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
of how to come up with prizes and write the rules,

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
and we're actually looking at creating prizes

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
in a number of different categories.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:33.958
We're looking at attacking energy, environment, nanotechnology --

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
and I'll talk about those more in a moment.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
And the way we're doing that is we're creating prize teams

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
within the X PRIZE. We have a space prize team.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
We're going after an orbital prize.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
We are looking at a number of energy prizes.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
Craig Venter has just joined our board

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
and we're doing a rapid genome sequencing prize with him,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
we'll be announcing later this fall,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:55.958
about -- imagine being able to sequence anybody's DNA

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
for under 1,000 dollars, revolutionize medicine.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:03.958
And clean water, education, medicine and even looking at social entrepreneurship.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
So my final slide here is, the most critical tool

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:10.958
for solving humanity's grand challenges -- it isn't technology,

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
it isn't money, it's only one thing --

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
it's the committed, passionate human mind.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:19.958
(Applause)

title: What we think we know
transcript: I'm going to try and explain why it is that perhaps we don't understand as much as we think we do. I'd like to begin with four questions. This is not some sort of cultural thing for the time of year. That's an in-joke, by the way. But these four questions, actually, are ones that people who even know quite a lot about science find quite hard. And they're questions that I've asked of science television producers, of audiences of science educators — so that's science teachers — and also of seven-year-olds, and I find that the seven-year-olds do marginally better than the other audiences, which is somewhat surprising.So the first question, and you might want to write this down, either on a bit of paper, physically, or a virtual piece of paper in your head. And, for viewers at home, you can try this as well. A little seed weighs next to nothing and a tree weighs a lot, right? I think we agree on that. Where does the tree get the stuff that makes up this chair, right? Where does all this stuff come from? (Knocks)And your next question is, can you light a little torch-bulb with a battery, a bulb and one piece of wire? And would you be able to, kind of, draw a — you don't have to draw the diagram, but would you be able to draw the diagram, if you had to do it? Or would you just say, that's actually not possible?The third question is, why is it hotter in summer than in winter? I think we can probably agree that it is hotter in summer than in winter, but why? And finally, would you be able to — and you can sort of scribble it, if you like — scribble a plan diagram of the solar system, showing the shape of the planets' orbits? Would you be able to do that? And if you can, just scribble a pattern.OK. Now, children get their ideas not from teachers, as teachers often think, but actually from common sense, from experience of the world around them, from all the things that go on between them and their peers, and their carers, and their parents, and all of that. Experience. And one of the great experts in this field, of course, was, bless him, Cardinal Wolsey. Be very careful what you get into people's heads because it's virtually impossible to shift it afterwards, right? (Laughter) I'm not quite sure how he died, actually. Was he beheaded in the end, or hung? (Laughter) Now, those questions, which, of course, you've got right, and you haven't been conferring, and so on.
