00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:17.958
If you ask people about what part of psychology do they think is hard,

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:20.958
and you say, "Well, what about thinking and emotions?"

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
Most people will say, "Emotions are terribly hard.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:29.958
They're incredibly complex. They can't -- I have no idea of how they work.

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
But thinking is really very straightforward:

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:35.958
it's just sort of some kind of logical reasoning, or something.

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:38.958
But that's not the hard part."

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.958
So here's a list of problems that come up.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:43.958
One nice problem is, what do we do about health?

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:47.958
The other day, I was reading something, and the person said

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:53.958
probably the largest single cause of disease is handshaking in the West.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:57.958
And there was a little study about people who don't handshake,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:00.958
and comparing them with ones who do handshake.

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:05.958
And I haven't the foggiest idea of where you find the ones that don't handshake,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
because they must be hiding.

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:12.958
And the people who avoid that

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:16.958
have 30 percent less infectious disease or something.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:19.958
Or maybe it was 31 and a quarter percent.

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:23.958
So if you really want to solve the problem of epidemics and so forth,

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:27.958
let's start with that. And since I got that idea,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:31.958
I've had to shake hundreds of hands.

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:36.958
And I think the only way to avoid it

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
is to have some horrible visible disease,

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
and then you don't have to explain.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:45.958
Education: how do we improve education?

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:49.958
Well, the single best way is to get them to understand

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
that what they're being told is a whole lot of nonsense.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
And then, of course, you have to do something

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:59.958
about how to moderate that, so that anybody can -- so they'll listen to you.

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:03.958
Pollution, energy shortage, environmental diversity, poverty.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:07.958
How do we make stable societies? Longevity.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:10.958
Okay, there're lots of problems to worry about.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.958
Anyway, the question I think people should talk about --

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:17.958
and it's absolutely taboo -- is, how many people should there be?

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:24.958
And I think it should be about 100 million or maybe 500 million.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:29.958
And then notice that a great many of these problems disappear.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
If you had 100 million people

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:37.958
properly spread out, then if there's some garbage,

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:44.958
you throw it away, preferably where you can't see it, and it will rot.

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:49.958
Or you throw it into the ocean and some fish will benefit from it.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
The problem is, how many people should there be?

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.958
And it's a sort of choice we have to make.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:57.958
Most people are about 60 inches high or more,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:01.958
and there's these cube laws. So if you make them this big,

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
by using nanotechnology, I suppose --

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:05.958
(Laughter)

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
-- then you could have a thousand times as many.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
That would solve the problem, but I don't see anybody

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:12.958
doing any research on making people smaller.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:17.958
Now, it's nice to reduce the population, but a lot of people want to have children.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
And there's one solution that's probably only a few years off.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:25.958
You know you have 46 chromosomes. If you're lucky, you've got 23

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:31.958
from each parent. Sometimes you get an extra one or drop one out,

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:35.958
but -- so you can skip the grandparent and great-grandparent stage

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:40.958
and go right to the great-great-grandparent. And you have 46 people

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
and you give them a scanner, or whatever you need,

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:47.958
and they look at their chromosomes and each of them says

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:52.958
which one he likes best, or she -- no reason to have just two sexes

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:57.958
any more, even. So each child has 46 parents,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:03.958
and I suppose you could let each group of 46 parents have 15 children.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
Wouldn't that be enough? And then the children

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:09.958
would get plenty of support, and nurturing, and mentoring,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
and the world population would decline very rapidly

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
and everybody would be totally happy.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
Timesharing is a little further off in the future.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
And there's this great novel that Arthur Clarke wrote twice,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:24.958
called "Against the Fall of Night" and "The City and the Stars."

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
They're both wonderful and largely the same,

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
except that computers happened in between.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:34.958
And Arthur was looking at this old book, and he said, "Well, that was wrong.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
The future must have some computers."

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:41.958
So in the second version of it, there are 100 billion

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:49.958
or 1,000 billion people on Earth, but they're all stored on hard disks or floppies,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
or whatever they have in the future.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:55.958
And you let a few million of them out at a time.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:59.958
A person comes out, they live for a thousand years

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:05.958
doing whatever they do, and then, when it's time to go back

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:09.958
for a billion years -- or a million, I forget, the numbers don't matter --

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:13.958
but there really aren't very many people on Earth at a time.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
And you get to think about yourself and your memories,

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:20.958
and before you go back into suspension, you edit your memories

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
and you change your personality and so forth.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:29.958
The plot of the book is that there's not enough diversity,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
so that the people who designed the city

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:36.958
make sure that every now and then an entirely new person is created.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:42.958
And in the novel, a particular one named Alvin is created. And he says,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:46.958
maybe this isn't the best way, and wrecks the whole system.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
I don't think the solutions that I proposed

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
are good enough or smart enough.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:55.958
I think the big problem is that we're not smart enough

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:59.958
to understand which of the problems we're facing are good enough.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:03.958
Therefore, we have to build super intelligent machines like HAL.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:08.958
As you remember, at some point in the book for "2001,"

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:13.958
HAL realizes that the universe is too big, and grand, and profound

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:17.958
for those really stupid astronauts. If you contrast HAL's behavior

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:21.958
with the triviality of the people on the spaceship,

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
you can see what's written between the lines.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
Well, what are we going to do about that? We could get smarter.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:32.958
I think that we're pretty smart, as compared to chimpanzees,

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:38.958
but we're not smart enough to deal with the colossal problems that we face,

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
either in abstract mathematics

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:45.958
or in figuring out economies, or balancing the world around.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
So one thing we can do is live longer.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
And nobody knows how hard that is,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
but we'll probably find out in a few years.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
You see, there's two forks in the road. We know that people live

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:00.958
twice as long as chimpanzees almost,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
and nobody lives more than 120 years,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
for reasons that aren't very well understood.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:14.958

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:19.958

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:24.958

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
So that's one way of going about it.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:35.958

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.958

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:18.958

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.958
So this is something that people will be discussing

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
(Laughter)

And it's very hard to find an ethicist who considers any change

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:46.958

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
And, of course, we're not responsible for the consequences

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:55.958

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
And yet two random people will mate and have this child,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:02.958
and both of them have some pretty rotten genes,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:06.958
and the child is likely to come out to be average.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:12.958

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
If we do have longevity, then we'll have to face the population growth

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:25.958

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:32.958
And one of the things Laurie Garrett pointed out, and others have,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:37.958

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:46.958

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:54.958

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:58.958

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
You know, there's about 400 different parts of the brain

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:33.958

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958

title: The psychology of evil
transcript: Philosophers, dramatists, theologians have grappled with this question for centuries: what makes people go wrong? Interestingly, I asked this question when I was a little kid. I grew up in the South Bronx, inner-city ghetto in New York, and I was surrounded by evil, as all kids are who grew up in an inner city. And I had friends who were really good kids, who lived out the Dr. Jekyll Mr. Hyde scenario — Robert Louis Stevenson. That is, they took drugs, got in trouble, went to jail. Some got killed, and some did it without drug assistance.So when I read Robert Louis Stevenson, that wasn't fiction. The only question is, what was in the juice? And more importantly, that line between good and evil — which privileged people like to think is fixed and impermeable, with them on the good side, the others on the bad side — I knew that line was movable, and it was permeable. Good people could be seduced across that line, and under good and some rare circumstances, bad kids could recover with help, with reform, with rehabilitation.So I want to begin with this wonderful illusion by [Dutch] artist M.C. Escher. If you look at it and focus on the white, what you see is a world full of angels. But let's look more deeply, and as we do, what appears is the demons, the devils in the world. That tells us several things.One, the world is, was, will always be filled with good and evil, because good and evil is the yin and yang of the human condition. It tells me something else. If you remember, God's favorite angel was Lucifer. Apparently, Lucifer means "the light." It also means "the morning star," in some scripture. And apparently, he disobeyed God, and that's the ultimate disobedience to authority. And when he did, Michael, the archangel, was sent to kick him out of heaven along with the other fallen angels. And so Lucifer descends into hell, becomes Satan, becomes the devil, and the force of evil in the universe begins.Paradoxically, it was God who created hell as a place to store evil. He didn't do a good job of keeping it there though. So, this arc of the cosmic transformation of God's favorite angel into the Devil, for me, sets the context for understanding human beings who are transformed from good, ordinary people into perpetrators of evil.So the Lucifer effect, although it focuses on the negatives — the negatives that people can become, not the negatives that people are — leads me to a psychological definition. Evil is the exercise of power. And that's the key: it's about power. To intentionally harm people psychologically, to hurt people physically, to destroy people mortally, or ideas, and to commit crimes against humanity. If you Google "evil," a word that should surely have withered by now, you come up with 136 million hits in a third of a second.A few years ago — I am sure all of you were shocked, as I was, with the revelation of American soldiers abusing prisoners in a strange place in a controversial war, Abu Ghraib in Iraq. And these were men and women who were putting prisoners through unbelievable humiliation. I was shocked, but I wasn't surprised, because I had seen those same visual parallels when I was the prison superintendent of the Stanford Prison Study.Immediately the Bush administration military said what? What all administrations say when there's a scandal: "Don't blame us. It's not the system. It's the few bad apples, the few rogue soldiers." My hypothesis is, American soldiers are good, usually. Maybe it was the barrel that was bad. But how am I going to deal with that hypothesis?I became an expert witness for one of the guards, Sergeant Chip Frederick, and in that position, I had access to the dozen investigative reports. I had access to him. I could study him, have him come to my home, get to know him, do psychological analysis to see, was he a good apple or bad apple. And thirdly, I had access to all of the 1,000 pictures that these soldiers took. These pictures are of a violent or sexual nature. All of them come from the cameras of American soldiers. Because everybody has a digital camera or cell phone camera, they took pictures of everything, more than 1,000.And what I've done is I organized them into various categories. But these are by United States military police, army reservists. They are not soldiers prepared for this mission at all. And it all happened in a single place, Tier 1-A, on the night shift. Why? Tier 1-A was the center for military intelligence. It was the interrogation hold. The CIA was there. Interrogators from Titan Corporation, all there, and they're getting no information about the insurgency. So they're going to put pressure on these soldiers, military police, to cross the line, give them permission to break the will of the enemy, to prepare them for interrogation, to soften them up, to take the gloves off. Those are the euphemisms, and this is how it was interpreted. Let's go down to that dungeon.(Typewriting)[Abu Ghraib Iraq Prison Abuses 2008 Military Police Guards' Photos][The following images include nudity and graphic depictions of violence](Camera shutter sounds)(Thuds)(Camera shutter)(Camera shutter)(Breathing)(Bells)(Bells end)So, pretty horrific. That's one of the visual illustrations of evil. And it should not have escaped you that the reason I paired the prisoner with his arms out with Leonardo da Vinci's ode to humanity is that that prisoner was mentally ill. That prisoner covered himself with shit every day, they had to roll him in dirt so he wouldn't stink. But the guards ended up calling him "Shit Boy." What was he doing in that prison rather than in some mental institution?In any event, here's former Secretary of Defense Rumsfeld. He comes down and says, "I want to know, who is responsible? Who are the bad apples?" Well, that's a bad question. You have to reframe it and ask, "What is responsible?" "What" could be the who of people, but it could also be the what of the situation, and obviously that's wrongheaded.How do psychologists try to understand such transformations of human character, if you believe that they were good soldiers before they went down to that dungeon? There are three ways. The main way is called dispositional. We look at what's inside of the person, the bad apples.This is the foundation of all of social science, the foundation of religion, the foundation of war. Social psychologists like me come along and say, "Yeah, people are the actors on the stage, but you'll have to be aware of the situation. Who are the cast of characters? What's the costume? Is there a stage director?" And so we're interested in what are the external factors around the individual — the bad barrel? Social scientists stop there and they miss the big point that I discovered when I became an expert witness for Abu Ghraib. The power is in the system. The system creates the situation that corrupts the individuals, and the system is the legal, political, economic, cultural background. And this is where the power is of the bad-barrel makers.If you want to change a person, change the situation. And to change it, you've got to know where the power is, in the system. So the Lucifer effect involves understanding human character transformations with these three factors. And it's a dynamic interplay. What do the people bring into the situation? What does the situation bring out of them? And what is the system that creates and maintains that situation?My recent book, "The Lucifer Effect," is about, how do you understand how good people turn evil? And it has a lot of detail about what I'm going to talk about today. So Dr. Z's "Lucifer Effect," although it focuses on evil, really is a celebration of the human mind's infinite capacity to make any of us kind or cruel, caring or indifferent, creative or destructive, and it makes some of us villains. And the good news that I'm going to hopefully come to at the end is that it makes some of us heroes. This wonderful cartoon in the New Yorker summarizes my whole talk: "I'm neither a good cop nor a bad cop, Jerome. Like yourself, I'm a complex amalgam of positive and negative personality traits that emerge or not, depending on the circumstances."(Laughter)There's a study some of you think you know about, but very few people have ever read the story. You watched the movie. This is Stanley Milgram, little Jewish kid from the Bronx, and he asked the question, "Could the Holocaust happen here, now?" People say, "No, that's Nazi Germany, Hitler, you know, that's 1939." He said, "Yeah, but suppose Hitler asked you, 'Would you electrocute a stranger?' 'No way, I'm a good person.'" He said, "Why don't we put you in a situation and give you a chance to see what you would do?"And so what he did was he tested 1,000 ordinary people. 500 New Haven, Connecticut, 500 Bridgeport. And the ad said, "Psychologists want to understand memory. We want to improve people's memory, because it is the key to success." OK? "We're going to give you five bucks — four dollars for your time. We don't want college students. We want men between 20 and 50." In the later studies, they ran women. Ordinary people: barbers, clerks, white-collar people.So, you go down, one of you will be a learner, one will be a teacher. The learner's a genial, middle-aged guy. He gets tied up to the shock apparatus in another room. The learner could be middle-aged, could be as young as 20. And one of you is told by the authority, the guy in the lab coat, "Your job as teacher is to give him material to learn. Gets it right, reward. Gets it wrong, you press a button on the shock box. The first button is 15 volts. He doesn't even feel it." That's the key. All evil starts with 15 volts. And then the next step is another 15 volts. The problem is, at the end of the line, it's 450 volts. And as you go along, the guy is screaming, "I've got a heart condition! I'm out of here!"You're a good person. You complain. "Sir, who will be responsible if something happens to him?" The experimenter says, "Don't worry, I will be responsible. Continue, teacher." And the question is, who would go all the way to 450 volts? You should notice here, when it gets up to 375, it says, "Danger. Severe Shock." When it gets up to here, there's "XXX" — the pornography of power.So Milgram asks 40 psychiatrists, "What percent of American citizens would go to the end?" They said only one percent. Because that's sadistic behavior, and we know, psychiatry knows, only one percent of Americans are sadistic. OK. Here's the data. They could not be more wrong. Two thirds go all the way to 450 volts. This was just one study. Milgram did more than 16 studies. And look at this. In study 16, where you see somebody like you go all the way, 90 percent go all the way. In study five, if you see people rebel, 90 percent rebel. What about women? Study 13 — no different than men. So Milgram is quantifying evil as the willingness of people to blindly obey authority, to go all the way to 450 volts. And it's like a dial on human nature. A dial in a sense that you can make almost everybody totally obedient, down to the majority, down to none.What are the external parallels? For all research is artificial. What's the validity in the real world? 912 American citizens committed suicide or were murdered by family and friends in Guyana jungle in 1978, because they were blindly obedient to this guy, their pastor — not their priest — their pastor, Reverend Jim Jones. He persuaded them to commit mass suicide. And so, he's the modern Lucifer effect, a man of God who becomes the Angel of Death. Milgram's study is all about individual authority to control people. Most of the time, we are in institutions, so the Stanford Prison Study is a study of the power of institutions to influence individual behavior. Interestingly, Stanley Milgram and I were in the same high school class in James Monroe in the Bronx, 1954.I did this study with my graduate students, especially Craig Haney — and it also began work with an ad. We had a cheap, little ad, but we wanted college students for a study of prison life. 75 people volunteered, took personality tests. We did interviews. Picked two dozen: the most normal, the most healthy. Randomly assigned them to be prisoner and guard. So on day one, we knew we had good apples. I'm going to put them in a bad situation.And secondly, we know there's no difference between the boys who will be guards and those who will be prisoners. To the prisoners, we said, "Wait at home. The study will begin Sunday." We didn't tell them that the city police were going to come and do realistic arrests.(Video) (Music)[Day 1]Student: A police car pulls up in front, and a cop comes to the front door, and knocks, and says he's looking for me. So they, right there, you know, they took me out the door, they put my hands against the car. It was a real cop car, it was a real policeman, and there were real neighbors in the street, who didn't know that this was an experiment. And there was cameras all around and neighbors all around. They put me in the car, then they drove me around Palo Alto. They took me to the basement of the police station. Then they put me in a cell. I was the first one to be picked up, so they put me in a cell, which was just like a room with a door with bars on it. You could tell it wasn't a real jail. They locked me in there, in this degrading little outfit. They were taking this experiment too seriously.Here are the prisoners, who are going to be dehumanized, they'll become numbers. Here are the guards with the symbols of power and anonymity. Guards get prisoners to clean the toilet bowls out with their bare hands, to do other humiliating tasks. They strip them naked. They sexually taunt them. They begin to do degrading activities, like having them simulate sodomy. You saw simulating fellatio in soldiers in Abu Ghraib. My guards did it in five days. The stress reaction was so extreme that normal kids we picked because they were healthy had breakdowns within 36 hours. The study ended after six days, because it was out of control. Five kids had emotional breakdowns.Does it make a difference if warriors go to battle changing their appearance or not? If they're anonymous, how do they treat their victims? In some cultures, they go to war without changing their appearance. In others, they paint themselves like "Lord of the Flies." In some, they wear masks. In many, soldiers are anonymous in uniform. So this anthropologist, John Watson, found 23 cultures that had two bits of data. Do they change their appearance? 15. Do they kill, torture, mutilate? 13. If they don't change their appearance, only one of eight kills, tortures or mutilates. The key is in the red zone. If they change their appearance, 12 of 13 — that's 90 percent — kill, torture, mutilate. And that's the power of anonymity.So what are the seven social processes that grease the slippery slope of evil? Mindlessly taking the first small step. Dehumanization of others. De-individuation of self. Diffusion of personal responsibility. Blind obedience to authority. Uncritical conformity to group norms. Passive tolerance of evil through inaction, or indifference.And it happens when you're in a new or unfamiliar situation. Your habitual response patterns don't work. Your personality and morality are disengaged. "Nothing is easier than to denounce the evildoer; nothing more difficult than understanding him," Dostoyevsky. Understanding is not excusing. Psychology is not excuse-ology.So social and psychological research reveals how ordinary, good people can be transformed without the drugs. You don't need it. You just need the social-psychological processes. Real world parallels? Compare this with this. James Schlesinger — I'm going to end with this — says, "Psychologists have attempted to understand how and why individuals and groups who usually act humanely can sometimes act otherwise in certain circumstances." That's the Lucifer effect. And he goes on to say, "The landmark Stanford study provides a cautionary tale for all military operations." If you give people power without oversight, it's a prescription for abuse. They knew that, and let that happen.So another report, an investigative report by General Fay, says the system is guilty. In this report, he says it was the environment that created Abu Ghraib, by leadership failures that contributed to the occurrence of such abuse, and because it remained undiscovered by higher authorities for a long period of time. Those abuses went on for three months. Who was watching the store? The answer is nobody, I think on purpose. He gave the guards permission to do those things, and they knew nobody was ever going to come down to that dungeon.So you need a paradigm shift in all of these areas. The shift is away from the medical model that focuses only on the individual. The shift is toward a public health model that recognizes situational and systemic vectors of disease. Bullying is a disease. Prejudice is a disease. Violence is a disease. Since the Inquisition, we've been dealing with problems at the individual level. It doesn't work. Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn says, "The line between good and evil cuts through the heart of every human being." That means that line is not out there. That's a decision that you have to make, a personal thing.So I want to end very quickly on a positive note. Heroism as the antidote to evil, by promoting the heroic imagination, especially in our kids, in our educational system. We want kids to think, "I'm a hero in waiting, waiting for the right situation to come along, and I will act heroically. My whole life, I'm now going to focus away from evil — that I've been in since I was a kid — to understanding heroes.Banality of heroism. It's ordinary people who do heroic deeds. It's the counterpoint to Hannah Arendt's "Banality of Evil." Our traditional societal heroes are wrong, because they are the exceptions. They organize their life around this. That's why we know their names. Our kids' heroes are also wrong models for them, because they have supernatural talents. We want our kids to realize most heroes are everyday people, and the heroic act is unusual. This is Joe Darby. He was the one that stopped those abuses you saw, because when he saw those images, he turned them over to a senior investigating officer. He was a low-level private, and that stopped it. Was he a hero? No. They had to put him in hiding, because people wanted to kill him, and then his mother and his wife. For three years, they were in hiding.This is the woman who stopped the Stanford Prison Study. When I said it got out of control, I was the prison superintendent. I didn't know it was out of control. I was totally indifferent. She saw that madhouse and said, "You know what, it's terrible what you're doing to those boys. They're not prisoners nor guards, they're boys, and you are responsible." And I ended the study the next day. The good news is I married her the next year.(Laughter)(Applause)I just came to my senses, obviously.So situations have the power to do [three things]. But the point is, this is the same situation that can inflame the hostile imagination in some of us, that makes us perpetrators of evil, can inspire the heroic imagination in others. It's the same situation and you're on one side or the other. Most people are guilty of the evil of inaction, because your mother said, "Don't get involved. Mind your own business." And you have to say, "Mama, humanity is my business."So the psychology of heroism is — we're going to end in a moment — how do we encourage children in new hero courses, that I'm working on with Matt Langdon — he has a hero workshop — to develop this heroic imagination, this self-labeling, "I am a hero in waiting," and teach them skills. To be a hero, you have to learn to be a deviant, because you're always going against the conformity of the group. Heroes are ordinary people whose social actions are extraordinary. Who act.The key to heroism is two things. You have to act when other people are passive. B: You have to act socio-centrically, not egocentrically. And I want to end with a known story about Wesley Autrey, New York subway hero. Fifty-year-old African-American construction worker standing on a subway. A white guy falls on the tracks. The subway train is coming. There's 75 people there. You know what? They freeze. He's got a reason not to get involved. He's black, the guy's white, and he's got two kids. Instead, he gives his kids to a stranger, jumps on the tracks, puts the guy between the tracks, lays on him, the subway goes over him. Wesley and the guy — 20 and a half inches height. The train clearance is 21 inches. A half an inch would have taken his head off. And he said, "I did what anyone could do," no big deal to jump on the tracks.And the moral imperative is "I did what everyone should do." And so one day, you will be in a new situation. Take path one, you're going to be a perpetrator of evil. Evil, meaning you're going to be Arthur Andersen. You're going to cheat, or you're going to allow bullying. Path two, you become guilty of the evil of passive inaction. Path three, you become a hero. The point is, are we ready to take the path to celebrating ordinary heroes, waiting for the right situation to come along to put heroic imagination into action? Because it may only happen once in your life, and when you pass it by, you'll always know, I could have been a hero and I let it pass me by. So the point is thinking it and then doing it.So I want to thank you. Thank you. Let's oppose the power of evil systems at home and abroad, and let's focus on the positive. Advocate for respect of personal dignity, for justice and peace, which sadly our administration has not been doing.Thanks so much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.592 --> 00:00:16.148
Philosophers, dramatists, theologians

00:00:16.172 --> 00:00:18.378
have grappled with
this question for centuries:

00:00:18.402 --> 00:00:19.934
what makes people go wrong?

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.934
Interestingly, I asked this question
when I was a little kid.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:26.014
I grew up in the South Bronx,
inner-city ghetto in New York,

00:00:26.038 --> 00:00:27.521
and I was surrounded by evil,

00:00:27.545 --> 00:00:30.101
as all kids are who grew up
in an inner city.

00:00:30.125 --> 00:00:32.450
And I had friends
who were really good kids,

00:00:32.474 --> 00:00:36.766
who lived out the Dr. Jekyll Mr. Hyde
scenario -- Robert Louis Stevenson.

00:00:36.790 --> 00:00:39.934
That is, they took drugs,
got in trouble, went to jail.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:43.817
Some got killed, and some did it
without drug assistance.

00:00:44.246 --> 00:00:47.040
So when I read Robert Louis Stevenson,
that wasn't fiction.

00:00:47.064 --> 00:00:49.288
The only question is,
what was in the juice?

00:00:49.312 --> 00:00:52.934
And more importantly, that line
between good and evil --

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:56.426
which privileged people like to think
is fixed and impermeable,

00:00:56.450 --> 00:00:59.123
with them on the good side,
the others on the bad side --

00:00:59.147 --> 00:01:02.210
I knew that line was movable,
and it was permeable.

00:01:02.234 --> 00:01:04.577
Good people could be
seduced across that line,

00:01:04.601 --> 00:01:08.805
and under good and some rare
circumstances, bad kids could recover

00:01:08.829 --> 00:01:11.125
with help, with reform,
with rehabilitation.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.435
So I want to begin
with this wonderful illusion

00:01:14.459 --> 00:01:16.733
by [Dutch] artist M.C. Escher.

00:01:16.757 --> 00:01:20.618
If you look at it and focus on the white,
what you see is a world full of angels.

00:01:20.642 --> 00:01:23.210
But let's look more deeply, and as we do,

00:01:23.234 --> 00:01:26.255
what appears is the demons,
the devils in the world.

00:01:26.790 --> 00:01:28.171
That tells us several things.

00:01:28.195 --> 00:01:31.303
One, the world is, was, will always
be filled with good and evil,

00:01:31.327 --> 00:01:34.375
because good and evil is the yin and yang
of the human condition.

00:01:34.399 --> 00:01:35.685
It tells me something else.

00:01:35.709 --> 00:01:38.737
If you remember,
God's favorite angel was Lucifer.

00:01:39.247 --> 00:01:41.685
Apparently, Lucifer means "the light."

00:01:41.709 --> 00:01:44.435
It also means "the morning star,"
in some scripture.

00:01:44.459 --> 00:01:47.664
And apparently, he disobeyed God,

00:01:47.688 --> 00:01:50.180
and that's the ultimate
disobedience to authority.

00:01:50.204 --> 00:01:55.702
And when he did, Michael, the archangel,
was sent to kick him out of heaven

00:01:55.726 --> 00:01:57.729
along with the other fallen angels.

00:01:57.753 --> 00:02:00.934
And so Lucifer descends into hell,
becomes Satan,

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
becomes the devil, and the force
of evil in the universe begins.

00:02:03.982 --> 00:02:08.451
Paradoxically, it was God
who created hell as a place to store evil.

00:02:08.934 --> 00:02:11.315
He didn't do a good job
of keeping it there though.

00:02:11.339 --> 00:02:15.928
So, this arc of the cosmic transformation
of God's favorite angel into the Devil,

00:02:15.952 --> 00:02:19.596
for me, sets the context
for understanding human beings

00:02:19.620 --> 00:02:23.934
who are transformed from good,
ordinary people into perpetrators of evil.

00:02:24.535 --> 00:02:28.562
So the Lucifer effect,
although it focuses on the negatives --

00:02:28.586 --> 00:02:31.241
the negatives that people can become,

00:02:31.265 --> 00:02:33.227
not the negatives that people are --

00:02:33.251 --> 00:02:36.605
leads me to a psychological definition.

00:02:36.629 --> 00:02:38.602
Evil is the exercise of power.

00:02:38.626 --> 00:02:40.865
And that's the key: it's about power.

00:02:40.889 --> 00:02:43.454
To intentionally harm
people psychologically,

00:02:43.478 --> 00:02:47.208
to hurt people physically,
to destroy people mortally, or ideas,

00:02:47.232 --> 00:02:49.426
and to commit crimes against humanity.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:54.244
If you Google "evil," a word that should
surely have withered by now,

00:02:54.268 --> 00:02:57.934
you come up with 136 million hits
in a third of a second.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:02.456
A few years ago -- I am sure
all of you were shocked, as I was,

00:03:02.480 --> 00:03:07.934
with the revelation of American soldiers
abusing prisoners in a strange place

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.934
in a controversial war,
Abu Ghraib in Iraq.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.965
And these were men and women

00:03:12.989 --> 00:03:17.276
who were putting prisoners
through unbelievable humiliation.

00:03:17.934 --> 00:03:19.744
I was shocked, but I wasn't surprised,

00:03:19.768 --> 00:03:21.934
because I had seen
those same visual parallels

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:25.360
when I was the prison superintendent
of the Stanford Prison Study.

00:03:25.384 --> 00:03:28.099
Immediately the Bush
administration military said what?

00:03:28.479 --> 00:03:30.979
What all administrations say
when there's a scandal:

00:03:31.003 --> 00:03:32.853
"Don't blame us. It's not the system.

00:03:32.877 --> 00:03:35.277
It's the few bad apples,
the few rogue soldiers."

00:03:35.301 --> 00:03:38.332
My hypothesis is,
American soldiers are good, usually.

00:03:38.356 --> 00:03:40.417
Maybe it was the barrel that was bad.

00:03:40.441 --> 00:03:42.934
But how am I going to deal
with that hypothesis?

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.478
I became an expert witness
for one of the guards,

00:03:45.502 --> 00:03:47.645
Sergeant Chip Frederick,
and in that position,

00:03:47.669 --> 00:03:50.582
I had access to the dozen
investigative reports.

00:03:50.606 --> 00:03:52.406
I had access to him.

00:03:52.430 --> 00:03:55.731
I could study him, have him come
to my home, get to know him,

00:03:55.755 --> 00:03:59.162
do psychological analysis to see,
was he a good apple or bad apple.

00:03:59.186 --> 00:04:03.097
And thirdly, I had access
to all of the 1,000 pictures

00:04:03.121 --> 00:04:04.334
that these soldiers took.

00:04:04.823 --> 00:04:07.333
These pictures are
of a violent or sexual nature.

00:04:07.357 --> 00:04:10.316
All of them come from the cameras
of American soldiers.

00:04:10.767 --> 00:04:13.626
Because everybody has
a digital camera or cell phone camera,

00:04:13.650 --> 00:04:15.984
they took pictures of everything,
more than 1,000.

00:04:16.008 --> 00:04:18.962
And what I've done is I organized them
into various categories.

00:04:18.986 --> 00:04:23.925
But these are by United States
military police, army reservists.

00:04:24.435 --> 00:04:27.917
They are not soldiers prepared
for this mission at all.

00:04:27.941 --> 00:04:31.614
And it all happened in a single place,
Tier 1-A, on the night shift.

00:04:31.638 --> 00:04:32.839
Why?

00:04:32.863 --> 00:04:35.465
Tier 1-A was the center
for military intelligence.

00:04:35.489 --> 00:04:37.465
It was the interrogation hold.

00:04:37.489 --> 00:04:38.690
The CIA was there.

00:04:38.714 --> 00:04:41.872
Interrogators from
Titan Corporation, all there,

00:04:41.896 --> 00:04:44.682
and they're getting no information
about the insurgency.

00:04:44.706 --> 00:04:47.176
So they're going to put pressure
on these soldiers,

00:04:47.200 --> 00:04:48.920
military police, to cross the line,

00:04:48.944 --> 00:04:51.934
give them permission to break
the will of the enemy,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.435
to prepare them for interrogation,
to soften them up,

00:04:54.459 --> 00:04:55.685
to take the gloves off.

00:04:55.709 --> 00:04:58.837
Those are the euphemisms,
and this is how it was interpreted.

00:04:59.592 --> 00:05:01.362
Let's go down to that dungeon.

00:05:03.243 --> 00:05:04.552
(Typewriting)

00:05:05.037 --> 00:05:10.585
[Abu Ghraib Iraq Prison Abuses 2008
Military Police Guards' Photos]

00:05:11.046 --> 00:05:17.403
[The following images include nudity
and graphic depictions of violence]

00:05:18.136 --> 00:05:19.269
(Camera shutter sounds)

00:05:38.971 --> 00:05:40.170
(Thuds)

00:05:45.519 --> 00:05:46.578
(Camera shutter)

00:05:59.314 --> 00:06:00.504
(Camera shutter)

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:12.627
(Breathing)

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.752
(Bells)

00:06:47.017 --> 00:06:48.383
(Bells end)

00:06:49.037 --> 00:06:50.823
So, pretty horrific.

00:06:51.299 --> 00:06:55.106
That's one of the visual
illustrations of evil.

00:06:55.130 --> 00:06:56.891
And it should not have escaped you

00:06:56.915 --> 00:07:00.152
that the reason I paired
the prisoner with his arms out

00:07:00.176 --> 00:07:02.934
with Leonardo da Vinci's ode to humanity

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.540
is that that prisoner was mentally ill.

00:07:05.564 --> 00:07:07.917
That prisoner covered himself
with shit every day,

00:07:07.941 --> 00:07:10.359
they had to roll him in dirt
so he wouldn't stink.

00:07:10.383 --> 00:07:12.731
But the guards ended up
calling him "Shit Boy."

00:07:12.755 --> 00:07:16.934
What was he doing in that prison
rather than in some mental institution?

00:07:17.455 --> 00:07:20.170
In any event, here's former
Secretary of Defense Rumsfeld.

00:07:20.194 --> 00:07:23.004
He comes down and says,
"I want to know, who is responsible?

00:07:23.028 --> 00:07:24.407
Who are the bad apples?"

00:07:24.431 --> 00:07:25.839
Well, that's a bad question.

00:07:25.863 --> 00:07:28.484
You have to reframe it and ask,
"What is responsible?"

00:07:28.508 --> 00:07:30.156
"What" could be the who of people,

00:07:30.180 --> 00:07:32.717
but it could also be
the what of the situation,

00:07:32.741 --> 00:07:34.427
and obviously that's wrongheaded.

00:07:34.451 --> 00:07:38.296
How do psychologists try to understand
such transformations of human character,

00:07:38.320 --> 00:07:40.320
if you believe
that they were good soldiers

00:07:40.344 --> 00:07:42.154
before they went down to that dungeon?

00:07:42.178 --> 00:07:45.040
There are three ways.
The main way is called dispositional.

00:07:45.064 --> 00:07:47.934
We look at what's inside
of the person, the bad apples.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:51.269
This is the foundation
of all of social science,

00:07:51.293 --> 00:07:53.953
the foundation of religion,
the foundation of war.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.197
Social psychologists like me
come along and say,

00:07:57.221 --> 00:07:59.340
"Yeah, people are the actors on the stage,

00:07:59.364 --> 00:08:01.714
but you'll have to be aware
of the situation.

00:08:01.738 --> 00:08:04.119
Who are the cast of characters?
What's the costume?

00:08:04.143 --> 00:08:05.602
Is there a stage director?"

00:08:05.626 --> 00:08:08.293
And so we're interested in
what are the external factors

00:08:08.317 --> 00:08:10.293
around the individual -- the bad barrel?

00:08:10.862 --> 00:08:13.509
Social scientists stop there
and they miss the big point

00:08:13.533 --> 00:08:16.772
that I discovered when I became
an expert witness for Abu Ghraib.

00:08:16.796 --> 00:08:18.347
The power is in the system.

00:08:18.371 --> 00:08:21.612
The system creates the situation
that corrupts the individuals,

00:08:21.636 --> 00:08:26.420
and the system is the legal, political,
economic, cultural background.

00:08:26.444 --> 00:08:29.738
And this is where the power
is of the bad-barrel makers.

00:08:30.097 --> 00:08:32.598
If you want to change a person,
change the situation.

00:08:32.622 --> 00:08:36.011
And to change it, you've got to know
where the power is, in the system.

00:08:36.035 --> 00:08:38.083
So the Lucifer effect
involves understanding

00:08:38.107 --> 00:08:42.562
human character transformations
with these three factors.

00:08:43.082 --> 00:08:44.471
And it's a dynamic interplay.

00:08:44.495 --> 00:08:46.561
What do the people bring
into the situation?

00:08:46.585 --> 00:08:48.593
What does the situation bring out of them?

00:08:48.617 --> 00:08:51.934
And what is the system
that creates and maintains that situation?

00:08:52.582 --> 00:08:54.866
My recent book,
"The Lucifer Effect," is about,

00:08:54.890 --> 00:08:57.129
how do you understand
how good people turn evil?

00:08:57.153 --> 00:09:00.416
And it has a lot of detail
about what I'm going to talk about today.

00:09:00.854 --> 00:09:03.934
So Dr. Z's "Lucifer Effect,"
although it focuses on evil,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:08.118
really is a celebration of the human
mind's infinite capacity

00:09:08.142 --> 00:09:10.700
to make any of us kind or cruel,

00:09:10.724 --> 00:09:13.246
caring or indifferent,
creative or destructive,

00:09:13.270 --> 00:09:15.548
and it makes some of us villains.

00:09:15.572 --> 00:09:18.669
And the good news that I'm going
to hopefully come to at the end

00:09:18.693 --> 00:09:20.460
is that it makes some of us heroes.

00:09:21.609 --> 00:09:25.158
This wonderful cartoon in the New Yorker
summarizes my whole talk:

00:09:25.182 --> 00:09:27.325
"I'm neither a good cop
nor a bad cop, Jerome.

00:09:27.349 --> 00:09:29.308
Like yourself, I'm a complex amalgam

00:09:29.332 --> 00:09:31.801
of positive and negative
personality traits

00:09:31.825 --> 00:09:35.315
that emerge or not, depending
on the circumstances."

00:09:35.339 --> 00:09:37.324
(Laughter)

00:09:37.348 --> 00:09:40.200
There's a study some of you
think you know about,

00:09:40.224 --> 00:09:42.411
but very few people
have ever read the story.

00:09:42.435 --> 00:09:44.360
You watched the movie.

00:09:44.384 --> 00:09:47.733
This is Stanley Milgram,
little Jewish kid from the Bronx,

00:09:47.757 --> 00:09:50.856
and he asked the question,
"Could the Holocaust happen here, now?"

00:09:50.880 --> 00:09:54.385
People say, "No, that's Nazi Germany,
Hitler, you know, that's 1939."

00:09:54.409 --> 00:09:56.802
He said, "Yeah, but suppose
Hitler asked you,

00:09:56.826 --> 00:09:59.996
'Would you electrocute a stranger?'
'No way, I'm a good person.'"

00:10:00.020 --> 00:10:02.116
He said, "Why don't
we put you in a situation

00:10:02.140 --> 00:10:04.379
and give you a chance
to see what you would do?"

00:10:04.403 --> 00:10:07.488
And so what he did was he tested
1,000 ordinary people.

00:10:07.512 --> 00:10:11.579
500 New Haven, Connecticut,
500 Bridgeport.

00:10:11.603 --> 00:10:14.318
And the ad said, "Psychologists
want to understand memory.

00:10:14.342 --> 00:10:17.636
We want to improve people's memory,
because it is the key to success."

00:10:17.660 --> 00:10:18.860
OK?

00:10:19.862 --> 00:10:23.847
"We're going to give you five bucks --
four dollars for your time.

00:10:23.871 --> 00:10:27.325
We don't want college students.
We want men between 20 and 50."

00:10:27.349 --> 00:10:29.111
In the later studies, they ran women.

00:10:29.135 --> 00:10:32.208
Ordinary people: barbers,
clerks, white-collar people.

00:10:32.232 --> 00:10:33.812
So, you go down,

00:10:33.836 --> 00:10:36.347
one of you will be a learner,
one will be a teacher.

00:10:36.371 --> 00:10:38.276
The learner's a genial, middle-aged guy.

00:10:38.300 --> 00:10:41.409
He gets tied up to the shock
apparatus in another room.

00:10:41.433 --> 00:10:45.001
The learner could be middle-aged,
could be as young as 20.

00:10:45.025 --> 00:10:48.241
And one of you is told by the authority,
the guy in the lab coat,

00:10:48.265 --> 00:10:50.880
"Your job as teacher is to give him
material to learn.

00:10:50.904 --> 00:10:52.118
Gets it right, reward.

00:10:52.142 --> 00:10:54.533
Gets it wrong, you press
a button on the shock box.

00:10:54.557 --> 00:10:57.411
The first button is 15 volts.
He doesn't even feel it."

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.121
That's the key.

00:10:59.145 --> 00:11:00.934
All evil starts with 15 volts.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.369
And then the next step
is another 15 volts.

00:11:03.807 --> 00:11:06.804
The problem is, at the end
of the line, it's 450 volts.

00:11:06.828 --> 00:11:08.934
And as you go along, the guy is screaming,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.149
"I've got a heart condition!
I'm out of here!"

00:11:11.173 --> 00:11:12.879
You're a good person. You complain.

00:11:12.903 --> 00:11:15.759
"Sir, who will be responsible
if something happens to him?"

00:11:15.783 --> 00:11:18.546
The experimenter says,
"Don't worry, I will be responsible.

00:11:18.570 --> 00:11:19.899
Continue, teacher."

00:11:19.923 --> 00:11:23.728
And the question is, who would go
all the way to 450 volts?

00:11:23.752 --> 00:11:26.328
You should notice here,
when it gets up to 375,

00:11:26.352 --> 00:11:27.877
it says, "Danger. Severe Shock."

00:11:27.901 --> 00:11:31.241
When it gets up to here, there's "XXX" --
the pornography of power.

00:11:31.695 --> 00:11:33.805
So Milgram asks 40 psychiatrists,

00:11:33.829 --> 00:11:36.934
"What percent of American citizens
would go to the end?"

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.459
They said only one percent.

00:11:38.483 --> 00:11:42.049
Because that's sadistic behavior,
and we know, psychiatry knows,

00:11:42.073 --> 00:11:44.165
only one percent
of Americans are sadistic.

00:11:44.189 --> 00:11:45.389
OK.

00:11:45.945 --> 00:11:48.551
Here's the data.
They could not be more wrong.

00:11:48.575 --> 00:11:51.396
Two thirds go all the way to 450 volts.

00:11:51.420 --> 00:11:52.934
This was just one study.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.242
Milgram did more than 16 studies.

00:11:55.266 --> 00:11:56.499
And look at this.

00:11:57.289 --> 00:12:00.126
In study 16, where you see
somebody like you go all the way,

00:12:00.150 --> 00:12:01.618
90 percent go all the way.

00:12:02.245 --> 00:12:04.433
In study five, if you see people rebel,

00:12:04.457 --> 00:12:05.800
90 percent rebel.

00:12:06.570 --> 00:12:09.415
What about women?
Study 13 -- no different than men.

00:12:09.736 --> 00:12:13.277
So Milgram is quantifying evil
as the willingness of people

00:12:13.301 --> 00:12:16.094
to blindly obey authority,
to go all the way to 450 volts.

00:12:16.404 --> 00:12:18.526
And it's like a dial on human nature.

00:12:18.550 --> 00:12:22.934
A dial in a sense that you can make
almost everybody totally obedient,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.648
down to the majority, down to none.

00:12:26.565 --> 00:12:29.565
What are the external parallels?
For all research is artificial.

00:12:29.589 --> 00:12:31.399
What's the validity in the real world?

00:12:31.423 --> 00:12:34.437
912 American citizens
committed suicide or were murdered

00:12:34.461 --> 00:12:37.446
by family and friends
in Guyana jungle in 1978,

00:12:37.470 --> 00:12:40.500
because they were blindly obedient
to this guy, their pastor --

00:12:40.524 --> 00:12:43.231
not their priest -- their pastor,
Reverend Jim Jones.

00:12:43.255 --> 00:12:46.051
He persuaded them to commit mass suicide.

00:12:46.075 --> 00:12:47.940
And so, he's the modern Lucifer effect,

00:12:47.964 --> 00:12:50.816
a man of God who becomes
the Angel of Death.

00:12:52.460 --> 00:12:56.854
Milgram's study is all about individual
authority to control people.

00:12:57.591 --> 00:12:59.934
Most of the time, we are in institutions,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:03.495
so the Stanford Prison Study
is a study of the power of institutions

00:13:03.519 --> 00:13:05.459
to influence individual behavior.

00:13:05.483 --> 00:13:09.087
Interestingly, Stanley Milgram and I
were in the same high school class

00:13:09.111 --> 00:13:11.815
in James Monroe in the Bronx, 1954.

00:13:12.934 --> 00:13:15.021
I did this study
with my graduate students,

00:13:15.045 --> 00:13:17.871
especially Craig Haney --
and it also began work with an ad.

00:13:17.895 --> 00:13:19.323
We had a cheap, little ad,

00:13:19.347 --> 00:13:22.099
but we wanted college students
for a study of prison life.

00:13:23.047 --> 00:13:25.487
75 people volunteered,
took personality tests.

00:13:25.511 --> 00:13:26.761
We did interviews.

00:13:26.785 --> 00:13:29.231
Picked two dozen: the most normal,
the most healthy.

00:13:29.255 --> 00:13:31.522
Randomly assigned them
to be prisoner and guard.

00:13:31.546 --> 00:13:33.566
So on day one, we knew we had good apples.

00:13:33.590 --> 00:13:35.543
I'm going to put them in a bad situation.

00:13:35.567 --> 00:13:37.844
And secondly, we know
there's no difference

00:13:37.868 --> 00:13:41.210
between the boys who will be guards
and those who will be prisoners.

00:13:41.234 --> 00:13:42.760
To the prisoners, we said,

00:13:42.784 --> 00:13:44.910
"Wait at home. The study
will begin Sunday."

00:13:44.934 --> 00:13:46.134
We didn't tell them

00:13:46.158 --> 00:13:49.353
that the city police were going
to come and do realistic arrests.

00:13:49.377 --> 00:13:51.009
(Video) (Music)

00:13:55.797 --> 00:13:56.997
[Day 1]

00:14:23.271 --> 00:14:28.245
Student: A police car pulls up in front,
and a cop comes to the front door,

00:14:28.269 --> 00:14:30.264
and knocks, and says he's looking for me.

00:14:30.288 --> 00:14:33.209
So they, right there, you know,
they took me out the door,

00:14:33.233 --> 00:14:36.731
they put my hands against the car.

00:14:36.755 --> 00:14:38.956
It was a real cop car,
it was a real policeman,

00:14:38.980 --> 00:14:41.043
and there were real
neighbors in the street,

00:14:41.067 --> 00:14:44.093
who didn't know
that this was an experiment.

00:14:44.587 --> 00:14:47.341
And there was cameras
all around and neighbors all around.

00:14:47.365 --> 00:14:50.581
They put me in the car,
then they drove me around Palo Alto.

00:14:52.136 --> 00:14:57.129
They took me to the basement
of the police station.

00:15:04.171 --> 00:15:05.565
Then they put me in a cell.

00:15:05.589 --> 00:15:08.507
I was the first one to be picked up,
so they put me in a cell,

00:15:08.531 --> 00:15:11.324
which was just like a room
with a door with bars on it.

00:15:12.244 --> 00:15:14.038
You could tell it wasn't a real jail.

00:15:14.062 --> 00:15:17.824
They locked me in there,
in this degrading little outfit.

00:15:18.568 --> 00:15:21.143
They were taking
this experiment too seriously.

00:15:21.167 --> 00:15:25.000
Here are the prisoners, who are going
to be dehumanized, they'll become numbers.

00:15:25.024 --> 00:15:27.916
Here are the guards
with the symbols of power and anonymity.

00:15:27.940 --> 00:15:31.389
Guards get prisoners to clean the toilet
bowls out with their bare hands,

00:15:31.413 --> 00:15:32.885
to do other humiliating tasks.

00:15:32.909 --> 00:15:35.151
They strip them naked.
They sexually taunt them.

00:15:35.175 --> 00:15:38.712
They begin to do degrading activities,
like having them simulate sodomy.

00:15:38.736 --> 00:15:41.967
You saw simulating fellatio
in soldiers in Abu Ghraib.

00:15:41.991 --> 00:15:43.873
My guards did it in five days.

00:15:44.293 --> 00:15:46.120
The stress reaction was so extreme

00:15:46.144 --> 00:15:48.580
that normal kids we picked
because they were healthy

00:15:48.604 --> 00:15:50.187
had breakdowns within 36 hours.

00:15:50.211 --> 00:15:54.236
The study ended after six days,
because it was out of control.

00:15:54.260 --> 00:15:56.390
Five kids had emotional breakdowns.

00:15:58.264 --> 00:15:59.717
Does it make a difference

00:15:59.741 --> 00:16:02.466
if warriors go to battle
changing their appearance or not?

00:16:02.490 --> 00:16:05.243
If they're anonymous,
how do they treat their victims?

00:16:05.267 --> 00:16:08.426
In some cultures, they go to war
without changing their appearance.

00:16:08.450 --> 00:16:11.178
In others, they paint themselves
like "Lord of the Flies."

00:16:11.202 --> 00:16:12.394
In some, they wear masks.

00:16:12.418 --> 00:16:14.479
In many, soldiers
are anonymous in uniform.

00:16:14.503 --> 00:16:19.200
So this anthropologist, John Watson, found
23 cultures that had two bits of data.

00:16:19.224 --> 00:16:21.563
Do they change their appearance? 15.

00:16:21.587 --> 00:16:23.894
Do they kill, torture, mutilate? 13.

00:16:24.198 --> 00:16:26.021
If they don't change their appearance,

00:16:26.045 --> 00:16:28.258
only one of eight kills,
tortures or mutilates.

00:16:28.282 --> 00:16:29.586
The key is in the red zone.

00:16:29.610 --> 00:16:31.175
If they change their appearance,

00:16:31.199 --> 00:16:34.416
12 of 13 -- that's 90 percent --
kill, torture, mutilate.

00:16:34.934 --> 00:16:36.554
And that's the power of anonymity.

00:16:36.578 --> 00:16:38.483
So what are the seven social processes

00:16:38.507 --> 00:16:40.365
that grease the slippery slope of evil?

00:16:40.389 --> 00:16:42.515
Mindlessly taking the first small step.

00:16:42.539 --> 00:16:45.181
Dehumanization of others.
De-individuation of self.

00:16:45.205 --> 00:16:47.107
Diffusion of personal responsibility.

00:16:47.131 --> 00:16:48.778
Blind obedience to authority.

00:16:48.802 --> 00:16:50.696
Uncritical conformity to group norms.

00:16:50.720 --> 00:16:53.934
Passive tolerance of evil
through inaction, or indifference.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.816
And it happens when you're
in a new or unfamiliar situation.

00:16:56.840 --> 00:16:58.889
Your habitual response
patterns don't work.

00:16:58.913 --> 00:17:01.360
Your personality
and morality are disengaged.

00:17:02.601 --> 00:17:04.911
"Nothing is easier
than to denounce the evildoer;

00:17:04.935 --> 00:17:07.957
nothing more difficult
than understanding him," Dostoyevsky.

00:17:07.981 --> 00:17:11.553
Understanding is not excusing.
Psychology is not excuse-ology.

00:17:12.017 --> 00:17:14.144
So social and psychological
research reveals

00:17:14.168 --> 00:17:17.440
how ordinary, good people can be
transformed without the drugs.

00:17:17.464 --> 00:17:20.765
You don't need it. You just need
the social-psychological processes.

00:17:20.789 --> 00:17:22.484
Real world parallels?

00:17:22.508 --> 00:17:24.692
Compare this with this.

00:17:25.934 --> 00:17:28.622
James Schlesinger --
I'm going to end with this -- says,

00:17:28.646 --> 00:17:31.245
"Psychologists have attempted
to understand how and why

00:17:31.269 --> 00:17:33.698
individuals and groups
who usually act humanely

00:17:33.722 --> 00:17:36.910
can sometimes act otherwise
in certain circumstances."

00:17:36.934 --> 00:17:38.173
That's the Lucifer effect.

00:17:38.197 --> 00:17:40.626
And he goes on to say,
"The landmark Stanford study

00:17:40.650 --> 00:17:44.570
provides a cautionary tale
for all military operations."

00:17:44.594 --> 00:17:46.934
If you give people power
without oversight,

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:48.441
it's a prescription for abuse.

00:17:48.465 --> 00:17:50.876
They knew that, and let that happen.

00:17:51.635 --> 00:17:54.715
So another report, an investigative
report by General Fay,

00:17:54.739 --> 00:17:56.689
says the system is guilty.

00:17:56.713 --> 00:18:00.176
In this report, he says it was
the environment that created Abu Ghraib,

00:18:00.200 --> 00:18:03.582
by leadership failures that contributed
to the occurrence of such abuse,

00:18:03.606 --> 00:18:05.516
and because it remained undiscovered

00:18:05.540 --> 00:18:07.780
by higher authorities
for a long period of time.

00:18:07.804 --> 00:18:09.629
Those abuses went on for three months.

00:18:09.653 --> 00:18:11.261
Who was watching the store?

00:18:11.285 --> 00:18:13.532
The answer is nobody, I think on purpose.

00:18:13.556 --> 00:18:15.849
He gave the guards permission
to do those things,

00:18:15.873 --> 00:18:18.937
and they knew nobody was ever going
to come down to that dungeon.

00:18:18.961 --> 00:18:21.529
So you need a paradigm shift
in all of these areas.

00:18:21.553 --> 00:18:25.230
The shift is away from the medical model
that focuses only on the individual.

00:18:25.254 --> 00:18:27.934
The shift is toward a public health model

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:31.740
that recognizes situational
and systemic vectors of disease.

00:18:31.764 --> 00:18:34.101
Bullying is a disease.
Prejudice is a disease.

00:18:34.125 --> 00:18:35.293
Violence is a disease.

00:18:35.317 --> 00:18:39.085
Since the Inquisition, we've been dealing
with problems at the individual level.

00:18:39.109 --> 00:18:40.550
It doesn't work.

00:18:40.574 --> 00:18:43.390
Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn says,
"The line between good and evil

00:18:43.414 --> 00:18:45.534
cuts through the heart
of every human being."

00:18:45.558 --> 00:18:47.370
That means that line is not out there.

00:18:47.394 --> 00:18:50.365
That's a decision that you have
to make, a personal thing.

00:18:50.389 --> 00:18:52.934
So I want to end very quickly
on a positive note.

00:18:53.450 --> 00:18:55.910
Heroism as the antidote to evil,

00:18:55.934 --> 00:18:57.829
by promoting the heroic imagination,

00:18:57.853 --> 00:19:00.351
especially in our kids,
in our educational system.

00:19:00.375 --> 00:19:02.839
We want kids to think,
"I'm a hero in waiting,

00:19:02.863 --> 00:19:05.006
waiting for the right
situation to come along,

00:19:05.030 --> 00:19:06.573
and I will act heroically.

00:19:06.597 --> 00:19:09.275
My whole life, I'm now going
to focus away from evil --

00:19:09.299 --> 00:19:12.252
that I've been in since I was a kid
-- to understanding heroes.

00:19:12.276 --> 00:19:13.441
Banality of heroism.

00:19:13.465 --> 00:19:15.469
It's ordinary people who do heroic deeds.

00:19:15.493 --> 00:19:18.439
It's the counterpoint
to Hannah Arendt's "Banality of Evil."

00:19:18.463 --> 00:19:22.424
Our traditional societal heroes are wrong,
because they are the exceptions.

00:19:22.448 --> 00:19:25.783
They organize their life around this.
That's why we know their names.

00:19:25.807 --> 00:19:28.085
Our kids' heroes
are also wrong models for them,

00:19:28.109 --> 00:19:30.053
because they have supernatural talents.

00:19:30.077 --> 00:19:33.038
We want our kids to realize
most heroes are everyday people,

00:19:33.062 --> 00:19:35.166
and the heroic act is unusual.

00:19:35.190 --> 00:19:36.481
This is Joe Darby.

00:19:36.505 --> 00:19:38.791
He was the one that stopped
those abuses you saw,

00:19:38.815 --> 00:19:40.408
because when he saw those images,

00:19:40.432 --> 00:19:43.003
he turned them over
to a senior investigating officer.

00:19:43.027 --> 00:19:45.755
He was a low-level private,
and that stopped it.

00:19:45.779 --> 00:19:46.957
Was he a hero? No.

00:19:46.981 --> 00:19:50.131
They had to put him in hiding,
because people wanted to kill him,

00:19:50.155 --> 00:19:51.807
and then his mother and his wife.

00:19:51.831 --> 00:19:53.716
For three years, they were in hiding.

00:19:53.740 --> 00:19:56.426
This is the woman who stopped
the Stanford Prison Study.

00:19:56.450 --> 00:19:59.699
When I said it got out of control,
I was the prison superintendent.

00:19:59.723 --> 00:20:02.722
I didn't know it was out of control.
I was totally indifferent.

00:20:02.746 --> 00:20:04.337
She saw that madhouse and said,

00:20:04.361 --> 00:20:07.266
"You know what, it's terrible
what you're doing to those boys.

00:20:07.290 --> 00:20:10.934
They're not prisoners nor guards,
they're boys, and you are responsible."

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:12.934
And I ended the study the next day.

00:20:13.497 --> 00:20:15.607
The good news
is I married her the next year.

00:20:15.631 --> 00:20:17.934
(Laughter)

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:24.958
(Applause)

00:20:25.403 --> 00:20:27.414
I just came to my senses, obviously.

00:20:27.438 --> 00:20:30.107
So situations have the power
to do [three things].

00:20:30.131 --> 00:20:32.912
But the point is,
this is the same situation

00:20:32.936 --> 00:20:36.402
that can inflame the hostile
imagination in some of us,

00:20:36.426 --> 00:20:38.163
that makes us perpetrators of evil,

00:20:38.187 --> 00:20:40.380
can inspire the heroic
imagination in others.

00:20:40.404 --> 00:20:43.518
It's the same situation
and you're on one side or the other.

00:20:43.542 --> 00:20:45.733
Most people are guilty
of the evil of inaction,

00:20:45.757 --> 00:20:49.105
because your mother said, "Don't get
involved. Mind your own business."

00:20:49.129 --> 00:20:51.606
And you have to say,
"Mama, humanity is my business."

00:20:51.630 --> 00:20:54.821
So the psychology of heroism is --
we're going to end in a moment --

00:20:54.845 --> 00:20:57.272
how do we encourage children
in new hero courses,

00:20:57.296 --> 00:21:00.588
that I'm working on with Matt Langdon --
he has a hero workshop --

00:21:00.612 --> 00:21:03.655
to develop this heroic imagination,
this self-labeling,

00:21:03.679 --> 00:21:06.442
"I am a hero in waiting,"
and teach them skills.

00:21:06.466 --> 00:21:08.821
To be a hero, you have
to learn to be a deviant,

00:21:08.845 --> 00:21:11.845
because you're always going
against the conformity of the group.

00:21:12.495 --> 00:21:16.335
Heroes are ordinary people whose social
actions are extraordinary. Who act.

00:21:16.359 --> 00:21:18.110
The key to heroism is two things.

00:21:18.134 --> 00:21:20.515
You have to act
when other people are passive.

00:21:20.539 --> 00:21:23.306
B: You have to act socio-centrically,
not egocentrically.

00:21:23.330 --> 00:21:27.113
And I want to end with a known story
about Wesley Autrey, New York subway hero.

00:21:27.137 --> 00:21:30.934
Fifty-year-old African-American
construction worker standing on a subway.

00:21:30.958 --> 00:21:32.486
A white guy falls on the tracks.

00:21:32.510 --> 00:21:34.970
The subway train is coming.
There's 75 people there.

00:21:34.994 --> 00:21:36.490
You know what? They freeze.

00:21:36.514 --> 00:21:38.380
He's got a reason not to get involved.

00:21:38.404 --> 00:21:40.821
He's black, the guy's white,
and he's got two kids.

00:21:40.845 --> 00:21:42.798
Instead, he gives his kids to a stranger,

00:21:42.822 --> 00:21:45.299
jumps on the tracks,
puts the guy between the tracks,

00:21:45.323 --> 00:21:47.493
lays on him, the subway goes over him.

00:21:47.517 --> 00:21:50.775
Wesley and the guy --
20 and a half inches height.

00:21:50.799 --> 00:21:53.089
The train clearance is 21 inches.

00:21:53.638 --> 00:21:55.741
A half an inch
would have taken his head off.

00:21:56.335 --> 00:22:00.404
And he said, "I did what anyone could do,"
no big deal to jump on the tracks.

00:22:00.428 --> 00:22:04.076
And the moral imperative
is "I did what everyone should do."

00:22:04.100 --> 00:22:06.487
And so one day,
you will be in a new situation.

00:22:06.958 --> 00:22:09.578
Take path one, you're going
to be a perpetrator of evil.

00:22:09.602 --> 00:22:11.934
Evil, meaning you're going to be
Arthur Andersen.

00:22:11.958 --> 00:22:14.673
You're going to cheat,
or you're going to allow bullying.

00:22:14.697 --> 00:22:17.511
Path two, you become guilty
of the evil of passive inaction.

00:22:17.535 --> 00:22:19.258
Path three, you become a hero.

00:22:19.282 --> 00:22:23.700
The point is, are we ready to take
the path to celebrating ordinary heroes,

00:22:23.724 --> 00:22:25.928
waiting for the right
situation to come along

00:22:25.952 --> 00:22:28.018
to put heroic imagination into action?

00:22:28.042 --> 00:22:30.836
Because it may only happen
once in your life,

00:22:30.860 --> 00:22:33.003
and when you pass it by,
you'll always know,

00:22:33.027 --> 00:22:35.462
I could have been a hero
and I let it pass me by.

00:22:35.486 --> 00:22:37.659
So the point is thinking it
and then doing it.

00:22:38.357 --> 00:22:40.305
So I want to thank you. Thank you.

00:22:40.329 --> 00:22:43.331
Let's oppose the power of evil systems
at home and abroad,

00:22:43.355 --> 00:22:44.934
and let's focus on the positive.

00:22:44.958 --> 00:22:48.479
Advocate for respect of personal dignity,
for justice and peace,

00:22:48.503 --> 00:22:50.841
which sadly our administration
has not been doing.

00:22:50.865 --> 00:22:52.115
Thanks so much.

00:22:52.139 --> 00:22:55.248
(Applause)

title: Remember to say thank you
transcript: Hi. I'm here to talk to you about the importance of praise, admiration and thank you, and having it be specific and genuine.And the way I got interested in this was, I noticed in myself, when I was growing up, and until about a few years ago, that I would want to say thank you to someone, I would want to praise them, I would want to take in their praise of me and I'd just stop it. And I asked myself, why? I felt shy, I felt embarrassed. And then my question became, am I the only one who does this? So, I decided to investigate.I'm fortunate enough to work in the rehab facility, so I get to see people who are facing life and death with addiction. And sometimes it comes down to something as simple as, their core wound is their father died without ever saying he's proud of them. But then, they hear from all the family and friends that the father told everybody else that he was proud of him, but he never told the son. It's because he didn't know that his son needed to hear it.So my question is, why don't we ask for the things that we need? I know a gentleman, married for 25 years, who's longing to hear his wife say, "Thank you for being the breadwinner, so I can stay home with the kids," but won't ask. I know a woman who's good at this. She, once a week, meets with her husband and says, "I'd really like you to thank me for all these things I did in the house and with the kids." And he goes, "Oh, this is great, this is great." And praise really does have to be genuine, but she takes responsibility for that. And a friend of mine, April, who I've had since kindergarten, she thanks her children for doing their chores. And she said, "Why wouldn't I thank it, even though they're supposed to do it?"So, the question is, why was I blocking it? Why were other people blocking it? Why can I say, "I'll take my steak medium rare, I need size six shoes," but I won't say, "Would you praise me this way?" And it's because I'm giving you critical data about me. I'm telling you where I'm insecure. I'm telling you where I need your help. And I'm treating you, my inner circle, like you're the enemy. Because what can you do with that data? You could neglect me. You could abuse it. Or you could actually meet my need.And I took my bike into the bike store— I love this — same bike, and they'd do something called "truing" the wheels. The guy said, "You know, when you true the wheels, it's going to make the bike so much better." I get the same bike back, and they've taken all the little warps out of those same wheels I've had for two and a half years, and my bike is like new. So, I'm going to challenge all of you. I want you to true your wheels: be honest about the praise that you need to hear. What do you need to hear? Go home to your wife — go ask her, what does she need? Go home to your husband — what does he need? Go home and ask those questions, and then help the people around you.And it's simple. And why should we care about this? We talk about world peace. How can we have world peace with different cultures, different languages? I think it starts household by household, under the same roof. So, let's make it right in our own backyard. And I want to thank all of you in the audience for being great husbands, great mothers, friends, daughters, sons. And maybe somebody's never said that to you, but you've done a really, really good job. And thank you for being here, just showing up and changing the world with your ideas.Thank you. (Applause)
