00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.958
A year ago, I spoke to you about a book

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:18.958
that I was just in the process of completing,

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:21.958
that has come out in the interim, and I would like to talk to you today

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:25.958
about some of the controversies that that book inspired.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:27.958
The book is called "The Blank Slate,"

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:29.958
based on the popular idea

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
that the human mind is a blank slate,

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:34.958
and that all of its structure comes from

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
socialization, culture, parenting, experience.

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:42.958
The "blank slate" was an influential idea in the 20th century.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
Here are a few quotes indicating that:

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
"Man has no nature," from the historian

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
Jose Ortega y Gasset;

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:51.958
"Man has no instincts," from the

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:53.958
anthropologist Ashley Montagu;

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:56.958
"The human brain is capable of a full range of behaviors

00:00:56.958 --> 00:01:00.958
and predisposed to none," from the late scientist Stephen Jay Gould.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
There are a number of reasons to doubt that the human mind

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
is a blank slate,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
and some of them just come from common sense.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:10.958
As many people have told me over the years,

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:12.958
anyone who's had more than one child

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.958
knows that kids come into the world

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:17.958
with certain temperaments and talents;

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
it doesn't all come from the outside.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
Oh, and anyone who

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
has both a child and a house pet

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
has surely noticed that the child, exposed to speech,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
will acquire a human language,

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
whereas the house pet won't,

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:33.958
presumably because of some innate different between them.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
And anyone who's ever been

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
in a heterosexual relationship knows that

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
the minds of men and the minds of women are not indistinguishable.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
There are also, I think,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
increasing results from

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:48.958
the scientific study of humans

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:50.958
that, indeed, we're not born blank slates.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
One of them, from anthropology,

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
is the study of human universals.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
If you've ever taken anthropology, you know that it's a --

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
kind of an occupational

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
pleasure of anthropologists to show

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
how exotic other cultures can be,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
and that there are places out there where, supposedly,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
everything is the opposite to the way it is here.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.958
But if you instead

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:16.958
look at what is common to the world's cultures,

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:18.958
you find that there is an enormously rich set

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:21.958
of behaviors and emotions

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
and ways of construing the world

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:26.958
that can be found in all of the world's 6,000-odd cultures.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
The anthropologist Donald Brown has tried to list them all,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
and they range from aesthetics,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:35.958
affection and age statuses

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.958
all the way down to weaning, weapons, weather,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
attempts to control, the color white

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
and a worldview.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
Also, genetics and neuroscience

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
are increasingly showing that the brain

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:48.958
is intricately structured.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
This is a recent study by the neurobiologist Paul Thompson

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
and his colleagues in which they --

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
using MRI --

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
measured the distribution of gray matter --

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
that is, the outer layer of the cortex --

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
in a large sample of pairs of people.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
They coded correlations in the thickness

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
of gray matter in different parts of the brain

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
using a false color scheme, in which

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
no difference is coded as purple,

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
and any color other than purple indicates

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
a statistically significant correlation.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
Well, this is what happens when you pair people up at random.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
By definition, two people picked at random

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
can't have correlations in the distribution

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
of gray matter in the cortex.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
This is what happens in people who share

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
half of their DNA -- fraternal twins.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
And as you can see, large amounts of the brain

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
are not purple, showing that if one person

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
has a thicker bit of cortex

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
in that region, so does his fraternal twin.

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.958
And here's what happens if you

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
get a pair of people who share all their DNA --

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
namely, clones or identical twins.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:01.958
And you can see huge areas of cortex where there are

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
massive correlations in the distribution of gray matter.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
Now, these aren't just

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
differences in anatomy,

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
like the shape of your ear lobes,

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:14.958
but they have consequences in thought and behavior

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:18.958
that are well illustrated in this famous cartoon by Charles Addams:

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:22.958
"Separated at birth, the Mallifert twins meet accidentally."

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
As you can see, there are two inventors

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
with identical contraptions in their lap, meeting

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
in the waiting room of a patent attorney.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
Now, the cartoon is not such an exaggeration, because

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
studies of identical twins who were separated at birth

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
and then tested in adulthood

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
show that they have astonishing similarities.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
And this happens in every pair of identical twins

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
separated at birth ever studied --

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
but much less so with fraternal twins separated at birth.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
My favorite example is a pair of twins,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
one of whom was brought up

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:57.958
as a Catholic in a Nazi family in Germany,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
the other brought up in a Jewish family in Trinidad.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
When they walked into the lab in Minnesota,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
they were wearing identical navy blue shirts with epaulettes;

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
both of them liked to dip buttered toast in coffee,

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:13.958
both of them kept rubber bands around their wrists,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
both of them flushed the toilet before using it as well as after,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
and both of them liked to surprise people

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:23.958
by sneezing in crowded elevators to watch them jump.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
Now --

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
the story might seem to good to be true,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
but when you administer

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
batteries of psychological tests,

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
you get the same results -- namely,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
identical twins separated at birth show

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
quite astonishing similarities.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
Now, given both the common sense

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
and scientific data

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
calling the doctrine of the blank slate into question,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
why should it have been such an appealing notion?

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
Well, there are a number of political reasons why people have found it congenial.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
The foremost is that if we're blank slates,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
then, by definition, we are equal,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
because zero equals zero equals zero.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
But if something is written on the slate,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
then some people could have more of it than others,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
and according to this line of thinking, that would justify

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
discrimination and inequality.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
Another political fear of human nature

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
is that if we are blank slates,

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
we can perfect mankind --

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
the age-old dream of the perfectibility of our species

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
through social engineering.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
Whereas, if we're born with certain instincts,

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
then perhaps some of them might condemn us

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
to selfishness, prejudice and violence.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
Well, in the book, I argue that these are, in fact, non sequiturs.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
And just to make a long story short:

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
first of all, the concept of fairness

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
is not the same as the concept of sameness.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
And so when Thomas Jefferson wrote

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
in the Declaration of Independence,

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
"We hold these truths to be self-evident,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
that all men are created equal,"

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
he did not mean "We hold these truths to be self-evident,

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
that all men are clones."

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
Rather, that all men are equal in terms of their rights,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
and that every person ought to be treated

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
as an individual, and not prejudged

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
by the statistics of particular groups

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
that they may belong to.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
Also, even if we were born

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
with certain ignoble motives,

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
they don't automatically lead to ignoble behavior.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
That is because the human mind

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
is a complex system with many parts,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
and some of them can inhibit others.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
For example, there's excellent reason to believe

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
that virtually all humans are born with a moral sense,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
and that we have cognitive abilities that allow us

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
to profit from the lessons of history.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
So even if people did have impulses

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
towards selfishness or greed,

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
that's not the only thing in the skull,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
and there are other parts of the mind that can counteract them.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
In the book, I

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
go over controversies such as this one,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
and a number of other hot buttons,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
hot zones, Chernobyls, third rails, and so on --

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
including the arts, cloning, crime,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
free will, education, evolution,

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
gender differences, God, homosexuality,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
infanticide, inequality, Marxism, morality,

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
Nazism, parenting, politics,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
race, rape, religion, resource depletion,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
social engineering, technological risk and war.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
And needless to say, there were certain risks

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
in taking on these subjects.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
When I wrote a first draft of the book,

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
I circulated it to a number of colleagues for comments,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
and here are some of

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
the reactions that I got:

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
"Better get a security camera for your house."

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
"Don't expect to get any more awards, job offers

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
or positions in scholarly societies."

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
"Tell your publisher not to list your hometown

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
in your author bio."

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
"Do you have tenure?"

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
(Laughter)

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
Well, the book came out in October,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
and nothing terrible has happened.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
I -- I like --

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
There was indeed reason to be nervous,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
and there were moments in which I did feel nervous,

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
knowing the history

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
of what has happened to people

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
who've taken controversial stands

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
or discovered disquieting findings

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
in the behavioral sciences.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
There are many cases, some of which I talk about in the book,

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:13.958
of people who have been slandered, called Nazis,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
physically assaulted, threatened with criminal prosecution

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
for stumbling across or arguing

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
about controversial findings.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
And you never know when you're going to

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
come across one of these booby traps.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
My favorite example is a pair of psychologists

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
who did research on left-handers,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
and published some data showing that left-handers are, on average,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
more susceptible to disease, more prone to accidents

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
and have a shorter lifespan.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
It's not clear, by the way, since then,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
whether that is an accurate generalization,

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
but the data at the time seemed to support that.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
Well, pretty soon they were barraged

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
with enraged letters,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
death threats,

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
ban on the topic in a number of scientific journals,

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
coming from irate left-handers

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
and their advocates,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
and they were literally afraid to open their mail

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
because of the venom and vituperation

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
that they had inadvertently inspired.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
Well,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
the night is young, but the book has been out

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
for half a year,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
and nothing terrible has happened.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
None of the dire professional consequences

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
has taken place --

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
I haven't been

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
exiled from the city of Cambridge.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
But what I wanted to talk about

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
are two of these hot buttons

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:38.958
that have aroused the strongest response

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
in the 80-odd reviews

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
that The Blank Slate has received.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
I'll just put that list up for a few seconds,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
and see if you can guess which two

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
-- I would estimate that probably two of these topics

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
inspired probably 90 percent

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
of the reaction in the various reviews

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
and radio interviews.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
It's not violence and war,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
it's not race, it's not gender,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
it's not Marxism, it's not Nazism.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
They are: the arts and parenting.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
(Laughter)

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
So let me tell you what

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
aroused such irate responses,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
and I'll let you decide if whether they --

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
the claims are really that outrageous.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
Let me start with the arts.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
I note that among the long list of human universals

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
that I presented a few slides ago

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
are art.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
There is no society ever discovered

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
in the remotest corner of the world that has not had something

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
that we would consider the arts.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
Visual arts -- decoration of surfaces and bodies --

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
appears to be a human universal.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
The telling of stories, music,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
dance, poetry -- found in all cultures,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
and many of the motifs and themes

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
that

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
give us pleasure in the arts

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
can be found in all human societies:

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
a preference for symmetrical forms,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
the use of repetition and variation,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
even things as specific as the fact

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
that in poetry all over the world,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
you have lines that are very close

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
to three seconds long, separated by pauses.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
Now, on the other hand,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
in the second half of the 20th century,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
the arts are frequently said to be in decline.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
And I have a collection,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
probably 10 or 15 headlines, from highbrow magazines

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
deploring the fact that

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
the arts are in decline in our time.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
I'll give you a couple of representative quotes:

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
"We can assert with some confidence that our own period is

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
one of decline, that the standards of culture are lower

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
than they were 50 years ago, and that the evidences of this decline

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
are visible in every department of human activity."

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
That's a quote from T. S. Eliot, a little more than 50 years ago.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
And a more recent one:

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
"The possibility of sustaining high culture in our time

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
is becoming increasing problematical.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
Serious book stores are losing their franchise,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
nonprofit theaters are surviving primarily

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
by commercializing their repertory,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
symphony orchestras are diluting their programs,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
public television is increasing its dependence

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
on reruns of British sitcoms,

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
classical radio stations are dwindling,

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
museums are resorting to blockbuster shows, dance is dying."

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
That's from Robert Brustein,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
the famous drama critic and director,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
in The New Republic about five years ago.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
Well, in fact, the arts are not in decline.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
I don't think this will as a surprise to anyone in this room,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
but by any standard

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
they have never been flourishing

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
to a greater extent.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
There are, of course, entirely new art forms

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
and new media, many of which you've heard

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
over these few days.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
By any economic standard,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
the demand for art of all forms

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
is skyrocketing,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
as you can tell from the price of opera tickets,

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
by the number of books sold,

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
by the number of books published,

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
the number of musical titles released,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
the number of new albums and so on.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
The only grain of truth to this

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
complaint that the arts are in decline

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:08.958
come from three spheres.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
One of them is in elite art since the 1930s --

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
say, the kinds of works performed

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
by major symphony orchestras,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
where most of the repertory is before 1930,

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
or the works shown in

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
major galleries and prestigious museums.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
In literary criticism and analysis,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
probably 40 or 50 years ago,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
literary critics were a kind of cultural hero;

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
now they're kind of a national joke.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
And the humanities and arts programs

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
in the universities, which by many measures,

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
indeed are in decline.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
Students are staying away in droves,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
universities are disinvesting

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
in the arts and humanities.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
Well, here's a diagnosis.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
They didn't ask me, but by their own admission,

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
they need all the help that they can get.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
And I would like to suggest that it's not a coincidence

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
that this supposed decline

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
in the elite arts and criticism

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
occurred in the same point in history in which

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
there was a widespread denial of human nature.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
A famous quotation can be found --

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
if you look on the web, you can find it in

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
literally scores

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
of English core syllabuses --

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
"In or about December 1910,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
human nature changed."

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
A paraphrase of a quote by Virginia Woolf,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
and there's some debate

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
as to what she actually meant by that.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
But it's very clear, looking at these syllabuses,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
that -- it's used now

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
as a way of saying that all forms

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
of appreciation of art

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:42.958
that were in place for centuries, or millennia,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
in the 20th century were discarded.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
The beauty and pleasure in art --

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
probably a human universal --

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
were -- began to be considered saccharine,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
or kitsch, or commercial.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
Barnett Newman had a famous quote that "the impulse of modern art

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.958
is the desire to destroy beauty" --

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
which was considered bourgeois or tacky.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
And here's just one example.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
I mean, this is perhaps a representative example

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
of the visual depiction of the female form

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:13.958
in the 15th century;

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:15.958
here is a representative example

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
of the depiction of the female form in the 20th century.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
And, as you can see, there -- something has changed

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
in the way the elite arts

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
appeal to the senses.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
Indeed, in movements of modernism

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
and post-modernism,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
there was visual art without beauty,

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
literature without narrative and plot,

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
poetry without meter and rhyme,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
architecture and planning without ornament,

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
human scale, green space and natural light,

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
music without melody and rhythm,

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
and criticism without clarity,

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
attention to aesthetics and insight into the human condition.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
(Laughter)

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
Let me give just you an example to back up that last statement.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
But here, there -- one of the most famous literary

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
English scholars of our time

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
is the Berkeley professor,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
Judith Butler.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.958
And here is an example of

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:05.958
one of her analyses:

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
"The move from a structuralist account in which capital

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
is understood to structure social relations

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
in relatively homologous ways

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
to a view of hegemony in which power relations are subject to repetition,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
convergence and rearticulation

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
brought the question of temporality into the thinking of structure,

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
and marked a shift from the form of Althusserian theory

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
that takes structural totalities as theoretical objects ..."

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
Well, you get the idea.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:29.958
By the way, this is one sentence --

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:32.958
you can actually parse it.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
Well, the argument in "The Blank Slate"

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
was that elite art and criticism

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:39.958
in the 20th century,

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
although not the arts in general,

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:43.958
have disdained beauty, pleasure,

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:46.958
clarity, insight and style.

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
People are staying away from elite art and criticism.

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:52.958
What a puzzle -- I wonder why.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:55.958
Well, this turned out to be probably

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:57.958
the most controversial claim in the book.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
Someone asked me whether I stuck it in

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
in order to deflect ire

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:04.958
from discussions of gender and Nazism

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:08.958
and race and so on. I won't comment on that.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:12.958
But it certainly inspired

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:15.958
an energetic reaction

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:18.958
from many university professors.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.958
Well, the other hot button is parenting.

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:24.958
And the starting point is the -- for that discussion

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
was the fact that we have all

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
been subject to the advice

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:31.958
of the parenting industrial complex.

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:33.958
Now, here is -- here is a

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:36.958
representative quote from a besieged mother:

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:38.958
"I'm overwhelmed with parenting advice.

00:18:38.958 --> 00:18:40.958
I'm supposed to do lots of physical activity with my kids

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:43.958
so I can instill in them a physical fitness habit

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:45.958
so they'll grow up to be healthy adults.

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:47.958
And I'm supposed to do all kinds of intellectual play

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:49.958
so they'll grow up smart.

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:52.958
And there are all kinds of play -- clay for finger dexterity,

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:55.958
word games for reading success, large motor play,

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:57.958
small motor play. I feel like I could devote my life

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:00.958
to figuring out what to play with my kids."

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:02.958
I think anyone who's recently been a parent can sympathize

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:05.958
with this mother.

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.958
Well, here's some sobering facts about parenting.

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:11.958
Most studies of parenting on which this advice is based

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:15.958
are useless. They're useless because they don't control

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:18.958
for heritability. They measure some correlation

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:21.958
between what the parents do, how the children turn out

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:23.958
and assume a causal relation:

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:25.958
that the parenting shaped the child.

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:27.958
Parents who talk a lot to their kids

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:29.958
have kids who grow up to be articulate,

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:31.958
parents who spank their kids have kids who grow up

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:33.958
to be violent and so on.

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:36.958
And very few of them control for the possibility

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:39.958
that parents pass on genes for --

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:41.958
that increase the chances a child will be articulate

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:43.958
or violent and so on.

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:46.958
Until the studies are redone with adoptive children,

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:48.958
who provide an environment

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:50.958
but not genes to their kids,

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:53.958
we have no way of knowing whether these conclusions are valid.

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:55.958
The genetically controlled studies

00:19:55.958 --> 00:19:57.958
have some sobering results.

00:19:57.958 --> 00:19:59.958
Remember the Mallifert twins:

00:19:59.958 --> 00:20:02.958
separated at birth, then they meet in the patent office --

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:04.958
remarkably similar.

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:07.958
Well, what would have happened if the Mallifert twins had grown up together?

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:10.958
You might think, well, then they'd be even more similar,

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:12.958
because not only would they share their genes,

00:20:12.958 --> 00:20:15.958
but they would also share their environment.

00:20:15.958 --> 00:20:17.958
That would make them super-similar, right?

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:20.958
Wrong. Identical twins, or any siblings,

00:20:20.958 --> 00:20:24.958
who are separated at birth are no less similar

00:20:24.958 --> 00:20:26.958
than if they had grown up together.

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:28.958
Everything that happens to you in a given home

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:30.958
over all of those years

00:20:30.958 --> 00:20:32.958
appears to leave no permanent stamp

00:20:32.958 --> 00:20:34.958
on your personality or intellect.

00:20:35.958 --> 00:20:38.958
A complementary finding, from a completely different methodology,

00:20:38.958 --> 00:20:42.958
is that adopted siblings reared together --

00:20:42.958 --> 00:20:44.958
the mirror image of identical twins reared apart,

00:20:44.958 --> 00:20:46.958
they share their parents, their home,

00:20:46.958 --> 00:20:48.958
their neighborhood,

00:20:48.958 --> 00:20:51.958
don't share their genes -- end up not similar at all.

00:20:51.958 --> 00:20:54.958
OK -- two different bodies of research with a similar finding.

00:20:54.958 --> 00:20:56.958
What it suggests is that children are shaped

00:20:56.958 --> 00:20:59.958
not by their parents over the long run,

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:02.958
but in part -- only in part -- by their genes,

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:04.958
in part by their culture --

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:06.958
the culture of the country at large

00:21:06.958 --> 00:21:08.958
and the children's own culture, namely their peer group --

00:21:08.958 --> 00:21:11.958
as we heard from Jill Sobule earlier today,

00:21:11.958 --> 00:21:13.958
that's what kids care about --

00:21:14.958 --> 00:21:17.958
and, to a very large extent, larger than most people are prepared to acknowledge,

00:21:17.958 --> 00:21:20.958
by chance: chance events in the wiring of the brain in utero;

00:21:20.958 --> 00:21:22.958
chance events as you live your life.

00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:26.958
So let me conclude

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:28.958
with just a remark

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:31.958
to bring it back to the theme of choices.

00:21:31.958 --> 00:21:33.958
I think that the sciences of human nature --

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:36.958
behavioral genetics, evolutionary psychology, 


00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:38.958
neuroscience, cognitive science --

00:21:38.958 --> 00:21:41.958
are going to, increasingly in the years to come,

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:44.958
upset various dogmas,

00:21:44.958 --> 00:21:47.958
careers and deeply-held political belief systems.

00:21:47.958 --> 00:21:49.958
And that presents us with a choice.

00:21:49.958 --> 00:21:52.958
The choice is whether certain facts about humans,

00:21:52.958 --> 00:21:55.958
or topics, are to be considered taboos,

00:21:56.958 --> 00:21:58.958
forbidden knowledge, where we shouldn't go there

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:00.958
because no good can come from it,

00:22:00.958 --> 00:22:03.958
or whether we should explore them honestly.

00:22:03.958 --> 00:22:05.958
I have my own

00:22:05.958 --> 00:22:07.958
answer to that question,

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:10.958
which comes from a great artist of the 19th century,

00:22:10.958 --> 00:22:13.958
Anton Chekhov, who said,

00:22:13.958 --> 00:22:15.958
"Man will become better when you show him

00:22:15.958 --> 00:22:17.958
what he is like."

00:22:17.958 --> 00:22:19.958
And I think that the argument

00:22:19.958 --> 00:22:22.958
can't be put any more eloquently than that.

00:22:22.958 --> 00:22:24.958
Thank you very much.

00:22:25.958 --> 00:22:30.958
(Applause)

title: Robots will invade our lives
transcript: What I want to tell you about today is how I see robots invading our lives at multiple levels, over multiple timescales. And when I look out in the future, I can't imagine a world, 500 years from now, where we don't have robots everywhere. Assuming — despite all the dire predictions from many people about our future — assuming we're still around, I can't imagine the world not being populated with robots. And then the question is, well, if they're going to be here in 500 years, are they going to be everywhere sooner than that? Are they going to be around in 50 years? Yeah, I think that's pretty likely — there's going to be lots of robots everywhere. And in fact I think that's going to be a lot sooner than that. I think we're sort of on the cusp of robots becoming common, and I think we're sort of around 1978 or 1980 in personal computer years, where the first few robots are starting to appear.Computers sort of came around through games and toys. And you know, the first computer most people had in the house may have been a computer to play Pong, a little microprocessor embedded, and then other games that came after that. And we're starting to see that same sort of thing with robots: LEGO Mindstorms, Furbies — who here — did anyone here have a Furby? Yeah, there's 38 million of them sold worldwide. They are pretty common. And they're a little tiny robot, a simple robot with some sensors, a little bit of processing actuation.On the right there is another robot doll, who you could get a couple of years ago. And just as in the early days, when there was a lot of sort of amateur interaction over computers, you can now get various hacking kits, how-to-hack books. And on the left there is a platform from Evolution Robotics, where you put a PC on, and you program this thing with a GUI to wander around your house and do various stuff. And then there's a higher price point sort of robot toys — the Sony Aibo. And on the right there, is one that the NEC developed, the PaPeRo, which I don't think they're going to release. But nevertheless, those sorts of things are out there.And we've seen, over the last two or three years, lawn-mowing robots, Husqvarna on the bottom, Friendly Robotics on top there, an Israeli company. And then in the last 12 months or so we've started to see a bunch of home-cleaning robots appear. The top left one is a very nice home-cleaning robot from a company called Dyson, in the U.K. Except it was so expensive — 3,500 dollars — they didn't release it.But at the bottom left, you see Electrolux, which is on sale. Another one from Karcher. At the bottom right is one that I built in my lab about 10 years ago, and we finally turned that into a product. And let me just show you that. We're going to give this away I think, Chris said, after the talk. This is a robot that you can go out and buy, and that will clean up your floor. And it starts off sort of just going around in ever-increasing circles. If it hits something — you people see that? Now it's doing wall-following, it's following around my feet to clean up around me. Let's see, let's — oh, who stole my Rice Krispies? They stole my Rice Krispies! (Laughter) Don't worry, relax, no, relax, it's a robot, it's smart! (Laughter) See, the three-year-old kids, they don't worry about it. It's grown-ups that get really upset. (Laughter) We'll just put some crap here. (Laughter) Okay. (Laughter) I don't know if you see — so, I put a bunch of Rice Krispies there, I put some pennies, let's just shoot it at that, see if it cleans up. Yeah, OK. So — we'll leave that for later. (Applause)Part of the trick was building a better cleaning mechanism, actually; the intelligence on board was fairly simple. And that's true with a lot of robots. We've all, I think, become, sort of computational chauvinists, and think that computation is everything, but the mechanics still matter. Here's another robot, the PackBot, that we've been building for a bunch of years. It's a military surveillance robot, to go in ahead of troops — looking at caves, for instance. But we had to make it fairly robust, much more robust than the robots we build in our labs. (Laughter) On board that robot is a PC running Linux. It can withstand a 400G shock. The robot has local intelligence: it can flip itself over, can get itself into communication range, can go upstairs by itself, et cetera. Okay, so it's doing local navigation there. A soldier gives it a command to go upstairs, and it does. That was not a controlled descent. (Laughter) Now it's going to head off. And the big breakthrough for these robots, really, was September 11th. We had the robots down at the World Trade Center late that evening. Couldn't do a lot in the main rubble pile, things were just too — there was nothing left to do. But we did go into all the surrounding buildings that had been evacuated, and searched for possible survivors in the buildings that were too dangerous to go into. Let's run this video. Reporter: ...battlefield companions are helping to reduce the combat risks. Nick Robertson has that story. Rodney Brooks: Can we have another one of these? Okay, good. So, this is a corporal who had seen a robot two weeks previously. He's sending robots into caves, looking at what's going on. The robot's being totally autonomous. The worst thing that's happened in the cave so far was one of the robots fell down ten meters.So one year ago, the US military didn't have these robots. Now they're on active duty in Afghanistan every day. And that's one of the reasons they say a robot invasion is happening. There's a sea change happening in how — where technology's going. Thanks. And over the next couple of months, we're going to be sending robots in production down producing oil wells to get that last few years of oil out of the ground. Very hostile environments, 150˚ C, 10,000 PSI. Autonomous robots going down, doing this sort of work. But robots like this, they're a little hard to program. How, in the future, are we going to program our robots and make them easier to use? And I want to actually use a robot here — a robot named Chris — stand up. Yeah. Okay. Come over here. Now notice, he thinks robots have to be a bit stiff. He sort of does that. But I'm going to — Chris Anderson: I'm just British. RB: Oh. (Laughter) (Applause) I'm going to show this robot a task. It's a very complex task. Now notice, he nodded there, he was giving me some indication he was understanding the flow of communication. And if I'd said something completely bizarre he would have looked askance at me, and regulated the conversation. So now I brought this up in front of him. I'd looked at his eyes, and I saw his eyes looked at this bottle top. And I'm doing this task here, and he's checking up. His eyes are going back and forth up to me, to see what I'm looking at — so we've got shared attention. And so I do this task, and he looks, and he looks to me to see what's happening next. And now I'll give him the bottle, and we'll see if he can do the task. Can you do that? (Laughter) Okay. He's pretty good. Yeah. Good, good, good. I didn't show you how to do that. Now see if you can put it back together. (Laughter) And he thinks a robot has to be really slow. Good robot, that's good.So we saw a bunch of things there. We saw when we're interacting, we're trying to show someone how to do something, we direct their visual attention. The other thing communicates their internal state to us, whether he's understanding or not, regulates a social interaction. There was shared attention looking at the same sort of thing, and recognizing socially communicated reinforcement at the end. And we've been trying to put that into our lab robots because we think this is how you're going to want to interact with robots in the future. I just want to show you one technical diagram here. The most important thing for building a robot that you can interact with socially is its visual attention system. Because what it pays attention to is what it's seeing and interacting with, and what you're understanding what it's doing. So in the videos I'm about to show you, you're going to see a visual attention system on a robot which has — it looks for skin tone in HSV space, so it works across all human colorings. It looks for highly saturated colors, from toys. And it looks for things that move around. And it weights those together into an attention window, and it looks for the highest-scoring place — the stuff where the most interesting stuff is happening — and that is what its eyes then segue to. And it looks right at that. At the same time, some top-down sort of stuff: might decide that it's lonely and look for skin tone, or might decide that it's bored and look for a toy to play with. And so these weights change.And over here on the right, this is what we call the Steven Spielberg memorial module. Did people see the movie "AI"? (Audience: Yes.)RB: Yeah, it was really bad, but —remember, especially when Haley Joel Osment, the little robot, looked at the blue fairy for 2,000 years without taking his eyes off it? Well, this gets rid of that, because this is a habituation Gaussian that gets negative, and more and more intense as it looks at one thing. And it gets bored, so it will then look away at something else. So, once you've got that — and here's a robot, here's Kismet, looking around for a toy. You can tell what it's looking at. You can estimate its gaze direction from those eyeballs covering its camera, and you can tell when it's actually seeing the toy. And it's got a little bit of an emotional response here. (Laughter) But it's still going to pay attention if something more significant comes into its field of view — such as Cynthia Breazeal, the builder of this robot, from the right. It sees her, pays attention to her. Kismet has an underlying, three-dimensional emotional space, a vector space, of where it is emotionally. And at different places in that space, it expresses — can we have the volume on here? Can you hear that now, out there? (Audience: Yeah.)Kismet: Do you really think so? Do you really think so? Do you really think so?RB: So it's expressing its emotion through its face and the prosody in its voice. And when I was dealing with my robot over here, Chris, the robot, was measuring the prosody in my voice, and so we have the robot measure prosody for four basic messages that mothers give their children pre-linguistically. Here we've got naive subjects praising the robot:Voice: Nice robot. You're such a cute little robot. (Laughter) RB: And the robot's reacting appropriately.Voice: ...very good, Kismet. (Laughter)Voice: Look at my smile.RB: It smiles. She imitates the smile. This happens a lot. These are naive subjects. Here we asked them to get the robot's attention and indicate when they have the robot's attention.Voice: Hey, Kismet, ah, there it is.RB: So she realizes she has the robot's attention. Voice: Kismet, do you like the toy? Oh.RB: Now, here they're asked to prohibit the robot, and this first woman really pushes the robot into an emotional corner.Voice: No. No. You're not to do that. No. (Laughter)Not appropriate. No. No. (Laughter)RB: I'm going to leave it at that.We put that together. Then we put in turn taking. When we talk to someone, we talk. Then we sort of raise our eyebrows, move our eyes, give the other person the idea it's their turn to talk. And then they talk, and then we pass the baton back and forth between each other. So we put this in the robot. We got a bunch of naive subjects in, we didn't tell them anything about the robot, sat them down in front of the robot and said, talk to the robot. Now what they didn't know was, the robot wasn't understanding a word they said, and that the robot wasn't speaking English. It was just saying random English phonemes. And I want you to watch carefully, at the beginning of this, where this person, Ritchie, who happened to talk to the robot for 25 minutes — (Laughter) — says, "I want to show you something. I want to show you my watch." And he brings the watch center, into the robot's field of vision, points to it, gives it a motion cue, and the robot looks at the watch quite successfully. We don't know whether he understood or not that the robot — Notice the turn-taking. Ritchie: OK, I want to show you something. OK, this is a watch that my girlfriend gave me. Robot: Oh, cool. Ritchie: Yeah, look, it's got a little blue light in it too. I almost lost it this week. (Laughter) RB: So it's making eye contact with him, following his eyes. Ritchie: Can you do the same thing? Robot: Yeah, sure. RB: And they successfully have that sort of communication.And here's another aspect of the sorts of things that Chris and I were doing. This is another robot, Cog. They first make eye contact, and then, when Christie looks over at this toy, the robot estimates her gaze direction and looks at the same thing that she's looking at. (Laughter) So we're going to see more and more of this sort of robot over the next few years in labs. But then the big questions, two big questions that people ask me are: if we make these robots more and more human-like, will we accept them, will we — will they need rights eventually? And the other question people ask me is, will they want to take over? (Laughter) And on the first — you know, this has been a very Hollywood theme with lots of movies. You probably recognize these characters here — where in each of these cases, the robots want more respect. Well, do you ever need to give robots respect? They're just machines, after all. But I think, you know, we have to accept that we are just machines. After all, that's certainly what modern molecular biology says about us. You don't see a description of how, you know, Molecule A, you know, comes up and docks with this other molecule. And it's moving forward, you know, propelled by various charges, and then the soul steps in and tweaks those molecules so that they connect. It's all mechanistic. We are mechanism. If we are machines, then in principle at least, we should be able to build machines out of other stuff, which are just as alive as we are. But I think for us to admit that, we have to give up on our special-ness, in a certain way. And we've had the retreat from special-ness under the barrage of science and technology many times over the last few hundred years, at least. 500 years ago we had to give up the idea that we are the center of the universe when the earth started to go around the sun; 150 years ago, with Darwin, we had to give up the idea we were different from animals. And to imagine — you know, it's always hard for us. Recently we've been battered with the idea that maybe we didn't even have our own creation event, here on earth, which people didn't like much. And then the human genome said, maybe we only have 35,000 genes. And that was really — people didn't like that, we've got more genes than that. We don't like to give up our special-ness, so, you know, having the idea that robots could really have emotions, or that robots could be living creatures — I think is going to be hard for us to accept. But we're going to come to accept it over the next 50 years or so.And the second question is, will the machines want to take over? And here the standard scenario is that we create these things, they grow, we nurture them, they learn a lot from us, and then they start to decide that we're pretty boring, slow. They want to take over from us. And for those of you that have teenagers, you know what that's like. (Laughter) But Hollywood extends it to the robots. And the question is, you know, will someone accidentally build a robot that takes over from us? And that's sort of like this lone guy in the backyard, you know — "I accidentally built a 747." I don't think that's going to happen. And I don't think — (Laughter) — I don't think we're going to deliberately build robots that we're uncomfortable with. We'll — you know, they're not going to have a super bad robot. Before that has to come to be a mildly bad robot, and before that a not so bad robot. (Laughter) And we're just not going to let it go that way. (Laughter) So, I think I'm going to leave it at that: the robots are coming, we don't have too much to worry about, it's going to be a lot of fun, and I hope you all enjoy the journey over the next 50 years. (Applause)

(Applause)

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:19.958
Part of the trick was building a better cleaning mechanism, actually;

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:23.958
the intelligence on board was fairly simple.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
And that's true with a lot of robots.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:29.958
We've all, I think, become, sort of computational chauvinists,

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
and think that computation is everything,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
but the mechanics still matter.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
Here's another robot, the PackBot,

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
that we've been building for a bunch of years.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:44.958
It's a military surveillance robot, to go in ahead of troops --

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
looking at caves, for instance.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
But we had to make it fairly robust,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:56.958
much more robust than the robots we build in our labs.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
(Laughter)

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:09.958
On board that robot is a PC running Linux.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:15.958
It can withstand a 400G shock. The robot has local intelligence:

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:21.958
it can flip itself over, can get itself into communication range,

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
can go upstairs by itself, et cetera.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:35.958
Okay, so it's doing local navigation there.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:41.958
A soldier gives it a command to go upstairs, and it does.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
That was not a controlled descent.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
(Laughter)

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
Now it's going to head off.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:54.958
And the big breakthrough for these robots, really, was September 11th.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:58.958
We had the robots down at the World Trade Center late that evening.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
Couldn't do a lot in the main rubble pile,

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
things were just too -- there was nothing left to do.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:09.958
But we did go into all the surrounding buildings that had been evacuated,

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
and searched for possible survivors in the buildings

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
that were too dangerous to go into.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
Let's run this video.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
Reporter: ...battlefield companions are helping to reduce the combat risks.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
Nick Robertson has that story.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
Rodney Brooks: Can we have another one of these?

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
Okay, good.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
So, this is a corporal who had seen a robot two weeks previously.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:45.958
He's sending robots into caves, looking at what's going on.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
The robot's being totally autonomous.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:51.958
The worst thing that's happened in the cave so far

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
was one of the robots fell down ten meters.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
So one year ago, the US military didn't have these robots.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
Now they're on active duty in Afghanistan every day.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
And that's one of the reasons they say a robot invasion is happening.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:13.958
There's a sea change happening in how -- where technology's going.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
Thanks.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
And over the next couple of months,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
we're going to be sending robots in production

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:25.958
down producing oil wells to get that last few years of oil out of the ground.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:29.958
Very hostile environments, 150˚ C, 10,000 PSI.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:33.958
Autonomous robots going down, doing this sort of work.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
But robots like this, they're a little hard to program.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
How, in the future, are we going to program our robots

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
and make them easier to use?

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
And I want to actually use a robot here --

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:48.958
a robot named Chris -- stand up. Yeah. Okay.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:54.958
Come over here. Now notice, he thinks robots have to be a bit stiff.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
He sort of does that. But I'm going to --

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
Chris Anderson: I'm just British. RB: Oh.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
(Laughter)

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
(Applause)

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
I'm going to show this robot a task. It's a very complex task.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
Now notice, he nodded there, he was giving me some indication

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
he was understanding the flow of communication.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
And if I'd said something completely bizarre

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
he would have looked askance at me, and regulated the conversation.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
So now I brought this up in front of him.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:24.958
I'd looked at his eyes, and I saw his eyes looked at this bottle top.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
And I'm doing this task here, and he's checking up.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
His eyes are going back and forth up to me, to see what I'm looking at --

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
so we've got shared attention.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
And so I do this task, and he looks, and he looks to me

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:38.958
to see what's happening next. And now I'll give him the bottle,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
and we'll see if he can do the task. Can you do that?

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
(Laughter)

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:47.958
Okay. He's pretty good. Yeah. Good, good, good.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
I didn't show you how to do that.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
Now see if you can put it back together.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
(Laughter)

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:54.958
And he thinks a robot has to be really slow.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
Good robot, that's good.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
So we saw a bunch of things there.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
We saw when we're interacting,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:06.958
we're trying to show someone how to do something, we direct their visual attention.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:10.958
The other thing communicates their internal state to us,

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
whether he's understanding or not, regulates a social interaction.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
There was shared attention looking at the same sort of thing,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958
and recognizing socially communicated reinforcement at the end.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
And we've been trying to put that into our lab robots

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:26.958
because we think this is how you're going to want to interact with robots in the future.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
I just want to show you one technical diagram here.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:32.958
The most important thing for building a robot that you can interact with socially

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
is its visual attention system.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
Because what it pays attention to is what it's seeing

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
and interacting with, and what you're understanding what it's doing.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
So in the videos I'm about to show you,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:47.958
you're going to see a visual attention system on a robot

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
which has -- it looks for skin tone in HSV space,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
so it works across all human colorings.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
It looks for highly saturated colors, from toys.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
And it looks for things that move around.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
And it weights those together into an attention window,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
and it looks for the highest-scoring place --

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
the stuff where the most interesting stuff is happening --

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:10.958
and that is what its eyes then segue to.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
And it looks right at that.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
At the same time, some top-down sort of stuff:

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
might decide that it's lonely and look for skin tone,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
or might decide that it's bored and look for a toy to play with.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
And so these weights change.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
And over here on the right,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
this is what we call the Steven Spielberg memorial module.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
Did people see the movie "AI"? (Audience: Yes.)

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
RB: Yeah, it was really bad, but --

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
remember, especially when Haley Joel Osment, the little robot,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
looked at the blue fairy for 2,000 years without taking his eyes off it?

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Well, this gets rid of that,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:46.958
because this is a habituation Gaussian that gets negative,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
and more and more intense as it looks at one thing.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
And it gets bored, so it will then look away at something else.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:56.958
So, once you've got that -- and here's a robot, here's Kismet,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
looking around for a toy. You can tell what it's looking at.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:05.958
You can estimate its gaze direction from those eyeballs covering its camera,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
and you can tell when it's actually seeing the toy.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
And it's got a little bit of an emotional response here.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:11.958
(Laughter)

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
But it's still going to pay attention

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:17.958
if something more significant comes into its field of view --

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
such as Cynthia Breazeal, the builder of this robot, from the right.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:26.958
It sees her, pays attention to her.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.958
Kismet has an underlying, three-dimensional emotional space,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
a vector space, of where it is emotionally.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:38.958
And at different places in that space, it expresses --

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
can we have the volume on here?

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
Can you hear that now, out there? (Audience: Yeah.)

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:48.958
Kismet: Do you really think so? Do you really think so?

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
Do you really think so?

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
RB: So it's expressing its emotion through its face

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
and the prosody in its voice.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:02.958
And when I was dealing with my robot over here,

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
Chris, the robot, was measuring the prosody in my voice,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:10.958
and so we have the robot measure prosody for four basic messages

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:14.958
that mothers give their children pre-linguistically.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
Here we've got naive subjects praising the robot:

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
Voice: Nice robot.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
You're such a cute little robot.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
(Laughter)

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
RB: And the robot's reacting appropriately.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:32.958
Voice: ...very good, Kismet.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
(Laughter)

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
Voice: Look at my smile.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
RB: It smiles. She imitates the smile. This happens a lot.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
These are naive subjects.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
Here we asked them to get the robot's attention

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
and indicate when they have the robot's attention.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:54.958
Voice: Hey, Kismet, ah, there it is.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:58.958
RB: So she realizes she has the robot's attention.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:05.958
Voice: Kismet, do you like the toy? Oh.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
RB: Now, here they're asked to prohibit the robot,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:12.958
and this first woman really pushes the robot into an emotional corner.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:17.958
Voice: No. No. You're not to do that. No.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
(Laughter)

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:26.958
Not appropriate. No. No.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
(Laughter)

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
RB: I'm going to leave it at that.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
We put that together. Then we put in turn taking.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
When we talk to someone, we talk.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:40.958
Then we sort of raise our eyebrows, move our eyes,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
give the other person the idea it's their turn to talk.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:47.958
And then they talk, and then we pass the baton back and forth between each other.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
So we put this in the robot.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
We got a bunch of naive subjects in,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
we didn't tell them anything about the robot,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
sat them down in front of the robot and said, talk to the robot.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
Now what they didn't know was,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
the robot wasn't understanding a word they said,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
and that the robot wasn't speaking English.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
It was just saying random English phonemes.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
And I want you to watch carefully, at the beginning of this,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:10.958
where this person, Ritchie, who happened to talk to the robot for 25 minutes --

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
(Laughter)

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
-- says, "I want to show you something.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
I want to show you my watch."

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:21.958
And he brings the watch center, into the robot's field of vision,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
points to it, gives it a motion cue,

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
and the robot looks at the watch quite successfully.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
We don't know whether he understood or not that the robot --

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
Notice the turn-taking.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
Ritchie: OK, I want to show you something. OK, this is a watch

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
that my girlfriend gave me.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
Robot: Oh, cool.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:43.958
Ritchie: Yeah, look, it's got a little blue light in it too. I almost lost it this week.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:48.958
(Laughter)

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
RB: So it's making eye contact with him, following his eyes.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
Ritchie: Can you do the same thing? Robot: Yeah, sure.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
RB: And they successfully have that sort of communication.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:59.958
And here's another aspect of the sorts of things that Chris and I were doing.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
This is another robot, Cog.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:07.958
They first make eye contact, and then, when Christie looks over at this toy,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
the robot estimates her gaze direction

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
and looks at the same thing that she's looking at.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:12.958
(Laughter)

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
So we're going to see more and more of this sort of robot

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
over the next few years in labs.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:22.958
But then the big questions, two big questions that people ask me are:

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
if we make these robots more and more human-like,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:29.958
will we accept them, will we -- will they need rights eventually?

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
And the other question people ask me is, will they want to take over?

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:33.958
(Laughter)

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
And on the first -- you know, this has been a very Hollywood theme

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
with lots of movies. You probably recognize these characters here --

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:43.958
where in each of these cases, the robots want more respect.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
Well, do you ever need to give robots respect?

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
They're just machines, after all.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:53.958
But I think, you know, we have to accept that we are just machines.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:58.958
After all, that's certainly what modern molecular biology says about us.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
You don't see a description of how, you know,

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:05.958
Molecule A, you know, comes up and docks with this other molecule.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
And it's moving forward, you know, propelled by various charges,

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.958
and then the soul steps in and tweaks those molecules so that they connect.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
It's all mechanistic. We are mechanism.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
If we are machines, then in principle at least,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:22.958
we should be able to build machines out of other stuff,

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
which are just as alive as we are.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
But I think for us to admit that,

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
we have to give up on our special-ness, in a certain way.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
And we've had the retreat from special-ness

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
under the barrage of science and technology many times

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
over the last few hundred years, at least.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
500 years ago we had to give up the idea

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
that we are the center of the universe

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
when the earth started to go around the sun;

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:50.958
150 years ago, with Darwin, we had to give up the idea we were different from animals.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:53.958
And to imagine -- you know, it's always hard for us.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.958
Recently we've been battered with the idea that maybe

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
we didn't even have our own creation event, here on earth,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:01.958
which people didn't like much. And then the human genome said,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
maybe we only have 35,000 genes. And that was really --

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
people didn't like that, we've got more genes than that.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.958
We don't like to give up our special-ness, so, you know,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
having the idea that robots could really have emotions,

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
or that robots could be living creatures --

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
I think is going to be hard for us to accept.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:20.958
But we're going to come to accept it over the next 50 years or so.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
And the second question is, will the machines want to take over?

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:28.958
And here the standard scenario is that we create these things,

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:31.958
they grow, we nurture them, they learn a lot from us,

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:35.958
and then they start to decide that we're pretty boring, slow.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
They want to take over from us.

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:40.958
And for those of you that have teenagers, you know what that's like.

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:41.958
(Laughter)

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:44.958
But Hollywood extends it to the robots.

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
And the question is, you know,

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:51.958
will someone accidentally build a robot that takes over from us?

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.958
And that's sort of like this lone guy in the backyard,

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
you know -- "I accidentally built a 747."

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
I don't think that's going to happen.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:01.958
And I don't think --

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:02.958
(Laughter)

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:05.958
-- I don't think we're going to deliberately build robots

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:07.958
that we're uncomfortable with.

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:09.958
We'll -- you know, they're not going to have a super bad robot.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:12.958
Before that has to come to be a mildly bad robot,

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:14.958
and before that a not so bad robot.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:15.958
(Laughter)

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:17.958
And we're just not going to let it go that way.

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:18.958
(Laughter)

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:24.958
So, I think I'm going to leave it at that: the robots are coming,

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:27.958
we don't have too much to worry about, it's going to be a lot of fun,

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:31.958
and I hope you all enjoy the journey over the next 50 years.

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:33.958
(Applause)

title: Things I've learned in my life so far
transcript: I was here about four years ago, talking about the relationship of design and happiness. At the very end of it, I showed a list under that title. I learned very few things in addition since (Laughter) — but made a whole number of them into projects since. These are inflatable monkeys in every city in Scotland: "Everybody always thinks they are right." They were combined in the media. "Drugs are fun in the beginning but become a drag later on." We're doing changing media. This is a projection that can see the viewer as the viewer walks by. You can't help but actually ripping that spider web apart. All of these things are pieces of graphic design. We do them for our clients. They are commissioned. I would never have the money to actually pay for the installment or pay for all the billboards or the production of these, so there's always a client attached to them. These are 65,000 coat hangers in a street that's lined with fashion stores. "Worrying solves nothing." "Money does not make me happy" appeared first as double-page spreads in a magazine. The printer lost the file, didn't tell us. When the magazine — actually, when I got the subscription — it was 12 following pages. It said, "Money does does make me happy." And a friend of mine in Austria felt so sorry for me that he talked the largest casino owner in Linz into letting us wrap his building. So this is the big pedestrian zone in Linz. It just says "Money," and if you look down the side street, it says, "does not make me happy." We had a show that just came down last week in New York. We steamed up the windows permanently, and every hour we had a different designer come in and write these things that they've learned into the steam in the window. Everybody participated — Milton Glaser, Massimo Vignelli. Singapore was quite in discussion. This is a little spot that we filmed there that's to be displayed on the large JumboTrons in Singapore. And, of course, it's one that's dear to my heart, because all of these sentiments — some banal, some a bit more profound — all originally had come out of my diary. And I do go often into the diary and check if I wanted to change something about the situation. If it's — see it for a long enough time, I actually do something about it. And the very last one is a billboard. This is our roof in New York, the roof of the studio. This is newsprint plus stencils that lie on the newsprint. We let that lie around in the sun. As you all know, newsprint yellows significantly in the sun. After a week, we took the stencils and the leaves off, shipped the newsprints to Lisbon to a very sunny spot, so on day one the billboard said, "Complaining is silly. Either act or forget." Three days later it faded, and a week later, no more complaining anywhere. (Laughter) Thank you so much. (Applause)
