00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
is the work of some scientists from UCLA.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
This kind of alphabet soup is a new way to mark proteins --

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
not only by color but literally by alphabet letters.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
So they construct it, and they can construct all kinds of forms

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
at the nanoscale. This is the work of design students

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
from the Royal College of Arts in London

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
that have been working together with their tutor, Tony Dunne,

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
and with a bunch of scientists around Great Britain

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
on the possibilities of nanotechnology for design in the future.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
New sensing elements on the body --

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
you can grow hairs on your nails,

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
and therefore grab some of the particles from another person.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:13.958
They seem very, very obsessed

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
with finding out more about the ideal mate.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:20.958
So they're working on enhancing everything: touch, smell --

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
everything they can, in order to find the perfect mate.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
Very interesting. This is a typeface designer

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:30.958
from Israel who has designed -- he calls them "typosperma."

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
He's thinking -- of course it's all a concept --

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:37.958
of injecting typefaces into spermatozoa,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
I don't know how to say it in English -- spermatazoi --

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:44.958
in order to make them become -- to almost have a song

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:51.958
or a whole poem written with every ejaculation. (Laughter)

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
I tell you, designers are quite fantastic, you know.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
So, tissue design.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
In this case too, you have a mixture of scientists and designers.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:03.958
This here is part of the same lab at the Royal College of Arts.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
The RCA is really quite an amazing school from that viewpoint.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
One of the assignments for a year was to work with in-vitro meat.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
You know that already you can grow meat in vitro.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
In Australia they did it -- this research company, called SymbioticA.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:19.958
But the problem is that it's a really ugly patty.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
And so, the assignment to the students was,

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
how should the steak of tomorrow be?

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
When you don't have to kill cows and it can have any shape,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:27.958
what should it be like?

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
So this particular student, James King,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
went around the beautiful English countryside,

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
picked the best, best cow that he could see,

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
and then put her in the MRI machine.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:41.958
Then, he took the scans of the best organs and made the meat --

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
of course, this is done with a Japanese resins food maker,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
but you know, in the future it could be made better --

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
which reproduces the best MRI scan of the best cow he could find.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:55.958
Instead, this element here is much more banal.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
Something that you know can be done already

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:01.958
is to grow bone tissue, so that you can make a wedding ring

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
out of the bone tissue of your loved one -- literally.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:07.958
So, this is indeed made of human bone tissue.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
This is SymbioticA, and they've been working --

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
they were the first ones to do this in-vitro meat --

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
and now they've also done an in-vitro coat, a leather coat.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:19.958
It's miniscule, but it's a real coat. It's shaped like one.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
So, we'll be able to really not have any excuse

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
to be wearing everything leather in the future.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
One of the most important topics of the show -- you know,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
as anything in our life today,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
we can look at it from many, many different viewpoints,

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:33.958
and at different levels.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
One of the most interesting and most important concepts

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
is the idea of scale. We change scale very often:

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
we change resolution of screens, and

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
we're not really fazed by it, we do it very comfortably.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
So you go, even in the exhibition,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
from the idea of nanotechnology and the nanoscale

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
to the manipulation of really great amounts of data --

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
the mapping and tagging of the universe and of the world.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
In this particular case a section will be devoted

00:07:58.958 --> 00:07:59.958
to information design.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:03.958
You see here the work of Ben Fry. This is "Human vs. Chimps" --

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
the few chromosomes that distinguish us from chimps.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
It was a beautiful visualization that he did for Seed magazine.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
And here's the whole code of Pac-Man, visualized

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:14.958
with all the go-to, go-back-to,

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
also made into a beautiful choreography.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
And then also graphs by scientists,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
this beautiful diagraph of protein homology.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
Scientists are starting to also consider aesthetics.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
We were discussing with Keith Shrubb* this morning

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
the fact that many scientists

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
tend not to use anything beautiful in their presentations,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
otherwise they're afraid of being considered dumb blondes.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
So they pick the worst background

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:42.958
from any kind of PowerPoint presentation, the worst typeface.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
It's only recently that this kind of marriage

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:49.958
between design and science is producing some of the first "pretty" --

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
if we can say so -- scientific presentations.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
Another aspect of contemporary design

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
that I think is mind-opening, promising

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:58.958
and will really be the future of design,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
is the idea of collective design.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:04.958
You know, the whole XO laptop, from One Laptop per Child,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:08.958
is based on the idea of collaboration and mash and networking.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
So, the more the merrier.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
The more computers, the stronger the signal,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:16.958
and children work on the interface so that it's all based

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
on doing things together, tasks together.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
So the idea of collective design

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
is something that will become even bigger in the future,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
and this is chosen as an example.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
Related to the idea of collective design and to the new balance

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:35.958
between the individual and the collectiveness, collectivity

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
is the idea of existence maximum.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
That's a term that I coined a few years ago

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
while I was thinking of how pressed we are together,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
and at the same time how these small objects,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
like the Walkman first and then the iPod,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
create bubbles of space around us that enable us

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
to have a metaphysical space

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
that is much bigger than our physical space.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:59.958
You can be in the subway and you can be completely isolated

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
and have your own room in your iPod.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
And this is the work of several designers

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:08.958
that really enhance the idea of solitude and expansion

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
by means of various techniques.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:14.958
This is a spa telephone. The idea is that it's become so difficult

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:15.958
to have a private conversation anywhere

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
that you go to the spa, you have a massage, you have a facial,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
maybe a rub, and then you have this beautiful pool

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
with this perfect temperature, and you can have

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
this isolation tank phone conversation

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
with whomever you've been wanting to talk with for a long time.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
And same thing here, Social Tele-presence.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
It's actually already used by the military a little bit,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
but it's the idea of being able to be somewhere else

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
with your senses while you're removed from it physically.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
And this is called Blind Date. It's a [unclear],

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
so if you're too shy to be really at the date,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:46.958
you can stay at a distance with your flowers

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
and somebody else reenacts the date for you.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
Rapid manufacturing is another big area

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:57.958
in which technology and design are, I think,

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:01.958
bound to change the world. You've heard about it before many times.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
Rapid manufacturing is a computer file

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
sent directly from the computer to the manufacturing machine.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:10.958
It used to be called rapid prototyping, rapid modeling.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
It started out in the '80s, but at the beginning

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
it was machines carving out of a foam block

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
a model that was very, very fragile,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
and could not have any real use.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:24.958
Slowly but surely, the materials became better -- better resins.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
Techniques became better -- not only carving

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:32.958
but also stereolithography and laser -- solidifying all kinds of resins,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:36.958
whether in powder or in liquid form. And the vats became bigger,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
to the point that now we can have actual chairs

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
made by rapid manufacturing.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
It takes seven days today to manufacture a chair,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
but you know what? One day it will take seven hours.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
And then the dream is that you'll be able to, from home,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
customize your chair. You know, companies and designers

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
will be designing the matrix or the margins

00:11:55.958 --> 00:12:00.958
that respect both solidity and brand, and design identity.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
And then you can send it to the Kinko's store at the corner

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
and go get your chair. Now, the implications of this are enormous,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
not only regarding the participation of the final buyer

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
in the design process, but also no tracking,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
no warehousing, no wasted materials.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
Also, I can imagine many design manufacturers

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
will have to retool their own business plans

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:24.958
and maybe invest in this Kinko's store. But it really is a big change.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
And here I'm showing a picture that was in Wired Magazine --

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
you know, the Artifacts of the Future section that I love so much --

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
that shows you can have your desktop 3D printer

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
and print your own basketball.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:38.958
But here instead are examples, you can already 3D-print textiles,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
which is very interesting.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
This is just a really nice touch -- it's called slow prototyping.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:48.958
It's a designer that put 10,000 bees at work and they built this vase.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
They had a particular shape that they had to stay in.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:52.958
Mapping and tagging.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
As the capacity of computers becomes really, really big,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
and the capacity of our mind not that much bigger,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
we find that we need to tag as much as we can what we do

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
in order to then retrace our path.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
Also, we do it in order to share with other people.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
Again, this communal sense of experience

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
that seems to be so important today.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
So, various ways to map and tag

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
are also the work of many designers nowadays.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.958
Also, the senses -- designers and scientists all work on trying to expand

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
our senses capabilities so that we can achieve more.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
And also animal senses in a way.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:35.958
This particular object that many people love so much

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
is actually based on kind of a scientific experiment --

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
the fact that bees have a very strong olfactory sense,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
and so -- much like dogs that can smell certain kinds of skin cancer --

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:49.958
bees can be trained by Pavlovian reflex

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
to detect one type of cancer, and also pregnancy.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
And so this student at the RCA

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
designed this beautiful blown-glass object

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
where the bees move from one chamber to the other

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
if they detect that particular smell

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
that signifies, in this case, pregnancy.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
Another shape is made for cancer.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:10.958
Design for Debate is a very interesting new endeavor

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
that designers have really shaped for themselves.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
Some designers don't design objects, products,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:17.958
things that we're going to actually use,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:21.958
but rather, they design scenarios that are object-based.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
They're still very useful.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
They help companies and other designers think better about the future.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
And usually they are accompanied by videos.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
This is quite beautiful. It's Dunne and Raby, "All the Robots."

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
Those are a series of robots that are meant to be taken care of.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
We always think that robots will take care of us,

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
and instead they designed these robots that are very, very needy.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
You need to take one in your arms and look at it in the eyes

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
for about five minutes before it does something.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
Another one gets really, really nervous if you get in to the room,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
and starts shaking, so you have to calm it down.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
So it's really a way to make us think more

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
about what robots mean to us.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:00.958
Noam Toran and "Accessories for Lonely Men":

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
the idea is that when you lose your loved one

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
or you go through a bad breakup,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
what you miss the most are those annoying things

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
that you used to hate when you were with the other person.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
So he designed all these series of accessories.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:17.958
This one is something that takes away the sheets from you at night.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
Then there's another one that breathes on your neck.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
There's another one that throws plates and breaks them.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:26.958
So it's just this idea of what we really miss in life.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
Elio Caccavale: he took the idea

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
of those dolls that explain leukemia.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
He's working on dolls that explain xenotransplantation,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:41.958
and also the spider gene into the goat, from a few years ago.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
He's working for the exhibition on a whole series of dolls

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
that explain to children where babies come from today.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:50.958
Because it's not anymore Mom, Dad, the flowers and the bees,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.958
and then there's the baby. No, it can be two moms, three dads,

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
in-vitro -- there's the whole idea

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
of how babies can be made today that has changed.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
So it's a series of dolls that he's working on right now.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:05.958
One of the most beautiful things

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
is that designers really work on life,

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
even though they take technology into account.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
And many designers have been working recently

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
on the idea of death and mourning,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
and what we can do about it today with new technologies.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
Or how we should behave about it with new technologies.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
These three objects over there are hard drives

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
with a Bluetooth connection. But they're in reality

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
very, very beautiful sculpted artifacts

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
that contain the whole desktop and computer memory

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
of somebody who passed away.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
So instead of having only the pictures,

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
you will be able to put this object next to the computer

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
and all of a sudden have, you know,

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
Gertrude's whole life and all of her files

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:46.958
and her address book come alive.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
And this is even better. This is Auger-Loizeau, "AfterLife."

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
It's the idea that some people don't believe in an afterlife.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
So to give them something tangible that shows that

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:59.958
there is something after death, they take the gastric juices

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
of people who passed away and concentrate them,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
and put them into a battery that can actually be used

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:08.958
to power flashlights. They also go -- you know, sex toys, whatever.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:12.958
It's quite amazing how these things can make you smile,

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
can make you laugh, can make you cry sometimes.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
But I'm hoping that this particular exhibition

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:20.958
will be able to trace a new portrait of where design is going --

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
which is always, hopefully, a portrait a few years in advance

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:25.958
of where the world is going.

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:26.958
Thank you very much.

title: On glamour
transcript: You might be wondering why I'm wearing sunglasses, and one answer to that is, because I'm here to talk about glamour. So, we all think we know what glamour is. Here it is. It's glamorous movie stars, like Marlene Dietrich. And it comes in a male form, too — very glamorous. Not only can he shoot, drive, drink — you know, he drinks wine, there actually is a little wine in there — and of course, always wears a tuxedo. But I think that glamour actually has a much broader meaning — one that is true for the movie stars and the fictional characters, but also comes in other forms.A magazine? Well, it's certainly not this one. This is the least glamorous magazine on the newsstand — it's all about sex tips. Sex tips are not glamorous. And Drew Barrymore, for all her wonderful charm, is not glamorous either. But there is a glamour of industry. This is Margaret Bourke-White's — one of her pictures she did. Fantastic, glamorous pictures of steel mills and paper mills and all kinds of glamorous industrial places. And there's the mythic glamour of the garage entrepreneur. This is the Hewlett-Packard garage. We know everyone who starts a business in a garage ends up founding Hewlett-Packard. There's the glamour of physics. What could be more glamorous than understanding the entire universe, grand unification? And, by the way, it helps if you're Brian Greene — he has other kinds of glamour.And there is, of course, this glamour. This is very, very glamorous: the glamour of outer space — and not the alien-style glamour, but the nice, clean, early '60s version. So what do we mean by glamour? Well, one thing you can do if you want to know what glamour means is you can look in the dictionary. And it actually helps a lot more if you look in a very old dictionary, in this case the 1913 dictionary. Because for centuries, glamour had a very particular meaning, and the word was actually used differently from the way we think of it. You had "a" glamour. It wasn't glamour as a quality — you "cast a glamour." Glamour was a literal magic spell. Not a metaphorical one, the way we use it today, but a literal magic spell associated with witches and gypsies and to some extent, Celtic magic. And over the years, around the turn of the 20th century, it started to take on this other kind of deception — this definition for any artificial interest in, or association with, an object through which it appears delusively magnified or glorified. But still, glamour is an illusion. Glamour is a magic spell. And there's something dangerous about glamour throughout most of history. When the witches cast a magic spell on you, it was not in your self-interest — it was to get you to act against your interest.Well of course, in the 20th century, glamour came to have this different meaning associated with Hollywood. And this is Hedy Lamarr. Hedy Lamarr said, "Anyone can look glamorous, all you have to do is sit there and look stupid." (Laughter) But in fact, with all due respect to Hedy — about whom we'll hear more later — there's a lot more to it. There was a tremendous amount of technical achievement associated with creating this Hollywood glamour. There were scores of retouchers and lighting experts and make-up experts. You can go to the museum of Hollywood history in Hollywood and see Max Factor's special rooms that he painted different colors depending on the complexion of the star he was going to make up. So you've got this highly stylized portrait of something that was not entirely of this earth — it was a portrait of a star. And actually, we see glamorized photos of stars all the time — they call them false color.Glamour is a form of falsification, but falsification to achieve a particular purpose. It may be to illuminate the star; it may be to sell a film. And it involves a great deal of technique. It's not — glamour is not something — you don't wake up in the morning glamorous. I don't care who you are. Even Nicole Kidman doesn't wake up in the morning glamorous. There is a process of "idealization, glorification and dramatization," and it's not just the case for people. Glamour doesn't have to be people. Architectural photography — Julius Schulman, who has talked about transfiguration, took this fabulous, famous picture of the Kauffman House. Architectural photography is extremely glamorous. It puts you into this special, special world. This is Alex Ross's comic book art, which appears to be extremely realistic, as part of his style is he gives you a kind of realism in his comic art. Except that light doesn't work this way in the real world.When you stack people in rows, the ones in the background look smaller than the ones in the foreground — but not in the world of glamour. What glamour is all about — I took this from a blurb in the table of contents of New York magazine, which was telling us that glamour is back — glamour is all about transcending the everyday. And I think that that's starting to get at what the core that combines all sorts of glamour is. This is Filippino Lippi's 1543 portrait of Saint Apollonia. And I don't know who she is either, but this is the [16th] century equivalent of a supermodel. It's a very glamorous portrait. Why is it glamorous? It's glamorous, first, because she is beautiful — but that does not make you glamorous, that only makes you beautiful. She is graceful, she is mysterious and she is transcendent, and those are the central qualities of glamour. You don't see her eyes; they're looking downward. She's not looking away from you exactly, but you have to mentally imagine her world. She's encouraging you to contemplate this higher world to which she belongs, where she can be completely tranquil while holding the iron instruments of her death by torture. Mel Gibson's "Passion Of The Christ" — not glamorous. That's glamour: that's Michelangelo's "Pieta," where Mary is the same age as Jesus and they're both awfully happy and pleasant.Glamour invites us to live in a different world. It has to simultaneously be mysterious, a little bit distant — that's why, often in these glamour shots, the person is not looking at the audience, it's why sunglasses are glamorous — but also not so far above us that we can't identify with the person. In some sense, there has to be something like us. So as I say, in religious art, you know, God is not glamorous. God cannot be glamorous because God is omnipotent, omniscient — too far above us. And yet you will see in religious art, saints or the Virgin Mary will often be portrayed — not always — in glamorous forms. As I said earlier, glamour does not have to be about people, but it has to have this transcendent quality. What is it about Superman? Aside from Alex Ross's style, which is very glamorous, one thing about Superman is he makes you believe that a man can fly.Glamour is all about transcending this world and getting to an idealized, perfect place. And this is one reason that modes of transportation tend to be extremely glamorous. The less experience we have with them, the more glamorous they are. So you can do a glamorized picture of a car, but you can't do a glamorized picture of traffic. You can do a glamorized picture of an airplane, but not the inside. The notion is that it's going to transport you, and the story is not about, you know, the guy in front of you in the airplane, who has this nasty little kid, or the big cough. The story is about where you're arriving, or thinking about where you're arriving. And this sense of being transported is one reason that we have glamour styling. This sort of streamlining styling is not just glamorous because we associate it with movies of that period, but because, in it's streamlining, it transports us from the everyday.The same thing — arches are very glamorous. Arches with stained glass — even more glamorous. Staircases that curve away from you are glamorous. I happen to find that particular staircase picture very glamorous because, to me, it captures the whole promise of the academic contemplative life — but maybe that's because I went to Princeton. Anyway, skylines are super glamorous, city streets — not so glamorous. You know, when you get, actually to this town it has reality. The horizon, the open road, is very, very glamorous. There are few things more glamorous than the horizon — except, possibly, multiple horizons. Of course, here you don't feel the cold, or the heat — you just see the possibilities. In order to pull glamour off, you need this Renaissance quality of sprezzatura, which is a term coined by Castiglione in his book, "The Book Of The Courtier." There's the not-glamorous version of what it looks like today, after a few centuries.And sprezzatura is the art that conceals art. It makes things look effortless. You don't think about how Nicole Kidman is maneuvering that dress — she just looks completely natural. And I remember reading, after the Lara Croft movies, how Angelina Jolie would go home completely black and blue. Of course, they covered that with make-up, because Lara Croft did all those same stunts — but she doesn't get black and blue, because she has sprezzatura. "To conceal all art and make whatever is done or said appear to be without effort": And this is one of the critical aspects of glamour. Glamour is about editing. How do you create the sense of transcendence, the sense of evoking a perfect world? The sense of, you know, life could be better, I could join this — I could be a perfect person, I could join this perfect world. We don't tell you all the grubby details.Now, this was kindly lent to me by Jeff Bezos, from last year. This is underneath Jeff's desk. This is what the real world of computers, lamps, electrical appliances of all kinds, looks like. But if you look in a catalog — particularly a catalog of modern, beautiful objects for your home — it looks like this. There are no cords. Look next time you get these catalogs in your mail — you can usually figure out where they hid the cord. But there's always this illusion that if you buy this lamp, you will live in a world without cords. (Laughter) And the same thing is true of, if you buy this laptop or you buy this computer — and even in these wireless eras, you don't get to live in the world without cords. You have to have mystery and you have to have grace. And there she is — Grace. This is the most glamorous picture, I think, ever. Part of the thing is that, in "Rear Window," the question is, is she too glamorous to live in his world? And the answer is no, but of course it's really just a movie.Here's Hedy Lamarr again. And, you know, this kind of head covering is extremely glamorous because, like sunglasses, it conceals and reveals at the same time. Translucence is glamorous — that's why all these people wear pearls. It's why barware is glamorous. Glamour is translucent — not transparent, not opaque. It invites us into the world but it doesn't give us a completely clear picture. And I think if Grace Kelly is the most glamorous person, maybe a spiral staircase with glass block may be the most glamorous interior shot, because a spiral staircase is incredibly glamorous. It has that sense of going up and away, and yet you never think about how you would really trip if you were — particularly going down. And of course glass block has that sense of translucence. So, this session's supposed to be about pure pleasure but glamour's really partly about meaning. All individuals and all cultures have ideals that cannot possibly be realized in reality.They have contradictions, they uphold principles that are incommensurable with each other — whatever it is — and yet these ideals give meaning and purpose to our lives as cultures and as individuals. And the way we deal with that is we displace them — we put them into a golden world, an imagined world, an age of heroes, the world to come. And in the life of an individual, we often associate that with some object. The white picket fence, the perfect house. The perfect kitchen — no bills on the counter in the perfect kitchen. You know, you buy that Viking range, this is what your kitchen will look like. The perfect love life — symbolized by the perfect necklace, the perfect diamond ring. The perfect getaway in your perfect car. This is an interior design firm that is literally called Utopia. The perfect office — again, no cords, as far as I can tell. And certainly, no, it doesn't look a thing like my office. I mean, there's no paper on the desk. We want this golden world. And some people get rich enough, and if they have their ideals — in a sort of domestic sense, they get to acquire their perfect world.Dean Koontz built this fabulous home theater, which is — I don't think accidentally — in Art Deco style. That symbolizes this sense of being safe and at home. This is not always good, because what is your perfect world? What is your ideal, and also, what has been edited out? Is it something important? "The Matrix" is a movie that is all about glamour. I could do a whole talk on "The Matrix" and glamour. It was criticized for glamorizing violence, because, look — sunglasses and those long coats, and, of course, they could walk up walls and do all these kinds of things that are impossible in the real world. This is another Margaret Bourke-White photo. This is from Soviet Union. Attractive. I mean, look how happy the people are, and good-looking too. You know, we're marching toward Utopia.I'm not a fan of PETA, but I think this is a great ad. Because what they're doing is they're saying, your coat's not so glamorous, what's been edited out is something important. But actually, what's even more important than remembering what's been edited out is thinking, are the ideals good? Because glamour can be very totalitarian and deceptive. And it's not just a matter of glamorizing cleaning your floor. This is from "Triumph Of The Will" — brilliant editing to cut together things. There's a glamour shot. National Socialism is all about glamour. It was a very aesthetic ideology. It was all about cleaning up Germany, and the West, and the world, and ridding it of anything unglamorous. So glamour can be dangerous.I think glamour has a genuine appeal, has a genuine value. I'm not against glamour. But there's a kind of wonder in the stuff that gets edited away in the cords of life. And there is both a way to avoid the dangers of glamour and a way to broaden your appreciation of it. And that's to take Isaac Mizrahi's advice and confront the manipulation of it all, and sort of admit that manipulation is something that we enjoy, but also enjoy how it happens. And here's Hedy Lamarr. She's very glamorous but, you know, she invented spread-spectrum technology. So she's even more glamorous if you know that she really wasn't stupid, even though she thought she could look stupid.David Hockney talks about how the appreciation of this very glamorous painting is heightened if you think about the fact that it takes two weeks to paint this splash, which only took a fraction of a second to happen. There is a book out in the bookstore — it's called "Symphony In Steel," and it's about the stuff that's hidden under the skin of the Disney Center. And that has a fascination. It's not necessarily glamorous, but unveiling the glamour has an appeal. There's a wonderful book called "Crowns" that's all these glamour pictures of black women in their church hats. And there's a quote from one of these women, and she talks about, "As a little girl, I'd admire women at church with beautiful hats. They looked like beautiful dolls, like they'd just stepped out of a magazine. But I also knew how hard they worked all week. Sometimes under those hats there's a lot of joy and a lot of sorrow." And, actually, you get more appreciation for glamour when you realize what went into creating it. Thank you.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
You might be wondering why I'm wearing sunglasses,

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:18.958
and one answer to that is, because I'm here to talk about glamour.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:21.958
So, we all think we know what glamour is. Here it is.

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:24.958
It's glamorous movie stars, like Marlene Dietrich.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
And it comes in a male form, too --

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:28.958
very glamorous.

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:32.958
Not only can he shoot, drive, drink -- you know, he drinks wine,

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
there actually is a little wine in there --

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
and of course, always wears a tuxedo.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:41.958
But I think that glamour actually has a much broader meaning --

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:45.958
one that is true for the movie stars and the fictional characters,

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
but also comes in other forms.

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
A magazine?

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:51.958
Well, it's certainly not this one.

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:54.958
This is the least glamorous magazine on the newsstand -- it's all about sex tips.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
Sex tips are not glamorous.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.958
And Drew Barrymore, for all her wonderful charm,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
is not glamorous either.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
But there is a glamour of industry.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
This is Margaret Bourke-White's --

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
one of her pictures she did.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:10.958
Fantastic, glamorous pictures

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:14.958
of steel mills and paper mills and all kinds of glamorous industrial places.

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
And there's the mythic glamour

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
of the garage entrepreneur.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
This is the Hewlett-Packard garage.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:23.958
We know everyone who starts a business in a garage

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:26.958
ends up founding Hewlett-Packard.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
There's the glamour of physics.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
What could be more glamorous than understanding the entire universe,

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:34.958
grand unification? And, by the way, it helps if you're Brian Greene --

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
he has other kinds of glamour.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
And there is, of course, this glamour.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
This is very, very glamorous: the glamour of outer space --

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
and not the alien-style glamour,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:47.958
but the nice, clean, early '60s version.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
So what do we mean by glamour?

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:53.958
Well, one thing you can do if you want to know what glamour means

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:55.958
is you can look in the dictionary.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
And it actually helps a lot more if you look in a very old dictionary,

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
in this case the 1913 dictionary.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:05.958
Because for centuries, glamour had a very particular meaning,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:10.958
and the word was actually used differently from the way we think of it.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.958
You had "a" glamour.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
It wasn't glamour as a quality -- you "cast a glamour."

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:17.958
Glamour was a literal magic spell.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
Not a metaphorical one, the way we use it today,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:23.958
but a literal magic spell associated with witches and gypsies

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:26.958
and to some extent, Celtic magic.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:29.958
And over the years, around the turn of the 20th century,

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:35.958
it started to take on this other kind of deception --

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:40.958
this definition for any artificial interest in, or association with,

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:45.958
an object through which it appears delusively magnified or glorified.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
But still, glamour is an illusion.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
Glamour is a magic spell.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
And there's something dangerous about glamour

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:56.958
throughout most of history. When the witches cast a magic spell

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
on you, it was not in your self-interest --

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
it was to get you to act against your interest.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
Well of course, in the 20th century,

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:06.958
glamour came to have this different meaning associated with Hollywood.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
And this is Hedy Lamarr.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
Hedy Lamarr said, "Anyone can look glamorous,

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
all you have to do is sit there and look stupid." (Laughter)

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:18.958
But in fact, with all due respect to Hedy --

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:22.958
about whom we'll hear more later -- there's a lot more to it.

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
There was a tremendous amount of technical achievement

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
associated with creating this Hollywood glamour.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:31.958
There were scores of retouchers and lighting experts and make-up experts.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
You can go to the museum of Hollywood history in Hollywood

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
and see Max Factor's special rooms that he painted different colors

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:41.958
depending on the complexion of the star he was going to make up.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958
So you've got this highly stylized portrait of something

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
that was not entirely of this earth -- it was a portrait of a star.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:51.958
And actually, we see glamorized photos of stars all the time --

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
they call them false color.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:57.958
Glamour is a form of falsification,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
but falsification to achieve a particular purpose.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:04.958
It may be to illuminate the star; it may be to sell a film.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
And it involves a great deal of technique.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
It's not -- glamour is not something --

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
you don't wake up in the morning glamorous. I don't care who you are.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
Even Nicole Kidman doesn't wake up in the morning glamorous.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:18.958
There is a process of "idealization, glorification and dramatization,"

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
and it's not just the case for people.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
Glamour doesn't have to be people.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
Architectural photography --

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
Julius Schulman, who has talked about transfiguration,

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
took this fabulous, famous picture of the Kauffman House.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
Architectural photography is extremely glamorous.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:37.958
It puts you into this special, special world.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
This is Alex Ross's comic book art,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
which appears to be extremely realistic,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:47.958
as part of his style is he gives you a kind of realism in his comic art.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
Except that light doesn't work this way in the real world.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
When you stack people in rows,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
the ones in the background look smaller than the ones in the foreground --

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
but not in the world of glamour.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
What glamour is all about -- I took this from a blurb

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
in the table of contents of New York magazine,

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
which was telling us that glamour is back --

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
glamour is all about transcending the everyday.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
And I think that that's starting to get at what the core

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
that combines all sorts of glamour is.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:20.958
This is Filippino Lippi's 1543 portrait of Saint Apollonia.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
And I don't know who she is either,

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
but this is the [16th] century equivalent of a supermodel.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
It's a very glamorous portrait.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
Why is it glamorous?

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
It's glamorous, first, because she is beautiful --

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
but that does not make you glamorous,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
that only makes you beautiful.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:40.958
She is graceful, she is mysterious and she is transcendent,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
and those are the central qualities of glamour.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:46.958
You don't see her eyes; they're looking downward.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
She's not looking away from you exactly,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:52.958
but you have to mentally imagine her world.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:56.958
She's encouraging you to contemplate this higher world

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
to which she belongs, where she can be completely tranquil

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:03.958
while holding the iron instruments of her death by torture.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
Mel Gibson's "Passion Of The Christ" -- not glamorous.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
That's glamour:

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
that's Michelangelo's "Pieta," where Mary is the same age as Jesus

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
and they're both awfully happy and pleasant.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
Glamour invites us to live in a different world.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:21.958
It has to simultaneously be mysterious, a little bit distant --

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
that's why, often in these glamour shots,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
the person is not looking at the audience,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
it's why sunglasses are glamorous --

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:32.958
but also not so far above us that we can't identify with the person.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:36.958
In some sense, there has to be something like us.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
So as I say, in religious art, you know, God is not glamorous.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
God cannot be glamorous because God is omnipotent,

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
omniscient -- too far above us.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
And yet you will see in religious art, saints or the Virgin Mary

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
will often be portrayed -- not always -- in glamorous forms.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:54.958
As I said earlier, glamour does not have to be about people,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
but it has to have this transcendent quality.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
What is it about Superman?

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
Aside from Alex Ross's style, which is very glamorous,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
one thing about Superman is he makes you believe that a man can fly.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
Glamour is all about transcending this world

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:12.958
and getting to an idealized, perfect place.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:16.958
And this is one reason that modes of transportation

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
tend to be extremely glamorous.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
The less experience we have with them,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
the more glamorous they are.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
So you can do a glamorized picture of a car,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
but you can't do a glamorized picture of traffic.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:31.958
You can do a glamorized picture of an airplane, but not the inside.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
The notion is that it's going to transport you,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:37.958
and the story is not about, you know, the guy in front of you in the airplane,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
who has this nasty little kid, or the big cough.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
The story is about where you're arriving,

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
or thinking about where you're arriving.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
And this sense of being transported

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:51.958
is one reason that we have glamour styling.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:55.958
This sort of streamlining styling is not just glamorous

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:59.958
because we associate it with movies of that period, but because,

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
in it's streamlining, it transports us from the everyday.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
The same thing -- arches are very glamorous.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
Arches with stained glass -- even more glamorous.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
Staircases that curve away from you are glamorous.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
I happen to find that particular staircase picture very glamorous

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
because, to me, it captures the whole promise

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
of the academic contemplative life --

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
but maybe that's because I went to Princeton.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
Anyway, skylines are super glamorous,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
city streets -- not so glamorous.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
You know, when you get, actually to this town it has reality.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:33.958
The horizon, the open road, is very, very glamorous.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
There are few things more glamorous than the horizon --

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:40.958
except, possibly, multiple horizons.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:45.958
Of course, here you don't feel the cold, or the heat --

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
you just see the possibilities.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
In order to pull glamour off, you need this Renaissance quality

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:55.958
of sprezzatura, which is a term coined by Castiglione

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
in his book, "The Book Of The Courtier."

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
There's the not-glamorous version of what it looks like today,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
after a few centuries.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:07.958
And sprezzatura is the art that conceals art.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
It makes things look effortless.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:13.958
You don't think about how Nicole Kidman is maneuvering that dress --

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
she just looks completely natural.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
And I remember reading, after the Lara Croft movies,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:22.958
how Angelina Jolie would go home completely black and blue.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
Of course, they covered that with make-up,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
because Lara Croft did all those same stunts --

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:30.958
but she doesn't get black and blue, because she has sprezzatura.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:35.958
"To conceal all art and make whatever is done or said appear to be without effort":

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
And this is one of the critical aspects of glamour.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
Glamour is about editing.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
How do you create the sense of transcendence,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
the sense of evoking a perfect world?

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:49.958
The sense of, you know, life could be better, I could join this --

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
I could be a perfect person, I could join this perfect world.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
We don't tell you all the grubby details.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:58.958
Now, this was kindly lent to me by Jeff Bezos, from last year.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
This is underneath Jeff's desk.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
This is what the real world of computers,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:07.958
lamps, electrical appliances of all kinds, looks like.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
But if you look in a catalog --

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
particularly a catalog of modern, beautiful objects for your home --

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
it looks like this.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
There are no cords.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
Look next time you get these catalogs in your mail --

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
you can usually figure out where they hid the cord.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
But there's always this illusion that if you buy this lamp,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
you will live in a world without cords. (Laughter)

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
And the same thing is true of, if you buy this laptop

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
or you buy this computer -- and even in these wireless eras,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
you don't get to live in the world without cords.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
You have to have mystery and you have to have grace.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
And there she is -- Grace.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
This is the most glamorous picture, I think, ever.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
Part of the thing is that, in "Rear Window,"

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
the question is, is she too glamorous to live in his world?

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
And the answer is no, but of course it's really just a movie.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
Here's Hedy Lamarr again.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
And, you know, this kind of head covering is extremely glamorous

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:02.958
because, like sunglasses, it conceals and reveals at the same time.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
Translucence is glamorous --

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
that's why all these people wear pearls.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:10.958
It's why barware is glamorous. Glamour is translucent --

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
not transparent, not opaque.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
It invites us into the world

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.958
but it doesn't give us a completely clear picture.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
And I think if Grace Kelly is the most glamorous person,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:27.958
maybe a spiral staircase with glass block may be the most glamorous interior shot,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
because a spiral staircase is incredibly glamorous.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:34.958
It has that sense of going up and away,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
and yet you never think about how you would really trip

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
if you were -- particularly going down.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
And of course glass block has that sense of translucence.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.958
So, this session's supposed to be about pure pleasure

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
but glamour's really partly about meaning.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
All individuals and all cultures have ideals

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:56.958
that cannot possibly be realized in reality.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
They have contradictions,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
they uphold principles that are incommensurable with each other --

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
whatever it is -- and yet these ideals give meaning and purpose

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
to our lives as cultures and as individuals.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
And the way we deal with that is we displace them --

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
we put them into a golden world, an imagined world,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
an age of heroes, the world to come.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:21.958
And in the life of an individual, we often associate that with some object.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:25.958
The white picket fence, the perfect house.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
The perfect kitchen -- no bills on the counter in the perfect kitchen.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
You know, you buy that Viking range, this is what your kitchen will look like.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
The perfect love life -- symbolized by the perfect necklace,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
the perfect diamond ring.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
The perfect getaway in your perfect car.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:42.958
This is an interior design firm that is literally called Utopia.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
The perfect office --

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
again, no cords, as far as I can tell.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
And certainly, no, it doesn't look a thing like my office.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
I mean, there's no paper on the desk.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
We want this golden world.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
And some people get rich enough,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
and if they have their ideals -- in a sort of domestic sense,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
they get to acquire their perfect world.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
Dean Koontz built this fabulous home theater, which is --

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:08.958
I don't think accidentally -- in Art Deco style.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
That symbolizes this sense of being safe and at home.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
This is not always good, because what is your perfect world?

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
What is your ideal, and also, what has been edited out?

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
Is it something important?

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
"The Matrix" is a movie that is all about glamour.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
I could do a whole talk on "The Matrix" and glamour.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
It was criticized for glamorizing violence,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:33.958
because, look -- sunglasses and those long coats, and, of course,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
they could walk up walls and do all these kinds of things

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
that are impossible in the real world.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
This is another Margaret Bourke-White photo.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
This is from Soviet Union. Attractive.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
I mean, look how happy the people are, and good-looking too.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
You know, we're marching toward Utopia.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
I'm not a fan of PETA, but I think this is a great ad.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
Because what they're doing is they're saying,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:57.958
your coat's not so glamorous, what's been edited out is something important.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
But actually, what's even more important

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:03.958
than remembering what's been edited out is thinking, are the ideals good?

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
Because glamour can be very totalitarian and deceptive.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
And it's not just a matter of glamorizing cleaning your floor.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
This is from "Triumph Of The Will" --

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
brilliant editing to cut together things.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
There's a glamour shot.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
National Socialism is all about glamour.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
It was a very aesthetic ideology.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
It was all about cleaning up Germany, and the West, and the world,

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
and ridding it of anything unglamorous.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
So glamour can be dangerous.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
I think glamour has a genuine appeal, has a genuine value.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
I'm not against glamour.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:37.958
But there's a kind of wonder in the stuff that gets edited away in the cords of life.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:41.958
And there is both a way to avoid the dangers of glamour

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
and a way to broaden your appreciation of it.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
And that's to take Isaac Mizrahi's advice

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
and confront the manipulation of it all,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:53.958
and sort of admit that manipulation is something that we enjoy,

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
but also enjoy how it happens.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
And here's Hedy Lamarr.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
She's very glamorous but, you know, she invented spread-spectrum technology.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
So she's even more glamorous if you know that she really wasn't stupid,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
even though she thought she could look stupid.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:09.958
David Hockney talks about how the appreciation of this

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
very glamorous painting is heightened if you think about

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:16.958
the fact that it takes two weeks to paint this splash,

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
which only took a fraction of a second to happen.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
There is a book out in the bookstore --

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
it's called "Symphony In Steel,"

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
and it's about the stuff that's hidden under the skin of the Disney Center.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
And that has a fascination.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
It's not necessarily glamorous, but unveiling the glamour has an appeal.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
There's a wonderful book called "Crowns"

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:38.958
that's all these glamour pictures of black women in their church hats.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
And there's a quote from one of these women, and she talks about,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
"As a little girl, I'd admire women at church with beautiful hats.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:48.958
They looked like beautiful dolls, like they'd just stepped out of a magazine.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
But I also knew how hard they worked all week.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:55.958
Sometimes under those hats there's a lot of joy and a lot of sorrow."

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
And, actually, you get more appreciation for glamour

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
when you realize what went into creating it.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:02.958
Thank you.

title: Healing through diet
transcript: This session is on natural wonders, and the bigger conference is on the pursuit of happiness. I want to try to combine them all, because to me, healing is really the ultimate natural wonder. Your body has a remarkable capacity to begin healing itself, and much more quickly than people had once realized, if you simply stop doing what’s causing the problem. And so, really, so much of what we do in medicine and life in general is focused on mopping up the floor without also turning off the faucet.I love doing this work, because it really gives many people new hope and new choices that they didn’t have before, and it allows us to talk about things that — not just diet, but that happiness is not — we're talking about the pursuit of happiness, but when you really look at all the spiritual traditions, what Aldous Huxley called the "perennial wisdom," when you get past the named and forms and rituals that really divide people, it’s really about — our nature is to be happy; our nature is to be peaceful, our nature is to be healthy. And so it’s not something — happiness is not something you get, health is generally not something that you get. But rather all of these different practices — you know, the ancient swamis and rabbis and priests and monks and nuns didn’t develop these techniques to just manage stress or lower your blood pressure, unclog your arteries, even though it can do all those things. They’re powerful tools for transformation, for quieting down our mind and bodies to allow us to experience what it feels like to be happy, to be peaceful, to be joyful and to realize that it’s not something that you pursue and get, but rather it’s something that you have already until you disturb it.I studied yoga for many years with a teacher named Swami Satchidananda and people would say, "What are you, a Hindu?" He’d say, "No, I’m an undo." And it’s really about identifying what’s causing us to disturb our innate health and happiness, and then to allow that natural healing to occur. To me, that’s the real natural wonder.So, within that larger context, we can talk about diet, stress management — which are really these spiritual practices — moderate exercise, smoking cessation, support groups and community — which I’ll talk more about — and some vitamins and supplements. And it’s not a diet. You know, when most people think about the diet I recommend, they think it’s a really strict diet. For reversing disease, that’s what it takes, but if you’re just trying to be healthy, you have a spectrum of choices. And to the degree that you can move in a healthy direction, you’re going to live longer, you’re going to feel better, you’re going to lose weight, and so on. And in our studies, what we’ve been able to do is to use very expensive, high-tech, state-of-the-art measures to prove how powerful these very simple and low-tech and low-cost — and in many ways, ancient — interventions, can be.We first began by looking at heart disease, and when I began doing this work 26 or 27 years ago, it was thought that once you have heart disease it can only get worse. And what we found was that, instead of getting worse and worse, in many cases it could get better and better, and much more quickly than people had once realized.This is a representative patient who at the time was 73 — totally needed to have a bypass, decided to do this instead. We used quantitative arteriography, showing the narrowing. This is one of the arteries that feed the heart, one of the main arteries, and you can see the narrowing here. A year later, it’s not as clogged; normally, it goes the other direction. These minor changes in blockages caused a 300 percent improvement in blood flow, and using cardiac positron emission tomography, or "PET," scans, blue and black is no blood flow, orange and white is maximal.Huge differences can occur without drugs, without surgery. Clinically, he literally couldn’t walk across the street without getting severe chest pain; within a month, like most people, was pain-free, and within a year, climbing more than 100 floors a day on a Stairmaster. This is not unusual, and it’s part of what enables people to maintain these kinds of changes, because it makes such a big difference in their quality of life. Overall, if you looked at all the arteries in all the patients, they got worse and worse, from one year to five years, in the comparison group. This is the natural history of heart disease, but it’s really not natural because we found it could get better and better, and much more quickly than people had once thought. We also found that the more people change, the better they got. It wasn’t a function of how old or how sick they were — it was mainly how much they changed, and the oldest patients improved as much as the young ones.I got this as a Christmas card a few years ago from two of the patients in one of our programs. The younger brother is 86, the older one’s 95; they wanted to show me how much more flexible they were. And the following year they sent me this one, which I thought was kind of funny. (Laughter) You just never know. And what we found was that 99 percent of the patients start to reverse the progression of their heart disease. Now I thought, you know, if we just did good science, that would change medical practice. But, that was a little naive. It’s important, but not enough. Because we doctors do what we get paid to do, and we get trained to do what we get paid to do, so if we change insurance, then we change medical practice and medical education. Insurance will cover the bypass, it’ll cover the angioplasty; it won’t, until recently, cover diet and lifestyle.So, we began through our nonprofit institute's training hospitals around the country, and we found that most people could avoid surgery, and not only was it medically effective, it was also cost effective. And the insurance companies found that they began to save almost 30,000 dollars per patient, and Medicare is now in the middle of doing a demonstration project where they’re paying for 1,800 people to go through the program on the sites that we train. The fortuneteller says, "I give smokers a discount because there’s not as much to tell." (Laughter) I like this slide, because it’s a chance to talk about what really motivates people to change, and what doesn’t. And what doesn’t work is fear of dying, and that’s what’s normally used.Everybody who smokes knows it’s not good for you, and still 30 percent of Americans smoke — 80 percent in some parts of the world. Why do people do it? Well, because it helps them get through the day. And I’ll talk more about this, but the real epidemic isn’t just heart disease or obesity or smoking — it’s loneliness and depression. As one woman said, "I’ve got 20 friends in this package of cigarettes, and they’re always there for me and nobody else is. You’re going to take away my 20 friends? What are you going to give me?" Or they eat when they get depressed, or they use alcohol to numb the pain, or they work too hard, or watch too much TV. There are lots of ways we have of avoiding and numbing and bypassing pain, but the point of all of this is to deal with the cause of the problem. And the pain is not the problem: it’s the symptom. And telling people they’re going to die is too scary to think about, or, they’re going to get emphysema or heart attack is too scary, and so they don’t want to think about it, so they don’t.The most effective anti-smoking ad was this one. You’ll notice the limp cigarette hanging out of his mouth, and "impotence" — the headline is, "Impotent" — it’s not emphysema. What was the biggest selling drug of all time when it was introduced a few years ago? Viagra, right? Why? Because a lot of guys need it. It’s not like you say, "Hey Joe, I’m having erectile dysfunction, how about you?" And yet, look at the number of prescriptions that are being sold. It’s not so much psychological, it’s vascular, and nicotine makes your arteries constrict. So does cocaine, so does a high fat diet, so does emotional stress.So the very behaviors that we think of as being so sexy in our culture are the very ones that leave so many people feeling tired, lethargic, depressed and impotent, and that’s not much fun. But when you change those behaviors, your brain gets more blood, you think more clearly, you have more energy, your heart gets more blood in ways I’ve shown you. Your sexual function improves. And these things occur within hours. This is a study: a high fat meal, and within one or two hours blood-flow is measurably less — and you’ve all experienced this at Thanksgiving. When you eat a big fatty meal, how do you feel? You feel kind of sleepy afterwards. On a low-fat meal, the blood flow doesn’t go down — it even goes up. Many of you have kids, and you know that’s a big change in your lifestyle, and so people are not afraid to make big changes in lifestyle if they’re worth it. And the paradox is that when you make big changes, you get big benefits, and you feel so much better so quickly. For many people, those are choices worth making — not to live longer, but to live better.I want to talk a little bit about the obesity epidemic, because it really is a problem. Two-thirds of adults are overweight or obese, and diabetes in kids and 30-year-olds has increased 70 percent in the last 10 years. It’s no joke: it’s real. And just to show you this, this is from the CDC. These are not election returns; these are the percentage of people who are overweight. And if you see from '85 to '86 to '87, '88, '89, '90, '91 — you get a new category, 15 to 20 percent; '92, '93, '94, '95, '96, '97 — you get a new category; '98, '99, 2000, and 2001. Mississippi, more than 25 percent of people are overweight. Why is this? Well, this is one way to lose weight that works very well ... but it doesn’t last, which is the problem.(Laughter)Now, there’s no mystery in how you lose weight; you either burn more calories by exercise or you eat fewer calories. Now, one way to eat fewer calories is to eat less food, which is why you can lose weight on any diet if you eat less food, or if you restrict entire categories of foods. But the problem is, you get hungry, so it’s hard to keep it off. The other way is to change the type of food. And fat has nine calories per gram, whereas protein and carbs only have four. So, when you eat less fat, you eat fewer calories without having to eat less food. So you can eat the same amount of food, but you’ll be getting fewer calories because the food is less dense in calories. And it’s the volume of food that affects satiety, rather than the type of food.You know, I don’t like talking about the Atkins diet, but I get asked about it every day, and so I just thought I’d spend a few minutes on that. The myth that you hear about is, Americans have been told to eat less fat, the percent of calories from fat is down, Americans are fatter than ever, therefore fat doesn’t make you fat. It’s a half-truth. Actually, Americans are eating more fat than ever, and even more carbs. And so the percentage is lower, the actual amount is higher, and so the goal is to reduce both. Dr. Atkins and I debated each other many times before he died, and we agreed that Americans eat too many simple carbs, the "bad carbs," and these are things like — (Laughter) — sugar, white flour, white rice, alcohol. And you get a double whammy: you get all these calories that don’t fill you up because you’ve removed the fiber, and they get absorbed quickly so your blood sugar zooms up. Your pancreas makes insulin to bring it back down, which is good. But insulin accelerates the conversion of calories into fat. So, the goal is not to go to pork rinds and bacon and sausages — these are not health foods — but to go from "bad carbs" to what are called "good carbs." And these are things like whole foods, or unrefined carbs: fruits, vegetables, whole wheat flour, brown rice, in their natural forms, are rich in fiber. And the fiber fills you up before you get too many calories, and it slows the absorption so you don’t get that rapid rise in blood sugar. So, and you get all the disease-protective substances.It’s not just what you exclude from your diet, but also what you include that’s protective. Just as all carbs are not bad for you, all fats are not bad for you. There are good fats. And these are predominantly what are called the Omega-3 fatty acids. You find these, for example, in fish oil. And the bad fats are things like trans-fatty acids and processed food and saturated fats, which we find in meat. If you don’t remember anything else from this talk, three grams a day of fish oil can reduce your risk of a heart attack and sudden death by 50 to 80 percent. Three grams a day. They come in one-gram capsules; more than that just gives you extra fat you don’t need. It also helps reduce the risk of the most common cancers like breast, prostate and colon cancer. Now, the problem with the Atkins diet, everybody knows people who have lost weight on it, but you can lose weight on amphetamines, you know, and fen-phen. I mean, there are lots of ways of losing weight that aren’t good for you. You want to lose weight in a way that enhances your health rather than the one that harms it. And the problem is that it’s based on this half-truth, which is that Americans eat too many simple carbs, so if you eat fewer simple carbs you’re going to lose weight. You’ll lose even more weight if you go to whole foods and less fat, and you’ll enhance your health rather than harming it. He says, "I’ve got some good news. While your cholesterol level has remained the same, the research findings have changed."(Laughter)Now, what happens to your heart when you go on an Atkins diet? The red is good at the beginning, and a year later — this is from a study done in a peer-reviewed journal called Angiology — there’s more red after a year on a diet like I would recommend, there’s less red, less blood flow after a year on an Atkins-type diet. So, yes, you can lose weight, but your heart isn’t happy. Now, one of the studies funded by the Atkins Center found that 70 percent of the people were constipated, 65 percent had bad breath, 54 percent had headaches – this is not a healthy way to eat. And so, you might start to lose weight and start to attract people towards you, but when they get too close it’s going to be a problem.(Laughter)And more seriously, there are case reports now of 16-year-old girls who died after a few weeks on the Atkins diet — of bone disease, kidney disease, and so on. And that’s how your body excretes waste, is through your breath, your bowels and your perspiration. So when you go on these kinds of diet, they begin to smell bad. So, an optimal diet is low in fat, low in the bad carbs, high in the good carbs and enough of the good fats. And then, again, it’s a spectrum: when you move in this direction, you’re going to lose weight, you’re going to feel better and you’re going to gain health.Now, there are ecological reasons for eating lower on the food chain too, whether it’s the deforestation of the Amazon, or making more protein available, to the four billion people who live on a dollar a day — not to mention whatever ethical concerns people have. So, there are lots of reasons for eating this way that go beyond just your health.Now, we’re about to publish the first study looking at the effects of this program on prostate cancer, and, in collaboration with Sloane-Kettering and with UCSF. We took 90 men who had biopsy-proven prostate cancer and who had elected, for reasons unrelated to the study, not to have surgery. We could randomly divide them into two groups, and then we could have one group that is a non-intervention control group to compare to, which we can’t do with, say, breast cancer, because everyone gets treated.What we found was that, after a year, none of the experimental group patients who made these lifestyle changes needed treatment, whereas six of the control-group patients needed surgery or radiation. When we looked at their PSA levels — which is a marker for prostate cancer — they got worse in the control group, but they actually got better in the experimental group, and these differences were highly significant.And then I wondered: was there any relationship between how much people changed their diet and lifestyle — whichever group they were in — and the changes in PSA? And sure enough, we found a dose-response relationship, just like we found in the arterial blockages in our cardiac studies. And in order for the PSA to go down, they had to make pretty big changes.I then wondered, well, maybe they’re just changing their PSA, but it’s not really affecting the tumor growth.
