So we took some of their blood serum and sent it down to UCLA; they added it to a standard line of prostate tumor cells growing in tissue culture, and it inhibited the growth seven times more in the experimental group than in the control group — 70 versus 9 percent. And finally, I said, I wonder if there’s any relationship between how much people change and how it inhibited their tumor growth, whichever group they happened to be in. And this really got me excited because again, we found the same pattern: the more people change, the more it affected the growth of their tumors. And finally, we did MRI and MR spectroscopy scans on some of these patients, and the tumor activity is shown in red in this patient, and you can see clearly it’s better a year later, along with the PSA going down. So, if it’s true for prostate cancer, it’ll almost certainly be true for breast cancer as well. And whether or not you have conventional treatment, in addition, if you make these changes, it may help reduce the risk of recurrence.The last thing I want to talk about, apropos of the issue of the pursuit of happiness, is that study after study have shown that people who are lonely and depressed — and depression is the other real epidemic in our culture — are many times more likely to get sick and die prematurely, in part because, as we talked about, they’re more likely to smoke and overeat and drink too much and work too hard and so on. But also, through mechanisms that we don’t fully understand, people who are lonely and depressed are many times — three to five to ten times, in some studies — more likely to get sick and die prematurely. And depression is treatable. We need to do something about that.Now, on the other hand, anything that promotes intimacy is healing. It can be sexual intimacy – I happen to think that healing energy and erotic energy are just different forms of the same thing. Friendship, altruism, compassion, service – all the perennial truths that we talked about that are part of all religion and all cultures — once you stop trying to see the differences, these are the things in our own self-interest, because they free us from our suffering and from disease. And it’s in a sense the most selfish thing that we can do.Just take a look at one study. This was done by David Spiegel at Stanford. He took women with metastatic breast cancer, randomly divided them into two groups. One group of people just met for an hour-and-a-half once a week in a support group. It was a nurturing, loving environment, where they were encouraged to let down their emotional defenses and talk about how awful it is to have breast cancer with people who understood, because they were going through it too. They just met once a week for a year. Five years later, those women lived twice as long, and you can see that the people — and that was the only difference between the groups. It was a randomized control study published in The Lancet. Other studies have shown this as well. So, these simple things that create intimacy are really healing, and even the word healing, it comes from the root "to make whole." The word yoga comes from the Sanskrit, meaning "union, to yoke, to bring together."And the last slide I want to show you is from — I was — again, this swami that I studied with for so many years, and I did a combined oncology and cardiology Grand Rounds at the University of Virginia medical school a couple of years ago. And at the end of it, somebody said, "Hey, Swami, what’s the difference between wellness and illness?" And so he went up on the board and he wrote the word "illness," and circled the first letter, and then wrote the word "wellness," and circled the first two letters ... To me, it’s just shorthand for what we’re talking about: that anything that creates a sense of connection and community and love is really healing. And then we can enjoy our lives more fully without getting sick in the process. Thank you. (Applause)

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:42.958
I love doing this work, because it really gives many people

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:44.958
new hope and new choices that they didn’t have before,

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:49.958
and it allows us to talk about things that -- not just diet,

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:51.958
but that happiness is not --

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:53.958
we're talking about the pursuit of happiness,

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:55.958
but when you really look at all the spiritual traditions,

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
what Aldous Huxley called the "perennial wisdom,"

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:02.958
when you get past the named and forms and rituals that really divide people,

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
it’s really about -- our nature is to be happy;

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:07.958
our nature is to be peaceful, our nature is to be healthy.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:10.958
And so it’s not something -- happiness is not something you get,

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:12.958
health is generally not something that you get.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.958
But rather all of these different practices --

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
you know, the ancient swamis and rabbis and priests and monks and nuns

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:21.958
didn’t develop these techniques to just manage stress

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:23.958
or lower your blood pressure, unclog your arteries,

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:25.958
even though it can do all those things.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
They’re powerful tools for transformation,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:30.958
for quieting down our mind and bodies

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:33.958
to allow us to experience what it feels like to be happy,

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
to be peaceful, to be joyful

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:38.958
and to realize that it’s not something that you pursue and get,

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:42.958
but rather it’s something that you have already until you disturb it.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:46.958
I studied yoga for many years with a teacher named Swami Satchidananda

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
and people would say, "What are you, a Hindu?" He’d say, "No, I’m an undo."

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
And it’s really about identifying what’s causing us

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
to disturb our innate health and happiness,

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
and then to allow that natural healing to occur.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
To me, that’s the real natural wonder.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
So, within that larger context,

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
we can talk about diet, stress management --

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
which are really these spiritual practices --

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:11.958
moderate exercise, smoking cessation, support groups and community --

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
which I’ll talk more about -- and some vitamins and supplements.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
And it’s not a diet.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
You know, when most people think about the diet I recommend,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
they think it’s a really strict diet.

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:21.958
For reversing disease, that’s what it takes,

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
but if you’re just trying to be healthy, you have a spectrum of choices.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:26.958
And to the degree that you can move in a healthy direction,

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
you’re going to live longer, you’re going to feel better,

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
you’re going to lose weight, and so on.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
And in our studies, what we’ve been able to do

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:35.958
is to use very expensive, high-tech, state-of-the-art measures

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:39.958
to prove how powerful these very simple and low-tech and low-cost --

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
and in many ways, ancient -- interventions, can be.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
We first began by looking at heart disease,

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.958
and when I began doing this work 26 or 27 years ago,

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:51.958
it was thought that once you have heart disease it can only get worse.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
And what we found was that, instead of getting worse and worse,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
in many cases it could get better and better,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
and much more quickly than people had once realized.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
This is a representative patient who at the time was 73 --

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
totally needed to have a bypass, decided to do this instead.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
We used quantitative arteriography, showing the narrowing.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.958
This is one of the arteries that feed the heart, one of the main arteries,

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
and you can see the narrowing here.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
A year later, it’s not as clogged; normally, it goes the other direction.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
These minor changes in blockages

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
caused a 300 percent improvement in blood flow,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:23.958
and using cardiac positron emission tomography, or "PET," scans,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
blue and black is no blood flow, orange and white is maximal.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:30.958
Huge differences can occur without drugs, without surgery.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:34.958
Clinically, he literally couldn’t walk across the street without getting severe chest pain;

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
within a month, like most people, was pain-free, and within a year,

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
climbing more than 100 floors a day on a Stairmaster.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
This is not unusual, and it’s part of what enables people

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
to maintain these kinds of changes,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
because it makes such a big difference in their quality of life.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
Overall, if you looked at all the arteries in all the patients,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
they got worse and worse, from one year to five years, in the comparison group.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
This is the natural history of heart disease,

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:58.958
but it’s really not natural because we found it could get better and better,

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
and much more quickly than people had once thought.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
We also found that the more people change, the better they got.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.958
It wasn’t a function of how old or how sick they were --

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
it was mainly how much they changed,

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
and the oldest patients improved as much as the young ones.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
I got this as a Christmas card a few years ago

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
from two of the patients in one of our programs.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
The younger brother is 86, the older one’s 95;

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
they wanted to show me how much more flexible they were.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
And the following year they sent me this one, which I thought was kind of funny.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
(Laughter)

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
You just never know.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
And what we found was that 99 percent of the patients

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
start to reverse the progression of their heart disease.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
Now I thought, you know, if we just did good science,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
that would change medical practice. But, that was a little naive.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
It’s important, but not enough.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
Because we doctors do what we get paid to do,

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
and we get trained to do what we get paid to do,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:44.958
so if we change insurance, then we change medical practice and medical education.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
Insurance will cover the bypass, it’ll cover the angioplasty;

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
it won’t, until recently, cover diet and lifestyle.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
So, we began through our nonprofit institute's

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
training hospitals around the country,

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
and we found that most people could avoid surgery,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
and not only was it medically effective, it was also cost effective.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
And the insurance companies found

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
that they began to save almost 30,000 dollars per patient,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
and Medicare is now in the middle of doing a demonstration project

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
where they’re paying for 1,800 people to go through the program

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
on the sites that we train.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
The fortuneteller says, "I give smokers a discount

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
because there’s not as much to tell." (Laughter)

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:19.958
I like this slide, because it’s a chance to talk about

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
what really motivates people to change, and what doesn’t.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
And what doesn’t work is fear of dying,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
and that’s what’s normally used.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
Everybody who smokes knows it’s not good for you,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
and still 30 percent of Americans smoke --

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
80 percent in some parts of the world. Why do people do it?

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
Well, because it helps them get through the day.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
And I’ll talk more about this, but the real epidemic

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
isn’t just heart disease or obesity or smoking -- it’s loneliness and depression.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:44.958
As one woman said, "I’ve got 20 friends in this package of cigarettes,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
and they’re always there for me and nobody else is.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
You’re going to take away my 20 friends? What are you going to give me?"

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
Or they eat when they get depressed,

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
or they use alcohol to numb the pain,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
or they work too hard, or watch too much TV.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:58.958
There are lots of ways we have of avoiding and numbing and bypassing pain,

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:01.958
but the point of all of this is to deal with the cause of the problem.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
And the pain is not the problem: it’s the symptom.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:07.958
And telling people they’re going to die is too scary to think about,

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
or, they’re going to get emphysema or heart attack is too scary,

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
and so they don’t want to think about it, so they don’t.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
The most effective anti-smoking ad was this one.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
You’ll notice the limp cigarette hanging out of his mouth,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
and "impotence" -- the headline is, "Impotent" -- it’s not emphysema.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
What was the biggest selling drug of all time

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
when it was introduced a few years ago?

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
Viagra, right? Why? Because a lot of guys need it.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
It’s not like you say, "Hey Joe, I’m having erectile dysfunction, how about you?"

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
And yet, look at the number of prescriptions that are being sold.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
It’s not so much psychological, it’s vascular,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
and nicotine makes your arteries constrict.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:42.958
So does cocaine, so does a high fat diet, so does emotional stress.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:46.958
So the very behaviors that we think of as being so sexy in our culture

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
are the very ones that leave so many people feeling tired,

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
lethargic, depressed and impotent, and that’s not much fun.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
But when you change those behaviors, your brain gets more blood,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
you think more clearly, you have more energy,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
your heart gets more blood in ways I’ve shown you.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
Your sexual function improves.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:03.958
And these things occur within hours. This is a study: a high fat meal,

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
and within one or two hours blood-flow is measurably less --

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
and you’ve all experienced this at Thanksgiving.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
When you eat a big fatty meal, how do you feel?

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
You feel kind of sleepy afterwards.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
On a low-fat meal, the blood flow doesn’t go down -- it even goes up.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:18.958
Many of you have kids, and you know that’s a big change in your lifestyle,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:22.958
and so people are not afraid to make big changes in lifestyle if they’re worth it.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
And the paradox is that when you make big changes, you get big benefits,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
and you feel so much better so quickly.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
For many people, those are choices worth making --

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
not to live longer, but to live better.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
I want to talk a little bit about the obesity epidemic,

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
because it really is a problem.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
Two-thirds of adults are overweight or obese,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
and diabetes in kids and 30-year-olds

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:46.958
has increased 70 percent in the last 10 years. It’s no joke: it’s real.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
And just to show you this, this is from the CDC.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
These are not election returns; these are the percentage of people who are overweight.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:59.958
And if you see from '85 to '86 to '87, '88, '89, '90, '91 --

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:06.958
you get a new category, 15 to 20 percent; '92, '93, '94, '95, '96, '97 --

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:11.958
you get a new category; '98, '99, 2000, and 2001.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:15.958
Mississippi, more than 25 percent of people are overweight.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
Why is this? Well, this is one way to lose weight that works very well ...

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
but it doesn’t last, which is the problem.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
(Laughter)

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
Now, there’s no mystery in how you lose weight;

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:28.958
you either burn more calories by exercise or you eat fewer calories.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
Now, one way to eat fewer calories is to eat less food,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
which is why you can lose weight on any diet if you eat less food,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
or if you restrict entire categories of foods.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:39.958
But the problem is, you get hungry, so it’s hard to keep it off.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
The other way is to change the type of food.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
And fat has nine calories per gram,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
whereas protein and carbs only have four.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:49.958
So, when you eat less fat, you eat fewer calories without having to eat less food.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
So you can eat the same amount of food, but you’ll be getting fewer calories

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
because the food is less dense in calories.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:58.958
And it’s the volume of food that affects satiety, rather than the type of food.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
You know, I don’t like talking about the Atkins diet, but I get asked about it every day,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
and so I just thought I’d spend a few minutes on that.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
The myth that you hear about is,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
Americans have been told to eat less fat,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
the percent of calories from fat is down,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
Americans are fatter than ever, therefore fat doesn’t make you fat.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:15.958
It’s a half-truth. Actually, Americans are eating more fat than ever,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
and even more carbs. And so the percentage is lower,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
the actual amount is higher, and so the goal is to reduce both.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:24.958
Dr. Atkins and I debated each other many times before he died,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
and we agreed that Americans eat too many simple carbs,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
the "bad carbs," and these are things like --

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
(Laughter)

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
-- sugar, white flour, white rice, alcohol. And you get a double whammy:

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
you get all these calories that don’t fill you up because you’ve removed the fiber,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
and they get absorbed quickly so your blood sugar zooms up.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
Your pancreas makes insulin to bring it back down, which is good.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
But insulin accelerates the conversion of calories into fat.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
So, the goal is not to go to pork rinds and bacon and sausages --

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
these are not health foods --

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
but to go from "bad carbs" to what are called "good carbs."

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
And these are things like whole foods, or unrefined carbs:

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:59.958
fruits, vegetables, whole wheat flour, brown rice, in their natural forms, are rich in fiber.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
And the fiber fills you up before you get too many calories,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:06.958
and it slows the absorption so you don’t get that rapid rise in blood sugar.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
So, and you get all the disease-protective substances.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
It’s not just what you exclude from your diet,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
but also what you include that’s protective.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
Just as all carbs are not bad for you, all fats are not bad for you. There are good fats.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
And these are predominantly what are called the Omega-3 fatty acids.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
You find these, for example, in fish oil.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
And the bad fats are things like trans-fatty acids and processed food

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
and saturated fats, which we find in meat.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
If you don’t remember anything else from this talk,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
three grams a day of fish oil can reduce your risk of a heart attack

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
and sudden death by 50 to 80 percent.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
Three grams a day. They come in one-gram capsules;

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
more than that just gives you extra fat you don’t need.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
It also helps reduce the risk of the most common cancers

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
like breast, prostate and colon cancer.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
Now, the problem with the Atkins diet,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
everybody knows people who have lost weight on it,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
but you can lose weight on amphetamines, you know, and fen-phen.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
I mean, there are lots of ways of losing weight that aren’t good for you.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
You want to lose weight in a way that enhances your health

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
rather than the one that harms it.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
And the problem is that it’s based on this half-truth,

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
which is that Americans eat too many simple carbs,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
so if you eat fewer simple carbs you’re going to lose weight.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
You’ll lose even more weight if you go to whole foods and less fat,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
and you’ll enhance your health rather than harming it.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
He says, "I’ve got some good news.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
While your cholesterol level has remained the same,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
the research findings have changed."

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:14.958
(Laughter)

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
Now, what happens to your heart when you go on an Atkins diet?

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
The red is good at the beginning, and a year later --

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:23.958
this is from a study done in a peer-reviewed journal called Angiology --

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
there’s more red after a year on a diet like I would recommend,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
there’s less red, less blood flow after a year on an Atkins-type diet.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:33.958
So, yes, you can lose weight, but your heart isn’t happy.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
Now, one of the studies funded by the Atkins Center

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.958
found that 70 percent of the people were constipated, 65 percent had bad breath,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
54 percent had headaches – this is not a healthy way to eat.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
And so, you might start to lose weight and start to attract people towards you,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
but when they get too close it’s going to be a problem.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
(Laughter)

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
And more seriously, there are case reports now of 16-year-old girls

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
who died after a few weeks on the Atkins diet --

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
of bone disease, kidney disease, and so on.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
And that’s how your body excretes waste, is through your breath,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
your bowels and your perspiration.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
So when you go on these kinds of diet, they begin to smell bad.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:08.958
So, an optimal diet is low in fat, low in the bad carbs,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
high in the good carbs and enough of the good fats.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
And then, again, it’s a spectrum:

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
when you move in this direction, you’re going to lose weight,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
you’re going to feel better and you’re going to gain health.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
Now, there are ecological reasons for eating lower on the food chain too,

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:24.958
whether it’s the deforestation of the Amazon, or making more protein available,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
to the four billion people who live on a dollar a day --

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
not to mention whatever ethical concerns people have.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:33.958
So, there are lots of reasons for eating this way that go beyond just your health.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
Now, we’re about to publish the first study

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:39.958
looking at the effects of this program on prostate cancer,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
and, in collaboration with Sloane-Kettering and with UCSF.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:46.958
We took 90 men who had biopsy-proven prostate cancer

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
and who had elected, for reasons unrelated to the study, not to have surgery.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
We could randomly divide them into two groups,

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
and then we could have one group

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
that is a non-intervention control group to compare to,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
which we can’t do with, say, breast cancer, because everyone gets treated.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
What we found was that, after a year,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
none of the experimental group patients

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
who made these lifestyle changes needed treatment,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
whereas six of the control-group patients needed surgery or radiation.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:11.958
When we looked at their PSA levels -- which is a marker for prostate cancer --

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
they got worse in the control group,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
but they actually got better in the experimental group,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
and these differences were highly significant.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
And then I wondered: was there any relationship

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
between how much people changed their diet and lifestyle --

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
whichever group they were in -- and the changes in PSA?

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
And sure enough, we found a dose-response relationship,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
just like we found in the arterial blockages in our cardiac studies.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
And in order for the PSA to go down, they had to make pretty big changes.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
I then wondered, well, maybe they’re just changing their PSA,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
but it’s not really affecting the tumor growth.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
So we took some of their blood serum and sent it down to UCLA;

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:44.958
they added it to a standard line of prostate tumor cells growing in tissue culture,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
and it inhibited the growth seven times more

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:51.958
in the experimental group than in the control group -- 70 versus 9 percent.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
And finally, I said, I wonder if there’s any relationship between

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
how much people change and how it inhibited their tumor growth,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:57.958
whichever group they happened to be in.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
And this really got me excited because again,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
we found the same pattern: the more people change,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
the more it affected the growth of their tumors.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
And finally, we did MRI and MR spectroscopy scans on some of these patients,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
and the tumor activity is shown in red in this patient,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
and you can see clearly it’s better a year later, along with the PSA going down.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:18.958
So, if it’s true for prostate cancer, it’ll almost certainly be true for breast cancer as well.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
And whether or not you have conventional treatment,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:24.958
in addition, if you make these changes, it may help reduce the risk of recurrence.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:28.958
The last thing I want to talk about, apropos of the issue of the pursuit of happiness,

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
is that study after study have shown

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
that people who are lonely and depressed --

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
and depression is the other real epidemic in our culture --

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
are many times more likely to get sick and die prematurely,

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
in part because, as we talked about, they’re more likely to smoke

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
and overeat and drink too much and work too hard and so on.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
But also, through mechanisms that we don’t fully understand,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
people who are lonely and depressed are many times --

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
three to five to ten times, in some studies --

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
more likely to get sick and die prematurely.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
And depression is treatable. We need to do something about that.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
Now, on the other hand, anything that promotes intimacy is healing.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
It can be sexual intimacy –

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
I happen to think that healing energy and erotic energy

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
are just different forms of the same thing.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:10.958
Friendship, altruism, compassion, service – all the perennial truths that we talked about

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
that are part of all religion and all cultures --

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
once you stop trying to see the differences,

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
these are the things in our own self-interest,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:21.958
because they free us from our suffering and from disease.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:25.958
And it’s in a sense the most selfish thing that we can do.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
Just take a look at one study. This was done by David Spiegel at Stanford.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
He took women with metastatic breast cancer,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
randomly divided them into two groups.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
One group of people just met for an hour-and-a-half once a week in a support group.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
It was a nurturing, loving environment,

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
where they were encouraged to let down their emotional defenses

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
and talk about how awful it is to have breast cancer

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
with people who understood, because they were going through it too.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
They just met once a week for a year.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:49.958
Five years later, those women lived twice as long, and you can see that the people --

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
and that was the only difference between the groups.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
It was a randomized control study published in The Lancet.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
Other studies have shown this as well.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
So, these simple things that create intimacy are really healing,

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
and even the word healing, it comes from the root "to make whole."

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
The word yoga comes from the Sanskrit,

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
meaning "union, to yoke, to bring together."

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
And the last slide I want to show you is from -- I was -- again,

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
this swami that I studied with for so many years, and I

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
did a combined oncology and cardiology Grand Rounds

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
at the University of Virginia medical school a couple of years ago.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
And at the end of it, somebody said,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:22.958
"Hey, Swami, what’s the difference between wellness and illness?"

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
And so he went up on the board and he wrote the word "illness,"

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
and circled the first letter, and then wrote the word "wellness,"

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
and circled the first two letters ...

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
To me, it’s just shorthand for what we’re talking about:

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
that anything that creates a sense of connection

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
and community and love is really healing.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:41.958
And then we can enjoy our lives more fully without getting sick in the process.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
Thank you. (Applause)

title: Aliens, love -- where are they?
transcript: You all know this story. In the summer of 1950, Enrico Fermi, the Italian-American physicist and atomic-pile builder, went to lunch at Los Alamos National Laboratory and joined some colleagues there, and asked them a question: "Where is everybody?" This confused his colleagues, obviously, because they were sitting right there with him. And then he had to clarify that he wasn't talking about them. He was talking about the space aliens.You see, this was only a few years after the supposed flying saucer crash at Roswell, New Mexico. And even though that turned out to be nothing, nothing at all — (Laughter) — merely a downed weather balloon piloted by small hairless men with slits for mouths ... Still, America had gone saucer-mad, even famous scientists who were eating lunch. Fermi's reasoning, if I may paraphrase badly, is that the universe is so vast that it stands to reason, there should be other intelligent life out there. And the universe is so old that unless we were the very first civilization ever to evolve, we should have some evidence of their existence by now. And yet, to the best of our knowledge, we are alone."Where is everybody?" asked Fermi, and his colleagues had no answer. Fermi then went on with the same blunt logic to disprove fairies, Sasquatch, God, the possibility of love — and thereafter, as you know, Enrico Fermi ate alone. (Laughter) Now, I am not a scientist. I have never built an atomic pile. Although, I might argue that, technically, every pile is atomic.(Laughter)However, with respect, I might point out two possibilities that Enrico Fermi perhaps did not consider. One is that the aliens might be very far away. Perhaps, I dare say, even on other planets. The other possibility — (Laughter) — is, perhaps, Enrico Fermi himself was an alien.(Laughter)Think about it. Isn't it a little convenient that in the midst of the World War, out of nowhere, suddenly an Italian scientist showed up with an amazing new technology that would transform everything in the world and darken the history of the human species forever after? And isn't it a little strange that he required no payment for this? That he asked for only one thing — a gift of two healthy sperm whales? That's — that's not true. But it is strange.(Laughter)And if Enrico Fermi were indeed a space alien, wouldn't he be the first to have tried to convince his fellow scientists that the space aliens are not already here? For it is given in certain UFO-ology or UFOlogy circles, that the aliens are already here and have been for millennia; that they have walked among us in disguise, observing us, guiding our evolution from ape to man — if you believe in that sort of thing — and, occasionally, kidnapping us in their flying saucers and taking us away to have sex with us in pyramids.(Laughter)It's a difficult theory to discount, I think you'll agree.(Laughter)For even in my own life, there are memories I have that are difficult to explain — happenings that are so odd and unaccountably weird, that it is difficult to imagine they were not the result of prolonged and frequent contact with aliens throughout my life. For how else will you explain the amazing and absolutely true close encounters that I had and will describe to you now? Encounter one: Ocean City, New Jersey, 1980. This was the summer when the special edition of "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" was released. And I went on vacation with my parents to the Jersey shore. Within 12 hours, I was horribly sunburned, just like Richard Dreyfuss in the movie.(Laughter)And so I spent the rest of the vacation largely sitting outside our little rental house at night, the sidewalk still warm from the sun, watching the skies for UFOs. What did I see? Stars, satellites, blinking airplanes — typical sky junk. Occasionally, kids would come and join me and watch, but their necks soon got sore, and they would go off to the boardwalk to play video games and mingle with humans. I was pretty good at the video games. I was not very good at the other part, so I stayed alone with the cosmos.And that's when it happened. An elderly couple came walking down the street. I would say they were in their late seventies, and I would say that they were on a date, because he was wearing a very neat little suit with a yellow tie — a brown suit. And she was wearing a cardigan, because it was now fully night and a chill was coming in off the ocean. I remember, for some reason, that they were exactly the same height. And then they stopped, and the man turned to me and said, "What are you looking for, flying saucers?"(Laughter)You have to admit, that's a pretty boss piece of detective work for an old man on a date. But what was stranger still — and even I realized it at the time, as a nine-year-old child — was that they stopped at all. That this old man would interrupt his moonlight stroll with his sweetheart with the precise reason of making fun of a child. "Oh," he said, "little green men." And then his girlfriend joined in, too. "There's no such thing as space men," she said. "There's no such thing." And then they both laughed. "Ha, ha, ha." I looked around. The street was entirely empty. I had stopped hearing the sound of the ocean. It was as though time had stopped. I did not know why they were teasing me. I looked into their strangely angry faces, and I remember wondering, are they wearing rubber masks?(Laughter)And what would be behind those rubber masks, if they were? Giant, almond-shaped, unblinking eyes? Slits for mouths? The old man crooked his finger as though he were firing a gun, and then he made laser sounds. "Kew, kew, kew — watch out." And they turned at once and walked away. The old man reached out his knobbly claw for the woman's hand, and found it, and left me alone. Now, you could describe this as a simple misunderstanding — a strange encounter among humans. Maybe it was swamp gas, but — (Laughter) — I know what I saw.Close encounter two: Brookline, Massachusetts, 1984. I went to see the movie "Dune," and a girl talked to me. Now, on its face — (Laughter) — this is impossible on its face, I realize — but it is absolutely true. It was opening night, naturally. I went with my friend Tim McGonigal, who sat on my left. On my right was the girl in question. She had long, curly black hair, a blue jean jacket. I remember, she had some sort of injury to her ankle, an Ace bandage, and she had crutches. She was very tall, I would say. I was starting high school at the time. I would say she was a junior, but I had never seen her before. She didn't go to my school. I didn't know her name, and I never will. She was sitting with someone who I presume was her mother, and they were talking about the novel, "Dune." They were both big fans, mother and daughter — very unusual. They were talking about how their favorite characters were the giant sandworms. And then it got stranger. That's when she turned to me and said, "Are you looking forward to seeing the movie?"(Laughter)First of all, I was embarrassed because I had not read the novel "Dune" at that time. I was merely a connoisseur of movies featuring desert planets, as I still am.(Laughter) But it was also the tone of how she asked the question: apropos of nothing, like she didn't even care about the answer, as though she just wanted to talk to me. I did not know what to say. I said, "Yes." I did not even turn my head. The movie began. I need not remind you that this was David Lynch's version of "Dune," in which all of the characters were sexy and deformed at the same time.(Laughter)There was a character called the Third-Stage Guild Navigator, which was a kind of giant, floating fetus-creature that lived in a giant tank with this orange mist of psychedelic spice swirling around him, allowing him to bend space and time. He could never leave the tank or interact with the outside world. He had become, in his isolation, so deformed and so sexy, that he had to talk through a kind of old-timey radio to the outside world, and could never touch them. I mean, I liked him a lot better than the sandworms. The sandworms were fine, but your favorite character? Please.When the movie ended, everyone seemed very happy to get up and get out of the theatre as soon as possible. Except for the girl. As I walked out, her pace slowed. Perhaps it was the crutches, but it seemed — (Laughter) — it seemed as though she might want to talk to me again. When I say it out loud, it sounds so ridiculous, but I can only come to the conclusion that it was what, in the alien abductee community, they call a "screen memory": a ridiculous false recollection designed by their brain to cover up some trauma — say, of being kidnapped and flown off to a sex pyramid.(Laughter)And so I sure am glad I did not slow down to talk to her. I sure am glad I never saw her again.Close encounter three: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 1989. In the mid-to-late '80s, the novelist Whitley Strieber wrote a book called "Communion," in which he described his own lifelong experiences being abducted by aliens. And he also described the phenomenon known in this community as "lost time," where Whitley Strieber would suddenly become aware that he could not remember the previous ten minutes, or the previous ten hours, or the previous ten days. And would come to the conclusion that that was when the aliens were taking him and giving him rectal probes.(Laughter)This book became, naturally, an enormous best-seller. This image by Ted Joseph was from that book, and was his, sort of, police sketch of what the creatures looked like that Whitley Strieber had described to him. And it was so successful that they made it into a movie. And in 1989, the way I remember it, I was in Philadelphia visiting my girlfriend, and we decided, apropos of nothing, to go see this movie. And the way I remember it, the movie featured these details. One: Whitley Strieber was played by Christopher Walken. Two: the alien was played by a rubber puppet.(Laughter)Three: there was a surprisingly long sequence of the film in which the rubber puppet gives Christopher Walken a rectal probe. Four: this was being shown in a regular movie theater in Center City, Philadelphia. Five: all of which is to say, they made a movie out of the book, "Communion," and it starred Christopher Walken. Does something seem strange about this to you? Something odd? Something off? Something wrong with this picture? Think about it. Yes. The answer is: I had a girlfriend. What?(Laughter)How did this happen? When did this happen? I remember walking out of the theater and becoming suddenly aware of this fact, as we walked hand in hand, and pondering these very same questions. And to this day, I have no answer for you. Close encounter four: the Algarve, Portugal, 1991. Some years later, I and this woman — we'll call her "Catherine Fletcher" — (Laughter) — went traveling through the south of Portugal together. We stayed in old, crumbling, walled cities, in tiny little hotels, and we would climb up to the roof and drink Vinho Verde and watch the sun set and play checkers. What? Did we do this? Really? Does anyone do this? We went to some topless beaches. Excuse me? No, not in my life. For what it's worth, we went to Sagres, which was considered, at the time, to be the end of the world. And there I was chased by a pack of feral dogs on the dock, and the lead dog bit me on the ass, requiring me to go to a strange Portuguese clinic and receive an ass shot. Make of that what you will.(Laughter)Our last day in Portugal, we were in the district capital of Faro, and Catherine decided that she wanted to go to the beach one last time. Now, Faro is a bustling little city, and to get to the beach, she explained, you would have to take a bus and then a boat. And did I want to come with? But I was exhausted and dog-bitten, and so I said, "No." I remember what she looked like before she left. The freckles had grown and multiplied on her face and shoulders, clustering into a kind of a tan. A tan, we were both tan — is this true? Her eyes were extra bright and extra blue, as a result. She was smiling. She was a single woman about to go alone into a country, not even speaking the language, to travel alone by bus and boat to go to a beach she did not know or had never seen. I loved her, and then she went out into that strange, alien land.It took me some time to come to my senses. I had my own "lost time" moment, where I woke up and suddenly realized it was very late in the day, almost dinnertime, and she had not come back. Nervous, I went down to the street to look for her. Now, I did not speak Portuguese. I did not know where the beach was. I could not call her on a cell phone because this was 1991, and the aliens had not given us that technology yet.(Laughter)I realized that the day would only have two possible outcomes: either Catherine would come back to the hotel, or she would never come back to the hotel. And so I sat down to wait. I did not watch the skies, but the very end of the street where the buses and cars and pedestrians and little scooters were moving along. And I watched those constellations shift, hoping that they would part and I would see her face. It was at that moment, in that very small town of 30,000 or so, that I truly appreciated the vastness of the universe and the searching we might do in it. And that's when the Liberians came along. Five young men — all laughing, happy, traveling together, coming back to this hotel where they were staying.One of them was named Joseph, and he asked me what was I doing, and I explained. And he said, "Don't worry." He was sure that Catherine would be safe. But he did not seem so very sure, for he sat down to wait with me. And for the next two hours, they all waited with me: taking turns, going up to their room, coming back, telling me jokes, distracting me. Two hours, they gave me a message. We are not alone.And then, in the middle of a sentence, at the very birth of twilight, I turned and looked down the street. The stars aligned, and she came back. She was smiling. She did not understand why I was so worried. Neither did the Liberians, although there was a huge amount of relief in their laughter as they clapped us on the back, and went back up to their room and left us alone in the street, holding hands. An event like this leaves a scar on the memory, much like a piece of alien technology that has been inserted into your buttocks by a "Portuguese doctor."(Laughter)And even now, a decade and a half later, even now that we are married, I look for her still, whenever she is not in the room. And even though, I think you'll agree, it is probable that during the time she was away, she was kidnapped and replaced by an alien clone, I love her and wait for her still.Thank you for your kind attention.(Applause)
