00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
it's when we see something unexpected,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:09.958
it changes our understanding of the way things work.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
As you're seeing this gel magnet for the first time,

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
if you assume that all magnets had to be hard,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
then seeing this surprised you and it changed your understanding

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:20.958
of the way magnets could work.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:23.958
ZK: Now, it's important to understand what the unexpected properties are.

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:27.958
But to really think about the implications of what this makes possible,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:31.958
we found that it helps to think about how it could be applied in the world.

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
So, a first idea is to use it on cabinet doors.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:39.958
If you line the sides of the cabinets using the gel material --

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
if a cabinet slams shut it wouldn't make a loud noise,

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
and in addition the magnets would draw the cabinets closed.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:49.958
Imagine taking the same material, but putting it on the bottom of a sneaker.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
You know, this way you could go to the container store and buy one of those

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
metal sheets that they hang on the back of your door, in your closet,

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:59.958
and you could literally stick your shoes up instead of using a shelf.

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:02.958
For me, I really love this idea.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
(Laughter)

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
If you come to my apartment and see my closet,

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
I'm sure you'd figure out why: it's a mess.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
KS: Seeing the unexpected properties and then seeing a couple of

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:15.958
applications -- it helps you see why this is significant, what the potential is.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
But we've found that the way we present our ideas

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:21.958
it makes a big difference.

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:24.958
ZK: It was like six months ago that Keith and I were out in L.A.,

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
and we were at Starbucks having coffee with Roman Coppola.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
He works on mostly music videos and commercials

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
with his company, The Directors Bureau.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:36.958
As we were talking, Roman told us that he's kind of an inventor on the side.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:37.958
And we were showing him the same

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
gel magnet that you're holding in your hand -- and you know,

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
we shared the same ideas. And you could see it in his face:

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:47.958
Roman starts to get really excited and he whips out this manila folder;

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
he opens it up and Keith and I look in,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
and he starts showing us concepts that he's been working on.

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.958
These things just get him really excited. And so we're looking

00:02:55.958 --> 00:03:02.958
at these concepts, and we were just like, whoa, this guy's good.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:06.958
Because the way that he presented the concept -- his approach

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:12.958
was totally different than ours. He sold it to you as if it was for sale right now.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
When we were going in the car back to the airport,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:19.958
we were thinking: why was this so powerful?

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:20.958
And as we thought about it more, we realized that

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:24.958
it let you fill in all the details about the experience,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:28.958
just as if you saw it on TV. So, for TED we decided to take our favorite

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
idea for the gel magnet and work with Roman and his team

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:35.958
at the Directors Bureau to create a commercial for a product

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
from the future.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
Narrator: Do you have a need for speed?

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:46.958
Inventables Water Adventures dares you to launch yourself

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:50.958
on a magnetically-levitating board down a waterslide

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:59.958
so fast, so tall, that when you hit the bottom, it uses brakes to stop.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:06.958
Aqua Rocket: coming this summer.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
KS: Now, we showed the concept to a few people before this,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
and they asked us, when's it coming out?

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
So I just wanted to let you know, it's not actually coming out,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
just the concept is.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
ZK: So now, when we dream up these concepts, it's important for us

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
to make sure that they work from a technical standpoint.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
So I just want to quickly explain how this would work.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:29.958
This is the magnetically-levitating board that they mentioned in the commercial.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
The gel that you're holding would be lining the bottom of the board.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
Now this is important for two reasons.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
One: the soft properties of the magnet that make it so that, if it were

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
to hit the rider in the head, it wouldn't injure him.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
In addition, you can see from the diagram on the right,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
the underpart of the slide would be an electromagnet.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
So this would actually repel the rider a little bit as you're going down.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
The force of the water rushing down, in addition to that repulsion force,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
would make this slide go faster than any slide on the market.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
It's because of this that you need the magnetic braking system.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
When you get to the very bottom of the slide --

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
(Laughter)

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
-- the rider passes through an aluminum tube.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
And I'm going to kick it to Keith to explain why that's important

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:03.958
from a technical standpoint.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
KS: So I'm sure all you engineers know that even though aluminum is

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:10.958
a metal, it's not a magnetic material. But something unexpected

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
happens when you drop a magnet down an aluminum tube.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
So we set up a quick experiment here to show that to you.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
(Laughter)

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
Now, you see the magnet fell really slowly.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
Now, I'm not going to get into the physics of it,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
but all you need to know is that the faster the magnet's falling,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:42.958
the greater the stopping force.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
ZK: Now, our next technology is actually a 10-foot pole,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
and I have it right here in my pocket.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:51.958
(Laughter)

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
There're a few different versions of it.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:58.958
(Laughter)

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
KS: Some of them automatically unroll like this one.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
They can be made to automatically roll up, or they can be made

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
stable, like Zach's, to hold any position in between.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
ZK: As we were talking to the vendor -- to try to learn about

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
how you could apply these, or how they're being applied currently --

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:20.958
he was telling us that, in the military they use this one

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
so soldiers can keep it on their chests -- very concealed --

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
and then, when they're out on the field, erect it as an antenna

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
to clearly send signals back to the base.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:32.958
In our brainstorms, we came up with the idea you could use it for a soccer goal:

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
so at the end of the game, you just roll up the goal and put it in your gym bag.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
(Laughter)

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
KS: Now, the interesting thing about this is,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
you don't have to be an engineer to appreciate why

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
a 10-foot pole that can fit in your pocket is so interesting.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
(Laughter)

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
So we decided to go out onto the streets of Chicago

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
and ask a few people on the streets what they thought you could do with this.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
Man: I clean my ceiling fans with that and I get the spider webs

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
off my house -- I do it that way.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
Woman: I'd make my very own walking stick.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:03.958
Woman: I would create a ladder to use to get up on top of the tree.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
Woman: An olive server.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:09.958
Man: Some type of extension pole -- like what the painters use.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
Woman: I would make a spear that, when you went deep sea diving,

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:16.958
you could catch the fish really fast, and then roll it back up,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:20.958
and you could swim easier ... Yeah.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
(Laughter)

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
ZK: Now, for our next technology we're going to do a little demonstration,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
and so we need a volunteer from the audience.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:30.958
You sir, come on up.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:34.958
(Laughter)

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
Come on up. Tell everybody your name.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:37.958
Steve Jurvetson: Steve.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
ZK: It's Steve. All right Steve, now, follow me.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
We need you to stand right in front of the TED sign.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
Right there. That's great.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
And hold onto this. Good luck to you.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
(Laughter)

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:51.958
KS: No, not yet.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:57.958
(Laughter)

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
ZK: I'd just like to let you all know that this presentation

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:00.958
has been brought to you by Target.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:04.958
KS: Little bit -- that's perfect, just perfect.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
Now, Zach, we're going to demonstrate

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
a water gun fight from the future.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:15.958
(Laughter)

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
So here, come on up to the front. All right, so

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:22.958
now if you'll see here -- no, no, it's OK.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:27.958
So, describe to the audience the temperature of your shirt. Go ahead.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
SJ: It's cold.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
KS: Now the reason it's cold is that's it's not actually water loaded

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:35.958
into these squirt guns -- it's a dry liquid developed by 3M.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:40.958
It's perfectly clear, it's odorless, it's colorless.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
It's so safe you could drink this stuff.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
(Laughter)

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
And the reason it feels cold is because it evaporates

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
25 times faster than water.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
(Laughter)

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
All right, well thanks for coming up.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:55.958
(Laughter)

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:59.958
ZK: Wait, wait, Steven -- before you go we filled this with the dry liquid

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:00.958
so during the break you can shoot your friends.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:01.958
SJ: Excellent, thank you.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
KS: Thanks for coming up. Let's give him a big round of applause.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
(Applause)

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:10.958
So what's the significance of this dry liquid?

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:14.958
Early versions of the fluid were actually used on a Cray Supercomputer.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
Now, the unexpected thing about this

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
is that Zach could stand up on stage and drench

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
a perfectly innocent member of the audience without any concern

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
that we'd damage the electronics, that we'd get him wet,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:29.958
that we'd hurt the books or the computers. It works because it's non-conductive.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
So you can see here, you can immerse a whole circuit board

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
in this and it wouldn't cause any damage.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
You can circulate it to draw the heat away.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
But today it's most widely used in office buildings --

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
in the sprinkler system -- as a fire-suppression fluid.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:44.958
Again, it's perfectly safe for people. It puts out the fires, doesn't hurt anything.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:45.958
But our favorite idea for this

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
was using it in a basketball game. So during halftime,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
it could rain down on the players, cool everyone down,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:54.958
and in a matter of minutes it would dry. Wouldn't hurt the court.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
ZK: Our next technology comes to us from a company in Japan

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
called Sekisui Chemical. One of their R&D engineers

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
was working on a way to make plastic stiffer.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
While he was doing this, he noticed an unexpected thing.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:06.958
We have a video to show you.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
KS: So you see there, it didn't bounce back. Now, this was

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
an unintended side effect of some experiments they were doing.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
It's technically called, "shape-retaining property."

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
Now, think about your interactions with aluminum foil.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
Shape-retaining is common in metal: you bend a piece of aluminum foil,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
and it holds its place. Contrast that with

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
a plastic garbage can -- and you can push in the sides

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
and it always bounces back.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
ZK: For example, you could make a watch that wraps around your wrist,

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
but doesn't use a buckle.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
Taking it a little further, if you wove

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
those strips together -- kind of like a little basket -- you could make

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:09.958
a shape-retaining sheet, and then you could embed it in a cloth:

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
so you could make a picnic sheet that wraps around the table,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
so that way on a windy day it wouldn't blow away.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:15.958
For our next technology, it's hard to observe

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:19.958
the unexpected property by itself, because it's an ink.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
So, we've prepared a video to show it applied to paper.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.958
KS: As this paper is bending, the resistance of the ink changes.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:34.958
So with simple electronics, you can detect how much the page is being bent.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
Now, to think about the potential for this,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
think of all the places ink is supplied: on business cards,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
on the back of cereal boxes, board games. Any place you use ink,

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
you could change the way you interact with it.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:49.958
ZK: So my favorite idea for this is to apply the ink to a book.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
This could totally change the way that you interface with paper.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
You see the dark line on the side and the top. As you turn the pages

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
of the book, the book can actually detect what page you're on,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
based on the curvature of the pages.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:04.958
In addition, if you were to fold in one of the corners, then you could program

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:09.958
the book to actually email you the text on the page for your notes.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
KS: For our last technology, we worked again with Roman and his team

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
at the Directors Bureau to develop a commercial from the future

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
to explain how it works.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
Old Milk Carton: Oh yeah, it smells good.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
Who are you?

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
New Milk Carton: I'm New Milk.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
OMC: I used to smell like you.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
Narrator: Fresh Watch, from Inventables Dairy Farms.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
Packaging that changes color when your milk's gone off.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
Don't let milk spoil your morning.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
ZK: Now, this technology was developed by these two guys:

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
Professor Ken Suslick and Neil Rakow, of the University of Illinois.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
KS: Now the way it works: there's a matrix of color dyes.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And these dyes change color in response to odors.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:03.958
So the smell of vanilla, that might change the four on the left to brown

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
and the one on the right to yellow. This matrix can produce

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:10.958
thousands of different color combinations to represent thousands of different smells.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
But like in the milk commercial, if you know what odor you want to detect,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
then they can formulate a specific dye to detect just that odor.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:20.958
ZK: Right. It was that that started a conversation with Professor Suslick and myself,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
and he was explaining to me the things that this is making possible,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:28.958
beyond just detecting spoiled food. It's really where the significance of it lies.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:32.958
His company actually did a survey of firemen all across the country to try to learn,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
how are they currently testing the air when they respond to an emergency scene?

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
And he kind of comically explained that

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
time after time, what the firemen would say is:

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
they would rush to the scene of the crime; they would look around;

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
if there were no dead policemen, it was OK to go.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
(Laughter)

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:53.958
I mean, this is a true story. They're using policemen as canaries.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
(Laughter)

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
But more seriously, they determined that you could develop

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
a device that can smell better than the humans,

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
and say if it's safe for the firemen.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:07.958
In addition, he's spun off a company from the University called ChemSensing,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
where they're working on medical equipment.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
So, a patient can come in and actually blow into their device.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.958
By detecting the odor of particular bacteria, or viruses,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
or even lung cancer, the dots will change and they can use

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
software to analyze the results.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:27.958
This can radically improve the way that doctors diagnose patients.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
Currently, they're using a method of trial and error,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
but this could tell you precisely what disease you have.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
KS: So that was the six we had for you today, but I hope you're starting to see

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
why we find these things so fascinating.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
Because every one of these six changed our understanding

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
of what was possible in the world. Prior to seeing this,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
we would have assumed: a 10-foot pole couldn't fit in your pocket;

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
something as inexpensive as ink couldn't sense the way paper is being bent;

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:53.958
every one of these things -- and we're constantly trying to find more.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
ZK: This is something that Keith and I really enjoy doing.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:59.958
I'm sure it's obvious to you now, but it was actually yesterday

There's a young director, Hollywood director, with his friends --

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
fellow filmmakers -- talking about what cinema means.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:45.958
I suppose that will take me to my last piece --

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
what cinema means for me.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
My life started as a -- I started life in 1966,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
a few months before the Biafran, which lasted for three years

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
and it was three years of war.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
So that whole thing,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:05.958
that whole childhood echoes and takes me into the next piece.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
(Video) Voice: Onicha, off to school with your brother.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
Onicha: Yes, mama.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:15.958
Commander: Soldiers, you are going to fight a battle,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
so you must get ready and willing to die.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:19.958
You must get -- ?

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
Child Soldiers: Ready and willing to die.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:28.958
C: Success, the change is only coming through the barrel of the gun.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
CS: The barrel of the gun!

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:31.958
C: This is the gun.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:35.958
CS: This is the gun.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
C: This is an AK-47 rifle. This is your life.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:43.958
This is your life. This is ... this is ... this is your life.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
Ezra: They give us the special drugs. We call it bubbles.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
Amphetamines.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
Soldiers: Rain come, sun come, soldier man dey go.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
I say rain come, sun come, soldier man dey go.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
We went from one village to another -- three villages.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
I don’t remember how we got there.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
Witness: We walked and walked for two days.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
We didn't eat.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:08.958
There was no food, just little rice.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
The injection made us not to have mind.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
God will forgive us.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
He knows we did not know. We did not know!

Committee Chairman: Do you remember January 6th, 1999?

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
Ezra: I don’t remember.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
Various Voices: You will die! You will die! (Screaming)

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
Onicha: Ezra! (Ezra: Onicha! Onicha!)

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:54.958
Various Voices: ♫ We don't need no more trouble ♫

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
♫ No more trouble ♫

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
They killed my mother.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
The Mende sons of bastards.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
(Shouting)

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
Who is she?

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:06.958
Me.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:07.958

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
So you can stop staring at me.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
My story is a little bit complicated.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
I’m interested.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
Mariam is pregnant.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
You know what you are? A crocodile.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
Big mouth. Short legs.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
In front of Rufus you are Ezra the coward.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
He’s not taking care of his troops.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:33.958
Troop, pay your last honor. Salute.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
Open your eyes, Ezra.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
A blind man can see that the diamonds end up in his pocket.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:45.958
♫ We don't need no more trouble ♫

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
Get that idiot out!

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
I take you are preparing a major attack?

This must be the mine.

Your girl is here.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:59.958
Well done, well done.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
That is what you are here for, no?

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
You are planning to go back to fight are you?

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:12.958
♫ We don't need no more trouble ♫

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
♫ No more trouble ♫

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:24.958
♫ We don't need no more trouble ♫

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
♫ No more trouble. ♫

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
Wake up! Everybody wake up. Road block!

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
♫ We don't need no more ... ♫

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:04.958
Committee Chairman: We hope that, with your help and the help of others, that this commission

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:09.958
will go a long way towards understanding the causes of the rebel war.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
More than that, begin a healing process and finally to --

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:17.958
as an act of closure to a terrible period in this country’s history.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:18.958
The beginning of hope.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
Mr. Ezra Gelehun, please stand.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:35.958
State your name and age for the commission.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
Ezra: My name is Ezra Gelehun.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:41.958
I am 15 or 16. I don’t remember.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:46.958
Ask my sister, she is the witch, she knows everything.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:51.958

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958

E: We were fighting for our freedom.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:05.958
then you have to charge every soldier in the world.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:09.958

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:13.958
You too are a retired General, not so?

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
CC: Yes, correct.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
E: So you too must stand trial then.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:21.958
Our government was corrupt.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:26.958
Lack of education was their way to control power.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
If I may ask, do you pay for school in your country?

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:34.958
CC: No, we don’t.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
E: You are richer than us.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
But we pay for school.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
Your country talks about democracy,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:46.958
but you support corrupt governments like my own.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
Why? Because you want our diamond.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:53.958
Ask if anyone in this room have ever seen real diamond before?

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:55.958
No.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:16:01.958
CC: Mr. Gelehun, I'd like to remind you, you're not on trial here today.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:02.958
You are not on trial.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
E: Then let me go.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
CC: I can't do that, son.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
E: So you are a liar.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
NA: Thank you. Just very quickly to say that my point really here,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
is that while we’re making all these huge advancements,

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:23.958
what we're doing, which for me, you know, I think we should --

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:27.958
Africa should move forward, but we should remember,

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
so we do not go back here again.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:30.958
Thank you.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
Emeka Okafor: Thank you, Newton.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
(Applause)

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:39.958
One of the themes that comes through very strongly

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:49.958
in the piece we just watched is this sense of the psychological trauma of the young

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:54.958
that have to play this role of being child soldiers.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:58.958
And considering where you are coming from,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:04.958
and when we consider the extent to which it’s not taken as seriously

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:08.958
as it should be, what would you have to say about that?

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.958
NA: In the process of my research, I actually spent

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
a bit of time in Sierra Leone researching this.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:19.958
And I remember I met a lot of child soldiers --

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:23.958
ex-combatants, as they like to be called.

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:30.958
I met psychosocial workers who worked with them.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
I met psychiatrists who spent time with them,

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
aid workers, NGOs, the whole lot.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:40.958
But I remember on the flight back on my last trip,

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:44.958
I remember breaking down in tears and thinking to myself,

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:50.958
if any kid in the West, in the western world,

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:55.958
went through a day of what any of those kids have gone through,

00:17:55.958 --> 00:18:01.958
they will be in therapy for the rest of their natural lives.

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:06.958
So for me, the thought that we have all these children --

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:09.958
it’s a generation, we have a whole generation of children --

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:16.958
who have been put through so much psychological trauma or damage,

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:18.958
and Africa has to live with that.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:20.958
But I’m just saying to factor that in,

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:23.958
factor that in with all this great advancement,

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:25.958
all this pronouncement of great achievement.

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:29.958
That’s really my thinking.

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:32.958
EO: Well, we thank you again for coming to the TED stage.

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:34.958
That was a very moving piece.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:35.958
NA: Thank you.

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:36.958
EO: Thank you.

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:37.958
(Applause)

title: The balancing act of compassion
transcript: One of my favorite cartoon characters is Snoopy. I love the way he sits and lies on his kennel and contemplates the great things of life. So when I thought about compassion, my mind immediately went to one of the cartoon strips, where he's lying there and he says, "I really understand, and I really appreciate how one should love one's neighbor as one love's oneself. The only trouble is the people next door; I can't stand them." This, in a way, is one of the challenges of how to interpret a really good idea.We all, I think, believe in compassion. If you look at all the world religions, all the main world religions, you'll find within them some teaching concerning compassion. So in Judaism, we have, from our Torah, that you should love your neighbor as you love yourself. And within Jewish teachings, the rabbinic teachings, we have Hillel, who taught that you shouldn't do to others what you don't like being done to yourself. And all the main religions have similar teachings. And again, within Judaism, we have a teaching about God, who is called the compassionate one, Ha-rachaman. After all, how could the world exist without God being compassionate? And we, as taught within the Torah that we are made in the image of God, so we too have to be compassionate. But what does it mean? How does it impact on our everyday life? Sometimes, of course, being compassionate can produce feelings within us that are very difficult to control.I know there are many times when I've gone and conducted a funeral, or when I have been sitting with the bereaved, or with people who are dying, and I am overwhelmed by the sadness, by the difficulty, the challenge that is there for the family, for the person. And I'm touched, so that tears come to my eyes. And yet, if I just allowed myself to be overwhelmed by these feelings, I wouldn't be doing my job — because I have to actually be there for them and make sure that rituals happen, that practicalities are seen to. And yet, on the other hand, if I didn't feel this compassion, then I feel that it would be time for me to hang up my robe and give up being a rabbi.And these same feelings are there for all of us as we face the world. Who cannot be touched by compassion when we see the terrible horrors of the results of war, or famine, or earthquakes, or tsunamis? I know some people who say "Well, you know there's just so much out there — I can't do anything, I'm not going to even begin to try." And there are some charity workers who call this compassion fatigue. There are others who feel they can't confront compassion anymore, and so they turn off the television and don't watch. In Judaism, though, we tend to always say, there has to be a middle way.You have to, of course, be aware of the needs of others, but you have to be aware in such a way that you can carry on with your life and be of help to people. So part of compassion has to be an understanding of what makes people tick. And, of course, you can't do that unless you understand yourself a bit more.And there's a lovely rabbinic interpretation of the beginnings of creation, which says that when God created the world, God thought that it would be best to create the world only with the divine attribute of justice. Because, after all, God is just. Therefore, there should be justice throughout the world. And then God looked to the future and realized, if the world was created just with justice, the world couldn't exist.So, God thought, "Nope, I'm going to create the world just with compassion." And then God looked to the future and realized that, in fact, if the world were just filled with compassion, there would be anarchy and chaos. There had to be limits to all things. The rabbis describe this as being like a king who has a beautiful, fragile glass bowl. If you put too much cold water in, it will shatter. If you put boiling water in, it will shatter. What do you have to do? Put in a mixture of the two. And so God put both of these possibilities into the world.There is something more though that has to be there. And that is the translation of the feelings that we may have about compassion into the wider world, into action. So, like Snoopy, we can't just lie there and think great thoughts about our neighbors. We actually have to do something about it. And so there is also, within Judaism, this notion of love and kindness that becomes very important: "chesed."All these three things, then, have to be melded together. The idea of justice, which gives boundaries to our lives and gives us a feeling of what's right about life, what's right about living, what should we be doing, social justice. There has to be a willingness to do good deeds, but not, of course, at the expense of our own sanity. You know, there's no way that you can do anything for anyone if you overdo things. And balancing them all in the middle is this notion of compassion, which has to be there, if you like, at our very roots.This idea of compassion comes to us because we're made in the image of God, who is ultimately the compassionate one. What does this compassion entail? It entails understanding the pain of the other. But even more than that, it means understanding one's connection to the whole of creation: understanding that one is part of that creation, that there is a unity that underlies all that we see, all that we hear, all that we feel. I call that unity God. And that unity is something that connects all of creation.And, of course, in the modern world, with the environmental movement, we're becoming even more aware of the connectivity of things, that something I do here actually does matter in Africa, that if I use too much of my carbon allowance, it seems to be that we are causing a great lack of rain in central and eastern Africa. So there is a connectivity, and I have to understand that — as part of the creation, as part of me being made in the image of God. And I have to understand that my needs sometimes have to be sublimated to other needs.This "18 minutes" business, I find quite fascinating. Because in Judaism, the number 18, in Hebrew letters, stands for life — the word "life." So, in a sense, the 18 minutes is challenging me to say, "In life, this is what's important in terms of compassion." But, something else as well: actually, 18 minutes is important. Because at Passover, when we have to eat unleavened bread, the rabbis say, what is the difference between dough that is made into bread, and dough that is made into unleavened bread, or "matzah"? And they say "It's 18 minutes." Because that's how long they say it takes for this dough to become leaven. What does it mean, "dough becomes leaven"? It means it gets filled with hot air. What's matzah? What's unleavened bread? You don't get it.Symbolically, what the rabbis say is that at Passover, what we have to do is try to get rid of our hot air — our pride, our feeling that we are the most important people in the whole entire world, and that everything should revolve round us. So we try and get rid of those, and so doing, try to get rid of the habits, the emotions, the ideas that enslave us, that make our eyes closed, give us tunnel vision so we don't see the needs of others — and free ourselves and free ourselves from that. And that too is a basis for having compassion, for understanding our place in the world.Now there is, in Judaism, a gorgeous story of a rich man who sat in synagogue one day. And, as many people do, he was dozing off during the sermon. And as he was dozing off, they were reading from the book of Leviticus in the Torah. And they were saying that in the ancient times in the temple in Jerusalem, the priests used to have bread, which they used to place into a special table in the temple in Jerusalem. The man was asleep, but he heard the words bread, temple, God, and he woke up. He said, "God wants bread. That's it. God wants bread. I know what God wants."And he rushed home. And after the Sabbath, he made 12 loaves of bread, took them to the synagogue, went into the synagogue, opened the ark and said, "God, I don't know why you want this bread, but here you are." And he put it in the ark with the scrolls of the Torah. Then he went home.The cleaner came into the synagogue. "Oh God, I'm in such trouble. I've got children to feed. My wife's ill. I've got no money. What can I do?" He goes into the synagogue. "God, will you please help me? Ah, what a wonderful smell." He goes to the ark. He opens the ark. "There's bread! God, you've answered my plea. You've answered my question." Takes the bread and goes home.Meanwhile, the rich man thinks to himself, "I'm an idiot. God wants bread? God, the one who rules the entire universe, wants my bread?" He rushes to the synagogue. "I'll get it out of the ark before anybody finds it." He goes in there, and it's not there. And he says, "God, you really did want it. You wanted my bread. Next week, with raisins."This went on for years. Every week, the man would bring bread with raisins, with all sorts of good things, put it into the ark. Every week, the cleaner would come. "God you've answered my plea again." Take the bread. Take it home.Went on until a new rabbi came. Rabbis always spoil things. The rabbi came in and saw what was going on. And he called the two of them to his office. And he said, you know, "This is what's happening."And the rich man — oh, dear — crestfallen. "You mean God didn't want my bread?"And the poor man said, "And you mean God didn't answer my pleas?"And the rabbi said, "You've misunderstood me. You've misunderstood totally," he said. "Of course, what you are doing," he said to the rich man, "is answering God's plea that we should be compassionate. And God," he said to the poor man, "is answering your plea that people should be compassionate and give." He looked at the rich man. He held the rich man's hands and said, "Don't you understand?" He said, "These are the hands of God."So that is the way I feel: that I can only try to approach this notion of being compassionate, of understanding that there is a connectivity, that there is a unity in this world; that I want to try and serve that unity, and that I can try and do that by understanding, I hope, trying to understand something of the pain of others; but understanding that there are limits, that people have to bear responsibility for some of the problems that come upon them; and that I have to understand that there are limits to my energy, to the giving I can give. I have to reevaluate them, try and separate out the material things and my emotions that may be enslaving me, so that I can see the world clearly.And then I have to try to see in what ways I can make these the hands of God. And so try to bring compassion to life in this world.

and give up being a rabbi.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:13.958
And these same feelings are there for all of us as we face the world.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:17.958
Who cannot be touched by compassion

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:24.958
when we see the terrible horrors of the results of war,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:29.958
or famine, or earthquakes, or tsunamis?

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
I know some people who say

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:35.958
"Well, you know there's just so much out there -- I can't do anything,

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:39.958
I'm not going to even begin to try."

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:45.958
And there are some charity workers who call this compassion fatigue.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:52.958
There are others who feel they can't confront compassion anymore,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:57.958
and so they turn off the television and don't watch.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:04.958
In Judaism, though, we tend to always say, there has to be a middle way.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:11.958
You have to, of course, be aware of the needs of others,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:16.958
but you have to be aware in such a way that you can carry on with your life

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:19.958
and be of help to people.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:28.958
So part of compassion has to be an understanding of what makes people tick.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
And, of course, you can't do that unless you understand yourself a bit more.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:38.958
And there's a lovely rabbinic interpretation of the beginnings of creation,

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:42.958
which says that when God created the world,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:48.958
God thought that it would be best to create the world

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:52.958
only with the divine attribute of justice.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
Because, after all, God is just.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:59.958
Therefore, there should be justice throughout the world.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
And then God looked to the future and realized,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:06.958
if the world was created just with justice, the world couldn't exist.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:12.958
So, God thought, "Nope, I'm going to create the world just with compassion."

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:16.958
And then God looked to the future and realized that,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:20.958
in fact, if the world were just filled with compassion,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
there would be anarchy and chaos.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
There had to be limits to all things.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:32.958
The rabbis describe this as being like a king

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:38.958
who has a beautiful, fragile glass bowl.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
If you put too much cold water in, it will shatter.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
If you put boiling water in, it will shatter.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:49.958
What do you have to do? Put in a mixture of the two.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:57.958
And so God put both of these possibilities into the world.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:01.958
There is something more though that has to be there.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:06.958
And that is the translation of the feelings

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
that we may have about compassion

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:13.958
into the wider world, into action.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
So, like Snoopy, we can't just lie there

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
and think great thoughts about our neighbors.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
We actually have to do something about it.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:27.958
And so there is also, within Judaism, this notion of love and kindness

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:32.958
that becomes very important: "chesed."

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:37.958
All these three things, then, have to be melded together.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:43.958
The idea of justice, which gives boundaries to our lives

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:50.958
and gives us a feeling of what's right about life, what's right about living,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:54.958
what should we be doing, social justice.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:59.958
There has to be a willingness to do good deeds,

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:03.958
but not, of course, at the expense of our own sanity.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
You know, there's no way that you can do anything for anyone

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
if you overdo things.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:14.958
And balancing them all in the middle is this notion of compassion,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:20.958
which has to be there, if you like, at our very roots.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:25.958
This idea of compassion comes to us

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
because we're made in the image of God,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:32.958
who is ultimately the compassionate one.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
What does this compassion entail?

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:39.958
It entails understanding the pain of the other.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
But even more than that,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:49.958
it means understanding one's connection to the whole of creation:

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:53.958
understanding that one is part of that creation,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:57.958
that there is a unity that underlies all that we see,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:01.958
all that we hear, all that we feel.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
I call that unity God.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:09.958
And that unity is something that connects all of creation.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
And, of course, in the modern world, with the environmental movement,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:17.958
we're becoming even more aware of the connectivity of things,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:22.958
that something I do here actually does matter in Africa,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:26.958
that if I use too much of my carbon allowance,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
it seems to be that we are causing

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:35.958
a great lack of rain in central and eastern Africa.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
So there is a connectivity,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:43.958
and I have to understand that -- as part of the creation,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:48.958
as part of me being made in the image of God.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:52.958
And I have to understand that my needs

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:56.958
sometimes have to be sublimated to other needs.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:01.958
This "18 minutes" business, I find quite fascinating.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:06.958
Because in Judaism, the number 18, in Hebrew letters,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
stands for life -- the word "life."

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:14.958
So, in a sense, the 18 minutes is challenging me to say,

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:18.958
"In life, this is what's important in terms of compassion."

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
But, something else as well:

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
actually, 18 minutes is important.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:29.958
Because at Passover, when we have to eat unleavened bread,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:33.958
the rabbis say, what is the difference between dough that is made into bread,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
and dough that is made into unleavened bread, or "matzah"?

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
And they say "It's 18 minutes."

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:44.958
Because that's how long they say it takes for this dough to become leaven.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
What does it mean, "dough becomes leaven"?

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
It means it gets filled with hot air.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:54.958
What's matzah? What's unleavened bread? You don't get it.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:59.958
Symbolically, what the rabbis say is that at Passover,

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:05.958
what we have to do is try to get rid of our hot air -- our pride,

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:09.958
our feeling that we are the most important people in the whole entire world,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:13.958
and that everything should revolve round us.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
So we try and get rid of those,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:23.958
and so doing, try to get rid of the habits, the emotions, the ideas

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:29.958
that enslave us, that make our eyes closed, give us tunnel vision

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
so we don't see the needs of others --

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
and free ourselves and free ourselves from that.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:41.958
And that too is a basis for having compassion,

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:47.958
for understanding our place in the world.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:52.958
Now there is, in Judaism, a gorgeous story

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:58.958
of a rich man who sat in synagogue one day.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:04.958
And, as many people do, he was dozing off during the sermon.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:10.958
And as he was dozing off, they were reading from the book of Leviticus in the Torah.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:16.958
And they were saying that in the ancient times in the temple in Jerusalem,

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
the priests used to have bread,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:26.958
which they used to place into a special table in the temple in Jerusalem.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:33.958
The man was asleep, but he heard the words bread, temple, God, and he woke up.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:38.958
He said, "God wants bread. That's it. God wants bread. I know what God wants."

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:45.958
And he rushed home. And after the Sabbath, he made 12 loaves of bread,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
took them to the synagogue, went into the synagogue,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:52.958
opened the ark and said, "God, I don't know why you want this bread, but here you are."

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:57.958
And he put it in the ark with the scrolls of the Torah.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
Then he went home.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
The cleaner came into the synagogue.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:07.958
"Oh God, I'm in such trouble. I've got children to feed.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
My wife's ill. I've got no money. What can I do?"

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:15.958
He goes into the synagogue. "God, will you please help me?

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
Ah, what a wonderful smell."

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
He goes to the ark. He opens the ark.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:24.958
"There's bread! God, you've answered my plea. You've answered my question."

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
Takes the bread and goes home.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
Meanwhile, the rich man thinks to himself,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
"I'm an idiot. God wants bread?

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:38.958
God, the one who rules the entire universe, wants my bread?"

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
He rushes to the synagogue. "I'll get it out of the ark before anybody finds it."

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
He goes in there, and it's not there.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:49.958
And he says, "God, you really did want it. You wanted my bread.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
Next week, with raisins."

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
This went on for years.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
Every week, the man would bring bread with raisins,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
with all sorts of good things, put it into the ark.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:04.958
Every week, the cleaner would come. "God you've answered my plea again."

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
Take the bread. Take it home.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
Went on until a new rabbi came. Rabbis always spoil things.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:14.958
The rabbi came in and saw what was going on.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
And he called the two of them to his office.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
And he said, you know, "This is what's happening."

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:25.958
And the rich man -- oh, dear -- crestfallen.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:29.958
"You mean God didn't want my bread?"

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:36.958
And the poor man said, "And you mean God didn't answer my pleas?"

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:40.958
And the rabbi said, "You've misunderstood me.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
You've misunderstood totally," he said.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:47.958
"Of course, what you are doing," he said to the rich man,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:53.958
"is answering God's plea that we should be compassionate.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And God," he said to the poor man, "is answering your plea

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:01.958
that people should be compassionate and give."

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:07.958
He looked at the rich man. He held the rich man's hands and said,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:13.958
"Don't you understand?" He said, "These are the hands of God."

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:24.958
So that is the way I feel:

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:31.958
that I can only try to approach this notion of being compassionate,

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:37.958
of understanding that there is a connectivity, that there is a unity in this world;

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:42.958
that I want to try and serve that unity,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:46.958
and that I can try and do that by understanding, I hope,

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:51.958
trying to understand something of the pain of others;

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
but understanding that there are limits, that people have to bear responsibility

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:59.958
for some of the problems that come upon them;

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
and that I have to understand that there are limits to my energy,

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
to the giving I can give.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
I have to reevaluate them,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:13.958
try and separate out the material things

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:17.958
and my emotions that may be enslaving me,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:21.958
so that I can see the world clearly.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:26.958
And then I have to try to see in what ways

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:31.958
I can make these the hands of God.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:35.958
And so try to bring compassion to life in this world.

title: The profound journey of compassion
transcript: A human child is born, and for quite a long time is a consumer. It cannot be consciously a contributor. It is helpless. It doesn't know how to survive, even though it is endowed with an instinct to survive. It needs the help of mother, or a foster mother, to survive. It can't afford to doubt the person who tends the child. It has to totally surrender, as one surrenders to an anesthesiologist.It has to totally surrender. That implies a lot of trust. That implies the trusted person won't violate the trust. As the child grows, it begins to discover that the person trusted is violating the trust. It doesn't know even the word "violation." Therefore, it has to blame itself, a wordless blame, which is more difficult to really resolve — the wordless self-blame.As the child grows to become an adult: so far, it has been a consumer, but the growth of a human being lies in his or her capacity to contribute, to be a contributor. One cannot contribute unless one feels secure, one feels big, one feels: I have enough.To be compassionate is not a joke. It's not that simple. One has to discover a certain bigness in oneself. That bigness should be centered on oneself, not in terms of money, not in terms of power you wield, not in terms of any status that you can command in the society, but it should be centered on oneself. The self: you are self-aware. On that self, it should be centered — a bigness, a wholeness. Otherwise, compassion is just a word and a dream.You can be compassionate occasionally, more moved by empathy than by compassion. Thank God we are empathetic. When somebody's in pain, we pick up the pain.In a Wimbledon final match, these two guys fight it out. Each one has got two games. It can be anybody's game. What they have sweated so far has no meaning. One person wins. The tennis etiquette is, both the players have to come to the net and shake hands. The winner boxes the air and kisses the ground, throws his shirt as though somebody is waiting for it. (Laughter) And this guy has to come to the net. When he comes to the net, you see, his whole face changes. It looks as though he's wishing that he didn't win. Why? Empathy.That's human heart. No human heart is denied of that empathy. No religion can demolish that by indoctrination. No culture, no nation and nationalism — nothing can touch it because it is empathy. And that capacity to empathize is the window through which you reach out to people, you do something that makes a difference in somebody's life — even words, even time.Compassion is not defined in one form. There's no Indian compassion. There's no American compassion. It transcends nation, the gender, the age. Why? Because it is there in everybody. It's experienced by people occasionally.Then this occasional compassion, we are not talking about — it will never remain occasional. By mandate, you cannot make a person compassionate. You can't say, "Please love me." Love is something you discover. It's not an action, but in the English language, it is also an action. I will come to it later.So one has got to discover a certain wholeness. I am going to cite the possibility of being whole, which is within our experience, everybody's experience. In spite of a very tragic life, one is happy in moments which are very few and far between. And the one who is happy, even for a slapstick joke, accepts himself and also the scheme of things in which one finds oneself.That means the whole universe, known things and unknown things. All of them are totally accepted because you discover your wholeness in yourself. The subject — "me" — and the object — the scheme of things — fuse into oneness, an experience nobody can say, "I am denied of," an experience common to all and sundry.That experience confirms that, in spite of all your limitations — all your wants, desires, unfulfilled, and the credit cards and layoffs and, finally, baldness — you can be happy. But the extension of the logic is that you don't need to fulfill your desire to be happy. You are the very happiness, the wholeness that you want to be.There's no choice in this: that only confirms the reality that the wholeness cannot be different from you, cannot be minus you. It has got to be you. You cannot be a part of wholeness and still be whole. Your moment of happiness reveals that reality, that realization, that recognition: "Maybe I am the whole. Maybe the swami is right.Maybe the swami is right." You start your new life. Then everything becomes meaningful. I have no more reason to blame myself. If one has to blame oneself, one has a million reasons plus many. But if I say, in spite of my body being limited — if it is black it is not white, if it is white it is not black: body is limited any which way you look at it. Limited.Your knowledge is limited, health is limited, and power is therefore limited, and the cheerfulness is going to be limited. Compassion is going to be limited. Everything is going to be limitless. You cannot command compassion unless you become limitless, and nobody can become limitless, either you are or you are not. Period. And there is no way of your being not limitless too.Your own experience reveals, in spite of all limitations, you are the whole. And the wholeness is the reality of you when you relate to the world. It is love first. When you relate to the world, the dynamic manifestation of the wholeness is, what we say, love. And itself becomes compassion if the object that you relate to evokes that emotion. Then that again transforms into giving, into sharing. You express yourself because you have compassion.To discover compassion, you need to be compassionate. To discover the capacity to give and share, you need to be giving and sharing. There is no shortcut: it is like swimming by swimming. You learn swimming by swimming. You cannot learn swimming on a foam mattress and enter into water. (Laughter) You learn swimming by swimming. You learn cycling by cycling. You learn cooking by cooking, having some sympathetic people around you to eat what you cook. (Laughter)And, therefore, what I say, you have to fake it and make it. (Laughter) You need to. My predecessor meant that. You have to act it out. You have to act compassionately.There is no verb for compassion, but you have an adverb for compassion. That's interesting to me. You act compassionately. But then, how to act compassionately if you don't have compassion? That is where you fake. You fake it and make it. This is the mantra of the United States of America. (Laughter)You fake it and make it. You act compassionately as though you have compassion: grind your teeth, take all the support system. If you know how to pray, pray. Ask for compassion. Let me act compassionately. Do it. You'll discover compassion and also slowly a relative compassion, and slowly, perhaps if you get the right teaching, you'll discover compassion is a dynamic manifestation of the reality of yourself, which is oneness, wholeness, and that's what you are.With these words, thank you very much. (Applause)
