00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.958
I want to open by quoting Einstein's wonderful statement,

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:20.958
just so people will feel at ease that the great scientist of the 20th century

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:24.958
also agrees with us, and also calls us to this action.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:29.958
He said, "A human being is a part of the whole, called by us, the 'universe,' --

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958
a part limited in time and space.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:35.958
He experiences himself, his thoughts and feelings,

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:38.958
as something separated from the rest,

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:42.958
a kind of optical delusion of his consciousness.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
This delusion is a kind of prison for us,

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:51.958
restricting us to our personal desires and to affection for a few persons nearest to us.

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:57.958
Our task must be to free ourselves from this prison by widening our circle of compassion,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:01.958
to embrace all living creatures and the whole of nature in its beauty."

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:06.958
This insight of Einstein's is uncannily close to that of Buddhist psychology,

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:10.958
wherein compassion -- "karuna," it is called --

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:13.958
is defined as, "the sensitivity to another's suffering

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:18.958
and the corresponding will to free the other from that suffering."

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:22.958
It pairs closely with love, which is the will for the other to be happy,

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:26.958
which requires, of course, that one feels some happiness oneself

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:29.958
and wishes to share it.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
This is perfect in that it clearly opposes self-centeredness

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:36.958
and selfishness to compassion, the concern for others,

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:41.958
and, further, it indicates that those caught in the cycle of self-concern

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:45.958
suffer helplessly, while the compassionate are more free

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
and, implicitly, more happy.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:52.958
The Dalai Lama often states that compassion is his best friend.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
It helps him when he is overwhelmed with grief and despair.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:59.958
Compassion helps him turn away from the feeling of his suffering

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:04.958
as the most absolute, most terrible suffering anyone has ever had

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:07.958
and broadens his awareness of the sufferings of others,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:12.958
even of the perpetrators of his misery and the whole mass of beings.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
In fact, suffering is so huge and enormous,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
his own becomes less and less monumental.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:24.958
And he begins to move beyond his self-concern into the broader concern for others.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
And this immediately cheers him up,

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:30.958
as his courage is stimulated to rise to the occasion.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
Thus, he uses his own suffering

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:36.958
as a doorway to widening his circle of compassion.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:40.958
He is a very good colleague of Einstein's, we must say.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
Now, I want to tell a story,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
which is a very famous story in the Indian and Buddhist tradition,

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
of the great Saint Asanga

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
who was a contemporary of Augustine in the West

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
and was sort of like the Buddhist Augustine.

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:56.958
And Asanga lived 800 years after the Buddha's time.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:59.958
And he was discontented with the state of people's practice

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
of the Buddhist religion in India at that time.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:05.958
And so he said, "I'm sick of all this. Nobody's really living the doctrine.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
They're talking about love and compassion and wisdom and enlightenment,

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
but they are acting selfish and pathetic.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
So, Buddha's teaching has lost its momentum.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
I know the next Buddha will come a few thousand years from now,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:21.958
but exists currently in a certain heaven" -- that's Maitreya --

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
"so, I'm going to go on a retreat and I'm going to meditate

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:28.958
and pray until the Buddha Maitreya reveals himself to me,

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
and gives me a teaching or something

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:34.958
to revive the practice of compassion in the world today."

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
So he went on this retreat. And he meditated for three years

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
and he did not see the future Buddha Maitreya.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
And he left in disgust.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
And as he was leaving, he saw a man --

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
a funny little man sitting sort of part way down the mountain.

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.958
And he had a lump of iron.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
And he was rubbing it with a cloth.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
And he became interested in that.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
He said, "Well what are you doing?"

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:02.958
And the man said, "I'm making a needle."

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
And he said, "That's ridiculous. You can't make a needle

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
by rubbing a lump of iron with a cloth."

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
And the man said, "Really?" And he showed him a dish full of needles.

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
So he said, "Okay, I get the point."

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
He went back to his cave. He meditated again.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
Another three years, no vision. He leaves again.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
This time, he comes down.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:23.958
And as he's leaving, he sees a bird making a nest on a cliff ledge.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:27.958
And where it's landing to bring the twigs to the cliff,

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:31.958
its feathers brushes the rock -- and it had cut the rock

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:34.958
six to eight inches in. There was a cleft in the rock

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
by the brushing of the feathers of generations of the birds.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
So he said, "All right. I get the point." He went back.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
Another three years.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
Again, no vision of Maitreya after nine years.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
And he again leaves, and this time: water dripping,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:50.958
making a giant bowl in the rock where it drips in a stream.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:54.958
And so, again, he goes back. And after 12 years there is still no vision.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
And he's freaked out. And he won't even look left or right

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
to see any encouraging vision.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
And he comes to the town. He's a broken person.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
And there, in the town, he's approached by a dog

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:09.958
who comes like this -- one of these terrible dogs you can see in some poor countries,

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
even in America, I think, in some areas --

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
and he's looking just terrible.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
And he becomes interested in this dog because it's so pathetic,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
and it's trying to attract his attention. And he sits down looking at the dog.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:24.958
And the dog's whole hindquarters are a complete open sore.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
Some of it is like gangrenous,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
and there are maggots in the flesh. And it's terrible.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
He thinks, "What can I do to fix up this dog?

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:35.958
Well, at least I can clean this wound and wash it."

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
So, he takes it to some water. He's about to clean,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:41.958
but then his awareness focuses on the maggots.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.958
And he sees the maggots, and the maggots are kind of looking a little cute.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
And they're maggoting happily in the dog's hindquarters there.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:51.958
"Well, if I clean the dog, I'll kill the maggots. So how can that be?

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
That's it. I'm a useless person and there's no Buddha, no Maitreya,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
and everything is all hopeless.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
And now I'm going to kill the maggots?"

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
So, he had a brilliant idea.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:06.958
And he took a shard of something, and cut a piece of flesh from his thigh,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
and he placed it on ground.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:12.958
He was not really thinking too carefully about the ASPCA.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
He was just immediately caught with the situation.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
So he thought, "I will take the maggots and put them on this piece of flesh,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
then clean the dog's wounds, and then

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
I'll figure out what to do with the maggots."

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
So he starts to do that. He can't grab the maggots.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:29.958
Apparently they wriggle around. They're kind of hard to grab, these maggots.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:33.958
So he says, "Well, I'll put my tongue on the dog's flesh.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
And then the maggots will jump on my warmer tongue" --

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
the dog is kind of used up --

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
"and then I'll spit them one by one down on the thing."

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
So he goes down, and he's sticking his tongue out like this.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:48.958
And he had to close his eyes, it's so disgusting, and the smell and everything.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
And then, suddenly, there's a pfft, a noise like that.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:54.958
He jumps back and there, of course, is the future Buddha Maitreya

00:06:54.958 --> 00:07:01.958
in a beautiful vision -- rainbow lights, golden, jeweled, a plasma body,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
an exquisite mystic vision -- that he sees.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
And he says, "Oh." He bows.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:09.958
But, being human, he's immediately thinking of his next complaint.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
So as he comes up from his first bow he says,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
"My Lord, I'm so happy to see you, but where have you been for 12 years?

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
What is this?"

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
And Maitreya says, "I was with you. Who do you think was making needles

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.958
and making nests and dripping on rocks for you, mister dense?"

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
(Laughter)

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
"Looking for the Buddha in person," he said.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:35.958
And he said, "You didn't have, until this moment, real compassion.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
And, until you have real compassion, you cannot recognize love."

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:42.958
"Maitreya" means love, "the loving one," in Sanskrit.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
And so he looked very dubious, Asanga did.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
And he said, "If you don't believe me, just take me with you."

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:52.958
And so he took the Maitreya -- it shrunk into a globe, a ball --

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
took him on his shoulder.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:58.958
And he ran into town in the marketplace, and he said, "Rejoice! Rejoice!

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:02.958
The future Buddha has come ahead of all predictions. Here he is."

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
And then pretty soon they started throwing rocks and stones at him --

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
it wasn't Chautauqua, it was some other town --

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.958
because they saw a demented looking, scrawny looking yogi man,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:17.958
like some kind of hippie, with a bleeding leg and a rotten dog on his shoulder,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
shouting that the future Buddha had come.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
So, naturally, they chased him out of town.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:26.958
But on the edge of town, one elderly lady, a charwoman in the charnel ground,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958
saw a jeweled foot on a jeweled lotus on his shoulder and then the dog,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:34.958
but she saw the jewel foot of the Maitreya, and she offered a flower.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
So that encouraged him, and he went with Maitreya.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
Maitreya then took him to a certain heaven,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
which is the typical way a Buddhist myth unfolds.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
And Maitreya then kept him in heaven for five years,

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:48.958
dictating to him five complicated tomes

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
of the methodology of how you cultivate compassion.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
And then I thought I would share with you what that method is, or one of them.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:59.958
A famous one, it's called the "Sevenfold Causal Method of Developing Compassion."

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:06.958
And it begins first by one meditating and visualizing that all beings are with one --

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:10.958
even animals too, but everyone is in human form.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
The animals are in one of their human lives. The humans are human.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:18.958
And then, among them, you think of your friends and loved ones, the circle at the table.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
And you think of your enemies, and you think of the neutral ones.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.958
And then you try to say, "Well, the loved ones I love.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
But, you know, after all, they're nice to me.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
I had fights with them. Sometimes they were unfriendly.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
I got mad. Brothers can fight. Parents and children can fight.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:36.958
So, in a way, I like them so much because they're nice to me.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:40.958
While the neutral ones I don't know. They could all be just fine.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:44.958
And then the enemies I don't like because they're mean to me.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
But they are nice to somebody. I could be them."

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
And then the Buddhists, of course, think that, because we've all had infinite previous lives,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
we've all been each other's relatives, actually.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
Therefore all of you, in the Buddhist view,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:01.958
in some previous life, although you don't remember it and neither do I,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:06.958
have been my mother -- for which I do apologize for the trouble I caused you.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
And also, actually, I've been your mother.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
I've been female, and I've been every single one of yours' mother in a previous life,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
the way the Buddhists reflect.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
So, my mother in this life is really great. But all of you in a way

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
are part of the eternal mother.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:24.958
You gave me that expression; "the eternal mama," you said. That's wonderful.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
So, that's the way the Buddhists do it.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:31.958
A theist Christian can think that all beings, even my enemies, are God's children.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
So, in that sense, we're related.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
So, they first create this foundation of equality.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
So, we sort of reduce a little of the clinging to the ones we love --

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:44.958
just in the meditation -- and we open our mind to those we don't know.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:48.958
And we definitely reduce the hostility and the "I don't want to be compassionate to them"

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:53.958
to the ones we think of as the bad guys, the ones we hate and we don't like.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
And we don't hate anyone, therefore. So we equalize. That's very important.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
And then the next thing we do is what is called "mother recognition."

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:05.958
And that is, we think of every being as familiar, as family.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:10.958
We expand. We take the feeling about remembering a mama,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:14.958
and we defuse that to all beings in this meditation.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
And we see the mother in every being.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
We see that look that the mother has on her face,

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
looking at this child that is a miracle

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
that she has produced from her own body, being a mammal,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:28.958
where she has true compassion, truly is the other, and identifies completely.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:32.958
Often the life of that other will be more important to her than her own life.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
And that's why it's the most powerful form of altruism.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.958
The mother is the model of all altruism for human beings,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
in spiritual traditions.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:48.958
And so, we reflect until we can sort of see that motherly expression in all beings.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
People laugh at me because, you know, I used to say that

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:55.958
I used to meditate on mama Cheney as my mom,

00:11:55.958 --> 00:12:00.958
when, of course, I was annoyed with him about all of his evil doings in Iraq.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
I used to meditate on George Bush. He's quite a cute mom in a female form.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
He has his little ears and he smiles and he rocks you in his arms.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
And you think of him as nursing you.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
And then Saddam Hussein's serious mustache is a problem,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
but you think of him as a mom.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
And this is the way you do it. You take any being who looks weird to you,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:21.958
and you see how they could be familiar to you.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:25.958
And you do that for a while, until you really feel that.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
You can feel the familiarity of all beings.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
Nobody seems alien. They're not "other."

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
You reduce the feeling of otherness about beings.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:37.958
Then you move from there to remembering the kindness of mothers in general,

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
if you can remember the kindness of your own mother,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
if you can remember the kindness of your spouse,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
or, if you are a mother yourself, how you were with your children.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:49.958
And you begin to get very sentimental; you cultivate sentimentality intensely.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
You will even weep, perhaps, with gratitude and kindness.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
And then you connect that with your feeling that everyone has that motherly possibility.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:01.958
Every being, even the most mean looking ones, can be motherly.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:05.958
And then, third, you step from there to what is called "a feeling of gratitude."

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:09.958
You want to repay that kindness that all beings have shown to you.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:13.958
And then the fourth step, you go to what is called "lovely love."

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
In each one of these you can take some weeks, or months, or days

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:19.958
depending on how you do it, or you can do them in a run, this meditation.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:24.958
And then you think of how lovely beings are when they are happy,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
when they are satisfied.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
And every being looks beautiful when they are internally feeling a happiness.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.958
Their face doesn't look like this. When they're angry, they look ugly, every being,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
but when they're happy they look beautiful.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
And so you see beings in their potential happiness.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
And you feel a love toward them and you want them to be happy, even the enemy.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
We think Jesus is being unrealistic

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:48.958
when he says, "Love thine enemy."

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
He does say that, and we think he's being unrealistic

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
and sort of spiritual and highfalutin. "Nice for him to say it, but I can't do that."

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
But, actually, that's practical.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
If you love your enemy that means you want your enemy to be happy.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:03.958
If your enemy was really happy, why would they bother to be your enemy?

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
How boring to run around chasing you.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
They would be relaxing somewhere having a good time.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
So it makes sense to want your enemy to be happy,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
because they'll stop being your enemy because that's too much trouble.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
But anyway, that's the "lovely love. "

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:19.958
And then finally, the fifth step is compassion, "universal compassion."

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:25.958
And that is where you then look at the reality of all the beings you can think of.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And you look at them, and you see how they are.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:31.958
And you realize how unhappy they are actually, mostly, most of the time.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
You see that furrowed brow in people.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
And then you realize they don't even have compassion on themselves.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
They're driven by this duty and this obligation.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:42.958
"I have to get that. I need more. I'm not worthy. And I should do something."

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
And they're rushing around all stressed out.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:48.958
And they think of it as somehow macho, hard discipline on themselves.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
But actually they are cruel to themselves.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
And, of course, they are cruel and ruthless toward others.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
And they, then, never get any positive feedback.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
And the more they succeed and the more power they have,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
the more unhappy they are.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
And this is where you feel real compassion for them.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
And you then feel you must act.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
And the choice of the action, of course,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:11.958
hopefully will be more practical

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:15.958
than poor Asanga, who was fixing the maggots on the dog

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
because he had that motivation, and whoever was in front of him,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
he wanted to help.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:24.958
But, of course, that is impractical. He should have founded the ASPCA in the town

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
and gotten some scientific help for dogs and maggots.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:33.958
And I'm sure he did that later. (Laughter) But that just indicates the state of mind, you know.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:37.958
And so the next step -- the sixth step beyond "universal compassion" --

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:41.958
is this thing where you're linked with the needs of others in a true way,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
and you have compassion for yourself also,

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
and it isn't sentimental only. You might be in fear of something.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:50.958
Some bad guy is making himself more and more unhappy

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
being more and more mean to other people

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
and getting punished in the future for it in various ways.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
And in Buddhism, they catch it in the future life.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
Of course in theistic religion they're punished by God or whatever.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
And materialism, they think they get out of it just by not existing,

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
by dying, but they don't.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
And so they get reborn as whatever, you know.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
Never mind. I won't get into that.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
But the next step is called "universal responsibility."

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
And that is very important -- the Charter of Compassion

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:20.958
must lead us to develop through true compassion,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
what is called "universal responsibility."

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
In the great teaching of his Holiness the Dalai Lama

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
that he always teaches everywhere, he says

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
that that is the common religion of humanity: kindness.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
But "kindness" means "universal responsibility."

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:37.958
And that means whatever happens to other beings is happening to us:

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:41.958
we are responsible for that, and we should take it

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
and do whatever we can at whatever little level

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
and small level that we can do it.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:49.958
We absolutely must do that. There is no way not to do it.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:53.958
And then, finally, that leads to a new orientation in life

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:57.958
where we live equally for ourselves and for others

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:01.958
and we are

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
joyful and happy.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
One thing we mustn't think is that compassion makes you miserable.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
Compassion makes you happy.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:12.958
The first person who is happy when you get great compassion is yourself,

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
even if you haven't done anything yet for anybody else.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:19.958
Although, the change in your mind already does something for other beings:

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:22.958
they can sense this new quality in yourself,

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
and it helps them already, and gives them an example.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:28.958
And that uncompassionate clock has just showed me that it's all over.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:33.958
So, practice compassion, read the charter, disseminate it

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
and develop it within yourself.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:38.958
Don't just think, "Well, I'm compassionate," or "I'm not compassionate,"

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:40.958
and sort of think you're stuck there.

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:43.958
You can develop this. You can diminish the non-compassion,

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:47.958
the cruelty, the callousness, the neglect of others,

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
and take universal responsibility for them.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:54.958
And then, not only will God smile and the eternal mama will smile,

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:56.958
but Karen Armstrong will smile.

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:58.958
Thank you very much. (Applause)

title: The evolution of compassion
transcript: I'm going to talk about compassion and the golden rule from a secular perspective and even from a kind of scientific perspective. I'm going to try to give you a little bit of a natural history of compassion and the golden rule. So, I'm going to be sometimes using kind of clinical language, and so it's not going to sound as warm and fuzzy as your average compassion talk. I want to warn you about that.So, I do want to say, at the outset, that I think compassion's great. The golden rule is great. I'm a big supporter of both. And I think it's great that the leaders of the religions of the world are affirming compassion and the golden rule as fundamental principles that are integral to their faiths.At the same time, I think religions don't deserve all the credit. I think nature gave them a helping hand here. I'm going to argue tonight that compassion and the golden rule are, in a certain sense, built into human nature. But I'm also going to argue that once you understand the sense in which they are built into human nature, you realize that just affirming compassion, and affirming the golden rule, is really not enough. There's a lot of work to be done after that.OK so, a quick natural history, first of compassion. In the beginning, there was compassion, and I mean not just when human beings first showed up, but actually even before that. I think it's probably the case that, in the human evolutionary lineage, even before there were homo sapiens, feelings like compassion and love and sympathy had earned their way into the gene pool, and biologists have a pretty clear idea of how this first happened.It happened through a principle known as kin selection. And the basic idea of kin selection is that, if an animal feels compassion for a close relative, and this compassion leads the animal to help the relative, then, in the end, the compassion actually winds up helping the genes underlying the compassion itself. So, from a biologist's point of view, compassion is actually a gene's way of helping itself. OK.I warned you this was not going to be very warm and fuzzy. I'll get there — I hope to get a little fuzzier. This doesn't bother me so much, that the underlying Darwinian rationale of compassion is kind of self-serving at the genetic level. Actually, I think the bad news about kin selection is just that it means that this kind of compassion is naturally deployed only within the family. That's the bad news. The good news is compassion is natural. The bad news is that this kin selected compassion is naturally confined to the family.Now, there's more good news that came along later in evolution, a second kind of evolutionary logic. Biologists call that "reciprocal altruism." OK. And there, the basic idea is that compassion leads you to do good things for people who then will return the favor. Again, I know this is not as inspiring a notion of compassion as you may have heard in the past, but from a biologist's point of view, this reciprocal altruism kind of compassion is ultimately self-serving too. It's not that people think that, when they feel the compassion. It's not consciously self-serving, but to a biologist, that's the logic. And so, you wind up most easily extending compassion to friends and allies.I'm sure a lot of you, if a close friend has something really terrible happen to them, you feel really bad. But if you read in the newspaper that something really horrible happened to somebody you've never heard of, you can probably live with that. That's just human nature. So, it's another good news/bad news story. It's good that compassion was extended beyond the family by this kind of evolutionary logic. The bad news is this doesn't bring us universal compassion by itself. So, there's still work to be done.Now, there's one other result of this dynamic called reciprocal altruism, which I think is kind of good news, which is that the way that this is played out in the human species, it has given people an intuitive appreciation of the golden rule. I don't quite mean that the golden rule itself is written in our genes, but you can go to a hunter gatherer society that has had no exposure to any of the great religious traditions, no exposure to ethical philosophy, and you'll find, if you spend time with these people, that, basically, they believe that one good turn deserves another, and that bad deeds should be punished. And evolutionary psychologists think that these intuitions have a basis in the genes. So, they do understand that if you want to be treated well, you treat other people well. And it's good to treat other people well. That's close to being a kind of built-in intuition.So, that's good news. Now, if you've been paying attention, you're probably anticipating that there's bad news here; we still aren't to universal love, and it's true because, although an appreciation of the golden rule is natural, it's also natural to carve out exceptions to the golden rule.I mean, for example, none of us, probably, want to go to prison, but we all think that there are some people who should go to prison. Right? So, we think we should treat them differently than we would want to be treated. Now, we have a rationale for that. We say they did these bad things that make it just that they should go to prison.None of us really extends the golden rule in truly diffuse and universal fashion. We have the capacity to carve out exceptions, put people in a special category. And the problem is that — although in the case of sending people to prison, you have this impartial judiciary determining who gets excluded from the golden rule — that in everyday life, the way we all make these decisions about who we're not going to extend the golden rule to, is we use a much rougher and readier formula. Basically it's just like, if you're my enemy, if you're my rival — if you're not my friend, if you're not in my family — I'm much less inclined to apply the golden rule to you.We all do that, and you see it all over the world. You see it in the Middle East: people who, from Gaza, are firing missiles at Israel. They wouldn't want to have missiles fired at them, but they say, "Well, but the Israelis, or some of them have done things that put them in a special category." The Israelis would not want to have an economic blockade imposed on them, but they impose one on Gaza, and they say, "Well, the Palestinians, or some of them, have brought this on themselves."So, it's these exclusions to the golden rule that amount to a lot of the world's trouble. And it's natural to do that. So, the fact that the golden rule is in some sense built in to us is not, by itself, going to bring us universal love. It's not going to save the world.Now, there's one piece of good news I have that may save the world. Okay. Are you on the edges of your seats here? Good, because before I tell you about that good news, I'm going to have to take a little excursion through some academic terrain. So, I hope I've got your attention with this promise of good news that may save the world.It's this non-zero-sumness stuff you just heard a little bit about. It's just a quick introduction to game theory. This won't hurt. Okay. It's about zero-sum and non-zero-sum games. If you ask what kind of a situation is conducive to people becoming friends and allies, the technical answer is a non-zero-sum situation. And if you ask what kind of situation is conducive to people defining people as enemies, it's a zero-sum situation.So, what do those terms mean? Basically, a zero-sum game is the kind you're used to in sports, where there's a winner and a loser. So, their fortunes add up to zero. So, in tennis, every point is either good for you and bad for the other person, or good for them, bad for you. Either way, your fortunes add up to zero. That's a zero-sum game.Now, if you're playing doubles, then the person on your side of the net is in a non-zero-sum relationship with you, because every point is either good for both of you — positive, win-win — or bad for both of you, it's lose-lose. That's a non-zero-sum game. And in real life, there are lots of non-zero-sum games. In the realm of economics, say, if you buy something: that means you'd rather have the merchandise than the money, but the merchant would rather have the money than the merchandise. You both feel you've won. In a war, two allies are playing a non-zero-sum game. It's going to either be win-win or lose-lose for them.So, there are lots of non-zero-sum games in real life. And you could basically reformulate what I said earlier, about how compassion is deployed and the golden rule is deployed, by just saying, well, compassion most naturally flows along non-zero-sum channels where people perceive themselves as being in a potentially win-win situation with some of their friends or allies. The deployment of the golden rule most naturally happens along these non-zero-sum channels. So, kind of webs of non-zero-sumness are where you would expect compassion and the golden rule to kind of work their magic. With zero-sum channels you would expect something else.Okay. So, now you're ready for the good news that I said might save the world. And now I can admit that it might not too, now that I've held your attention for three minutes of technical stuff. But it may. And the good news is that history has naturally expanded these webs of non-zero-sumness, these webs that can be these channels for compassion. You can go back all the way to the stone age: technological evolution — roads, the wheel, writing, a lot of transportation and communication technologies — has just inexorably made it so that more people can be in more non-zero-sum relationships with more and more people at greater and greater distances. That's the story of civilization. It's why social organization has grown from the hunter-gatherer village to the ancient state, the empire, and now here we are in a globalized world. And the story of globalization is largely a story of non-zero-sumness.You've probably heard the term "interdependence" applied to the modern world. Well, that's just another term for non-zero-sum. If your fortunes are interdependent with somebody, then you live in a non-zero-sum relationship with them. And you see this all the time in the modern world. You saw it with the recent economic crash, where bad things happen in the economy — bad for everybody, for much of the world. Good things happen, and it's good for much of the world.And, you know, I'm happy to say, I think there's really evidence that this non-zero-sum kind of connection can expand the moral compass. I mean, if you look at the American attitudes toward Japanese during World War II — look at the depictions of Japanese in the American media as just about subhuman, and look at the fact that we dropped atomic bombs, really without giving it much of a thought — and you compare that to the attitude now, I think part of that is due to a kind of economic interdependence.Any form of interdependence, or non-zero-sum relationship forces you to acknowledge the humanity of people. So, I think that's good. And the world is full of non-zero-sum dynamics. Environmental problems, in many ways, put us all in the same boat. And there are non-zero-sum relationships that maybe people aren't aware of.For example, probably a lot of American Christians don't think of themselves as being in a non-zero-sum relationship with Muslims halfway around the world, but they really are, because if these Muslims become happier and happier with their place in the world and feel that they have a place in it, that's good for Americans, because there will be fewer terrorists to threaten American security. If they get less and less happy, that will be bad for Americans.So, there's plenty of non-zero-sumness. And so, the question is: If there's so much non-zero-sumness, why has the world not yet been suffused in love, peace, and understanding? The answer's complicated. It's the occasion for a whole other talk. Certainly, a couple of things are that, first of all, there are a lot of zero-sum situations in the world. And also, sometimes people don't recognize the non-zero-sum dynamics in the world. In both of these areas, I think politicians can play a role.This isn't only about religion. I think politicians can help foster non-zero-sum relationships, Economic engagement is generally better than blockades and so on, in this regard. And politicians can be aware, and should be aware that, when people around the world are looking at them, are looking at their nation and picking up their cues for whether they are in a zero-sum or a non-zero-sum relationship with a nation — like, say, America, or any other nation — human psychology is such that they use cues like: Do we feel we're being respected? Because, you know, historically, if you're not being respected, you're probably not going to wind up in a non-zero-sum, mutually profitable relationship with people. So, we need to be aware of what kind of signals we're sending out. And some of this, again, is in the realm of political work.If there's one thing I can encourage everyone to do, politicians, religious leaders, and us, it would be what I call "expanding the moral imagination" — that is to say, your ability to put yourself in the shoes of people in very different circumstances. This is not the same as compassion, but it's conducive to compassion. It opens the channels for compassion. And I'm afraid we have another good news/bad news story, which is that the moral imagination is part of human nature. That's good, but again we tend to deploy it selectively.Once we define somebody as an enemy, we have trouble putting ourselves in their shoes, just naturally. So, if you want to take a particularly hard case for an American: somebody in Iran who is burning an American flag, and you see them on TV. Well, the average American is going to resist the moral exercise of putting themselves in that person's head and is going to resist the idea that they have much in common with that person. And if you tell them, "Well, they think America disrespects them and even wants to dominate them, and they hate America. Has there ever been somebody who disrespected you so much that you kind of hated them briefly"? You know, they'll resist that comparison and that's natural, that's human.And, similarly, the person in Iran: when you try to humanize somebody in America who said that Islam is evil, they'll have trouble with that. So, it's a very difficult thing to get people to expand the moral imagination to a place it doesn't naturally go. I think it's worth the trouble because, again, it just helps us to understand. If you want to reduce the number of people who are burning flags, it helps to understand what makes them do it. And I think it's good moral exercise.I would say here is where religious leaders come in, because religious leaders are good at reframing issues for people, at harnessing the emotional centers of the brain to get people to alter their awareness and reframe the way they think. I mean, religious leaders are kind of in the inspiration business. It's their great calling right now, to get people all around the world better at expanding their moral imaginations, appreciating that in so many ways they're in the same boat.I would just sum up the way things look, at least from this secular perspective, as far as compassion and the golden rule go, by saying that it's good news that compassion and the golden rule are in some sense built into human nature. It's unfortunate that they tend to be selectively deployed. And it's going to take real work to change that. But, nobody ever said that doing God's work was going to be easy. Thanks. (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:16.958
I'm going to talk about compassion and the golden rule

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:22.958
from a secular perspective and even from a kind of scientific perspective.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:25.958
I'm going to try to give you a little bit of a natural history

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:27.958
of compassion and the golden rule.

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:32.958
So, I'm going to be sometimes using kind of clinical language,

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
and so it's not going to sound as warm and fuzzy

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.958
as your average compassion talk.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:39.958
I want to warn you about that.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:43.958
So, I do want to say, at the outset, that I think compassion's great.

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:46.958
The golden rule is great. I'm a big supporter of both.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
And I think it's great that

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
the leaders of the religions of the world

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:56.958
are affirming compassion and the golden rule as fundamental principles

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.958
that are integral to their faiths.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
At the same time, I think religions don't deserve all the credit.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:06.958
I think nature gave them a helping hand here.

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:11.958
I'm going to argue tonight that compassion and the golden rule

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
are, in a certain sense, built into human nature.

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
But I'm also going to argue

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:20.958
that once you understand the sense in which they are built into human nature,

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:24.958
you realize that just affirming compassion,

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:27.958
and affirming the golden rule, is really not enough.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:30.958
There's a lot of work to be done after that.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:35.958
OK so, a quick natural history, first of compassion.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:38.958
In the beginning, there was compassion,

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
and I mean not just when human beings first showed up,

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
but actually even before that.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:47.958
I think it's probably the case that, in the human evolutionary lineage,

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:50.958
even before there were homo sapiens,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
feelings like compassion and love and sympathy

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:56.958
had earned their way into the gene pool,

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
and biologists have a pretty clear idea of how this first happened.

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:03.958
It happened through a principle known as kin selection.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:09.958
And the basic idea of kin selection is that,

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
if an animal feels compassion for a close relative,

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:16.958
and this compassion leads the animal to help the relative,

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:21.958
then, in the end, the compassion actually winds up helping the genes

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:24.958
underlying the compassion itself.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:28.958
So, from a biologist's point of view, compassion is actually

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:32.958
a gene's way of helping itself. OK.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:36.958
I warned you this was not going to be very warm and fuzzy.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
I'll get there -- I hope to get a little fuzzier.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:41.958
This doesn't bother me so much,

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:45.958
that the underlying Darwinian rationale of compassion

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
is kind of self-serving at the genetic level.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
Actually, I think the bad news about kin selection

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:54.958
is just that it means that this kind of compassion

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:57.958
is naturally deployed only within the family.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
That's the bad news. The good news is compassion is natural.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
The bad news is that this kin selected compassion

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
is naturally confined to the family.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:09.958
Now, there's more good news that came along later in evolution,

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:12.958
a second kind of evolutionary logic.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
Biologists call that "reciprocal altruism." OK.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
And there, the basic idea is that

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:26.958
compassion leads you to do good things for people who then will return the favor.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:31.958
Again, I know this is not as inspiring a notion of compassion

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
as you may have heard in the past,

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:38.958
but from a biologist's point of view, this reciprocal altruism kind of compassion

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:41.958
is ultimately self-serving too.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
It's not that people think that, when they feel the compassion.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:48.958
It's not consciously self-serving, but to a biologist, that's the logic.

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:54.958
And so, you wind up most easily extending compassion to friends and allies.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:04:00.958
I'm sure a lot of you, if a close friend has something really terrible happen to them,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
you feel really bad.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:03.958
But if you read in the newspaper

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.958
that something really horrible happened to somebody you've never heard of,

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
you can probably live with that.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
That's just human nature.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
So, it's another good news/bad news story.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
It's good that compassion was extended beyond the family

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
by this kind of evolutionary logic.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:21.958
The bad news is this doesn't bring us universal compassion by itself.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
So, there's still work to be done.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:28.958
Now, there's one other result of this dynamic called reciprocal altruism,

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
which I think is kind of good news,

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:34.958
which is that the way that this is played out in the human species,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:38.958
it has given people an intuitive appreciation of the golden rule.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:42.958
I don't quite mean that the golden rule itself is written in our genes,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:46.958
but you can go to a hunter gatherer society

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
that has had no exposure to any of the great religious traditions,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
no exposure to ethical philosophy,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
and you'll find, if you spend time with these people,

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
that, basically, they believe that one good turn deserves another,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
and that bad deeds should be punished.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:04.958
And evolutionary psychologists think that these intuitions have a basis in the genes.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:08.958
So, they do understand that if you want to be treated well,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
you treat other people well.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
And it's good to treat other people well.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:16.958
That's close to being a kind of built-in intuition.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
So, that's good news. Now, if you've been paying attention,

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
you're probably anticipating that there's bad news here;

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
we still aren't to universal love,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:29.958
and it's true because, although an appreciation of the golden rule is natural,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:34.958
it's also natural to carve out exceptions to the golden rule.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:38.958
I mean, for example, none of us, probably, want to go to prison,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
but we all think that there are some people who should go to prison. Right?

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:45.958
So, we think we should treat them differently than we would want to be treated.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
Now, we have a rationale for that.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:52.958
We say they did these bad things that make it just that they should go to prison.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:56.958
None of us really extends the golden rule in truly diffuse and universal fashion.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
We have the capacity to carve out exceptions,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
put people in a special category.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:05.958
And the problem is that -- although in the case of sending people to prison,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
you have this impartial judiciary

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:12.958
determining who gets excluded from the golden rule --

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:16.958
that in everyday life, the way we all make these decisions

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
about who we're not going to extend the golden rule to,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
is we use a much rougher and readier formula.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:26.958
Basically it's just like, if you're my enemy, if you're my rival --

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
if you're not my friend, if you're not in my family --

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:33.958
I'm much less inclined to apply the golden rule to you.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
We all do that,

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
and you see it all over the world.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
You see it in the Middle East:

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
people who, from Gaza, are firing missiles at Israel.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
They wouldn't want to have missiles fired at them, but they say,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
"Well, but the Israelis, or some of them have done things

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
that put them in a special category."

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
The Israelis would not want to have an economic blockade imposed on them,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
but they impose one on Gaza, and they say,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
"Well, the Palestinians, or some of them, have brought this on themselves."

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:06.958
So, it's these exclusions to the golden rule that amount to a lot of the world's trouble.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
And it's natural to do that.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
So, the fact that the golden rule is in some sense built in to us

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:18.958
is not, by itself, going to bring us universal love.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
It's not going to save the world.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:25.958
Now, there's one piece of good news I have that may save the world. Okay.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
Are you on the edges of your seats here?

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
Good, because before I tell you about that good news,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:35.958
I'm going to have to take a little excursion through some academic terrain.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
So, I hope I've got your attention with this promise of good news

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
that may save the world.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
It's this non-zero-sumness stuff you just heard a little bit about.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
It's just a quick introduction to game theory.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
This won't hurt. Okay.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
It's about zero-sum and non-zero-sum games.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:55.958
If you ask what kind of a situation

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
is conducive to people becoming friends and allies,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
the technical answer is a non-zero-sum situation.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
And if you ask what kind of situation

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
is conducive to people defining people as enemies,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
it's a zero-sum situation.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
So, what do those terms mean?

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
Basically, a zero-sum game is the kind you're used to in sports,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
where there's a winner and a loser.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
So, their fortunes add up to zero.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:22.958
So, in tennis, every point is either good for you and bad for the other person,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
or good for them, bad for you.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
Either way, your fortunes add up to zero. That's a zero-sum game.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
Now, if you're playing doubles,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
then the person on your side of the net

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
is in a non-zero-sum relationship with you,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
because every point is either good for both of you -- positive, win-win --

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
or bad for both of you, it's lose-lose.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
That's a non-zero-sum game.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
And in real life, there are lots of non-zero-sum games.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
In the realm of economics, say, if you buy something:

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
that means you'd rather have the merchandise than the money,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
but the merchant would rather have the money than the merchandise.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
You both feel you've won.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
In a war, two allies are playing a non-zero-sum game.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
It's going to either be win-win or lose-lose for them.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:08.958
So, there are lots of non-zero-sum games in real life.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
And you could basically reformulate what I said earlier,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
about how compassion is deployed and the golden rule is deployed,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:21.958
by just saying, well, compassion most naturally flows along non-zero-sum channels

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
where people perceive themselves as being in a potentially win-win situation

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
with some of their friends or allies.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
The deployment of the golden rule

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
most naturally happens along these non-zero-sum channels.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
So, kind of webs of non-zero-sumness

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:38.958
are where you would expect compassion and the golden rule

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
to kind of work their magic.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
With zero-sum channels you would expect something else.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:46.958
Okay. So, now you're ready for the good news that I said might save the world.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
And now I can admit that it might not too,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:55.958
now that I've held your attention for three minutes of technical stuff.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:10:00.958
But it may. And the good news is that history

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:04.958
has naturally expanded these webs of non-zero-sumness,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:08.958
these webs that can be these channels for compassion.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
You can go back all the way to the stone age:

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:19.958
technological evolution -- roads, the wheel, writing,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
a lot of transportation and communication technologies --

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
has just inexorably made it so that more people

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
can be in more non-zero-sum relationships

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
with more and more people at greater and greater distances.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
That's the story of civilization.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:39.958
It's why social organization has grown from the hunter-gatherer village

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
to the ancient state, the empire, and now here we are in a globalized world.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:46.958
And the story of globalization is largely a story of non-zero-sumness.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
You've probably heard the term "interdependence"

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
applied to the modern world. Well, that's just another term for non-zero-sum.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
If your fortunes are interdependent with somebody,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
then you live in a non-zero-sum relationship with them.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
And you see this all the time in the modern world.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
You saw it with the recent economic crash,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
where bad things happen in the economy --

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
bad for everybody, for much of the world.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
Good things happen, and it's good for much of the world.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
And, you know, I'm happy to say, I think there's really evidence

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
that this non-zero-sum kind of connection

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
can expand the moral compass.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
I mean, if you look at the American attitudes

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:27.958
toward Japanese during World War II --

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
look at the depictions of Japanese

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
in the American media as just about subhuman,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
and look at the fact that we dropped atomic bombs,

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
really without giving it much of a thought --

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
and you compare that to the attitude now,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
I think part of that is due to a kind of economic interdependence.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
Any form of interdependence, or non-zero-sum relationship

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
forces you to acknowledge the humanity of people.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
So, I think that's good.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
And the world is full of non-zero-sum dynamics.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:56.958
Environmental problems, in many ways, put us all in the same boat.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:12:01.958
And there are non-zero-sum relationships that maybe people aren't aware of.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:05.958
For example, probably a lot of American Christians

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:09.958
don't think of themselves as being in a non-zero-sum relationship

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
with Muslims halfway around the world,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:16.958
but they really are, because if these Muslims become happier and happier

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:19.958
with their place in the world and feel that they have a place in it,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
that's good for Americans, because there will be fewer terrorists

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
to threaten American security.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:28.958
If they get less and less happy, that will be bad for Americans.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
So, there's plenty of non-zero-sumness.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:36.958
And so, the question is: If there's so much non-zero-sumness,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:40.958
why has the world not yet been suffused in love, peace, and understanding?

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
The answer's complicated. It's the occasion for a whole other talk.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:47.958
Certainly, a couple of things are that,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:51.958
first of all, there are a lot of zero-sum situations in the world.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:55.958
And also, sometimes people don't recognize

00:12:55.958 --> 00:13:00.958
the non-zero-sum dynamics in the world.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
In both of these areas,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
I think politicians can play a role.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
This isn't only about religion.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:12.958
I think politicians can help foster non-zero-sum relationships,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
Economic engagement is generally better than blockades and so on,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
in this regard.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
And politicians can be aware, and should be aware that,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
when people around the world are looking at them,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
are looking at their nation

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
and picking up their cues

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
for whether they are in a zero-sum or a non-zero-sum relationship with a nation --

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
like, say, America, or any other nation --

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
human psychology is such that they use cues like:

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
Do we feel we're being respected?

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
Because, you know, historically, if you're not being respected,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
you're probably not going to wind up in a non-zero-sum,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
mutually profitable relationship with people.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:52.958
So, we need to be aware of what kind of signals we're sending out.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And some of this, again, is in the realm of political work.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
If there's one thing I can encourage everyone to do,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
politicians, religious leaders, and us,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:07.958
it would be what I call "expanding the moral imagination" --

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
that is to say, your ability to put yourself in the shoes

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
of people in very different circumstances.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
This is not the same as compassion,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:21.958
but it's conducive to compassion. It opens the channels for compassion.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
And I'm afraid we have another good news/bad news story,

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
which is that the moral imagination is part of human nature.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:32.958
That's good, but again we tend to deploy it selectively.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
Once we define somebody as an enemy,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:39.958
we have trouble putting ourselves in their shoes, just naturally.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:43.958
So, if you want to take a particularly hard case for an American:

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:47.958
somebody in Iran who is burning an American flag, and you see them on TV.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
Well, the average American is going to resist

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:54.958
the moral exercise of putting themselves in that person's head

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
and is going to resist the idea that they have much in common with that person.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:01.958
And if you tell them, "Well, they think America disrespects them

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
and even wants to dominate them, and they hate America.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
Has there ever been somebody who disrespected you so much

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
that you kind of hated them briefly"?

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
You know, they'll resist that comparison and that's natural, that's human.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
And, similarly, the person in Iran:

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:17.958
when you try to humanize somebody in America who said that Islam is evil,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
they'll have trouble with that.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:24.958
So, it's a very difficult thing to get people to expand the moral imagination

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
to a place it doesn't naturally go.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
I think it's worth the trouble because,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
again, it just helps us to understand.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
If you want to reduce the number of people who are burning flags,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
it helps to understand what makes them do it.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
And I think it's good moral exercise.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
I would say here is where religious leaders come in,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:49.958
because religious leaders are good at reframing issues for people,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
at harnessing the emotional centers of the brain

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:56.958
to get people to alter their awareness and reframe the way they think.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:00.958
I mean, religious leaders are kind of in the inspiration business.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
It's their great calling right now,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:06.958
to get people all around the world better at expanding their moral imaginations,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
appreciating that in so many ways they're in the same boat.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:16.958
I would just sum up the way things look, at least from this secular perspective,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:20.958
as far as compassion and the golden rule go,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:26.958
by saying that it's good news that compassion and the golden rule

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:31.958
are in some sense built into human nature.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:36.958
It's unfortunate that they tend to be selectively deployed.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:40.958
And it's going to take real work to change that.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:45.958
But, nobody ever said that doing God's work was going to be easy. Thanks.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.958
(Applause)

title: A flight through the ocean
transcript: I think the future of this planet depends on humans, not technology, and we already have the knowledge — we’re kind of at the endgame with knowledge. But we’re nowhere near the endgame when it comes to our perception. We still have one foot in the dark ages. And when you listen to some of the presentations here — and the extraordinary range of human capability, our understandings — and then you contrast it with the fact we still call this planet, "Earth:" it’s pretty extraordinary — we have one foot in the dark ages.Just quickly: Aristotle, his thing was, "It’s not flat, stupid, it’s round." Galileo — he had the Inquisition, so he had to be a little bit more polite — his was, "It’s not in the middle, you know." And Hawkes: "it’s not earth, stupid, it’s ocean." This is an ocean planet. T.S. Eliot really said it for me — and this should give you goose bumps: "we shall not cease from exploration and the end of our exploring shall be to return where we started and know the place for the first time." And the next lines are, "Through the unknown remembered gate, where the last of earth discovered is that which is the beginning." So I have one message. It seems to me that we’re all pointed in the wrong direction.For the rocketeers in the audience: I love what you’re doing, I admire the guts, I admire the courage — but your rockets are pointed in the wrong goddamn direction. (Laughter) And it’s all a question of perspective. Let me try and tell you — I don’t mean to insult you, but look, if I — and I’m not doing this for real because it would be an insult, so I’m going to pretend, and it softens the blow — I’m going to tell you what you’re thinking. If I held up a square that was one foot square and the color of earth, and I held up another square that was the root two square — so it’s 1.5 times bigger — and was the color of the oceans; and I said, what is the relative value of these two things? Well, it’s the relative importance. You would say — yeah, yeah, yeah, we all know this; water covers twice the area of the planet than dry land. But it’s a question of perception, and if that’s what you’re thinking, if that’s what you think I mean when I say, "This is an ocean planet stupidly called 'Earth.'" If you think that that’s the relative importance, two to one, you’re wrong by a factor of ten. Now, you’re not as thick as two short planks, but you sound like it when you say "Earth," because that demonstration, if I turned around this way — that earth plane would be as thin as paper. It’s a thin film, two-dimensional existence. The ocean representation would have a depth to it. And if you hefted those two things you might find that the relative scale of those is 20 to 1.It turns out that something more than 94 percent of life on earth is aquatic. That means that us terrestrials occupy a minority. The problem we have in believing that is — you just have to give up this notion that this Earth was created for us. Because it’s a problem we have. If this is an ocean planet and we only have a small minority of this planet, it just interferes with a lot of what humanity thinks.Okay. Let me criticize this thing. I’m not talking about James Cameron — although I could, but I won’t. You really do have to go and see his latest film, "Aliens of the Deep." It’s incredible. It features two of these deep rovers, and I can criticize them because these sweet things are mine. This, I think, represents one of the most beautiful classic submersibles built. If you look at that sub, you’ll see a sphere. This is an acryclic sphere. It generates all of the buoyancy, all of the payload for the craft, and the batteries are down here hanging underneath, exactly like a balloon. This is the envelope, and this is the gondola, the payload. Also coming up later for criticism are these massive lights. And this one actually carries two great manipulators. It actually is a very good working sub — that’s what it was designed for. The problem with it is — and the reason I will never build another one like it — is that this is a product of two-dimensional thinking. It’s what we humans do when we go in the ocean as engineers; we take all our terrestrial hang-ups, all our constraints — importantly, these two-dimensional constraints that we have, and they’re so constrained we don’t even understand it — and we take them underwater. You notice that Jim Cameron is sitting in a seat. A seat works in a two-dimensional world, where gravity blasts down on that seat, OK? And in a two-dimensional world, we do know about the third dimension but we don’t use it because to go up requires an awful lot of energy against gravity. And then our mothers tell us, "Careful you don’t fall down" — because you’ll fall over.Now, go into the real atmosphere of this planet. This planet has an inner atmosphere of water; it’s its inner atmosphere. It has two atmospheres — a lesser, outer gaseous atmosphere, a lighter one. Most of life on earth is in that inner atmosphere. And that life enjoys a three-dimensional existence, which is alien to us. Fish do not sit in seats. (Laughter) They don’t. Their mothers don’t say to little baby fish, "Careful you don’t fall over." They don’t fall over. They don’t fall. They live in a three-dimensional world where there is no difference in energy between going this way, that way, that way or that way. It’s truly a three-dimensional space. And we’re only just beginning to grasp it. I don’t know of any other submersible, or even remote, that just takes advantage that this is a three-dimensional space.This is the way we should be going into the oceans. This is a three-dimensional machine. What we need to do is go down into the ocean with the freedom of the animals, and move in this three-dimensional space. OK, this is good stuff. This is man’s first attempt at flying underwater. Right now, I’m just coming down on this gorgeous, big, giant manta ray. She has twice the wingspan that I do. There I’m coming; she sees me. And just notice how she rolls under and turns; she doesn’t sit there and try and blow air into a tank and kind of flow up or sink down — she just rolls. And the craft that I’m in — this hasn’t been shown before. Chris asked us to show stuff that hasn’t been shown before. I wanted you to notice that she actually turned to come back up. There I am; I see her coming back, coming up underneath me. I put reverse thrust and I try and pull gently down. I’m trying to do everything very gently. We spent about three hours together and she’s beginning to trust me. And this ballet is controlled by this lady here. She gets about that close and then she pulls away. So now I try and go after her, but I’m practicing flying. This is the first flying machine. This was the first prototype. This was a fly by wire. It has wings. There’re no silly buoyancy tanks — it’s permanently, positively buoyant. And then by moving through the water it’s able to take that control. Now, look at that; look, it’s — she just blew me away. She just rolled right away from underneath. Really that’s the only real dive I’ve ever made in this machine.It took 10 years to build. But this lady here taught me, hah, taught me so much. We just learned so much in three hours in the water there. I just had to go and build another machine. But look here. Instead of blowing tanks and coming up slowly without thinking about it, it’s a little bit of back pressure, and that sub just comes straight back up out of the water.This is an internal Sony camera. Thank you, Sony. I don’t really look that ugly, but the camera is so close that it’s just distorted. Now, there she goes, right overhead. This is a wide-angle camera. She’s just a few inches off the top of my head. "Aah, ha, oh, he just crossed over the top of my head about, oh, I don’t know, just so close." I come back up, not for air. "This is an incredible encounter with a manta. I’m speechless. We’ve been just feet apart. I’m going back down now." Okay, can we cut that? Lights back up please. (Applause)Trying to fly and keep up with that animal — it wasn’t the lack of maneuverability that we had. It was the fact she was going so slow. I actually designed that to move faster through the water because I thought that was the thing that we needed to do: to move fast and get range. But after that encounter I really did want to go back with that animal and dance. She wanted to dance. And so what we needed to do was increase the wing area so that we just had more grip, develop higher forces.So the sub that was outside last year — this is the one. You see the larger wing area here. Also, clearly, it was such a powerful thing, we wanted to try and bring other people but we couldn't figure out how to do it. So we opened the world’s first flight school. The rational for the world’s first flight school goes something like: when the coastguards come up to me and say — they used to leave us alone when we were diving these goofy little spherical things, but when we started flying around in underwater jet fighters they got a little nervous — they would come up and say, "Do you have a license for that?" And then I’d put my sunglasses on, the beard that would all sprout out, and I would say, "I don’t need no stinking license." (Laughter) "I write these stinking license," which I do. So Bob Gelfond's around here — but somebody in the audience here has license number 20. They’re one of the first subsea aviators. So we’ve run two flight schools. Where the hell that goes, I don’t know, but it’s a lot of fun. What comes next in 30 seconds? I can’t tell you.But the patent for underwater flight — Karen and I, we were looking at it, some business partners wanted us to patent it — we weren’t sure about that. We’ve decided we’re just going to let that go. It just seems wrong to try and patent — (Applause) — the freedom for underwater flight. So anybody who wants to copy us and come and join us, go for it. The other thing is that we’ve got much lower costs. We developed some other technology called spider optics, and Craig Ventner asked me to make an announcement here this morning: we’re going to be building a beautiful, little, small version of this — unmanned, super deep — for his boat to go and get back some deep sea DNA stuff. (Applause) Thank you.
