00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
classic submersibles built.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:20.958
If you look at that sub, you’ll see a sphere.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:21.958
This is an acryclic sphere.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
It generates all of the buoyancy,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
all of the payload for the craft,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
and the batteries are down here hanging underneath,

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
exactly like a balloon.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:33.958
This is the envelope, and this is the gondola, the payload.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:38.958
Also coming up later for criticism are these massive lights.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
And this one actually carries two great manipulators.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
It actually is a very good working sub --

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
that’s what it was designed for.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
The problem with it is --

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
and the reason I will never build another one like it --

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:55.958
is that this is a product of two-dimensional thinking.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
It’s what we humans do when we go in the ocean as engineers;

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
we take all our terrestrial hang-ups,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
all our constraints -- importantly,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
these two-dimensional constraints that we have,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
and they’re so constrained we don’t even understand it --

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
and we take them underwater.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:15.958
You notice that Jim Cameron is sitting in a seat.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
A seat works in a two-dimensional world,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:22.958
where gravity blasts down on that seat, OK?

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
And in a two-dimensional world,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:25.958
we do know about the third dimension

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
but we don’t use it because to go up

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
requires an awful lot of energy against gravity.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:31.958
And then our mothers tell us,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:35.958
"Careful you don’t fall down" -- because you’ll fall over.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:40.958
Now, go into the real atmosphere of this planet.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:44.958
This planet has an inner atmosphere of water;

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
it’s its inner atmosphere. It has two atmospheres --

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:50.958
a lesser, outer gaseous atmosphere, a lighter one.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:54.958
Most of life on earth is in that inner atmosphere.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
And that life enjoys a three-dimensional existence,

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
which is alien to us.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:04.958
Fish do not sit in seats.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:05.958
(Laughter)

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:11.958
They don’t. Their mothers don’t say to little baby fish,

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
"Careful you don’t fall over."

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
They don’t fall over. They don’t fall.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:17.958
They live in a three-dimensional world

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
where there is no difference in energy

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
between going this way, that way, that way or that way.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
It’s truly a three-dimensional space.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
And we’re only just beginning to grasp it.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
I don’t know of any other submersible,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:33.958
or even remote, that just takes advantage

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
that this is a three-dimensional space.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
This is the way we should be going into the oceans.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
This is a three-dimensional machine.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
What we need to do is go down into the ocean with the freedom of the animals,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
and move in this three-dimensional space.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:47.958
OK, this is good stuff.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
This is man’s first attempt at flying underwater.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:56.958
Right now, I’m just coming down on this gorgeous, big, giant manta ray.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
She has twice the wingspan that I do.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
There I’m coming; she sees me.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
And just notice how she rolls under and turns;

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
she doesn’t sit there and try and blow air into a tank

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:11.958
and kind of flow up or sink down -- she just rolls.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
And the craft that I’m in --

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
this hasn’t been shown before.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
Chris asked us to show stuff that hasn’t been shown before.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:19.958
I wanted you to notice

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
that she actually turned to come back up.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
There I am; I see her coming back,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
coming up underneath me.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
I put reverse thrust and I try and pull gently down.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
I’m trying to do everything very gently.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
We spent about three hours together and she’s beginning to trust me.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:39.958
And this ballet is controlled by this lady here.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
She gets about that close and then she pulls away.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:48.958
So now I try and go after her, but I’m practicing flying.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:52.958
This is the first flying machine. This was the first prototype.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:57.958
This was a fly by wire. It has wings.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
There’re no silly buoyancy tanks --

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
it’s permanently, positively buoyant.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:03.958
And then by moving through the water

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
it’s able to take that control.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
Now, look at that; look, it’s -- she just blew me away.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.958
She just rolled right away from underneath.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:18.958
Really that’s the only real dive I’ve ever made in this machine.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
It took 10 years to build.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:27.958
But this lady here taught me, hah, taught me so much.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:31.958
We just learned so much in three hours in the water there.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
I just had to go and build another machine.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
But look here. Instead of blowing tanks

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
and coming up slowly without thinking about it,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
it’s a little bit of back pressure,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
and that sub just comes straight back up out of the water.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:48.958
This is an internal Sony camera. Thank you, Sony.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
I don’t really look that ugly,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
but the camera is so close that it’s just distorted.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
Now, there she goes, right overhead.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:56.958
This is a wide-angle camera.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:00.958
She’s just a few inches off the top of my head.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:07.958
"Aah, ha, oh, he just crossed over the top of my head about,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:12.958
oh, I don’t know, just so close."

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:13.958
I come back up, not for air.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:19.958
"This is an incredible encounter with a manta. I’m speechless.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
We’ve been just feet apart. I’m going back down now."

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
Okay, can we cut that? Lights back up please.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:30.958
(Applause)

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
Trying to fly and keep up with that animal --

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:37.958
it wasn’t the lack of maneuverability that we had.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
It was the fact she was going so slow.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:43.958
I actually designed that to move faster through the water

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:44.958
because I thought that was the thing

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
that we needed to do: to move fast and get range.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
But after that encounter I really did want to go back with that animal and dance.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
She wanted to dance.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
And so what we needed to do was increase the wing area

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:01.958
so that we just had more grip, develop higher forces.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
So the sub that was outside last year -- this is the one.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:08.958
You see the larger wing area here.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
Also, clearly, it was such a powerful thing,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:11.958
we wanted to try and bring other people

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
but we couldn't figure out how to do it.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
So we opened the world’s first flight school.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
The rational for the world’s first flight school

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
goes something like: when the coastguards come up to me and say --

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
they used to leave us alone when we were diving

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
these goofy little spherical things,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:27.958
but when we started flying around

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
in underwater jet fighters they got a little nervous --

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:34.958
they would come up and say,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
"Do you have a license for that?"

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
And then I’d put my sunglasses on, the beard

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
that would all sprout out, and I would say,

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
"I don’t need no stinking license."

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
(Laughter)

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
"I write these stinking license," which I do.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
So Bob Gelfond's around here --

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:56.958
but somebody in the audience here has license number 20.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
They’re one of the first subsea aviators.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
So we’ve run two flight schools.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:07.958
Where the hell that goes, I don’t know, but it’s a lot of fun.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:12.958
What comes next in 30 seconds? I can’t tell you.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
But the patent for underwater flight --

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
Karen and I, we were looking at it,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
some business partners wanted us to patent it --

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:20.958
we weren’t sure about that.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
We’ve decided we’re just going to let that go.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
It just seems wrong to try and patent --

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:26.958
(Applause)

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
-- the freedom for underwater flight.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:29.958
So anybody who wants to copy us

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
and come and join us, go for it.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:37.958
The other thing is that we’ve got much lower costs.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:38.958
We developed some other technology

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:42.958
called spider optics, and Craig Ventner asked me

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
to make an announcement here this morning:

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
we’re going to be building a beautiful, little,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
small version of this -- unmanned, super deep --

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:54.958
for his boat to go and get back some deep sea DNA stuff.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
(Applause)

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:58.958
Thank you.

title: The power and the danger of online crowds
transcript: This was in an area called Wellawatta, a prime residential area in Colombo. We stood on the railroad tracks that ran between my friend's house and the beach. The tracks are elevated about eight feet from the waterline normally, but at that point the water had receded to a level three or four feet below normal. I'd never seen the reef here before. There were fish caught in rock pools left behind by the receding water. Some children jumped down and ran to the rock pools with bags. They were trying to catch fish. No one realized that this was a very bad idea. The people on the tracks just continued to watch them. I turned around to check on my friend's house. Then someone on the tracks screamed. Before I could turn around, everyone on the tracks was screaming and running.The water had started coming back. It was foaming over the reef. The children managed to run back onto the tracks. No one was lost there. But the water continued to climb. In about two minutes, it had reached the level of the railroad tracks and was coming over it. We had run about 100 meters by this time. It continued to rise. I saw an old man standing at his gate, knee-deep in water, refusing to move. He said he'd lived his whole life there by the beach, and that he would rather die there than run. A boy broke away from his mother to run back into his house to get his dog, who was apparently afraid. An old lady, crying, was carried out of her house and up the road by her son. The slum built on the railroad reservation between the sea and the railroad tracks was completely swept away. Since this was a high-risk location, the police had warned the residents, and no one was there when the water rose. But they had not had any time to evacuate any belongings. For hours afterwards, the sea was strewn with bits of wood for miles around — all of this was from the houses in the slum. When the waters subsided, it was as if it had never existed.This may seem hard to believe — unless you've been reading lots and lots of news reports — but in many places, after the tsunami, villagers were still terrified. When what was a tranquil sea swallows up people, homes and long-tail boats — mercilessly, without warning — and no one can tell you anything reliable about whether another one is coming, I'm not sure you'd want to calm down either. One of the scariest things about the tsunami that I've not seen mentioned is the complete lack of information. This may seem minor, but it is terrifying to hear rumor after rumor after rumor that another tidal wave, bigger than the last, will be coming at exactly 1 p.m., or perhaps tonight, or perhaps ... You don't even know if it is safe to go back down to the water, to catch a boat to the hospital. We think that Phi Phi hospital was destroyed. We think this boat is going to Phuket hospital, but if it's too dangerous to land at its pier, then perhaps it will go to Krabi instead, which is more protected. We don't think another wave is coming right away.At the Phi Phi Hill Resort, I was tucked into the corner furthest away from the television, but I strained to listen for information. They reported that there was an 8.5 magnitude earthquake in Sumatra, which triggered the massive tsunami. Having this news was comforting in some small way to understand what had just happened to us. However, the report focused on what had already occurred and offered no information on what to expect now. In general, everything was merely hearsay and rumor, and not a single person I spoke to for over 36 hours knew anything with any certainty. Those were two accounts of the Asian tsunami from two Internet blogs that essentially sprang up after it occurred. I'm now going to show you two video segments from the tsunami that also were shown on blogs. I should warn you, they're pretty powerful. One from Thailand, and the second one from Phuket as well.(Screaming)Voice 1: It's coming in. It's coming again.Voice 2: It's coming again?Voice 1: Yeah. It's coming again.Voice 2: Come get inside here.Voice 1: It's coming again. Voice 2: New wave? Voice 1: It's coming again. New wave! [Unclear](Screaming)They called me out here.James Surowiecki: Phew. Those were both on this site: waveofdestruction.org. In the world of blogs, there's going to be before the tsunami and after the tsunami, because one of the things that happened in the wake of the tsunami was that, although initially — that is, in that first day — there was actually a kind of dearth of live reporting, there was a dearth of live video and some people complained about this. They said, "The blogsters let us down." What became very clear was that, within a few days, the outpouring of information was immense, and we got a complete and powerful picture of what had happened in a way that we never had been able to get before. And what you had was a group of essentially unorganized, unconnected writers, video bloggers, etc., who were able to come up with a collective portrait of a disaster that gave us a much better sense of what it was like to actually be there than the mainstream media could give us.And so in some ways the tsunami can be seen as a sort of seminal moment, a moment in which the blogosphere came, to a certain degree, of age. Now, I'm going to move now from this kind of — the sublime in the traditional sense of the word, that is to say, awe-inspiring, terrifying — to the somewhat more mundane. Because when we think about blogs, I think for most of us who are concerned about them, we're primarily concerned with things like politics, technology, etc. And I want to ask three questions in this talk, in the 10 minutes that remain, about the blogosphere. The first one is, What does it tell us about our ideas, about what motivates people to do things? The second is, Do blogs genuinely have the possibility of accessing a kind of collective intelligence that has previously remained, for the most part, untapped? And then the third part is, What are the potential problems, or the dark side of blogs as we know them?OK, the first question: What do they tell us about why people do things? One of the fascinating things about the blogosphere specifically, and, of course, the Internet more generally — and it's going to seem like a very obvious point, but I think it is an important one to think about — is that the people who are generating these enormous reams of content every day, who are spending enormous amounts of time organizing, linking, commenting on the substance of the Internet, are doing so primarily for free. They are not getting paid for it in any way other than in the attention and, to some extent, the reputational capital that they gain from doing a good job. And this is — at least, to a traditional economist — somewhat remarkable, because the traditional account of economic man would say that, basically, you do things for a concrete reward, primarily financial. But instead, what we're finding on the Internet — and one of the great geniuses of it — is that people have found a way to work together without any money involved at all. They have come up with, in a sense, a different method for organizing activity.The Yale Law professor Yochai Benkler, in an essay called "Coase's Penguin," talks about this open-source model, which we're familiar with from Linux, as being potentially applicable in a whole host of situations. And, you know, if you think about this with the tsunami, what you have is essentially a kind of an army of local journalists, who are producing enormous amounts of material for no reason other than to tell their stories. That's a very powerful idea, and it's a very powerful reality. And it's one that offers really interesting possibilities for organizing a whole host of activities down the road.So, I think the first thing that the blogosphere tells us is that we need to expand our idea of what counts as rational, and we need to expand our simple equation of value equals money, or, you have to pay for it to be good, but that in fact you can end up with collectively really brilliant products without any money at all changing hands. There are a few bloggers — somewhere maybe around 20, now — who do, in fact, make some kind of money, and a few who are actually trying to make a full-time living out of it, but the vast majority of them are doing it because they love it or they love the attention, or whatever it is. So, Howard Rheingold has written a lot about this and, I think, is writing about this more, but this notion of voluntary cooperation is an incredibly powerful one, and one worth thinking about.The second question is, What does the blogosphere actually do for us, in terms of accessing collective intelligence? You know, as Chris mentioned, I wrote a book called "The Wisdom of Crowds." And the premise of "The Wisdom of Crowds" is that, under the right conditions, groups can be remarkably intelligent. And they can actually often be smarter than even the smartest person within them. The simplest example of this is if you ask a group of people to do something like guess how many jellybeans are in a jar. If I had a jar of jellybeans and I asked you all to guess how many jellybeans were in that jar, your average guess would be remarkably good. It would be somewhere probably within three and five percent of the number of beans in the jar, and it would be better than 90 to 95 percent of you. There may be one or two of you who are brilliant jelly bean guessers, but for the most part the group's guess would be better than just about all of you. And what's fascinating is that you can see this phenomenon at work in many more complicated situations.For instance, if you look at the odds on horses at a racetrack, they predict almost perfectly how likely a horse is to win. In a sense, the group of betters at the racetrack is forecasting the future, in probabilistic terms. You know, if you think about something like Google, which essentially is relying on the collective intelligence of the Web to seek out those sites that have the most valuable information — we know that Google does an exceptionally good job of doing that, and it does that because, collectively, this disorganized thing we call the "World Wide Web" actually has a remarkable order, or a remarkable intelligence in it. And this, I think, is one of the real promises of the blogosphere.Dan Gillmor — whose book "We the Media" is included in the gift pack — has talked about it as saying that, as a writer, he's recognized that his readers know more than he does. And this is a very challenging idea. It's a very challenging idea to mainstream media. It's a very challenging idea to anyone who has invested an enormous amount of time and expertise, and who has a lot of energy invested in the notion that he or she knows better than everyone else. But what the blogosphere offers is the possibility of getting at the kind of collective, distributive intelligence that is out there, and that we know is available to us if we can just figure out a way of accessing it. Each blog post, each blog commentary may not, in and of itself, be exactly what we're looking for, but collectively the judgment of those people posting, those people linking, more often than not is going to give you a very interesting and enormously valuable picture of what's going on. So, that's the positive side of it. That's the positive side of what is sometimes called participatory journalism or citizen journalism, etc. — that, in fact, we are giving people who have never been able to talk before a voice, and we're able to access information that has always been there but has essentially gone untapped.But there is a dark side to this, and that's what I want to spend the last part of my talk on. One of the things that happens if you spend a lot of time on the Internet, and you spend a lot of time thinking about the Internet, is that it is very easy to fall in love with the Internet. It is very easy to fall in love with the decentralized, bottom-up structure of the Internet. It is very easy to think that networks are necessarily good things — that being linked from one place to another, that being tightly linked in a group, is a very good thing. And much of the time it is. But there's also a downside to this — a kind of dark side, in fact — and that is that the more tightly linked we've become to each other, the harder it is for each of us to remain independent.One of the fundamental characteristics of a network is that, once you are linked in the network, the network starts to shape your views and starts to shape your interactions with everybody else. That's one of the things that defines what a network is. A network is not just the product of its component parts. It is something more than that. It is, as Steven Johnson has talked about, an emergent phenomenon. Now, this has all these benefits: it's very beneficial in terms of the efficiency of communicating information; it gives you access to a whole host of people; it allows people to coordinate their activities in very good ways. But the problem is that groups are only smart when the people in them are as independent as possible. This is the paradox of the wisdom of crowds, or the paradox of collective intelligence, that what it requires is actually a form of independent thinking. And networks make it harder for people to do that, because they drive attention to the things that the network values.So, one of the phenomena that's very clear in the blogosphere is that once a meme, once an idea gets going, it is very easy for people to just sort of pile on, because other people have, say, a link. People have linked to it, and so other people in turn link to it, etc., etc. And that phenomenon of piling on the existing links is one that is characteristic of the blogosphere, particularly of the political blogosphere, and it is one that essentially throws off this beautiful, decentralized, bottom-up intelligence that blogs can manifest in the right conditions.The metaphor that I like to use is the metaphor of the circular mill. A lot of people talk about ants. You know, this is a conference inspired by nature. When we talk about bottom-up, decentralized phenomena, the ant colony is the classic metaphor, because, no individual ant knows what it's doing, but collectively ants are able to reach incredibly intelligent decisions. They're able to reach food as efficiently as possible, they're able to guide their traffic with remarkable speed. So, the ant colony is a great model: you have all these little parts that collectively add up to a great thing. But we know that occasionally ants go astray, and what happens is that, if army ants are wandering around and they get lost, they start to follow a simple rule — just do what the ant in front of you does. And what happens is that the ants eventually end up in a circle. And there's this famous example of one that was 1,200 feet long and lasted for two days, and the ants just kept marching around and around in a circle until they died. And that, I think, is a sort of thing to watch out for. That's the thing we have to fear — is that we're just going to keep marching around and around until we die.Now, I want to connect this back, though, to the tsunami, because one of the great things about the tsunami — in terms of the blogosphere's coverage, not in terms of the tsunami itself — is that it really did represent a genuine bottom-up phenomenon. You saw sites that had never existed before getting huge amounts of traffic. You saw people being able to offer up their independent points of view in a way that they hadn't before. There, you really did see the intelligence of the Web manifest itself. So, that's the upside. The circular mill is the downside. And I think that the former is what we really need to strive for.Thank you very much. (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:16.958
This was in an area called Wellawatta, a prime residential area in Colombo.

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
We stood on the railroad tracks

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
that ran between my friend's house and the beach.

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:24.958
The tracks are elevated about eight feet from the waterline normally,

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
but at that point the water had receded

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
to a level three or four feet below normal.

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
I'd never seen the reef here before.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:35.958
There were fish caught in rock pools left behind by the receding water.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:40.958
Some children jumped down and ran to the rock pools with bags.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958
They were trying to catch fish.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
No one realized that this was a very bad idea.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.958
The people on the tracks just continued to watch them.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
I turned around to check on my friend's house.

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:53.958
Then someone on the tracks screamed.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:57.958
Before I could turn around, everyone on the tracks was screaming and running.

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:01.958
The water had started coming back. It was foaming over the reef.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:05.958
The children managed to run back onto the tracks.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:09.958
No one was lost there. But the water continued to climb.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
In about two minutes, it had reached the level of the railroad tracks

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:16.958
and was coming over it. We had run about 100 meters by this time.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
It continued to rise.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:23.958
I saw an old man standing at his gate, knee-deep in water, refusing to move.

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:26.958
He said he'd lived his whole life there by the beach,

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:29.958
and that he would rather die there than run.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
A boy broke away from his mother to run back into his house

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:35.958
to get his dog, who was apparently afraid.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:40.958
An old lady, crying, was carried out of her house and up the road by her son.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
The slum built on the railroad reservation

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:47.958
between the sea and the railroad tracks was completely swept away.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:50.958
Since this was a high-risk location, the police had warned the residents,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
and no one was there when the water rose.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:56.958
But they had not had any time to evacuate any belongings.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:02:00.958
For hours afterwards, the sea was strewn with bits of wood for miles around --

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
all of this was from the houses in the slum.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:07.958
When the waters subsided, it was as if it had never existed.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
This may seem hard to believe --

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
unless you've been reading lots and lots of news reports --

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:17.958
but in many places, after the tsunami, villagers were still terrified.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
When what was a tranquil sea swallows up people, homes

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
and long-tail boats -- mercilessly, without warning --

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:26.958
and no one can tell you anything reliable about whether another one is coming,

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:29.958
I'm not sure you'd want to calm down either.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
One of the scariest things about the tsunami

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:35.958
that I've not seen mentioned is the complete lack of information.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.958
This may seem minor, but it is terrifying to hear rumor after rumor

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:41.958
after rumor that another tidal wave, bigger than the last,

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:46.958
will be coming at exactly 1 p.m., or perhaps tonight, or perhaps ...

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
You don't even know if it is safe to go back down to the water,

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
to catch a boat to the hospital.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
We think that Phi Phi hospital was destroyed.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.958
We think this boat is going to Phuket hospital,

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
but if it's too dangerous to land at its pier,

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:02.958
then perhaps it will go to Krabi instead, which is more protected.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
We don't think another wave is coming right away.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
At the Phi Phi Hill Resort,

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.958
I was tucked into the corner furthest away from the television,

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
but I strained to listen for information.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
They reported that there was an 8.5 magnitude earthquake in Sumatra,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
which triggered the massive tsunami.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
Having this news was comforting in some small way

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
to understand what had just happened to us.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
However, the report focused on what had already occurred

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:27.958
and offered no information on what to expect now.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
In general, everything was merely hearsay and rumor,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
and not a single person I spoke to for over 36 hours

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
knew anything with any certainty.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:42.958
Those were two accounts of the Asian tsunami from two Internet blogs

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
that essentially sprang up after it occurred.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:50.958
I'm now going to show you two video segments from the tsunami

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
that also were shown on blogs.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
I should warn you, they're pretty powerful.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
One from Thailand, and the second one from Phuket as well.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:07.958
(Screaming)

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
Voice 1: It's coming in. It's coming again.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
Voice 2: It's coming again?

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
Voice 1: Yeah. It's coming again.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:23.958
Voice 2: Come get inside here.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
Voice 1: It's coming again. Voice 2: New wave?

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
Voice 1: It's coming again. New wave!

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
[Unclear]

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:57.958
(Screaming)

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
They called me out here.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:19.958
James Surowiecki: Phew. Those were both on this site: waveofdestruction.org.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
In the world of blogs, there's going to be before the tsunami and after the tsunami,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:28.958
because one of the things that happened in the wake of the tsunami was that,

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
although initially -- that is, in that first day --

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.958
there was actually a kind of dearth of live reporting, there was a dearth of live video

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
and some people complained about this.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
They said, "The blogsters let us down."

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
What became very clear was that,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:46.958
within a few days, the outpouring of information was immense,

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:51.958
and we got a complete and powerful picture of what had happened

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
in a way that we never had been able to get before.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
And what you had was a group of essentially unorganized, unconnected

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:02.958
writers, video bloggers, etc., who were able to come up with

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:06.958
a collective portrait of a disaster that gave us a much better sense

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:11.958
of what it was like to actually be there than the mainstream media could give us.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:15.958
And so in some ways the tsunami can be seen as a sort of seminal moment,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:19.958
a moment in which the blogosphere came, to a certain degree, of age.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
Now, I'm going to move now from this kind of --

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
the sublime in the traditional sense of the word,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:30.958
that is to say, awe-inspiring, terrifying -- to the somewhat more mundane.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
Because when we think about blogs,

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
I think for most of us who are concerned about them,

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:40.958
we're primarily concerned with things like politics, technology, etc.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
And I want to ask three questions in this talk,

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
in the 10 minutes that remain, about the blogosphere.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
The first one is, What does it tell us about our ideas,

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
about what motivates people to do things?

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:55.958
The second is, Do blogs genuinely have the possibility

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:59.958
of accessing a kind of collective intelligence

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
that has previously remained, for the most part, untapped?

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:06.958
And then the third part is, What are the potential problems,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:10.958
or the dark side of blogs as we know them?

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
OK, the first question:

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
What do they tell us about why people do things?

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
One of the fascinating things about the blogosphere specifically,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
and, of course, the Internet more generally --

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
and it's going to seem like a very obvious point,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
but I think it is an important one to think about --

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.958
is that the people who are generating these enormous reams of content

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:33.958
every day, who are spending enormous amounts of time organizing,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
linking, commenting on the substance of the Internet,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
are doing so primarily for free.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:43.958
They are not getting paid for it in any way other than in the attention and,

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:48.958
to some extent, the reputational capital that they gain from doing a good job.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:53.958
And this is -- at least, to a traditional economist -- somewhat remarkable,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:57.958
because the traditional account of economic man would say that,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:02.958
basically, you do things for a concrete reward, primarily financial.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
But instead, what we're finding on the Internet --

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:09.958
and one of the great geniuses of it -- is that people have found a way

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
to work together without any money involved at all.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:17.958
They have come up with, in a sense, a different method for organizing activity.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:22.958
The Yale Law professor Yochai Benkler, in an essay called "Coase's Penguin,"

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:26.958
talks about this open-source model, which we're familiar with from Linux,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
as being potentially applicable in a whole host of situations.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
And, you know, if you think about this with the tsunami,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:35.958
what you have is essentially a kind of an army of local journalists,

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
who are producing enormous amounts of material

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
for no reason other than to tell their stories.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
That's a very powerful idea, and it's a very powerful reality.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
And it's one that offers really interesting possibilities

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:52.958
for organizing a whole host of activities down the road.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
So, I think the first thing that the blogosphere tells us

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
is that we need to expand our idea of what counts as rational,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:02.958
and we need to expand our simple equation of value equals money,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
or, you have to pay for it to be good,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
but that in fact you can end up with collectively really brilliant products

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
without any money at all changing hands.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
There are a few bloggers -- somewhere maybe around 20, now --

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
who do, in fact, make some kind of money, and a few

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
who are actually trying to make a full-time living out of it,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
but the vast majority of them are doing it because they love it

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
or they love the attention, or whatever it is.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
So, Howard Rheingold has written a lot about this

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
and, I think, is writing about this more,

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
but this notion of voluntary cooperation

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
is an incredibly powerful one, and one worth thinking about.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:38.958
The second question is, What does the blogosphere actually do for us,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
in terms of accessing collective intelligence?

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
You know, as Chris mentioned, I wrote a book called "The Wisdom of Crowds."

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
And the premise of "The Wisdom of Crowds" is that,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
under the right conditions, groups can be remarkably intelligent.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
And they can actually often be smarter

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
than even the smartest person within them.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
The simplest example of this is if you ask a group of people

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:02.958
to do something like guess how many jellybeans are in a jar.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
If I had a jar of jellybeans

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
and I asked you all to guess how many jellybeans were in that jar,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
your average guess would be remarkably good.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
It would be somewhere probably within three and five percent

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
of the number of beans in the jar,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:19.958
and it would be better than 90 to 95 percent of you.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
There may be one or two of you who are brilliant jelly bean guessers,

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
but for the most part the group's guess

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
would be better than just about all of you.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
And what's fascinating is that you can see this phenomenon at work

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
in many more complicated situations.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
For instance, if you look at the odds on horses at a racetrack,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:41.958
they predict almost perfectly how likely a horse is to win.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
In a sense, the group of betters at the racetrack

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:48.958
is forecasting the future, in probabilistic terms.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
You know, if you think about something like Google,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:54.958
which essentially is relying on the collective intelligence of the Web

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:58.958
to seek out those sites that have the most valuable information --

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
we know that Google does an exceptionally good job of doing that,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
and it does that because, collectively, this disorganized thing

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:08.958
we call the "World Wide Web" actually has a remarkable order,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
or a remarkable intelligence in it.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
And this, I think, is one of the real promises of the blogosphere.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
Dan Gillmor -- whose book "We the Media"

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
is included in the gift pack --

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
has talked about it as saying that, as a writer,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:25.958
he's recognized that his readers know more than he does.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
And this is a very challenging idea. It's a very challenging idea

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
to mainstream media. It's a very challenging idea to anyone

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:34.958
who has invested an enormous amount of time and expertise,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
and who has a lot of energy invested in the notion

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:41.958
that he or she knows better than everyone else.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
But what the blogosphere offers is the possibility

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:50.958
of getting at the kind of collective, distributive intelligence that is out there,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
and that we know is available to us

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:56.958
if we can just figure out a way of accessing it.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
Each blog post, each blog commentary

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:03.958
may not, in and of itself, be exactly what we're looking for,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:08.958
but collectively the judgment of those people posting, those people linking,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:12.958
more often than not is going to give you a very interesting

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
and enormously valuable picture of what's going on.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
So, that's the positive side of it.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
That's the positive side of what is sometimes called

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:24.958
participatory journalism or citizen journalism, etc. --

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
that, in fact, we are giving people

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
who have never been able to talk before a voice,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
and we're able to access information that has always been there

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
but has essentially gone untapped.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
But there is a dark side to this,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
and that's what I want to spend the last part of my talk on.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
One of the things that happens if you spend a lot of time on the Internet,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
and you spend a lot of time thinking about the Internet,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
is that it is very easy to fall in love with the Internet.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
It is very easy to fall in love with the decentralized,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
bottom-up structure of the Internet.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:13:00.958
It is very easy to think that networks are necessarily good things --

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
that being linked from one place to another,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:06.958
that being tightly linked in a group, is a very good thing.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
And much of the time it is.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:12.958
But there's also a downside to this -- a kind of dark side, in fact --

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:16.958
and that is that the more tightly linked we've become to each other,

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:20.958
the harder it is for each of us to remain independent.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
One of the fundamental characteristics of a network is that,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
once you are linked in the network,

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
the network starts to shape your views

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
and starts to shape your interactions with everybody else.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
That's one of the things that defines what a network is.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:37.958
A network is not just the product of its component parts.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
It is something more than that.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:44.958
It is, as Steven Johnson has talked about, an emergent phenomenon.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
Now, this has all these benefits:

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
it's very beneficial in terms of the efficiency of communicating information;

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
it gives you access to a whole host of people;

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
it allows people to coordinate their activities in very good ways.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:59.958
But the problem is that groups are only smart

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:03.958
when the people in them are as independent as possible.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
This is the paradox of the wisdom of crowds,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
or the paradox of collective intelligence,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:13.958
that what it requires is actually a form of independent thinking.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.958
And networks make it harder for people to do that,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:21.958
because they drive attention to the things that the network values.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:25.958
So, one of the phenomena that's very clear in the blogosphere

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:29.958
is that once a meme, once an idea gets going,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
it is very easy for people to just sort of pile on,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
because other people have, say, a link.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
People have linked to it, and so other people in turn link to it, etc., etc.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
And that phenomenon

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
of piling on the existing links

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
is one that is characteristic of the blogosphere,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
particularly of the political blogosphere,

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
and it is one that essentially throws off

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
this beautiful, decentralized, bottom-up intelligence

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
that blogs can manifest in the right conditions.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:03.958
The metaphor that I like to use is the metaphor of the circular mill.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
A lot of people talk about ants.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
You know, this is a conference inspired by nature.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
When we talk about bottom-up, decentralized phenomena,

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:14.958
the ant colony is the classic metaphor, because,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
no individual ant knows what it's doing,

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:22.632
but collectively ants are able to reach incredibly intelligent decisions.

00:15:22.751 --> 00:15:25.807
They're able to reach food
as efficiently as possible,

00:15:25.832 --> 00:15:29.858
they're able to guide their traffic
with remarkable speed.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
So, the ant colony is a great model:

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
you have all these little parts that collectively add up to a great thing.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:38.958
But we know that occasionally ants go astray,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:42.958
and what happens is that, if army ants are wandering around and they get lost,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
they start to follow a simple rule --

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:48.958
just do what the ant in front of you does.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:52.958
And what happens is that the ants eventually end up in a circle.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:56.958
And there's this famous example of one that was 1,200 feet long

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:00.958
and lasted for two days, and the ants just kept marching around and around

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
in a circle until they died.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
And that, I think, is a sort of thing to watch out for.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
That's the thing we have to fear --

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.958
is that we're just going to keep marching around and around until we die.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
Now, I want to connect this back, though, to the tsunami,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
because one of the great things about the tsunami --

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
in terms of the blogosphere's coverage,

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
not in terms of the tsunami itself --

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:25.958
is that it really did represent a genuine bottom-up phenomenon.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
You saw sites that had never existed before getting huge amounts of traffic.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:32.958
You saw people being able to offer up
their independent points of view

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
in a way that they hadn't before.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:39.958
There, you really did see the intelligence of the Web manifest itself.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
So, that's the upside. The circular mill is the downside.

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
And I think that the former is what we really need to strive for.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.140
Thank you very much. (Applause)

title: Walk the earth ... my 17-year vow of silence
transcript: (Music)(Applause)Thank you for being here. And I say "thank you for being here" because I was silent for 17 years. And the first words that I spoke were in Washington, D.C., on the 20th anniversary of Earth Day. And my family and friends had gathered there to hear me speak. And I said, "Thank you for being here." My mother, out in the audience, she jumped up, "Hallelujah, Johnny’s talking!"(Laughter)Imagine if you were quiet for 17 years and your mother was out in the audience, say. My dad said to me, "That’s one" — I’ll explain that. But I turned around because I didn’t recognize where my voice was coming from. I hadn’t heard my voice in 17 years, so I turned around and I looked and I said, "God, who's saying what I’m thinking?" And then I realized it was me, you know, and I kind of laughed. And I could see my father: "Yeah, he really is crazy." Well, I want to take you on this journey. And the journey, I believe, is a metaphor for all of our journeys. Even though this one is kind of unusual, I want you to think about your own journey.My journey began in 1971 when I witnessed two oil tankers collide beneath the Golden Gate, and a half a million gallons of oil spilled into the bay. It disturbed me so much that I decided that I was going to give up riding and driving in motorized vehicles. That’s a big thing in California. And it was a big thing in my little community of Point Reyes Station in Inverness, California, because there were only about 350 people there in the winter – this was back in '71 now. And so when I came in and I started walking around, people — they just knew what was going on. And people would drive up next to me and say, "John, what are you doing?" And I’d say, "Well, I’m walking for the environment." And they said, "No, you’re walking to make us look bad, right? You’re walking to make us feel bad." And maybe there was some truth to that, because I thought that if I started walking, everyone would follow. Because of the oil, everybody talked about the polllution. And so I argued with people about that, I argued and I argued. I called my parents up. I said, "I’ve given up riding and driving in cars." My dad said, "Why didn’t you do that when you were 16?"(Laughter)I didn’t know about the environment then. They’re back in Philadelphia. And so I told my mother, "I’m happy though, I’m really happy." She said, "If you were happy, son, you wouldn’t have to say it." Mothers are like that.And so, on my 27th birthday I decided, because I argued so much and I talk so much, that I was going to stop speaking for just one day — one day — to give it a rest. And so I did. I got up in the morning and I didn’t say a word. And I have to tell you, it was a very moving experience, because for the first time, I began listening — in a long time. And what I heard, it kind of disturbed me. Because what I used to do, when I thought I was listening, was I would listen just enough to hear what people had to say and think that I could — I knew what they were going to say, and so I stopped listening. And in my mind, I just kind of raced ahead and thought of what I was going to say back, while they were still finishing up. And then I would launch in. Well, that just ended communication.So on this first day I actually listened. And it was very sad for me, because I realized that for those many years I had not been learning. I was 27. I thought I knew everything. I didn’t. And so I decided I’d better do this for another day, and another day, and another day until finally, I promised myself for a year I would keep quiet because I started learning more and more and I needed to learn more. So for a year I said I would keep quiet, and then on my birthday I would reassess what I had learned and maybe I would talk again. Well, that lasted 17 years.Now during that time — those 17 years — I walked and I played the banjo and I painted and I wrote in my journal, and I tried to study the environment by reading books. And I decided that I was going to go to school. So I did. I walked up to Ashland, Oregon, where they were offering an environmental studies degree. It’s only 500 miles. And I went into the Registrar’s office and — "What, what, what?" I had a newspaper clipping. "Oh, so you really want to go to school here? You don’t …? We have a special program for you." They did. And in those two years, I graduated with my first degree — a bachelor’s degree. And my father came out, he was so proud. He said, "Listen, we’re really proud of you son, but what are you going to do with a bachelor’s degree? You don’t ride in cars, you don’t talk — you’re going to have to do those things."(Laughter)I hunched my shoulder, I picked my backpack up again and I started walking. I walked all the way up to Port Townsend, Washington, where I built a wooden boat, rode it across Puget Sound and walked across Washington [to] Idaho and down to Missoula, Montana. I had written the University of Montana two years earlier and said I'd like to go to school there. I said I'd be there in about two years.(Laughter)And I was there. I showed up in two years and they — I tell this story because they really helped me. There are two stories in Montana. The first story is I didn’t have any money — that’s a sign I used a lot. And they said,"Don't worry about that." The director of the program said, "Come back tomorrow." He gave me 150 dollars, and he said, "Register for one credit. You’re going to go to South America, aren’t you?" And I said — Rivers and lakes, the hydrological systems, South America. So I did that. He came back; he said to me, "OK John, now that you've registered for that one credit, you can have a key to an office, you can matriculate — you’re matriculating, so you can use the library. And what we’re going to do is, we’re going to have all of the professors allow you to go to class. They’re going to save your grade, and when we figure out how to get you the rest of the money, then you can register for that class and they’ll give you the grade." Wow, they don’t do that in graduate schools, I don’t think. But I use that story because they really wanted to help me. They saw that I was really interested in the environment, and they really wanted to help me along the way.And during that time, I actually taught classes without speaking. I had 13 students when I first walked into the class. I explained, with a friend who could interpret my sign language, that I was John Francis, I was walking around the world, I didn’t talk and this was the last time this person’s going to be here interpreting for me. All the students sat around and they went ...(Laughter)I could see they were looking for the schedule, to see when they could get out. They had to take that class with me. Two weeks later, everyone was trying to get into our class.And I learned in that class — because I would do things like this ... and they were all gathered around, going, "What's he trying to say?" "I don't know, I think he's talking about clear cutting." "Yeah, clear cutting." "No, no, no, that's not clear cutting, that’s — he's using a handsaw." "Well, you can’t clearcut with a ..." "Yes, you can clear cut ..." "No, I think he’s talking about selective forestry." Now this was a discussion class and we were having a discussion. I just backed out of that, you know, and I just kind of kept the fists from flying. But what I learned was that sometimes I would make a sign and they said things that I absolutely did not mean, but I should have. And so what came to me is, if you were a teacher and you were teaching, if you weren’t learning you probably weren’t teaching very well. And so I went on.My dad came out to see me graduate and, you know, I did the deal, and my father said, "We’re really proud of you son, but ... " You know what went on, he said, "You’ve got to start riding and driving and start talking. What are you going to do with a master’s degree?" I hunched my shoulder, I got my backpack and I went on to the University of Wisconsin.I spent two years there writing on oil spills. No one was interested in oil spills. But something happened — Exxon Valdez. And I was the only one in the United States writing on oil spills. My dad came out again. He said, "I don't know how you do this, son — I mean, you don't ride in cars, you don’t talk. My sister said maybe I should leave you alone, because you seem to be doing a lot better when you’re not saying anything."(Laughter)Well, I put on my backpack again. I put my banjo on and I walked all the way to the East Coast, put my foot in the Atlantic Ocean — it was seven years and one day it took me to walk across the United States.And on Earth Day, 1990 — the 20th anniversary of Earth Day — that’s when I began to speak. And that’s why I said, "Thank you for being here." Because it's sort of like that tree in the forest falling; and if there's no one there to hear, does it really make a sound? And I’m thanking you, and I'm thanking my family because they had come to hear me speak. And that’s communication. And they also taught me about listening — that they listened to me. And it’s one of those things that came out of the silence, the listening to each other. Really, very important — we need to listen to each other. Well, my journey kept going on. My dad said, "That’s one," and I still didn’t let that go.I worked for the Coastguard, was made a U.N. Goodwill Ambassador. I wrote regulations for the United States — I mean, I wrote oil spill regulations. 20 years ago, if someone had said to me, "John, do you really want to make a difference?" "Yeah, I want to make a difference." He said, "You just start walking east; get out of your car and just start walking east." And as I walked off a little bit, they'd say, "Yeah, and shut up, too."(Laughter)"You’re going to make a difference, buddy." How could that be, how could that be? How could doing such a simple thing like walking and not talking make a difference?Well, my time at the Coast Guard was a really good time. And after that — I only worked one year — I said, "That's enough. One year's enough for me to do that." I got on a sailboat and I sailed down to the Caribbean, and walked through all of the islands, and to Venezuela. And you know, I forgot the most important thing, which is why I started talking, which I have to tell you. I started talking because I had studied environment. I’d studied environment at this formal level, but there was this informal level. And the informal level — I learned about people, and what we do and how we are. And environment changed from just being about trees and birds and endangered species to being about how we treated each other. Because if we are the environment, then all we need to do is look around us and see how we treat ourselves and how we treat each other. And so that’s the message that I had. And I said, "Well, I'm going to have to spread that message." And I got in my sailboat, sailed all the way through the Caribbean — it wasn't really my sailboat, I kind of worked on that boat — got to Venezuela and I started walking.This is the last part of this story, because it’s how I got here, because I still didn't ride in motorized vehicles. I was walking through El Dorado — it's a prison town, famous prison, or infamous prison — in Venezuela, and I don’t know what possessed me, because this was not like me. There I am, walking past the guard gate and the guard stops and says, "Pasaporte, pasaporte," and with an M16 pointed at me. And I looked at him and I said, "Passport, huh? I don't need to show you my passport. It’s in the back of my pack. I'm Dr. Francis; I'm a U.N. Ambassador and I'm walking around the world." And I started walking off. What possessed me to say this thing? The road turned into the jungle. I didn’t get shot. And I got to — I start saying, "Free at last — thank God Almighty, I’m free at last." "What was that about," I’m saying. What was that about?It took me 100 miles to figure out that, in my heart, in me, I had become a prisoner. I was a prisoner and I needed to escape. The prison that I was in was the fact that I did not drive or use motorized vehicles. Now how could that be? Because when I started, it seemed very appropriate to me not to use motorized vehicles. But the thing that was different was that every birthday, I asked myself about silence, but I never asked myself about my decision to just use my feet. I had no idea I was going to become a U.N. Ambassador. I had no idea I would have a Ph.D.And so I realized that I had a responsibility to more than just me, and that I was going to have to change. You know, we can do it. I was going to have to change. And I was afraid to change, because I was so used to the guy who only just walked. I was so used to that person that I didn’t want to stop. I didn’t know who I would be if I changed. But I know I needed to. I know I needed to change, because it would be the only way that I could be here today. And I know that a lot of times we find ourselves in this wonderful place where we’ve gotten to, but there’s another place for us to go. And we kind of have to leave behind the security of who we’ve become, and go to the place of who we are becoming. And so, I want to encourage you to go to that next place, to let yourself out of any prison that you might find yourself in, as comfortable as it may be, because we have to do something now. We have to change now. As our former Vice President said, we have to become activists. So if my voice can touch you, if my actions can touch you, if my being here can touch you, please let it be. And I know that all of you have touched me while I’ve been here.So, let’s go out into the world and take this caring, this love, this respect that we’ve shown each other right here at TED, and take this out into the world. Because we are the environment, and how we treat each other is really how we’re going to treat the environment. So I want to thank you for being here and I want to end this in five seconds of silence.Thank you.(Applause)
