00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
This is a guy named Bob McKim.

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:19.958
He was a creativity researcher in the '60s and '70s,

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
and also led the Stanford Design Program.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:25.958
And in fact, my friend and IDEO founder, David Kelley,

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:31.958
who’s out there somewhere, studied under him at Stanford.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:37.958
And he liked to do an exercise with his students

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:42.958
where he got them to take a piece of paper

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:46.958
and draw the person who sat next to them, their neighbor,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
very quickly, just as quickly as they could.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
And in fact, we’re going to do that exercise right now.

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:54.958
You all have a piece of cardboard and a piece of paper.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:55.958
It’s actually got a bunch of circles on it.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:56.958
I need you to turn that piece of paper over;

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.958
you should find that it’s blank on the other side.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
And there should be a pencil.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:06.958
And I want you to pick somebody that’s seated next to you,

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:14.958
and when I say, go, you’ve got 30 seconds to draw your neighbor, OK?

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:19.958
So, everybody ready? OK. Off you go.

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:22.958
You’ve got 30 seconds, you’d better be fast.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:27.958
Come on: those masterpieces ...

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:38.958
OK? Stop. All right, now.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
(Laughter)

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
Yes, lot’s of laughter. Yeah, exactly.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:46.958
Lots of laughter, quite a bit of embarrassment.

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:47.958
(Laughter)

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:52.958
Am I hearing a few "sorry’s"? I think I’m hearing a few sorry’s.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
Yup, yup, I think I probably am.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:58.958
And that’s exactly what happens every time,

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
every time you do this with adults.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
McKim found this every time he did it with his students.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:07.958
He got exactly the same response: lots and lots of sorry’s.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:08.958
(Laughter)

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:12.958
And he would point this out as evidence

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
that we fear the judgment of our peers,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:19.958
and that we’re embarrassed about showing our ideas

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:23.958
to people we think of as our peers, to those around us.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:27.958
And this fear is what causes us

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
to be conservative in our thinking.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
So we might have a wild idea,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:35.958
but we’re afraid to share it with anybody else.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.958
OK, so if you try the same exercise with kids,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:41.958
they have no embarrassment at all.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
They just quite happily show their masterpiece

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:48.958
to whoever wants to look at it.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:51.958
But as they learn to become adults,

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.958
they become much more sensitive to the opinions of others,

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:59.958
and they lose that freedom and they do start to become embarrassed.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
And in studies of kids playing, it’s been shown

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:06.958
time after time that kids who feel secure,

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.958
who are in a kind of trusted environment --

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:15.958
they’re the ones that feel most free to play.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
And if you’re starting a design firm, let’s say,

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:22.958
then you probably also want to create

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
a place where people have the same kind of security.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
Where they have the same kind of security to take risks.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:32.958
Maybe have the same kind of security to play.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:37.958
Before founding IDEO, David said that what he wanted to do

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:43.958
was to form a company where all the employees are my best friends.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
Now, that wasn’t just self-indulgence.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:52.958
He knew that friendship is a short cut to play.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:57.958
And he knew that it gives us a sense of trust,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
and it allows us then to take the kind of creative risks

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
that we need to take as designers.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.958
And so, that decision to work with his friends --

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:14.958
now he has 550 of them -- was what got IDEO started.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:18.958
And our studios, like, I think, many creative workplaces today,

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
are designed to help people feel relaxed:

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
familiar with their surroundings,

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:28.958
comfortable with the people that they’re working with.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
It takes more than decor, but I think we’ve all seen that

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:36.958
creative companies do often have symbols in the workplace

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
that remind people to be playful,

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
and that it’s a permissive environment.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
So, whether it’s this microbus meeting room

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
that we have in one our buildings at IDEO;

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:52.958
or at Pixar, where the animators work in wooden huts and decorated caves;

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
or at the Googleplex, where

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:55.958
it’s famous for its [beach] volleyball courts,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:59.958
and even this massive dinosaur skeleton with pink flamingos on it.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
Don’t know the reason for the pink flamingos,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
but anyway, they’re there in the garden.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
Or even in the Swiss office of Google,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
which perhaps has the most wacky ideas of all.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
And my theory is, that’s so the Swiss can prove

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
to their Californian colleagues that they’re not boring.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
So they have the slide, and they even have a fireman’s pole.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:16.958
Don’t know what they do with that, but they have one.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
So all of these places have these symbols.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
Now, our big symbol at IDEO is actually

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
not so much the place, it’s a thing.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
And it’s actually something that we invented a few years ago,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:28.958
or created a few years ago.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
It’s a toy; it’s called a "finger blaster."

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
And I forgot to bring one up with me.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
So if somebody can reach under the chair that’s next to them,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
you’ll find something taped underneath it.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
That’s great. If you could pass it up. Thanks, David, I appreciate it.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:45.958
So this is a finger blaster, and you will find that every one of you

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
has got one taped under your chair.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:52.958
And I’m going to run a little experiment. Another little experiment.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
But before we start, I need just to put these on.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
Thank you. All right.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
Now, what I’m going to do is, I’m going to see how --

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:01.958
I can’t see out of these, OK.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
I’m going to see how many of you at the back of the room

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
can actually get those things onto the stage.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
So the way they work is, you know,

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
you just put your finger in the thing,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
pull them back, and off you go.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:18.958
So, don’t look backwards. That’s my only recommendation here.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
I want to see how many of you can get these things on the stage.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
So come on! There we go, there we go. Thank you. Thank you. Oh.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
I have another idea. I wanted to -- there we go.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:30.958
(Laughter)

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:31.958
There we go.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:35.958
(Laughter)

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:36.958
Thank you, thank you, thank you.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:40.958
Not bad, not bad. No serious injuries so far.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:44.958
(Laughter)

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:49.958
Well, they’re still coming in from the back there;

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:50.958
they’re still coming in.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:51.958
Some of you haven’t fired them yet.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
Can you not figure out how to do it, or something?

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
It’s not that hard. Most of your kids figure out how to do this

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
in the first 10 seconds, when they pick it up.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
All right. This is pretty good; this is pretty good.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:07.958
Okay, all right. Let’s -- I suppose we'd better...

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:08.958
I'd better clear these up out of the way;

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
otherwise, I’m going to trip over them.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
All right. So the rest of you can save them

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
for when I say something particularly boring,

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:16.958
and then you can fire at me.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
(Laughter)

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:19.958
All right. I think I’m going to take these off now,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:23.958
because I can’t see a damn thing when I’ve -- all right, OK.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:27.958
So, ah, that was fun.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
(Laughter)

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
All right, good.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
(Applause)

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
So, OK, so why?

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
So we have the finger blasters. Other people have dinosaurs, you know.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
Why do we have them? Well, as I said,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
we have them because we think maybe playfulness is important.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
But why is it important?

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
We use it in a pretty pragmatic way, to be honest.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:54.958
We think playfulness helps us get to better creative solutions.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:55.958
Helps us do our jobs better,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
and helps us feel better when we do them.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:02.958
Now, an adult encountering a new situation --

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
when we encounter a new situation we have a tendency

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
to want to categorize it just as quickly as we can, you know.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:14.958
And there’s a reason for that: we want to settle on an answer.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
Life’s complicated; we want to figure out

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:18.958
what’s going on around us very quickly.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
I suspect, actually, that the evolutionary biologists

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
probably have lots of reasons [for] why we want

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
to categorize new things very, very quickly.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
One of them might be, you know,

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:28.958
when we see this funny stripy thing:

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
is that a tiger just about to jump out and kill us?

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:32.958
Or is it just some weird shadows on the tree?

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
We need to figure that out pretty fast.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:35.958
Well, at least, we did once.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
Most of us don’t need to anymore, I suppose.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
This is some aluminum foil, right? You use it in the kitchen.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
That’s what it is, isn’t it? Of course it is, of course it is.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
Well, not necessarily.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
(Laughter)

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
Kids are more engaged with open possibilities.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
Now, they’ll certainly -- when they come across something new,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
they’ll certainly ask, "What is it?"

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
Of course they will. But they’ll also ask, "What can I do with it?"

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
And you know, the more creative of them

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
might get to a really interesting example.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:06.958
And this openness is the beginning of exploratory play.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
Any parents of young kids in the audience? There must be some.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
Yeah, thought so. So we’ve all seen it, haven’t we?

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
We’ve all told stories about how, on Christmas morning,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
our kids end up playing with the boxes

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
far more than they play with the toys that are inside them.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:24.958
And you know, from an exploration perspective,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
this behavior makes complete sense.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
Because you can do a lot more with boxes than you can do with a toy.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
Even one like, say, Tickle Me Elmo --

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
which, despite its ingenuity, really only does one thing,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:42.958
whereas boxes offer an infinite number of choices.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
So again, this is another one of those playful activities

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:48.958
that, as we get older, we tend to forget and we have to relearn.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
So another one of Bob McKim’s favorite exercises

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:53.958
is called the "30 Circles Test."

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
So we’re back to work. You guys are going to get back to work again.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
Turn that piece of paper that you did the sketch on

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:02.958
back over, and you’ll find those 30 circles printed on the piece of paper.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
So it should look like this. You should be looking at something like this.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
So what I’m going to do is, I’m going to give you minute,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
and I want you to adapt as many of those circles as you can

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
into objects of some form.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
So for example, you could turn one into a football,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
or another one into a sun. All I’m interested in is quantity.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
I want you to do as many of them as you can,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
in the minute that I’m just about to give you.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
So, everybody ready? OK? Off you go.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:45.958
Okay. Put down your pencils, as they say.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
So, who got more than five circles figured out?

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
Hopefully everybody? More than 10?

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
Keep your hands up if you did 10.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
15? 20? Anybody get all 30?

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
No? Oh! Somebody did. Fantastic.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:03.958
Did anybody to a variation on a theme? Like a smiley face?

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:08.958
Happy face? Sad face? Sleepy face? Anybody do that?

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
Anybody use my examples? The sun and the football?

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:16.958
Great. Cool. So I was really interested in quantity.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
I wasn’t actually very interested in whether they were all different.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
I just wanted you to fill in as many circles as possible.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:27.958
And one of the things we tend to do as adults, again, is we edit things.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:28.958
We stop ourselves from doing things.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
We self-edit as we’re having ideas.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:36.958
And in some cases, our desire to be original is actually a form of editing.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:40.958
And that actually isn’t necessarily really playful.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:45.958
So that ability just to go for it and explore lots of things,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
even if they don’t seem that different from each other,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:53.958
is actually something that kids do well, and it is a form of play.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
So now, Bob McKim did another

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:56.958
version of this test

00:11:56.958 --> 00:12:00.958
in a rather famous experiment that was done in the 1960s.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:05.958
Anybody know what this is? It’s the peyote cactus.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
It’s the plant from which you can create mescaline,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
one of the psychedelic drugs.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:10.958
For those of you around in the '60s, you probably know it well.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:16.958
McKim published a paper in 1966, describing an experiment

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:17.958
that he and his colleagues conducted

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:21.958
to test the effects of psychedelic drugs on creativity.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:28.958
So he picked 27 professionals -- they were

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
engineers, physicists, mathematicians, architects,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
furniture designers even, artists --

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
and he asked them to come along one evening,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:43.958
and to bring a problem with them that they were working on.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
He gave each of them some mescaline,

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:49.958
and had them listen to some nice, relaxing music for a while.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:55.958
And then he did what’s called the Purdue Creativity Test.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
You might know it as, "How many uses can you find for a paper clip?"

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:02.958
It’s basically the same thing as the 30 circles thing that I just had you do.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
Now, actually, he gave the test before the drugs

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:08.958
and after the drugs, to see

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
what the difference was in people’s

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
facility and speed with coming up with ideas.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:14.958
And then he asked them to go away

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:18.958
and work on those problems that they’d brought.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
And they’d come up with a bunch of

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
interesting solutions -- and actually, quite

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
valid solutions -- to the things that they’d been working on.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:26.958
And so, some of the things that they figured out,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
some of these individuals figured out;

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
in one case, a new commercial building and designs for houses

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:32.958
that were accepted by clients;

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
a design of a solar space probe experiment;

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:41.958
a redesign of the linear electron accelerator;

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
an engineering improvement to a magnetic tape recorder --

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:44.958
you can tell this is a while ago;

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:48.958
the completion of a line of furniture;

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
and even a new conceptual model of the photon.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
So it was a pretty successful evening.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:57.958
In fact, maybe this experiment was the reason that Silicon Valley

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
got off to its great start with innovation.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:01.958
We don’t know, but it may be.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:02.958
We need to ask some of the CEOs

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
whether they were involved in this mescaline experiment.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:08.958
But really, it wasn’t the drugs that were important;

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:09.958
it was this idea that what the drugs did

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
would help shock people out of their normal way of thinking,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:16.958
and getting them to forget the adult behaviors

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
that were getting in the way of their ideas.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:23.958
But it’s hard to break our habits, our adult habits.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:27.958
At IDEO we have brainstorming rules written on the walls.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:31.958
Edicts like, "Defer judgment," or "Go for quantity."

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:32.958
And somehow that seems wrong.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
I mean, can you have rules about creativity?

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
Well, it sort of turns out that we need rules

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
to help us break the old rules and norms

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:43.958
that otherwise we might bring to the creative process.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:44.958
And we’ve certainly learnt that over time,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
you get much better brainstorming,

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:52.958
much more creative outcomes when everybody does play by the rules.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
Now, of course, many designers, many individual designers,

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
achieve this is in a much more organic way.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:02.958
I think the Eameses are wonderful examples of experimentation.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
And they experimented with plywood for many years

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
without necessarily having one single goal in mind.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:12.958
They were exploring following what was interesting to them.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
They went from designing splints for wounded soldiers

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
coming out of World War II and the Korean War, I think,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
and from this experiment they moved on to chairs.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
Through constant experimentation with materials,

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
they developed a wide range of iconic solutions

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
that we know today, eventually resulting in,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
of course, the legendary lounge chair.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
Now, if the Eameses had stopped with that first great solution,

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
then we wouldn’t be the beneficiaries of so many

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
wonderful designs today.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:41.958
And of course, they used experimentation in all aspects of their work,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:47.958
from films to buildings, from games to graphics.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:51.958
So, they’re great examples, I think, of exploration

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
and experimentation in design.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
Now, while the Eameses were exploring those possibilities,

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
they were also exploring physical objects.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
And they were doing that through building prototypes.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:07.958
And building is the next of the behaviors that I thought I’d talk about.

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
So the average Western first-grader

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
spends as much as 50 percent of their play time

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
taking part in what’s called "construction play."

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
Construction play -- it’s playful, obviously,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
but also a powerful way to learn.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:25.958
When play is about building a tower out of blocks,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
the kid begins to learn a lot about towers.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
And as they repeatedly knock it down and start again,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:33.958
learning is happening as a sort of by-product of play.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:37.958
It’s classically learning by doing.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:38.958
Now, David Kelley calls this behavior,

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:42.958
when it’s carried out by designers, "thinking with your hands."

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
And it typically involves making multiple,

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:48.958
low-resolution prototypes very quickly,

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
often by bringing lots of found elements together

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:53.958
in order to get to a solution.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:57.958
On one of his earliest projects, the team was kind of stuck,

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:01.958
and they came up with a mechanism by hacking together

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
a prototype made from a roll-on deodorant.

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
Now, that became the first commercial computer mouse

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
for the Apple Lisa and the Macintosh.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:14.958
So, they learned their way to that by building prototypes.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
Another example is a group of designers

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
who were working on a surgical instrument with some surgeons.

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
They were meeting with them; they were talking to the surgeons

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
about what it was they needed with this device.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
And one of the designers ran out of the room

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
and grabbed a white board marker and a film canister --

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:32.958
which is now becoming a very precious prototyping medium --

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:34.958
and a clothespin. He taped them all together,

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:36.958
ran back into the room and said, "You mean, something like this?"

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:38.958
And the surgeons grabbed hold of it and said,

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:40.958
well, I want to hold it like this, or like that.

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:42.958
And all of a sudden a productive conversation

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:47.958
was happening about design around a tangible object.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:51.958
And in the end it turned into a real device.

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.958
And so this behavior is all about quickly getting something

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:59.958
into the real world, and having your thinking advanced as a result.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
At IDEO there’s a kind of a back-to-preschool feel

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:04.958
sometimes about the environment.

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:07.958
The prototyping carts, filled with colored paper

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:10.958
and Play-Doh and glue sticks and stuff --

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:13.958
I mean, they do have a bit of a kindergarten feel to them.

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:17.958
But the important idea is that everything’s at hand, everything’s around.

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
So when designers are working on ideas,

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:22.958
they can start building stuff whenever they want.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:23.958
They don’t necessarily even have to go

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:25.958
into some kind of formal workshop to do it.

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:27.958
And we think that’s pretty important.

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:29.958
And then the sad thing is, although preschools

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:33.958
are full of this kind of stuff, as kids go through the school system

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:35.958
it all gets taken away.

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:37.958
They lose this stuff that facilitates

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:42.958
this sort of playful and building mode of thinking.

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:44.958
And of course, by the time you get to the average workplace,

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:47.958
maybe the best construction tool we have

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
might be the Post-it notes. It’s pretty barren.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:54.958
But by giving project teams and the clients

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:56.958
who they’re working with permission to think with their hands,

00:18:56.958 --> 00:19:01.958
quite complex ideas can spring into life

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:05.958
and go right through to execution much more easily.

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:09.958
This is a nurse using a very simple -- as you can see -- plasticine prototype,

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:12.958
explaining what she wants out of a portable information system

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:15.958
to a team of technologists and designers

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:18.958
that are working with her in a hospital.

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:19.958
And just having this very simple prototype

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:24.958
allows her to talk about what she wants in a much more powerful way.

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:26.958
And of course, by building quick prototypes,

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:29.958
we can get out and test our ideas with consumers

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:31.958
and users much more quickly

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:37.958
than if we’re trying to describe them through words.

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:40.958
But what about designing something that isn’t physical?

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:42.958
Something like a service or an experience?

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:45.958
Something that exists as a series of interactions over time?

00:19:45.958 --> 00:19:51.958
Instead of building play, this can be approached with role-play.

00:19:51.958 --> 00:19:53.958
So, if you’re designing an interaction between two people --

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:56.958
such as, I don’t know -- ordering food at a fast food joint

00:19:56.958 --> 00:19:58.958
or something, you need to be able to imagine

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:01.958
how that experience might feel over a period of time.

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:03.958
And I think the best way to achieve that,

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:08.958
and get a feeling for any flaws in your design, is to act it out.

00:20:08.958 --> 00:20:10.958
So we do quite a lot of work at IDEO

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:12.958
trying to convince our clients of this.

00:20:12.958 --> 00:20:14.958
They can be a little skeptical; I’ll come back to that.

00:20:14.958 --> 00:20:18.958
But a place, I think, where the effort is really worthwhile

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:22.958
is where people are wrestling with quite serious problems --

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:27.958
things like education or security or finance or health.

00:20:27.958 --> 00:20:30.958
And this is another example in a healthcare environment

00:20:30.958 --> 00:20:32.958
of some doctors and some nurses and designers

00:20:32.958 --> 00:20:36.958
acting out a service scenario around patient care.

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:37.958
But you know, many adults

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:40.958
are pretty reluctant to engage with role-play.

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:42.958
Some of it’s embarrassment and some of it is because

00:20:42.958 --> 00:20:46.958
they just don’t believe that what emerges is necessarily valid.

00:20:46.958 --> 00:20:48.958
They dismiss an interesting interaction by saying,

00:20:48.958 --> 00:20:51.958
you know, "That’s just happening because they’re acting it out."

00:20:51.958 --> 00:20:53.958
Research into kids' behavior actually suggests

00:20:53.958 --> 00:20:56.958
that it’s worth taking role-playing seriously.

00:20:56.958 --> 00:20:57.958
Because when children play a role,

00:20:57.958 --> 00:21:00.958
they actually follow social scripts quite closely

00:21:00.958 --> 00:21:02.958
that they’ve learnt from us as adults.

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:05.958
If one kid plays "store," and another one’s playing "house,"

00:21:05.958 --> 00:21:07.958
then the whole kind of play falls down.

00:21:08.958 --> 00:21:11.958
So they get used to quite quickly

00:21:11.958 --> 00:21:15.958
to understanding the rules for social interactions,

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:18.958
and are actually quite quick to point out when they’re broken.

00:21:18.958 --> 00:21:21.958
So when, as adults, we role-play,

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:26.958
then we have a huge set of these scripts already internalized.

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:28.958
We’ve gone through lots of experiences in life,

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:31.958
and they provide a strong intuition

00:21:31.958 --> 00:21:34.958
as to whether an interaction is going to work.

00:21:34.958 --> 00:21:36.958
So we’re very good, when acting out a solution,

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:41.958
at spotting whether something lacks authenticity.

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:42.958
So role-play is actually, I think,

00:21:42.958 --> 00:21:46.958
quite valuable when it comes to thinking about experiences.

00:21:46.958 --> 00:21:49.958
Another way for us, as designers, to explore role-play

00:21:49.958 --> 00:21:53.958
is to put ourselves through an experience which we’re designing for,

00:21:53.958 --> 00:21:56.958
and project ourselves into an experience.

00:21:56.958 --> 00:21:58.958
So here are some designers who are trying to understand

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:01.958
what it might feel like to sleep in a

00:22:01.958 --> 00:22:03.958
confined space on an airplane.

00:22:03.958 --> 00:22:05.958
And so they grabbed some very simple materials, you can see,

00:22:05.958 --> 00:22:09.958
and did this role-play, this kind of very crude role-play,

00:22:09.958 --> 00:22:11.958
just to get a sense of what it would be like for passengers

00:22:11.958 --> 00:22:16.958
if they were stuck in quite small places on airplanes.

00:22:16.958 --> 00:22:18.958
This is one of our designers, Kristian Simsarian,

00:22:18.958 --> 00:22:22.958
and he’s putting himself through the experience of being an ER patient.

00:22:22.958 --> 00:22:24.958
Now, this is a real hospital, in a real emergency room.

00:22:24.958 --> 00:22:26.958
One of the reasons he chose to take

00:22:26.958 --> 00:22:27.958
this rather large video camera with him was

00:22:27.958 --> 00:22:29.958
because he didn’t want the doctors and nurses thinking

00:22:29.958 --> 00:22:32.958
he was actually sick, and sticking something into him

00:22:32.958 --> 00:22:34.958
that he was going to regret later.

00:22:34.958 --> 00:22:37.958
So anyhow, he went there with his video camera,

00:22:37.958 --> 00:22:41.958
and it’s kind of interesting to see what he brought back.

00:22:41.958 --> 00:22:43.958
Because when we looked at the video when he got back,

00:22:43.958 --> 00:22:45.958
we saw 20 minutes of this.

00:22:45.958 --> 00:22:48.958
(Laughter)

00:22:48.958 --> 00:22:51.958
And also, the amazing thing about this video --

00:22:51.958 --> 00:22:53.958
as soon as you see it you immediately

00:22:53.958 --> 00:22:56.958
project yourself into that experience.

00:22:56.958 --> 00:22:58.958
And you know what it feels like: all of that uncertainty

00:22:58.958 --> 00:23:00.958
while you’re left out in the hallway

00:23:00.958 --> 00:23:02.958
while the docs are dealing with some more urgent case

00:23:02.958 --> 00:23:06.958
in one of the emergency rooms, wondering what the heck’s going on.

00:23:06.958 --> 00:23:08.958
And so this notion of using role-play --

00:23:08.958 --> 00:23:11.958
or in this case, living through the experience

00:23:11.958 --> 00:23:12.958
as a way of creating empathy --

00:23:12.958 --> 00:23:15.958
particularly when you use video, is really powerful.

00:23:15.958 --> 00:23:17.958
Or another one of our designers, Altay Sendil:

00:23:17.958 --> 00:23:20.958
he’s here having his chest waxed, not because he’s very vain,

00:23:20.958 --> 00:23:22.958
although actually he is -- no, I’m kidding --

00:23:22.958 --> 00:23:26.958
but in order to empathize with the pain that chronic care patients

00:23:26.958 --> 00:23:28.958
go through when they’re having dressings removed.

00:23:28.958 --> 00:23:31.958
And so sometimes these analogous experiences,

00:23:31.958 --> 00:23:34.958
analogous role-play, can also be quite valuable.

00:23:34.958 --> 00:23:37.958
So when a kid dresses up as a firefighter, you know,

00:23:37.958 --> 00:23:39.958
he’s beginning to try on that identity.

00:23:39.958 --> 00:23:42.958
He wants to know what it feels like to be a firefighter.

00:23:42.958 --> 00:23:44.958
We’re doing the same thing as designers.

00:23:44.958 --> 00:23:46.958
We’re trying on these experiences.

00:23:46.958 --> 00:23:50.958
And so the idea of role-play is both as an empathy tool,

00:23:50.958 --> 00:23:54.958
as well as a tool for prototyping experiences.

00:23:54.958 --> 00:23:59.958
And you know, we kind of admire people who do this at IDEO anyway.

00:23:59.958 --> 00:24:02.958
Not just because they lead to insights about the experience,

00:24:02.958 --> 00:24:05.958
but also because of their willingness to explore

00:24:05.958 --> 00:24:08.958
and their ability to unselfconsciously

00:24:08.958 --> 00:24:11.958
surrender themselves to the experience.

00:24:11.958 --> 00:24:16.958
In short, we admire their willingness to play.

00:24:16.958 --> 00:24:22.958
Playful exploration, playful building and role-play:

00:24:22.958 --> 00:24:25.958
those are some of the ways that designers use play in their work.

00:24:25.958 --> 00:24:29.958
And so far, I admit, this might feel

00:24:29.958 --> 00:24:32.958
like it’s a message just to go out and play like a kid.

00:24:32.958 --> 00:24:36.958
And to certain extent it is, but I want to stress a couple of points.

00:24:36.958 --> 00:24:39.958
The first thing to remember is that play is not anarchy.

00:24:39.958 --> 00:24:44.958
Play has rules, especially when it’s group play.

00:24:44.958 --> 00:24:48.958
When kids play tea party, or they play cops and robbers,

00:24:48.958 --> 00:24:51.958
they’re following a script that they’ve agreed to.

00:24:51.958 --> 00:24:55.958
And it’s this code negotiation that leads to productive play.

00:24:56.958 --> 00:24:58.958
So, remember the sketching task we did at the beginning?

00:24:58.958 --> 00:25:00.958
The kind of little face, the portrait you did?

00:25:00.958 --> 00:25:04.958
Well, imagine if you did the same task with friends

00:25:04.958 --> 00:25:06.958
while you were drinking in a pub.

00:25:06.958 --> 00:25:09.958
But everybody agreed to play a game

00:25:09.958 --> 00:25:13.958
where the worst sketch artist bought the next round of drinks.

00:25:13.958 --> 00:25:17.958
That framework of rules would have turned an embarrassing,

00:25:17.958 --> 00:25:19.958
difficult situation into a fun game.

00:25:19.958 --> 00:25:25.958
As a result, we’d all feel perfectly secure and have a good time --

00:25:25.958 --> 00:25:30.958
but because we all understood the rules and we agreed on them together.

00:25:30.958 --> 00:25:34.958
But there aren’t just rules about how to play;

00:25:34.958 --> 00:25:37.958
there are rules about when to play.

00:25:37.958 --> 00:25:39.958
Kids don’t play all the time, obviously.

00:25:39.958 --> 00:25:41.958
They transition in and out of it,

00:25:41.958 --> 00:25:44.958
and good teachers spend a lot of time

00:25:44.958 --> 00:25:48.958
thinking about how to move kids through these experiences.

00:25:48.958 --> 00:25:53.958
As designers, we need to be able to transition in and out of play also.

00:25:53.958 --> 00:25:55.958
And if we’re running design studios

00:25:55.958 --> 00:25:57.958
we need to be able to figure out, how can we transition

00:25:57.958 --> 00:26:00.958
designers through these different experiences?

00:26:00.958 --> 00:26:03.958
I think this is particularly true if we think about the sort of --

00:26:03.958 --> 00:26:06.958
I think what’s very different about design

00:26:06.958 --> 00:26:10.958
is that we go through these two very distinctive modes of operation.

00:26:10.958 --> 00:26:15.958
We go through a sort of generative mode,

00:26:15.958 --> 00:26:16.958
where we’re exploring many ideas;

00:26:16.958 --> 00:26:18.958
and then we come back together again,

00:26:18.958 --> 00:26:21.958
and come back looking for that solution,

00:26:21.958 --> 00:26:22.958
and developing that solution.

00:26:22.958 --> 00:26:25.958
I think they’re two quite different modes:

00:26:25.958 --> 00:26:28.958
divergence and convergence.

00:26:28.958 --> 00:26:31.958
And I think it’s probably in the divergent mode

00:26:31.958 --> 00:26:33.958
that we most need playfulness.

00:26:33.958 --> 00:26:36.958
Perhaps in convergent mode we need to be more serious.

00:26:36.958 --> 00:26:38.958
And so being able to move between those modes

00:26:38.958 --> 00:26:42.958
is really quite important. So, it’s where there’s a

00:26:42.958 --> 00:26:45.958
more nuanced version view of play, I think, is required.

00:26:45.958 --> 00:26:48.958
Because it’s very easy to fall into the trap that these states are absolute.

00:26:48.958 --> 00:26:52.958
You’re either playful or you’re serious, and you can’t be both.

00:26:52.958 --> 00:26:57.958
But that’s not really true: you can be a serious professional adult

00:26:57.958 --> 00:27:00.958
and, at times, be playful.

00:27:00.958 --> 00:27:02.958
It’s not an either/or; it’s an "and."

00:27:02.958 --> 00:27:06.958
You can be serious and play.

00:27:06.958 --> 00:27:12.958
So to sum it up, we need trust to play,

00:27:12.958 --> 00:27:16.958
and we need trust to be creative. So, there’s a connection.

00:27:16.958 --> 00:27:19.958
And there are a series of behaviors that we’ve learnt as kids,

00:27:19.958 --> 00:27:22.958
and that turn out to be quite useful to us as designers.

00:27:22.958 --> 00:27:27.958
They include exploration, which is about going for quantity;

00:27:27.958 --> 00:27:30.958
building, and thinking with your hands;

00:27:30.958 --> 00:27:34.958
and role-play, where acting it out helps us both

00:27:34.958 --> 00:27:37.958
to have more empathy for the situations in which we’re designing,

00:27:37.958 --> 00:27:40.958
and to create services and experiences

00:27:40.958 --> 00:27:44.958
that are seamless and authentic.

00:27:44.958 --> 00:27:45.958
Thank you very much. (Applause)

title: The science of scent
transcript: The fragrance that you will smell, you will never be able to smell this way again. It’s a fragrance called Beyond Paradise, which you can find in any store in the nation. Except here it’s been split up in parts by Estée Lauder and by the perfumer who did it, Calice Becker, and I'm most grateful to them for this. And it’s been split up in successive bits and a chord.So what you’re smelling now is the top note. And then will come what they call the heart, the lush heart note. I will show it to you. The Eden top note is named after the Eden Project in the U.K.The lush heart note, Melaleuca bark note — which does not contain any Melaleuca bark, because it’s totally forbidden.And after that, the complete fragrance. Now what you are smelling is a combination of — I asked how many molecules there were in there, and nobody would tell me. So I put it through a G.C., a Gas Chromatograph that I have in my office, and it’s about 400. So what you’re smelling is several hundred molecules floating through the air, hitting your nose.And do not get the impression that this is very subjective. You are all smelling pretty much the same thing, OK? Smell has this reputation of being somewhat different for each person. It’s not really true. And perfumery shows you that can’t be true, because if it were like that it wouldn’t be an art, OK?Now, while the smell wafts over you, let me tell you the history of an idea. Everything that you’re smelling in here is made up of atoms that come from what I call the Upper East Side of the periodic table — a nice, safe neighborhood. (Laughter) You really don’t want to leave it if you want to have a career in perfumery. Some people have tried in the 1920s to add things from the bad parts, and it didn’t really work.These are the five atoms from which just about everything that you’re going to smell in real life, from coffee to fragrance, are made of. The top note that you smelled at the very beginning, the cut-grass green, what we call in perfumery — they’re weird terms — and this would be called a green note, because it smells of something green, like cut grass.This is cis-3-hexene-1-ol. And I had to learn chemistry on the fly in the last three years. A very expensive high school chemistry education. This has six carbon atoms, so "hexa," hexene-1-ol. It has one double bond, it has an alcohol on the end, so it’s "ol," and that’s why they call it cis-3-hexene-1-ol. Once you figure this out, you can really impress people at parties.This smells of cut grass. Now, this is the skeleton of the molecule. If you dress it up with atoms, hydrogen atoms — that’s what it looks like when you have it on your computer — but actually it’s sort of more like this, in the sense that the atoms have a certain sphere that you cannot penetrate. They repel.OK, now. Why does this thing smell of cut grass, OK? Why doesn’t it smell of potatoes or violets? Well, there are really two theories. But the first theory is: it must be the shape. And that’s a perfectly reasonable theory in the sense that almost everything else in biology works by shape. Enzymes that chew things up, antibodies, it’s all, you know, the fit between a protein and whatever it is grabbing, in this case a smell. And I will try and explain to you what’s wrong with this notion.And the other theory is that we smell molecular vibrations. Now, this is a totally insane idea. And when I first came across it in the early '90s, I thought my predecessor, Malcolm Dyson and Bob Wright, had really taken leave of their senses, and I’ll explain to you why this was the case. However, I came to realize gradually that they may be right — and I have to convince all my colleagues that this is so, but I’m working on it.Here’s how shape works in normal receptors. You have a molecule coming in, it gets into the protein, which is schematic here, and it causes this thing to switch, to turn, to move in some way by binding in certain parts. And the attraction, the forces, between the molecule and the protein cause the motion. This is a shape-based idea.Now, what’s wrong with shape is summarized in this slide. The way —I expect everybody to memorize these compounds. This is one page of work from a chemist’s workbook, OK? Working for a fragrance company. He’s making 45 molecules, and he’s looking for a sandalwood, something that smells of sandalwood. Because there’s a lot of money in sandalwoods. And of these 45 molecules, only 4629 actually smells of sandalwood. And he puts an exclamation mark, OK? This is an awful lot of work. This actually is roughly, in man-years of work, 200,000 dollars roughly, if you keep them on the low salaries with no benefits. So this is a profoundly inefficient process. And my definition of a theory is, it’s not just something that you teach people; it’s labor saving. A theory is something that enables you to do less work. I love the idea of doing less work. So let me explain to you why — a very simple fact that tells you why this shape theory really does not work very well.This is cis-3-hexene-1-ol. It smells of cut grass. This is cis-3-hexene-1-thiol, and this smells of rotten eggs, OK? Now, you will have noticed that vodka never smells of rotten eggs. If it does, you put the glass down, you go to a different bar. This is — in other words, we never get the O-H — we never mistake it for an S-H, OK? Like, at no concentration, even pure, you know, if you smelt pure ethanol, it doesn’t smell of rotten eggs. Conversely, there is no concentration at which the sulfur compound will smell like vodka. It’s very hard to explain this by molecular recognition. Now, I showed this to a physicist friend of mine who has a profound distaste for biology, and he says, "That’s easy! The things are a different color!" (Laughter)We have to go a little beyond that. Now let me explain why vibrational theory has some sort of interest in it. These molecules, as you saw in the beginning, the building blocks had springs connecting them to each other. In fact, molecules are able to vibrate at a set of frequencies which are very specific for each molecule and for the bonds connecting them.So this is the sound of the O-H stretch, translated into the audible range. S-H, quite a different frequency. Now, this is kind of interesting, because it tells you that you should be looking for a particular fact, which is this: nothing in the world smells like rotten eggs except S-H, OK?Now, Fact B: nothing in the world has that frequency except S-H. If you look on this, imagine a piano keyboard. The S-H stretch is in the middle of a part of the keyboard that has been, so to speak, damaged, and there are no neighboring notes, nothing is close to it. You have a unique smell, a unique vibration.So I went searching when I started in this game to convince myself that there was any degree of plausibility to this whole crazy story. I went searching for a type of molecule, any molecule, that would have that vibration and that — the obvious prediction was that it should absolutely smell of sulfur. If it didn’t, the whole idea was toast, and I might as well move on to other things.Now, after searching high and low for several months, I discovered that there was a type of molecule called a Borane which has exactly the same vibration. Now the good news is, Boranes you can get hold of. The bad news is they’re rocket fuels. Most of them explode spontaneously in contact with air, and when you call up the companies, they only give you minimum ten tons, OK? (Laughter) So this was not what they call a laboratory-scale experiment, and they wouldn’t have liked it at my college.However, I managed to get a hold of a Borane eventually, and here is the beast. And it really does have the same — if you calculate, if you measure the vibrational frequencies, they are the same as S-H.Now, does it smell of sulfur? Well, if you go back in the literature, there’s a man who knew more about Boranes than anyone alive then or since, Alfred Stock, he synthesized all of them. And in an enormous 40-page paper in German he says, at one point — my wife is German and she translated it for me — and at one point he says, "ganz widerlich Geruch," an "absolutely repulsive smell," which is good. Reminiscent of hydrogen sulfide. So this fact that Boranes smell of sulfur had been known since 1910, and utterly forgotten until 1997, 1998.Now, the slight fly in the ointment is this: that if we smell molecular vibrations, we must have a spectroscope in our nose. Now, this is a spectroscope, OK, on my laboratory bench. And it’s fair to say that if you look up somebody’s nose, you’re unlikely to see anything resembling this. And this is the main objection to the theory.OK, great, we smell vibrations. How? All right? Now when people ask this kind of question, they neglect something, which is that physicists are really clever, unlike biologists. (Laughter) This is a joke. I’m a biologist, OK? So it’s a joke against myself.Bob Jacklovich and John Lamb at Ford Motor Company, in the days when Ford Motor was spending vast amounts of money on fundamental research, discovered a way to build a spectroscope that was intrinsically nano-scale. In other words, no mirrors, no lasers, no prisms, no nonsense, just a tiny device, and he built this device. And this device uses electron tunneling. Now, I could do the dance of electron tunneling, but I’ve done a video instead, which is much more interesting. Here’s how it works.Electrons are fuzzy creatures, and they can jump across gaps, but only at equal energy. If the energy differs, they can’t jump. Unlike us, they won’t fall off the cliff. OK. Now. If something absorbs the energy, the electron can travel. So here you have a system, you have something — and there’s plenty of that stuff in biology — some substance giving an electron, and the electron tries to jump, and only when a molecule comes along that has the right vibration does the reaction happen, OK? This is the basis for the device that these two guys at Ford built.And every single part of this mechanism is actually plausible in biology. In other words, I’ve taken off-the-shelf components, and I’ve made a spectroscope. What’s nice about this idea, if you have a philosophical bent of mind, is that then it tells you that the nose, the ear and the eye are all vibrational senses. Of course, it doesn’t matter, because it could also be that they’re not. But it has a certain — (Laughter) — it has a certain ring to it which is attractive to people who read too much 19th-century German literature.And then a magnificent thing happened: I left academia and joined the real world of business, and a company was created around my ideas to make new molecules using my method, along the lines of, let’s put someone else’s money where your mouth is. And one of the first things that happened was we started going around to fragrance companies asking for what they needed, because, of course, if you could calculate smell, you don’t need chemists. You need a computer, a Mac will do it, if you know how to program the thing right, OK? So you can try a thousand molecules, you can try ten thousand molecules in a weekend, and then you only tell the chemists to make the right one. And so that’s a direct path to making new odorants.And one of the first things that happened was we went to see some perfumers in France — and here’s where I do my Charles Fleischer impression — and one of them says, "You cannot make a coumarin." He says to me, "I bet you cannot make a coumarin."Now, coumarin is a very common thing, a material, in fragrance which is derived from a bean that comes from South America. And it is the classic synthetic aroma chemical, OK? It’s the molecule that has made men’s fragrances smell the way they do since 1881, to be exact.And the problem is it’s a carcinogen. So nobody likes particularly to — you know, aftershave with carcinogens. (Laughter) There are some reckless people, but it’s not worth it, OK?So they asked us to make a new coumarin. And so we started doing calculations. And the first thing you do is you calculate the vibrational spectrum of coumarin, and you smooth it out, so that you have a nice picture of what the sort of chord, so to speak, of coumarin is. And then you start cranking the computer to find other molecules, related or unrelated, that have the same vibrations.And we actually, in this case, I’m sorry to say, it happened — it was serendipitous. Because I got a phone call from our chief chemist and he said, look, I’ve just found this such a beautiful reaction, that even if this compound doesn’t smell of coumarin, I want to do it, it’s just such a nifty, one step — I mean, chemists have weird minds — one step, 90 percent yield, you know, and you get this lovely crystalline compound. Let us try it.And I said, first of all, let me do the calculation on that compound, bottom right, which is related to coumarin, but has an extra pentagon inserted into the molecule. Calculate the vibrations, the purple spectrum is that new fellow, the white one is the old one. And the prediction is it should smell of coumarin. They made it ... and it smelled exactly like coumarin. And this is our new baby, called tonkene. You see, when you’re a scientist, you’re always selling ideas. And people are very resistant to ideas, and rightly so. Why should new ideas be accepted? But when you put a little 10-gram vial on the table in front of perfumers and it smells like coumarin, and it isn’t coumarin, and you’ve found it in three weeks, this focuses everybody’s mind wonderfully. (Laughter) (Applause)And people often ask me, is your theory accepted? And I said, well, by whom? I mean most, you know — there’s three attitudes: You’re right, and I don’t know why, which is the most rational one at this point. You’re right, and I don’t care how you do it, in a sense; you bring me the molecules, you know. And: You’re completely wrong, and I’m sure you’re completely wrong.OK? Now, we’re dealing with people who only want results, and this is the commercial world. And they tell us that even if we do it by astrology, they’re happy. But we’re not actually doing it by astrology. But for the last three years, I’ve had what I consider to be the best job in the entire universe, which is to put my hobby — which is, you know, fragrance and all the magnificent things — plus a little bit of biophysics, a small amount of self-taught chemistry at the service of something that actually works.Thank you very much. (Applause)

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:35.958
So what you’re smelling now is the top note.

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:39.958
And then will come what they call the heart, the lush heart note.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:42.958
I will show it to you.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
The Eden top note is named after the Eden Project in the U.K.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:50.958
The lush heart note, Melaleuca bark note -- which does not contain any Melaleuca bark,

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:53.958
because it’s totally forbidden.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:56.958
And after that, the complete fragrance.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.958
Now what you are smelling is a combination of --

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:03.958
I asked how many molecules there were in there, and nobody would tell me.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:08.958
So I put it through a G.C., a Gas Chromatograph that I have in my office,

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:11.958
and it’s about 400.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
So what you’re smelling is several hundred molecules

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
floating through the air, hitting your nose.

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:21.958
And do not get the impression that this is very subjective.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:25.958
You are all smelling pretty much the same thing, OK?

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:29.958
Smell has this reputation of being somewhat different for each person.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:30.958
It’s not really true.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
And perfumery shows you that can’t be true,

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:38.958
because if it were like that it wouldn’t be an art, OK?

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:42.958
Now, while the smell wafts over you, let me tell you the history of an idea.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:46.958
Everything that you’re smelling in here

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:48.958
is made up of atoms that come from what I call

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:51.958
the Upper East Side of the periodic table -- a nice, safe neighborhood.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:55.958
(Laughter)

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
You really don’t want to leave it if you want to have a career in perfumery.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
Some people have tried in the 1920s

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:04.958
to add things from the bad parts, and it didn’t really work.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
These are the five atoms from which just about everything

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:12.958
that you’re going to smell in real life, from coffee to fragrance, are made of.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
The top note that you smelled at the very beginning,

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:18.958
the cut-grass green, what we call in perfumery -- they’re weird terms --

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
and this would be called a green note,

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
because it smells of something green, like cut grass.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:29.958
This is cis-3-hexene-1-ol. And I had to learn chemistry on the fly

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:35.958
in the last three years. A very expensive high school chemistry education.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:39.958
This has six carbon atoms, so "hexa," hexene-1-ol.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:43.958
It has one double bond, it has an alcohol on the end,

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:46.958
so it’s "ol," and that’s why they call it cis-3-hexene-1-ol.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
Once you figure this out, you can really impress people at parties.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:53.958
This smells of cut grass. Now, this is the skeleton of the molecule.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.958
If you dress it up with atoms, hydrogen atoms --

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
that’s what it looks like when you have it on your computer --

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:02.958
but actually it’s sort of more like this, in the sense that the atoms have a certain

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
sphere that you cannot penetrate. They repel.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:11.958
OK, now. Why does this thing smell of cut grass, OK?

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:17.958
Why doesn’t it smell of potatoes or violets? Well, there are really two theories.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:21.958
But the first theory is: it must be the shape.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
And that’s a perfectly reasonable theory in the sense that

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
almost everything else in biology works by shape.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:29.958
Enzymes that chew things up, antibodies, it’s all, you know,

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:35.958
the fit between a protein and whatever it is grabbing, in this case a smell.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
And I will try and explain to you what’s wrong with this notion.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:41.958
And the other theory is that we smell molecular vibrations.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
Now, this is a totally insane idea.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:47.958
And when I first came across it in the early '90s, I thought my predecessor,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
Malcolm Dyson and Bob Wright, had really taken leave of their senses,

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:53.958
and I’ll explain to you why this was the case.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.958
However, I came to realize gradually that they may be right --

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
and I have to convince all my colleagues that this is so, but I’m working on it.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:05.958
Here’s how shape works in normal receptors.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:10.958
You have a molecule coming in, it gets into the protein, which is schematic here,

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:15.958
and it causes this thing to switch, to turn, to move in some way

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:19.958
by binding in certain parts.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
And the attraction, the forces, between the molecule and the protein

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:26.958
cause the motion. This is a shape-based idea.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:30.958
Now, what’s wrong with shape is summarized in this slide.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:35.958
The way --I expect everybody to memorize these compounds.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:40.958
This is one page of work from a chemist’s workbook, OK?

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
Working for a fragrance company.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
He’s making 45 molecules, and he’s looking for a sandalwood,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:46.958
something that smells of sandalwood.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
Because there’s a lot of money in sandalwoods.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:55.958
And of these 45 molecules, only 4629 actually smells of sandalwood.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
And he puts an exclamation mark, OK? This is an awful lot of work.


00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:03.958
This actually is roughly, in man-years of work, 200,000 dollars roughly,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:07.958
if you keep them on the low salaries with no benefits.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
So this is a profoundly inefficient process.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
And my definition of a theory is, it’s not just something

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
that you teach people; it’s labor saving.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
A theory is something that enables you to do less work.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:23.958
I love the idea of doing less work. So let me explain to you why -- a very simple fact

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:28.958
that tells you why this shape theory really does not work very well.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:33.958
This is cis-3-hexene-1-ol. It smells of cut grass.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:40.958
This is cis-3-hexene-1-thiol, and this smells of rotten eggs, OK?

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:45.958
Now, you will have noticed that vodka never smells of rotten eggs.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:49.958
If it does, you put the glass down, you go to a different bar.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:54.958
This is -- in other words, we never get the O-H --

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
we never mistake it for an S-H, OK?

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
Like, at no concentration, even pure, you know,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
if you smelt pure ethanol, it doesn’t smell of rotten eggs.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:10.958
Conversely, there is no concentration at which the sulfur compound will smell like vodka.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:14.958
It’s very hard to explain this by molecular recognition.


00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
Now, I showed this to a physicist friend of mine who has a profound distaste

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:20.958
for biology, and he says, "That’s easy! The things are a different color!"

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:25.958
(Laughter)

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:30.958
We have to go a little beyond that. Now let me explain why vibrational theory has

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:34.958
some sort of interest in it. These molecules, as you saw in the beginning,

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
the building blocks had springs connecting them to each other.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
In fact, molecules are able to vibrate at a set of frequencies

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:43.958
which are very specific for each molecule and for the bonds connecting them.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:51.958
So this is the sound of the O-H stretch, translated into the audible range.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
S-H, quite a different frequency.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:58.958
Now, this is kind of interesting, because it tells you

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
that you should be looking for a particular fact, which is this:

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
nothing in the world smells like rotten eggs except S-H, OK?

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:12.958
Now, Fact B: nothing in the world has that frequency except S-H.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
If you look on this, imagine a piano keyboard.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:18.958
The S-H stretch is in the middle of a part of the keyboard

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
that has been, so to speak, damaged,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
and there are no neighboring notes, nothing is close to it.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
You have a unique smell, a unique vibration.


00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
So I went searching when I started in this game

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
to convince myself that there was any degree of plausibility

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
to this whole crazy story.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
I went searching for a type of molecule, any molecule,

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:40.958
that would have that vibration and that -- the obvious prediction

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
was that it should absolutely smell of sulfur.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:48.958
If it didn’t, the whole idea was toast, and I might as well move on to other things.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:52.958
Now, after searching high and low for several months,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:57.958
I discovered that there was a type of molecule called a Borane

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
which has exactly the same vibration.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
Now the good news is, Boranes you can get hold of.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
The bad news is they’re rocket fuels.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
Most of them explode spontaneously in contact with air,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.958
and when you call up the companies, they only give you minimum ten tons, OK?

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
(Laughter)

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
So this was not what they call a laboratory-scale experiment,


00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
and they wouldn’t have liked it at my college.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:28.958
However, I managed to get a hold of a Borane eventually, and here is the beast.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
And it really does have the same -- if you calculate,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:34.958
if you measure the vibrational frequencies, they are the same as S-H.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:39.958
Now, does it smell of sulfur? Well, if you go back in the literature,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
there’s a man who knew more about Boranes than anyone

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:47.958
alive then or since, Alfred Stock, he synthesized all of them.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:53.958
And in an enormous 40-page paper in German he says, at one point --

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
my wife is German and she translated it for me --

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
and at one point he says, "ganz widerlich Geruch,"


00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:04.958
an "absolutely repulsive smell," which is good. Reminiscent of hydrogen sulfide.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
So this fact that Boranes smell of sulfur

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:14.958
had been known since 1910, and utterly forgotten until 1997, 1998.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:18.958
Now, the slight fly in the ointment is this: that

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:23.958
if we smell molecular vibrations, we must have a spectroscope in our nose.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:28.958
Now, this is a spectroscope, OK, on my laboratory bench.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
And it’s fair to say that if you look up somebody’s nose,

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
you’re unlikely to see anything resembling this.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
And this is the main objection to the theory.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:40.958
OK, great, we smell vibrations. How? All right?

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
Now when people ask this kind of question, they neglect something,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:46.958
which is that physicists are really clever, unlike biologists.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
(Laughter)

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
This is a joke. I’m a biologist, OK?

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:52.958
So it’s a joke against myself.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
Bob Jacklovich and John Lamb at Ford Motor Company,

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
in the days when Ford Motor was spending vast amounts of money

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:01.958
on fundamental research, discovered a way

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:05.958
to build a spectroscope that was intrinsically nano-scale.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
In other words, no mirrors, no lasers, no prisms, no nonsense,

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:13.958
just a tiny device, and he built this device. And this device uses electron tunneling.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
Now, I could do the dance of electron tunneling,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:21.958
but I’ve done a video instead, which is much more interesting. Here’s how it works.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:25.958
Electrons are fuzzy creatures, and they can jump across gaps,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:30.958
but only at equal energy. If the energy differs, they can’t jump.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
Unlike us, they won’t fall off the cliff.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:39.958
OK. Now. If something absorbs the energy, the electron can travel.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
So here you have a system, you have something --

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:43.958
and there’s plenty of that stuff in biology --

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:48.958
some substance giving an electron, and the electron tries to jump,

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and only when a molecule comes along that has the right vibration

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
does the reaction happen, OK?

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:58.958
This is the basis for the device that these two guys at Ford built.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:05.958
And every single part of this mechanism is actually plausible in biology.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:06.958
In other words, I’ve taken off-the-shelf components,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
and I’ve made a spectroscope.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
What’s nice about this idea, if you have a philosophical bent of mind,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
is that then it tells you that the nose,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
the ear and the eye are all vibrational senses.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
Of course, it doesn’t matter, because it could also be that they’re not.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:22.958
But it has a certain --

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
(Laughter)

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:28.958
-- it has a certain ring to it which is attractive to people

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:32.958
who read too much 19th-century German literature.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:33.958
And then a magnificent thing happened:

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:39.958
I left academia and joined the real world of business,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
and a company was created around my ideas

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
to make new molecules using my method,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:49.958
along the lines of, let’s put someone else’s money where your mouth is.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:53.958
And one of the first things that happened was

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
we started going around to fragrance companies

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:59.958
asking for what they needed, because, of course,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
if you could calculate smell, you don’t need chemists.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:05.958
You need a computer, a Mac will do it, if you know how to program the thing right,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:09.958
OK? So you can try a thousand molecules,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
you can try ten thousand molecules in a weekend,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
and then you only tell the chemists to make the right one.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:19.958
And so that’s a direct path to making new odorants.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:20.958
And one of the first things that happened was

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
we went to see some perfumers in France --

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
and here’s where I do my Charles Fleischer impression --

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:28.958
and one of them says, "You cannot make a coumarin."

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
He says to me, "I bet you cannot make a coumarin."

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:35.958
Now, coumarin is a very common thing, a material,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
in fragrance which is derived from a bean that comes from South America.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:42.958
And it is the classic synthetic aroma chemical, OK?

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:46.958
It’s the molecule that has made men’s fragrances

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
smell the way they do since 1881, to be exact.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
And the problem is it’s a carcinogen.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:58.958
So nobody likes particularly to -- you know, aftershave with carcinogens.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
(Laughter)

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
There are some reckless people, but it’s not worth it, OK?

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:08.958
So they asked us to make a new coumarin. And so we started doing calculations.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
And the first thing you do is you calculate the vibrational spectrum

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:12.958
of coumarin, and you smooth it out,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:18.958
so that you have a nice picture of what the sort of chord, so to speak, of coumarin is.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:24.958
And then you start cranking the computer to find other molecules,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
related or unrelated, that have the same vibrations.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:31.958
And we actually, in this case, I’m sorry to say,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
it happened -- it was serendipitous.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
Because I got a phone call from our chief chemist

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:41.958
and he said, look, I’ve just found this such a beautiful reaction,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:42.958
that even if this compound doesn’t smell of coumarin,

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
I want to do it, it’s just such a nifty,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
one step -- I mean, chemists have weird minds --

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:52.958
one step, 90 percent yield, you know, and you get this lovely

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
crystalline compound. Let us try it.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:58.958
And I said, first of all, let me do the calculation on that compound, bottom right,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:04.958
which is related to coumarin, but has an extra pentagon inserted into the molecule.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:09.958
Calculate the vibrations, the purple spectrum is that new fellow,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:10.958
the white one is the old one.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
And the prediction is it should smell of coumarin.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:22.958
They made it ... and it smelled exactly like coumarin.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And this is our new baby, called tonkene.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
You see, when you’re a scientist, you’re always selling ideas.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:33.958
And people are very resistant to ideas, and rightly so.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
Why should new ideas be accepted?

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:41.958
But when you put a little 10-gram vial on the table in front of perfumers

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
and it smells like coumarin, and it isn’t coumarin,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
and you’ve found it in three weeks,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
this focuses everybody’s mind wonderfully.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:49.958
(Laughter)

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:55.958
(Applause)

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:59.958
And people often ask me, is your theory accepted?

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:04.958
And I said, well, by whom? I mean most, you know -- there’s three attitudes:

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:08.958
You’re right, and I don’t know why, which is the most rational one at this point.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:12.958
You’re right, and I don’t care how you do it, in a sense;

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:13.958
you bring me the molecules, you know.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
And: You’re completely wrong, and I’m sure you’re completely wrong.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
OK? Now, we’re dealing with people who only want results,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
and this is the commercial world.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:26.958
And they tell us that even if we do it by astrology, they’re happy.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
But we’re not actually doing it by astrology.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
But for the last three years, I’ve had what I consider to be

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:36.958
the best job in the entire universe, which is to put my hobby --

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
which is, you know, fragrance and all the magnificent things --
