00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:42.958
there is good news, amazing news, in the 21st century,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:49.958
and that is that, almost out of nowhere, there has come into being

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
an anti-genocide movement, an anti-genocide constituency,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:56.958
and one that looks destined, in fact, to be permanent.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
It grew up in response to the atrocities in Darfur.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:05.958
It is comprised of students. There are something like 300 anti-genocide chapters

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
on college campuses around the country.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
It's bigger than the anti-apartheid movement.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:14.958
There are something like 500 high school chapters

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
devoted to stopping the genocide in Darfur.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:21.958
Evangelicals have joined it. Jewish groups have joined it.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:25.958
"Hotel Rwanda" watchers have joined it. It is a cacophonous movement.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
To call it a movement, as with all movements, perhaps, is a little misleading.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
It's diverse. It's got a lot of different approaches.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
It's got all the ups and the downs of movements.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:37.958
But it has been amazingly successful in one regard,

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
in that it has become,

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
it has congealed into this endangered people's movement

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
that was missing in the 20th century.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
It sees itself, such as it is, the it,

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:52.958
as something that will create the impression that there will be political cost,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
there will be a political price to be paid,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:59.958
for allowing genocide, for not having an heroic imagination,

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:03.958
for not being an upstander but for being, in fact, a bystander.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:07.958
Now because it's student-driven,

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
there's some amazing things that the movement has done.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
They have launched a divestment campaign

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:15.958
that has now convinced, I think, 55 universities in 22 states

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
to divest their holdings of stocks

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:21.958
with regard to companies doing business in Sudan.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
They have a 1-800-GENOCIDE number --

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
this is going to sound very kitsch,

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:29.958
but for those of you who may not be, I mean, may be apolitical,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
but interested in doing something about genocide,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
you dial 1-800-GENOCIDE and you type in your zip code,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
and you don't even have to know who your congressperson is.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:40.958
It will refer you directly to your congressperson, to your U.S. senator,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:43.958
to your governor where divestment legislation is pending.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:47.958
They've lowered the transaction costs of stopping genocide.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
I think the most innovative thing they've introduced recently

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
are genocide grades.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
And it takes students to introduce genocide grades.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
So what you now have when a Congress is in session

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:04.958
is members of Congress calling up these 19-year-olds or 24-year-olds

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
and saying, I'm just told I have a D minus on genocide;

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:11.958
what do I do to get a C? I just want to get a C. Help me.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
And the students and the others

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
who are part of this incredibly energized base

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:19.958
are there to answer that, and there's always something to do.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:24.958
Now, what this movement has done is it has extracted from the Bush administration

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
from the United States,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:31.958
at a time of massive over-stretch -- military, financial, diplomatic --

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
a whole series of commitments to Darfur

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
that no other country in the world is making.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
For instance, the referral of the crimes in Darfur

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
to the International Criminal Court,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
which the Bush administration doesn't like.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:46.958
The expenditure of 3 billion dollars in refugee camps to try to keep,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
basically, the people who've been displaced from their homes

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
by the Sudanese government, by the so-called Janjaweed, the militia,

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
to keep those people alive

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:57.958
until something more durable can be achieved.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
And recently, or now not that recently,

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
about six months ago, the authorization of a peacekeeping force

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
of 26,000 that will go.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
And that's all the Bush administration's leadership,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
and it's all because of this bottom-up pressure

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
and the fact that the phones haven't stopped ringing

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
from the beginning of this crisis.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
The bad news, however, to this question of will evil prevail,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
is that evil lives on.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:22.958
The people in those camps are surrounded on all sides

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
by so-called Janjaweed, these men on horseback

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
with spears and Kalashnikovs.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:30.958
Women who go to get firewood in order to heat the humanitarian aid

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
in order to feed their families -- humanitarian aid,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
the dirty secret of it is it has to be heated, really, to be edible --

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
are themselves subjected to rape,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
which is a tool of the genocide that is being used.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
And the peacekeepers I've mentioned, the force has been authorized,

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:48.958
but almost no country on Earth has stepped forward since the authorization

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
to actually put its troops or its police in harm's way.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:56.958
So we have achieved an awful lot relative to the 20th century,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:08:00.958
and yet far too little relative to the gravity of the crime that is unfolding

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
as we sit here, as we speak.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
Why the limits to the movement?

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:09.958
Why is what has been achieved, or what the movement has done,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
been necessary but not sufficient to the crime?

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
I think there are a couple -- there are many reasons --

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
but a couple just to focus on briefly.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:19.958
The first is that the movement, such as it is,


00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:23.958
stops at America's borders. 
It is not a global movement. 


00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:27.958
It does not have too many compatriots abroad who themselves

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:31.958
are asking their governments to do more to stop genocide.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
And the Holocaust culture that we have in this country

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
makes Americans, sort of, more prone to, I think,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
want to bring Never Again to life.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:43.958
The guilt that the Clinton administration expressed,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
that Bill Clinton expressed over Rwanda,

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
created a space in our society for a consensus

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
that Rwanda was bad and wrong

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
and we wish we had done more, and that is something

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
that the movement has taken advantage of.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:54.958
European governments, for the most part,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
haven't acknowledged responsibility, and there's nothing to kind of

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:01.958
to push back and up against.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:05.958
So this movement, if it's to be durable and global,

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
will have to cross borders, and you will have to see

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
other citizens in democracies, not simply resting on the assumption

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
that their government would do something in the face of genocide,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
but actually making it such.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
Governments will never gravitate towards crimes of this magnitude

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
naturally or eagerly.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
As we saw, they haven't even gravitated towards protecting our ports

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
or reigning in loose nukes.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:30.958
Why would we expect in a bureaucracy that it would orient itself

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
towards distant suffering?

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
So one reason is it hasn't gone global.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:38.958
The second is, of course, that at this time in particular in America's history,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
we have a credibility problem,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
a legitimacy problem in international institutions.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
It is structurally really, really hard to do,

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
as the Bush administration rightly does,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
which is to denounce genocide on a Monday

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
and then describe water boarding on a Tuesday as a no-brainer

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:58.958
and then turn up on Wednesday and look for troop commitments.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Now, other countries have their own reasons for not wanting to get involved.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
Let me be clear.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
They're in some ways using the Bush administration as an alibi.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:10.958
But it is essential for us to be a leader in this sphere,

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:14.958
of course to restore our standing and our leadership in the world.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
The recovery's going to take some time.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
We have to ask ourselves, what now? What do we do going forward

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:23.958
as a country and as citizens in relationship to the world's worst places,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:28.958
the world's worst suffering, killers, and the kinds of killers

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:33.958
that could come home to roost sometime in the future?

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:39.958
The place that I turned to answer that question was to a man

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
that many of you may not have ever heard of,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:47.958
and that is a Brazilian named Sergio Vieira de Mello who,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:53.958
as Chris said, was blown up in Iraq in 2003.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
He was the victim of the first-ever suicide bomb in Iraq.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
It's hard to remember, but there was actually a time in the summer of 2003,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
even after the U.S. invasion, where,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:06.958
apart from looting, civilians were relatively safe in Iraq.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
Now, who was Sergio? Sergio Vieira de Mello was his name.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
In addition to being Brazilian, he was described to me

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
before I met him in 1994 as someone who was a cross between

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:19.958
James Bond on the one hand and Bobby Kennedy on the other.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
And in the U.N., you don't get that many people

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
who actually manage to merge those qualities.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:29.958
He was James Bond-like in that he was ingenious.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
He was drawn to the flames, he chased the flames,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
he was like a moth to the flames. Something of an adrenalin junkie.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.958
He was successful with women.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:44.958
He was Bobby Kennedy-like because in some ways one could never tell

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
if he was a realist masquerading as an idealist

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:50.958
or an idealist masquerading as a realist, as people always wondered

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
about Bobby Kennedy and John Kennedy in that way.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:57.958
What he was was a decathlete of nation-building, of problem-solving,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
of troubleshooting in the world's worst places

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
and in the world's most broken places.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:07.958
In failing states, genocidal states, under-governed states,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:12.958
precisely the kinds of places that threats to this country exist

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
on the horizon, and precisely the kinds of places

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:19.958
where most of the world's suffering tends to get concentrated.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
These are the places he was drawn to.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
He moved with the headlines.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:28.958
He was in the U.N. for 34 years. He joined at the age of 21.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
Started off when the causes in the wars du jour in the '70s

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
were wars of independence and decolonization.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
He was there in Bangladesh

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
dealing with the outflow of millions of refugees --

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
the largest refugee flow in history up to that point.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
He was in Sudan when the civil war broke out there.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
He was in Cyprus right after the Turkish invasion.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
He was in Mozambique for the War of Independence.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
He was in Lebanon. Amazingly, he was in Lebanon -- the U.N. base was used --

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:55.958
Palestinians staged attacks out from behind the U.N. base.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
Israel then invaded and overran the U.N. base.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
Sergio was in Beirut when the U.S. Embassy was hit

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
by the first-ever suicide attack against the United States. 


00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:08.958
People date the beginning of this new era to 9/11, but surely 1983,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
with the attack on the US Embassy and the Marine barracks --

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
which Sergio witnessed -- those are, in fact, in some ways,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:17.958
the dawning of the era that we find ourselves in today.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
From Lebanon he went to Bosnia in the '90s.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.958
The issues were, of course, ethnic sectarian violence.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
He was the first person to negotiate with the Khmer Rouge.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
Talk about evil prevailing. I mean, here he was in the room

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
with the embodiment of evil in Cambodia.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
He negotiates with the Serbs.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:38.958
He actually crosses so far into this realm of talking to evil

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
and trying to convince evil that it doesn't need to prevail

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
that he earns the nickname -- not Sergio but Serbio

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:49.958
while he's living in the Balkans and conducting these kinds of negotiations.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
He then goes to Rwanda and to Congo in the aftermath of the genocide,

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
and he's the guy who has to decide -- huh, OK, the genocide is over;

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:59.958
800,000 people have been killed; the people responsible are fleeing

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
into neighboring countries -- into Congo, into Tanzania.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
I'm Sergio, I'm a humanitarian, and I want to feed those --

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
well, I don't want to feed the killers

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
but I want to feed the two million people who are with them, so we're going to go,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
we're going to set up camps,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
and we're going to supply humanitarian aid.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
But, uh-oh, the killers are within the camps.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
Well, I'd like to separate the sheep from the wolves.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
Let me go door-to-door to the international community

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
and see if anybody will give me police or troops to do the separation.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And their response, of course, was no more than we wanted

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
to stop the genocide and put our troops in harm's way to do that,

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:35.958
nor do we now want to get in the way and pluck genocidaires from camps.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
So then you have to make the decision.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
Do you turn off the international spigot of life support

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:43.958
and risk two million civilian lives?

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
Or do you continue feeding the civilians, knowing that the genocidaires

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:50.958
are in the camps, literally sharpening their knives for future battle?

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:51.958
What do you do?

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
It's all lesser-evil terrain in these broken places.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
Late '90s: nation-building is the cause du jour.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:01.958
He's the guy put in charge. He's the Paul Bremer or the Jerry Bremer

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
of first Kosovo and then East Timor. He governs the places.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:08.958
He's the viceroy. He has to decide on tax policy, on currency,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:12.958
on border patrol, on policing. He has to make all these judgments.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
He's a Brazilian in these places. He speaks seven languages.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
He's been up to that point in 14 war zones

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
so he's positioned to make better judgments, perhaps,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
than people who have never done that kind of work.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:26.958
But nonetheless, he is the cutting edge of our experimentation

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
with doing good with very few resources being brought to bear in,

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
again, the world's worst places.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
And then after Timor, 9/11 has happened,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
he's named U.N. Human Rights Commissioner,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
and he has to balance liberty and security and figure out,

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
what do you do when the most powerful country in the United Nations

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
is bowing out of the Geneva Conventions,

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
bowing out of international law? Do you denounce?

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:48.958
Well, if you denounce,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
you're probably never going to get back in the room.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:55.958
Maybe you stay reticent. Maybe you try to charm President Bush --

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
and that's what he did. And in so doing he earned himself,

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
unfortunately, his final and tragic appointment to Iraq --

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
the one that resulted in his death.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
One note on his death, which is so devastating,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
is that despite predicating the war on Iraq

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:13.958
on a link between Saddam Hussein and terrorism in 9/11,

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
believe it or not, the Bush administration or the invaders

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:20.958
did no planning, no pre-war planning, to respond to terrorism.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:24.958
So Sergio -- this receptacle of all of this learning on how to deal with evil

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
and how to deal with brokenness,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:30.958
lay under the rubble for three and a half hours without rescue.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:34.958
Stateless. The guy who tried to help the stateless people his whole career.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
Like a refugee. Because he represents the U.N.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
If you represent everyone, in some ways you represent no one.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
You're un-owned.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
And what the American -- the most powerful military in the history of mankind

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
was able to muster for his rescue,

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:50.958
believe it or not, was literally these heroic two American soldiers

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
went into the shaft. Building was shaking.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:56.958
One of them had been at 9/11 and lost his buddies on September 11th,

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
and yet went in and risked his life in order to save Sergio.

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:02.958
But all they had was a woman's handbag --

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
literally one of those basket handbags --

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:08.958
and they tied it to a curtain rope from one of the offices at U.N. headquarters,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:13.958
and created a pulley system into this shaft in this quivering building

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
in the interests of rescuing this person,

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
the person we most need to turn to now, this shepherd,

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:22.958
at a time when so many of us feel like we're lacking guidance.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:25.958
And this was the pulley system. This was what we were able to muster for Sergio.

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:27.958
The good news, for what it's worth,

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:31.958
is after Sergio and 21 others were killed that day in the attack on the U.N.,

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:33.958
the military created a search and rescue unit

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:37.958
that had the cutting equipment, the shoring wood, the cranes,

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:39.958
the things that you would have needed to do the rescue.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
But it was too late for Sergio.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:43.958
I want to wrap up, but I want to close

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:47.958
with what I take to be the four lessons from Sergio's life

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:50.958
on this question of how do we prevent evil from prevailing,

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:53.958
which is how I would have framed the question.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:56.958
Here's this guy who got a 34-year head start

00:17:56.958 --> 00:18:00.958
thinking about the kinds of questions we as a country are grappling with,

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:05.958
we as citizens are grappling with now. What do we take away?

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:10.958
First, I think, is his relationship to, in fact, evil is something to learn from.

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:13.958
He, over the course of his career, changed a great deal.

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:15.958
He had a lot of flaws, but he was very adaptive.

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:17.958
I think that was his greatest quality.

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:21.958
He started as somebody who would denounce harmdoers,

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:24.958
he would charge up to people who were violating international law,

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
and he would say, you're violating, this is the U.N. Charter.

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
Don't you see it's unacceptable what you're doing?

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:31.958
And they would laugh at him because he didn't have the power of states,

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:33.958
the power of any military or police.

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:36.958
He just had the rules, he had the norms, and he tried to use them.

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:39.958
And in Lebanon, Southern Lebanon in '82,

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:42.958
he said to himself and to everybody else,

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:45.958
I will never use the word "unacceptable" again.

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:47.958
I will never use it. I will try to make it such,

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:49.958
but I will never use that word again.

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:51.958
But he lunged in the opposite direction.

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:54.958
He started, as I mentioned, to get in the room with evil,

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:58.958
to not denounce, and became almost obsequious

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:01.958
when he won the nickname Serbio, for instance,

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:03.958
and even when he negotiated with the Khmer Rouge

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:07.958
would black-box what had occurred prior to entering the room.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:10.958
But by the end of his life, I think he had struck a balance

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:12.958
that we as a country can learn from.

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:16.958
Be in the room, don't be afraid of talking to your adversaries,

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:20.958
but don't bracket what happened before you entered the room.

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:25.958
Don't black-box history. Don't check your principles at the door.

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:28.958
And I think that's something that we have to be in the room,

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:32.958
whether it's Nixon going to China or Khrushchev and Kennedy

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:34.958
or Reagan and Gorbachev.

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:38.958
All the great progress in this country with relation to our adversaries

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:40.958
has come by going into the room.

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:43.958
And it doesn't have to be an act of weakness.

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:46.958
You can actually do far more to build an international coalition

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:49.958
against a harmdoer or a wrongdoer by being in the room

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:52.958
and showing to the rest of the world that that person, that regime,

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:55.958
is the problem and that you, the United States, are not the problem.

00:19:55.958 --> 00:19:59.958
Second take-away from Sergio's life, briefly.

00:19:59.958 --> 00:20:01.958
What I take away, and this in some ways is the most important,

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:07.958
he espoused and exhibited a reverence for dignity

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:09.958
that was really, really unusual.

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:13.958
At a micro level, the individuals around him were visible.

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:14.958
He saw them.

00:20:14.958 --> 00:20:16.958
At a macro level, he thought, you know,

00:20:16.958 --> 00:20:19.958
we talk about democracy promotion, but we do it in a way sometimes

00:20:19.958 --> 00:20:22.958
that's an affront to people's dignity.

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:24.958
We put people on humanitarian aid

00:20:24.958 --> 00:20:26.958
and we boast about it because we've spent three billion.

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:27.958
It's incredibly important,

00:20:27.958 --> 00:20:29.958
those people would no longer be alive if the United States, for instance,

00:20:29.958 --> 00:20:32.958
hadn't spent that money in Darfur,

00:20:32.958 --> 00:20:33.958
but it's not a way to live.

00:20:33.958 --> 00:20:36.958
If we think about dignity in our conduct as citizens

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:39.958
and as individuals with relation to the people around us,

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:41.958
and as a country, if we could inject a regard for dignity

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:44.958
into our dealings with other countries,

00:20:44.958 --> 00:20:46.958
it would be something of a revolution.

00:20:46.958 --> 00:20:50.958
Third point, very briefly. He talked a lot about freedom from fear.

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:53.958
And I recognize there is so much to be afraid of.

00:20:53.958 --> 00:20:55.958
There are so many genuine threats in the world.

00:20:55.958 --> 00:20:57.958
But what Sergio was talking about is,

00:20:57.958 --> 00:20:59.958
let's calibrate our relationship to the threat.

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:02.958
Let's not hype the threat; let's actually see it clearly.

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:05.958
We have reason to be afraid of melting ice caps.

00:21:05.958 --> 00:21:08.958
We have reason to be afraid that we haven't secured

00:21:08.958 --> 00:21:11.958
loose nuclear material in the former Soviet Union.

00:21:11.958 --> 00:21:15.958
Let's focus on what are the legitimate challenges and threats,

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:20.958
but not lunge into bad decisions because of a panic, of a fear.

00:21:20.958 --> 00:21:22.958
In times of fear, for instance, one of the things Sergio used to say

00:21:22.958 --> 00:21:24.958
is, fear is a bad advisor.

00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:26.958
We lunge towards the extremes

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:28.958
when we aren't operating and trying to, again,

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:30.958
calibrate our relationship to the world around us.

00:21:30.958 --> 00:21:33.958
Fourth and final point: he somehow, because he was working

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:36.958
in all the world's worst places and all lesser evils,

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:38.958
had a humility, of course,

00:21:38.958 --> 00:21:41.958
and an awareness of the complexity of the world around him.

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:43.958
I mean, such an acute awareness of how hard it was.

00:21:43.958 --> 00:21:47.958
How Sisyphean this task was of mending,

00:21:47.958 --> 00:21:49.958
and yet aware of that complexity, 


00:21:49.958 --> 00:21:52.958
humbled by it, he wasn't paralyzed by it.

00:21:52.958 --> 00:21:57.958
And we as citizens, as we go through this experience of the kind of,

00:21:57.958 --> 00:22:01.958
the crisis of confidence, crisis of competence, crisis of legitimacy,

00:22:01.958 --> 00:22:04.958
I think there's a temptation to pull back from the world and say,

00:22:04.958 --> 00:22:06.958
ah, Katrina, Iraq -- we don't know what we're doing.

00:22:06.958 --> 00:22:09.958
We can't afford to pull back from the world.

00:22:09.958 --> 00:22:12.958
It's a question of how to be in the world.

00:22:12.958 --> 00:22:13.958
And the lesson, I think,

00:22:13.958 --> 00:22:15.958
of the anti-genocide movement that I mentioned,

00:22:15.958 --> 00:22:17.958
that is a partial success but by no means

00:22:17.958 --> 00:22:20.958
has it achieved what it has set out to do --

00:22:20.958 --> 00:22:23.958
it'll be many decades, probably, before that happens --

00:22:23.958 --> 00:22:27.958
but is that if we want to see change, we have to become the change.

00:22:27.958 --> 00:22:31.958
We can't rely upon our institutions to do the work

00:22:31.958 --> 00:22:35.958
of necessarily talking to adversaries on their own

00:22:35.958 --> 00:22:37.958
without us creating a space for that to happen,

00:22:37.958 --> 00:22:39.958
for having respect for dignity,

00:22:39.958 --> 00:22:41.958
and for bringing that combination of humility

00:22:41.958 --> 00:22:44.958
and a sort of emboldened sense of responsibility

00:22:44.958 --> 00:22:46.958
to our dealings with the rest of the world.

00:22:46.958 --> 00:22:48.958
So will evil prevail? Is that the question?

00:22:48.958 --> 00:22:52.958
I think the short answer is: no, not unless we let it.

00:22:52.958 --> 00:22:53.958
Thank you.

00:22:53.958 --> 00:22:56.958
(Applause)

title: The story behind the Mars Rovers
transcript: I thought I'd start with telling you or showing you the people who started [Jet Propulsion Lab]. When they were a bunch of kids, they were kind of very imaginative, very adventurous, as they were trying at Caltech to mix chemicals and see which one blows up more. Well, I don't recommend that you try to do that now. Naturally, they blew up a shack, and Caltech, well, then, hey, you go to the Arroyo and really do all your tests in there.So, that's what we call our first five employees during the tea break, you know, in here. As I said, they were adventurous people. As a matter of fact, one of them, who was, kind of, part of a cult which was not too far from here on Orange Grove, and unfortunately he blew up himself because he kept mixing chemicals and trying to figure out which ones were the best chemicals. So, that gives you a kind of flavor of the kind of people we have there. We try to avoid blowing ourselves up.This one I thought I'd show you. Guess which one is a JPL employee in the heart of this crowd. I tried to come like him this morning, but as I walked out, then it was too cold, and I said, I'd better put my shirt back on. But more importantly, the reason I wanted to show this picture: look where the other people are looking, and look where he is looking. Wherever anybody else looks, look somewhere else, and go do something different, you know, and doing that. And that's kind of what has been the spirit of what we are doing.And I want to tell you a quote from Ralph Emerson that one of my colleagues, you know, put on my wall in my office, and it says, "Do not go where the path may lead. Go instead where there is no path, and leave a trail." And that's my recommendation to all of you: look what everybody is doing, what they are doing; go do something completely different. Don't try to improve a little bit on what somebody else is doing, because that doesn't get you very far.In our early days we used to work a lot on rockets, but we also used to have a lot of parties, you know. As you can see, one of our parties, you know, a few years ago. But then a big difference happened about 50 years ago, after Sputnik was launched. We launched the first American satellite, and that's the one you see on the left in there. And here we made 180 degrees change: we changed from a rocket house to be an exploration house. And that was done over a period of a couple of years, and now we are the leading organization, you know, exploring space on all of your behalf.But even when we did that, we had to remind ourselves, sometimes there are setbacks. So you see, on the bottom, that rocket was supposed to go upward; somehow it ended going sideways. So that's what we call the misguided missile. But then also, just to celebrate that, we started an event at JPL for "Miss Guided Missile."So, we used to have a celebration every year and select — there used to be competition and parades and so on. It's not very appropriate to do it now. Some people tell me to do it; I think, well, that's not really proper, you know, these days. So, we do something a little bit more serious. And that's what you see in the last Rose Bowl, you know, when we entered one of the floats. That's more on the play side. And on the right side, that's the Rover just before we finished its testing to take it to the Cape to launch it. These are the Rovers up here that you have on Mars now. So that kind of tells you about, kind of, the fun things, you know, and the serious things that we try to do. But I said I'm going to show you a short clip of one of our employees to kind of give you an idea about some of the talent that we have.Video: Morgan Hendry: Beware of Safety is an instrumental rock band. It branches on more the experimental side. There's the improvisational side of jazz. There's the heavy-hitting sound of rock. Being able to treat sound as an instrument, and be able to dig for more abstract sounds and things to play live, mixing electronics and acoustics. The music's half of me, but the other half — I landed probably the best gig of all. I work for the Jet Propulsion Lab. I'm building the next Mars Rover. Some of the most brilliant engineers I know are the ones who have that sort of artistic quality about them. You've got to do what you want to do. And anyone who tells you you can't, you don't listen to them. Maybe they're right - I doubt it. Tell them where to put it, and then just do what you want to do. I'm Morgan Hendry. I am NASA.Charles Elachi: Now, moving from the play stuff to the serious stuff, always people ask, why do we explore? Why are we doing all of these missions and why are we exploring them? Well, the way I think about it is fairly simple. Somehow, 13 billion years ago there was a Big Bang, and you've heard a little bit about, you know, the origin of the universe. But somehow what strikes everybody's imagination — or lots of people's imagination — somehow from that original Big Bang we have this beautiful world that we live in today.You look outside: you have all that beauty that you see, all that life that you see around you, and here we have intelligent people like you and I who are having a conversation here. All that started from that Big Bang. So, the question is: How did that happen? How did that evolve? How did the universe form? How did the galaxies form? How did the planets form? Why is there a planet on which there is life which have evolved? Is that very common? Is there life on every planet that you can see around the stars? So we literally are all made out of stardust. We started from those stars; we are made of stardust. So, next time you are really depressed, look in the mirror and you can look and say, hi, I'm looking at a star here. You can skip the dust part. But literally, we are all made of stardust.So, what we are trying to do in our exploration is effectively write the book of how things have came about as they are today. And one of the first, or the easiest, places we can go and explore that is to go towards Mars. And the reason Mars takes particular attention: it's not very far from us. You know, it'll take us only six months to get there. Six to nine months at the right time of the year. It's a planet somewhat similar to Earth. It's a little bit smaller, but the land mass on Mars is about the same as the land mass on Earth, you know, if you don't take the oceans into account. It has polar caps. It has an atmosphere somewhat thinner than ours, so it has weather. So, it's very similar to some extent, and you can see some of the features on it, like the Grand Canyon on Mars, or what we call the Grand Canyon on Mars. It is like the Grand Canyon on Earth, except a hell of a lot larger.So it's about the size, you know, of the United States. It has volcanoes on it. And that's Mount Olympus on Mars, which is a kind of huge volcanic shield on that planet. And if you look at the height of it and you compare it to Mount Everest, you see, it'll give you an idea of how large that Mount Olympus, you know, is, relative to Mount Everest. So, it basically dwarfs, you know, Mount Everest here on Earth. So, that gives you an idea of the tectonic events or volcanic events which have happened on that planet. Recently from one of our satellites, this shows that it's Earth-like — we caught a landslide occurring as it was happening. So it is a dynamic planet, and activity is going on as we speak today.And these Rovers, people wonder now, what are they doing today, so I thought I would show you a little bit what they are doing. This is one very large crater. Geologists love craters, because craters are like digging a big hole in the ground without really working at it, and you can see what's below the surface. So, this is called Victoria Crater, which is about a few football fields in size. And if you look at the top left, you see a little teeny dark dot. This picture was taken from an orbiting satellite. If I zoom on it, you can see: that's the Rover on the surface. So, that was taken from orbit; we had the camera zoom on the surface, and we actually saw the Rover on the surface. And we actually used the combination of the satellite images and the Rover to actually conduct science, because we can observe large areas and then you can get those Rovers to move around and basically go to a certain location.So, specifically what we are doing now is that Rover is going down in that crater. As I told you, geologists love craters. And the reason is, many of you went to the Grand Canyon, and you see in the wall of the Grand Canyon, you see these layers. And what these layers — that's what the surface used to be a million years ago, 10 million years ago, 100 million years ago, and you get deposits on top of them. So if you can read the layers it's like reading your book, and you can learn the history of what happened in the past in that location.So what you are seeing here are the layers on the wall of that crater, and the Rover is going down now, measuring, you know, the properties and analyzing the rocks as it's going down, you know, that canyon. Now, it's kind of a little bit of a challenge driving down a slope like this. If you were there you wouldn't do it yourself. But we really made sure we tested those Rovers before we got them down — or that Rover — and made sure that it's all working well.Now, when I came last time, shortly after the landing — I think it was, like, a hundred days after the landing — I told you I was surprised that those Rovers are lasting even a hundred days. Well, here we are four years later, and they're still working. Now you say, Charles, you are really lying to us, and so on, but that's not true. We really believed they were going to last 90 days or 100 days, because they are solar powered, and Mars is a dusty planet, so we expected the dust would start accumulating on the surface, and after a while we wouldn't have enough power, you know, to keep them warm.Well, I always say it's important that you are smart, but every once in a while it's good to be lucky. And that's what we found out. It turned out that every once in a while there are dust devils which come by on Mars, as you are seeing here, and when the dust devil comes over the Rover, it just cleans it up. It is like a brand new car that you have, and that's literally why they have lasted so long. And now we designed them reasonably well, but that's exactly why they are lasting that long and still providing all the science data. Now, the two Rovers, each one of them is, kind of, getting old. You know, one of them, one of the wheels is stuck, is not working, one of the front wheels, so what we are doing, we are driving it backwards. And the other one has arthritis of the shoulder joint, you know, it's not working very well, so it's walking like this, and we can move the arm, you know, that way. But still they are producing a lot of scientific data. Now, during that whole period, a number of people got excited, you know, outside the science community about these Rovers, so I thought I'd show you a video just to give you a reflection about how these Rovers are being viewed by people other than the science community.So let me go on the next short video. By the way, this video is pretty accurate of how the landing took place, you know, about four years ago. Video: Okay, we have parachute aligned. Okay, deploy the airbags. Open. Camera. We have a picture right now. Yeah! CE: That's about what happened in the Houston operation room. It's exactly like this. Video: Now, if there is life, the Dutch will find it. What is he doing? What is that? CE: Not too bad.So anyway, let me continue on showing you a little bit about the beauty of that planet. As I said earlier, it looked very much like Earth, so you see sand dunes. It looks like I could have told you these are pictures taken from the Sahara Desert or somewhere, and you'd have believed me, but these are pictures taken from Mars. But one area which is particularly intriguing for us is the northern region, you know, of Mars, close to the North Pole, because we see ice caps, and we see the ice caps shrinking and expanding, so it's very much like you have in northern Canada. And we wanted to find out — and we see all kinds of glacial features on it. So, we wanted to find out, actually, what is that ice made of, and could that have embedded in it some organic, you know, material.So we have a spacecraft which is heading towards Mars, called Phoenix, and that spacecraft will land 17 days, seven hours and 20 seconds from now, so you can adjust your watch. So it's on May 25 around just before five o'clock our time here on the West Coast, actually we will be landing on another planet. And as you can see, this is a picture of the spacecraft put on Mars, but I thought that just in case you're going to miss that show, you know, in 17 days, I'll show you, kind of, a little bit of what's going to happen.Video: That's what we call the seven minutes of terror. So the plan is to dig in the soil and take samples that we put them in an oven and actually heat them and look what gases will come from it. So this was launched about nine months ago. We'll be coming in at 12,000 miles per hour, and in seven minutes we have to stop and touch the surface very softly so we don't break that lander.Ben Cichy: Phoenix is the first Mars Scout mission. It's the first mission that's going to try to land near the North Pole of Mars, and it's the first mission that's actually going to try and reach out and touch water on the surface of another planet.Lynn Craig: Where there tends to be water, at least on Earth, there tends to be life, and so it's potentially a place where life could have existed on the planet in the past.Erik Bailey: The main purpose of EDL is to take a spacecraft that is traveling at 12,500 miles an hour and bring it to a screeching halt in a soft way in a very short amount of time. BC: We enter the Martian atmosphere. We're 70 miles above the surface of Mars. And our lander is safely tucked inside what we call an aeroshell.EB: Looks kind of like an ice cream cone, more or less.BC: And on the front of it is this heat shield, this saucer-looking thing that has about a half-inch of essentially what's cork on the front of it, which is our heat shield. Now, this is really special cork, and this cork is what's going to protect us from the violent atmospheric entry that we're about to experience.Rob Grover: Friction really starts to build up on the spacecraft, and we use the friction when it's flying through the atmosphere to our advantage to slow us down. BC: From this point, we're going to decelerate from 12,500 miles an hour down to 900 miles an hour.EB: The outside can get almost as hot as the surface of the Sun.RG: The temperature of the heat shield can reach 2,600 degrees Fahrenheit.EB: The inside doesn't get very hot. It probably gets about room temperature. Richard Kornfeld: There is this window of opportunity within which we can deploy the parachute.EB: If you fire the 'chute too early, the parachute itself could fail. The fabric and the stitching could just pull apart. And that would be bad.BC: In the first 15 seconds after we deploy the parachute, we'll decelerate from 900 miles an hour to a relatively slow 250 miles an hour. We no longer need the heat shield to protect us from the force of atmospheric entry, so we jettison the heat shield, exposing for the first time our lander to the atmosphere of Mars.LC: After the heat shield has been jettisoned and the legs are deployed, the next step is to have the radar system begin to detect how far Phoenix really is from the ground.BC: We've lost 99 percent of our entry velocity. So, we're 99 percent of the way to where we want to be. But that last one percent, as it always seems to be, is the tricky part.EB: Now the spacecraft actually has to decide when it's going to get rid of its parachute.BC: We separate from the lander going 125 miles an hour at roughly a kilometer above the surface of Mars: 3,200 feet. That's like taking two Empire State Buildings and stacking them on top of one another.EB: That's when we separate from the back shell, and we're now in free-fall. It's a very scary moment; a lot has to happen in a very short amount of time. LC: So it's in a free-fall, but it's also trying to use all of its actuators to make sure that it's in the right position to land.EB: And then it has to light up its engines, right itself, and then slowly slow itself down and touch down on the ground safely.BC: Earth and Mars are so far apart that it takes over ten minutes for a signal from Mars to get to Earth. And EDL itself is all over in a matter of seven minutes. So by the time you even hear from the lander that EDL has started it'll already be over.EB: We have to build large amounts of autonomy into the spacecraft so that it can land itself safely.BC: EDL is this immense, technically challenging problem. It's about getting a spacecraft that's hurtling through deep space and using all this bag of tricks to somehow figure out how to get it down to the surface of Mars at zero miles an hour. It's this immensely exciting and challenging problem.CE: Hopefully it all will happen the way you saw it in here. So it will be a very tense moment, you know, as we are watching that spacecraft landing on another planet.So now let me talk about the next things that we are doing. So we are in the process, as we speak, of actually designing the next Rover that we are going to be sending to Mars. So I thought I would go a little bit and tell you, kind of, the steps we go through. It's very similar to what you do when you design your product. As you saw a little bit earlier, when we were doing the Phoenix one, we have to take into account the heat that we are going to be facing. So we have to study all kinds of different materials, the shape that we want to do. In general we don't try to please the customer here. What we want to do is to make sure we have an effective, you know, an efficient kind of machine.First we start by we want to have our employees to be as imaginative as they can. And we really love being close to the art center, because we have, as a matter of fact, one of the alumni from the art center, Eric Nyquist, had put a series of displays, far-out displays, you know, in our what we call mission design or spacecraft design room, just to get people to think wildly about things. We have a bunch of Legos. So, as I said, this is a playground for adults, where they sit down and try to play with different shapes and different designs.Then we get a little bit more serious, so we have what we call our CAD/CAMs and all the engineers who are involved, or scientists who are involved, who know about thermal properties, know about design, know about atmospheric interaction, parachutes, all of these things, which they work in a team effort and actually design a spacecraft in a computer to some extent, so to see, does that meet the requirement that we need. On the right, also, we have to take into account the environment of the planet where we are going. If you are going to Jupiter, you have a very high-radiation, you know, environment. It's about the same radiation environment close by Jupiter as inside a nuclear reactor.So just imagine: you take your P.C. and throw it into a nuclear reactor and it still has to work. So these are kind of some of the little challenges, you know, that we have to face. If we are doing entry, we have to do tests of parachutes. You saw in the video a parachute breaking. That would be a bad day, you know, if that happened, so we have to test, because we are deploying this parachute at supersonic speeds. We are coming at extremely high speeds, and we are deploying them to slow us down. So we have to do all kinds of tests. To give you an idea of the size, you know, of that parachute relative to the people standing there.Next step, we go and actually build some kind of test models and actually test them, you know, in the lab at JPL, in what we call our Mars Yard. We kick them, we hit them, we drop them, just to make sure we understand how, where would they break. And then we back off, you know, from that point. And then we actually do the actual building and the flight. And this next Rover that we're flying is about the size of a car. That big shield that you see outside, that's a heat shield which is going to protect it. And that will be basically built over the next year, and it will be launched June a year from now. Now, in that case, because it was a very big Rover, we couldn't use airbags. And I know many of you, kind of, last time afterwards said well, that was a cool thing to have — those airbags. Unfortunately this Rover is, like, ten times the size of the, you know, mass-wise, of the other Rover, or three times the mass. So we can't use airbags. So we have to come up with another ingenious idea of how do we land it. And we didn't want to take it propulsively all the way to the surface because we didn't want to contaminate the surface; we wanted the Rover to immediately land on its legs.So we came up with this ingenious idea, which is used here on Earth for helicopters. Actually, the lander will come down to about 100 feet and hover above that surface for 100 feet, and then we have a sky crane which will take that Rover and land it down on the surface. Hopefully it all will work, you know, it will work that way. And that Rover will be more kind of like a chemist. What we are going to be doing with that Rover as it drives around, it's going to go and analyze the chemical composition of rocks. So it will have an arm which will take samples, put them in an oven, crush and analyze them. But also, if there is something that we cannot reach because it is too high on a cliff, we have a little laser system which will actually zap the rock, evaporate some of it, and actually analyze what's coming from that rock. So it's a little bit like "Star Wars," you know, but it's real. It's real stuff. And also to help you, to help the community so you can do ads on that Rover, we are going to train that Rover to actually in addition to do this, to actually serve cocktails, you know, also on Mars.So that's kind of giving you an idea of the kind of, you know, fun things we are doing on Mars. I thought I'd go to "The Lord of the Rings" now and show you some of the things we have there. Now, "The Lord of the Rings" has two things played through it. One, it's a very attractive planet — it just has the beauty of the rings and so on. But for scientists, also the rings have a special meaning, because we believe they represent, on a small scale, how the Solar System actually formed. Some of the scientists believe that the way the Solar System formed, that the Sun when it collapsed and actually created the Sun, a lot of the dust around it created rings and then the particles in those rings accumulated together, and they formed bigger rocks, and then that's how the planets, you know, were formed.So, the idea is, by watching Saturn we're actually watching our solar system in real time being formed on a smaller scale, so it's like a test bed for it. So, let me show you a little bit on what that Saturnian system looks like. First, I'm going to fly you over the rings. By the way, all of this is real stuff. This is not animation or anything like this. This is actually taken from the satellite that we have in orbit around Saturn, the Cassini. And you see the amount of detail that is in those rings, which are the particles. Some of them are agglomerating together to form larger particles. So that's why you have these gaps, is because a small satellite, you know, is being formed in that location. Now, you think that those rings are very large objects. Yes, they are very large in one dimension; in the other dimension they are paper thin. Very, very thin. What you are seeing here is the shadow of the ring on Saturn itself. And that's one of the satellites which was actually formed on that one. So, think about it as a paper-thin, huge area of many hundreds of thousands of miles, which is rotating.And we have a wide variety of kind of satellites which will form, each one looking very different and very odd, and that keeps scientists busy for tens of years trying to explain this, and telling NASA we need more money so we can explain what these things look like, or why they formed that way. Well, there were two satellites which were particularly interesting. One of them is called Enceladus. It's a satellite which was all made of ice, and we measured it from orbit. Made of ice. But there was something bizarre about it. If you look at these stripes in here, what we call tiger stripes, when we flew over them, all of a sudden we saw an increase in the temperature, which said that those stripes are warmer than the rest of the planet.So as we flew by away from it, we looked back. And guess what? We saw geysers coming out. So this is a Yellowstone, you know, of Saturn. We are seeing geysers of ice which are coming out of that planet, which indicate that most likely there is an ocean, you know, below the surface. And somehow, through some dynamic effect, we're having these geysers which are being, you know, emitted from it. And the reason I showed the little arrow there, I think that should say 30 miles, we decided a few months ago to actually fly the spacecraft through the plume of that geyser so we can actually measure the material that it is made of. That was [unclear] also — you know, because we were worried about the risk of it, but it worked pretty well. We flew at the top of it, and we found that there is a fair amount of organic material which is being emitted in combination with the ice. And over the next few years, as we keep orbiting, you know, Saturn, we are planning to get closer and closer down to the surface and make more accurate measurements.Now, another satellite also attracted a lot of attention, and that's Titan. And the reason Titan is particularly interesting, it's a satellite bigger than our moon, and it has an atmosphere. And that atmosphere is very — as dense as our own atmosphere. So if you were on Titan, you would feel the same pressure that you feel in here. Except it's a lot colder, and that atmosphere is heavily made of methane. Now, methane gets people all excited, because it's organic material, so immediately people start thinking, could life have evolved in that location, when you have a lot of organic material. So people believe now that Titan is most likely what we call a pre-biotic planet, because it's so cold organic material did not get to the stage of becoming biological material, and therefore life could have evolved on it.So it could be Earth, frozen three billion years ago before life actually started on it. So that's getting a lot of interest, and to show you some example of what we did in there, we actually dropped a probe, which was developed by our colleagues in Europe, we dropped a probe as we were orbiting Saturn. We dropped a probe in the atmosphere of Titan. And this is a picture of an area as we were coming down. Just looked like the coast of California for me. You see the rivers which are coming along the coast, and you see that white area which looks like Catalina Island, and that looks like an ocean. And then with an instrument we have on board, a radar instrument, we found there are lakes like the Great Lakes in here, so it looks very much like Earth. It looks like there are rivers on it, there are oceans or lakes, we know there are clouds. We think it's raining also on it. So it's very much like the cycle on Earth except because it's so cold, it could not be water, you know, because water would have frozen. What it turned out, that all that we are seeing, all this liquid, [is made of] hydrocarbon and ethane and methane, similar to what you put in your car.So here we have a cycle of a planet which is like our Earth, but is all made of ethane and methane and organic material. So if you were on Mars — sorry, on Titan, you don't have to worry about four-dollar gasoline. You just drive to the nearest lake, stick your hose in it, and you've got your car filled up. On the other hand, if you light a match the whole planet will blow up. So in closing, I said I want to close by a couple of pictures. And just to kind of put us in perspective, this is a picture of Saturn taken with a spacecraft from behind Saturn, looking towards the Sun. The Sun is behind Saturn, so we see what we call "forward scattering," so it highlights all the rings. And I'm going to zoom. There is a — I'm not sure you can see it very well, but on the top left, around 10 o'clock, there is a little teeny dot, and that's Earth. You barely can see ourselves. So what I did, I thought I'd zoom on it. So as you zoom in, you know, you can see Earth, you know, just in the middle here. So we zoomed all the way on the art center.So thank you very much.
