00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:55.958
I mean, it's a hobby of mine that I've been indulging in for the last few years,

00:01:55.958 --> 00:02:00.958
and it all started out with this picture of the American artist, Donald Baechler

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
I had hanging at home. I had to look at it every day

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:07.958
and after a while I just couldn't stand the mess anymore

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:10.958
this guy was looking at all day long.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.958
Yeah, I kind of felt sorry for him.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
And it seemed to me even he felt really bad

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:19.958
facing these unorganized red squares day after day.

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:21.958
So I decided to give him a little support,

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:26.958
and brought some order into neatly stacking the blocks on top of each other.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:29.958
(Laughter)

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:33.958
Yeah. And I think he looks now less miserable.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:39.958
And it was great. With this experience, I started to look more closely

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:44.958
at modern art. Then I realized how, you know, the world of modern art

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
is particularly topsy-turvy.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
And I can show here a very good example.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:52.958
It's actually a simple one, but it's a good one to start with.

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.958
It's a picture by Paul Klee.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:59.958
And we can see here very clearly, it's a confusion of color.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
(Laughter)

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:07.958
Yeah. The artist doesn't really seem to know where to put the different colors.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.958
The various pictures here of the various elements of the picture --

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:11.958
the whole thing is unstructured.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:15.958
We don't know, maybe Mr. Klee was probably in a hurry, I mean --

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
(Laughter)

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
-- maybe he had to catch a plane, or something.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
We can see here he started out with orange,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
and then he already ran out of orange,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:30.958
and here we can see he decided to take a break for a square.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
And I would like to show you here my tidied up version of this picture.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:38.958
(Laughter)

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:42.958
We can see now what was barely recognizable in the original:

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:49.958
17 red and orange squares are juxtaposed with just two green squares.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:50.958
Yeah, that's great.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:56.958
So I mean, that's just tidying up for beginners.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
I would like to show you here a picture which is a bit more advanced.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:04.958
(Laughter)

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:05.958
What can you say? What a mess.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:12.958
I mean, you see, everything seems to have been scattered aimlessly around the space.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
If my room back home had looked like this,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
my mother would have grounded me for three days.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:22.958
So I'd like to -- I wanted to reintroduce some structure into that picture.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:27.958
And that's really advanced tidying up.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
(Applause)

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
Yeah, you're right. Sometimes people clap at this point,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
but that's actually more in Switzerland.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:40.958
(Laughter)

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:44.958
We Swiss are famous for chocolate and cheese. Our trains run on time.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
We are only happy when things are in order.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:51.958
But to go on, here is a very good example to see.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
This is a picture by Joan Miro.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:59.958
And yeah, we can see the artist has drawn a few lines and shapes

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:03.958
and dropped them any old way onto a yellow background.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
And yeah, it's the sort of thing you produce when you're doodling on the phone.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
(Laughter)

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:10.958
And this is my --

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
(Laughter)

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:17.958
-- you can see now the whole thing takes up far less space.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
It's more economical and also more efficient.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
With this method Mr. Miro could have saved canvas for another picture.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:28.958
But I can see in your faces that you're still a little bit skeptical.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:32.958
So that you can just appreciate how serious I am about all this,

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:37.958
I brought along the patents, the specifications for some of these works,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
because I've had my working methods patented

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:43.958
at the Eidgenössische Amt für Geistiges Eigentum in Bern, Switzerland.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
(Laughter)

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
I'll just quote from the specification.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:52.958
"Laut den Kunstprüfer Dr. Albrecht --"

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
It's not finished yet.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:58.958
"Laut den Kunstprüfer Dr. Albrecht Götz von Ohlenhusen

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:01.958
wird die Verfahrensweise rechtlich geschützt welche die Kunst

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
durch spezifisch aufgeräumte Regelmässigkeiten

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
des allgemeinen Formenschatzes

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
neue Wirkungen zu erzielen möglich wird."

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:14.958
Ja, well I could have translated that, but you would have been none the wiser.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:18.958
I'm not sure myself what it means but it sounds good anyway.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:23.958
I just realized it's important how one introduces new ideas to people,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
that's why these patents are sometimes necessary.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
I would like to do a short test with you.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
Everyone is sitting in quite an orderly fashion here this morning.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:35.958
So I would like to ask you all to raise your right hand. Yeah.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
The right hand is the one we write with, apart from the left-handers.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:43.958
And now, I'll count to three. I mean, it still looks very orderly to me.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
Now, I'll count to three, and on the count of three

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
I'd like you all to shake hands with the person behind you. OK?

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
One, two, three.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:59.958
(Laughter)

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:03.958
You can see now, that's a good example: even behaving in an orderly, systematic way

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
can sometimes lead to complete chaos.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:10.958
So we can also see that very clearly in this next painting.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:15.958
This is a painting by the artist, Niki de Saint Phalle.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:20.958
And I mean, in the original it's completely unclear to see

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:25.958
what this tangle of colors and shapes is supposed to depict.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:30.958
But in the tidied up version, it's plain to see that it's a sunburnt woman playing volleyball.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
(Laughter)

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:41.958
Yeah, it's a -- this one here, that's much better.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
That's a picture by Keith Haring.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:48.958
(Laughter)

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
I think it doesn't matter.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:54.958
So, I mean, this picture has not even got a proper title.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:08:00.958
It's called "Untitled" and I think that's appropriate.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:05.958
So, in the tidied-up version we have a sort of Keith Haring spare parts shop.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
(Laughter)

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
This is Keith Haring looked at statistically.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
One can see here quite clearly,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:17.958
you can see we have 25 pale green elements,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
of which one is in the form of a circle.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:24.958
Or here, for example, we have 27 pink squares with only one pink curve.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:28.958
I mean, that's interesting. One could extend this sort of statistical analysis

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
to cover all Mr. Haring's various works,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:36.958
in order to establish in which period the artist favored pale green circles or pink squares.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:40.958
And the artist himself could also benefit from this sort of listing procedure

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:45.958
by using it to estimate how many pots of paint he's likely to need in the future.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:46.958
(Laughter)

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
One can obviously also make combinations.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:53.958
For example, with the Keith Haring circles and Kandinsky's dots.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
You can add them to all the squares of Paul Klee.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
In the end, one has a list with which one then can arrange.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:02.958
Then you categorize it, then you file it, put that file in a filing cabinet,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:08.958
put it in your office and you can make a living doing it.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
(Laughter)

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
Yeah, from my own experience. So I'm --

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
(Laughter)

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:20.958
Actually, I mean, here we have some artists that are a bit more structured. It's not too bad.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:25.958
This is Jasper Johns. We can see here he was practicing with his ruler.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
(Laughter)

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:31.958
But I think it could still benefit from more discipline.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:35.958
And I think the whole thing adds up much better if you do it like this.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:41.958
(Laughter)

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
And here, that's one of my favorites.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
Tidying up Rene Magritte -- this is really fun.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:48.958
You know, there is a --

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
(Laughter)

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:54.958
I'm always being asked what inspired me to embark on all this.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
It goes back to a time when I was very often staying in hotels.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:01.958
So once I had the opportunity to stay in a ritzy, five-star hotel.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
And you know, there you had this little sign --

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:09.958
I put this little sign outside the door every morning that read,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
"Please tidy room." I don't know if you have them over here.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:18.958
So actually, my room there hasn't been tidied once daily, but three times a day.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
So after a while I decided to have a little fun,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:26.958
and before leaving the room each day I'd scatter a few things around the space.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:30.958
Like books, clothes, toothbrush, etc. And it was great.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:34.958
By the time I returned everything had always been neatly returned to its place.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:42.958
But then one morning, I hang the same little sign onto that picture by Vincent van Gogh.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
(Laughter)

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:50.958
And you have to say this room hadn't been tidied up since 1888.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
And when I returned it looked like this.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:11:00.958
(Laughter)

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
Yeah, at least it is now possible to do some vacuuming.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
(Laughter)

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
OK, I mean, I can see there are always people

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:11.958
that like reacting that one or another picture

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:16.958
hasn't been properly tidied up. So we can make a short test with you.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
This is a picture by Rene Magritte,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:22.958
and I'd like you all to inwardly -- like in your head, that is --

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:28.958
to tidy that up. So it's possible that some of you would make it like this.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
(Laughter)

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:35.958
Yeah? I would actually prefer to do it more this way.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.958
Some people would make apple pie out of it.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
But it's a very good example to see that the whole work

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:46.958
was more of a handicraft endeavor that involved the very time-consuming job

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:52.958
of cutting out the various elements and sticking them back in new arrangements.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
And it's not done, as many people imagine, with the computer,

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:59.958
otherwise it would look like this.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:04.958
(Laughter)

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:10.958
So now I've been able to tidy up pictures that I've wanted to tidy up for a long time.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
Here is a very good example. Take Jackson Pollock, for example.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:18.958
It's -- oh, no, it's -- that's a really hard one.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:23.958
But after a while, I just decided here to go all the way

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
and put the paint back into the cans.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:36.958
(Applause)

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:41.958
Or you could go into three-dimensional art.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:46.958
Here we have the fur cup by Meret Oppenheim.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
Here I just brought it back to its original state.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:57.958
(Laughter)

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:02.958
But yeah, and it's great, you can even go, you know --

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:08.958
Or we have this pointillist movement for those of you who are into art.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
The pointillist movement is that kind of paintings

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
where everything is broken down into dots and pixels.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:18.958
And then I -- this sort of thing is ideal for tidying up.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
(Laughter)

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:25.958
So I once applied myself to the work of the inventor of that method, Georges Seurat,

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
and I collected together all his dots.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
And now they're all in here.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:34.958
(Laughter)

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:35.958
You can count them afterwards, if you like.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:40.958
You see, that's the wonderful thing about the tidy up art idea:

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
it's new. So there is no existing tradition in it.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:47.958
There is no textbooks, I mean, not yet, anyway.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:51.958
I mean, it's "the future we will create."

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
(Laughter)

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:58.958
But to round things up I would like to show you just one more.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
This is the village square by Pieter Bruegel.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
That's how it looks like when you send everyone home.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:15.958
(Laughter)

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
Yeah, maybe you're asking yourselves

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:21.958
where old Bruegel's people went?

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:25.958
Of course, they're not gone. They're all here.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:26.958
(Laughter)

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
I just piled them up.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:32.958
(Laughter)

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:36.958
So I'm -- yeah, actually I'm kind of finished at that moment.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:41.958
And for those who want to see more, I've got my book downstairs in the bookshop.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
And I'm happy to sign it for you with any name of any artist.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
(Laughter)

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:53.958
But before leaving I would like to show you,

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:58.958
I'm working right now on another -- in a related field

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
with my tidying up art method. I'm working in a related field.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:07.958
And I started to bring some order into some flags.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:14.958
Here -- that's just my new proposal here for the Union Jack.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:19.958
(Laughter)

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:24.958
And then maybe before I leave you ...

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:28.958
yeah, I think, after you have seen that I have to leave anyway.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
(Laughter)

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:37.958
Yeah, that was a hard one. I couldn't find a way to tidy that up properly,

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:41.958
so I just decided to make it a little bit more simpler.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
(Laughter)

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:44.958
Thank you very much.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:45.958
(Applause)

title: The Long Now
transcript: Welcome to 10,000 feet. Let me explain why we are here and why some of you have a pine cone close to you. Once upon a time, I did a book called "How Buildings Learn." Today's event you might call "How Mountains Teach." A little background: For 10 years I've been trying to figure out how to hack civilization so that we can get long-term thinking to be automatic and common instead of difficult and rare — or in some cases, non-existent. It would be helpful if humanity got into the habit of thinking of the now not just as next week or next quarter, but you know, next 10,000 years and the last 10,000 years — basically civilization's story so far.So we have the Long Now Foundation in San Francisco. It's an incubator for about a dozen projects, all having to do with continuity over the long term. Our core project is a rather ambitious folly — I suppose, a mythic undertaking: to build a 10,000-year clock that can really keep good time for that long a period. And the design problems of a project like that are just absolutely delicious. Go to the clock. And what we have here is something many of you saw here three years ago. It's the first working prototype of the clock. It's about nine feet high. Designed by Danny Hillis and Alexander Rose. It's presently in London, and is ticking away very deliberately at the science museum there.So the design problem for today is going to be, how do you house an eventual monumental clock like this so it can really tick, save time beautifully for 100 centuries? Well, this was the first solution. Alexander Rose came up with this idea of a spiraloid tower with continuous sloping ramps. And it looked like a way to go, until you start thinking about, what does deep time do to a building? Well, this is what deep time does to a building. This is the Parthenon. It's only 2,450 years old, and look what happened to it. Here's a beautiful project. They really knew it'd last forever, because they'd build it out of absolutely huge stones. And now it's a pathetic ruin and no one even knows what it was used for. That's what happens to buildings. They're vulnerable. Even the most durable and intactable buildings, like the pyramids of Giza, are in bad shape when you look up close. They've been looted inside and out. And they're built to protect things but they don't protect things.So we got to thinking, if you can't put things safely in a building, where can you safely put them? We thought, OK, underground. How about underground with a view? Underground in a place that's really solid. So the obvious answer was, we need a mountain. You don't want just any mountain. You need absolutely the right mountain if you're going to have a clock for 10,000 years. So here's an image of the long view of the search problem. And we got to thinking for various reasons it ought to be a desert mountain, so we got looking in the dry areas of the Southwest. We looked at mesas in New Mexico. We were looking at dead volcanoes in Arizona.Then Roger Kennedy, who was the director of the National Parks Service, led us to Eastern Nevada, to America's newest and oldest national park, which is called Great Basin National Park. It's right on the eastern border of Nevada. It's the highest range in the state — over 13,000 feet. And you'll notice that on the left, on the left, on the west, it's very steep, and on the right it's gentle. This place is remote. It's over 200 miles from any major city. It's nowhere near any Interstate or railroad. And it's — the only thing that goes by is what's called America's loneliest highway, U.S. 50.Now, inside the yellow line here, on the right is — that's all national park. Inside the green line is national forest. And then over to the left is Bureau of Land Management land and some private land. Now, as it happened, that two-mile-long strip right in the middle, this vertical, was available because it was private land. And thanks to Jay Walker who was here and Mitch Kapor who was here, who started the process, Long Now was able to get that two-mile-long strip of land. And now let's look at the grand truth of what's there.We're in Pole Canyon, looking west up the western escarpment of Mount Washington, which is 11,600 feet on top. Those white cliffs are a dense Cambrian limestone. That's a 2,000-foot thick formation, and it might be a beautiful place to hide a clock. It would be a pilgrimage to get to it; it would be a serious hike to get up to where the clock is. So last June, the Long Now board, some staff and some donors and advisors, made a two-week expedition to the mountain to explore it and investigate, one, if it's the right mountain, and two, if it's the right mountain, how it might actually work for us.Now Danny Hillis sort of framed the problem. He has a theory of how the overall clock experience should work. It's what he calls the seven stages of a mythic adventure. It starts with the image. The image is a picture you have in your mind of the goal at the end of the journey. In this case it might well be an image of the clock. Then there's the point of embarkation, that is, the point of transition from ordinary life to being a pilgrim on a quest. Then — this is a nice image of it, there's the labyrinth. The labyrinth is a concept, it's like a twilight zone, it's a place where it's difficult, where you get disoriented, maybe you get scared — but you have to go through it if you're going to get to some kind of deep reintegration. Then there should always be in sight the draw — a kind of a beacon that draws you on through the labyrinth to finish the process of getting there.Now Brian Eno, who's been in the thick of the Long Now process, spent two years making a C.D. called "January 7003," and it's "Bell Studies for the Clock of the Long Now." Based on — parts of it are based on an algorithm that Danny Hillis developed, so that a peal of 10 bells makes a different peal every day for 10,000 years. The Hillis algorithm. 10 factorial gives you that number. And in fact, pretty soon we'll hear the sound. January 7003. There it is.OK, back to Danny's list. Number five of the seven is the payoff. This is it. The climax. The goal. The main thing that you're trying to get to. And then Danny says a really great journey will have a secret payoff. Something you didn't expect that caps what you did expect. Then there's the return. You've got to have a gradual return to the ordinary world, so you have time to assimilate what you've learned. And then, how about a memento? Number seven. At the end of it there's something physical, a kind of reward that you take away. It might be a piece of a core drill of the mountain. Something that's just yours. How do you study a mountain for the kinds of things we're talking about? This is not a normal building project. What do you look for? What are the elements that will most affect your ideas and decisions?Start with borders. If you look on the left side of the cliffs here, that's national park. That's sacrosanct — you can't do anything with that. To the right of it is national forest. There's possibilities. The borders are important. Other elements were mines, weather, approaches and elevation. And especially trees. Look at those things up on top there. It turns out that Mount Washington is covered with bristlecone pines. They're the world's oldest living thing. People think they're just the size of shrubs, but that's not actually true. There are trees on that mountain that are 5,000 years old and still living. The wood is so solid it's like stone, and it lasts for a long time. So when you do tree ring studies of trunks that are on the mountain, some of them go back 10,000 years. The stone itself is absolutely beautiful, sculpted by millennia of very tough winters up there. We had tree ring analysts from the University of Arizona join us on the expedition.Now, if you guys have a pine cone handy, now's a good time to put it in your hand and feel it, especially on the end. That's interesting. You'll find out why it's called a bristlecone pine. A little sensory experience. Here's Danny Hillis in the midst of a bristlecone pine forest on Long Now land. I should say that the age of bristlecones was discovered, led by a theory. Edmund Schulman in the 1950s had been studying trees under great stress at Timberline, and came to the realization that he put in an article in Science magazine called, "Longevity under Adversity in Conifers." And then, based on that principle, he started looking around at the various trees at Timberline, and realized that the bristlecone pines — he found some in the White Mountains that were over 4,000 years old. Longevity under adversity is a pretty interesting design principle in its own right.OK, onto the mines. The first asking price for the property when we looked at it in 1998 was one billion dollars for 180 acres and a couple of mines. Because the owner said, "There's one billion dollars of beryllium in that mountain." And we said, "Wow, that's great. Listen, we'll counter. How about zero?(Laughter)And we're a non-profit foundation, you can give us the property and take a hell of a tax deduction.(Laughter)All you have to do is prove to the government it's worth a billion dollars."Well, a few years went by and there was some kind of back and forth, and by and by, thanks to Mitch and Jay, we were able to buy the whole property for 140,000 dollars. This is one of the mines. It doesn't have any beryllium in it. It's called the Pole Adit. And it does have tungsten, a little bit of tungsten, left over, that's the kind of mine it was. But it goes a mile-and-a-half in a straight line, due east into the range, into very interesting territory — except that, as you'll see when we go inside in a minute, we were hoping for limestone but in there is just shale. And shale is not quite completely competent rock. Competent rock is rock that will hold itself up without any shoring. The shale would like some shoring, and so parts of it are caved in in there.That's Ben Roberts from — he's the bat specialist from the National Park. But there are many wonders back in there, like this weird fungus on some of the collapsed timbers. OK, here's another mine that's up on top of the property, and it dates back to 1870. That's what the property was originally built around — it was a set of mining claims. It was a very productive silver mine. In fact, it was the highest-operating mine in Nevada, and it ran year round. You can imagine what it was like in the winter at 10,000 feet. You may recognize a couple of the miners there. There's Jeff Bezos on the right and Paul Saville on the left looking for galena, which is the lead-silver thing. They didn't find any. They both kept their day jobs. Here's the last mine.It's called the Bonanza Adit. It's down in a canyon. And Alexander Rose on the left there worked with a bunch of people from the National Park to survey the whole mine. It's a mile deep. And they also found four species of bats in there. Now, almost all those mines, by the way, meet underneath the mountain. They don't quite, but it's something to think about. They don't quite meet. Let's go to weather. Mountains specialize in interesting weather. Way more interesting than Monterey even today.And so one Tuesday morning last June, there we were. Woke up in the morning — the mountain was covered with snow. That was a great time to go up and visit our weather station which again, thanks to Mitch Kapor, we're building up there. And it's a pretty interesting scene. This is, on the left there, the joyful lady is Pat Irwin, who's the regional head of the National Forest Service, and they gave us the temporary use permit to be there. We want a temporary use permit for the clock, eventually — 10,000-year temporary use permit.(Laughter)The weather station's pretty interesting. Kurt Bollacker and Alexander Rose designed a radically wireless station. It runs on solar, and it sends a signal with that antenna and bounces it off of micrometeorite trails in the atmosphere to a place in Bozeman, Montana, where the data is taken down and then sent through landlines to San Francisco, where we put the data in real time up on our website. And there you see a week of weather at 9,400 feet on Mount Washington. Let's go to approaches. As it happens, there are no trails anywhere on Mount Washington, just a few old mining roads like this, so you have to bushwhack everywhere. But there's no bears, and there's no poison oak, and there's basically no people because this place has been empty for a long time. You can hike for days and not encounter anybody.Well, here's a potential approach. You need to come up the Lincoln Canyon. It's this beautiful world all of its own, surrounded by cliffs, and it's an easy hike to stroll up the canyon bottom, until you get to this barrier, and it actually presents a problem. So you can scratch Lincoln Canyon as an approach. Another possible approach is right up the western front of the mountain. You can see why we sometimes call it Long Mountain. And from where you're standing at 6,000 feet in the valley, it's an easy hike up to the mature pinyon and juniper forest through that knoll at the front at 7,600 feet. And you can carry right on up through meadows and steepening forest to the high base of the cliffs at 10,500 feet, where there's a bit of a problem.Now, Jeff Bezos advised us when he left at the end of the expedition, "Make the clock inaccessible. The harder it is to get to, the more people will value it." And check — those are 600-foot vertical walls there. So Alexander Rose wanted to explore this route, and he started over here on the left from his pickup truck at 8,900 feet and headed up the mountain. Now, as you gain elevation your IQ goes down —(Laughter)but your emotional affect goes up, which is great for having a mythic experience, whether you want to or not. In fact, Danny Hillis can estimate altitude by how much math he can't do in his head.(Laughter)Now, I happened to be on the radio with Alexander when he got to this point at the base of the cliffs, and he said, quote, "There's a hidden notch. I think I can get up a ways." Now, he's a rock climber, but you know, he's our executive director. I don't want him killed. I know he's going to love cliffs. I'm saying, "Be careful, be careful, be careful." Then he starts going up, and the next thing I hear is, "I'm half-way up. It's like climbing stairs. I'm going up 60 degrees. It's a secret passage. It's like something from Tolkien." And I'm going, "Careful, careful. Please be careful." And then, of course, the next thing I hear is, "I've made it to the top. You can see all of creation from up here." And he dashed across the top of the mountains.In fact, there he is. That's Alexander Rose. First ascent of the western face to Mount Washington, and a solo ascent at that. This discovery changed everything about our sense of these cliffs and what to do with them. We realized that we had to name this thing that Alexander discovered. How about Zander's Crevice? No.(Laughter)So we finally decided on Alexander's Siq. Zander's Siq is named after — some of you have been to Petra, there's this wonderful slot canyon that leads into Petra called the Siq, and so this is the Siq. And it really is hidden. I can't find it in this image, and I'm not sure you can. Only when you get fresh snow can you see just along the rim there, and that brings it out.Now, Danny and I were up at this same area one day, and Danny looked over to the right and noticed something halfway up the cliffs, which is a kind of a porch or a cliff shelf with bristlecones on it, and supposed that people going up to the clock inside the mountain could come out onto that shelf and look down at the view. And the people toiling up the mountain could see them, these tiny little people up there, incredibly halfway up the cliff. How did they get there? Do I have to do that? And so that maybe becomes part of the draw and part of the labyrinth. You can get another angle on Danny's porch by going around to the south and looking north at the whole formation there. And you need to know that Danny's clock is to be kept accurate by a ray of sunshine, that perfect noon hitting it every sunny day, and the pulse of heat from that sets off a solar trigger which resets the clock to make it perfectly accurate. So even with the slowing of the rotation of the earth and so on, the clock will keep perfectly good time.So here we're looking from the south, look north. This is all Forest Service land. If you go up on top of those cliffs, that's some of the Long Now land in those trees. And if you go up there and look back, then you'll get a sense of what the view starts to be like from the top of the mountain. That's the long view. That's 80 miles to the horizon. And that's also timberline and those bristlecones really are shrubs. That's a different place to be. It's 11,400 feet and it's exquisite. Now, if you go over to the right from this image to looking at the edge of the cliffs, it's 600 foot, just about a yard to the left of Kurt Bollacker's foot, there is a 600-foot drop. He's ambling on over to Zander's Siq. That's what it looks like looking down it. We should probably put in a rail or something. Over on the eastern side it's gentle, as you can see. And that's not snow — that's what the white limestone looks like. You also see there a bighorn sheep. Their herd was reintroduced from Wyoming. And they're doing pretty well, but they've got a bit of trouble.This is Danny Hillis, and he's figuring out a design problem. he's trying to determine if where he is on a bit of Long Now land would appear from down in the valley to be the actual peak of the mountain. because the real peak is hidden around the corner. This is what in the infantry we used to call the military crest. And as it turned out the answer is, yes, that is from down below in the valley it does look like the peak, and that might be conjured with. We gradually realized we have three serious design domains to work on with this. One is the experience of the mountain. Another is the experience in the mountain. And the third is the experience from the mountain, which is really dominated by the view shed of the spring valley there behind Danny, and if you look off to the right, out there, 15 miles across to the Schell Creek range.In the front, there are 10 ranches strung right along the base of the mountains using the water from the mountains. In fact, there are artesian wells where water springs right into the air. One of the ranches is called the Kirkeby Ranch, and I'll take you there for a minute. It's a very nice ranch. Alfalfa and cattle, run by Paul and Ronnie Brenham, and it's pretty idyllic. It's also hard work. And most of these ranches are having trouble keeping going. This is their view to the west of the Schell Creek range. And if you go out to that line of trees at the far end, you'll see what the valley used to look like. This is Rocky Mountain junipers that have been there for thousands of years.And a scheme emerged that Long Now is looking to see if it might be possible to buy up the whole valley, because those 10 ranches with their 17,000 acres dominate a 500 square mile valley with their grazing allotments and so on, and there's a possibility that you could get the whole thing for five million dollars and gradually restore it to its wild condition, and somewhere in the process turn it back over to the National Park, and it would double the size of Great Basin National Park. That would be swell.OK, let's take one more look at the mountain itself. The clock experience should be profound, but from the outside it should be invisible. Now, at the base of the high cliffs there's this natural cave. It's only about 12 feet deep, but what if it were deepened from inside? You excavated from somewhere, came up from inside and deepened it. And then you could have an entrance which was very rough and narrow as you first went in, that gradually becomes more refined and then actually quite exquisite. And this stone takes a perfect polish. You'd have a polished set of passages and chambers in there eventually leading to the 10,000 year clock.And it's not a mine. This would be a nuanced evocation of the basic structure of the mountain, and you would be appreciating it as much from inside as you do from outside. This is architecture not made by building, but by what you very carefully take away. So that's what the mountain taught us. Most of the amazingness of the clock we can borrow from the amazingness of the mountain. All we have to do is highlight its spectacular features and blend in with them. It's not a clock in a mountain — it's a mountain clock. Now, the Tewa Indians in the Southwest have a saying for what you need to do when you want to think long term about anything. They say, "pin peya obe" — welcome to the mountain.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
Welcome to 10,000 feet.

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:15.958
Let me explain why we are here

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:19.958
and why some of you have a pine cone close to you.

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
Once upon a time, I did a book called "How Buildings Learn."

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:26.958
Today's event you might call "How Mountains Teach."

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:28.958
A little background: For 10 years I've been trying to figure out how to

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:33.958
hack civilization so that we can get long-term thinking

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:37.958
to be automatic and common instead of difficult and rare --

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:40.958
or in some cases, non-existent.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:45.958
It would be helpful if humanity got into the habit of thinking

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:49.958
of the now not just as next week or next quarter, but you know,

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:53.958
next 10,000 years and the last 10,000 years --

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:57.958
basically civilization's story so far.

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
So we have the Long Now Foundation in San Francisco.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
It's an incubator for about a dozen projects,

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:05.958
all having to do with continuity over the long term.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:10.958
Our core project is a rather ambitious folly --

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:15.958
I suppose, a mythic undertaking: to build a 10,000-year clock

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:20.958
that can really keep good time for that long a period.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:27.958
And the design problems of a project like that are just absolutely delicious.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:32.958
Go to the clock. And what we have here is something

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
many of you saw here three years ago.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
It's the first working prototype of the clock.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:37.958
It's about nine feet high.

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:42.958
Designed by Danny Hillis and Alexander Rose. It's presently in London,

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:46.958
and is ticking away very deliberately at the science museum there.

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:50.958
So the design problem for today is going to be,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:54.958
how do you house an eventual monumental clock like this

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:59.958
so it can really tick, save time beautifully for 100 centuries?

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
Well, this was the first solution.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:03.958
Alexander Rose came up with this idea

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:08.958
of a spiraloid tower with continuous sloping ramps.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:10.958
And it looked like a way to go, until you start thinking

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.958
about, what does deep time do to a building?

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
Well, this is what deep time does to a building.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:20.958
This is the Parthenon. It's only 2,450 years old,

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:21.958
and look what happened to it.

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:24.958
Here's a beautiful project. They really knew it'd last forever,

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:28.958
because they'd build it out of absolutely huge stones.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:31.958
And now it's a pathetic ruin and no one even knows what it was used for.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
That's what happens to buildings. They're vulnerable.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
Even the most durable and intactable buildings,

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:41.958
like the pyramids of Giza, are in bad shape when you look up close.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:44.958
They've been looted inside and out.

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.958
And they're built to protect things but they don't protect things.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:51.958
So we got to thinking, if you can't put things safely in a building,

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.958
where can you safely put them? We thought, OK, underground.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:57.958
How about underground with a view?

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
Underground in a place that's really solid.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:03.958
So the obvious answer was, we need a mountain.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
You don't want just any mountain.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
You need absolutely the right mountain

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
if you're going to have a clock for 10,000 years.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:15.958
So here's an image of the long view of the search problem.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:19.958
And we got to thinking for various reasons it ought to be a desert mountain,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
so we got looking in the dry areas of the Southwest.

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
We looked at mesas in New Mexico.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
We were looking at dead volcanoes in Arizona.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
Then Roger Kennedy, who was the director of the National Parks Service,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
led us to Eastern Nevada,

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
to America's newest and oldest national park,

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:39.958
which is called Great Basin National Park.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
It's right on the eastern border of Nevada.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:46.958
It's the highest range in the state -- over 13,000 feet.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:50.958
And you'll notice that on the left, on the left, on the west, it's very steep,

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:53.958
and on the right it's gentle.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:57.958
This place is remote. It's over 200 miles from any major city.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
It's nowhere near any Interstate or railroad.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:04.958
And it's -- the only thing that goes by is what's called

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:08.958
America's loneliest highway, U.S. 50.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:13.958
Now, inside the yellow line here, on the right is -- that's all national park.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
Inside the green line is national forest.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:20.958
And then over to the left is Bureau of Land Management land and some private land.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
Now, as it happened, that two-mile-long strip right in the middle,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:29.958
this vertical, was available because it was private land.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:33.958
And thanks to Jay Walker who was here and Mitch Kapor who was here,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:39.958
who started the process, Long Now was able to get that two-mile-long strip of land.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
And now let's look at the grand truth of what's there.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:46.958
We're in Pole Canyon, looking west up the western escarpment

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:51.958
of Mount Washington, which is 11,600 feet on top.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
Those white cliffs are a dense Cambrian limestone.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
That's a 2,000-foot thick formation,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:02.958
and it might be a beautiful place to hide a clock.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
It would be a pilgrimage to get to it; it would be a serious hike

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
to get up to where the clock is.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:13.958
So last June, the Long Now board, some staff and some donors

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:18.958
and advisors, made a two-week expedition to the mountain

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:23.958
to explore it and investigate, one, if it's the right mountain,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:27.958
and two, if it's the right mountain, how it might actually work for us.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
Now Danny Hillis sort of framed the problem.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
He has a theory of how the overall clock experience should work.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:37.958
It's what he calls the seven stages of a mythic adventure.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:41.958
It starts with the image. The image is a picture you have in your mind

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
of the goal at the end of the journey.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
In this case it might well be an image of the clock.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:50.958
Then there's the point of embarkation, that is, the point of transition

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:54.958
from ordinary life to being a pilgrim on a quest.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:58.958
Then -- this is a nice image of it, there's the labyrinth.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.958
The labyrinth is a concept, it's like a twilight zone,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
it's a place where it's difficult, where you get disoriented,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
maybe you get scared -- but you have to go through it

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
if you're going to get to some kind of deep reintegration.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:15.958
Then there should always be in sight the draw --

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
a kind of a beacon that draws you on through the labyrinth

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
to finish the process of getting there.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
Now Brian Eno, who's been in the thick of the Long Now process,

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:29.958
spent two years making a C.D. called "January 7003,"

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
and it's "Bell Studies for the Clock of the Long Now."

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:37.958
Based on -- parts of it are based on an algorithm that Danny Hillis developed,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
so that a peal of 10 bells

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:43.958
makes a different peal every day for 10,000 years.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:47.958
The Hillis algorithm. 10 factorial gives you that number.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
And in fact, pretty soon we'll hear the sound.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:54.958
January 7003. There it is.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
OK, back to Danny's list.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:00.958
Number five of the seven is the payoff. This is it. The climax.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
The goal. The main thing that you're trying to get to.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:08.958
And then Danny says a really great journey will have a secret payoff.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:12.958
Something you didn't expect that caps what you did expect.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
Then there's the return.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
You've got to have a gradual return to the ordinary world,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:21.958
so you have time to assimilate what you've learned. 


00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:25.958
And then, how about a memento? Number seven.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:26.958
At the end of it there's something physical,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
a kind of reward that you take away.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
It might be a piece of a core drill of the mountain.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
Something that's just yours.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
How do you study a mountain

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
for the kinds of things we're talking about?

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
This is not a normal building project.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:41.958
What do you look for?

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:47.958
What are the elements that will most affect your ideas and decisions?

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
Start with borders. If you look on the left side of the cliffs here,

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
that's national park. That's sacrosanct --

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
you can't do anything with that. To the right of it is national forest.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
There's possibilities. The borders are important.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:06.958
Other elements were mines, weather, approaches and elevation.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
And especially trees. Look at those things up on top there.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:13.958
It turns out that Mount Washington is covered with bristlecone pines.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
They're the world's oldest living thing.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:21.958
People think they're just the size of shrubs, but that's not actually true.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:28.958
There are trees on that mountain that are 5,000 years old and still living.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:33.958
The wood is so solid it's like stone, and it lasts for a long time.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:37.958
So when you do tree ring studies of trunks that are on the mountain,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
some of them go back 10,000 years.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
The stone itself is absolutely beautiful,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:46.958
sculpted by millennia of very tough winters up there.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
We had tree ring analysts from the University of Arizona

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
join us on the expedition.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
Now, if you guys have a pine cone handy,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:58.958
now's a good time to put it in your hand and feel it, especially on the end.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
That's interesting.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:06.958
You'll find out why it's called a bristlecone pine. A little sensory experience. 


00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:11.958
Here's Danny Hillis in the midst of a bristlecone pine forest

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:16.958
on Long Now land. I should say that the age of bristlecones

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
was discovered, led by a theory.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
Edmund Schulman in the 1950s

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.958
had been studying trees under great stress at Timberline,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
and came to the realization that he put in an article in Science magazine

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:34.958
called, "Longevity under Adversity in Conifers."

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
And then, based on that principle, he started looking around

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
at the various trees at Timberline,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
and realized that the bristlecone pines --

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:46.958
he found some in the White Mountains that were over 4,000 years old.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:51.958
Longevity under adversity is a pretty interesting design principle in its own right. 


00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
OK, onto the mines. The first asking price for the property

00:09:55.958 --> 00:10:05.958
when we looked at it in 1998 was one billion dollars for 180 acres and a couple of mines.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:09.958
Because the owner said, "There's one billion dollars of beryllium in that mountain."

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:14.958
And we said, "Wow, that's great. Listen, we'll counter. How about zero?

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
(Laughter)

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:20.958
And we're a non-profit foundation, you can give us the property

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
and take a hell of a tax deduction.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
(Laughter)

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
All you have to do is prove to the government it's worth a billion dollars."

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
Well, a few years went by and there was some kind of back and forth,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
and by and by, thanks to Mitch and Jay,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:38.958
we were able to buy the whole property for 140,000 dollars.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:42.958
This is one of the mines. It doesn't have any beryllium in it.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:46.958
It's called the Pole Adit. And it does have tungsten,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
a little bit of tungsten, left over, that's the kind of mine it was.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
But it goes a mile-and-a-half in a straight line,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:57.958
due east into the range, into very interesting territory -- except that,

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
as you'll see when we go inside in a minute,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:04.958
we were hoping for limestone but in there is just shale.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
And shale is not quite completely competent rock.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:11.958
Competent rock is rock that will hold itself up without any shoring.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
The shale would like some shoring,

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
and so parts of it are caved in in there.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:19.958
That's Ben Roberts from -- he's the bat specialist from the National Park.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:23.958
But there are many wonders back in there, like this weird fungus

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
on some of the collapsed timbers.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:29.958
OK, here's another mine that's up on top of the property,

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
and it dates back to 1870.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
That's what the property was originally built around --

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:38.958
it was a set of mining claims. It was a very productive silver mine.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
In fact, it was the highest-operating mine in Nevada,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
and it ran year round.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
You can imagine what it was like in the winter at 10,000 feet.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
You may recognize a couple of the miners there.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:55.958
There's Jeff Bezos on the right and Paul Saville on the left looking for galena, 


00:11:55.958 --> 00:12:00.958
which is the lead-silver thing. They didn't find any.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:05.958
They both kept their day jobs. Here's the last mine.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
It's called the Bonanza Adit. It's down in a canyon.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
And Alexander Rose on the left there worked with a bunch of people

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
from the National Park to survey the whole mine. It's a mile deep.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
And they also found four species of bats in there.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:21.958
Now, almost all those mines, by the way, meet underneath the mountain.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
They don't quite, but it's something to think about.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
They don't quite meet.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:32.958
Let's go to weather. Mountains specialize in interesting weather.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
Way more interesting than Monterey even today.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
And so one Tuesday morning last June, there we were.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
Woke up in the morning -- the mountain was covered with snow.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:45.958
That was a great time to go up and visit our weather station which again,

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
thanks to Mitch Kapor, we're building up there.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
And it's a pretty interesting scene.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
This is, on the left there, the joyful lady is Pat Irwin,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
who's the regional head of the National Forest Service,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:01.958
and they gave us the temporary use permit to be there.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
We want a temporary use permit for the clock, eventually --

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
10,000-year temporary use permit.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
(Laughter)

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
The weather station's pretty interesting.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:13.958
Kurt Bollacker and Alexander Rose designed a radically wireless station.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
It runs on solar, and it sends a signal
with that antenna

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:22.958
and bounces it off of micrometeorite trails in the atmosphere

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:26.958
to a place in Bozeman, Montana, where the data is taken down

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
and then sent through landlines to San Francisco,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:33.958
where we put the data in real time up on our website.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:39.958
And there you see a week of weather at 9,400 feet on Mount Washington.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
Let's go to approaches.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:46.958
As it happens, there are no trails anywhere on Mount Washington,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
just a few old mining roads like this,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:49.958
so you have to bushwhack everywhere.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:53.958
But there's no bears, and there's no poison oak,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:59.958
and there's basically no people because this place has been empty for a long time. 


00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
You can hike for days and not encounter anybody.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
Well, here's a potential approach.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
You need to come up the Lincoln Canyon.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
It's this beautiful world all of its own, surrounded by cliffs,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
and it's an easy hike to stroll up the canyon bottom,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:21.958
until you get to this barrier, and it actually presents a problem.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:26.958
So you can scratch Lincoln Canyon as an approach.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
Another possible approach is right up the western front of the mountain.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
You can see why we sometimes call it Long Mountain.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
And from where you're standing at 6,000 feet in the valley,

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
it's an easy hike up to the mature pinyon and juniper forest

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
through that knoll at the front at 7,600 feet.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
And you can carry right on up through meadows

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:48.958
and steepening forest to the high base of the cliffs at 10,500 feet,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
where there's a bit of a problem.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:56.958
Now, Jeff Bezos advised us when he left at the end of the expedition,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:00.958
"Make the clock inaccessible.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:04.958
The harder it is to get to, the more people will value it."

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:09.958
And check -- those are 600-foot vertical walls there.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:14.958
So Alexander Rose wanted to explore this route,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.958
and he started over here on the left from his pickup truck

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
at 8,900 feet and headed up the mountain.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:25.958
Now, as you gain elevation your IQ goes down --

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
(Laughter)

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
but your emotional affect goes up,

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
which is great for having a mythic experience,


00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
whether you want to or not.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
In fact, Danny Hillis can estimate altitude

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
by how much math he can't do in his head.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
(Laughter)

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
Now, I happened to be on the radio with Alexander

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:50.958
when he got to this point at the base of the cliffs, and he said, quote, 


00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:55.958
"There's a hidden notch. I think I can get up a ways."

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:59.958
Now, he's a rock climber, but you know, he's our executive director.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
I don't want him killed. I know he's going to love cliffs.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
I'm saying, "Be careful, be careful, be careful."

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
Then he starts going up, and the next thing I hear is,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:13.958
"I'm half-way up. It's like climbing stairs. I'm going up 60 degrees.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:17.958
It's a secret passage. It's like something from Tolkien."

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:20.958
And I'm going, "Careful, careful. Please be careful."

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:21.958
And then, of course, the next thing I hear is,

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
"I've made it to the top. You can see all of creation from up here."

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
And he dashed across the top of the mountains.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
In fact, there he is. That's Alexander Rose.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
First ascent of the western face to Mount Washington,

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:36.958
and a solo ascent at that.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
This discovery changed everything about our sense of these cliffs

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
and what to do with them.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:45.958
We realized that we had to name this thing that Alexander discovered.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:49.958
How about Zander's Crevice? No.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:53.958
(Laughter)

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.958
So we finally decided on Alexander's Siq.

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
Zander's Siq is named after -- some of you have been to Petra,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:03.958
there's this wonderful slot canyon that leads into Petra

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
called the Siq, and so this is the Siq.

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
And it really is hidden. I can't find it in this image,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:09.958
and I'm not sure you can.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:13.958
Only when you get fresh snow can you see just along the rim there,

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
and that brings it out.

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:17.958
Now, Danny and I were up at this same area one day,

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:19.958
and Danny looked over to the right

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:22.958
and noticed something halfway up the cliffs,

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:26.958
which is a kind of a porch or a cliff shelf with bristlecones on it,

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:30.958
and supposed that people going up to the clock inside the mountain

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:34.958
could come out onto that shelf and look down at the view.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:37.958
And the people toiling up the mountain could see them,

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:40.958
these tiny little people up there, incredibly halfway up the cliff.

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:43.958
How did they get there? Do I have to do that?

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:46.958
And so that maybe becomes part of the draw and part of the labyrinth.

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:50.958
You can get another angle on Danny's porch

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:57.958
by going around to the south and looking north at the whole formation there. 


00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:00.958
And you need to know that Danny's clock is to be kept accurate

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:05.958
by a ray of sunshine, that perfect noon hitting it every sunny day,

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:08.958
and the pulse of heat from that sets off a solar trigger

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:11.958
which resets the clock to make it perfectly accurate.

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:13.958
So even with the slowing of the rotation of the earth and so on,

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:16.958
the clock will keep perfectly good time.

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:18.958
So here we're looking from the south, look north.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:22.958
This is all Forest Service land. If you go up on top of those cliffs,

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:25.958
that's some of the Long Now land in those trees.

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:30.958
And if you go up there and look back, then you'll get a sense of

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.958
what the view starts to be like from the top of the mountain.

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:37.958
That's the long view. That's 80 miles to the horizon.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:41.958
And that's also timberline and those bristlecones really are shrubs.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:49.958
That's a different place to be. It's 11,400 feet and it's exquisite.

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:53.958
Now, if you go over to the right from this image to looking at the edge of the cliffs,

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:57.958
it's 600 foot, just about a yard to the left of Kurt Bollacker's foot,

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:02.958
there is a 600-foot drop. He's ambling on over to Zander's Siq.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:06.958
That's what it looks like looking down it.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:10.958
We should probably put in a rail or something.

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:14.958
Over on the eastern side it's gentle, as you can see.

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:17.958
And that's not snow -- that's what the white limestone looks like.

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:21.958
You also see there a bighorn sheep.

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:24.958
Their herd was reintroduced from Wyoming.

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:27.958
And they're doing pretty well, but they've got a bit of trouble.

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:30.958
This is Danny Hillis, and he's figuring out a design problem.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:35.958
he's trying to determine if where he is on a bit of Long Now land

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:41.958
would appear from down in the valley to be the actual peak of the mountain.

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:43.958
because the real peak is hidden around the corner.

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:47.958
This is what in the infantry we used to call the military crest.

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:50.958
And as it turned out the answer is, yes,

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:54.958
that is from down below in the valley it does look like the peak,

00:19:54.958 --> 00:19:56.958
and that might be conjured with.

00:19:56.958 --> 00:20:01.958
We gradually realized we have three serious design domains to work on with this.

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:03.958
One is the experience of the mountain.

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:06.958
Another is the experience in the mountain.

00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:09.958
And the third is the experience from the mountain,

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:12.958
which is really dominated by the view shed

00:20:12.958 --> 00:20:16.958
of the spring valley there behind Danny,

00:20:16.958 --> 00:20:18.958
and if you look off to the right, out there,

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:22.958
15 miles across to the Schell Creek range.

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:25.958
In the front, there are 10 ranches strung right along the base of the mountains

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:27.958
using the water from the mountains.

00:20:27.958 --> 00:20:32.958
In fact, there are artesian wells where water springs right into the air.

00:20:32.958 --> 00:20:35.958
One of the ranches is called the Kirkeby Ranch,

00:20:35.958 --> 00:20:37.958
and I'll take you there for a minute.

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:39.958
It's a very nice ranch.

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:44.958
Alfalfa and cattle, run by Paul and Ronnie Brenham,

00:20:44.958 --> 00:20:49.958
and it's pretty idyllic. It's also hard work.

00:20:49.958 --> 00:20:51.958
And most of these ranches are having trouble keeping going.

00:20:51.958 --> 00:20:55.958
This is their view to the west of the Schell Creek range.

00:20:55.958 --> 00:20:58.958
And if you go out to that line of trees at the far end,

00:20:58.958 --> 00:21:02.958
you'll see what the valley used to look like.

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:07.958
This is Rocky Mountain junipers that have been there for thousands of years.

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:10.958
And a scheme emerged that Long Now is looking to see

00:21:10.958 --> 00:21:13.958
if it might be possible to buy up the whole valley,

00:21:13.958 --> 00:21:17.958
because those 10 ranches with their 17,000 acres

00:21:17.958 --> 00:21:22.958
dominate a 500 square mile valley with their grazing allotments and so on, 


00:21:22.958 --> 00:21:25.958
and there's a possibility that you could get the whole thing

00:21:25.958 --> 00:21:29.958
for five million dollars and gradually restore it to its wild condition,

00:21:29.958 --> 00:21:33.958
and somewhere in the process turn it back over to the National Park,

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:37.958
and it would double the size of Great Basin National Park. That would be swell.

00:21:37.958 --> 00:21:40.958
OK, let's take one more look at the mountain itself.

00:21:40.958 --> 00:21:44.958
The clock experience should be profound,

00:21:44.958 --> 00:21:48.958
but from the outside it should be invisible.

00:21:48.958 --> 00:21:52.958
Now, at the base of the high cliffs there's this natural cave.

00:21:52.958 --> 00:21:56.958
It's only about 12 feet deep, but what if it were deepened from inside?

00:21:56.958 --> 00:21:59.958
You excavated from somewhere, came up from inside and deepened it.

00:21:59.958 --> 00:22:00.958
And then you could have an entrance

00:22:00.958 --> 00:22:03.958
which was very rough and narrow as you first went in,

00:22:03.958 --> 00:22:07.958
that gradually becomes more refined and then actually quite exquisite.

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:10.958
And this stone takes a perfect polish.

00:22:10.958 --> 00:22:15.958
You'd have a polished set of passages and chambers in there

00:22:15.958 --> 00:22:19.958
eventually leading to the 10,000 year clock.

00:22:19.958 --> 00:22:23.958
And it's not a mine. This would be a nuanced evocation

00:22:23.958 --> 00:22:26.958
of the basic structure of the mountain,

00:22:26.958 --> 00:22:29.958
and you would be appreciating it as much from inside as you do from outside. 


00:22:29.958 --> 00:22:32.958
This is architecture not made by building,

00:22:32.958 --> 00:22:36.958
but by what you very carefully take away.

00:22:36.958 --> 00:22:39.958
So that's what the mountain taught us.

00:22:39.958 --> 00:22:42.958
Most of the amazingness of the clock

00:22:42.958 --> 00:22:46.958
we can borrow from the amazingness of the mountain.

00:22:46.958 --> 00:22:50.958
All we have to do is highlight its spectacular features and blend in with them.

00:22:50.958 --> 00:22:55.958
It's not a clock in a mountain -- it's a mountain clock.

00:22:55.958 --> 00:22:57.958
Now, the Tewa Indians in the Southwest have a saying

00:22:57.958 --> 00:23:03.958
for what you need to do when you want to think long term about anything.

And so I was following this guy. And I took a picture of his shoes, and we thanked each other and just went on our way. But I do that all the time. As a matter of fact, I think a lot of my design ideas come from mistakes and tricks of the eye. Because I feel like, you know, there are so many images out there, so many clothes out there. And the only ones that look interesting to me are the ones that look slightly mistaken, of course, or very, very surprising. And often, I'm driving in a taxi and I see a hole in a shirt, or something that looks very interesting or pretty or functional in some way that I'd never seen happen before. And so I'd make the car stop, and I'd get out of the car and walk, and see that in fact there wasn't a hole, but it was a trick of my eye, it was a shadow, you know. Someone made that mistake already so I can't do it anymore.I don't know where inspiration comes from. It does not come for me from research. I don't get necessarily inspired by research. I know about a wolf and a bird and, you know, he ate the bird, and then in the end you hear, you know, you hear the bird squeaking, or something, you know?So I don't really know that. I don't really — actually I do my own kind of research, you know. I'm very, very, very inspired by movies. The color of movies and the way light makes the colors, light from behind the projection, or light from the projection, makes the colors look so impossible. And anyway, roll this little clip, I'll just show you. I sit up at night and I watch movies and I watch women in movies a lot. So you'll have to, like, go check it out and come see me or something. Because it's mortifying, and yet it feels ... I don't know how to put this. 00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:19.958
And I kind of try not to look back, you know.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:26.958
Like, looking back and thinking, what a fool you made of yourself, you know.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:30.958
But I guess that's okay. Right?

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:31.958
Because if you do many things

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
you get to feel lousy about everything,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
and not just one, you know.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
You don't master feeling lousy about one thing.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
Yeah, exactly.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:45.958
speaking of costumes for operas.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:52.958
who is one of my best friends.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:56.958

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
and the most recent one, "King Arthur."

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
I'd been very ingrained in the dance world

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:02.958
since I was a teenager.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
I went to performing arts high school,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:05.958
where I was an actor.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
Again, I don't know where inspiration comes from.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
I don't know where it comes from.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
I started making puppets when I was a kid.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:20.958
Maybe that's where the whole inspiration thing started from, puppets, right.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
And then performing arts high school.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:24.958
There I was in high school,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
meeting dancers and acting.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:48.958
I think of myself as a ... I don't know what I think of myself as.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:49.958

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:53.958
(Laughter)

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:57.958

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958

she books everything and she makes everything happen.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
so ... somehow, like, about ten years ago

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
like for a day show. Some kind of day talk show.
