00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
to talk at the conference. I really don't talk about this anymore

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:32.958
because, you know, there's enough frustrating and depressing things going on.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:35.958
But I agreed to come and say a few things about this.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
And I would say that we can't give up the rule of law

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
to fight an asymmetric threat, which is what we seem to be doing

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:47.958
because of the present, the people that are in power,

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:52.958
because that's to give up the thing that makes civilization.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
And we can't fight the threat in the kind of stupid way we're doing,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
because a million-dollar act

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
causes a billion dollars of damage, causes a trillion dollar response

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
which is largely ineffective and arguably, probably almost certainly,

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
has made the problem worse.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:10.958
So we can't fight the thing with a million-to-one cost,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:16.958
one-to-a-million cost-benefit ratio.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:22.958
So after giving up on the book -- and I had the great honor

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:26.958
to be able to join Kleiner Perkins about a year ago,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:33.958
and to work through venture capital on the innovative side,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:37.958
and to try to find some innovations that could address what I saw as

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
some of these big problems.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
Things where, you know, a factor of 10 difference

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:46.958
can make a factor of 1,000 difference in the outcome.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
I've been amazed in the last year at the incredible quality

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:54.958
and excitement of the innovations that have come across my desk.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
It's overwhelming at times. I'm very thankful for Google and Wikipedia

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:01.958
so I can understand at least a little of what people are talking about

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
who come through the doors.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
But I wanted to share with you three areas

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
that I'm particularly excited about and that relate to the problems

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:14.958
that I was talking about in the Wired article.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
The first is this whole area of education,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:20.958
and it really relates to what Nicholas was talking about with a $100 computer.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.958
And that is to say that there's a lot of legs left in Moore's Law.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.958
The most advanced transistors today are at 65 nanometers,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
and we've seen, and I've had the pleasure to invest

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:37.958
in, companies that give me great confidence that we'll extend Moore's Law

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
all the way down to roughly the 10 nanometer scale.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:46.958
Another factor of, say, six in dimensional reduction,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:51.958
which should give us about another factor of 100 in raw improvement

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:56.958
in what the chips can do. And so, to put that in practical terms,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:08:00.958
if something costs about 1,000 dollars today,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:05.958
say, the best personal computer you can buy, that might be its cost,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:11.958
I think we can have that in 2020 for 10 dollars. Okay?

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:16.958
Now, just imagine what that $100 computer will be in 2020

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
as a tool for education.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
I think the challenge for us is --

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
I'm very certain that that will happen, the challenge is,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:27.958
will we develop the kind of educational tools and things with the net

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
to let us take advantage of that device?

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:34.958
I'd argue today that we have incredibly powerful computers,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
but we don't have very good software for them.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
And it's only in retrospect, after the better software comes along,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
and you take it and you run it on a ten-year-old machine, you say,

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
God, the machine was that fast?

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
I remember when they took the Apple Mac interface

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
and they put it back on the Apple II.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
The Apple II was perfectly capable of running that kind of interface,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
we just didn't know how to do it at the time.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
So given that we know and should believe --

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
because Moore's Law's been, like, a constant,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
I mean, it's just been very predictable progress

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
over the last 40 years or whatever.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:09.958
We can know what the computers are going to be like in 2020.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
It's great that we have initiatives to say,

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
let's go create the education and educate people in the world,

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
because that's a great force for peace.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
And we can give everyone in the world a $100 computer

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:24.958
or a $10 computer in the next 15 years.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:29.958
The second area that I'm focusing on is the environmental problem,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:33.958
because that's clearly going to put a lot of pressure on this world.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:37.958
We'll hear a lot more about that from Al Gore very shortly.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
The thing that we see as the kind of Moore's Law trend

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
that's driving improvement in our ability to address

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:47.958
the environmental problem is new materials.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
We have a challenge, because the urban population is growing

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
in this century from two billion to six billion

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
in a very short amount of time. People are moving to the cities.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
They all need clean water, they need energy, they need transportation,

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:03.958
and we want them to develop in a green way.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
We're reasonably efficient in the industrial sectors.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
We've made improvements in energy and resource efficiency,

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:12.958
but the consumer sector, especially in America, is very inefficient.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
But these new materials bring such incredible innovations

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:20.958
that there's a strong basis for hope that these things

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
will be so profitable that they can be brought to the market.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
And I want to give you a specific example of a new material

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
that was discovered 15 years ago.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:33.958
If we take carbon nanotubes, you know, Iijima discovered them in 1991,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
they just have incredible properties.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:36.958
And these are the kinds of things we're going to discover

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
as we start to engineer at the nano scale.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Their strength: they're almost the strongest material,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
tensile strength material known.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:50.958
They're very, very stiff. They stretch very, very little.


00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
In two dimensions, if you make, like, a fabric out of them,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
they're 30 times stronger than Kevlar.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
And if you make a three-dimensional structure, like a buckyball,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
they have all sorts of incredible properties.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
If you shoot a particle at them and knock a hole in them,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
they repair themselves; they go zip and they repair the hole

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
in femtoseconds, which is not -- is really quick.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
(Laughter)

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:17.958
If you shine a light on them, they produce electricity.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
In fact, if you flash them with a camera they catch on fire.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:24.958
If you put electricity on them, they emit light.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
If you run current through them, you can run 1,000 times more current

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:31.958
through one of these than through a piece of metal.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
You can make both p- and n-type semiconductors,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
which means you can make transistors out of them.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
They conduct heat along their length but not across --

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
well, there is no width, but not in the other direction

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:47.958
if you stack them up; that's a property of carbon fiber also.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
If you put particles in them, and they go shooting out the tip --

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
they're like miniature linear accelerators or electron guns.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
The inside of the nanotubes is so small --

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
the smallest ones are 0.7 nanometers --

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
that it's basically a quantum world.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
It's a strange place inside a nanotube.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
And so we begin to see, and we've seen business plans already,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
where the kind of things Lisa Randall's talking about are in there.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
I had one business plan where I was trying to learn more about

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
Witten's cosmic dimension strings to try to understand

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
what the phenomenon was going on in this proposed nanomaterial.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:23.958
So inside of a nanotube, we're really at the limit here.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.958
So what we see is with these and other new materials

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.958
that we can do things with different properties -- lighter, stronger --

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:37.958
and apply these new materials to the environmental problems.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:38.958
New materials that can make water,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
new materials that can make fuel cells work better,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:44.958
new materials that catalyze chemical reactions,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
that cut pollution and so on.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Ethanol -- new ways of making ethanol.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
New ways of making electric transportation.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:57.958
The whole green dream -- because it can be profitable.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And we've dedicated -- we've just raised a new fund,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
we dedicated 100 million dollars to these kinds of investments.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:06.958
We believe that Genentech, the Compaq, the Lotus, the Sun,

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:10.958
the Netscape, the Amazon, the Google in these fields

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
are yet to be found, because this materials revolution

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
will drive these things forward.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
The third area that we're working on,

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:23.958
and we just announced last week -- we were all in New York.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:29.958
We raised 200 million dollars in a specialty fund

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:33.958
to work on a pandemic in biodefense.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
And to give you an idea of the last fund that Kleiner raised

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:41.958
was a $400 million fund, so this for us is a very substantial fund.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
And what we did, over the last few months -- well, a few months ago,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
Ray Kurzweil and I wrote an op-ed in the New York Times

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
about how publishing the 1918 genome was very dangerous.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:55.958
And John Doerr and Brook and others got concerned, [unclear],

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:59.958
and we started looking around at what the world was doing

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:04.958
about being prepared for a pandemic. And we saw a lot of gaps.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:08.958
And so we asked ourselves, you know, can we find innovative things

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:12.958
that will go fill these gaps? And Brooks told me in a break here,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
he said he's found so much stuff he can't sleep,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
because there's so many great technologies out there,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
we're essentially buried. And we need them, you know.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
We have one antiviral that people are talking about stockpiling

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
that still works, roughly. That's Tamiflu.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:31.958
But Tamiflu -- the virus is resistant. It is resistant to Tamiflu.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:35.958
We've discovered with AIDS we need cocktails to work well

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
so that the viral resistance -- we need several anti-virals.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
We need better surveillance.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
We need networks that can find out what's going on.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:47.958
We need rapid diagnostics so that we can tell if somebody has

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.958
a strain of flu which we have only identified very recently.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
We've got to be able to make the rapid diagnostics quickly.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
We need new anti-virals and cocktails. We need new kinds of vaccines.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
Vaccines that are broad spectrum.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:02.958
Vaccines that we can manufacture quickly.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
Cocktails, more polyvalent vaccines.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
You normally get a trivalent vaccine against three possible strains.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
We need -- we don't know where this thing is going.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
We believe that if we could fill these 10 gaps,

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:19.958
we have a chance to help really reduce the risk of a pandemic.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:23.958
And the difference between a normal flu season and a pandemic

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
is about a factor of 1,000 in deaths

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
and certainly enormous economic impact.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
So we're very excited because we think we can fund 10,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
or speed up 10 projects and see them come to market

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
in the next couple years that will address this.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
So if we can address, use technology, help address education,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
help address the environment, help address the pandemic,

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:49.958
does that solve the larger problem that I was talking about

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:54.958
in the Wired article? And I'm afraid the answer is really no,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:58.958
because you can't solve a problem with the management of technology

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
with more technology.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:06.958
If we let an unlimited amount of power loose, then we will --

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
a very small number of people will be able to abuse it.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.958
We can't fight at a million-to-one disadvantage.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
So what we need to do is, we need better policy.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
And for example, some things we could do

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:22.958
that would be policy solutions which are not really in the political air right now

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
but perhaps with the change of administration would be -- use markets.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
Markets are a very strong force.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
For example, rather than trying to regulate away problems,

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
which probably won't work, if we could price

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:38.958
into the cost of doing business, the cost of catastrophe,

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
so that people who are doing things that had a higher cost of catastrophe

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
would have to take insurance against that risk.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
So if you wanted to put a drug on the market you could put it on.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
But it wouldn't have to be approved by regulators;

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:52.958
you'd have to convince an actuary that it would be safe.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:55.958
And if you apply the notion of insurance more broadly,

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:58.958
you can use a more powerful force, a market force,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
to provide feedback.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:01.958
How could you keep the law?

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
I think the law would be a really good thing to keep.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
Well, you have to hold people accountable.

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
The law requires accountability.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.958
Today scientists, technologists, businessmen, engineers

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
don't have any personal responsibility

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
for the consequences of their actions.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:18.958
So if you tie that -- you have to tie that back with the law.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:22.958
And finally, I think we have to do something that's not really --

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:23.958
it's almost unacceptable to say this -- which,

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
we have to begin to design the future.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:30.958
We can't pick the future, but we can steer the future.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:32.958
Our investment in trying to prevent pandemic flu

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:36.958
is affecting the distribution of possible outcomes.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:38.958
We may not be able to stop it, but the likelihood

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:42.958
that it will get past us is lower if we focus on that problem.

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:46.958
So we can design the future if we choose what kind of things

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
we want to have happen and not have happen,

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:52.958
and steer us to a lower-risk place.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:58.958
Vice President Gore will talk about how we could steer the climate trajectory

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:01.958
into a lower probability of catastrophic risk.

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:04.958
But above all, what we have to do is we have to help the good guys,

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
the people on the defensive side,

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:10.958
have an advantage over the people who want to abuse things.

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:12.958
And what we have to do to do that

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:15.958
is we have to limit access to certain information.

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:18.958
And growing up as we have, and holding very high

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:22.958
the value of free speech, this is a hard thing for us to accept --

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:23.958
for all of us to accept.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:28.958
It's especially hard for the scientists to accept who still remember,

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:30.958
you know, Galileo essentially locked up,

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:34.958
and who are still fighting this battle against the church.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:39.958
But that's the price of having a civilization.

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:41.958
The price of retaining the rule of law

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:46.958
is to limit the access to the great and kind of unbridled power.

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:47.958
Thank you.

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:49.958
(Applause)

title: A foie gras parable
transcript: I went to Spain a few months ago and I had the best foie gras of my life. The best culinary experience of my life. Because what I saw, I'm convinced, is the future of cooking. Ridiculous, right? Foie gras and the future of cooking. There's not a food today that's more maligned than foie gras, right? I mean, it's crucified. It was outlawed in Chicago for a while. It's pending here in California, and just recently in New York. It's like if you're a chef and you put it on your menu, you risk being attacked. Really, it happened here in San Francisco to a famous chef.I'm not saying that there's not a rationale for being opposed to foie gras. The reasons usually just boil down to the gavage, which is the force feeding. Basically you take a goose or a duck and you force feed a ton of grain down its throat. More grain in a couple of weeks than it would ever get in a lifetime. Its liver expands by eight times. Suffice to say it's like — it's not the prettiest picture of sustainable farming.The problem for us chefs is that it's so freakin' delicious. (Laughter) I mean, I love the stuff. It is fatty, it's sweet, it's silky, it's unctuous. It makes everything else you put it with taste incredible. Can we produce a menu that's delicious without foie gras? Yes, sure. You can also bike the Tour de France without steroids, right? (Laughter) Not a lot of people are doing it. And for good reason. (Laughter)So several months ago, a friend of mine sent me this link to this guy, Eduardo Sousa. Eduardo is doing what he calls natural foie gras. Natural foie gras. What's natural about foie gras? To take advantage of when the temperature drops in the fall, geese and ducks gorge on food to prepare for the harsh realities of winter. And the rest of the year they're free to roam around Eduardo's land and eat what they want. So no gavage, no force feeding, no factory-like conditions, no cruelty.And it's shockingly not a new idea. His great-granddad started — Patería de Sousa — in 1812. And they've been doing it quietly ever since. That is until last year, when Eduardo won the Coup de Coeur, the coveted French gastronomic prize. It's like the Olympics of food products. He placed first for his foie gras. Big, big problem. As he said to me, that really pissed the French off. (Laughter) He said it sort of gleefully.It was all over the papers. I read about it. It was in Le Monde. "Spanish chef accused ... " — and the French accused him. "Spanish chef accused of cheating." They accused him of paying off the judges. They implicated actually, the Spanish government, amazingly. Huh, amazing. A huge scandal for a few weeks. Couldn't find a shred of evidence. Now, look at the guy. He doesn't look like a guy who's paying off French judges for his foie gras. So that died down, and very soon afterward, new controversy. He shouldn't win because it's not foie gras. It's not foie gras because it's not gavage. There's no force feeding. So by definition, he's lying and should be disqualified.As funny as it sounds, articulating it now and reading about it — actually, if we had talked about it before this controversy, I would have said, "That's kind of true." You know, foie gras by definition, force feeding, it's gavage, and that's what you get when you want foie gras. That is, until I went to Eduardo's farm in Extremadura, 50 miles north of Seville, right on the Portugal border. I saw first-hand a system that is incredibly complex and then at the same time, like everything beautiful in nature, is utterly simple. And he said to me, really from the first moment, my life's work is to give the geese what they want. He repeated that about 50 times in the two days I was with him. I'm just here to give the geese what they want. Actually, when I showed up he was lying down with the geese with his cell phone taking pictures of them like his children in the grass. Amazing. He's really just in love with — he's at one with — he's the goose whisperer. (Laughter)And when I was speaking to him, you know, I thought, like I'm speaking to you now, right, but sort of in the middle of my questions, my excited questions, because the more I got to know him and his system, the more exciting this whole idea became. He kept going like this to me. And I thought, OK, excited Jew from New York, right? I'm talking a little too aggressively, whatever, so you know, I slowed down. And finally, by the end of the day I was like, Ed-uar-do, you know like this? But he was still going like this. I figured it out. I was speaking too loudly. So I hushed my voice. I kind of like asked these questions and chatted with him through a translator in kind of a half whisper. And he stopped doing this. And amazingly, the geese who were on the other side of the paddock when I was around — "Get the hell away from this kid!" — when I lowered my voice, they all came right up to us. Right up to us, like right up to here. Right along the fence line.And fence line was amazing in itself. The fence — like this conception of fence that we have it's totally backward with him. The electricity on this fiberglass fence is only on the outside. He rewired it. He invented it. I've never seen it. Have you? You fence in animals. You electrify the inside. He doesn't. He electrifies only the outside. Why? Because he said to me that he felt like the geese — and he proved this actually, not just a conceit, he proved this — the geese felt manipulated when they were imprisoned in their little paddocks. Even though they were imprisoned in this Garden of Eden with figs and everything else. He felt like they felt manipulated. So he got rid of the electricity, he got rid of current on the inside and kept it on the outside, so it would protect them against coyotes and other predators.Now, what happened? They ate, and he showed me on a chart, how they ate about 20 percent more feed to feed their livers. The landscape is incredible. I mean, his farm is incredible. It really is the Garden of Eden. There's figs and everything else there for the taking. And the irony of ironies is because Extremadura, the area — what does Extremadura mean? Extra hard land, right? Extra difficult. Extra hard. But over four generations, he and his family have literally transformed this extra hard land into a tasting menu. Upgrades the life for these geese. And they are allowed to take whatever they want.Another irony, the double irony is that on the figs and the olives, Eduardo can make more money selling those than he can on the foie gras. He doesn't care. He lets them take what they want and he says, "Usually, it's about 50 percent. They're very fair." The other 50 percent, he takes and he sells and he makes money on them. Part of the income for his farm. A big part of his income for his farm. But he never controls it. They get what they want, they leave the rest for me and I sell it.His biggest obstacle, really, was the marketplace, which demands these days bright yellow foie gras. That's how I've been trained. You want to look and see what good foie gras is, it's got to be bright yellow. It's the indication that it's the best foie gras. Well, because he doesn't force feed, because he doesn't gavage tons of corn, his livers were pretty grey. Or they were. But he found this wild plant called the Lupin bush. The Lupin bush, it's all around Extremadura. He let it go to seed, he took the seeds, he planted it on his 30 acres, all around. And the geese love the Lupin bush. Not for the bush, but for the seeds. And when they eat the seeds, their foie gras turns yellow. Radioactive yellow. Bright yellow. Of the highest quality foie gras yellow I've ever seen. (Laughter)So I'm listening to all this, you know, and I'm like, is this guy for real? Is he making some of this up? Is he like, you know — because he seemed to have an answer for everything, and it was always nature. It was never him. And I was like, you know, I always get a little, like, weirded out by people who deflect everything away from themselves. Because, really, they want you to look at themselves, right? But he deflected everything away from his ingenuity into working with his landscape.So it's like, here I am, I'm on the fence about this guy, but increasingly, eating up his every word. And we're sitting there, and I hear [clapping] from a distance, so I look over. And he grabs my arm and the translator's, and ducks us under a bush and says, "Watch this." "Shush," he says again for the 500th time to me. "Shush, watch this." And this squadron of geese come over. [Clapping] And they're getting louder, louder, louder, like really loud, right over us. And like airport traffic control, as they start to go past us they're called back — and they're called back and back and back. And then they circle around. And his geese are calling up now to the wild geese. [Clapping] And the wild geese are calling down. [Clapping] And it's getting louder and louder and they circle and circle and they land. And I'm just saying, "No way." (Laughter) No way.And I look at Eduardo, who's near tears looking at this, and I say, "You're telling me that your geese are calling to the wild geese to say come for a visit?" And he says, "No, no, no. They've come to stay." They've come to stay? (Laughter) It's like the DNA of a goose is to fly south in the winter, right? I said that. I said "Isn't that what they're put on this Earth for? To fly south in the winter and north when it gets warm?" He said, "No, no, no. Their DNA is to find the conditions that are conducive to life. To happiness. They find it here. They don't need anything more." They stop. They mate with his domesticated geese, and his flock continues. Think about that for a minute. It's brilliant, right? Imagine — I don't know, imagine a hog farm in, like, North Carolina, and a wild pig comes upon a factory farm and decides to stay. (Laughter)So how did it taste? I finally got to taste it before I left. He took me to his neighborhood restaurant and he served me some of his foie gras, confit de foie gras. It was incredible. And the problem with saying that, of course, is that you know, at this point it risks hyperbole really easily. And I'd like to make a metaphor, but I don't have one really. I was drinking this guy's Kool-Aid so much, he could have served me goose feathers and I would have been like, this guy's a genius, you know? I'm really in love with him at this point.But it truly was the best foie gras of my life. So much so that I don't think I had ever really had foie gras until that moment. I'd had something that was called foie gras. But this was transformative. Really transformative. And I say to you, I might not stick to this, but I don't think I'll ever serve foie gras on my menu again because of that taste experience with Eduardo. It was sweet, it was unctuous. It had all the qualities of foie gras, but its fat had a lot of integrity and a lot of honesty.And you could taste herbs, you could taste spices. And I kept — I said, you know, I swear to God I tasted star anise. I was sure of it. And I'm not like some super taster, you know? But I can taste things. There's 100 percent star anise in there. And he says, "No." And I ended up like going down the spices, and finally, it was like, OK, salt and pepper, thinking he's salted and peppered his liver. But no. He takes the liver when he harvests the foie gras, he sticks them in this jar and he confits it. No salt, no pepper, no oil, no spices. What?We went back out for the final tour of the farm, and he showed me the wild pepper plants and the plants that he made sure existed on his farm for salinity. He doesn't need salt and pepper. And he doesn't need spices, because he's got this potpourri of herbs and flavors that his geese love to gorge on. I turned to him at the end of the meal, and it's a question I asked several times, and he hadn't, kind of, answered me directly, but I said, "Now look, you're in Spain, some of the greatest chefs in the world are — Ferran Adria, the preeminent chef of the world today, not that far from you. How come you don't give him this? How come no one's really heard of you?" And it may be because of the wine, or it may be because of my excitement, he answered me directly and he said, "Because chefs don't deserve my foie gras." (Laughter) And he was right. He was right.Chefs take foie gras and they make it their own. They create a dish where all the vectors point at us. With Eduardo it's about the expression of nature. And as he said, I think fittingly, it's a gift from God, with God saying, you've done good work. Simple. I flew home, I'm on the flight with my little black book and I took, you know, pages and pages of notes about it. I really was moved. And in the corner of one of these — one of my notes, is this note that says, when asked, what do you think of conventional foie gras? What do you think of foie gras that 99.99999 percent of the world eats? He said, "I think it's an insult to history." And I wrote, insult to history. I'm on the plane and I'm just tearing my hair out. It's like, why didn't I follow up on that? What the hell does that mean? Insult to history.So I did some research when I got back, and here's what I found. The history of foie gras. Jews invented foie gras. True story. True story. By accident. They were looking for an alternative to schmaltz. Gotten sick of the chicken fat. They were looking for an alternative. And they saw in the fall that there was this natural, beautiful, sweet, delicious fat from geese. And they slaughtered them, used the fat throughout the winter for cooking. The Pharaoh got wind of this — This is true, right off the Internet. The Pharaoh got — (Laughter) I swear to God. (Laughter) The Pharaoh got wind of this and wanted to taste it. He tasted it and fell in love with it. He started demanding it.And he didn't want it just in the fall, he wanted it all year round. And he demanded that the Jews supply enough for everyone. And the Jews, fearing for their life, had to come up with an ingenious idea, or at least try and satisfy the Pharaoh's wishes, of course. And they invented, what? Gavage. They invented gavage in a great moment of fear for their lives, and they provided the Pharaoh with gavage liver, and the good stuff they kept for themselves. Supposedly, anyway. I believe that one.That's the history of foie gras. And if you think about it, it's the history of industrial agriculture. It's the history of what we eat today. Most of what we eat today. Mega-farms, feed lots, chemical amendments, long-distance travel, food processing. All of it, our food system. That's also an insult to history. It's an insult to the basic laws of nature and of biology. Whether we're talking about beef cattle or we're talking about chickens, or we're talking about broccoli or Brussels sprouts, or in the case of this morning's New York Times, catfish — which wholesale are going out of business.Whatever it is, it's a mindset that is reminiscent of General Motors. It's rooted in extraction. Take more, sell more, waste more. And for the future it won't serve us. Jonas Salk has a great quote. He said, "If all the insects disappeared, life on Earth as we know it would disappear within 50 years. If human beings disappeared, life on Earth as we know it would flourish."And he's right. We need now to adopt a new conception of agriculture. Really new. One in which we stop treating the planet as if it were some kind of business in liquidation. And stop degrading resources under the guise of cheap food. We can start by looking to farmers like Eduardo. Farmers that rely on nature for solutions, for answers, rather than imposing solutions on nature. Listening as Janine Benyus, one of my favorite writers and thinkers about this topic says, "Listening to nature's operating instructions." That's what Eduardo does, and does so brilliantly. And what he showed me and what he can show all of us, I think, is that the great thing for chefs, the great blessing for chefs, and for people that care about food and cooking, is that the most ecological choice for food is also the most ethical choice for food. Whether we're talking about Brussels sprouts or foie gras. And it's also almost always, and I haven't found an example otherwise, but almost always, the most delicious choice. That's serendipitous. Thank you. (Applause)

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.958
I went to Spain a few months ago

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:21.958
and I had the best foie gras of my life.

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:24.958
The best culinary experience of my life.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:32.958
Because what I saw, I'm convinced, is the future of cooking.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:33.958
Ridiculous, right?

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:35.958
Foie gras and the future of cooking.

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:38.958
There's not a food today that's more maligned than foie gras, right?

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.958
I mean, it's crucified.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958
It was outlawed in Chicago for a while.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:47.958
It's pending here in California, and just recently in New York.

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:50.958
It's like if you're a chef and you put it on your menu,

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
you risk being attacked.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:56.958
Really, it happened here in San Francisco to a famous chef.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:01:02.958
I'm not saying that there's not a rationale

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
for being opposed to foie gras.

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:08.958
The reasons usually just boil down to the gavage, which is the force feeding.

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:10.958
Basically you take a goose or a duck

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:15.958
and you force feed a ton of grain down its throat.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:19.958
More grain in a couple of weeks than it would ever get in a lifetime.

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:22.958
Its liver expands by eight times.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:27.958
Suffice to say it's like -- it's not the prettiest picture of sustainable farming.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:33.958
The problem for us chefs is that it's so freakin' delicious.

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:36.958
(Laughter)

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
I mean, I love the stuff.

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:44.958
It is fatty, it's sweet, it's silky, it's unctuous.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:49.958
It makes everything else you put it with taste incredible.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:55.958
Can we produce a menu that's delicious without foie gras?

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:57.958
Yes, sure.

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:00.958
You can also bike the Tour de France without steroids, right?

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
(Laughter)

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.958
Not a lot of people are doing it.

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
And for good reason.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:08.958
(Laughter)

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:13.958
So several months ago, a friend of mine sent me this link to this guy,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
Eduardo Sousa.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:20.958
Eduardo is doing what he calls natural foie gras.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
Natural foie gras.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:25.958
What's natural about foie gras?

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:29.958
To take advantage of when the temperature drops in the fall,

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:34.958
geese and ducks gorge on food

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:39.958
to prepare for the harsh realities of winter.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:44.958
And the rest of the year they're free to roam around Eduardo's land

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
and eat what they want.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:47.958
So no gavage, no force feeding,

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:51.958
no factory-like conditions, no cruelty.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
And it's shockingly not a new idea.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:59.958
His great-granddad started -- Patería de Sousa -- in 1812.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:05.958
And they've been doing it quietly ever since.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
That is until last year,

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:13.958
when Eduardo won the Coup de Coeur,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:17.958
the coveted French gastronomic prize.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
It's like the Olympics of food products.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:24.958
He placed first for his foie gras.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
Big, big problem.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:29.958
As he said to me, that really pissed the French off.

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:33.958
(Laughter)

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
He said it sort of gleefully.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
It was all over the papers.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
I read about it. It was in Le Monde.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:43.958
"Spanish chef accused ... " -- and the French accused him.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
"Spanish chef accused of cheating."

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
They accused him of paying off the judges.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
They implicated actually, the Spanish government, amazingly.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
Huh, amazing.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:54.958
A huge scandal for a few weeks.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
Couldn't find a shred of evidence.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:58.958
Now, look at the guy.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
He doesn't look like a guy who's paying off French judges

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
for his foie gras.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
So that died down, and very soon afterward,

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
new controversy.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:12.958
He shouldn't win because it's not foie gras.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
It's not foie gras because it's not gavage.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
There's no force feeding.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:21.958
So by definition, he's lying and should be disqualified.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
As funny as it sounds, articulating it now and reading about it --

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
actually, if we had talked about it before this controversy,

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
I would have said, "That's kind of true."

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
You know, foie gras by definition, force feeding, it's gavage,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:37.958
and that's what you get when you want foie gras.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:42.958
That is, until I went to Eduardo's farm in Extremadura,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:46.958
50 miles north of Seville, right on the Portugal border.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:50.958
I saw first-hand a system that is incredibly complex

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:55.958
and then at the same time, like everything beautiful in nature,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
is utterly simple.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
And he said to me, really from the first moment,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:06.958
my life's work is to give the geese what they want.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
He repeated that about 50 times in the two days I was with him.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:13.958
I'm just here to give the geese what they want.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
Actually, when I showed up he was lying down with the geese with his cell phone

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:17.958
taking pictures of them

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
like his children in the grass.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
Amazing.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
He's really just in love with -- he's at one with --

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
he's the goose whisperer.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
(Laughter)

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:36.958
And when I was speaking to him, you know, I thought,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
like I'm speaking to you now, right,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:43.958
but sort of in the middle of my questions, my excited questions,

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:44.958
because the more I got to know him and his system,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:48.958
the more exciting this whole idea became.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:49.958
He kept going like this to me.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:56.958
And I thought, OK, excited Jew from New York, right?

00:05:56.958 --> 00:06:00.958
I'm talking a little too aggressively, whatever,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
so you know, I slowed down.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:03.958
And finally, by the end of the day I was like,

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
Ed-uar-do, you know like this?

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
But he was still going like this.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
I figured it out.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
I was speaking too loudly.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
So I hushed my voice.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:20.958
I kind of like asked these questions and chatted with him through a translator

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
in kind of a half whisper.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
And he stopped doing this.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:29.958
And amazingly, the geese who were on the other side of the paddock when I was around --

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
"Get the hell away from this kid!" --

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
when I lowered my voice, they all came right up to us.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:35.958
Right up to us, like right up to here.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:36.958
Right along the fence line.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
And fence line was amazing in itself.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
The fence -- like this conception of fence that we have

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
it's totally backward with him.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
The electricity on this fiberglass fence

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
is only on the outside.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
He rewired it. He invented it.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
I've never seen it. Have you?

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
You fence in animals. You electrify the inside.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:06:59.958
He doesn't.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
He electrifies only the outside.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:03.958
Why?

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
Because he said to me that he felt like the geese --

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:10.958
and he proved this actually, not just a conceit, he proved this --

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:16.958
the geese felt manipulated when they were imprisoned in their little paddocks.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
Even though they were imprisoned in this Garden of Eden

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:19.958
with figs and everything else.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
He felt like they felt manipulated.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
So he got rid of the electricity,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
he got rid of current on the inside

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:27.958
and kept it on the outside,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
so it would protect them against coyotes and other predators.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
Now, what happened?

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
They ate, and he showed me on a chart,

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:39.958
how they ate about 20 percent more feed to feed their livers.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
The landscape is incredible.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
I mean, his farm is incredible.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
It really is the Garden of Eden.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
There's figs and everything else there for the taking.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
And the irony of ironies is because Extremadura, the area --

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:50.958
what does Extremadura mean?

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
Extra hard land, right?

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
Extra difficult. Extra hard.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
But over four generations, he and his family

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:02.958
have literally transformed this extra hard land into a tasting menu.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:08.958
Upgrades the life for these geese.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
And they are allowed to take whatever they want.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:11.958
Another irony, the double irony

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:12.958
is that on the figs and the olives,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
Eduardo can make more money selling those

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
than he can on the foie gras.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:18.958
He doesn't care.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
He lets them take what they want and he says,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
"Usually, it's about 50 percent. They're very fair."

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
The other 50 percent, he takes and he sells and he makes money on them.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
Part of the income for his farm.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
A big part of his income for his farm.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
But he never controls it.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:33.958
They get what they want,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
they leave the rest for me and I sell it.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:40.958
His biggest obstacle, really, was the marketplace,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:45.958
which demands these days bright yellow foie gras.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:46.958
That's how I've been trained.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
You want to look and see what good foie gras is,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
it's got to be bright yellow.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.958
It's the indication that it's the best foie gras.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
Well, because he doesn't force feed,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:00.958
because he doesn't gavage tons of corn,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
his livers were pretty grey.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
Or they were.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:10.958
But he found this wild plant called the Lupin bush.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
The Lupin bush, it's all around Extremadura.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
He let it go to seed, he took the seeds,

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
he planted it on his 30 acres, all around.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
And the geese love the Lupin bush.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
Not for the bush, but for the seeds.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.958
And when they eat the seeds, their foie gras turns yellow.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
Radioactive yellow.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
Bright yellow.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
Of the highest quality foie gras yellow I've ever seen.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
(Laughter)

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
So I'm listening to all this, you know, and I'm like,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
is this guy for real? Is he making some of this up?

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
Is he like, you know -- because he seemed to have an answer for everything,

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
and it was always nature.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
It was never him.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:53.958
And I was like, you know, I always get a little, like,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
weirded out by people who deflect everything away from themselves.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
Because, really, they want you to look at themselves, right?

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
But he deflected everything away from his ingenuity

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
into working with his landscape.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
So it's like, here I am, I'm on the fence about this guy,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
but increasingly, eating up his every word.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:15.958
And we're sitting there, and I hear [clapping] from a distance, so I look over.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
And he grabs my arm and the translator's,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
and ducks us under a bush and says, "Watch this."

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
"Shush," he says again for the 500th time to me.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
"Shush, watch this."

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
And this squadron of geese come over.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:28.958
[Clapping]

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:33.958
And they're getting louder, louder, louder, like really loud, right over us.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:39.958
And like airport traffic control, as they start to go past us

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:43.958
they're called back -- and they're called back and back and back.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:44.958
And then they circle around.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
And his geese are calling up now to the wild geese.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:48.958
[Clapping]

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:49.958
And the wild geese are calling down.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:50.958
[Clapping]

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
And it's getting louder and louder and they circle and circle

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:53.958
and they land.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
And I'm just saying, "No way."

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
(Laughter)

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
No way.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:05.958
And I look at Eduardo, who's near tears looking at this,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:09.958
and I say, "You're telling me that your geese are calling to the wild geese

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
to say come for a visit?"

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
And he says, "No, no, no.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
They've come to stay."

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
They've come to stay?

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
(Laughter)

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:26.958
It's like the DNA of a goose is to fly south in the winter, right?

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
I said that. I said "Isn't that what they're put on this Earth for?

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
To fly south in the winter and north when it gets warm?"

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
He said, "No, no, no.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:37.958
Their DNA is to find the conditions that are conducive to life.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
To happiness.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
They find it here.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
They don't need anything more."

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:48.958
They stop. They mate with his domesticated geese,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
and his flock continues.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
Think about that for a minute.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:54.958
It's brilliant, right?

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:58.958
Imagine -- I don't know, imagine a hog farm

00:11:58.958 --> 00:11:59.958
in, like, North Carolina,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:04.958
and a wild pig comes upon a factory farm

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
and decides to stay.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:07.958
(Laughter)

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
So how did it taste?

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
I finally got to taste it before I left.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
He took me to his neighborhood restaurant

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:18.958
and he served me some of his foie gras, confit de foie gras.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
It was incredible.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
And the problem with saying that, of course, is that

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:28.958
you know, at this point it risks hyperbole really easily.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:32.958
And I'd like to make a metaphor, but I don't have one really.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
I was drinking this guy's Kool-Aid so much,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:39.958
he could have served me goose feathers and I would have been like,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
this guy's a genius, you know?

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
I'm really in love with him at this point.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
But it truly was the best foie gras of my life.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
So much so that I don't think I had ever really had foie gras until that moment.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
I'd had something that was called foie gras.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
But this was transformative. Really transformative.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And I say to you, I might not stick to this,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:04.958
but I don't think I'll ever serve foie gras on my menu again

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:10.958
because of that taste experience with Eduardo.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:11.958
It was sweet, it was unctuous.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
It had all the qualities of foie gras,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:19.958
but its fat had a lot of integrity and a lot of honesty.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
And you could taste herbs, you could taste spices.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:28.958
And I kept -- I said, you know, I swear to God I tasted star anise.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:29.958
I was sure of it.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
And I'm not like some super taster, you know?

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
But I can taste things.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
There's 100 percent star anise in there.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
And he says, "No."

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:38.958
And I ended up like going down the spices,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
and finally, it was like, OK, salt and pepper,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
thinking he's salted and peppered his liver.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:44.958
But no.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
He takes the liver when he harvests the foie gras,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
he sticks them in this jar

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
and he confits it.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
No salt, no pepper, no oil, no spices.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
What?

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
We went back out for the final tour of the farm,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
and he showed me the wild pepper plants

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:06.958
and the plants that he made sure existed on his farm for salinity.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:07.958
He doesn't need salt and pepper.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:13.958
And he doesn't need spices, because he's got this potpourri of herbs and flavors

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.958
that his geese love to gorge on.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:18.958
I turned to him at the end of the meal,

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
and it's a question I asked several times,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
and he hadn't, kind of, answered me directly,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
but I said, "Now look, you're in Spain,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
some of the greatest chefs in the world are --

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:35.958
Ferran Adria, the preeminent chef of the world today, not that far from you.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
How come you don't give him this?

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
How come no one's really heard of you?"

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:41.958
And it may be because of the wine,

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:42.958
or it may be because of my excitement,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:47.958
he answered me directly and he said, "Because chefs don't deserve my foie gras."

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
(Laughter)

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:51.958
And he was right.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:52.958
He was right.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:56.958
Chefs take foie gras and they make it their own.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
They create a dish

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:02.958
where all the vectors point at us.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:07.958
With Eduardo it's about the expression of nature.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:11.958
And as he said, I think fittingly,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:17.958
it's a gift from God, with God saying, you've done good work.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:18.958
Simple.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
I flew home, I'm on the flight with my little black book

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
and I took, you know, pages and pages of notes about it.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
I really was moved.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:31.958
And in the corner of one of these -- one of my notes,

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:35.958
is this note that says, when asked,

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:36.958
what do you think of conventional foie gras?

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:37.958
What do you think of foie gras that

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:42.958
99.99999 percent of the world eats?

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
He said, "I think it's an insult to history."

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
And I wrote, insult to history.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
I'm on the plane and I'm just tearing my hair out.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:51.958
It's like, why didn't I follow up on that?

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:52.958
What the hell does that mean?

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
Insult to history.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
So I did some research when I got back,

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
and here's what I found.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:00.958
The history of foie gras.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:04.958
Jews invented foie gras.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:05.958
True story.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:06.958
True story.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
By accident.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.958
They were looking for an alternative to schmaltz.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:13.958
Gotten sick of the chicken fat.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:14.958
They were looking for an alternative.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
And they saw in the fall that there was this natural,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:20.958
beautiful, sweet, delicious fat from geese.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:24.958
And they slaughtered them, used the fat throughout the winter for cooking.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
The Pharaoh got wind of this --

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
This is true, right off the Internet.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
The Pharaoh got -- (Laughter)

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
I swear to God.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:34.958
(Laughter)

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:38.958
The Pharaoh got wind of this and wanted to taste it.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
He tasted it and fell in love with it.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:41.958
He started demanding it.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
And he didn't want it just in the fall, he wanted it all year round.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:48.958
And he demanded that the Jews supply enough for everyone.

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
And the Jews, fearing for their life,

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
had to come up with an ingenious idea,

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:56.958
or at least try and satisfy the Pharaoh's wishes, of course.

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
And they invented, what? Gavage.

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:06.958
They invented gavage in a great moment of fear for their lives,

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:09.958
and they provided the Pharaoh with gavage liver,

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
and the good stuff they kept for themselves.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
Supposedly, anyway. I believe that one.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
That's the history of foie gras.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:18.958
And if you think about it,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:23.958
it's the history of industrial agriculture.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
It's the history of what we eat today.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
Most of what we eat today.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:32.958
Mega-farms, feed lots, chemical amendments,

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:35.958
long-distance travel, food processing.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
All of it, our food system.

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:41.958
That's also an insult to history.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:45.958
It's an insult to the basic laws of nature

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:49.958
and of biology.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:52.958
Whether we're talking about beef cattle

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:55.958
or we're talking about chickens,

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:59.958
or we're talking about broccoli or Brussels sprouts,

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:03.958
or in the case of this morning's New York Times, catfish --

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:08.958
which wholesale are going out of business.

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:13.958
Whatever it is, it's a mindset that is reminiscent of General Motors.

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:16.958
It's rooted in extraction.

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:19.958
Take more, sell more, waste more.

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:23.958
And for the future it won't serve us.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:25.958
Jonas Salk has a great quote.

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:27.958
He said, "If all the insects disappeared,

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:34.958
life on Earth as we know it would disappear within 50 years.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:41.958
If human beings disappeared, life on Earth as we know it would flourish."

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:43.958
And he's right.

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:51.958
We need now to adopt a new conception of agriculture.

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:52.958
Really new.

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:55.958
One in which we stop treating the planet

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:59.958
as if it were some kind of business in liquidation.

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:03.958
And stop degrading resources under the guise of

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:05.958
cheap food.

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:09.958
We can start by looking to farmers like Eduardo.

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:10.958
Farmers that rely on nature

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:14.958
for solutions, for answers,

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:17.958
rather than imposing solutions on nature.

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:19.958
Listening as Janine Benyus,

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:22.958
one of my favorite writers and thinkers about this topic says,

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:25.958
"Listening to nature's operating instructions."

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:28.958
That's what Eduardo does, and does so brilliantly.

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:30.958
And what he showed me and what he can show all of us, I think,

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:37.958
is that the great thing for chefs, the great blessing for chefs,

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:44.958
and for people that care about food and cooking,

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:47.958
is that the most ecological choice for food

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:50.958
is also the most ethical choice for food.

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:53.958
Whether we're talking about Brussels sprouts or foie gras.

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:57.958
And it's also almost always, and I haven't found an example otherwise,

00:19:57.958 --> 00:20:02.958
but almost always, the most delicious choice.

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:03.958
That's serendipitous.

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:04.958
Thank you.

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:10.958
(Applause)

title: Do the green thing
transcript: Great creativity. In times of need, we need great creativity. Discuss. Great creativity is astonishingly, absurdly, rationally, irrationally powerful. Great creativity can spread tolerance, champion freedom, make education seem like a bright idea. (Laughter)Great creativity can turn a spotlight on deprivation, or show that deprivation ain't necessarily so. Great creativity can make politicians electable, or parties unelectable. It can make war seem like tragedy or farce.Creativity is the meme-maker that puts slogans on our t-shirts and phrases on our lips. It's the pathfinder that shows us a simple road through an impenetrable moral maze. Science is clever, but great creativity is something less knowable, more magical. And now we need that magic. This is a time of need.Our climate is changing quickly, too quickly. And great creativity is needed to do what it does so well: to provoke us to think differently with dramatic creative statements. To tempt us to act differently with delightful creative scraps. Here is one such scrap from an initiative I'm involved in using creativity to inspire people to be greener.(Video) Man: You know, rather than drive today, I'm going to walk.Narrator: And so he walked, and as he walked he saw things. Strange and wonderful things he would not otherwise have seen. A deer with an itchy leg. A flying motorcycle. A father and daughter separated from a bicycle by a mysterious wall. And then he stopped. Walking in front of him was her. The woman who as a child had skipped with him through fields and broken his heart. Sure, she had aged a little. In fact, she had aged a lot. But he felt all his old passion for her return. "Ford," he called softly. For that was her name. "Don't say another word, Gusty," she said, for that was his name. "I know a tent next to a caravan, exactly 300 yards from here. Let's go there and make love. In the tent." Ford undressed. She spread one leg, and then the other. Gusty entered her boldly and made love to her rhythmically while she filmed him, because she was a keen amateur pornographer. The earth moved for both of them. And they lived together happily ever after. And all because he decided to walk that day. (Applause)Andy Hobsbawm: We've got the science, we've had the debate. The moral imperative is on the table. Great creativity is needed to take it all, make it simple and sharp. To make it connect. To make it make people want to act. So this is a call, a plea, to the incredibly talented TED community. Let's get creative against climate change. And let's do it soon. Thank you. (Applause)

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:43.958
Great creativity can make politicians electable,

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:46.958
or parties unelectable.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:50.958
It can make war seem like tragedy or farce.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:54.958
Creativity is the meme-maker that puts slogans on our t-shirts

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
and phrases on our lips.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.958
It's the pathfinder that shows us a simple road

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
through an impenetrable moral maze.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:06.958
Science is clever, but great creativity is something less knowable,

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:09.958
more magical. And now we need that magic.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
This is a time of need.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:13.958
Our climate is changing quickly, too quickly.

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:16.958
And great creativity is needed to do what it does so well:

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:20.958
to provoke us to think differently with dramatic creative statements.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
To tempt us to act differently

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
with delightful creative scraps.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:28.958
Here is one such scrap from an initiative I'm involved in

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:31.958
using creativity to inspire people to be greener.

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:35.958
(Video) Man: You know, rather than drive today, I'm going to walk.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:39.958
Narrator: And so he walked, and as he walked he saw things.

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:43.958
Strange and wonderful things he would not otherwise have seen.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:46.958
A deer with an itchy leg. A flying motorcycle.

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:51.958
A father and daughter separated from a bicycle by a mysterious wall.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:56.958
And then he stopped. Walking in front of him was her.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
The woman who as a child had skipped with him through fields

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:00.958
and broken his heart.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
Sure, she had aged a little.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:03.958
In fact, she had aged a lot.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
But he felt all his old passion for her return.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
"Ford," he called softly. For that was her name.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.958
"Don't say another word, Gusty," she said,

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:13.958
for that was his name.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:18.958
"I know a tent next to a caravan, exactly 300 yards from here.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:21.958
Let's go there and make love. In the tent."

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:25.958
Ford undressed. She spread one leg, and then the other.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:29.958
Gusty entered her boldly and made love to her rhythmically

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.958
while she filmed him, because she was a keen amateur pornographer.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
The earth moved for both of them.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
And they lived together happily ever after.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:42.958
And all because he decided to walk that day.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:53.958
(Applause)

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.958
Andy Hobsbawm: We've got the science, we've had the debate.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
The moral imperative is on the table.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
Great creativity is needed to take it all,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
make it simple and sharp.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:06.958
To make it connect. To make it make people want to act.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
So this is a call, a plea,

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
to the incredibly talented TED community.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
Let's get creative against climate change.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
And let's do it soon. Thank you.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:15.958
(Applause)

title: The coming neurological epidemic
transcript: Unless we do something to prevent it, over the next 40 years we’re facing an epidemic of neurologic diseases on a global scale. A cheery thought. On this map, every country that’s colored blue has more than 20 percent of its population over the age of 65. This is the world we live in. And this is the world your children will live in. For 12,000 years, the distribution of ages in the human population has looked like a pyramid, with the oldest on top. It’s already flattening out. By 2050, it’s going to be a column and will start to invert. This is why it’s happening. The average lifespan’s more than doubled since 1840, and it’s increasing currently at the rate of about five hours every day. And this is why that’s not entirely a good thing: because over the age of 65, your risk of getting Alzheimer’s or Parkinson’s disease will increase exponentially. By 2050, there’ll be about 32 million people in the United States over the age of 80, and unless we do something about it, half of them will have Alzheimer’s disease and three million more will have Parkinson’s disease. Right now, those and other neurologic diseases — for which we have no cure or prevention — cost about a third of a trillion dollars a year. It will be well over a trillion dollars by 2050. Alzheimer’s disease starts when a protein that should be folded up properly misfolds into a kind of demented origami. So one approach we’re taking is to try to design drugs that function like molecular Scotch tape, to hold the protein into its proper shape. That would keep it from forming the tangles that seem to kill large sections of the brain when they do. Interestingly enough, other neurologic diseases which affect very different parts of the brain also show tangles of misfolded protein, which suggests that the approach might be a general one, and might be used to cure many neurologic diseases, not just Alzheimer’s disease. There’s also a fascinating connection to cancer here, because people with neurologic diseases have a very low incidence of most cancers. And this is a connection that most people aren’t pursuing right now, but which we’re fascinated by. Most of the important and all of the creative work in this area is being funded by private philanthropies. And there’s tremendous scope for additional private help here, because the government has dropped the ball on much of this, I’m afraid. In the meantime, while we’re waiting for all these things to happen, here’s what you can do for yourself. If you want to lower your risk of Parkinson’s disease, caffeine is protective to some extent; nobody knows why. Head injuries are bad for you. They lead to Parkinson’s disease. And the Avian Flu is also not a good idea. As far as protecting yourself against Alzheimer’s disease, well, it turns out that fish oil has the effect of reducing your risk for Alzheimer’s disease. You should also keep your blood pressure down, because chronic high blood pressure is the biggest single risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease. It’s also the biggest risk factor for glaucoma, which is just Alzheimer’s disease of the eye. And of course, when it comes to cognitive effects, "use it or lose it" applies, so you want to stay mentally stimulated. But hey, you’re listening to me. So you’ve got that covered. And one final thing. Wish people like me luck, okay? Because the clock is ticking for all of us. Thank you.
