00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
You know, we're going to do things a little differently.

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:17.958
I'm not going to show you a presentation. I'm going to talk to you.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:22.958
And at the same time, we're going to look at just images

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:27.958
from a photo stream that is pretty close to live of things that --

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:31.958
snapshots from Second Life. So hopefully this will be fascinating.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:35.958
You can -- I can compete for your attention with the strange pictures

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
that you see on screen that come from there.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:42.958
I thought I'd talk a little bit about some just big ideas about this,

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:46.958
and then get John back out here so we can talk interactively

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:50.958
a little bit more and think and ask questions.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:53.958
You know, I guess the first question is,

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:58.958
why build a virtual world at all?

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:02.958
And I think the answer to that is always going to be

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
at least driven to a certain extent by the people

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:09.958
initially crazy enough to start the project, you know.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
So I can give you a little bit of first background just on me

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:17.958
and what moved me as a -- really going back as far as a teenager

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:20.958
and then an adult, to actually try and build this kind of thing.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:29.958
I was a very creative kid who read a lot, and got into electronics first,

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:33.958
and then later, programming computers, when I was really young.

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:37.958
I was just always trying to make things.

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:41.958
I was just obsessed with taking things apart and building things,

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:45.958
and just anything I could do with my hands or with wood

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:48.958
or electronics or metal or anything else.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:52.958
And so, for example -- and it's a great Second Life thing -- I had a bedroom.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
And every kid, you know, as a teenager, has got his bedroom he retreats to --

00:01:55.958 --> 00:02:00.958
but I wanted my door, I thought it would be cool if my door went up

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
rather than opened, like on Star Trek.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
I thought it would be neat to do that. And so I got up in the ceiling

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:10.958
and I cut through the ceiling joists, much to my parents' delight,

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:14.958
and put the door, you know, being pulled up through the ceiling.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:18.958
I built -- I put a garage-door opener up in the attic

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
that would pull this door up.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:25.958
You can imagine the amount of time that it took me to do this to the house

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
and the displeasure of my parents.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
The thing that was always striking to me was that we as people

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:35.958
could have so many really amazing ideas about things we'd like to do,

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:41.958
but are so often unable, in the real world, to actually do those things --

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:44.958
to actually cobble together the materials

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.958
and go through the actual execution phase of building something

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.958
that you imagine from a design perspective.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:52.958
And so for me, I know that when the Internet came around

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.958
and I was doing computer programming and just, you know,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
just generally trying to run my own little company

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
and figure out what to do with the Internet and with computers,

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:07.958
I was just immediately struck by how the ultimate thing

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.958
that you would really want to do with the Internet and with computers

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
would be to use the Internet and connected computers

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:20.958
to simulate a world to sort of recreate the laws of physics

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:24.958
and the rules of how things went together --

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:27.958
the sort of -- the idea of atoms and how to make things,

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:33.958
and do that inside a computer so that we could all get in there and make stuff.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:37.958
And so for me that was the thing that was so enticing.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
I just wanted this place where you could build things.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
And so I think you see that in the genesis

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:47.958
of what has happened with Second Life, and I think it's important.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:53.958
I also think that more generally, the use of the Internet and technology

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:59.958
as a kind of a space between us for creativity and design is a general trend.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
It is a -- sort of a great human progress.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:08.958
Technology is just generally being used to allow us to create

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
in as shared and social a way as possible.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
And I think that Second Life and virtual worlds more generally

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:18.958
represent the best we can do to achieve that right now.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
You know, another way to look at that,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
and related to the content and, you know, thinking about space,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
is to connect sort of virtual worlds to space.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
I thought that might be a fun thing to talk about for a second.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:34.958
If you think about going into space, it's a fascinating thing.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
So many movies, so many kids, we all sort of

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
dream about exploring space. Now, why is that?

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
Stop for a moment and ask, why that conceit?

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:46.958
Why do we as people want to do that?

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
I think there's a couple of things. It's what we see in the movies --

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
you know, it's this dream that we all share.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:56.958
One is that if you went into space you'd be able to begin again.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
In some sense, you would become someone else in that journey,

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:04.958
because there wouldn't be -- you'd leave society and life as you know it, behind.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
And so inevitably, you would transform yourself --

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:11.958
irreversibly, in all likelihood -- as you began this exploration.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:15.958
And then the second thing is that there's this tangible sense

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:21.958
that if you travel far enough, you can find out there --

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
oh, yeah -- you have no idea what you're going to find

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
once you get there, into space.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
It's going to be different than here.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:33.958
And in fact, it's going to be so different than what we see here on earth

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
that anything is going to be possible.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
So that's kind of the idea -- we as humans crave the idea of

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:44.958
creating a new identity and going into a place where anything is possible.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
And I think that if you really sit and think about it,

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:51.958
virtual worlds, and where we're going

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:55.958
with more and more computing technology,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:06:01.958
represent essentially the likely, really tactically possible

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
version of space exploration.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:08.958
We are moved by the idea of virtual worlds because, like space,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:12.958
they allow us to reinvent ourselves and they contain anything

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
and everything, and probably anything could happen there.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
You know, to give you a size idea about scale, you know,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:21.958
comparing space to Second Life, most people don't realize, kind of --

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
and then this is just like the Internet in the early '90s.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
In fact, Second Life virtual worlds are a lot like the Internet in the early '90s today:

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
everybody's very excited,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
there's a lot of hype and excitement about one idea or the next

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
from moment to moment, and then there's despair

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
and everybody thinks the whole thing's not going to work.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
Everything that's happening with Second Life

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
and more broadly with virtual worlds, all happened in the early '90s.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
We always play a game at the office where you can take any article

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:49.958
and find the same article where you just replace the words "Second Life"

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:54.958
with "Web," and "virtual reality" with "Internet."

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
You can find exactly the same articles

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:00.958
written about everything that people are observing.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:07.958
To give you an idea of scale, Second Life is about 20,000 CPUs at this point.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
It's about 20,000 computers connected together

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:13.958
in three facilities in the United States right now,

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:17.958
that are simulating this virtual space. And the virtual space itself --

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:21.958
there's about 250,000 people a day that are wandering around in there,

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:25.958
so the kind of, active population is something like a smallish city.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:29.958
The space itself is about 10 times the size of San Francisco,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
and it's about as densely built out.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
So it gives you an idea of scale. Now, it's expanding very rapidly --

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:39.958
about five percent a month or so right now, in terms of new servers being added.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
And so of course, radically unlike the real world,

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
and like the Internet, the whole thing is expanding

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
very, very quickly, and historically exponentially.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
So that sort of space exploration thing is matched up here

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
by the amount of content that's in there,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
and I think that amount is critical.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
It was critical with the virtual world

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
that it be this space of truly infinite possibility.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
We're very sensitive to that as humans.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
You know, you know when you see it. You know when you can do anything in a space

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
and you know when you can't.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
Second Life today is this 20,000 machines,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.958
and it's about 100 million or so user-created objects where, you know,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
an object would be something like this, possibly interactive.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
Tens of millions of them are thinking all the time;

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
they have code attached to them.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
So it's a really large world already, in terms of the amount of stuff that's there

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
and that's very important.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
If anybody plays, like, World of Warcraft,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
World of Warcraft comes on, like, four DVDs.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:33.958
Second Life, by comparison, has about 100 terabytes

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:38.958
of user-created data, making it about 25,000 times larger.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:42.958
So again, like the Internet compared to AOL,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
and the sort of chat rooms and content on AOL at the time,

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
what's happening here is something very different,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
because the sheer scale of what people can do

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:53.958
when they're enabled to do anything they want is pretty amazing.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:57.958
The last big thought is that it is almost certainly true

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
that whatever this is going to evolve into

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:04.958
is going to be bigger in total usage than the Web itself.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
And let me justify that with two statements.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:11.958
Generically, what we use the Web for is to organize, exchange,

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
create and consume information.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:17.958
It's kind of like Irene talking about Google being data-driven.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
I'd say I kind of think about the world as being information.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
Everything that we interact with, all the experiences that we have,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
is kind of us flowing through a sea of information

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
and interacting with it in different ways.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:34.958
The Web puts information in the form of text and images.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:39.958
The topology, the geography of the Web is text-to-text links for the most part.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
That's one way of organizing information,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:47.958
but there are two things about the way you access information in a virtual world

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
that I think are the important ways that they're very different

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:54.958
and much better than what we've been able to do to date with the Web.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:58.958
The first is that, as I said, the --

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
well, the first difference for virtual worlds is that

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
information is presented to you in the virtual world

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:08.958
using the most powerful iconic symbols

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
that you can possibly use with human beings.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:15.958
So for example, C-H-A-I-R is the English word for that,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:20.958
but a picture of this is a universal symbol.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
Everybody knows what it means. There's no need to translate it.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
It's also more memorable if I show you that picture,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
and I show you C-H-A-I-R on a piece of paper.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
You can do tests that show that you'll remember

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
that I was talking about a chair a couple of days later a lot better.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:38.958
So when you organize information using the symbols of our memory,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:42.958
using the most common symbols that we've been immersed in all our lives,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:46.958
you maximally both excite, stimulate,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
are able to remember, transfer and manipulate data.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
And so virtual worlds are the best way

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:56.958
for us to essentially organize and experience information.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
And I think that's something that people have talked about for 20 years --

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:03.958
you know, that 3D, that lifelike environments

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
are really important in some magical way to us.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:09.958
But the second thing -- and I think this one is less obvious --

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:17.958
is that the experience of creating, consuming, exploring that information

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:22.958
is in the virtual world implicitly and inherently social.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
You are always there with other people.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:31.958
And we as humans are social creatures and must, or are aided by,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:36.958
or enjoy more, the consumption of information in the presence of others.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
It's essential to us. You can't escape it.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:44.958
When you're on Amazon.com and you're looking for digital cameras or whatever,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:50.958
you're on there right now, when you're on the site, with like 5,000 other people,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
but you can't talk to them.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:56.958
You can't just turn to the people that are browsing digital cameras

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
on the same page as you, and ask them,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
"Hey, have you seen one of these before? Because I'm thinking about buying it."

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:06.958
That experience of like, shopping together, just as a simple example,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
is an example of how as social creatures

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
we want to experience information in that way.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:16.958
So that second point, that we inherently experience information together

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
or want to experience it together,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
is critical to essentially, kind of,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:26.958
this trend of where we're going to use technology to connect us.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:31.958
And so I think, again, that it's likely that in the next decade or so

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:36.958
these virtual worlds are going to be the most common way as human beings

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:41.958
that we kind of use the electronics of the Internet, if you will,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:45.958
to be together, to consume information.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
You know, mapping in India -- that's such a great example.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:52.958
Maybe the solution there involves talking to other people in real time.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:57.958
Asking for advice, rather than any possible way

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:01.958
that you could just statically organize a map.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
So I think that's another big point.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
I think that wherever this is all going,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:10.958
whether it's Second Life or its descendants, or something broader

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
that happens all around the world at a lot of different points --

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
this is what we're going to see the Internet used for,

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:20.958
and total traffic and total unique users is going to invert,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:25.958
so that the Web and its bibliographic set of text and graphical information

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
is going to become a tool or a part of that consumption pattern,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:32.958
but the pattern itself is going to happen mostly in this type of an environment.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
Big idea, but I think highly defensible.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
So let me stop there and bring John back,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
and maybe we can just have a longer conversation.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
Thank you. John. That's great.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:49.958
(Applause)

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:53.958
John Hockenberry: Why is the creation, the impulse to create Second Life,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
not a utopian impulse?

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
Like for example, in the 19th century,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:02.958
any number of works of literature that imagined alternative worlds

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
were explicitly utopian.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:08.958
Philip Rosedale: I think that's great. That's such a deep question. Yeah.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:13.958
Is a virtual world likely to be a utopia, would be one way I'd say it.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.958
The answer is no, and I think the reason why is because

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
the Web itself as a good example is profoundly bottoms-up.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:25.958
That idea of infinite possibility, that magic of anything can happen,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
only happens in an environment

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
where you really know that there's a fundamental freedom

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:34.958
at the level of the individual actor, at the level of the Lego blocks,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
if you will, that make up the virtual world.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
You have to have that level of freedom, and so I'm often asked that,

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
you know, is there a, kind of, utopian or,

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
is there a utopian tendency to Second Life and things like it,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
that you would create a world that has a grand scheme to it?

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.958
Those top-down schemes are alienating to just about everybody,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
even if you mean well when you build them.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:58.958
And what's more, human society, when it's controlled,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
when you set out a grand scheme of rules,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:04.958
a new way of people interacting, or a new way of laying out a city, or whatever,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
that stuff historically has never scaled much beyond,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
you know -- I always laughingly say -- the Mall of America, you know,

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
which is like, the largest piece of centrally designed architecture

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
that, you know, has been built.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
JH: The Kremlin was pretty big.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
PR: The Kremlin, yeah. That's true. The whole complex.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:24.958
JH: Give me a story of a tool you created at the beginning

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
in Second Life that you were pretty sure people would want to use

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
in the creation of their avatars or in communicating

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:34.958
that people actually in practice said, no, I'm not interested in that at all,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:39.958
and name something that you didn't come up with

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
that almost immediately people began to demand.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
PR: I'm sure I can think of multiple examples of both of those.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
One of my favorites. I had this feature that I built into Second Life --

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
I was really passionate about it.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.958
It was an ability to kind of walk up close to somebody

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:55.958
and have a more private conversation,

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
but it wasn't instant messaging because you had to sort of befriend somebody.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
It was just this idea that you could kind of have a private chat.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
I just remember it was one of those examples of data-driven design.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
I thought it was such a good idea from my perspective,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
and it was just absolutely never used, and we ultimately --

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
I think we've now turned it off, if I remember.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
We finally gave up, took it out of the code.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:18.958
But more generally, you know, one other example I think about this,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
which is great relative to the utopian idea.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:26.958
Second Life originally had 16 simulators. It now has 20,000.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
So when it only had 16,

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
it was only about as big as this college campus.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:35.958
And we had -- we zoned it, you know: we put a nightclub,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
we put a disco where you could dance,

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:41.958
and then we had a place where you could fight with guns if you wanted to,

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:45.958
and we had another place that was like a boardwalk, kind of a Coney Island.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:48.958
And we laid out the zoning, but of course,

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.958
people could build all around it however they wanted to.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:55.958
And what was so amazing right from the start was that the idea

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:59.958
that we had put out in the zoning concept, basically,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
was instantly and thoroughly ignored,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
and like, two months into the whole thing,

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
-- which is really a small amount of time, even in Second Life time --

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:11.958
I remember the users, the people who were then using Second Life,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:15.958
the residents came to me and said, we want to buy the disco --

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:19.958
because I had built it -- we want to buy that land and raze it

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:22.958
and put houses on it. And I sold it to them --

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
I mean, we transferred ownership and they had a big party

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
and blew up the entire building.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:30.958
And I remember that that was just so telling, you know,

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:32.958
that you didn't know exactly what was going to happen.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:35.958
When you think about stuff that people have built that's popular --

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:38.958
JH: CBGB's has to close eventually, you know. That's the rule.

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:43.958
PR: Exactly. And it -- but it closed on day one, basically, in Internet time.

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
You know, an example of something -- pregnancy.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:50.958
You can have a baby in Second Life.

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:56.958
This is done entirely using, kind of, the tools that are built into Second Life,

00:17:56.958 --> 00:18:00.958
so the innate concept of becoming pregnant and having a baby, of course --

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:05.958
Second Life is, at the platform level, at the level of the company -- at Linden Lab --

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:08.958
Second Life has no game properties to it whatsoever.

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
There is no attempt to structure the experience,

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:13.958
to make it utopian in that sense that we put into it.

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:16.958
So of course, we never would have put a mechanism for having babies or, you know,

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:19.958
taking two avatars and merging them, or something.

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:24.958
But people built the ability to have babies and care for babies

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:28.958
as a purchasable experience that you can have in Second Life and so --

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:31.958
I mean, that's a pretty fascinating example of, you know,

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:33.958
what goes on in the overall economy.

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:35.958
And of course, the existence of an economy is another idea.

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:38.958
I didn't talk about it, but it's a critical feature.

00:18:38.958 --> 00:18:41.958
When people are given the opportunity to create in the world,

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:43.958
there's really two things they want.

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:46.958
One is fair ownership of the things they create.

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:48.958
And then the second one is -- if they feel like it,

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:50.958
and they're not going to do it in every case, but in many they are --

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:54.958
they want to actually be able to sell that creation

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:56.958
as a way of providing for their own livelihood.

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:59.958
True on the Web -- also true in Second Life.

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:01.958
And so the existence of an economy is critical.

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:05.958
JH: Questions for Philip Rosedale? Right here.

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:08.958
(Audience: Well, first an observation, which is that you look like a character.)

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:13.958
JH: The observation is, Philip has been accused of looking like a character,

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:15.958
an avatar, in Second Life.

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:17.958
Respond, and then we'll get the rest of your question.

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:19.958
PR: But I don't look like my avatar.

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:21.958
(Laughter)

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:23.958
How many people here know what my avatar looks like?

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:25.958
That's probably not very many.

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:27.958
JH: Are you ripping off somebody else's avatar with that, sort of --


00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:30.958
PR: No, no. I didn't. One of the other guys at work had a fantastic avatar --

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:33.958
a female avatar -- that I used to be once in a while.

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:39.958
But my avatar is a guy wearing chaps.

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:43.958
Spiky hair -- spikier than this. Kind of orange hair.

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:48.958
Handlebar mustache. Kind of a Village People sort of a character.

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:50.958
So, very cool.

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:52.958
JH: And your question?

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:55.958
(Audience: [Unclear].)

00:19:55.958 --> 00:20:01.958
JH: The question is, there appears to be a lack of cultural fine-tuning in Second Life.

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:03.958
It doesn't seem to have its own culture,

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:05.958
and the sort of differences that exist in the real world

00:20:05.958 --> 00:20:08.958
aren't translated into the Second Life map.

00:20:08.958 --> 00:20:10.958
PR: Well, first of all, we're very early,

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:13.958
so this has only been going on for a few years.

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:16.958
And so part of what we see is the same evolution of human behavior

00:20:16.958 --> 00:20:18.958
that you see in emerging societies.

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:22.958
So a fair criticism -- is what it is -- of Second Life today is that

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:27.958
it's more like the Wild West than it is like Rome, from a cultural standpoint.

00:20:27.958 --> 00:20:33.958
That said, the evolution of, and the nuanced interaction that creates culture,

00:20:33.958 --> 00:20:36.958
is happening at 10 times the speed of the real world,

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:41.958
and in an environment where, if you walk into a bar in Second Life,

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:44.958
65 percent of the people there are not in the United States,

00:20:44.958 --> 00:20:49.958
and in fact are speaking their, you know, various and different languages.

00:20:49.958 --> 00:20:51.958
In fact, one of the ways to make money in Second Life

00:20:51.958 --> 00:20:56.958
is to make really cool translators that you drag onto your body

00:20:56.958 --> 00:20:58.958
and they basically, kind of, pop up on your screen

00:20:58.958 --> 00:21:01.958
and allow you to use Google or Babel Fish

00:21:01.958 --> 00:21:04.958
or one of the other online text translators to on-the-fly

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:09.958
translate spoken -- I'm sorry -- typed text between individuals.

00:21:09.958 --> 00:21:13.958
And so, the multicultural nature and the sort of cultural melting pot

00:21:13.958 --> 00:21:16.958
that's happening inside Second Life is quite --

00:21:16.958 --> 00:21:21.958
I think, quite remarkable relative to what in real human terms

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:23.958
in the real world we've ever been able to achieve.

00:21:23.958 --> 00:21:26.958
So, I think that culture will fine-tune, it will emerge,

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:30.958
but we still have some years to wait while that happens,

00:21:30.958 --> 00:21:32.958
as you would naturally expect.

00:21:32.958 --> 00:21:35.958
JH: Other questions? Right here.

00:21:35.958 --> 00:21:37.958
(Audience: What's your demographic?)

00:21:37.958 --> 00:21:39.958
JH: What's your demographic?

00:21:39.958 --> 00:21:41.958
PR: So, the question is, what's the demographic.

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:46.958
So, the average age of a person in Second Life is 32,

00:21:46.958 --> 00:21:51.958
however, the use of Second Life increases dramatically

00:21:51.958 --> 00:21:56.958
as your physical age increases. So as you go from age 30 to age 60 --

00:21:56.958 --> 00:21:58.958
and there are many people in their sixties using Second Life --

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:03.958
this is also not a sharp curve -- it's very, very distributed --

00:22:03.958 --> 00:22:07.958
usage goes up in terms of, like, hours per week by 40 percent

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:11.958
as you go from age 30 to age 60 in real life, so there's not --

00:22:11.958 --> 00:22:13.958
many people make the mistake of believing that Second Life

00:22:13.958 --> 00:22:18.958
is some kind of an online game. Actually it's generally unappealing --

00:22:18.958 --> 00:22:21.958
I'm just speaking broadly and critically --

00:22:21.958 --> 00:22:23.958
it's not very appealing to people that play online video games,

00:22:23.958 --> 00:22:27.958
because the graphics are not yet equivalent to --

00:22:27.958 --> 00:22:28.958
I mean, these are very nice pictures,

00:22:28.958 --> 00:22:30.958
but in general the graphics are not quite equivalent

00:22:30.958 --> 00:22:34.958
to the fine-tuned graphics that you see in a Grand Theft Auto 4.

00:22:34.958 --> 00:22:37.958
So average age: 32. I mentioned

00:22:37.958 --> 00:22:39.958
65 percent of the users are not in the United States.

00:22:39.958 --> 00:22:42.958
The distribution amongst countries is extremely broad.

00:22:42.958 --> 00:22:45.958
There's users from, you know, virtually every country in the world now in Second Life.

00:22:45.958 --> 00:22:49.958
The dominant ones are -- if you take the UK and Europe,

00:22:49.958 --> 00:22:53.958
together they make up about 55 percent of the usage base in Second Life.

00:22:53.958 --> 00:22:55.958
In terms of psychographic --

00:22:55.958 --> 00:23:00.958
oh, men and women: men and women are almost equally matched in Second Life,

00:23:00.958 --> 00:23:05.958
so about 45 percent of the people online right now on Second Life are women.

00:23:05.958 --> 00:23:07.958
Women use Second Life, though,

00:23:07.958 --> 00:23:10.958
about 30 to 40 percent more, on an hours basis, than men do,

00:23:10.958 --> 00:23:12.958
meaning that more men sign up than women,

00:23:12.958 --> 00:23:15.958
and more women stay and use it than men.

00:23:15.958 --> 00:23:17.958
So that's another demographic fact.

00:23:17.958 --> 00:23:22.958
In terms of psychographic, you know, the people in Second Life

00:23:22.958 --> 00:23:26.958
are remarkably dissimilar relative to what you might think,

00:23:26.958 --> 00:23:28.958
when you go in and talk to them and meet them, and I would, you know,

00:23:28.958 --> 00:23:30.958
challenge you to just do this and find out.

00:23:30.958 --> 00:23:33.958
But it's not a bunch of programmers.

00:23:33.958 --> 00:23:37.958
It's not easy to describe as a demographic.

00:23:37.958 --> 00:23:41.958
If I had to just sort of paint a broad picture, I'd say, remember the people

00:23:41.958 --> 00:23:45.958
who were really getting into eBay in the first few years of eBay?

00:23:45.958 --> 00:23:48.958
Maybe a little bit like that: in other words, people who are early adopters.

00:23:48.958 --> 00:23:51.958
They tend to be creative. They tend to be entrepreneurial.

00:23:51.958 --> 00:23:55.958
A lot of them -- about 55,000 people so far -- are cash-flow positive:

00:23:55.958 --> 00:23:58.958
they're making money from what -- I mean, real-world money --

00:23:58.958 --> 00:24:02.958
from what they're doing in Second Life, so it's a very build --

00:24:02.958 --> 00:24:05.958
still a creative, building things, build-your-own-business

00:24:05.958 --> 00:24:07.958
type of an orientation. So, that's it.

00:24:07.958 --> 00:24:09.958
JH: You describe yourself, Philip, as someone who was really creative

00:24:09.958 --> 00:24:13.958
when you were young and, you know, liked to make things.

00:24:13.958 --> 00:24:16.958
I mean, it's not often that you hear somebody

00:24:16.958 --> 00:24:18.958
describe themselves as really creative.

00:24:18.958 --> 00:24:22.958
I suspect that's possibly a euphemism for C student

00:24:22.958 --> 00:24:25.958
who spent a lot of time in his room? Is it possible?

00:24:25.958 --> 00:24:26.958
(Laughter)

00:24:26.958 --> 00:24:30.958
PR: I was a -- there were times I was a C student. You know, it's funny.

00:24:30.958 --> 00:24:32.958
When I got to college -- I studied physics in college --

00:24:32.958 --> 00:24:34.958
and I got really -- it was funny,

00:24:34.958 --> 00:24:39.958
because I was definitely a more antisocial kid. I read all the time.

00:24:39.958 --> 00:24:44.958
I was shy. I don't seem like it now, but I was very shy.

00:24:44.958 --> 00:24:46.958
Moved around a bunch -- had that experience too.

00:24:46.958 --> 00:24:49.958
So I did, kind of, I think, live in my own world,

00:24:49.958 --> 00:24:52.958
and obviously that helps, you know, engage your real interest in something.

00:24:52.958 --> 00:24:55.958
JH: So you're on your fifth life at this point?

00:24:55.958 --> 00:25:01.958
PR: If you count, yeah, cities. So -- but I did --

00:25:01.958 --> 00:25:05.958
and I didn't do -- I think I didn't do as well in school as I could have. I think you're right.

00:25:05.958 --> 00:25:09.958
I wasn't, like, an obsessed -- you know, get A's kind of guy.

00:25:09.958 --> 00:25:11.958
I was going to say, I had a great social experience

00:25:11.958 --> 00:25:13.958
when I went to college that I hadn't had before,

00:25:13.958 --> 00:25:16.958
a more fraternal experience, where I met six or seven other guys

00:25:16.958 --> 00:25:19.958
who I studied physics with, and I was very competitive with them,

00:25:19.958 --> 00:25:23.958
so then I started to get A's. But you're right: I wasn't an A student.

00:25:23.958 --> 00:25:25.958
JH: Last question. Right here.

00:25:25.958 --> 00:25:28.958
(Audience: In the pamphlet, there's a statement -- )

00:25:28.958 --> 00:25:30.958
JH: You want to paraphrase that?

00:25:30.958 --> 00:25:32.958
PR: Yeah, so let me restate that.

00:25:32.958 --> 00:25:35.958
So, you're saying that in the pamphlet there's a statement

00:25:35.958 --> 00:25:39.958
that we may come to prefer our digital selves to our real ones --

00:25:39.958 --> 00:25:43.958
our more malleable or manageable digital identities to our real identities --

00:25:43.958 --> 00:25:46.958
and that in fact, much of human life and human experience

00:25:46.958 --> 00:25:49.958
may move into the digital realm.

00:25:49.958 --> 00:25:52.958
And then that's kind of a horrifying thought, of course.

00:25:52.958 --> 00:25:56.958
That's a frightening change, frightening disruption.

00:25:56.958 --> 00:25:59.958
I guess, and you're asking, what do I think about that? How do I --

00:25:59.958 --> 00:26:01.958
JH: What's your response to the people who would say, that's horrifying?

00:26:01.958 --> 00:26:03.958
(Audience: If someone would say to you, I find that disturbing,

00:26:03.958 --> 00:26:05.958
what would be your response?)

00:26:05.958 --> 00:26:08.958
PR: Well, I'd say a couple of things.

00:26:08.958 --> 00:26:11.958
One is, it's disturbing like the Internet or electricity was.

00:26:11.958 --> 00:26:15.958
That is to say, it's a big change, but it isn't avoidable.

00:26:15.958 --> 00:26:20.958
So, no amount of backpedaling or intentional behavior

00:26:20.958 --> 00:26:23.958
or political behavior is going to keep these technology changes

00:26:23.958 --> 00:26:25.958
from connecting us together,

00:26:25.958 --> 00:26:27.958
because the basic motive that people have --

00:26:27.958 --> 00:26:31.958
to be creative and entrepreneurial -- is going to drive energy

00:26:31.958 --> 00:26:34.958
into these virtual worlds in the same way that it has with the Web.

00:26:34.958 --> 00:26:39.958
So this change, I believe, is a huge disruptive change.

00:26:39.958 --> 00:26:43.958
Obviously, I'm the optimist and a big believer in what's going on here,

00:26:43.958 --> 00:26:47.958
but I think that as -- even a sober, you know, the most sober,

00:26:47.958 --> 00:26:50.958
disconnected thinker about this, looking at it from the side,

00:26:50.958 --> 00:26:52.958
has to conclude, based on the data,

00:26:52.958 --> 00:26:54.958
that with those kinds of economic forces at play,

00:26:54.958 --> 00:26:57.958
there is definitely going to be a sea change,

00:26:57.958 --> 00:27:00.958
and that change is going to be intensely disruptive

00:27:00.958 --> 00:27:04.958
relative to our concept of our very lives and being,

00:27:04.958 --> 00:27:06.958
and our identities, as well.

00:27:06.958 --> 00:27:08.958
I don't think we can get away from those changes.

00:27:08.958 --> 00:27:11.958
I think generally, we were talking about this --

00:27:11.958 --> 00:27:17.958
I think that generally being present in a virtual world and being challenged by it,

00:27:17.958 --> 00:27:21.958
being -- surviving there, having a good life there, so to speak,

00:27:21.958 --> 00:27:24.958
is a challenge because of the multiculturality of it,

00:27:24.958 --> 00:27:29.958
because of the languages, because of the entrepreneurial richness of it,

00:27:29.958 --> 00:27:32.958
the sort of flea market nature, if you will, of the virtual world today.

00:27:32.958 --> 00:27:38.958
It puts challenges on us to rise to. We must be better than ourselves, in many ways.

00:27:38.958 --> 00:27:41.958
We must learn things and, you know, be more tolerant,

00:27:41.958 --> 00:27:47.958
and be smarter and learn faster and be more creative, perhaps,

00:27:47.958 --> 00:27:49.958
than we are typically in our real lives.

00:27:49.958 --> 00:27:51.958
And I think that if that is true of virtual worlds,

00:27:51.958 --> 00:27:55.958
then these changes, though scary -- and, I say, inevitable --

00:27:55.958 --> 00:27:57.958
are ultimately for the better,

00:27:57.958 --> 00:28:00.958
and therefore something that we should ride out.

title: The future of cars
transcript: People love their automobiles. They allow us to go where we want to when we want to. They're a form of entertainment, they're a form of art, a pride of ownership. Songs are written about cars. Prince wrote a great song: "Little Red Corvette." He didn't write "Little Red Laptop Computer" or "Little Red Dirt Devil." He wrote about a car. One of my favorites has always been: "Make Love to Your Man in a Chevy Van," because that was my vehicle when I was in college.The fact is, when we do our market research around the world, we see there's a nearly universal aspiration on the part of people to own an automobile — 750 million people in the world today own a car. And you say, boy, that's a lot. But you know what? That's just 12 percent of the population. We really have to ask the question: Can the world sustain that number of automobiles? And if you look at projections over the next 10 to 15 to 20 years, it looks like the world car park could grow to on the order of 1.1 billion vehicles. If you park those end to end and wrap them around the Earth, that would stretch around the Earth 125 times.Now, we've made great progress with automobile technology over the last 100 years. Cars are dramatically cleaner, dramatically safer, more efficient and radically more affordable than they were 100 years ago. But the fact remains: the fundamental DNA of the automobile has stayed pretty much the same. If we were to reinvent the automobile today, rather than 100 years ago, knowing what we know about the issues associated with our product and about the technologies that exist today, what would we do?We wanted something that was really affordable. The fuel cell looked great: one-tenth as many moving parts, a fuel-cell propulsion system as an internal combustion engine, and it emits just water. And we wanted to take advantage of Moore's Law with electronic controls and software, and we absolutely wanted our car to be connected. So we embarked upon the reinvention around an electrochemical engine, the fuel cell, and hydrogen as the energy carrier. First was Autonomy. Autonomy really set the vision for where we wanted to head. We embodied all of the key components of a fuel-cell propulsion system. We then had Autonomy drivable with Hy-Wire, and we showed Hy-Wire here at this conference last year. Hy-Wire is the world's first drivable fuel cell, and we have followed up that now with Sequel. And Sequel truly is a real car. So if we could run the video —(Futuristic music)[Reinventing the Automobile](Video) It truly is my great pleasure to introduce Sequel.[Acceleration][Cruising][Steering][Braking]But the real key question I'm sure that's on your mind: Where is the hydrogen going to come from? And secondly, when are these kinds of cars going to be available? So let me talk about hydrogen first. The beauty of hydrogen is it can come from so many different sources: it can come from fossil fuels, it can come from any way that you can create electricity, including renewables. And it can come from biofuels. And that's quite exciting. The vision here is to have each local community play to its natural strength in creating the hydrogen. A lot of hydrogen is produced today in the world. It's produced to get sulfur out of gasoline — which I find is somewhat ironic. It's produced in the fertilizer industry; it's produced in the chemical manufacturing industry. That hydrogen is being made because there's a good business reason for its use. But it tells us that we know how to create it, we know how to create it cost-effectively, we know how to handle it safely.We did an analysis where you would have a station in each city with each of the 100 largest cities in the United States, and located the stations so you'd be no more than two miles from a station at any time. We put one every 25 miles on the freeway, and it turns out that translates into about 12,000 stations. And at a million dollars each, that would be about 12 billion dollars. That's a lot of money. But if you built the Alaskan pipeline today, that's half of what the Alaskan pipeline would cost. But the real exciting vision that we see, truly, is home refueling, much like recharging your laptop or recharging your cell phone. So we're pretty excited about the future of hydrogen. We think it's a question of not whether, but a question of when.What we've targeted for ourselves — and we're making great progress toward this goal — is to have a propulsion system based on hydrogen and fuel cells, designed and validated, that can go head-to-head with the internal combustion engine. We're talking about obsoleting the internal combustion engine, and doing it in terms of affordability at scale volumes, its performance and its durability. So that's what we're driving to for 2010. We haven't seen anything yet in our development work that says that isn't possible. We actually think the future is going to be event-driven. So since we can't predict the future, we want to spend a lot of our time trying to create that future.I'm very, very intrigued by the fact that our cars and trucks sit idle 90 percent of the time: they're parked all around us. They're usually parked within 100 feet of the people that own them. Now, if you take the power-generating capability of an automobile and you compare that to the electric grid in the United States, it turns out that the power in four percent of the automobiles equals that of the electric grid of the US. That's a huge power-generating capability, a mobile power-generating capability. And hydrogen and fuel cells give us that opportunity to actually use our cars and trucks when they're parked to generate electricity for the grid.We talked about swarm networks earlier. Talk about the ultimate swarm — having all of the processors and all of the cars when they're sitting idle being part of a global grid for computing capability. We find that premise quite exciting. The automobile becomes, then, an appliance — not in a commodity sense, but an appliance, mobile power, mobile platform for information and computing and communication, as well as a form of transportation.And the key to all of this is to make it affordable, to make it exciting, to get it on a pathway where there's a way to make money doing it. And again, this is a pretty big march to take here. A lot of people say: How do you sleep at night when you're wrestling with a problem of that magnitude? I tell them I sleep like a baby: I wake up crying every two hours.(Laughter)Actually, the theme of this conference, I think, has hit on one of the major keys to pull that off, and that's relationships and working together. Thank you very much.(Applause)Chris Anderson: Larry, Larry — wait, wait, wait. Larry, wait one sec. I've got so many questions I could ask you. I just want to ask one. You know, I could be wrong about this, but my sense is that in the public mind today, GM is not viewed as as serious about some of these environmental ideas as some of your Japanese competitors, maybe even as Ford. Are you serious about it, and not just, you know, when the consumers want it, when the regulators force us to do it, we will go there? Will you guys really try and show leadership on this?Larry Burns: Absolutely. We're absolutely serious. We're into this over a billion dollars already, so I would hope people would think we're serious when we're spending that kind of money. And secondly, it's a fundamental business proposition. I'll be honest with you; we're into it for business growth opportunities. We can't grow our business unless we solve these problems. The growth of the auto industry will be capped by sustainability issues if we don't solve the problems. And there's a simple principle of strategy that says: Do unto yourself before others do unto you. If we can see this possible future, others can, too. And we want to be the first one to create it, Chris.

title: Demo: The Orb
transcript: In 1962, Buckminster Fuller presented the particularly audacious proposal for the Geoscope. It was a 200-foot diameter geodesic sphere to be suspended over the East River in New York City, in full view of the United Nations. It was a big idea, for sure, and it was one that he felt could truly inform and deeply affect the decision making of this body through animations of global data, trends and other information regarding the globe, on this sphere. And today, 45 years later, we clearly have no less need for this kind of clarity and perspective, but what we do have is improved technology.Today we don't need one million light bulbs to create a spherical display. We can use LEDs. LEDs are smaller, they're cheaper, they're longer lasting, they're more efficient. Most importantly for this, they're faster. And this speed, combined with today's high-performance micro-controllers, allows us to actually simulate, in this piece, over 17,000 LEDs — using just 64. And the way this happens is through the phenomenon of persistence of vision. But as this ring rotates at about 1,700 rpm — that's 28 times per second. The equator's speed is actually about 60 miles per hour. There are four on-board micro-controllers that, each time this ring rotates it, as it passes the rear of the display, it picks up a position signal. And from that, the on-board micro-controllers can extrapolate the position of the ring at all points around the revolution and display arbitrary bitmap images and animations.But this is really just the beginning. In addition to higher resolution versions of this display, my father and I are working on a new patent-pending design for a fully volumetric display using the same phenomenon. It achieves this by rotating LEDs about two axes. So as you can see here, this is a, eleven-inch diameter circuit board. These blocks represent LEDs. And so you could see that as this disc rotates about this axis, it will create a disc of light that we can control. That's nothing new: that's a propeller clock; that's the rims that you can buy for your car. But what is new is that, when we rotate this disc about this axis, this disc of light actually becomes a sphere of light. And so we can control that with micro-controllers and create a fully volumetric, three-dimensional display with just 256 LEDs.Now this piece is currently in process — due out in May — but what we've done is we've put together a small demo, just to show the geometric translation of points into a sphere. I've got a little video to show you, but keep in mind that this is with no electronic control, and this is also with only four LEDs. This is actually only about 1.5 percent of what the final display will be in May. So, take a look. And here you can see it's rotating about the vertical axis only, creating circles. And then, as the other axis kicks in, those actually blur into a volume. And the shutter speed of the camera actually makes it slightly less effective in this case.But this piece is due out in May. It'll be on display at the Interactive Telecommunications Spring Show in Greenwich Village in New York City — that's open to the public, definitely invite you all to come and attend — it's a fantastic show. There are hundreds of student innovators with fantastic projects. This piece, actually, will be on display down in the Sierra Simulcast Lounge in the breaks between now and the end of the show. 00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:14.958
In 1962, Buckminster Fuller

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:18.958
presented the particularly audacious proposal for the Geoscope.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:21.958
It was a 200-foot diameter geodesic sphere

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:26.958
to be suspended over the East River in New York City, in full view of the United Nations.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:32.958
It was a big idea, for sure, and it was one that he felt could truly inform

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:36.958
and deeply affect the decision making of this body

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:40.958
through animations of global data, trends

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:44.958
and other information regarding the globe, on this sphere.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
And today, 45 years later,

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:50.958
we clearly have no less need for this kind of clarity and perspective,

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:53.958
but what we do have is improved technology.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:56.958
Today we don't need one million light bulbs to create a spherical display.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.958
We can use LEDs.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:03.958
LEDs are smaller, they're cheaper, they're longer lasting, they're more efficient.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
Most importantly for this, they're faster.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:09.958
And this speed, combined with today's high-performance micro-controllers,

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
allows us to actually simulate, in this piece,

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:16.958
over 17,000 LEDs -- using just 64.

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:21.958
And the way this happens is through the phenomenon of persistence of vision.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:25.958
But as this ring rotates at about 1,700 rpm -- that's 28 times per second.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:29.958
The equator's speed is actually about 60 miles per hour.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
There are four on-board micro-controllers

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
that, each time this ring rotates

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
it, as it passes the rear of the display,

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
it picks up a position signal.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
And from that, the on-board micro-controllers

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:45.958
can extrapolate the position of the ring at all points around the revolution

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:48.958
and display arbitrary bitmap images and animations.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:51.958
But this is really just the beginning.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
In addition to higher resolution versions of this display,

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:57.958
my father and I are working on a new patent-pending design

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:00.958
for a fully volumetric display using the same phenomenon.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
It achieves this by rotating LEDs about two axes.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
So as you can see here, this is a, eleven-inch diameter circuit board.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:08.958
These blocks represent LEDs.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:12.958
And so you could see that as this disc rotates about this axis,

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
it will create a disc of light that we can control.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
That's nothing new: that's a propeller clock;

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
that's the rims that you can buy for your car.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:25.958
But what is new is that, when we rotate this disc about this axis,

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:28.958
this disc of light actually becomes a sphere of light.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
And so we can control that with micro-controllers

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:36.958
and create a fully volumetric, three-dimensional display with just 256 LEDs.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
Now this piece is currently in process --

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:43.958
due out in May -- but what we've done is we've put together a small demo,

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:47.958
just to show the geometric translation of points into a sphere.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.958
I've got a little video to show you,

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:53.958
but keep in mind that this is with no electronic control,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
and this is also with only four LEDs.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
This is actually only about 1.5 percent of what the final display will be in May.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
So, take a look.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:06.958
And here you can see it's rotating about the vertical axis only, creating circles.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
And then, as the other axis kicks in,

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
those actually blur into a volume.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
And the shutter speed of the camera

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
actually makes it slightly less effective in this case.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
But this piece is due out in May.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
It'll be on display at the Interactive Telecommunications Spring Show

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
in Greenwich Village in New York City -- that's open to the public,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:30.958
definitely invite you all to come and attend -- it's a fantastic show.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:34.958
There are hundreds of student innovators with fantastic projects.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
This piece, actually, will be on display

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
down in the Sierra Simulcast Lounge

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
in the breaks between now and the end of the show.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
So I'd love to talk to you all, and invite you

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
to come down and take a closer look.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
It's an honor to be here. Thanks very much.

title: The joyful tradition of mountain music
transcript: This is Aunt Zip from Sodom, North Carolina. She was 105 years old when I took this picture. She was always saying things that made me stop and think, like, "Time may be a great healer, but it ain't no beauty specialist." (Laughter) She said, "Be good to your friends. Why, without them, you'd be a total stranger." (Laughter)This is one of her songs. Let's see if we can get into the flow here and all do this one together. And I'm going to have Michael Manring play bass with me. Give him a big old hand. (Applause)One, two, three, four.(Music)Well, my true love's a black-eyed daisy; if I don't see her, I go crazy.My true love lives up the river; a few more jumps and I'll be with her.Hey, hey, black-eyed Susie! Hey, hey, black-eyed Susie! Hey, hey black-eyed Susie, hey.Now you've got to picture Aunt Zip at 105 years old in Sodom, North Carolina. I'd go up and learn these old songs from her. She couldn't sing much, couldn't play anymore. And I'd pull her out on the front porch. Down below, there was her grandson plowing the tobacco field with a mule. A double outhouse over here on the side. And we'd sing this old song. She didn't have a whole lot of energy, so I'd sing, "Hey, hey!" and she'd just answer back with, "Black-eyed Susie."Oh, hey, hey, black-eyed Susie! Hey, hey, black-eyed Susie! Hey, hey, black-eyed Susie, hey.Well, she and I went blackberry picking. She got mad; I took a licking.Ducks on the millpond, geese in the ocean, Devil in the pretty girl when she takes a notion.Hey, hey, black-eyed Susie! Hey, hey, black-eyed Susie! Hey, hey black-eyed Susie, hey.Let's have the banjo.Well, we'll get married next Thanksgiving. I'll lay around; she'll make a living.She'll cook blackjacks, I'll cook gravy; we'll have chicken someday, maybe.Hey, hey, hey, hey. Hey, hey, black-eyed Susie, hey!One more time now. Oh, hey, hey, black-eyed Susie! Hey, hey, black-eyed Susie! Hey, hey, black-eyed Susie, hey.(Applause) Thank you, Michael.This is Ralph Stanley. When I was going to college at University of California at Santa Barbara in the College of Creative Studies, taking majors in biology and art, he came to the campus. This was in 1968, I guess it was. And he played his bluegrass style of music, but near the end of the concert, he played the old timing style of banjo picking that came from Africa, along with the banjo. It's called claw-hammer style, that he had learned from his mother and grandmother. I fell in love with that. I went up to him and said, how can I learn that? He said, well, you can go back to Clinch Mountain, where I'm from, or Asheville or Mount Airy, North Carolina — some place that has a lot of music. Because there's a lot of old people still living that play that old style.So I went back that very summer. I just fell in love with the culture and the people. And you know, I came back to school, I finished my degrees and told my parents I wanted to be a banjo player. You can imagine how excited they were.So I thought I would just like to show you some of the pictures I've taken of some of my mentors. Just a few of them, but maybe you'll get just a little hint of some of these folks.And play a little banjo. Let's do a little medley. (Music)(Applause) Those last few pictures were of Ray Hicks, who just passed away last year. He was one of the great American folk tale-tellers. The Old Jack tales that he had learned — he talked like this, you could hardly understand him. But it was really wonderful. And he lived in that house that his great-grandfather had built. No running water, no electricity. A wonderful, wonderful guy.And you can look at more pictures. I've actually got a website that's got a bunch of photos that I've done of some of the other folks I didn't get a chance to show you. This instrument came up in those pictures. It's called the mouth bow. It is definitely the first stringed instrument ever in the world, and still played in the Southern mountains. Now, the old timers didn't take a fancy guitar string and make anything like this. They would just take a stick and a catgut and string it up. It was hard on the cats, but it made a great little instrument. It sounds something like this.(Music) Well, have you heard the many stories told by young and old with joy about the many deeds of daring that were done by the Johnson boys?You take Kate, I'll take Sal; we'll both have a Johnson gal. You take Kate, I'll take Sal; we'll both have a Johnson gal.Now, they were scouts in the rebels' army, they were known both far and wide.When the Yankees saw them coming, they'd lay down their guns and hide.You take Kate, I'll take Sal; we'll both have a Johnson gal. You take Kate, I'll take Sal; we'll both have a Johnson gal.Ain't that a sound? (Applause)Well, it was 1954, I guess it was. We were driving in the car outside of Gatesville, Texas, where I grew up in the early part of my life. Outside of Gatesville we were coming back from the grocery store. My mom was driving; my brother and I were in the back seat. We were really mad at my mom. We looked out the window. We were surrounded by thousands of acres of cotton fields. You see, we'd just been to the grocery store, and my mom refused to buy us the jar of Ovaltine that had the coupon for the Captain Midnight decoder ring in it. And, buddy, that made us mad. Well, my mom didn't put up with much either, and she was driving, and she said, "You boys! You think you can have anything you want. You don't know how hard it is to earn money. Your dad works so hard. You think money grows on trees. You've never worked a day in your lives. You boys make me so mad. You're going to get a job this summer."She pulled the car over; she said, "Get out of the car." My brother and I stepped out of the car. We were standing on the edge of thousands of acres of cotton. There were about a hundred black folks out there picking. My mom grabbed us by the shoulders. She marched us out in the field. She went up to the foreman; she said, "I've got these two little boys never worked a day in their lives." Of course, we were just eight and 10. (Laughter) She said, "Would you put them to work?" Well, that must have seemed like a funny idea to that foreman: put these two middle-class little white boys out in a cotton field in August in Texas — it's hot. So he gave us each a cotton sack, about 10 feet long, about that big around, and we started picking. Now, cotton is soft but the outside of the plant is just full of stickers. And if you don't know what you're doing, your hands are bleeding in no time. And my brother and I started to pick it, and our hands were startin' to bleed, and then — "Mom!" And Mom was just sitting by the car like this. She wasn't going to give up.Well, the foreman could see he was in over his head, I guess. He kind of just snuck up behind us and he sang out in a low voice. He just sang: "Well, there's a long white robe in heaven, I know. Don't want it to leave me behind. Well, there's a long white robe in heaven, I know. Don't want it to leave me behind." And from all around as people started singing and answering back, he sang: "Good news, good news: Chariot's coming. Good news: Chariot's coming. Good news: Chariot's coming. And I don't want it to leave me behind." Now, my brother and I had never heard anything like that in our whole lives. It was so beautiful. We sat there all day picking cotton, without complaining, without crying, while they sang things like: "Oh, Mary, don't you weep, don't you moan" and "Wade in the water," and "I done done," "This little light of mine."Finally, by the end of the day, we'd each picked about a quarter of a bag of cotton. But the foreman was kind enough to give us each a check for a dollar, but my mother would never let us cash it. I'm 57; still have the check. Now, my mother hoped that we learned from that the value of hard work. But if you have children, you know it doesn't often work that way. No, we learned something else. The first thing I learned that day was that I never ever wanted to work that hard again. (Laughter) And pretty much never did. But I also learned that some people in this world do have to work that hard every day, and that was an eye-opener. And I also learned that a great song can make hard work go a little easier. And it also can bring the group together in a way that nothing else can.Now, I was just a little eight-year-old boy that day when my mama put me out of the car in that hot Texas cotton field. I wasn't even aware of music — not even aware of it. But that day in the cotton field out there picking, when those people started singing, I realized I was in the very heart of real music, and that's where I've wanted to be ever since.Try this old song with me. I sing: Well, there's a long white robe in heaven, I know.You sing: Don't want it to leave me behind. Well, there's a long white robe in heaven, I know. Don't want it to leave me behind.Good news, good news: Chariot's coming. Good news: Chariot's coming. Good news: Chariot's coming. And I don't want it to leave me —It's been a while since you guys have been picking your last bale of cotton, isn't it? Let's try it one more time.There's a starry crown in heaven, I know. Don't want it to leave me behind. There's a starry crown in heaven, I know. Don't want it to leave me behind.Good news: Chariot's coming. Good news: Chariot's coming. Good news: Chariot's coming. And I don't want it to leave me behind.It was a few years ago, but I sort of remembered this story, and I told it at a concert. My mom was in the audience. After the — she was glad to have a story about herself, of course, but after the concert she came up and she said, "David, I've got to tell you something. I set that whole thing up. I set it up with the foreman. I set it up with the owner of the land. I just wanted you boys to learn the value of hard work. I didn't know it was going to make you fall in love with music though."Let's try. Good news: Chariot's coming. Good news: Chariot's coming. Good news: Chariot's coming. And I don't want it to leave me behind. (Applause)Well, this is the steel guitar. It's an American-made instrument. It was originally made by the Dopyera Brothers, who later on made the Dobro, which is a wood-bodied instrument with a metal cone for — where the sound comes from. It's usually played flat on your lap. It was made to play Hawaiian music back in the 1920s, before they had electric guitars, trying to make a loud guitar. And then African-American folks figured out you could take a broken bottle neck, just like that — a nice Merlot works very well. That wine we had yesterday would have been perfect. Break it off, put it on your finger, and slide into the notes. This instrument pretty much saved my life.Fifteen years ago, 14 years ago, I guess, this year, my wife and I lost our daughter, Sarah Jane, in a car accident, and it was the most — it almost took me out — it almost took me out of this world. And I think I learned a lot about what happiness was by going through such unbelievable grief, just standing on the edge of that abyss and just wanting to jump in. I had to make lists of reasons to stay alive. I had to sit down and make lists, because I was ready to go; I was ready to check out of this world. And you know, at the top of the list, of course, were Jenny, and my son, Zeb, my parents — I didn't want to hurt them. But then, when I thought about it beyond that, it was very simple things. I didn't care about — I had a radio show, I have a radio show on public radio, "Riverwalk," I didn't care about that. I didn't care about awards or money or anything. Nothing. Nothing. On the list it would be stuff like, seeing the daffodils bloom in the spring, the smell of new-mown hay, catching a wave and bodysurfing, the touch of a baby's hand, the sound of Doc Watson playing the guitar, listening to old records of Muddy Waters and Uncle Dave Macon. And for me, the sound of a steel guitar, because one of my parents' neighbors just gave me one of these things. And I would sit around with it, and I didn't know how to play it, but I would just play stuff as sad as I could play. And it was the only instrument that, of all the ones that I play, that would really make that connection. This is a song that came out of that.(Music) Well, I hear you're having trouble. Lord, I hate to hear that news. If you want to talk about it, you know, I will listen to you through.Words no longer say it; let me tell you what I always do. I just break off another bottleneck and play these steel guitar blues.People say, "Oh, snap out of it!" Oh yeah, that's easier said than done. While you can hardly move, they're running around having all kinds of fun.Sometimes I think it's better just to sink way down in your funky mood 'til you can rise up humming these steel guitar blues.Now, you can try to keep it all inside with drink and drugs and cigarettes, but you know that's not going to get you where you want to get.But I got some medicine here that just might shake things loose. Call me in the morning after a dose of these steel guitar blues. Open up now. (Applause)Oh, I think I've got time to tell you about this. My dad was an inventor. We moved to California when Sputnik went up, in 1957. And he was working on gyroscopes; he has a number of patents for that kind of thing. And we moved across the street from Michael and John Whitney. They were about my age. John went on, and Michael did too, to become some of the inventors of computer animation. Michael's dad was working on something called the computer. This was 1957, I was a little 10-year-old kid; I didn't know what that was. But he took me down to see one, you know, what they were making. It was like a library, just full of vacuum tubes as far as you could see, just floors and floors of these things, and one of the engineers said, some day you're going to be able to put this thing in your pocket. I thought, damn, those are going to be some big pants! (Laughter)So that Christmas — maybe I've got time for this — that Christmas I got the Mister Wizard Fun-o-Rama chemistry set. Well, I wanted to be an inventor just like my dad; so did Michael. His great-granddad had been Eli Whitney, the inventor of the cotton gin. So we looked in that — this was a commercial chemistry set. It had three chemicals we were really surprised to see: sulfur, potassium nitrate and charcoal. Man, we were only 10, but we knew that made gunpowder. We made up a little batch and we put it on the driveway and we threw a match and phew, it flared up. Ah, it was great.Well, obviously the next thing to do was build a cannon. So we went over into Michael's garage — his dad had all kinds of stuff, and we put a pipe in the vice there, and screwed a cap on the end of the pipe, drilled a hole in the back of the pipe, took some of our firecrackers, pulled out the fuses, tied them together, put them in the back there, and — down in that hole — and then stuffed some of our gunpowder down that pipe and put three ball bearings on the top, in the garage. (Laughter) We weren't stupid: we put up a sheet of plywood about five feet in front of it. We stood back, we lit that thing, and they flew out of there — they went through that plywood like it was paper. Through the garage. Two of them landed in the side door of his new Citroen. (Laughter) We tore everything down and buried it in his backyard. That was Pacific Palisades; it probably is still there, back there.Well, my brother heard that we had made gunpowder. He and his buddies, they were older, and they were pretty mean. They said they were going to beat us up if we didn't make some gunpowder for them. We said, well, what are you going to do with it? They said, we're going to melt it down and make rocket fuel. (Laughter) Sure. We'll make you a big batch. (Laughter) So we made them a big batch, and it was in my — now, we'd just moved here. We'd just moved to California. Mom had redone the kitchen; Mom was gone that day. We had a pie tin. It became Chris Berquist's job to do the melting down. Michael and I were standing way at the side of the kitchen. He said, "Yeah, hey, it's melting. Yeah, the sulfur's melting. No problem. Yeah, you know." It just flared up, and he turned around, and he looked like this. No hair, no eyelashes, no nothing. There were big welts all over my mom's kitchen cabinet; the air was the just full of black smoke. She came home, she took that chemistry set away, and we never saw it again. But we thought of it often, because every time she'd cook tuna surprise it made — tasted faintly of gunpowder.So I like to invent things too, and I think I'll close out my set with something I invented a good while back. When drum machines were new, I got to thinking, why couldn't you take the oldest form of music, the hambone rhythms, and combine it with the newest technology? I call this Thunderwear. At that time, drum triggers were new. And so I put them all together and sewed 12 of them in this suit. I showed you some of the hambone rhythms yesterday; I'm going to be doing some of the same ones. I have a trigger here, trigger here, here, here. Right there. It's going to really hurt if I don't take that off. Okay. Now, the drum triggers go out my tail here, into the drum machine, and they can make various sounds, like drums. So let me put them all together. And also, I can change the sounds by stepping on this pedal right here, and — let me just close out here by doing you a little hambone solo or something like this.Thank you, folks. (Applause)

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
