00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
This is Ralph Stanley.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.958
When I was going to college at University of California

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
at Santa Barbara in the College of Creative Studies,

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:12.958
taking majors in biology and art, he came to the campus.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
This was in 1968, I guess it was.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
And he played his bluegrass style of music,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:21.958
but near the end of the concert, he played the old timing style of banjo picking

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
that came from Africa, along with the banjo.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
It's called claw-hammer style, that he had learned from his mother and grandmother.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
I fell in love with that.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
I went up to him and said, how can I learn that?

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
He said, well, you can go back to Clinch Mountain, where I'm from,

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
or Asheville or Mount Airy, North Carolina --

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
some place that has a lot of music.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
Because there's a lot of old people still living that play that old style.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
So I went back that very summer.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
I just fell in love with the culture and the people.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:50.958
And you know, I came back to school, I finished my degrees

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:53.958
and told my parents I wanted to be a banjo player.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.958
You can imagine how excited they were.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
So I thought I would just like to show you some of the pictures

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
I've taken of some of my mentors.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:06.958
Just a few of them, but maybe you'll get just a little hint of some of these folks.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:10.958
And play a little banjo. Let's do a little medley.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:05:45.958
(Music)

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:54.958
(Applause)

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
Those last few pictures were of Ray Hicks, who just passed away last year.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:01.958
He was one of the great American folk tale-tellers.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
The Old Jack tales that he had learned -- he talked like this,

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
you could hardly understand him. But it was really wonderful.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:11.958
And he lived in that house that his great-grandfather had built.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:15.958
No running water, no electricity. A wonderful, wonderful guy.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
And you can look at more pictures.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
I've actually got a website that's got a bunch of photos that I've done

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
of some of the other folks I didn't get a chance to show you.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
This instrument came up in those pictures. It's called the mouth bow.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
It is definitely the first stringed instrument ever in the world,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:33.958
and still played in the Southern mountains.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:38.958
Now, the old timers didn't take a fancy guitar string and make anything like this.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:43.958
They would just take a stick and a catgut and string it up.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
It was hard on the cats, but it made a great little instrument.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
It sounds something like this.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:05.958
Well, it was 1954, I guess it was.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
We were driving in the car outside of Gatesville, Texas,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
where I grew up in the early part of my life.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
Outside of Gatesville we were coming back from the grocery store.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
My mom was driving; my brother and I were in the back seat.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
We were really mad at my mom. We looked out the window.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
We were surrounded by thousands of acres of cotton fields.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
You see, we'd just been to the grocery store,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:28.958
and my mom refused to buy us the jar of Ovaltine

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:32.958
that had the coupon for the Captain Midnight decoder ring in it.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
And, buddy, that made us mad.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
Well, my mom didn't put up with much either, and she was driving, and she said,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
"You boys! You think you can have anything you want.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
You don't know how hard it is to earn money. Your dad works so hard.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
You think money grows on trees. You've never worked a day in your lives.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
You boys make me so mad. You're going to get a job this summer."

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:52.958
She pulled the car over; she said, "Get out of the car."

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
My brother and I stepped out of the car.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
We were standing on the edge of thousands of acres of cotton.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
There were about a hundred black folks out there picking.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
My mom grabbed us by the shoulders. She marched us out in the field.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
She went up to the foreman; she said,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
"I've got these two little boys never worked a day in their lives."

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
Of course, we were just eight and 10.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:10.958
(Laughter)

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
She said, "Would you put them to work?"

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
Well, that must have seemed like a funny idea to that foreman:

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
put these two middle-class little white boys out in a cotton field

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
in August in Texas -- it's hot.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
So he gave us each a cotton sack,

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
about 10 feet long, about that big around, and we started picking.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:29.958
Now, cotton is soft but the outside of the plant is just full of stickers.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
And if you don't know what you're doing,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
your hands are bleeding in no time.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
And my brother and I started to pick it,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
and our hands were startin' to bleed, and then -- "Mom!"

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
And Mom was just sitting by the car like this.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
She wasn't going to give up.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:47.958
Well, the foreman could see he was in over his head, I guess.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
He kind of just snuck up behind us and he sang out in a low voice.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:59.958
He just sang: "Well, there's a long white robe in heaven, I know.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
Don't want it to leave me behind.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:06.958
Well, there's a long white robe in heaven, I know.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
Don't want it to leave me behind."

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:13.958
And from all around as people started singing and answering back, he sang:

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:17.958
"Good news, good news: Chariot's coming.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
Good news: Chariot's coming.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:24.958
Good news: Chariot's coming.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:28.958
And I don't want it to leave me behind."

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
Now, my brother and I had never heard anything like that

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
in our whole lives. It was so beautiful.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
We sat there all day picking cotton, without complaining,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
without crying, while they sang things like:

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:42.958
"Oh, Mary, don't you weep, don't you moan" and "Wade in the water,"

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
and "I done done," "This little light of mine."

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
Finally, by the end of the day,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:51.958
we'd each picked about a quarter of a bag of cotton.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:55.958
But the foreman was kind enough to give us each a check for a dollar,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
but my mother would never let us cash it.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
I'm 57; still have the check.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:05.958
Now, my mother hoped that we learned from that the value of hard work.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
But if you have children, you know it doesn't often work that way.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
No, we learned something else.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
The first thing I learned that day

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
was that I never ever wanted to work that hard again.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
(Laughter)

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
And pretty much never did.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
But I also learned that some people in this world

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:29.958
do have to work that hard every day, and that was an eye-opener.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:34.958
And I also learned that a great song can make hard work go a little easier.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:39.958
And it also can bring the group together in a way that nothing else can.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
Now, I was just a little eight-year-old boy that day

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
when my mama put me out of the car in that hot Texas cotton field.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:49.958
I wasn't even aware of music -- not even aware of it.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
But that day in the cotton field out there picking,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
when those people started singing,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:57.958
I realized I was in the very heart of real music,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
and that's where I've wanted to be ever since.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
Try this old song with me. I sing:

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:06.958
Well, there's a long white robe in heaven, I know.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
You sing: Don't want it to leave me behind.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:13.958
Well, there's a long white robe in heaven, I know.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
Don't want it to leave me behind.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:20.958
Good news, good news: Chariot's coming.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
Good news: Chariot's coming.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
Good news: Chariot's coming.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
And I don't want it to leave me --

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:33.958
It's been a while since you guys have been picking your last bale of cotton, isn't it?

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
Let's try it one more time.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:39.958
There's a starry crown in heaven, I know.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
Don't want it to leave me behind.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:46.958
There's a starry crown in heaven, I know.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
Don't want it to leave me behind.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:53.958
Good news: Chariot's coming.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:56.958
Good news: Chariot's coming.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:00.958
Good news: Chariot's coming.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
And I don't want it to leave me behind.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
It was a few years ago, but I sort of remembered this story,

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
and I told it at a concert.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
My mom was in the audience.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
After the -- she was glad to have a story about herself, of course,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
but after the concert she came up and she said,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
"David, I've got to tell you something.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
I set that whole thing up.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:23.958
I set it up with the foreman. I set it up with the owner of the land.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
I just wanted you boys to learn the value of hard work.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:29.958
I didn't know it was going to make you fall in love with music though."

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:33.958
Let's try. Good news: Chariot's coming.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
Good news: Chariot's coming.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:40.958
Good news: Chariot's coming.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:44.958
And I don't want it to leave me behind.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:59.958
Well, this is the steel guitar. It's an American-made instrument.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
It was originally made by the Dopyera Brothers,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
who later on made the Dobro, which is a wood-bodied instrument

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:10.958
with a metal cone for -- where the sound comes from.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
It's usually played flat on your lap.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
It was made to play Hawaiian music back in the 1920s,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
before they had electric guitars, trying to make a loud guitar.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:21.958
And then African-American folks figured out you could take a broken bottle neck,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:25.958
just like that -- a nice Merlot works very well.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
That wine we had yesterday would have been perfect.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
Break it off, put it on your finger, and slide into the notes.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
This instrument pretty much saved my life.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:43.958
Fifteen years ago, 14 years ago, I guess, this year,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:47.958
my wife and I lost our daughter, Sarah Jane, in a car accident,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:53.958
and it was the most -- it almost took me out -- it almost took me out of this world.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
And I think I learned a lot about what happiness was

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
by going through such unbelievable grief,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
just standing on the edge of that abyss and just wanting to jump in.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:07.958
I had to make lists of reasons to stay alive.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
I had to sit down and make lists, because I was ready to go;

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
I was ready to check out of this world.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
And you know, at the top of the list, of course,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.958
were Jenny, and my son, Zeb, my parents -- I didn't want to hurt them.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
But then, when I thought about it beyond that,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
it was very simple things.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
I didn't care about -- I had a radio show,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
I have a radio show on public radio, "Riverwalk,"

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:31.958
I didn't care about that. I didn't care about awards or money or anything.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
Nothing. Nothing.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
On the list it would be stuff like,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:42.958
seeing the daffodils bloom in the spring, the smell of new-mown hay,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:48.958
catching a wave and bodysurfing, the touch of a baby's hand,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
the sound of Doc Watson playing the guitar,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:55.958
listening to old records of Muddy Waters and Uncle Dave Macon.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
And for me, the sound of a steel guitar,

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:02.958
because one of my parents' neighbors just gave me one of these things.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
And I would sit around with it, and I didn't know how to play it,

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:10.958
but I would just play stuff as sad as I could play.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
And it was the only instrument that, of all the ones that I play,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:16.958
that would really make that connection.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
This is a song that came out of that.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:51.958
(Music)

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
Well, I hear you're having trouble.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
Lord, I hate to hear that news.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:03.958
If you want to talk about it, you know, I will listen to you through.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:08.958
Words no longer say it; let me tell you what I always do.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:18.958
I just break off another bottleneck and play these steel guitar blues.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
People say, "Oh, snap out of it!"

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
Oh yeah, that's easier said than done.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:31.958
While you can hardly move, they're running around having all kinds of fun.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:40.958
Sometimes I think it's better just to sink way down in your funky mood

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:48.958
'til you can rise up humming these steel guitar blues.

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.958
Now, you can try to keep it all inside

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
with drink and drugs and cigarettes,

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:02.958
but you know that's not going to get you where you want to get.

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:08.958
But I got some medicine here that just might shake things loose.

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:17.958
Call me in the morning after a dose of these steel guitar blues.

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
Open up now.

00:18:53.958 --> 00:19:06.958
(Applause)

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:09.958
Oh, I think I've got time to tell you about this. My dad was an inventor.

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:13.958
We moved to California when Sputnik went up, in 1957.

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:15.958
And he was working on gyroscopes;

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:18.958
he has a number of patents for that kind of thing.

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:21.958
And we moved across the street from Michael and John Whitney.

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:23.958
They were about my age.

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:25.958
John went on, and Michael did too,

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:28.958
to become some of the inventors of computer animation.

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:30.958
Michael's dad was working on something called the computer.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:33.958
This was 1957, I was a little 10-year-old kid;

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:36.958
I didn't know what that was. But he took me down to see one,

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:38.958
you know, what they were making. It was like a library,

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:41.958
just full of vacuum tubes as far as you could see,

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:43.958
just floors and floors of these things,

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:45.958
and one of the engineers said,

00:19:45.958 --> 00:19:49.958
some day you're going to be able to put this thing in your pocket.

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:52.958
I thought, damn, those are going to be some big pants!

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:54.958
(Laughter)

00:19:54.958 --> 00:20:00.958
So that Christmas -- maybe I've got time for this --

00:20:00.958 --> 00:20:04.958
that Christmas I got the Mister Wizard Fun-o-Rama chemistry set.

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:07.958
Well, I wanted to be an inventor just like my dad; so did Michael.

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:09.958
His great-granddad had been Eli Whitney,

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:11.958
the inventor of the cotton gin.

00:20:11.958 --> 00:20:13.958
So we looked in that --

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:15.958
this was a commercial chemistry set.

00:20:15.958 --> 00:20:17.958
It had three chemicals we were really surprised to see:

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:20.958
sulfur, potassium nitrate and charcoal.

00:20:20.958 --> 00:20:23.958
Man, we were only 10, but we knew that made gunpowder.

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:26.958
We made up a little batch and we put it on the driveway

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:29.958
and we threw a match and phew, it flared up. Ah, it was great.

00:20:29.958 --> 00:20:33.958
Well, obviously the next thing to do was build a cannon.

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:36.958
So we went over into Michael's garage --

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:39.958
his dad had all kinds of stuff, and we put a pipe in the vice there,

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:41.958
and screwed a cap on the end of the pipe,

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:44.958
drilled a hole in the back of the pipe, took some of our firecrackers,

00:20:44.958 --> 00:20:48.958
pulled out the fuses, tied them together, put them in the back there,

00:20:48.958 --> 00:20:51.958
and -- down in that hole -- and then stuffed some of our gunpowder

00:20:51.958 --> 00:20:56.958
down that pipe and put three ball bearings on the top, in the garage.

00:20:56.958 --> 00:20:57.958
(Laughter)

00:20:57.958 --> 00:21:01.958
We weren't stupid: we put up a sheet of plywood about five feet in front of it.

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:04.958
We stood back, we lit that thing,

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:08.958
and they flew out of there -- they went through that plywood like it was paper.

00:21:08.958 --> 00:21:10.958
Through the garage.

00:21:10.958 --> 00:21:13.958
Two of them landed in the side door of his new Citroen.

00:21:14.958 --> 00:21:17.958
(Laughter)

00:21:17.958 --> 00:21:21.958
We tore everything down and buried it in his backyard.

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:25.958
That was Pacific Palisades; it probably is still there, back there.

00:21:25.958 --> 00:21:28.958
Well, my brother heard that we had made gunpowder.

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:31.958
He and his buddies, they were older, and they were pretty mean.

00:21:31.958 --> 00:21:33.958
They said they were going to beat us up

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:35.958
if we didn't make some gunpowder for them.

00:21:35.958 --> 00:21:37.958
We said, well, what are you going to do with it?

00:21:37.958 --> 00:21:41.958
They said, we're going to melt it down and make rocket fuel.

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:43.958
(Laughter)

00:21:43.958 --> 00:21:46.958
Sure. We'll make you a big batch.

00:21:46.958 --> 00:21:49.958
(Laughter)

00:21:49.958 --> 00:21:51.958
So we made them a big batch, and it was in my --

00:21:51.958 --> 00:21:53.958
now, we'd just moved here. We'd just moved to California.

00:21:53.958 --> 00:21:57.958
Mom had redone the kitchen; Mom was gone that day. We had a pie tin.

00:21:57.958 --> 00:22:01.958
It became Chris Berquist's job to do the melting down.

00:22:01.958 --> 00:22:04.958
Michael and I were standing way at the side of the kitchen.

00:22:04.958 --> 00:22:07.958
He said, "Yeah, hey, it's melting. Yeah, the sulfur's melting.

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:09.958
No problem. Yeah, you know."

00:22:09.958 --> 00:22:12.958
It just flared up, and he turned around, and he looked like this.

00:22:12.958 --> 00:22:16.958
No hair, no eyelashes, no nothing.

00:22:16.958 --> 00:22:19.958
There were big welts all over my mom's kitchen cabinet;

00:22:19.958 --> 00:22:21.958
the air was the just full of black smoke.

00:22:21.958 --> 00:22:27.958
She came home, she took that chemistry set away, and we never saw it again.

00:22:27.958 --> 00:22:30.958
But we thought of it often, because every time she'd cook tuna surprise

00:22:30.958 --> 00:22:33.958
it made -- tasted faintly of gunpowder.

00:22:34.958 --> 00:22:36.958
So I like to invent things too,

00:22:36.958 --> 00:22:41.958
and I think I'll close out my set with something I invented a good while back.

00:22:41.958 --> 00:22:43.958

00:22:43.958 --> 00:22:47.958
why couldn't you take the oldest form of music, the hambone rhythms,

00:22:47.958 --> 00:22:49.958
and combine it with the newest technology?

00:22:49.958 --> 00:22:51.958
I call this Thunderwear.

00:22:53.958 --> 00:22:55.958
At that time, drum triggers were new.

00:22:59.958 --> 00:23:04.958

00:23:09.958 --> 00:23:11.958

00:23:11.958 --> 00:23:13.958
I'm going to be doing some of the same ones.

00:23:13.958 --> 00:23:20.958
I have a trigger here, trigger here, here, here. Right there.

00:23:25.958 --> 00:23:29.958

00:23:29.958 --> 00:23:36.958
Now, the drum triggers go out my tail here, into the drum machine,

00:23:36.958 --> 00:23:39.958
and they can make various sounds, like drums.

00:23:40.958 --> 00:23:43.958
So let me put them all together. And also, I can change the sounds

00:23:43.958 --> 00:23:46.958
by stepping on this pedal right here, and --

00:23:48.958 --> 00:23:51.958
let me just close out here by doing you a little

00:23:51.958 --> 00:23:53.958
hambone solo or something like this.

00:24:54.958 --> 00:24:56.958
Thank you, folks.

(Applause)

title: The playful search for beauty
transcript: So I understand that this meeting was planned, and the slogan was From Was to Still. And I am illustrating Still. Which, of course, I am not agreeing with because, although I am 94, I am not still working. And anybody who asks me, "Are you still doing this or that?" I don't answer because I'm not doing things still, I'm doing it like I always did. I still have — or did I use the word still? I didn't mean that.(Laughter)I have my file which is called To Do. I have my plans. I have my clients. I am doing my work like I always did. So this takes care of my age. I want to show you my work so you know what I am doing and why I am here. This was about 1925. All of these things were made during the last 75 years.(Laughter)(Applause)But, of course, I'm working since 25, doing more or less what you see here. This is Castleton China. This was an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. This is now for sale at the Metropolitan Museum. This is still at the Metropolitan Museum now for sale. This is a portrait of my daughter and myself.(Applause)These were just some of the things I've made. I made hundreds of them for the last 75 years. I call myself a maker of things. I don't call myself an industrial designer because I'm other things. Industrial designers want to make novel things. Novelty is a concept of commerce, not an aesthetic concept. The industrial design magazine, I believe, is called "Innovation." Innovation is not part of the aim of my work. Well, makers of things: they make things more beautiful, more elegant, more comfortable than just the craftsmen do. I have so much to say. I have to think what I am going to say. Well, to describe our profession otherwise, we are actually concerned with the playful search for beauty. That means the playful search for beauty was called the first activity of Man. Sarah Smith, who was a mathematics professor at MIT, wrote, "The playful search for beauty was Man's first activity — that all useful qualities and all material qualities were developed from the playful search for beauty." These are tiles. The word, "playful" is a necessary aspect of our work because, actually, one of our problems is that we have to make, produce, lovely things throughout all of life, and this for me is now 75 years.So how can you, without drying up, make things with the same pleasure, as a gift to others, for so long? The playful is therefore an important part of our quality as designer. Let me tell you some about my life. As I said, I started to do these things 75 years ago. My first exhibition in the United States was at the Sesquicentennial exhibition in 1926 — that the Hungarian government sent one of my hand-drawn pieces as part of the exhibit. My work actually took me through many countries, and showed me a great part of the world. This is not that they took me — the work didn't take me — I made the things particularly because I wanted to use them to see the world. I was incredibly curious to see the world, and I made all these things, which then finally did take me to see many countries and many cultures. I started as an apprentice to a Hungarian craftsman, and this taught me what the guild system was in Middle Ages.The guild system: that means when I was an apprentice, I had to apprentice myself in order to become a pottery master. In my shop where I studied, or learned, there was a traditional hierarchy of master, journeyman and learned worker, and apprentice, and I worked as the apprentice. The work as an apprentice was very primitive. That means I had to actually learn every aspect of making pottery by hand. We mashed the clay with our feet when it came from the hillside. After that, it had to be kneaded. It had to then go in, kind of, a mangle. And then finally it was prepared for the throwing. And there I really worked as an apprentice. My master took me to set ovens because this was part of oven-making, oven-setting, in the time. And finally, I had received a document that I had accomplished my apprenticeship successfully, that I had behaved morally, and this document was given to me by the Guild of Roof-Coverers, Rail-Diggers, Oven-Setters, Chimney Sweeps and Potters.(Laughter)I also got at the time a workbook which explained my rights and my working conditions, and I still have that workbook. First I set up a shop in my own garden, and made pottery which I sold on the marketplace in Budapest. And there I was sitting, and my then-boyfriend — I didn't mean it was a boyfriend like it is meant today — but my boyfriend and I sat at the market and sold the pots. My mother thought that this was not very proper, so she sat with us to add propriety to this activity.(Laughter)However, after a while there was a new factory being built in Budapest, a pottery factory, a large one. And I visited it with several ladies, and asked all sorts of questions of the director. Then the director asked me, why do you ask all these questions? I said, I also have a pottery. So he asked me, could he please visit me, and then finally he did, and explained to me that what I did now in my shop was an anachronism, that the industrial revolution had broken out, and that I rather should join the factory. There he made an art department for me where I worked for several months. However, everybody in the factory spent his time at the art department. The director there said there were several women casting and producing my designs now in molds, and this was sold also to America.I remember that it was quite successful. However, the director, the chemist, model maker — everybody — concerned himself much more with the art department — that means, with my work — than making toilets, so finally they got a letter from the center, from the bank who owned the factory, saying, make toilet-setting behind the art department, and that was my end. So this gave me the possibility because now I was a journeyman, and journeymen also take their satchel and go to see the world. So as a journeyman, I put an ad into the paper that I had studied, that I was a down-to-earth potter's journeyman and I was looking for a job as a journeyman. And I got several answers, and I accepted the one which was farthest from home and practically, I thought, halfway to America.And that was in Hamburg. Then I first took this job in Hamburg, at an art pottery where everything was done on the wheel, and so I worked in a shop where there were several potters. And the first day, I was coming to take my place at the turntable — there were three or four turntables — and one of them, behind where I was sitting, was a hunchback, a deaf-mute hunchback, who smelled very bad. So I doused him in cologne every day, which he thought was very nice, and therefore he brought bread and butter every day, which I had to eat out of courtesy. The first day I came to work in this shop there was on my wheel a surprise for me. My colleagues had thoughtfully put on the wheel where I was supposed to work a very nicely modeled natural man's organs. (Laughter) After I brushed them off with a hand motion, they were very — I finally was now accepted, and worked there for some six months. This was my first job. If I go on like this, you will be here till midnight.(Laughter)(Applause)So I will try speed it up a little(Laughter)Moderator: Eva, we have about five minutes.(Laughter)Eva Zeisel: Are you sure?Moderator: Yes, I am sure.EZ: Well, if you are sure, I have to tell you that within five minutes I will talk very fast. And actually, my work took me to many countries because I used my work to fill my curiosity. And among other things, other countries I worked, was in the Soviet Union, where I worked from '32 to '37 — actually, to '36. I was finally there, although I had nothing to do — I was a foreign expert. I became art director of the china and glass industry, and eventually under Stalin's purges — at the beginning of Stalin's purges, I didn't know that hundreds of thousands of innocent people were arrested. So I was arrested quite early in Stalin's purges, and spent 16 months in a Russian prison. The accusation was that I had successfully prepared an Attentat on Stalin's life. This was a very dangerous accusation. And if this is the end of my five minutes, I want to tell you that I actually did survive, which was a surprise. But since I survived and I'm here, and since this is the end of the five minutes, I will —Moderator: Tell me when your last trip to Russia was. Weren't you there recently?EZ: Oh, this summer, in fact, the Lomonosov factory was bought by an American company, invited me. They found out that I had worked in '33 at this factory, and they came to my studio in Rockland County, and brought the 15 of their artists to visit me here. And they invited myself to come to the Russian factory last summer, in July, to make some dishes, design some dishes. And since I don't like to travel alone, they also invited my daughter, son-in-law and granddaughter, so we had a lovely trip to see Russia today, which is not a very pleasant and happy view. Here I am now, if this is the end? Thank you.(Applause)

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:15.958
and therefore he brought bread and butter every day,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
which I had to eat out of courtesy.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
The first day I came to work in this shop

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:28.958
there was on my wheel a surprise for me.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:41.958
My colleagues had thoughtfully put on the wheel where I was supposed to work

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:47.958
a very nicely modeled natural man's organs.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:51.958
(Laughter)

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:58.958
After I brushed them off with a hand motion, they were very --

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:04.958
I finally was now accepted, and worked there for some six months.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
This was my first job.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
If I go on like this, you will be here till midnight.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
(Laughter)

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:20.958
(Applause)

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
So I will try speed it up a little

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
(Laughter)

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
Moderator: Eva, we have about five minutes.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:31.958
(Laughter)

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
Eva Zeisel: Are you sure?

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
Moderator: Yes, I am sure.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
EZ: Well, if you are sure,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:45.958
I have to tell you that within five minutes I will talk very fast.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:53.958
And actually, my work took me to many countries

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:58.958
because I used my work to fill my curiosity.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:05.958
And among other things, other countries I worked, was in the Soviet Union,

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:13.958
where I worked from '32 to '37 -- actually, to '36.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:19.958
I was finally there, although I had nothing to do -- I was a foreign expert.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
I became art director of the china and glass industry,

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:33.958
and eventually under Stalin's purges -- at the beginning of Stalin's purges,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:39.958
I didn't know that hundreds of thousands of innocent people were arrested.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:44.958
So I was arrested quite early in Stalin's purges,

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:52.958
and spent 16 months in a Russian prison.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:16:00.958
The accusation was that I had successfully prepared an Attentat on Stalin's life.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:06.958
This was a very dangerous accusation.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:13.958
And if this is the end of my five minutes, I want to tell you that

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:18.958
I actually did survive, which was a surprise.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
But since I survived and I'm here,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:27.958
and since this is the end of the five minutes, I will --

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
Moderator: Tell me when your last trip to Russia was.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
Weren't you there recently?

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
EZ: Oh, this summer, in fact,

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:45.958
the Lomonosov factory was bought by an American company, invited me.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:50.958
They found out that I had worked in '33 at this factory,

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:57.958
and they came to my studio in Rockland County,

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:03.958
and brought the 15 of their artists to visit me here.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:09.958
And they invited myself to come to the Russian factory last summer,

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:14.958
in July, to make some dishes, design some dishes.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:22.958
And since I don't like to travel alone, they also invited my daughter,

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
son-in-law and granddaughter,

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:29.958
so we had a lovely trip to see Russia today,

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:33.958
which is not a very pleasant and happy view.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:39.958
Here I am now, if this is the end? Thank you.

(Applause)

title: A plea for bees
transcript: What I'd like you to do is, just really quickly, is just, sort of, nod to the person on your right, and then nod to the person on your left. (Laughter) Now, chances are that over the last winter, if you had been a beehive, either you or one of the two people you just nodded at would have died. Now, that's an awful lot of bees. And this is the second year in a row we have lost over 30 percent of the colonies, or we estimate we've lost 30 percent of the colonies over the winter.Now, that's a lot, a lot of bees, and that's really important. And most of those losses are because of things we know. We know that there are these varroa mites that have introduced and caused a lot of losses, and we also have this new phenomenon, which I talked about last year, Colony Collapse Disorder. And here we see a picture on top of a hill in Central Valley last December. And below, you can see all these out yards, or temporary yards, where the colonies are brought in until February, and then they're shipped out to the almonds. And one documentary writer, who was here and looked at this two months after I was here, described this not as beehives but as a graveyard, with these empty white boxes with no bees left in them.Now, I'm going to sum up a year's worth of work in two sentences to say that we have been trying to figure out what the cause of this is. And what we know is that it's as if the bees have caught a flu. And this flu has wiped through the population of bees. In some cases, and in fact in most cases in one year, this flu was caused by a new virus to us, or newly identified by us, called Israeli Acute Paralysis virus. It was called that because a guy in Israel first found it, and he now regrets profoundly calling it that disease, because, of course, there's the implication. But we think this virus is pretty ubiquitous. It's also pretty clear that the bees sometimes catch other viruses or other flus, and so the question we're still struggling with, and the question that keeps us up at night, is why have the bees suddenly become so susceptible to this flu, and why are they so susceptible to these other diseases? And we don't have the answer to that yet, and we spend a lot of time trying to figure that out. We think perhaps it's a combination of factors. We know from the work of a very large and dynamic working team that, you know, we're finding a lot of different pesticides in the hive, and surprisingly, sometimes the healthiest hives have the most pesticides. And so we discover all these very strange things that we can't begin to understand.And so this opens up the whole idea of looking at colony health. Now of course, if you lose a lot of colonies, beekeepers can replace them very quickly. And that's why we've been able to recover from a lot of loss. If we lost one in every three cows in the winter, you know, the National Guard would be out. But what beekeepers can do is, if they have one surviving colony, they can split that colony in two. And then the one half that doesn't have a queen, they can buy a queen. It comes in the mail; it can come from Australia or Hawaii or Florida, and you can introduce that queen. And in fact, America was the first country that ever did mail-delivery queens and in fact, it's part of the postal code that you have to deliver queens by mail in order to make sure that we have enough bees in this country. If you don't just want a queen, you can buy, actually, a three-pound package of bees, which comes in the mail, and of course, the Postal Office is always very concerned when they get, you know, your three-pound packages of bees. And you can install this in your hive and replace that dead-out. So it means that beekeepers are very good at replacing dead-outs, and so they've been able to cover those losses. So even though we've lost 30 percent of the colonies every year, the same number of colonies have existed in the country, at about 2.4 million colonies.Now, those losses are tragic on many fronts, and one of those fronts is for the beekeeper. And it's really important to talk about beekeepers first, because beekeepers are among the most fascinating people you'll ever meet. If this was a group of beekeepers, you would have everyone from the card-carrying NRA member who's, you know, live free or die, to the, you know, the self-expressed quirky San Francisco backyard pig farmer. (Laughter) And you get all of these people in the same room, and they're all engaged and they're getting along, and they're all there because of the passion for bees. Now, there's another part of that community which are the commercial beekeepers, the ones who make their livelihood from beekeeping alone. And these tend to be some of the most independent, tenacious, intuitive, you know, inventive people you will ever meet. They're just fascinating. And they're like that all over the world.I had the privilege of working in Haiti just for two weeks earlier this year. And Haiti, if you've ever been there, is just a tragedy. I mean, there may be 100 explanations for why Haiti is the impoverished nation it is, but there is no excuse to see that sort of squalor. But you meet this beekeeper, and I met this beekeeper here, and he is one of the most knowledgeable beekeepers I've ever met. No formal education, but very knowledgeable. We needed beeswax for a project we were working on; he was so capable, he was able to render the nicest block of beeswax I have ever seen from cow dung, tin cans and his veil, which he used as a screening, right in this meadow. And so that ingenuity is inspiring.We also have Dave Hackenberg, who is the poster child of CCD. He's the one who first identified this condition and raised the alarm bells. And he has a history of these trucks, and he's moved these bees up and down the coast. And a lot of people talk about trucks and moving bees, and that being bad, but we've done that for thousands of years. The ancient Egyptians used to move bees up and down the Nile on rafts, so this idea of a movable bee force is not new at all. And one of our real worries with Colony Collapse Disorder is the fact that it costs so much money to replace those dead-out colonies. And you can do that one year in a row, you may be able to do it two years in a row. But if you're losing 50 percent to 80 percent of your colonies, you can't survive three years in a row. And we're really worried about losing this segment of our industry.And that's important for many fronts, and one of them is because of that culture that's in agriculture. And these migratory beekeepers are the last nomads of America. You know, they pick up their hives; they move their families once or twice in a year. And if you look at Florida, in Dade City, Florida, that's where all the Pennsylvania beekeepers go. And then 20 miles down the road is Groveland, and that's where all the Wisconsin beekeepers go. And if you're ever in Central Valley in February, you go to this café at 10 o'clock in the morning, Kathy and Kate's. And that's where all the beekeepers come after a night of moving bees into the almond groves. They all have their breakfast and complain about everyone right there. And it's a great experience, and I really encourage you to drop in at that diner during that time, because that's quite essential American experience. And we see these families, these nomadic families, you know, father to son, father to son, and these guys are hurting. And they're not people who like to ask for help, although they are the most helpful people ever. If there's one guy who loses all his bees because of a truck overhaul, everyone pitches in and gives 20 hives to help him replace those lost colonies. And so, it's a very dynamic, and I think, historic and exciting community to be involved with.Of course, the real importance for bees is not the honey. And although I highly encourage you, all use honey. I mean, it's the most ethical sweetener, and you know, it's a dynamic and fun sweetener. But we estimate that about one in three bites of food we eat is directly or indirectly pollinated by honeybees. Now, I want to just illustrate that in the fact that if we look at the breakfast I had yesterday morning — a little cranberry juice, some fruits, some granola, I should have had whole wheat bread, I realized, but you know, jam on my Wonderbread, and some coffee — and had we taken out all those ingredients, — except for the almonds I wasn't going to pick out from the granola — if we had taken out all those ingredients the bees had indirectly or directly pollinated, we wouldn't have much on our plate. So if we did not have bees, it's not like we would starve, but clearly our diet would be diminished. It's said that for bees, the flower is the fountain of life, and for flowers bees are the messengers of love.And that's a really great expression, because really, bees are the sex workers for flowers. They are, you know — they get paid for their services. They get paid by pollen and nectar, to move that male sperm, the pollen, from flower to flower. And there are flowers that are self-infertile. That means they can't — the pollen in their bloom can't fertilize themselves. So in an apple orchard, for instance, you'll have rows of 10 apples of one variety, and then you have another apple tree that's a different type of pollen. And bees are very faithful. When they're out pollinating or gathering pollen from one flower, they stay to that crop exclusively, in order to help generate. And of course, they're made to carry this pollen. They build up a static electric charge and the pollen jumps on them and helps spread that pollen from bloom to bloom.However, honeybees are a minority. Honeybees are not native to America; they were introduced with the colonialists. And there are actually more species of bees than there are mammals and birds combined. In Pennsylvania alone, we have been surveying bees for 150 years, and very intensely in the last three years. We have identified over 400 species of bees in Pennsylvania. Thirty-two species have not been identified or found in the state since 1950. Now, that could be because we haven't been sampling right, but it does, I think, suggest that something's wrong with the pollinator force. And these bees are fascinating.We have bumblebees on the top. And bumblebees are what we call eusocial: they're not truly social, because only the queen is, over winter. We also have the sweat bees, and these are little gems flying around. They're like tiny little flies and they fly around. And then you have another type of bee, which we call kleptoparasites, which is a very fancy way of saying, bad-minded, murdering — what's the word I'm looking for? Murdering — Audience: Bee? Dennis vanEngelsdorp: Bee. Okay, thanks. (Laughter) What these bees do is, they sit there. These solitary bees, they drill a hole in the ground or drill a hole in a branch, and they collect pollen and make it into a ball, and they lay an egg on it. Well, these bees hang out at that hole, and they wait for that mother to fly away, they go in, eat the egg, and lay their own egg there. So they don't do any work. And so, in fact, if you know you have these kleptoparasitic bees, you know that your environment is healthy, because they're top-of-the-food-chain bees. And in fact, there is now a red list of pollinators that we're worried have disappeared, and on top of that list are a lot of these kleptoparasites, but also these bumblebees. And in fact, if you guys live on the West Coast, go to these websites here, and they're really looking for people to look for some of these bumblebees, because we think some have gone extinct. Or some, the population has declined.And so it's not just honeybees that are in trouble, but we don't understand these native pollinators or all those other parts of our community. And of course, bees are not the only important factor here. There are other animals that pollinate, like bats, and bats are in trouble too. And I'm glad I'm a bee man and not a bat man, because there's no money to research the bat problems. And bats are dying at an extraordinary rate. White-nose syndrome has wiped out populations of bats. If there's a cave in New York that had 15,000 bats in it, and there are 1,000 left. That's like San Francisco becoming the population of half of this county in three years. And so that's incredible. And there's no money to do that.But I'm glad to say that I think we know the cause of all these conditions, and that cause is NDD: Nature Deficit Disorder. And that is that I think that what we have in our society is, we forgot our connection with nature. And I think if we reconnect to nature, we'll be able to have the resources and that interest to solve these problems. And I think that there is an easy cure for NDD. And that is, make meadows and not lawns. And I think we have lost our connection, and this is a wonderful way of reconnecting to our environment. I've had the privilege of living by a meadow for the last little while, and it is terribly engaging. And if we look at the history of lawns, it's actually rather tragic. It used to be, two, three hundred years ago, that a lawn was a symbol of prestige, and so it was only the very rich that could keep these green actually, deserts: they're totally sterile. Americans spent, in 2001 — 11 percent of all pesticide use was done on lawns. Five percent of our greenhouse gases are produced by mowing our lawns.And so it's incredible the amount of resources we've spent keeping our lawns, which are these useless biosystems. And so we need to rethink this idea. In fact, you know, the White House used to have sheep in front in order to help fund the war effort in World War I, which probably is not a bad idea; it wouldn't be a bad idea. I want to say this not because I'm opposed completely to mowing lawns. I think that there is perhaps some advantage to keeping lawns at a limited scale, and I think we're encouraged to do that. But I also want to reinforce some of the ideas we've heard here, because having a meadow or living by a meadow is transformational. That it is amazing that connection we can have with what's there. These milkweed plants have grown up in my meadow over the last four years. Add to watch the different plants, or insects, that come to these flowers, to watch that — and we've heard about, you know, this relationship you can have with wine, this companion you can have as it matures and as it has these different fragrances. And this is a companion, and this is a relationship that never dries up. You never run out of that companion as you drink this wine, too. And I encourage you to look at that.Now, not all of us have meadows, or lawns that we can convert, and so you can always, of course, grow a meadow in a pot. Bees apparently, can be the gateway to, you know, other things. So I'm not saying that you should plant a meadow of pot, but a pot in a meadow. But you can also have this great community of city or building-top beekeepers, these beekeepers that live — This is in Paris where these beekeepers live. And everyone should open a beehive, because it is the most amazing, incredible thing. And if we want to cure ourselves of NDD, or Nature Deficit Disorder, I think this is a great way of doing it. Get a beehive and grow a meadow, and watch that life come back into your life. And so with that, I think that what we can do, if we do this, we can make sure that our future — our more perfect future — includes beekeepers and it includes bees and it includes those meadows. And that journey — that journey of transformation that occurs as you grow your meadow and as you keep your bees or you watch those native bees there — is an extremely exciting one. And I hope that you experience it and I hope you tell me about it one day. So thank you very much for being here.  Thank you very much.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
Now, there's another part of that community

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:55.958
which are the commercial beekeepers,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
the ones who make their livelihood from beekeeping alone.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:06.958
And these tend to be some of the most independent, tenacious,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:10.958
intuitive, you know, inventive people you will ever meet.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
They're just fascinating. And they're like that all over the world.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:17.958
I had the privilege of working in Haiti just for two weeks earlier this year.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
And Haiti, if you've ever been there, is just a tragedy.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
I mean, there may be 100 explanations

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
for why Haiti is the impoverished nation it is,

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
but there is no excuse to see that sort of squalor.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
But you meet this beekeeper, and I met this beekeeper here,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
and he is one of the most knowledgeable beekeepers I've ever met.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
No formal education, but very knowledgeable.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:40.958
We needed beeswax for a project we were working on; he was so capable,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:44.958
he was able to render the nicest block of beeswax I have ever seen

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:49.958
from cow dung, tin cans and his veil, which he used as a screening,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:53.958
right in this meadow. And so that ingenuity is inspiring.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
We also have Dave Hackenberg, who is the poster child of CCD.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
He's the one who first identified this condition

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
and raised the alarm bells.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
And he has a history of these trucks,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
and he's moved these bees up and down the coast.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
And a lot of people talk about trucks and moving bees,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
and that being bad, but we've done that for thousands of years.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
The ancient Egyptians used to move bees up and down the Nile on rafts,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:20.958
so this idea of a movable bee force is not new at all.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:24.958
And one of our real worries with Colony Collapse Disorder

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:28.958
is the fact that it costs so much money to replace those dead-out colonies.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
And you can do that one year in a row,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
you may be able to do it two years in a row.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:37.958
But if you're losing 50 percent to 80 percent of your colonies,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
you can't survive three years in a row. And we're really worried

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:44.958
about losing this segment of our industry.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
And that's important for many fronts,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:50.958
and one of them is because of that culture that's in agriculture.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:55.958
And these migratory beekeepers are the last nomads of America.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:56.958
You know, they pick up their hives;

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
they move their families once or twice in a year.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
And if you look at Florida, in Dade City, Florida,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
that's where all the Pennsylvania beekeepers go.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
And then 20 miles down the road is Groveland,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
and that's where all the Wisconsin beekeepers go.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:13.958
And if you're ever in Central Valley in February, you go to this café

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
at 10 o'clock in the morning, Kathy and Kate's.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
And that's where all the beekeepers come after a night of moving bees

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:20.958
into the almond groves.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:21.958
They all have their breakfast

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:26.958
and complain about everyone right there. And it's a great experience,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
and I really encourage you to drop in at that diner during that time,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
because that's quite essential American experience.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:36.958
And we see these families, these nomadic families, you know,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:40.958
father to son, father to son, and these guys are hurting.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
And they're not people who like to ask for help,

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
although they are the most helpful people ever.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:49.958
If there's one guy who loses all his bees because of a truck overhaul,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
everyone pitches in and gives 20 hives

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
to help him replace those lost colonies.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
And so, it's a very dynamic, and I think,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:08:01.958
historic and exciting community to be involved with.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
Of course, the real importance for bees is not the honey.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
And although I highly encourage you, all use honey.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
I mean, it's the most ethical sweetener,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
and you know, it's a dynamic and fun sweetener.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:17.958
But we estimate that about one in three bites of food we eat

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:22.958
is directly or indirectly pollinated by honeybees.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
Now, I want to just illustrate that in the fact

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:28.958
that if we look at the breakfast I had yesterday morning --

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
a little cranberry juice, some fruits, some granola,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
I should have had whole wheat bread, I realized, but you know,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:38.958
jam on my Wonderbread, and some coffee --

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:43.958
and had we taken out all those ingredients,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
-- except for the almonds I wasn't going to pick out from the granola --

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
if we had taken out all those ingredients

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
the bees had indirectly or directly pollinated,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
we wouldn't have much on our plate.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
So if we did not have bees, it's not like we would starve,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:01.958
but clearly our diet would be diminished.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
It's said that for bees, the flower is the fountain of life,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
and for flowers bees are the messengers of love.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
And that's a really great expression, because really,

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
bees are the sex workers for flowers. They are, you know --

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
they get paid for their services.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
They get paid by pollen and nectar,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:21.958
to move that male sperm, the pollen, from flower to flower.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
And there are flowers that are self-infertile. That means they can't --

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:28.958
the pollen in their bloom can't fertilize themselves.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
So in an apple orchard, for instance, you'll have rows of 10 apples

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
of one variety, and then you have another apple tree

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
that's a different type of pollen.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:37.958
And bees are very faithful.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:41.958
When they're out pollinating or gathering pollen from one flower,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:45.958
they stay to that crop exclusively, in order to help generate.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:49.958
And of course, they're made to carry this pollen.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
They build up a static electric charge and the pollen jumps on them

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:56.958
and helps spread that pollen from bloom to bloom.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
However, honeybees are a minority.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Honeybees are not native to America; they were introduced

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:02.958
with the colonialists.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
And there are actually more species of bees

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
than there are mammals and birds combined.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:12.958
In Pennsylvania alone, we have been surveying bees for 150 years,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
and very intensely in the last three years.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:20.958
We have identified over 400 species of bees in Pennsylvania.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:26.958
Thirty-two species have not been identified or found in the state since 1950.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
Now, that could be because we haven't been sampling right,

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
but it does, I think, suggest that something's wrong

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
with the pollinator force. And these bees are fascinating.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
We have bumblebees on the top.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
And bumblebees are what we call eusocial: they're not truly social,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
because only the queen is, over winter.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
We also have the sweat bees, and these are little gems flying around.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
They're like tiny little flies and they fly around.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
And then you have another type of bee, which we call kleptoparasites,

00:10:52.958 --> 00:11:00.958
which is a very fancy way of saying, bad-minded, murdering --

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
what's the word I'm looking for? Murdering --

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:04.958
Audience: Bee?

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:05.958
Dennis vanEngelsdorp: Bee. Okay, thanks.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
(Laughter)

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:14.958
What these bees do is, they sit there. These solitary bees,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
they drill a hole in the ground or drill a hole in a branch,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
and they collect pollen and make it into a ball,

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
and they lay an egg on it.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:22.958
Well, these bees hang out at that hole,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:26.958
and they wait for that mother to fly away, they go in, eat the egg,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
and lay their own egg there. So they don't do any work.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:34.958
And so, in fact, if you know you have these kleptoparasitic bees,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
you know that your environment is healthy,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
because they're top-of-the-food-chain bees.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
And in fact, there is now a red list of pollinators

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:47.958
that we're worried have disappeared, and on top of that list

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
are a lot of these kleptoparasites, but also these bumblebees.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
And in fact, if you guys live on the West Coast,

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
go to these websites here, and they're really looking for people

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
to look for some of these bumblebees, because we think

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:02.958
some have gone extinct. Or some, the population has declined.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
And so it's not just honeybees that are in trouble,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
but we don't understand these native pollinators

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
or all those other parts of our community.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:15.958
And of course, bees are not the only important factor here.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
There are other animals that pollinate, like bats,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
and bats are in trouble too.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
And I'm glad I'm a bee man and not a bat man,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:25.958
because there's no money to research the bat problems.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
And bats are dying at an extraordinary rate.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
White-nose syndrome has wiped out populations of bats.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:36.958
If there's a cave in New York that had 15,000 bats in it,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:40.958
and there are 1,000 left. That's like San Francisco

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:45.958
becoming the population of half of this county in three years.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
And so that's incredible. And there's no money to do that.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
But I'm glad to say that I think we know the cause

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:53.958
of all these conditions, and that cause is NDD:

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
Nature Deficit Disorder.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And that is that I think that what we have in our society is,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
we forgot our connection with nature.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
And I think if we reconnect to nature,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
we'll be able to have the resources and that interest

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
to solve these problems.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
And I think that there is an easy cure for NDD.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:16.958
And that is, make meadows and not lawns.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
And I think we have lost our connection,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
and this is a wonderful way of reconnecting to our environment.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
I've had the privilege of living by a meadow

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
for the last little while, and it is terribly engaging.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:33.958
And if we look at the history of lawns, it's actually rather tragic.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
It used to be, two, three hundred years ago,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
that a lawn was a symbol of prestige,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
and so it was only the very rich that could keep these green

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
actually, deserts: they're totally sterile.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:48.958
Americans spent, in 2001 -- 11 percent of all pesticide use was done on lawns.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:54.958
Five percent of our greenhouse gases are produced by mowing our lawns.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And so it's incredible the amount of resources we've spent

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:01.958
keeping our lawns, which are these useless biosystems.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
And so we need to rethink this idea.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
In fact, you know, the White House

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
used to have sheep in front in order to help fund

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
the war effort in World War I, which probably is not a bad idea;

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:12.958
it wouldn't be a bad idea.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
I want to say this not because I'm opposed completely to mowing lawns.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:19.958
I think that there is perhaps some advantage to keeping lawns

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:23.958
at a limited scale, and I think we're encouraged to do that.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
But I also want to reinforce some of the ideas we've heard here,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:30.958
because having a meadow or living by a meadow is transformational.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:34.958
That it is amazing that connection we can have with what's there.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
These milkweed plants have grown up in my meadow

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:40.958
over the last four years. Add to watch the different plants,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:44.958
or insects, that come to these flowers, to watch that --

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
and we've heard about, you know, this relationship you can have with wine,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
this companion you can have as it matures

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
and as it has these different fragrances.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
And this is a companion,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
and this is a relationship that never dries up.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:01.958
You never run out of that companion as you drink this wine, too.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
And I encourage you to look at that.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
Now, not all of us have meadows,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
or lawns that we can convert, and so you can always, of course,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
grow a meadow in a pot.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
Bees apparently, can be the gateway to, you know, other things.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.958
So I'm not saying that you should plant a meadow of pot,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
but a pot in a meadow.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
But you can also have this great community of city

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
or building-top beekeepers, these beekeepers that live --

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
This is in Paris where these beekeepers live.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
And everyone should open a beehive,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
because it is the most amazing, incredible thing.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
And if we want to cure ourselves of NDD, or Nature Deficit Disorder,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
I think this is a great way of doing it.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
Get a beehive and grow a meadow,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
and watch that life come back into your life.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:49.958
And so with that, I think that what we can do, if we do this,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
we can make sure that our future -- our more perfect future --

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:57.958
includes beekeepers and it includes bees and it includes those meadows.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.958
And that journey -- that journey of transformation that occurs

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
as you grow your meadow and as you keep your bees

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:07.958
or you watch those native bees there -- is an extremely exciting one.

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:08.958
And I hope that you experience it

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
and I hope you tell me about it one day.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:13.958
So thank you very much for being here. 
Thank you very much.

title: My library of human imagination
transcript: These rocks have been hitting our earth for about three billion years, and are responsible for much of what’s gone on on our planet. This is an example of a real meteorite, and you can see all the melting of the iron from the speed and the heat when a meteorite hits the earth, and just how much of it survives and melts. From a meteorite from space, we’re over here with an original Sputnik. This is one of the seven surviving Sputniks that was not launched into space. This is not a copy. The space age began 50 years ago in October, and that’s exactly what Sputnik looked like.And it wouldn’t be fun to talk about the space age without seeing a flag that was carried to the moon and back, on Apollo 11. The astronauts each got to carry about ten silk flags in their personal kits. They would bring them back and mount them. So this has actually been carried to the moon and back. So that’s for fun.The dawn of books is, of course, important. And it wouldn’t be interesting to talk about the dawn of books without having a copy of a Guttenberg Bible. You can see how portable and handy it was to have your own Guttenberg in 1455. But what’s interesting about the Guttenberg Bible, and the dawn of this technology, is not the book. You see, the book was not driven by reading. In 1455, nobody could read. So why did the printing press succeed? This is an original page of a Guttenberg Bible. So you’re looking here at one of the first printed books using movable type in the history of man, 550 years ago. We are living at the age here at the end of the book, where electronic paper will undoubtedly replace it.But why is this so interesting? Here’s the quick story. It turns out that in the 1450s, the Catholic Church needed money, and so they actually hand-wrote these things called indulgences, which were forgiveness’s on pieces of paper. They traveled all around Europe and sold by the hundreds or by the thousands. They got you out of purgatory faster. And when the printing press was invented what they found was they could print indulgences, which was the equivalent of printing money.And so all of Western Europe started buying printing presses in 1455 — to print out thousands, and then hundreds of thousands, and then ultimately millions of single, small pieces of paper that got you out of middle hell and into heaven. That is why the printing press succeeded, and that is why Martin Luther nailed his 90 theses to the door: because he was complaining that the Catholic Church had gone amok in printing out indulgences and selling them in every town and village and city in all of Western Europe.So the printing press, ladies and gentlemen, was driven entirely by the printing of forgivenesses and had nothing to do with reading. More tomorrow. I also have pictures coming of the library for those of you that have asked for pictures. We’re going to have some tomorrow. (Applause)Instead of showing an object from the stage I’m going to do something special for the first time. We are going to show, actually, what the library looks like, OK? So, I am married to the most wonderful woman in the world. You’re going to find out why in a minute, because when I went to see Eileen, this is what I said I wanted to build.This is the Library of Human Imagination. The room itself is three stories tall. In the glass panels are 5,000 years of human imagination that are computer controlled. The room is a theatre. It changes colors. And all throughout the library are different objects, different spaces. It’s designed like an Escher print. Here is some of the lower level of the library, where the exhibits constantly change. You can walk through. You can touch. You can see exactly how many of these types of items would fit in a room. There’s my very own Saturn V. Everybody should have one, OK? (Laughter) So you can see here in the lower level of the library the books and the objects. In the glass panels all along is sort of the history of imagination. There is a glass bridge that you walk across that’s suspended in space. So it’s a leap of imagination.How do we create? Part of the question that I have answered is, is we create by surrounding ourselves with stimuli: with human achievement, with history, with the things that drive us and make us human — the passionate discovery, the bones of dinosaurs long gone, the maps of space that we’ve experienced, and ultimately the hallways that stimulate our mind and our imagination.So hopefully tomorrow I’ll show one or two more objects from the stage, but for today I just wanted to say thank you for all the people that came and talked to us about it. And Eileen and I are thrilled to open our home and share it with the TED community. (Applause) TED is all about patterns in the clouds. It’s all about connections. It’s all about seeing things that everybody else has seen before but thinking about them in ways that nobody has thought of them before. And that’s really what discovery and imagination is all about.For example, we can look at a DNA molecule model here. None of us really have ever seen one, but we know it exists because we’ve been taught to understand this molecule. But we can also look at an Enigma machine from the Nazis in World War II that was a coding and decoding machine. Now, you might say, what does this have to do with this? Well, this is the code for life, and this is a code for death. These two molecules code and decode. And yet, looking at them, you would see a machine and a molecule. But once you’ve seen them in a new way, you realize that both of these things really are connected. And they’re connected primarily because of this here.You see, this is a human brain model, OK? These rocks have been hitting our earth for about three billion years,

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:18.958

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:26.958
from the speed and the heat when a meteorite hits the earth,

and just how much of it survives and melts.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.958
we’re over here with an original Sputnik.

This is one of the seven surviving Sputniks that was not launched into space.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:37.958
This is not a copy.

The space age began 50 years ago in October,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
without seeing a flag that was carried

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
to the moon and back, on Apollo 11.

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:53.958
The astronauts each got to carry

about ten silk flags in their personal kits.

title: Why we make bad decisions
transcript: We all make decisions every day; we want to know what the right thing is to do — in domains from the financial to the gastronomic to the professional to the romantic. And surely, if somebody could really tell us how to do exactly the right thing at all possible times, that would be a tremendous gift.It turns out that, in fact, the world was given this gift in 1738 by a Dutch polymath named Daniel Bernoulli. And what I want to talk to you about today is what that gift is, and I also want to explain to you why it is that it hasn't made a damn bit of difference.Now, this is Bernoulli's gift. This is a direct quote. And if it looks like Greek to you, it's because, well, it's Greek. But the simple English translation — much less precise, but it captures the gist of what Bernoulli had to say — was this: The expected value of any of our actions — that is, the goodness that we can count on getting — is the product of two simple things: the odds that this action will allow us to gain something, and the value of that gain to us.In a sense, what Bernoulli was saying is, if we can estimate and multiply these two things, we will always know precisely how we should behave.Now, this simple equation, even for those of you who don't like equations, is something that you're quite used to. Here's an example: if I were to tell you, let's play a little coin toss game, and I'm going to flip a coin, and if it comes up heads, I'm going to pay you 10 dollars, but you have to pay four dollars for the privilege of playing with me, most of you would say, sure, I'll take that bet. Because you know that the odds of you winning are one half, the gain if you do is 10 dollars, that multiplies to five, and that's more than I'm charging you to play. So, the answer is, yes. This is what statisticians technically call a damn fine bet.Now, the idea is simple when we're applying it to coin tosses, but in fact, it's not very simple in everyday life.
