People are horrible at estimating both of these things, and that's what I want to talk to you about today.There are two kinds of errors people make when trying to decide what the right thing is to do, and those are errors in estimating the odds that they're going to succeed, and errors in estimating the value of their own success. Now, let me talk about the first one first. Calculating odds would seem to be something rather easy: there are six sides to a die, two sides to a coin, 52 cards in a deck. You all know what the likelihood is of pulling the ace of spades or of flipping a heads. But as it turns out, this is not a very easy idea to apply in everyday life. That's why Americans spend more — I should say, lose more — gambling than on all other forms of entertainment combined. The reason is, this isn't how people do odds.The way people figure odds requires that we first talk a bit about pigs. Now, the question I'm going to put to you is whether you think there are more dogs or pigs on leashes observed in any particular day in Oxford. And of course, you all know that the answer is dogs. And the way that you know that the answer is dogs is you quickly reviewed in memory the times you've seen dogs and pigs on leashes. It was very easy to remember seeing dogs, not so easy to remember pigs. And each one of you assumed that if dogs on leashes came more quickly to your mind, then dogs on leashes are more probable. That's not a bad rule of thumb, except when it is.So, for example, here's a word puzzle. Are there more four-letter English words with R in the third place or R in the first place? Well, you check memory very briefly, make a quick scan, and it's awfully easy to say to yourself, Ring, Rang, Rung, and very hard to say to yourself, Pare, Park: they come more slowly. But in fact, there are many more words in the English language with R in the third than the first place. The reason words with R in the third place come slowly to your mind isn't because they're improbable, unlikely or infrequent. It's because the mind recalls words by their first letter. You kind of shout out the sound, S — and the word comes. It's like the dictionary; it's hard to look things up by the third letter. So, this is an example of how this idea that the quickness with which things come to mind can give you a sense of their probability —how this idea could lead you astray. It's not just puzzles, though. For example, when Americans are asked to estimate the odds that they will die in a variety of interesting ways — these are estimates of number of deaths per year per 200 million U.S. citizens. And these are just ordinary people like yourselves who are asked to guess how many people die from tornado, fireworks, asthma, drowning, etc. Compare these to the actual numbers.Now, you see a very interesting pattern here, which is first of all, two things are vastly over-estimated, namely tornadoes and fireworks. Two things are vastly underestimated: dying by drowning and dying by asthma. Why? When was the last time that you picked up a newspaper and the headline was, "Boy dies of Asthma?" It's not interesting because it's so common. It's very easy for all of us to bring to mind instances of news stories or newsreels where we've seen tornadoes devastating cities, or some poor schmuck who's blown his hands off with a firework on the Fourth of July. Drownings and asthma deaths don't get much coverage. They don't come quickly to mind, and as a result, we vastly underestimate them.Indeed, this is kind of like the Sesame Street game of "Which thing doesn't belong?" And you're right to say it's the swimming pool that doesn't belong, because the swimming pool is the only thing on this slide that's actually very dangerous. The way that more of you are likely to die than the combination of all three of the others that you see on the slide.The lottery is an excellent example, of course — an excellent test-case of people's ability to compute probabilities. And economists — forgive me, for those of you who play the lottery — but economists, at least among themselves, refer to the lottery as a stupidity tax, because the odds of getting any payoff by investing your money in a lottery ticket are approximately equivalent to flushing the money directly down the toilet — which, by the way, doesn't require that you actually go to the store and buy anything.Why in the world would anybody ever play the lottery? Well, there are many answers, but one answer surely is, we see a lot of winners. Right? When this couple wins the lottery, or Ed McMahon shows up at your door with this giant check — how the hell do you cash things that size, I don't know. We see this on TV; we read about it in the paper. When was the last time that you saw extensive interviews with everybody who lost? Indeed, if we required that television stations run a 30-second interview with each loser every time they interview a winner, the 100 million losers in the last lottery would require nine-and-a-half years of your undivided attention just to watch them say, "Me? I lost." "Me? I lost." Now, if you watch nine-and-a-half years of television — no sleep, no potty breaks — and you saw loss after loss after loss, and then at the end there's 30 seconds of, "and I won," the likelihood that you would play the lottery is very small.Look, I can prove this to you: here's a little lottery. There's 10 tickets in this lottery. Nine of them have been sold to these individuals. It costs you a dollar to buy the ticket and, if you win, you get 20 bucks. Is this a good bet? Well, Bernoulli tells us it is. The expected value of this lottery is two dollars; this is a lottery in which you should invest your money. And most people say, "OK, I'll play."Now, a slightly different version of this lottery: imagine that the nine tickets are all owned by one fat guy named Leroy. Leroy has nine tickets; there's one left. Do you want it? Most people won't play this lottery. Now, you can see the odds of winning haven't changed, but it's now fantastically easy to imagine who's going to win. It's easy to see Leroy getting the check, right? You can't say to yourself, "I'm as likely to win as anybody," because you're not as likely to win as Leroy. The fact that all those tickets are owned by one guy changes your decision to play, even though it does nothing whatsoever to the odds.Now, estimating odds, as difficult as it may seem, is a piece of cake compared to trying to estimate value: trying to say what something is worth, how much we'll enjoy it, how much pleasure it will give us. I want to talk now about errors in value. How much is this Big Mac worth? Is it worth 25 dollars? Most of you have the intuition that it's not — you wouldn't pay that for it.But in fact, to decide whether a Big Mac is worth 25 dollars requires that you ask one, and only one question, which is: What else can I do with 25 dollars? If you've ever gotten on one of those long-haul flights to Australia and realized that they're not going to serve you any food, but somebody in the row in front of you has just opened the McDonald's bag, and the smell of golden arches is wafting over the seat, you think, I can't do anything else with this 25 dollars for 16 hours. I can't even set it on fire — they took my cigarette lighter! Suddenly, 25 dollars for a Big Mac might be a good deal.On the other hand, if you're visiting an underdeveloped country, and 25 dollars buys you a gourmet meal, it's exorbitant for a Big Mac. Why were you all sure that the answer to the question was no, before I'd even told you anything about the context? Because most of you compared the price of this Big Mac to the price you're used to paying. Rather than asking, "What else can I do with my money," comparing this investment to other possible investments, you compared to the past. And this is a systematic error people make. What you knew is, you paid three dollars in the past; 25 is outrageous.This is an error, and I can prove it to you by showing the kinds of irrationalities to which it leads. For example, this is, of course, one of the most delicious tricks in marketing, is to say something used to be higher, and suddenly it seems like a very good deal. When people are asked about these two different jobs: a job where you make 60K, then 50K, then 40K, a job where you're getting a salary cut each year, and one in which you're getting a salary increase, people like the second job better than the first, despite the fact they're all told they make much less money. Why? Because they had the sense that declining wages are worse than rising wages, even when the total amount of wages is higher in the declining period. Here's another nice example.Here's a $2,000 Hawaiian vacation package; it's now on sale for 1,600. Assuming you wanted to go to Hawaii, would you buy this package? Most people say they would. Here's a slightly different story: $2,000 Hawaiian vacation package is now on sale for 700 dollars, so you decide to mull it over for a week. By the time you get to the ticket agency, the best fares are gone — the package now costs 1,500. Would you buy it? Most people say, no. Why? Because it used to cost 700, and there's no way I'm paying 1,500 for something that was 700 last week.This tendency to compare to the past is causing people to pass up the better deal. In other words, a good deal that used to be a great deal is not nearly as good as an awful deal that was once a horrible deal.Here's another example of how comparing to the past can befuddle our decisions. Imagine that you're going to the theater. You're on your way to the theater. In your wallet you have a ticket, for which you paid 20 dollars. You also have a 20-dollar bill. When you arrive at the theater, you discover that somewhere along the way you've lost the ticket. Would you spend your remaining money on replacing it? Most people answer, no. Now, let's just change one thing in this scenario. You're on your way to the theater, and in your wallet you have two 20-dollar bills. When you arrive you discover you've lost one of them. Would you spend your remaining 20 dollars on a ticket? Well, of course, I went to the theater to see the play. What does the loss of 20 dollars along the way have to do?Now, just in case you're not getting it, here's a schematic of what happened, OK? (Laughter) Along the way, you lost something. In both cases, it was a piece of paper. In one case, it had a U.S. president on it; in the other case it didn't. What the hell difference should it make? The difference is that when you lost the ticket you say to yourself, I'm not paying twice for the same thing. You compare the cost of the play now — 40 dollars — to the cost that it used to have — 20 dollars — and you say it's a bad deal. Comparing with the past causes many of the problems that behavioral economists and psychologists identify in people's attempts to assign value. But even when we compare with the possible, instead of the past, we still make certain kinds of mistakes. And I'm going to show you one or two of them.One of the things we know about comparison: that when we compare one thing to the other, it changes its value. So in 1992, this fellow, George Bush, for those of us who were kind of on the liberal side of the political spectrum, didn't seem like such a great guy. Suddenly, we're almost longing for him to return. (Laughter) The comparison changes how we evaluate him.Now, retailers knew this long before anybody else did, of course, and they use this wisdom to help you — spare you the undue burden of money. And so a retailer, if you were to go into a wine shop and you had to buy a bottle of wine, and you see them here for eight, 27 and 33 dollars, what would you do? Most people don't want the most expensive, they don't want the least expensive. So, they will opt for the item in the middle. If you're a smart retailer, then, you will put a very expensive item that nobody will ever buy on the shelf, because suddenly the $33 wine doesn't look as expensive in comparison.So I'm telling you something you already knew: namely, that comparison changes the value of things. Here's why that's a problem: the problem is that when you get that $33 bottle of wine home, it won't matter what it used to be sitting on the shelf next to. The comparisons we make when we are appraising value, where we're trying to estimate how much we'll like things, are not the same comparisons we'll be making when we consume them. This problem of shifting comparisons can bedevil our attempts to make rational decisions.Let me just give you an example. I have to show you something from my own lab, so let me sneak this in. These are subjects coming to an experiment to be asked the simplest of all questions: How much will you enjoy eating potato chips one minute from now? They're sitting in a room with potato chips in front of them. For some of the subjects, sitting in the far corner of a room is a box of Godiva chocolates, and for others is a can of Spam. In fact, these items that are sitting in the room change how much the subjects think they're going to enjoy the potato chips. Namely, those who are looking at Spam think potato chips are going to be quite tasty; those who are looking at Godiva chocolate think they won't be nearly so tasty. Of course, what happens when they eat the potato chips? Well, look, you didn't need a psychologist to tell you that when you have a mouthful of greasy, salty, crispy, delicious snacks, what's sitting in the corner of the room makes not a damn bit of difference to your gustatory experience. Nonetheless, their predictions are perverted by a comparison that then does not carry through and change their experience.You've all experienced this yourself, even if you've never come into our lab to eat potato chips. So here's a question: You want to buy a car stereo. The dealer near your house sells this particular stereo for 200 dollars, but if you drive across town, you can get it for 100 bucks. So would you drive to get 50 percent off, saving 100 dollars? Most people say they would. They can't imagine buying it for twice the price when, with one trip across town, they can get it for half off.Now, let's imagine instead you wanted to buy a car that had a stereo, and the dealer near your house had it for 31,000. But if you drove across town, you could get it for 30,900. Would you drive to get it? At this point, 0.003 savings — the 100 dollars. Most people say, no, I'm going to schlep across town to save 100 bucks on the purchase of a car?This kind of thinking drives economists crazy, and it should. Because this 100 dollars that you save — hello! — doesn't know where it came from. It doesn't know what you saved it on. When you go to buy groceries with it, it doesn't go, I'm the money saved on the car stereo, or, I'm the dumb money saved on the car. It's money. And if a drive across town is worth 100 bucks, it's worth 100 bucks no matter what you're saving it on. People don't think that way. That's why they don't know whether their mutual fund manager is taking 0.1 percent or 0.15 percent of their investment, but they clip coupons to save one dollar off of toothpaste.Now, you can see, this is the problem of shifting comparisons, because what you're doing is, you're comparing the 100 bucks to the purchase that you're making, but when you go to spend that money you won't be making that comparison. You've all had this experience.If you're an American, for example, you've probably traveled in France. And at some point you may have met a couple from your own hometown, and you thought, "Oh, my God, these people are so warm. They're so nice to me. I mean, compared to all these people who hate me when I try to speak their language and hate me more when I don't, these people are just wonderful." And so you tour France with them, and then you get home and you invite them over for dinner, and what do you find? Compared to your regular friends, they are boring and dull, right? Because in this new context, the comparison is very, very different. In fact, you find yourself disliking them enough almost to qualify for French citizenship.Now, you have exactly the same problem when you shop for a stereo. You go to the stereo store, you see two sets of speakers — these big, boxy, monoliths, and these little, sleek speakers, and you play them, and you go, you know, I do hear a difference: the big ones sound a little better. And so you buy them, and you bring them home, and you entirely violate the décor of your house. And the problem, of course, is that this comparison you made in the store is a comparison you'll never make again. What are the odds that years later you'll turn on the stereo and go, "Sounds so much better than those little ones," which you can't even remember hearing.The problem of shifting comparisons is even more difficult when these choices are arrayed over time. People have a lot of trouble making decisions about things that will happen at different points in time. And what psychologists and behavioral economists have discovered is that by and large people use two simple rules. So let me give you one very easy problem, a second very easy problem and then a third, hard, problem.Here's the first easy problem: You can have 60 dollars now or 50 dollars now. Which would you prefer? This is what we call a one-item IQ test, OK? All of us, I hope, prefer more money, and the reason is, we believe more is better than less.Here's the second problem: You can have 60 dollars today or 60 dollars in a month. Which would you prefer? Again, an easy decision, because we all know that now is better than later. What's hard in our decision-making is when these two rules conflict. For example, when you're offered 50 dollars now or 60 dollars in a month. This typifies a lot of situations in life in which you will gain by waiting, but you have to be patient. What do we know? What do people do in these kinds of situations? Well, by and large people are enormously impatient. That is, they require interest rates in the hundred or thousands of percents in order to delay gratification and wait until next month for the extra 10 dollars. Maybe that isn't so remarkable, but what is remarkable is how easy it is to make this impatience go away by simply changing when the delivery of these monetary units will happen. Imagine that you can have 50 dollars in a year — that's 12 months — or 60 dollars in 13 months. What do we find now? People are gladly willing to wait: as long as they're waiting 12, they might as well wait 13.What makes this dynamic inconsistency happen? Comparison. Troubling comparison. Let me show you.This is just a graph showing the results that I just suggested you would show if I gave you time to respond, which is, people find that the subjective value of 50 is higher than the subjective value of 60 when they'll be delivered in now or one month, respectively — a 30-day delay — but they show the reverse pattern when you push the entire decision off into the future a year. Now, why in the world do you get this pattern of results?These guys can tell us. What you see here are two lads, one of them larger than the other: the fireman and the fiddler. They are going to recede towards the vanishing point in the horizon, and I want you to notice two things. At no point will the fireman look taller than the fiddler. No point. However, the difference between them seems to be getting smaller. First it's an inch in your view, then it's a quarter-inch, then a half-inch, and then finally they go off the edge of the earth.Here are the results of what I just showed you. This is the subjective height — the height you saw of these guys at various points. And I want you to see that two things are true. One, the farther away they are, the smaller they look; and two, the fireman is always bigger than the fiddler. But watch what happens when we make some of them disappear. Right. At a very close distance, the fiddler looks taller than the fireman, but at a far distance their normal, their true, relations are preserved. As Plato said, what space is to size, time is to value. These are the results of the hard problem I gave you: 60 now or 50 in a month? And these are subjective values, and what you can see is, our two rules are preserved.People always think more is better than less: 60 is always better than 50, and they always think now is better than later: the bars on this side are higher than the bars on this side. Watch what happens when we drop some out. Suddenly we have the dynamic inconsistency that puzzled us. We have the tendency for people to go for 50 dollars now over waiting a month, but not if that decision is far in the future. Notice something interesting that this implies — namely, that when people get to the future, they will change their minds. That is, as that month 12 approaches, you will say, what was I thinking, waiting an extra month for 60 dollars? I'll take the 50 dollars now.Well, the question with which I'd like to end is this: If we're so damn stupid, how did we get to the moon? Because I could go on for about two hours with evidence of people's inability to estimate odds and inability to estimate value.The answer to this question, I think, is an answer you've already heard in some of the talks, and I dare say you will hear again: namely, that our brains were evolved for a very different world than the one in which we are living. They were evolved for a world in which people lived in very small groups, rarely met anybody who was terribly different from themselves, had rather short lives in which there were few choices and the highest priority was to eat and mate today.Bernoulli's gift, Bernoulli's little formula, allows us, it tells us how we should think in a world for which nature never designed us. That explains why we are so bad at using it, but it also explains why it is so terribly important that we become good, fast. We are the only species on this planet that has ever held its own fate in its hands. We have no significant predators, we're the masters of our physical environment; the things that normally cause species to become extinct are no longer any threat to us. The only thing — the only thing — that can destroy us and doom us are our own decisions. If we're not here in 10,000 years, it's going to be because we could not take advantage of the gift given to us by a young Dutch fellow in 1738, because we underestimated the odds of our future pains and overestimated the value of our present pleasures.Thank you. (Applause)Chris Anderson: That was remarkable. We have time for some questions for Dan Gilbert. One and two.Bill Lyell: Would you say that this mechanism is in part how terrorism actually works to frighten us, and is there some way that we could counteract that?Dan Gilbert: I actually was consulting recently with the Department of Homeland Security, which generally believes that American security dollars should go to making borders safer. I tried to point out to them that terrorism was a name based on people's psychological reaction to a set of events, and that if they were concerned about terrorism they might ask what causes terror and how can we stop people from being terrified, rather than — not rather than, but in addition to stopping the atrocities that we're all concerned about. Surely the kinds of play that at least American media give to — and forgive me, but in raw numbers these are very tiny accidents. We already know, for example, in the United States, more people have died as a result of not taking airplanes — because they were scared — and driving on highways, than were killed in 9/11. OK? If I told you that there was a plague that was going to kill 15,000 Americans next year, you might be alarmed if you didn't find out it was the flu. These are small-scale accidents, and we should be wondering whether they should get the kind of play, the kind of coverage, that they do. Surely that causes people to overestimate the likelihood that they'll be hurt in these various ways, and gives power to the very people who want to frighten us.CA: Dan, I'd like to hear more on this. So, you're saying that our response to terror is, I mean, it's a form of mental bug? Talk more about it.DG: It's out-sized. I mean, look. If Australia disappears tomorrow, terror is probably the right response. That's an awful large lot of very nice people. On the other hand, when a bus blows up and 30 people are killed, more people than that were killed by not using their seatbelts in the same country. Is terror the right response?CA: What causes the bug? Is it the drama of the event — that it's so spectacular? Is it the fact that it's an intentional attack by, quote, outsiders? What is it?DG: Yes. It's a number of things, and you hit on several of them. First, it's a human agent trying to kill us — it's not a tree falling on us by accident. Second, these are enemies who may want to strike and hurt us again. People are being killed for no reason instead of good reason — as if there's good reason, but sometimes people think there are. So there are a number of things that together make this seem like a fantastic event, but let's not play down the fact that newspapers sell when people see something in it they want to read. So there's a large role here played by the media, who want these things to be as spectacular as they possibly can.CA: I mean, what would it take to persuade our culture to downplay it?DG: Well, go to Israel. You know, go to Israel. And a mall blows up, and then everybody's unhappy about it, and an hour-and-a-half later — at least when I was there, and I was 150 feet from the mall when it blew up — I went back to my hotel and the wedding that was planned was still going on. And as the Israeli mother said, she said, "We never let them win by stopping weddings." I mean, this is a society that has learned — and there are others too — that has learned to live with a certain amount of terrorism and not be quite as upset by it, shall I say, as those of us who have not had many terror attacks.CA: But is there a rational fear that actually, the reason we're frightened about this is because we think that the Big One is to come?DG: Yes, of course. So, if we knew that this was the worst attack there would ever be, there might be more and more buses of 30 people — we would probably not be nearly so frightened. I don't want to say — please, I'm going to get quoted somewhere as saying, "Terrorism is fine and we shouldn't be so distressed." That's not my point at all. What I'm saying is that, surely, rationally, our distress about things that happen, about threats, should be roughly proportional to the size of those threats and threats to come. I think in the case of terrorism, it isn't. And many of the things we've heard about from our speakers today — how many people do you know got up and said, Poverty! I can't believe what poverty is doing to us. People get up in the morning; they don't care about poverty. It's not making headlines, it's not making news, it's not flashy. There are no guns going off. I mean, if you had to solve one of these problems, Chris, which would you solve? Terrorism or poverty? (Laughter) (Applause) That's a tough one.CA: There's no question. Poverty, by an order of magnitude, a huge order of magnitude, unless someone can show that there's, you know, terrorists with a nuke are really likely to come. The latest I've read, seen, thought is that it's incredibly hard for them to do that. If that turns out to be wrong, we all look silly, but with poverty it's a bit —DG: Even if that were true, still more people die from poverty.CA: We've evolved to get all excited about these dramatic attacks. Is that because in the past, in the ancient past, we just didn't understand things like disease and systems that cause poverty and so forth, and so it made no sense for us as a species to put any energy into worrying about those things? People died; so be it. But if you got attacked, that was something you could do something about. And so we evolved these responses. Is that what happened?DG: Well, you know, the people who are most skeptical about leaping to evolutionary explanations for everything are the evolutionary psychologists themselves. My guess is that there's nothing quite that specific in our evolutionary past. But rather, if you're looking for an evolutionary explanation, you might say that most organisms are neo-phobic — that is, they're a little scared of stuff that's new and different. And there's a good reason to be, because old stuff didn't eat you. Right? Any animal you see that you've seen before is less likely to be a predator than one that you've never seen before. So, you know, when a school bus is blown up and we've never seen this before, our general tendency is to orient towards that which is new and novel is activated. I don't think it's quite as specific a mechanism as the one you alluded to, but maybe a more fundamental one underlying it.Jay Walker: You know, economists love to talk about the stupidity of people who buy lottery tickets. But I suspect you're making the exact same error you're accusing those people of, which is the error of value. I know, because I've interviewed about 1,000 lottery buyers over the years. It turns out that the value of buying a lottery ticket is not winning. That's what you think it is. All right? The average lottery buyer buys about 150 tickets a year, so the buyer knows full well that he or she is going to lose, and yet she buys 150 tickets a year. Why is that? It's not because she is stupid or he is stupid. It's because the anticipation of possibly winning releases serotonin in the brain, and actually provides a good feeling until the drawing indicates you've lost. Or, to put it another way, for the dollar investment, you can have a much better feeling than flushing the money down the toilet, which you cannot have a good feeling from. Now, economists tend to — (Applause) — economists tend to view the world through their own lenses, which is: this is just a bunch of stupid people. And as a result, many people look at economists as stupid people. And so fundamentally, the reason we got to the moon is, we didn't listen to the economists. Thank you very much. (Applause)DG: Well, no, it's a great point. It remains to be seen whether the joy of anticipation is exactly equaled by the amount of disappointment after the lottery. Because remember, people who didn't buy tickets don't feel awful the next day either, even though they don't feel great during the drawing. I would disagree that people know they're not going to win. I think they think it's unlikely, but it could happen, which is why they prefer that to the flushing. But certainly I see your point: that there can be some utility to buying a lottery ticket other than winning. Now, I think there's many good reasons not to listen to economists. That isn't one of them, for me, but there's many others.CA: Last question.Aubrey de Grey: My name's Aubrey de Grey, from Cambridge. I work on the thing that kills more people than anything else kills — I work on aging — and I'm interested in doing something about it, as we'll all hear tomorrow. I very much resonate with what you're saying, because it seems to me that the problem with getting people interested in doing anything about aging is that by the time aging is about to kill you it looks like cancer or heart disease or whatever. Do you have any advice? (Laughter)DG: For you or for them?AdG: In persuading them.DG: Ah, for you in persuading them. Well, it's notoriously difficult to get people to be farsighted. But one thing that psychologists have tried that seems to work is to get people to imagine the future more vividly. One of the problems with making decisions about the far future and the near future is that we imagine the near future much more vividly than the far future. To the extent that you can equalize the amount of detail that people put into the mental representations of near and far future, people begin to make decisions about the two in the same way. So, would you like to have an extra 100,000 dollars when you're 65 is a question that's very different than, imagine who you'll be when you're 65: will you be living, what will you look like, how much hair will you have, who will you be living with. Once we have all the details of that imaginary scenario, suddenly we feel like it might be important to save so that that guy has a little retirement money. But these are tricks around the margins. I think in general you're battling a very fundamental human tendency, which is to say, "I'm here today, and so now is more important than later."CA: Dan, thank you. Members of the audience, that was a fantastic session. Thank you. (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
We all make decisions every day; we want to know

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:16.958
what the right thing is to do -- in domains from the financial

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:20.958
to the gastronomic to the professional to the romantic.

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
And surely, if somebody could really tell us how to do

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:26.958
exactly the right thing at all possible times,

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
that would be a tremendous gift.

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:34.958
It turns out that, in fact, the world was given this gift in 1738

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
by a Dutch polymath named Daniel Bernoulli.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:40.958
And what I want to talk to you about today is what that gift is,

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:43.958
and I also want to explain to you why it is

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:46.958
that it hasn't made a damn bit of difference.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:51.958
Now, this is Bernoulli's gift. This is a direct quote.

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:54.958
And if it looks like Greek to you, it's because, well, it's Greek.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:59.958
But the simple English translation -- much less precise,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:03.958
but it captures the gist of what Bernoulli had to say -- was this:

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
The expected value of any of our actions --

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:09.958
that is, the goodness that we can count on getting --

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
is the product of two simple things:

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:15.958
the odds that this action will allow us to gain something,

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
and the value of that gain to us.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
In a sense, what Bernoulli was saying is,

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:23.958
if we can estimate and multiply these two things,

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:26.958
we will always know precisely how we should behave.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:29.958
Now, this simple equation, even for those of you

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
who don't like equations, is something that you're quite used to.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:35.958
Here's an example: if I were to tell you, let's play

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:38.958
a little coin toss game, and I'm going to flip a coin,

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
and if it comes up heads, I'm going to pay you 10 dollars,

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:45.958
but you have to pay four dollars for the privilege of playing with me,

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:48.958
most of you would say, sure, I'll take that bet. Because you know

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:53.958
that the odds of you winning are one half, the gain if you do is 10 dollars,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:55.958
that multiplies to five, and that's more

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:59.958
than I'm charging you to play. So, the answer is, yes.

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:03.958
This is what statisticians technically call a damn fine bet.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
Now, the idea is simple when we're applying it to coin tosses,

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:10.958
but in fact, it's not very simple in everyday life.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:14.958
People are horrible at estimating both of these things,

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
and that's what I want to talk to you about today.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
There are two kinds of errors people make when trying to decide

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:21.958
what the right thing is to do, and those are

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:24.958
errors in estimating the odds that they're going to succeed,

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:28.958
and errors in estimating the value of their own success.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:32.958
Now, let me talk about the first one first.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
Calculating odds would seem to be something rather easy:

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:38.958
there are six sides to a die, two sides to a coin, 52 cards in a deck.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:42.958
You all know what the likelihood is of pulling the ace of spades

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:43.958
or of flipping a heads.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:48.958
But as it turns out, this is not a very easy idea to apply

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:51.958
in everyday life. That's why Americans spend more --

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.958
I should say, lose more -- gambling

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:59.958
than on all other forms of entertainment combined.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
The reason is, this isn't how people do odds.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:03.958
The way people figure odds

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
requires that we first talk a bit about pigs.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
Now, the question I'm going to put to you is whether you think

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
there are more dogs or pigs on leashes

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
observed in any particular day in Oxford.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
And of course, you all know that the answer is dogs.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
And the way that you know that the answer is dogs is

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
you quickly reviewed in memory the times

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
you've seen dogs and pigs on leashes.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
It was very easy to remember seeing dogs,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:29.958
not so easy to remember pigs. And each one of you assumed

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:33.958
that if dogs on leashes came more quickly to your mind,

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
then dogs on leashes are more probable.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:40.958
That's not a bad rule of thumb, except when it is.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
So, for example, here's a word puzzle.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
Are there more four-letter English words

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:48.958
with R in the third place or R in the first place?

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.958
Well, you check memory very briefly, make a quick scan,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.958
and it's awfully easy to say to yourself, Ring, Rang, Rung,

00:03:54.958 --> 00:04:01.958
and very hard to say to yourself, Pare, Park: they come more slowly.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
But in fact, there are many more words in the English language

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.958
with R in the third than the first place.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:10.958
The reason words with R in the third place come slowly to your mind

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
isn't because they're improbable, unlikely or infrequent.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:17.958
It's because the mind recalls words by their first letter.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
You kind of shout out the sound, S -- and the word comes.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:21.958
It's like the dictionary;

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
it's hard to look things up by the third letter.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
So, this is an example of how this idea that

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
the quickness with which things come to mind

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
can give you a sense of their probability --

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:34.958
how this idea could lead you astray. It's not just puzzles, though.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
For example, when Americans are asked to estimate the odds

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
that they will die in a variety of interesting ways --

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
these are estimates of number of deaths per year

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
per 200 million U.S. citizens.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
And these are just ordinary people like yourselves who are asked

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:51.958
to guess how many people die from tornado, fireworks, asthma, drowning, etc.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
Compare these to the actual numbers.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
Now, you see a very interesting pattern here, which is first of all,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:02.958
two things are vastly over-estimated, namely tornadoes and fireworks.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
Two things are vastly underestimated:

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
dying by drowning and dying by asthma. Why?

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
When was the last time that you picked up a newspaper

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
and the headline was, "Boy dies of Asthma?"

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
It's not interesting because it's so common.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:20.958
It's very easy for all of us to bring to mind instances

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
of news stories or newsreels where we've seen

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
tornadoes devastating cities, or some poor schmuck

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:29.958
who's blown his hands off with a firework on the Fourth of July.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
Drownings and asthma deaths don't get much coverage.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
They don't come quickly to mind, and as a result,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
we vastly underestimate them.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
Indeed, this is kind of like the Sesame Street game

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
of "Which thing doesn't belong?" And you're right to say

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
it's the swimming pool that doesn't belong, because the swimming pool

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:49.958
is the only thing on this slide that's actually very dangerous.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
The way that more of you are likely to die than the combination

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:55.958
of all three of the others that you see on the slide.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:59.958
The lottery is an excellent example, of course -- an excellent test-case

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
of people's ability to compute probabilities.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
And economists -- forgive me, for those of you who play the lottery --

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
but economists, at least among themselves, refer to the lottery

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:13.958
as a stupidity tax, because the odds of getting any payoff

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
by investing your money in a lottery ticket

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
are approximately equivalent to flushing the money

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
directly down the toilet -- which, by the way,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:23.958
doesn't require that you actually go to the store and buy anything.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
Why in the world would anybody ever play the lottery?

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
Well, there are many answers, but one answer surely is,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:33.958
we see a lot of winners. Right? When this couple wins the lottery,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
or Ed McMahon shows up at your door with this giant check --

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
how the hell do you cash things that size, I don't know.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
We see this on TV; we read about it in the paper.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
When was the last time that you saw extensive interviews

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
with everybody who lost?

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
Indeed, if we required that television stations run

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
a 30-second interview with each loser

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:56.958
every time they interview a winner, the 100 million losers

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
in the last lottery would require nine-and-a-half years

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
of your undivided attention just to watch them say,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
"Me? I lost." "Me? I lost."

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
Now, if you watch nine-and-a-half years of television --

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:12.958
no sleep, no potty breaks -- and you saw loss after loss after loss,

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
and then at the end there's 30 seconds of, "and I won,"

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
the likelihood that you would play the lottery is very small.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
Look, I can prove this to you: here's a little lottery.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
There's 10 tickets in this lottery.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
Nine of them have been sold to these individuals.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
It costs you a dollar to buy the ticket and, if you win,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
you get 20 bucks. Is this a good bet?

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:31.958
Well, Bernoulli tells us it is.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
The expected value of this lottery is two dollars;

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
this is a lottery in which you should invest your money.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
And most people say, "OK, I'll play."

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
Now, a slightly different version of this lottery:

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
imagine that the nine tickets are all owned

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
by one fat guy named Leroy.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
Leroy has nine tickets; there's one left.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
Do you want it? Most people won't play this lottery.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
Now, you can see the odds of winning haven't changed,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:58.958
but it's now fantastically easy to imagine who's going to win.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
It's easy to see Leroy getting the check, right?

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
You can't say to yourself, "I'm as likely to win as anybody,"

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
because you're not as likely to win as Leroy.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
The fact that all those tickets are owned by one guy

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
changes your decision to play,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
even though it does nothing whatsoever to the odds.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:18.958
Now, estimating odds, as difficult as it may seem, is a piece of cake

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
compared to trying to estimate value:

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
trying to say what something is worth, how much we'll enjoy it,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
how much pleasure it will give us.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
I want to talk now about errors in value.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:32.958
How much is this Big Mac worth? Is it worth 25 dollars?

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
Most of you have the intuition that it's not --

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
you wouldn't pay that for it.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:41.958
But in fact, to decide whether a Big Mac is worth 25 dollars requires

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
that you ask one, and only one question, which is:

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
What else can I do with 25 dollars?

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:50.958
If you've ever gotten on one of those long-haul flights to Australia

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
and realized that they're not going to serve you any food,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
but somebody in the row in front of you has just opened

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
the McDonald's bag, and the smell of golden arches

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
is wafting over the seat, you think,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
I can't do anything else with this 25 dollars for 16 hours.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
I can't even set it on fire -- they took my cigarette lighter!

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
Suddenly, 25 dollars for a Big Mac might be a good deal.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
On the other hand, if you're visiting an underdeveloped country,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:16.958
and 25 dollars buys you a gourmet meal, it's exorbitant for a Big Mac.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
Why were you all sure that the answer to the question was no,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
before I'd even told you anything about the context?

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:26.958
Because most of you compared the price of this Big Mac

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
to the price you're used to paying. Rather than asking,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
"What else can I do with my money," comparing this investment

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:36.958
to other possible investments, you compared to the past.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
And this is a systematic error people make.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:43.958
What you knew is, you paid three dollars in the past; 25 is outrageous.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
This is an error, and I can prove it to you by showing

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
the kinds of irrationalities to which it leads.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
For example, this is, of course,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
one of the most delicious tricks in marketing,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
is to say something used to be higher,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
and suddenly it seems like a very good deal.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
When people are asked about these two different jobs:

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
a job where you make 60K, then 50K, then 40K,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
a job where you're getting a salary cut each year,

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
and one in which you're getting a salary increase,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:11.958
people like the second job better than the first, despite the fact

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
they're all told they make much less money. Why?

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:18.958
Because they had the sense that declining wages are worse

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:22.958
than rising wages, even when the total amount of wages is higher

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:26.958
in the declining period. Here's another nice example.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:31.958
Here's a $2,000 Hawaiian vacation package; it's now on sale for 1,600.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
Assuming you wanted to go to Hawaii, would you buy this package?

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:38.958
Most people say they would. Here's a slightly different story:

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:42.958
$2,000 Hawaiian vacation package is now on sale for 700 dollars,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
so you decide to mull it over for a week.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
By the time you get to the ticket agency, the best fares are gone --

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:51.958
the package now costs 1,500. Would you buy it? Most people say, no.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:55.958
Why? Because it used to cost 700, and there's no way I'm paying 1,500

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
for something that was 700 last week.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
This tendency to compare to the past

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:04.958
is causing people to pass up the better deal. In other words,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
a good deal that used to be a great deal is not nearly as good

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:11.958
as an awful deal that was once a horrible deal.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
Here's another example of how comparing to the past

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:17.958
can befuddle our decisions.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
Imagine that you're going to the theater.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:20.958
You're on your way to the theater.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
In your wallet you have a ticket, for which you paid 20 dollars.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
You also have a 20-dollar bill.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
When you arrive at the theater,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
you discover that somewhere along the way you've lost the ticket.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
Would you spend your remaining money on replacing it?

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
Most people answer, no.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
Now, let's just change one thing in this scenario.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:39.958
You're on your way to the theater,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
and in your wallet you have two 20-dollar bills.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
When you arrive you discover you've lost one of them.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
Would you spend your remaining 20 dollars on a ticket?

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
Well, of course, I went to the theater to see the play.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
What does the loss of 20 dollars along the way have to do?

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
Now, just in case you're not getting it,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
here's a schematic of what happened, OK?

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:57.958
(Laughter)

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
Along the way, you lost something.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
In both cases, it was a piece of paper.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:05.958
In one case, it had a U.S. president on it; in the other case it didn't.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
What the hell difference should it make?

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
The difference is that when you lost the ticket you say to yourself,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
I'm not paying twice for the same thing.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
You compare the cost of the play now -- 40 dollars --

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:20.958
to the cost that it used to have -- 20 dollars -- and you say it's a bad deal.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:24.958
Comparing with the past causes many of the problems

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
that behavioral economists and psychologists identify

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
in people's attempts to assign value.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:34.958
But even when we compare with the possible, instead of the past,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
we still make certain kinds of mistakes.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
And I'm going to show you one or two of them.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
One of the things we know about comparison:

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
that when we compare one thing to the other, it changes its value.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:48.958
So in 1992, this fellow, George Bush, for those of us who were

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
kind of on the liberal side of the political spectrum,

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
didn't seem like such a great guy.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:57.958
Suddenly, we're almost longing for him to return.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
(Laughter)

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
The comparison changes how we evaluate him.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:07.958
Now, retailers knew this long before anybody else did, of course,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
and they use this wisdom to help you --

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
spare you the undue burden of money.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
And so a retailer, if you were to go into a wine shop

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:15.958
and you had to buy a bottle of wine,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:19.958
and you see them here for eight, 27 and 33 dollars, what would you do?

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
Most people don't want the most expensive,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
they don't want the least expensive.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
So, they will opt for the item in the middle.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
If you're a smart retailer, then, you will put a very expensive item

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
that nobody will ever buy on the shelf,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:36.958
because suddenly the $33 wine doesn't look as expensive in comparison.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:37.958
So I'm telling you something you already knew:

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:41.958
namely, that comparison changes the value of things.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:42.958
Here's why that's a problem:

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:48.958
the problem is that when you get that $33 bottle of wine home,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:52.958
it won't matter what it used to be sitting on the shelf next to.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:57.958
The comparisons we make when we are appraising value,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:01.958
where we're trying to estimate how much we'll like things,

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
are not the same comparisons we'll be making when we consume them.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:08.958
This problem of shifting comparisons can bedevil

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
our attempts to make rational decisions.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:12.958
Let me just give you an example.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:16.958
I have to show you something from my own lab, so let me sneak this in.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
These are subjects coming to an experiment to be asked

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
the simplest of all questions:

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:24.958
How much will you enjoy eating potato chips one minute from now?

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
They're sitting in a room with potato chips in front of them.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
For some of the subjects, sitting in the far corner of a room

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:35.958
is a box of Godiva chocolates, and for others is a can of Spam.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:39.958
In fact, these items that are sitting in the room change

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
how much the subjects think they're going to enjoy the potato chips.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
Namely, those who are looking at Spam

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
think potato chips are going to be quite tasty;

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
those who are looking at Godiva chocolate

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
think they won't be nearly so tasty.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
Of course, what happens when they eat the potato chips?

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
Well, look, you didn't need a psychologist to tell you that

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:59.958
when you have a mouthful of greasy, salty, crispy, delicious snacks,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:00.958
what's sitting in the corner of the room

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:05.958
makes not a damn bit of difference to your gustatory experience.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:09.958
Nonetheless, their predictions are perverted by a comparison

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:13.958
that then does not carry through and change their experience.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
You've all experienced this yourself, even if you've never come

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
into our lab to eat potato chips. So here's a question:

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
You want to buy a car stereo.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:25.958
The dealer near your house sells this particular stereo for 200 dollars,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
but if you drive across town, you can get it for 100 bucks.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
So would you drive to get 50 percent off, saving 100 dollars?

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
Most people say they would.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
They can't imagine buying it for twice the price

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:39.958
when, with one trip across town, they can get it for half off.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:43.958
Now, let's imagine instead you wanted to buy a car that had a stereo,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
and the dealer near your house had it for 31,000.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:50.958
But if you drove across town, you could get it for 30,900.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:54.958
Would you drive to get it? At this point, 0.003 savings -- the 100 dollars.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
Most people say, no, I'm going to schlep across town

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
to save 100 bucks on the purchase of a car?

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:03.958
This kind of thinking drives economists crazy, and it should.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:07.958
Because this 100 dollars that you save -- hello! --

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
doesn't know where it came from.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
It doesn't know what you saved it on.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:13.958
When you go to buy groceries with it, it doesn't go,

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
I'm the money saved on the car stereo, or,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:20.958
I'm the dumb money saved on the car. It's money.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
And if a drive across town is worth 100 bucks, it's worth 100 bucks

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
no matter what you're saving it on. People don't think that way.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
That's why they don't know whether their mutual fund manager

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:33.958
is taking 0.1 percent or 0.15 percent of their investment,

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
but they clip coupons to save one dollar off of toothpaste.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
Now, you can see, this is the problem of shifting comparisons,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
because what you're doing is, you're comparing the 100 bucks

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
to the purchase that you're making,

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:48.958
but when you go to spend that money you won't be making that comparison.

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
You've all had this experience.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:54.958
If you're an American, for example, you've probably traveled in France.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
And at some point you may have met a couple

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:57.958
from your own hometown, and you thought,

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:02.958
"Oh, my God, these people are so warm. They're so nice to me.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
I mean, compared to all these people who hate me

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
when I try to speak their language and hate me more when I don't,

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.958
these people are just wonderful." And so you tour France with them,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
and then you get home and you invite them over for dinner,

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:13.958
and what do you find?

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
Compared to your regular friends,

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:19.958
they are boring and dull, right? Because in this new context,

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:23.958
the comparison is very, very different. In fact, you find yourself

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
disliking them enough almost to qualify for French citizenship.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:30.958
Now, you have exactly the same problem when you shop for a stereo.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
You go to the stereo store, you see two sets of speakers --

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:37.958
these big, boxy, monoliths, and these little, sleek speakers,

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:39.958
and you play them, and you go, you know, I do hear a difference:

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
the big ones sound a little better.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:43.958
And so you buy them, and you bring them home,

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:46.958
and you entirely violate the décor of your house.

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:50.958
And the problem, of course, is that this comparison you made in the store

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:52.958
is a comparison you'll never make again.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
What are the odds that years later you'll turn on the stereo and go,

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
"Sounds so much better than those little ones,"

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
which you can't even remember hearing.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
The problem of shifting comparisons is even more difficult

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:05.958
when these choices are arrayed over time.

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:08.958
People have a lot of trouble making decisions

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:11.958
about things that will happen at different points in time.

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:13.958
And what psychologists and behavioral economists have discovered

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:16.958
is that by and large people use two simple rules.

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:20.958
So let me give you one very easy problem, a second very easy problem

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:21.958
and then a third, hard, problem.

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:24.958
Here's the first easy problem:

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:27.958
You can have 60 dollars now or 50 dollars now. Which would you prefer?

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:30.958
This is what we call a one-item IQ test, OK?

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.958
All of us, I hope, prefer more money, and the reason is,

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:36.958
we believe more is better than less.

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:37.958
Here's the second problem:

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:41.958
You can have 60 dollars today or 60 dollars in a month. Which would you prefer?

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:43.958
Again, an easy decision,

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:47.958
because we all know that now is better than later.

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
What's hard in our decision-making is when these two rules conflict.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:54.958
For example, when you're offered 50 dollars now or 60 dollars in a month.

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:57.958
This typifies a lot of situations in life in which you will gain

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:00.958
by waiting, but you have to be patient.

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:03.958
What do we know? What do people do in these kinds of situations?

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:07.958
Well, by and large people are enormously impatient.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:10.958
That is, they require interest rates in the hundred

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:14.958
or thousands of percents in order to delay gratification

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:18.958
and wait until next month for the extra 10 dollars.

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:21.958
Maybe that isn't so remarkable, but what is remarkable is

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:25.958
how easy it is to make this impatience go away by simply changing

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:29.958
when the delivery of these monetary units will happen.

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:32.958
Imagine that you can have 50 dollars in a year -- that's 12 months --

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:35.958
or 60 dollars in 13 months.

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:36.958
What do we find now?

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:39.958
People are gladly willing to wait: as long as they're waiting 12,

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:41.958
they might as well wait 13.

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:44.958
What makes this dynamic inconsistency happen?

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:48.958
Comparison. Troubling comparison. Let me show you.

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:51.958
This is just a graph showing the results that I just suggested

00:19:51.958 --> 00:19:53.958
you would show if I gave you time to respond, which is,

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:56.958
people find that the subjective value of 50 is higher

00:19:56.958 --> 00:20:00.958
than the subjective value of 60 when they'll be delivered in now

00:20:00.958 --> 00:20:02.958
or one month, respectively -- a 30-day delay --

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:06.958
but they show the reverse pattern when you push the entire decision

00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:09.958
off into the future a year.

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:13.958
Now, why in the world do you get this pattern of results?

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:14.958
These guys can tell us.

00:20:14.958 --> 00:20:17.958
What you see here are two lads,

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:20.958
one of them larger than the other: the fireman and the fiddler.

00:20:20.958 --> 00:20:23.958
They are going to recede towards the vanishing point in the horizon,

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:25.958
and I want you to notice two things.

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:31.958
At no point will the fireman look taller than the fiddler. No point.

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:34.958
However, the difference between them seems to be getting smaller.

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:37.958
First it's an inch in your view, then it's a quarter-inch,

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:41.958
then a half-inch, and then finally they go off the edge of the earth.

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:44.958
Here are the results of what I just showed you.

00:20:44.958 --> 00:20:46.958
This is the subjective height --

00:20:46.958 --> 00:20:49.958
the height you saw of these guys at various points.

00:20:49.958 --> 00:20:51.958
And I want you to see that two things are true.

00:20:51.958 --> 00:20:54.958
One, the farther away they are, the smaller they look;

00:20:54.958 --> 00:20:56.958
and two, the fireman is always bigger than the fiddler.

00:20:56.958 --> 00:21:02.958
But watch what happens when we make some of them disappear. Right.

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:05.958
At a very close distance, the fiddler looks taller than the fireman,

00:21:05.958 --> 00:21:07.958
but at a far distance

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:10.958
their normal, their true, relations are preserved.

00:21:10.958 --> 00:21:15.958
As Plato said, what space is to size, time is to value.

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:20.958
These are the results of the hard problem I gave you:

00:21:20.958 --> 00:21:22.958
60 now or 50 in a month?

00:21:22.958 --> 00:21:23.958
And these are subjective values,

00:21:23.958 --> 00:21:25.958
and what you can see is, our two rules are preserved.

00:21:25.958 --> 00:21:27.958
People always think more is better than less:

00:21:27.958 --> 00:21:29.958
60 is always better than 50,

00:21:29.958 --> 00:21:31.958
and they always think now is better than later:

00:21:31.958 --> 00:21:34.958
the bars on this side are higher than the bars on this side.

00:21:34.958 --> 00:21:37.958
Watch what happens when we drop some out.

00:21:37.958 --> 00:21:40.958
Suddenly we have the dynamic inconsistency that puzzled us.

00:21:40.958 --> 00:21:44.958
We have the tendency for people to go for 50 dollars now

00:21:44.958 --> 00:21:47.958
over waiting a month, but not if that decision is far in the future.

00:21:47.958 --> 00:21:51.958
Notice something interesting that this implies -- namely, that

00:21:51.958 --> 00:21:55.958
when people get to the future, they will change their minds.

00:21:55.958 --> 00:21:58.958
That is, as that month 12 approaches, you will say,

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:01.958
what was I thinking, waiting an extra month for 60 dollars?

00:22:01.958 --> 00:22:04.958
I'll take the 50 dollars now.

00:22:04.958 --> 00:22:07.958
Well, the question with which I'd like to end is this:

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:10.958
If we're so damn stupid, how did we get to the moon?

00:22:10.958 --> 00:22:13.958
Because I could go on for about two hours with evidence

00:22:13.958 --> 00:22:19.958
of people's inability to estimate odds and inability to estimate value.

00:22:19.958 --> 00:22:21.958
The answer to this question, I think, is an answer you've already heard

00:22:21.958 --> 00:22:23.958
in some of the talks, and I dare say you will hear again:

00:22:23.958 --> 00:22:27.958
namely, that our brains were evolved for a very different world

00:22:27.958 --> 00:22:29.958
than the one in which we are living.

00:22:29.958 --> 00:22:31.958
They were evolved for a world

00:22:31.958 --> 00:22:33.958
in which people lived in very small groups,

00:22:33.958 --> 00:22:36.958
rarely met anybody who was terribly different from themselves,

00:22:36.958 --> 00:22:39.958
had rather short lives in which there were few choices

00:22:39.958 --> 00:22:44.958
and the highest priority was to eat and mate today.

00:22:44.958 --> 00:22:49.958
Bernoulli's gift, Bernoulli's little formula, allows us, it tells us

00:22:49.958 --> 00:22:54.958
how we should think in a world for which nature never designed us.

00:22:54.958 --> 00:22:58.958
That explains why we are so bad at using it, but it also explains

00:22:58.958 --> 00:23:03.958
why it is so terribly important that we become good, fast.

00:23:03.958 --> 00:23:05.958
We are the only species on this planet

00:23:05.958 --> 00:23:09.958
that has ever held its own fate in its hands.

00:23:09.958 --> 00:23:11.958
We have no significant predators,

00:23:11.958 --> 00:23:13.958
we're the masters of our physical environment;

00:23:13.958 --> 00:23:16.958
the things that normally cause species to become extinct

00:23:16.958 --> 00:23:19.958
are no longer any threat to us.

00:23:19.958 --> 00:23:24.958
The only thing -- the only thing -- that can destroy us and doom us

00:23:24.958 --> 00:23:26.958
are our own decisions.

00:23:26.958 --> 00:23:30.958
If we're not here in 10,000 years, it's going to be because

00:23:30.958 --> 00:23:34.958
we could not take advantage of the gift given to us

00:23:34.958 --> 00:23:37.958
by a young Dutch fellow in 1738,

00:23:37.958 --> 00:23:41.958
because we underestimated the odds of our future pains

00:23:41.958 --> 00:23:45.958
and overestimated the value of our present pleasures.

00:23:45.958 --> 00:23:46.958
Thank you.

00:23:46.958 --> 00:23:56.958
(Applause)

00:23:56.958 --> 00:23:59.958
Chris Anderson: That was remarkable.

00:23:59.958 --> 00:24:04.958
We have time for some questions for Dan Gilbert. One and two.

00:24:04.958 --> 00:24:07.958
Bill Lyell: Would you say that this mechanism

00:24:07.958 --> 00:24:11.958
is in part how terrorism actually works to frighten us,

00:24:11.958 --> 00:24:15.958
and is there some way that we could counteract that?

00:24:15.958 --> 00:24:16.958
Dan Gilbert: I actually was consulting recently

00:24:16.958 --> 00:24:19.958
with the Department of Homeland Security, which generally believes

00:24:19.958 --> 00:24:23.958
that American security dollars should go to making borders safer.

00:24:23.958 --> 00:24:26.958
I tried to point out to them that terrorism was a name

00:24:26.958 --> 00:24:30.958
based on people's psychological reaction to a set of events,

00:24:30.958 --> 00:24:32.958
and that if they were concerned about terrorism they might ask

00:24:32.958 --> 00:24:35.958
what causes terror and how can we stop people from being terrified,

00:24:35.958 --> 00:24:38.958
rather than -- not rather than, but in addition to

00:24:38.958 --> 00:24:41.958
stopping the atrocities that we're all concerned about.

00:24:41.958 --> 00:24:47.958
Surely the kinds of play that at least American media give to --

00:24:47.958 --> 00:24:52.958
and forgive me, but in raw numbers these are very tiny accidents.

00:24:52.958 --> 00:24:54.958
We already know, for example, in the United States,

00:24:54.958 --> 00:24:58.958
more people have died as a result of not taking airplanes --

00:24:58.958 --> 00:25:00.958
because they were scared -- and driving on highways,

00:25:00.958 --> 00:25:02.958
than were killed in 9/11. OK?

00:25:02.958 --> 00:25:04.958
If I told you that there was a plague

00:25:04.958 --> 00:25:07.958
that was going to kill 15,000 Americans next year,

00:25:07.958 --> 00:25:10.958
you might be alarmed if you didn't find out it was the flu.

00:25:10.958 --> 00:25:13.958
These are small-scale accidents, and we should be wondering

00:25:13.958 --> 00:25:15.958
whether they should get the kind of play,

00:25:15.958 --> 00:25:17.958
the kind of coverage, that they do.

00:25:17.958 --> 00:25:20.958
Surely that causes people to overestimate the likelihood

00:25:20.958 --> 00:25:22.958
that they'll be hurt in these various ways,

00:25:22.958 --> 00:25:24.958
and gives power to the very people who want to frighten us.

00:25:24.958 --> 00:25:26.958
CA: Dan, I'd like to hear more on this. So, you're saying

00:25:26.958 --> 00:25:30.958
that our response to terror is, I mean, it's a form of mental bug?

00:25:30.958 --> 00:25:31.958
Talk more about it.

00:25:31.958 --> 00:25:34.958
DG: It's out-sized. I mean, look.

00:25:34.958 --> 00:25:36.958
If Australia disappears tomorrow,

00:25:36.958 --> 00:25:38.958
terror is probably the right response.

00:25:38.958 --> 00:25:43.958
That's an awful large lot of very nice people. On the other hand,

00:25:43.958 --> 00:25:46.958
when a bus blows up and 30 people are killed,

00:25:46.958 --> 00:25:48.958
more people than that were killed

00:25:48.958 --> 00:25:51.958
by not using their seatbelts in the same country.

00:25:51.958 --> 00:25:52.958
Is terror the right response?

00:25:52.958 --> 00:25:56.958
CA: What causes the bug? Is it the drama of the event --

00:25:56.958 --> 00:25:57.958
that it's so spectacular?

00:25:57.958 --> 00:26:00.958
Is it the fact that it's an intentional attack by, quote, outsiders?

00:26:00.958 --> 00:26:01.958
What is it?

00:26:01.958 --> 00:26:04.958
DG: Yes. It's a number of things, and you hit on several of them.

00:26:04.958 --> 00:26:06.958
First, it's a human agent trying to kill us --

00:26:06.958 --> 00:26:09.958
it's not a tree falling on us by accident.

00:26:09.958 --> 00:26:12.958
Second, these are enemies who may want to strike and hurt us again.

00:26:12.958 --> 00:26:15.958
People are being killed for no reason instead of good reason --

00:26:15.958 --> 00:26:18.958
as if there's good reason, but sometimes people think there are.

00:26:18.958 --> 00:26:20.958
So there are a number of things that together

00:26:20.958 --> 00:26:23.958
make this seem like a fantastic event, but let's not play down

00:26:23.958 --> 00:26:27.958
the fact that newspapers sell when people see something in it

00:26:27.958 --> 00:26:30.958
they want to read. So there's a large role here played by the media,

00:26:30.958 --> 00:26:32.958
who want these things to be

00:26:32.958 --> 00:26:36.958
as spectacular as they possibly can.

00:26:36.958 --> 00:26:42.958
CA: I mean, what would it take to persuade our culture to downplay it?

00:26:42.958 --> 00:26:43.958
DG: Well, go to Israel. You know,

00:26:43.958 --> 00:26:45.958
go to Israel. And a mall blows up,

00:26:45.958 --> 00:26:48.958
and then everybody's unhappy about it, and an hour-and-a-half later --

00:26:48.958 --> 00:26:51.958
at least when I was there, and I was 150 feet from the mall

00:26:51.958 --> 00:26:53.958
when it blew up -- I went back to my hotel

00:26:53.958 --> 00:26:56.958
and the wedding that was planned was still going on.

00:26:56.958 --> 00:26:57.958
And as the Israeli mother said,

00:26:57.958 --> 00:27:01.958
she said, "We never let them win by stopping weddings."

00:27:01.958 --> 00:27:02.958
I mean, this is a society that has learned --

00:27:02.958 --> 00:27:04.958
and there are others too -- that has learned to live

00:27:04.958 --> 00:27:09.958
with a certain amount of terrorism and not be quite as upset by it,

00:27:09.958 --> 00:27:12.958
shall I say, as those of us who have not had many terror attacks.

00:27:12.958 --> 00:27:15.958
CA: But is there a rational fear that actually,

00:27:15.958 --> 00:27:18.958
the reason we're frightened about this is because we think that

00:27:18.958 --> 00:27:19.958
the Big One is to come?

00:27:19.958 --> 00:27:23.958
DG: Yes, of course. So, if we knew that this was the worst attack

00:27:23.958 --> 00:27:27.958
there would ever be, there might be more and more buses of 30 people --

00:27:27.958 --> 00:27:29.958
we would probably not be nearly so frightened.

00:27:29.958 --> 00:27:31.958
I don't want to say -- please, I'm going to get quoted somewhere

00:27:31.958 --> 00:27:35.958
as saying, "Terrorism is fine and we shouldn't be so distressed."

00:27:35.958 --> 00:27:37.958
That's not my point at all.

00:27:37.958 --> 00:27:39.958
What I'm saying is that, surely, rationally,

00:27:39.958 --> 00:27:43.958
our distress about things that happen, about threats,

00:27:43.958 --> 00:27:46.958
should be roughly proportional to the size of those threats

00:27:46.958 --> 00:27:48.958
and threats to come.

00:27:48.958 --> 00:27:51.958
I think in the case of terrorism, it isn't.

00:27:51.958 --> 00:27:53.958
And many of the things we've heard about from our speakers today --

00:27:53.958 --> 00:27:55.958
how many people do you know got up and said,

00:27:55.958 --> 00:27:59.958
Poverty! I can't believe what poverty is doing to us.

00:27:59.958 --> 00:28:01.958
People get up in the morning; they don't care about poverty.

00:28:01.958 --> 00:28:03.958
It's not making headlines, it's not making news, it's not flashy.

00:28:03.958 --> 00:28:05.958
There are no guns going off.

00:28:05.958 --> 00:28:07.958
I mean, if you had to solve one of these problems, Chris,

00:28:07.958 --> 00:28:09.958
which would you solve? Terrorism or poverty?

00:28:09.958 --> 00:28:13.958
(Laughter)

00:28:13.958 --> 00:28:15.958
(Applause)

00:28:15.958 --> 00:28:17.958
That's a tough one.

00:28:17.958 --> 00:28:18.958
CA: There's no question.

00:28:18.958 --> 00:28:22.958
Poverty, by an order of magnitude, a huge order of magnitude,
