00:28:22.958 --> 00:28:25.958
unless someone can show that there's, you know,

00:28:25.958 --> 00:28:29.958
terrorists with a nuke are really likely to come.

00:28:29.958 --> 00:28:31.958
The latest I've read, seen, thought

00:28:31.958 --> 00:28:35.958
is that it's incredibly hard for them to do that.

00:28:35.958 --> 00:28:37.958
If that turns out to be wrong, we all look silly,

00:28:37.958 --> 00:28:39.958
but with poverty it's a bit --

00:28:39.958 --> 00:28:42.958
DG: Even if that were true, still more people die from poverty.

00:28:46.958 --> 00:28:47.958
CA: We've evolved to get all excited

00:28:47.958 --> 00:28:50.958
about these dramatic attacks. Is that because in the past,

00:28:50.958 --> 00:28:53.958
in the ancient past, we just didn't understand things like disease

00:28:53.958 --> 00:28:55.958
and systems that cause poverty and so forth,

00:28:55.958 --> 00:28:59.958
and so it made no sense for us as a species to put any energy

00:28:59.958 --> 00:29:01.958
into worrying about those things?

00:29:01.958 --> 00:29:03.958
People died; so be it.

00:29:03.958 --> 00:29:05.958
But if you got attacked, that was something you could do something about.

00:29:05.958 --> 00:29:07.958
And so we evolved these responses.

00:29:07.958 --> 00:29:08.958
Is that what happened?

00:29:08.958 --> 00:29:11.958
DG: Well, you know, the people who are most skeptical

00:29:11.958 --> 00:29:13.958
about leaping to evolutionary explanations for everything

00:29:13.958 --> 00:29:15.958
are the evolutionary psychologists themselves.

00:29:15.958 --> 00:29:18.958
My guess is that there's nothing quite that specific

00:29:18.958 --> 00:29:20.958
in our evolutionary past. But rather, if you're looking for

00:29:20.958 --> 00:29:22.958
an evolutionary explanation, you might say

00:29:22.958 --> 00:29:26.958
that most organisms are neo-phobic -- that is, they're a little scared

00:29:26.958 --> 00:29:27.958
of stuff that's new and different.

00:29:27.958 --> 00:29:29.958
And there's a good reason to be,

00:29:29.958 --> 00:29:30.958
because old stuff didn't eat you. Right?

00:29:30.958 --> 00:29:33.958
Any animal you see that you've seen before is less likely

00:29:33.958 --> 00:29:36.958
to be a predator than one that you've never seen before.

00:29:36.958 --> 00:29:39.958
So, you know, when a school bus is blown up and we've never seen this before,

00:29:39.958 --> 00:29:41.958
our general tendency is to orient towards

00:29:41.958 --> 00:29:46.958
that which is new and novel is activated.

00:29:46.958 --> 00:29:48.958
I don't think it's quite as specific a mechanism

00:29:48.958 --> 00:29:50.958
as the one you alluded to, but maybe a more fundamental one underlying it.

00:29:54.958 --> 00:29:59.958
Jay Walker: You know, economists love to talk about

00:29:59.958 --> 00:30:03.958
the stupidity of people who buy lottery tickets. But I suspect

00:30:03.958 --> 00:30:06.958
you're making the exact same error you're accusing those people of,

00:30:06.958 --> 00:30:07.958
which is the error of value.

00:30:07.958 --> 00:30:08.958
I know, because I've interviewed

00:30:08.958 --> 00:30:10.958
about 1,000 lottery buyers over the years.

00:30:10.958 --> 00:30:14.958
It turns out that the value of buying a lottery ticket is not winning.

00:30:14.958 --> 00:30:16.958
That's what you think it is. All right?

00:30:16.958 --> 00:30:19.958
The average lottery buyer buys about 150 tickets a year,

00:30:19.958 --> 00:30:23.958
so the buyer knows full well that he or she is going to lose,

00:30:23.958 --> 00:30:26.958
and yet she buys 150 tickets a year. Why is that?

00:30:26.958 --> 00:30:30.958
It's not because she is stupid or he is stupid.

00:30:30.958 --> 00:30:33.958
It's because the anticipation of possibly winning

00:30:33.958 --> 00:30:37.958
releases serotonin in the brain, and actually provides a good feeling

00:30:37.958 --> 00:30:39.958
until the drawing indicates you've lost.

00:30:39.958 --> 00:30:42.958
Or, to put it another way, for the dollar investment,

00:30:42.958 --> 00:30:45.958
you can have a much better feeling than flushing the money

00:30:45.958 --> 00:30:48.958
down the toilet, which you cannot have a good feeling from.

00:30:48.958 --> 00:30:50.958
Now, economists tend to --

00:30:50.958 --> 00:30:53.958
(Applause)

00:30:53.958 --> 00:30:54.958
-- economists tend to view the world

00:30:54.958 --> 00:30:56.958
through their own lenses, which is:

00:30:56.958 --> 00:30:58.958
this is just a bunch of stupid people.

00:30:58.958 --> 00:31:02.958
And as a result, many people look at economists as stupid people.

00:31:02.958 --> 00:31:05.958
And so fundamentally, the reason we got to the moon is,

00:31:05.958 --> 00:31:08.958
we didn't listen to the economists. Thank you very much.

00:31:08.958 --> 00:31:13.958
(Applause)

00:31:13.958 --> 00:31:16.958
DG: Well, no, it's a great point. It remains to be seen

00:31:16.958 --> 00:31:20.958
whether the joy of anticipation is exactly equaled

00:31:20.958 --> 00:31:23.958
by the amount of disappointment after the lottery. Because remember,

00:31:23.958 --> 00:31:26.958
people who didn't buy tickets don't feel awful the next day either,

00:31:26.958 --> 00:31:28.958
even though they don't feel great during the drawing.

00:31:28.958 --> 00:31:30.958
I would disagree that people know they're not going to win.

00:31:30.958 --> 00:31:33.958
I think they think it's unlikely, but it could happen,

00:31:33.958 --> 00:31:36.958
which is why they prefer that to the flushing.

00:31:36.958 --> 00:31:39.958
But certainly I see your point: that there can be

00:31:39.958 --> 00:31:43.958
some utility to buying a lottery ticket other than winning.

00:31:43.958 --> 00:31:46.958
Now, I think there's many good reasons not to listen to economists.

00:31:46.958 --> 00:31:49.958
That isn't one of them, for me, but there's many others.

00:31:49.958 --> 00:31:51.958
CA: Last question.

00:31:51.958 --> 00:31:54.958
Aubrey de Grey: My name's Aubrey de Grey, from Cambridge.

00:31:54.958 --> 00:31:58.958
I work on the thing that kills more people than anything else kills --

00:31:58.958 --> 00:32:00.958
I work on aging -- and I'm interested in doing something about it,

00:32:00.958 --> 00:32:01.958
as we'll all hear tomorrow.

00:32:01.958 --> 00:32:04.958
I very much resonate with what you're saying,

00:32:04.958 --> 00:32:06.958
because it seems to me that the problem

00:32:06.958 --> 00:32:09.958
with getting people interested in doing anything about aging

00:32:09.958 --> 00:32:12.958
is that by the time aging is about to kill you it looks like cancer

00:32:12.958 --> 00:32:15.958
or heart disease or whatever. Do you have any advice?

00:32:15.958 --> 00:32:18.958
(Laughter)

00:32:18.958 --> 00:32:19.958
DG: For you or for them?

00:32:19.958 --> 00:32:20.958
AdG: In persuading them.

00:32:20.958 --> 00:32:22.958
DG: Ah, for you in persuading them.

00:32:22.958 --> 00:32:25.958
Well, it's notoriously difficult to get people to be farsighted.

00:32:25.958 --> 00:32:29.958
But one thing that psychologists have tried that seems to work

00:32:29.958 --> 00:32:32.958
is to get people to imagine the future more vividly.

00:32:32.958 --> 00:32:35.958
One of the problems with making decisions about the far future

00:32:35.958 --> 00:32:38.958
and the near future is that we imagine the near future

00:32:38.958 --> 00:32:40.958
much more vividly than the far future.

00:32:40.958 --> 00:32:44.958
To the extent that you can equalize the amount of detail

00:32:44.958 --> 00:32:46.958
that people put into the mental representations

00:32:46.958 --> 00:32:48.958
of near and far future, people begin to make decisions

00:32:48.958 --> 00:32:50.958
about the two in the same way.

00:32:50.958 --> 00:32:55.958
So, would you like to have an extra 100,000 dollars when you're 65

00:32:55.958 --> 00:32:56.958
is a question that's very different than,

00:32:56.958 --> 00:33:00.958
imagine who you'll be when you're 65: will you be living,

00:33:00.958 --> 00:33:02.958
what will you look like, how much hair will you have,

00:33:02.958 --> 00:33:03.958
who will you be living with.

00:33:03.958 --> 00:33:06.958
Once we have all the details of that imaginary scenario,

00:33:06.958 --> 00:33:08.958
suddenly we feel like it might be important to save

00:33:08.958 --> 00:33:11.958
so that that guy has a little retirement money.

00:33:11.958 --> 00:33:13.958
But these are tricks around the margins.

00:33:13.958 --> 00:33:16.958
I think in general you're battling a very fundamental human tendency,

00:33:16.958 --> 00:33:18.958
which is to say, "I'm here today,

00:33:18.958 --> 00:33:21.958
and so now is more important than later."

00:33:21.958 --> 00:33:23.958
CA: Dan, thank you. Members of the audience,

00:33:23.958 --> 00:33:24.958
that was a fantastic session. Thank you.

00:33:24.958 --> 00:33:26.958
(Applause)

transcript: I'm just going to play a brief video clip.Video: On the fifth of December 1985, a bottle of 1787 Lafitte was sold for 105,000 pounds — nine times the previous world record. The buyer was Kip Forbes, son of one of the most flamboyant millionaires of the 20th century. The original owner of the bottle turned out to be one of the most enthusiastic wine buffs of the 18th century. Château Lafitte is one of the greatest wines in the world, the prince of any wine cellar.Benjamin Wallace: Now, that's about all the videotape that remains of an event that set off the longest-running mystery in the modern wine world. And the mystery existed because of a gentleman named Hardy Rodenstock. In 1985, he announced to his friends in the wine world that he had made this incredible discovery. Some workmen in Paris had broken through a brick wall, and happened upon this hidden cache of wines — apparently the property of Thomas Jefferson. 1787, 1784. He wouldn't reveal the exact number of bottles, he would not reveal exactly where the building was and he would not reveal exactly who owned the building. The mystery persisted for about 20 years.It finally began to get resolved in 2005 because of this guy. Bill Koch is a Florida billionaire who owns four of the Jefferson bottles, and he became suspicious. And he ended up spending over a million dollars and hiring ex-FBI and ex-Scotland Yard agents to try to get to the bottom of this. There's now ample evidence that Hardy Rodenstock is a con man, and that the Jefferson bottles were fakes.But for those 20 years, an unbelievable number of really eminent and accomplished figures in the wine world were sort of drawn into the orbit of these bottles. I think they wanted to believe that the most expensive bottle of wine in the world must be the best bottle of wine in the world, must be the rarest bottle of wine in the world. I became increasingly, kind of voyeuristically interested in the question of you know, why do people spend these crazy amounts of money, not only on wine but on lots of things, and are they living a better life than me?So, I decided to embark on a quest. With the generous backing of a magazine I write for sometimes, I decided to sample the very best, or most expensive, or most coveted item in about a dozen categories, which was a very grueling quest,  as you can imagine.(Laughter)This was the first one. A lot of the Kobe beef that you see in the U.S. is not the real thing. It may come from Wagyu cattle, but it's not from the original, Appalachian Hyogo Prefecture in Japan. There are very few places in the U.S. where you can try real Kobe, and one of them is Wolfgang Puck's restaurant, Cut, in Los Angeles. I went there, and I ordered the eight-ounce rib eye for 160 dollars. And it arrived, and it was tiny. And I was outraged. It was like, 160 dollars for this? And then I took a bite, and I wished that it was tinier, because Kobe beef is so rich. It's like foie gras — it's not even like steak. I almost couldn't finish it. I was really happy when I was done.(Laughter)Now, the photographer who took the pictures for this project for some reason posed his dog in a lot of them, so that's why you're going to see this recurring character. Which, I guess, you know, communicates to you that I did not think that one was really worth the price.White truffles. One of the most expensive luxury foods by weight in the world. To try this, I went to a Mario Batali restaurant in Manhattan — Del Posto. The waiter, you know, came out with the white truffle knob and his shaver, and he shaved it onto my pasta and he said, you know, "Would Signore like the truffles?" And the charm of white truffles is in their aroma. It's not in their taste, really. It's not in their texture. It's in the smell. These white pearlescent flakes hit the noodles, this haunting, wonderful, nutty, mushroomy smell wafted up. 10 seconds passed and it was gone. And then I was left with these little ugly flakes on my pasta that, you know, their purpose had been served, and so I'm afraid to say that this was also a disappointment to me. There were several — several of these items were disappointments.(Laughter)Yeah. The magazine wouldn't pay for me to go there.(Laughter)They did give me a tour, though. And this hotel suite is 4,300 square feet. It has 360-degree views. It has four balconies. It was designed by the architect I.M. Pei. It comes with its own Rolls Royce and driver. It comes with its own wine cellar that you can draw freely from. When I took the tour, it actually included some Opus One, I was glad to see. 30,000 dollars for a night in a hotel.This is soap that's made from silver nanoparticles, which have antibacterial properties. I washed my face with this this morning in preparation for this. And it, you know, tickled a little bit and it smelled good, but I have to say that nobody here has complimented me on the cleanliness of my face today.(Laughter)But then again, nobody has complimented me on the jeans I'm wearing. These ones GQ did spring for — I own these — but I will tell you, not only did I not get a compliment from any of you, I have not gotten a compliment from anybody in the months that I have owned and worn these. I don't think that whether or not you're getting a compliment should be the test of something's value, but I think in the case of a fashion item, an article of clothing, that's a reasonable benchmark. That said, a lot of work goes into these. They are made from handpicked organic Zimbabwean cotton that has been shuttle loomed and then hand-dipped in natural indigo 24 times. But no compliments.(Laughter)Thank you.Armando Manni is a former filmmaker who makes this olive oil from an olive that grows on a single slope in Tuscany. And he goes to great lengths to protect the olive oil from oxygen and light. He uses tiny bottles, the glass is tinted, he tops the olive oil off with an inert gas. And he actually — once he releases a batch of it, he regularly conducts molecular analyses and posts the results online, so you can go online and look at your batch number and see how the phenolics are developing, and, you know, gauge its freshness. I did a blind taste test of this with 20 people and five other olive oils. It tasted fine. It tasted interesting. It was very green, it was very peppery. But in the blind taste test, it came in last. The olive oil that came in first was actually a bottle of Whole Foods 365 olive oil which had been oxidizing next to my stove for six months.(Laughter)A recurring theme is that a lot of these things are from Japan — you'll start to notice.I don't play golf, so I couldn't actually road test these, but I did interview a guy who owns them. Even the people who market these clubs — I mean, they'll say these have four axis shafts which minimize loss of club speed and thereby drive the ball farther — but they'll say, look, you know, you're not getting 57,000 dollars worth of performance from these clubs. You're paying for the bling, that they're encrusted with gold and platinum. The guy who I interviewed who owns them did say that he's gotten a lot of pleasure out of them, so ...Oh, yeah, you know this one? This is a coffee made from a very unusual process. The luwak is an Asian Palm Civet. It's a cat that lives in trees, and at night it comes down and it prowls the coffee plantations. And apparently it's a very picky eater and it, you know, hones in on only the ripest coffee cherries. And then an enzyme in its digestive tract leeches into the beans, and people with the unenviable job of collecting these cats' leavings then go through the forest collecting the, you know, results and processing it into coffee — although you actually can buy it in the unprocessed form. That's right.Unrelatedly —(Laughter)Japan is doing crazy things with toilets.(Laughter)There is now a toilet that has an MP3 player in it. There's one with a fragrance dispenser. There's one that actually analyzes the contents of the bowl and transmits the results via email to your doctor. It's almost like a home medical center — and that is the direction that Japanese toilet technology is heading in. This one does not have those bells and whistles, but for pure functionality it's pretty much the best — the Neorest 600. And to try this — I couldn't get a loaner, but I did go into the Manhattan showroom of the manufacturer, Toto, and they have a bathroom off of the showroom that you can use, which I used. It's fully automated — you walk towards it, and the seat lifts. The seat is preheated. There's a water jet that cleans you. There's an air jet that dries you. You get up, it flushes by itself. The lid closes, it self-cleans. Not only is it a technological leap forward, but I really do believe it's a bit of a cultural leap forward. I mean, a no hands, no toilet paper toilet. And I want to get one of these.(Laughter)This was another one I could not get a loaner of. Tom Cruise supposedly owns this bed. There's a little plaque on the end that, you know, each buyer gets their name engraved on it.(Laughter)To try this one, the maker of it let me and my wife spend the night in the Manhattan showroom. Lights glaring in off the street, and we had to hire a security guard and all these things. But anyway, we had a great night's sleep. And you spend a third of your life in bed. I don't think it's that bad of a deal.(Laughter)This was a fun one. This is the fastest street-legal car in the world and the most expensive production car. I got to drive this with a chaperone from the company, a professional race car driver, and we drove around the canyons outside of Los Angeles and down on the Pacific Coast Highway. And, you know, when we pulled up to a stoplight the people in the adjacent cars kind of gave us respectful nods. And it was really amazing. It was such a smooth ride. Most of the cars that I drive, if I get up to 80 they start to rattle. I switched lanes on the highway and the driver, this chaperone, said, "You know, you were just going 110 miles an hour." And I had no idea that I was one of those obnoxious people you occasionally see weaving in and out of traffic, because it was just that smooth. And if I was a billionaire, I would get one.(Laughter)This is a completely gratuitous video I'm just going to show of one of the pitfalls of advanced technology. This is Tom Cruise arriving at the "Mission: Impossible III" premiere. When he tries to open the door, you could call it "Mission: Impossible IV."There was one object that I could not get my hands on, and that was the 1947 Cheval Blanc. The '47 Cheval Blanc is probably the most mythologized wine of the 20th century. And Cheval Blanc is kind of an unusual wine for Bordeaux in having a significant percentage of the Cabernet Franc grape. And 1947 was a legendary vintage, especially in the right bank of Bordeaux. And just together, that vintage and that chateau took on this aura that eventually kind of gave it this cultish following. But it's 60 years old. There's not much of it left. What there is of it left you don't know if it's real — it's considered to be the most faked wine in the world. Not that many people are looking to pop open their one remaining bottle for a journalist.So, I'd about given up trying to get my hands on one of these. I'd put out feelers to retailers, to auctioneers, and it was coming up empty. And then I got an email from a guy named Bipin Desai. Bipin Desai is a U.C. Riverside theoretical physicist who also happens to be the preeminent organizer of rare wine tastings, and he said, "I've got a tasting coming up where we're going to serve the '47 Cheval Blanc." And it was going to be a double vertical — it was going to be 30 vintages of Cheval Blanc, and 30 vintages of Yquem. And it was an invitation you do not refuse. I went.It was three days, four meals. And at lunch on Saturday, we opened the '47. And you know, it had this fragrant softness, and it smelled a little bit of linseed oil. And then I tasted it, and it, you know, had this kind of unctuous, porty richness, which is characteristic of that wine — that it sort of resembles port in a lot of ways. There were people at my table who thought it was, you know, fantastic. There were some people who were a little less impressed. And I wasn't that impressed. And I don't — call my palate a philistine palate — so it doesn't necessarily mean something that I wasn't impressed, but I was not the only one there who had that reaction. And it wasn't just to that wine. Any one of the wines served at this tasting, if I'd been served it at a dinner party, it would have been, you know, the wine experience of my lifetime, and incredibly memorable. But drinking 60 great wines over three days, they all just blurred together, and it became almost a grueling experience.And I just wanted to finish by mentioning a very interesting study which came out earlier this year from some researchers at Stanford and Caltech. And they gave subjects the same wine, labeled with different price tags. A lot of people, you know, said that they liked the more expensive wine more — it was the same wine, but they thought it was a different one that was more expensive. But what was unexpected was that these researchers did MRI brain imaging while the people were drinking the wine, and not only did they say they enjoyed the more expensively labeled wine more — their brain actually registered as experiencing more pleasure from the same wine when it was labeled with a higher price tag.Thank you.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:15.958
(Laughter)

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:19.958
But then again, nobody has complimented me on the jeans I'm wearing.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:25.958
These ones GQ did spring for -- I own these -- but I will tell you, 



00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
not only did I not get a compliment from any of you,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
I have not gotten a compliment from anybody 


00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
in the months that I have owned and worn these.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
I don't think that whether or not you're getting a compliment

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
should be the test of something's value,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
but I think in the case of a fashion item, an article of clothing,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
that's a reasonable benchmark.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
That said, a lot of work goes into these.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:46.958
They are made from handpicked organic Zimbabwean cotton

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.958
that has been shuttle loomed

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:53.958
and then hand-dipped in natural indigo 24 times.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:54.958
But no compliments.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:55.958
(Laughter)

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
Thank you.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
Armando Manni is a former filmmaker who makes this olive oil

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:05.958
from an olive that grows on a single slope in Tuscany.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:10.958
And he goes to great lengths to protect the olive oil from oxygen and light.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
He uses tiny bottles, the glass is tinted,

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
he tops the olive oil off with an inert gas.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
And he actually -- once he releases a batch of it,

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:25.958
he regularly conducts molecular analyses and posts the results online,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
so you can go online and look at your batch number

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
and see how the phenolics are developing,


00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
and, you know, gauge its freshness.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:35.958
I did a blind taste test of this with 20 people and five other olive oils.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
It tasted fine. It tasted interesting.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
It was very green, it was very peppery.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
But in the blind taste test, it came in last.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
The olive oil that came in first was actually a bottle of

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:52.958
Whole Foods 365 olive oil which had been oxidizing next to my stove

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:53.958
for six months.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:59.958
(Laughter)

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
A recurring theme is that a lot of these things are from Japan --

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:06.958
you'll start to notice.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
I don't play golf, so I couldn't actually road test these,

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
but I did interview a guy who owns them.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
Even the people who market these clubs -- I mean, they'll say

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:18.958
these have four axis shafts which minimize loss of club speed

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:22.958
and thereby drive the ball farther -- but they'll say, look, you know,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
you're not getting 57,000 dollars worth of performance from these clubs.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
You're paying for the bling,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
that they're encrusted with gold and platinum.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
The guy who I interviewed who owns them did say

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
that he's gotten a lot of pleasure out of them, so ...

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
Oh, yeah, you know this one?

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
This is a coffee made from a very unusual process.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
The luwak is an Asian Palm Civet.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
It's a cat that lives in trees,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:51.958
and at night it comes down and it prowls the coffee plantations. 



00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
And apparently it's a very picky eater and it, you know,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
hones in on only the ripest coffee cherries.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:01.958
And then an enzyme in its digestive tract leeches into the beans,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:06.958
and people with the unenviable job of collecting these cats' leavings

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:11.958
then go through the forest collecting the, you know, results

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:15.958
and processing it into coffee -- although you actually can buy it

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
in the unprocessed form.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
That's right. 


00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
Unrelatedly --

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
(Laughter)


00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
Japan is doing crazy things with toilets.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:33.958
(Laughter)

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
There is now a toilet that has an MP3 player in it.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
There's one with a fragrance dispenser.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
There's one that actually analyzes the contents of the bowl

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:48.958
and transmits the results via email to your doctor.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
It's almost like a home medical center -- 


00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
and that is the direction that Japanese toilet technology is heading in.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
This one does not have those bells and whistles,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:00.958
but for pure functionality it's pretty much the best -- the Neorest 600.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
And to try this -- I couldn't get a loaner,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:08.958
but I did go into the Manhattan showroom of the manufacturer, Toto,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
and they have a bathroom off of the showroom that you can use, which I used.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
It's fully automated -- you walk towards it, and the seat lifts.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
The seat is preheated. 


00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
There's a water jet that cleans you.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
There's an air jet that dries you.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
You get up, it flushes by itself.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
The lid closes, it self-cleans.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
Not only is it a technological leap forward,

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
but I really do believe it's a bit of a cultural leap forward.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
I mean, a no hands, no toilet paper toilet.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
And I want to get one of these.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:38.958
(Laughter)

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
This was another one I could not get a loaner of.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
Tom Cruise supposedly owns this bed.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
There's a little plaque on the end that, you know,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
each buyer gets their name engraved on it.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:56.958
(Laughter)

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
To try this one, the maker of it let me and my wife

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
spend the night in the Manhattan showroom. 


00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
Lights glaring in off the street, 


00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
and we had to hire a security guard and all these things.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
But anyway, we had a great night's sleep.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
And you spend a third of your life in bed.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
I don't think it's that bad of a deal.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:13.958
(Laughter)

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
This was a fun one.


00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958
This is the fastest street-legal car in the world

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
and the most expensive production car. 



00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
I got to drive this with a chaperone from the company,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
a professional race car driver,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
and we drove around the canyons outside of Los Angeles

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
and down on the Pacific Coast Highway.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
And, you know, when we pulled up to a stoplight

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:37.958
the people in the adjacent cars kind of gave us respectful nods.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
And it was really amazing.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
It was such a smooth ride.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
Most of the cars that I drive, if I get up to 80 they start to rattle.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
I switched lanes on the highway and the driver, this chaperone, said,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
"You know, you were just going 110 miles an hour."

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
And I had no idea that I was one of those obnoxious people

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
you occasionally see weaving in and out of traffic,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
because it was just that smooth.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
And if I was a billionaire, I would get one.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
(Laughter)

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
This is a completely gratuitous video I'm just going to show

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
of one of the pitfalls of advanced technology.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:11.958
This is Tom Cruise arriving at the "Mission: Impossible III" premiere.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
When he tries to open the door, 



00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
you could call it "Mission: Impossible IV."

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
There was one object that I could not get my hands on,

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
and that was the 1947 Cheval Blanc. 



00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:35.958
The '47 Cheval Blanc is probably the most mythologized wine of the 20th century.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
And Cheval Blanc is kind of an unusual wine for Bordeaux

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:42.958
in having a significant percentage of the Cabernet Franc grape.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
And 1947 was a legendary vintage,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
especially in the right bank of Bordeaux.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:51.958
And just together, that vintage and that chateau took on this aura

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:55.958
that eventually kind of gave it this cultish following.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
But it's 60 years old.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
There's not much of it left.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
What there is of it left you don't know if it's real --

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
it's considered to be the most faked wine in the world.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
Not that many people are looking to pop open

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
their one remaining bottle for a journalist.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
So, I'd about given up trying to get my hands on one of these.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
I'd put out feelers to retailers, to auctioneers,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
and it was coming up empty.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
And then I got an email from a guy named Bipin Desai.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:23.958
Bipin Desai is a U.C. Riverside theoretical physicist

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.958
who also happens to be the preeminent organizer of rare wine tastings,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
and he said, "I've got a tasting coming up

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
where we're going to serve the '47 Cheval Blanc."

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
And it was going to be a double vertical --

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
it was going to be 30 vintages of Cheval Blanc,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
and 30 vintages of Yquem.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
And it was an invitation you do not refuse.


00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
I went.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
It was three days, four meals. 


00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
And at lunch on Saturday, we opened the '47.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:52.958
And you know, it had this fragrant softness,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
and it smelled a little bit of linseed oil.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
And then I tasted it, and it,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:01.958
you know, had this kind of unctuous, porty richness,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
which is characteristic of that wine --

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
that it sort of resembles port in a lot of ways.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
There were people at my table who thought it was, you know, fantastic.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
There were some people who were a little less impressed.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
And I wasn't that impressed.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:18.958
And I don't -- call my palate a philistine palate --

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
so it doesn't necessarily mean something that I wasn't impressed,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
but I was not the only one there who had that reaction.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
And it wasn't just to that wine.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
Any one of the wines served at this tasting,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
if I'd been served it at a dinner party, it would have been, you know,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
the wine experience of my lifetime, and incredibly memorable.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
But drinking 60 great wines over three days,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
they all just blurred together,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:44.958
and it became almost a grueling experience.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:48.958
And I just wanted to finish by mentioning a very interesting study

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:52.958
which came out earlier this year from some researchers at Stanford and Caltech.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:56.958
And they gave subjects the same wine,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
labeled with different price tags.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
A lot of people, you know,

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
said that they liked the more expensive wine more --

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
it was the same wine, but they thought it was a different one

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
that was more expensive.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
But what was unexpected was that these researchers did

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
MRI brain imaging while the people were drinking the wine,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:16.958
and not only did they say they enjoyed the more expensively labeled wine more --

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:20.958
their brain actually registered as experiencing more pleasure

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
from the same wine when it was labeled with a higher price tag.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:24.958
Thank you.

title: There might just be life on Mars
transcript: The career that I started early on in my life was looking for exotic life forms in exotic places, and at that time I was working in the Antarctic and the Arctic, and high deserts and low deserts. Until about a dozen years ago, when I was really captured by caves, and I really re-focused most of my research in that direction.So I have a really cool day job— I get to do some really amazing stuff. I work in some of the most extreme cave environments on the planet. Many of them are trying to kill us from the minute we go into them, but nevertheless, they're absolutely gripping, and contain unbelievable biological wonders that are very, very different from those that we have on the planet. Apart from the intrinsic value of the biology and mineralogy and geo-microbiology that we do there, we're also using these as templates for figuring out how to go look for life on other planets. Particularly Mars, but also Europa, the small, icy moon around Jupiter. And perhaps, someday, far beyond our solar system itself.I'm very passionately interested in the human future, on the Moon and Mars particularly, and elsewhere in the solar system. I think it's time that we transitioned to a solar system-going civilization and species. And, as an outgrowth of all of this then, I wonder about whether we can, and whether we even should, think about transporting Earth-type life to other planets. Notably Mars, as a first example.Something I never talk about in scientific meetings is how I actually got to this state and why I do the work that I do. Why don't I have a normal job, a sensible job? And then of course, I blame the Soviet Union. Because in the mid-1950s, when I was a tiny child, they had the audacity to launch a very primitive little satellite called Sputnik, which sent the Western world into a hysterical tailspin. And a tremendous amount of money went into the funding of science and mathematics skills for kids. And I'm a product of that generation, like so many other of my peers. It really caught hold of us, and caught fire, and it would be lovely if we could reproduce that again now.Of course, refusing to grow up — — even though I impersonate a grown-up in daily life, but I do a fairly good job of that — but really retaining that childlike quality of not caring what other people think about what you're interested in, is really critical. The next element is the fact that I have applied a value judgment and my value judgment is that the presence of life is better than no life. And so, life is more valuable than no life. And so I think that that holds together a great deal of the work that people in this audience approach.I'm very interested in Mars, of course, and that was a product of my being a young undergraduate when the Viking Landers landed on Mars. And that took what had been a tiny little astronomical object in the sky, that you would see as a dot, and turned it completely into a landscape, as that very first primitive picture came rastering across the screen. And when it became a landscape, it also became a destination, and altered, really, the course of my life.In my graduate years I worked with my colleague and mentor and friend, Steve Schneider, at the National Center for Atmospheric Research, working on global change issues. We've written a number of things on the role of Gaia hypothesis — whether or not you could consider Earth as a single entity in any meaningful scientific sense, and then, as an outgrowth of that, I worked on the environmental consequences of nuclear war.So, wonderful things and grim things. But what it taught me was to look at Earth as a planet with external eyes, not just as our home. And that is a wonderful stepping away in perspective, to try to then think about the way our planet behaves, as a planet, and with the life that's on it. And all of this seems to me to be a salient point in history. We're getting ready to begin to go through the process of leaving our planet of origin and out into the wider solar system and beyond.So, back to Mars. How hard is it going to be to find life on Mars? Well, sometimes it's really very hard for us to find each other, even on this planet. So, finding life on another planet is a non-trivial occupation and we spend a lot of time trying to think about that. Whether or not you think it's likely to be successful sort of depends on what you think about the chances of life in the universe. I think, myself, that life is a natural outgrowth of the increasing complexification of matter over time.So, you start with the Big Bang and you get hydrogen, and then you get helium, and then you get more complicated stuff, and you get planets forming — and life is a common, planetary-based phenomenon, in my view. Certainly, in the last 15 years, we've seen increasing numbers of planets outside of our solar system being confirmed, and just last month, a couple of weeks ago, a planet in the size-class of Earth has actually been found. And so this is very exciting news.So, my first bold prediction is that, is that in the universe, life is going to be everywhere. It's going to be everywhere we look — where there are planetary systems that can possibly support it. And those planetary systems are going to be very common. So, what about life on Mars? Well, if somebody had asked me about a dozen years ago what I thought the chances of life on Mars would be, I would've probably said, a couple of percent. And even that was considered outrageous at the time. I was once sneeringly introduced by a former NASA official, as the only person on the planet who still thought there was life on Mars. Of course, that official is now dead, and I'm not, so there's a certain amount of glory in outliving your adversaries.But things have changed greatly over the last dozen years. And the reason that they have changed is because we now have new information. The amazing Pathfinder mission that went in '97, and the MER Rover missions that are on Mars as we speak now and the European Space Agency's Mars Express, has taught us a number of amazing things. There is sub-surface ice on that planet. And so where there is water, there is a very high chance of our kind of life. There's clearly sedimentary rocks all over the place – one of the landers is sitting in the middle of an ancient seabed, and there are these amazing structures called blueberries, which are these little, rocky concretions that we are busy making biologically in my lab right now.So, with all of these things put together, I think that the chances of life are much greater than I would've ever thought. I think that the chance of life having arisen on Mars, sometime in its past, is maybe one in four to maybe even half and half. So this is a very bold statement. I think it's there, and I think we need to go look for it, and I think it's underground. So the game's afoot, and this is the game that we play in astro-biology. How do you try to get a handle on extraterrestrial life? How do you plan to look for it? How do you know it when you find it? Because if it's big and obvious, we would've already found it — it would've already bitten us on the foot, and it hasn't.So, we know that it's probably quite cryptic. Very critically, how do we protect it, if we find it, and not contaminate it? And also, even perhaps more critically, because this is the only home planet we have, how do we protect us from it, while we study it? So why might it be hard to find? Well, it's probably microscopic, and it's never easy to study microscopic things, although the amazing tools that we now have to do that allow us to study things in much greater depth, at much smaller scales than ever before. But it's probably hiding, because if you are out sequestering resources from your environment, that makes you yummy, and other things might want to eat you, or consume you. And so, there's a game of predator-prey that's going to be, essentially, universal, really, in any kind of biological system. It also may be very, very different in its fundamental properties – its chemistry, or its size.We say small, but what does that mean? Is it virus-sized? Is it smaller than that? Is it bigger than the biggest bacterium? We don't know. And speed of activity, which is something that we face in our work with sub-surface organisms, because they grow very, very slowly. If I were to take a swab off your teeth and plate it on a Petri plate, within about four or five hours, I would have to see growth. But the organisms that we work with, from the sub-surface of Earth, very often it's months — and in many cases, years — before we see any growth whatsoever. So they are, intrinsically, a slower life-form.But the real issue is that we are guided by our limited experience, and until we can think out of the box of our cranium and what we know, then we can't recognize what to look for, or how to plan for it. So, perspective is everything and, because of the history that I've just briefly talked to you about, I have learned to think about Earth as an extraterrestrial planet. And this has been invaluable in our approach to try to study these things.This is my favorite game on airplanes: where you're in an airplane and you look out the window, you see the horizon. I always turn my head on the side, and that simple change makes me go from seeing this planet as home, to seeing it as a planet. It's a very simple trick, and I never fail to do it when I'm sitting in a window seat. Well, this is what we apply to our work. This shows one of the most extreme caves that we work in. This is Cueva de Villa Luz in Tabasco, in Mexico, and this cave is saturated with sulfuric acid. There is tremendous amounts of hydrogen sulfide coming into this cave from volcanic sources and from the breakdown of evaporite — minerals below the carbonates in which this cave is formed — and it is a completely hostile environment for us. We have to go in with protective suits and breathing gear, and 30 parts per million of H2S will kill you. This is regularly several hundred parts per million. So, it's a very hazardous environment, with CO as well, and many other gases. These extreme physical and chemical parameters make the biology that grows in these places very special. Because contrary to what you might think, this is not devoid of life.This is one of the richest caves that we have found on the planet, anywhere. It's bursting with life. The extremes on Earth are interesting in their own right, but one of the reasons that we're interested in them is because they represent, really, the average conditions that we may expect on other planets. So, this is part of the ability that we have, to try to stretch our imagination, in terms of what we may find in the future. There's so much life in this cave, and I can't even begin to scratch the surface of it with you.But one of the most famous objects out of this are what we call Snottites, for obvious reasons. This stuff looks like what comes out of your two-year-old's nose when he has a cold. And this is produced by bacteria who are actually making more sulfuric acid, and living at pHs right around zero. And so, this stuff is like battery acid. And yet, everything in this cave has adapted to it. In fact, there's so much energy available for biology in this cave, that there's actually a huge number of cavefish. And the local Zoque Indians harvest this twice a year, as part of their Easter week celebration and Holy Week celebration.This is very unusual for caves. In some of the other amazing caves that we work in — this is in Lechuguilla cave in New Mexico near Carlsbad, and this is one of the most famous caves in the world. It's 115 miles of mapped passage, it's pristine, it has no natural opening and it's a gigantic biological, geo-microbiological laboratory. In this cave, great areas are covered by this reddish material that you see here, and also these enormous crystals of selenite that you can see dangling down. This stuff is produced biologically. This is the breakdown product of the bedrock, that organisms are busy munching their way through. They take iron and manganese minerals within the bedrock and they oxidize them. And every time they do that, they get a tiny little packet of energy. And that tiny little packet of energy is what they use, then, to run their life processes. Interestingly enough, they also do this with uranium and chromium, and various other toxic metals.And so, the obvious avenue for bio-remediation comes from organisms like this. These organisms we now bring into the lab, and you can see some of them growing on Petri plates, and get them to reproduce the precise biominerals that we find on the walls of these caves. So, these are signals that they leave in the rock record. Well, even in basalt surfaces in lava-tube caves, which are a by-product of volcanic activity, we find these walls totally covered, in many cases, by these beautiful, glistening silver walls, or shiny pink or shiny red or shiny gold. And these are mineral deposits that are also made by bacteria. And you can see in these central images here, scanning electron micrographs of some of these guys — these are gardens of these bacteria.One of the interesting things about these particular guys is that they're in the actinomycete and streptomycete groups of the bacteria, which is where we get most of our antibiotics. The sub-surface of Earth contains a vast biodiversity. And these organisms, because they're very separate from the surface, make a vast array of novel compounds. And so, the potential for exploiting this for pharmaceutical and industrial chemical uses is completely untapped, but probably exceeds most of the rest of the biodiversity of the planet.So, lava-tube caves— I've just told you about organisms that live here on this planet. We know that on Mars and the Moon there are tons of these structures. We can see them. On the left you can see a lava tube forming at a recent eruption — Mount Etna in Sicily — and this is the way these tubes form. And when they hollow out, then they become habitats for organisms. These are all over the planet Mars, and we're busy cataloguing them now. And so, there's very interesting cave real estate on Mars, at least of that type.In order to access these sub-surface environments that we're interested in, we're very interested in developing the tools to do this. You know, it's not easy to get into these caves. It requires crawling, climbing, rope-work, technical rope-work and many other complex human motions in order to access these. We face the problem of, how can we do this robotically? Why would we want to do it robotically? Well, we're going to be sending robotic missions to Mars long in advance of human missions.And then, secondly, getting back to that earlier point that I made about the preciousness of any life that we may find on Mars, we don't want to contaminate it. And one of the best ways to study something without contaminating it is to have an intermediary. And in this case, we're imagining intermediary robotic devices that can actually do some of that front-end work for us, to protect any potential life that we find. I'm not going to go through all of these projects now, but we're involved in about half-a-dozen robotic development projects, in collaboration with a number of different groups. I want to talk specifically about the array that you see on the top.These are hopping microbot swarms. I'm working on this with the Field and Space Robotics Laboratory and my friend Steve Dubowsky at MIT, and we have come up with the idea of having little, jumping bean-like robots that are propelled by artificial muscle, which is one of the Dubowsky Lab's specialties — are the EPAMs, or artificial muscles. And these allow them to hop. They behave with a swarm behavior, where they relate to each other, modeled after insect swarm behavior, and they could be made very numerous. And so, one can send a thousand of them, as you can see in this upper left-hand picture, a thousand of them could fit into the payload bay that was used for one of the current MER Rovers. And these little guys — you could lose many of them. If you send a thousand of them, you could probably get rid of 90 percent of them and still have a mission. And so, that allows you the flexibility to go into very challenging terrain and actually make your way where you want to go.Now, to wrap this up, I want to talk for two seconds about caves and the human expansion beyond Earth as a natural outgrowth of the work that we do in caves. It occurred to us a number of years ago that caves have many properties that people have used and other organisms have used as habitat in the past. And perhaps it's time we started to explore those, in the context of future Mars and the Moon exploration.So, we have just finished a NASA Institute for Advanced Concepts Phase II study, looking at the irreducible set of technologies that you would need in order to actually allow people to inhabit lava tubes on the Moon or Mars. It turns out to be a fairly simple and small list, and we have gone in the relatively primitive technology direction. So, we're talking about things like inflatable liners that can conform to the complex topological shape on the inside of a cave, foamed-in-place airlocks to deal with this complex topology, various ways of getting breathing gases made from the intrinsic materials of these bodies. And the future is there for us to use these lava-tube caves on Mars. And right now we're in caves, and we're doing science and recreation, but I think in the future we'll be using them for habitat and science on these other bodies.Now, my view of what the current status of potential life on Mars is that it's probably been on the planet, maybe one in two chances. The question as to whether there is life on Mars that is related to life on Earth has now been very muddied, because we now know, from Mars meteorites that have made it to Earth, that there's material that can be exchanged between those two planets.One of the burning questions, of course, is if we go there and find life in the sub-surface, as I fully expect that we will, is that a second genesis of life? Did life start here and was it transported there? Did it start there and get transported here? This will be a fascinating puzzle as we go into the next half-century, and where I expect that we will have more and more Mars missions to answer these questions. Thank you.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
The career that I started early on in my life

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:18.958
was looking for exotic life forms in exotic places,

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:21.958
and at that time I was working in the Antarctic and the Arctic,

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:23.958
and high deserts and low deserts.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:26.958
Until about a dozen years ago, when I was really captured by caves,

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
and I really re-focused most of my research in that direction.

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:33.958
So I have a really cool day job-- I get to do some really amazing stuff.

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:36.958
I work in some of the most extreme cave environments on the planet.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
Many of them are trying to kill us from the minute we go into them,

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:42.958
but nevertheless, they're absolutely gripping,

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:44.958
and contain unbelievable biological wonders

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
that are very, very different from those that we have on the planet.

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
Apart from the intrinsic value

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
of the biology and mineralogy and geo-microbiology that we do there,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:54.958
we're also using these as templates

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
for figuring out how to go look

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.958
for life on other planets.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
Particularly Mars, but also Europa,

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:03.958
the small, icy moon around Jupiter.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:06.958
And perhaps, someday, far beyond our solar system itself.

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:09.958
I'm very passionately interested in the human future,

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
on the Moon and Mars particularly,

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:13.958
and elsewhere in the solar system.

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:15.958
I think it's time that we transitioned

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
to a solar system-going civilization and species.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:21.958
And, as an outgrowth of all of this then,

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:24.958
I wonder about whether we can, and whether we even should,

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:28.958
think about transporting Earth-type life to other planets.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
Notably Mars, as a first example.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
Something I never talk about in scientific meetings

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
is how I actually got to this state

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
and why I do the work that I do.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
Why don't I have a normal job, a sensible job?

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.958
And then of course, I blame the Soviet Union.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
Because in the mid-1950s,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
when I was a tiny child,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:48.958
they had the audacity to launch

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:51.958
a very primitive little satellite called Sputnik,

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
which sent the Western world into a hysterical tailspin.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:57.958
And a tremendous amount of money

00:01:57.958 --> 00:01:59.958
went into the funding of science

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
and mathematics skills for kids.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:03.958
And I'm a product of that generation,

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.958
like so many other of my peers.

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
It really caught hold of us, and caught fire,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:10.958
and it would be lovely if we could reproduce that again now.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.958
Of course, refusing to grow up --

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
-- even though I impersonate a grown-up in daily life,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
but I do a fairly good job of that --

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
but really retaining that childlike quality

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:21.958
of not caring what other people think

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
about what you're interested in, is really critical.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
The next element is the fact that

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
I have applied a value judgment

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
and my value judgment is that the presence of life

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
is better than no life.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
And so, life is more valuable than no life.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
And so I think that that holds together

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
a great deal of the work

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:43.958
that people in this audience approach.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:46.958
I'm very interested in Mars, of course,

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:50.958
and that was a product of my being a young undergraduate

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
when the Viking Landers landed on Mars.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
And that took what had been

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
a tiny little astronomical object in the sky,

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
that you would see as a dot,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:04.958
and turned it completely into a landscape,

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
as that very first primitive picture

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
came rastering across the screen.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
And when it became a landscape,

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
it also became a destination,

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
and altered, really, the course of my life.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
In my graduate years I worked with

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
my colleague and mentor and friend, Steve Schneider,

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
at the National Center for Atmospheric Research,

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
working on global change issues.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
We've written a number of things on

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:28.958
the role of Gaia hypothesis --

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
whether or not you could consider Earth as a single entity

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
in any meaningful scientific sense,

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
and then, as an outgrowth of that,

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:39.958
I worked on the environmental consequences of nuclear war.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
So, wonderful things and grim things.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958
But what it taught me was to look at Earth as a planet

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
with external eyes, not just as our home.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:51.958
And that is a wonderful stepping away in perspective,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
to try to then think about the way

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.958
our planet behaves, as a planet,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
and with the life that's on it.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:01.958
And all of this seems to me to be

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
a salient point in history.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
We're getting ready to begin to go

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
through the process of leaving our planet of origin

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
and out into the wider solar system and beyond.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
So, back to Mars.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
How hard is it going to be to find life on Mars?

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
Well, sometimes it's really very hard for us to find each other,

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
even on this planet.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
So, finding life on another planet

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
is a non-trivial occupation

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
and we spend a lot of time trying to think about that.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
Whether or not you think it's likely to be successful

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
sort of depends on what you think about

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
the chances of life in the universe.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
I think, myself,

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:38.958
that life is a natural outgrowth

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
of the increasing complexification of matter over time.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
So, you start with the Big Bang and you get hydrogen,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
and then you get helium, and then you get more complicated stuff,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
and you get planets forming --

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:51.958
and life is a common, planetary-based phenomenon, in my view.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
Certainly, in the last 15 years,

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
we've seen increasing numbers of planets

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
outside of our solar system being confirmed,

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
and just last month, a couple of weeks ago,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
a planet in the size-class of Earth

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
has actually been found.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
And so this is very exciting news.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
So, my first bold prediction is that,

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
is that in the universe, life is going to be everywhere.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
It's going to be everywhere we look --

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
where there are planetary systems that can possibly support it.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
And those planetary systems are going to be very common.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
So, what about life on Mars?

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
Well, if somebody had asked me about a dozen years ago

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
what I thought the chances of life on Mars would be,

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
I would've probably said, a couple of percent.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
And even that was considered outrageous at the time.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
I was once sneeringly introduced

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
by a former NASA official,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
as the only person on the planet

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
who still thought there was life on Mars.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
Of course, that official is now dead, and I'm not,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
so there's a certain amount of glory

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
in outliving your adversaries.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
But things have changed greatly

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
over the last dozen years.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
And the reason that they have changed

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
is because we now have new information.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:01.958
The amazing Pathfinder mission that went in '97,

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
and the MER Rover missions

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
that are on Mars as we speak now

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
and the European Space Agency's Mars Express,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
has taught us a number of amazing things.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
There is sub-surface ice on that planet.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
And so where there is water,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
there is a very high chance of our kind of life.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
There's clearly sedimentary rocks all over the place –

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
one of the landers is sitting in the middle of an ancient seabed,

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:26.958
and there are these amazing structures called blueberries,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
which are these little, rocky concretions

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
that we are busy making biologically

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
in my lab right now.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
So, with all of these things put together,

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
I think that the chances of life

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
are much greater than I would've ever thought.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:42.958
I think that the chance of life having arisen on Mars, sometime in its past,

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
is maybe one in four to maybe even half and half.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
So this is a very bold statement.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
I think it's there, and I think we need

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
to go look for it, and I think it's underground.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:55.958
So the game's afoot, and this is the game that we play in astro-biology.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
How do you try to get a handle on extraterrestrial life?

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
How do you plan to look for it?

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
How do you know it when you find it?

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
Because if it's big and obvious, we would've already found it --

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
it would've already bitten us on the foot, and it hasn't.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
So, we know that it's probably quite cryptic.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
Very critically, how do we protect it,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
if we find it, and not contaminate it?

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
And also, even perhaps more critically, because

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
this is the only home planet we have,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
how do we protect us from it, while we study it?

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
So why might it be hard to find?

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
Well, it's probably microscopic, and it's never easy

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
to study microscopic things,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
although the amazing tools that we now have to do that

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
allow us to study things in much greater depth,

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
at much smaller scales than ever before.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
But it's probably hiding, because if you are out

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
sequestering resources from your environment, that makes you yummy,

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
and other things might want to eat you, or consume you.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
And so, there's a game of predator-prey

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:53.958
that's going to be, essentially, universal, really,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
in any kind of biological system.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
It also may be very, very different in its fundamental properties –

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
its chemistry, or its size.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
We say small, but what does that mean?

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
Is it virus-sized? Is it smaller than that?

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
Is it bigger than the biggest bacterium? We don't know.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
And speed of activity, which is something that we face

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
in our work with sub-surface organisms,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
because they grow very, very slowly.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
If I were to take a swab off your teeth

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
and plate it on a Petri plate,

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
within about four or five hours, I would have to see growth.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
But the organisms that we work with,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:24.958
from the sub-surface of Earth,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
very often it's months -- and in many cases, years --

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
before we see any growth whatsoever.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
So they are, intrinsically, a slower life-form.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
But the real issue is that we are guided by

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
our limited experience,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:41.958
and until we can think out of the box of our cranium and what we know,

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
then we can't recognize what to look for,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
or how to plan for it.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
So, perspective is everything

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
and, because of the history that I've just briefly talked to you about,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
I have learned to think about Earth

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
as an extraterrestrial planet.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:59.958
And this has been invaluable in our approach to try to study these things.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
This is my favorite game on airplanes:

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
where you're in an airplane and you look out the window,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:04.958
you see the horizon.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
I always turn my head on the side,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
and that simple change makes me go from

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
seeing this planet as home,

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
to seeing it as a planet.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
It's a very simple trick, and I never fail to do it

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
when I'm sitting in a window seat.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
Well, this is what we apply to our work.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
This shows one of the most extreme caves that we work in.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:26.958
This is Cueva de Villa Luz in Tabasco, in Mexico,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
and this cave is saturated with sulfuric acid.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
There is tremendous amounts of hydrogen sulfide

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
coming into this cave from volcanic sources

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
and from the breakdown of evaporite --

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:40.958
minerals below the carbonates in which this cave is formed --

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
and it is a completely hostile environment for us.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:46.958
We have to go in with protective suits and breathing gear,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:51.958
and 30 parts per million of H2S will kill you.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
This is regularly several hundred parts per million.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
So, it's a very hazardous environment,

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
with CO as well, and many other gases.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
These extreme physical and chemical parameters

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:04.958
make the biology that grows in these places very special.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
Because contrary to what you might think, this is not devoid of life.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
This is one of the richest caves

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
that we have found on the planet, anywhere.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
It's bursting with life.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
The extremes on Earth are interesting in their own right,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
but one of the reasons that we're interested in them

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
is because they represent, really,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
the average conditions that we may expect on other planets.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
So, this is part of the ability that we have,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
to try to stretch our imagination,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
in terms of what we may find in the future.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
There's so much life in this cave,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
and I can't even begin

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
to scratch the surface of it with you.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
But one of the most famous objects out of this

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
are what we call Snottites, for obvious reasons.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:44.958
This stuff looks like what comes out of your two-year-old's nose when he has a cold.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
And this is produced by bacteria who are actually

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
making more sulfuric acid,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and living at pHs right around zero.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
And so, this stuff is like battery acid.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
And yet, everything in this cave has adapted to it.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
In fact, there's so much energy available

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
for biology in this cave,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
that there's actually a huge number of cavefish.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
And the local Zoque Indians

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
harvest this twice a year,

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
as part of their Easter week celebration and Holy Week celebration.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
This is very unusual for caves.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
In some of the other amazing caves that we work in --

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.958
this is in Lechuguilla cave in New Mexico near Carlsbad,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
and this is one of the most famous caves in the world.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
It's 115 miles of mapped passage,

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
it's pristine, it has no natural opening

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
and it's a gigantic biological,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
geo-microbiological laboratory.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
In this cave, great areas are covered by

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
this reddish material that you see here,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
and also these enormous crystals

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
of selenite that you can see dangling down.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
This stuff is produced biologically.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
This is the breakdown product of the bedrock,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
that organisms are busy munching their way through.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
They take iron and manganese minerals

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
within the bedrock and they oxidize them.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:58.958
And every time they do that, they get a tiny little packet of energy.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
And that tiny little packet of energy is what they use, then,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
to run their life processes.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
Interestingly enough, they also do this

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
with uranium and chromium, and various other toxic metals.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
And so, the obvious avenue

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
for bio-remediation

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
comes from organisms like this.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
These organisms we now bring into the lab,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
and you can see some of them growing on Petri plates,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
and get them to reproduce the precise biominerals

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
that we find on the walls of these caves.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
So, these are signals that they leave in the rock record.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
Well, even in basalt surfaces in lava-tube caves,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
which are a by-product of volcanic activity,

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
we find these walls totally covered,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
in many cases,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
by these beautiful, glistening silver walls,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
or shiny pink or shiny red or shiny gold.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
And these are mineral deposits

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
that are also made by bacteria.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
And you can see in these central images here,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
scanning electron micrographs of some of these guys --

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
these are gardens of these bacteria.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
One of the interesting things about these particular guys

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
is that they're in the actinomycete

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
and streptomycete groups of the bacteria,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
which is where we get most of our antibiotics.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
The sub-surface of Earth

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
contains a vast biodiversity.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
And these organisms,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
because they're very separate from the surface,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:14.958
make a vast array of novel compounds.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
And so, the potential for exploiting this

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
for pharmaceutical and industrial chemical uses

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
is completely untapped,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
but probably exceeds most of the rest

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
of the biodiversity of the planet.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
So, lava-tube caves--

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
I've just told you about organisms that live here on this planet.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
We know that on Mars and the Moon

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
there are tons of these structures.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:35.958
We can see them.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
On the left you can see a lava tube forming

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
at a recent eruption -- Mount Etna in Sicily --

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
and this is the way these tubes form.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:43.958
And when they hollow out,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
then they become habitats for organisms.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
These are all over the planet Mars,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
