and we're busy cataloguing them now.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
And so, there's very interesting cave real estate

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
on Mars, at least of that type.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
In order to access

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
these sub-surface environments that we're interested in,

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
we're very interested in developing the tools to do this.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
You know, it's not easy to get into these caves.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
It requires crawling, climbing,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
rope-work, technical rope-work

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
and many other complex human motions

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
in order to access these.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
We face the problem of, how can we do this robotically?

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
Why would we want to do it robotically?

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
Well, we're going to be sending

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
robotic missions to Mars

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
long in advance of human missions.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
And then, secondly, getting back to that earlier point that I made

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:34.958
about the preciousness of any life that we may find

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
on Mars, we don't want to contaminate it.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
And one of the best ways to study something without contaminating it

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
is to have an intermediary.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
And in this case, we're imagining

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
intermediary robotic devices

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
that can actually do some of that

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
front-end work for us,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
to protect any potential life that we find.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
I'm not going to go through all of these projects now,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
but we're involved in about half-a-dozen robotic development projects,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
in collaboration with a number of different groups.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
I want to talk specifically about the

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
array that you see on the top.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
These are hopping microbot swarms.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
I'm working on this with the Field and Space Robotics Laboratory

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
and my friend Steve Dubowsky at MIT,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
and we have come up with the idea

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
of having little, jumping bean-like

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
robots

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
that are propelled by artificial muscle,

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
which is one of the Dubowsky Lab's specialties --

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
are the EPAMs, or artificial muscles.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
And these allow them to hop.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
They behave with

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
a swarm behavior,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
where they relate to each other,

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
modeled after insect swarm behavior,

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
and they could be made very numerous.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
And so, one can send a thousand of them,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
as you can see in this upper left-hand picture,

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
a thousand of them could fit into the payload bay

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
that was used for one of the current MER Rovers.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
And these little guys -- you could lose many of them.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
If you send a thousand of them,

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
you could probably get rid of 90 percent of them and still have a mission.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
And so, that allows you the flexibility

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
to go into very challenging terrain

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
and actually make your way where you want to go.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
Now, to wrap this up, I want to talk for two seconds

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
about caves and the human expansion beyond Earth

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
as a natural outgrowth of the work that we do in caves.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
It occurred to us a number of years ago

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
that caves have many properties

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
that people have used

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
and other organisms have used as habitat in the past.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
And perhaps it's time we started to explore those,

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
in the context of future Mars and the Moon exploration.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:35.958
So, we have just finished a NASA Institute for Advanced Concepts Phase II study,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
looking at the irreducible set of technologies

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
that you would need in order to

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
actually allow people to inhabit lava tubes

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
on the Moon or Mars.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
It turns out to be a fairly simple and small list,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
and we have gone

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
in the relatively primitive technology direction.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
So, we're talking about things like inflatable liners

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
that can conform to the complex topological shape

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
on the inside of a cave,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:03.958
foamed-in-place airlocks to deal with this complex topology,

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
various ways of getting breathing gases

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:09.958
made from the intrinsic materials of these bodies.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
And the future is there for us

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
to use these lava-tube caves on Mars.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:18.958
And right now we're in caves, and we're doing science and recreation,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
but I think in the future we'll be using them

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
for habitat and science on these other bodies.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:25.958
Now, my view of what the current status

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:27.958
of potential life on Mars is

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:30.958
that it's probably been on the planet,

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
maybe one in two chances.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
The question as to whether

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:40.958
there is life on Mars that is related to life on Earth

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:42.958
has now been very muddied,

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:43.958
because we now know,

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:46.958
from Mars meteorites that have made it to Earth,

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:50.958
that there's material that can be exchanged between those two planets.

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:52.958
One of the burning questions, of course, is

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:55.958
if we go there and find life in the sub-surface,

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:57.958
as I fully expect that we will,

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
is that a second genesis of life?

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:01.958
Did life start here

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:03.958
and was it transported there?

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:06.958
Did it start there and get transported here?

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:10.958
This will be a fascinating puzzle as we go into the next half-century,

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:12.958
and where I expect that we will

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:15.958
have more and more Mars missions to answer these questions.

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:17.958
Thank you.

title: The science of sync
transcript: I was trying to think, how is sync connected to happiness, and it occurred to me that for some reason we take pleasure in synchronizing. We like to dance together, we like singing together. And so, if you'll put up with this, I would like to enlist your help with a first experiment today. The experiment is — and I notice, by the way, that when you applauded, that you did it in a typical North American way, that is, you were raucous and incoherent. You were not organized. It didn't even occur to you to clap in unison. Do you think you could do it? I would like to see if this audience would — no, you haven't practiced, as far as I know — can you get it together to clap in sync?(Clapping)Whoa! Now, that's what we call emergent behavior.(Laughter)So I didn't expect that, but — I mean, I expected you could synchronize. It didn't occur to me you'd increase your frequency. It's interesting.(Laughter)So what do we make of that? First of all, we know that you're all brilliant. This is a room full of intelligent people, highly sensitive. Some trained musicians out there. Is that what enabled you to synchronize? So to put the question a little more seriously, let's ask ourselves what are the minimum requirements for what you just did, for spontaneous synchronization. Do you need, for instance, to be as smart as you are? Do you even need a brain at all just to synchronize? Do you need to be alive? I mean, that's a spooky thought, right? Inanimate objects that might spontaneously synchronize themselves. It's real. In fact, I'll try to explain today that sync is maybe one of, if not one of the most, perhaps the most pervasive drive in all of nature. It extends from the subatomic scale to the farthest reaches of the cosmos. It's a deep tendency toward order in nature that opposes what we've all been taught about entropy. I mean, I'm not saying the law of entropy is wrong — it's not. But there is a countervailing force in the universe — the tendency towards spontaneous order. And so that's our theme.Now, to get into that, let me begin with what might have occurred to you immediately when you hear that we're talking about synchrony in nature, which is the glorious example of birds that flock together, or fish swimming in organized schools. So these are not particularly intelligent creatures, and yet, as we'll see, they exhibit beautiful ballets. This is from a BBC show called "Predators," and what we're looking at here are examples of synchrony that have to do with defense. When you're small and vulnerable, like these starlings, or like the fish, it helps to swarm to avoid predators, to confuse predators. Let me be quiet for a second because this is so gorgeous. For a long time, biologists were puzzled by this behavior, wondering how it could be possible. We're so used to choreography giving rise to synchrony. These creatures are not choreographed. They're choreographing themselves.And only today is science starting to figure out how it works. I'll show you a computer model made by Iain Couzin, a researcher at Oxford, that shows how swarms work. There are just three simple rules. First, all the individuals are only aware of their nearest neighbors. Second, all the individuals have a tendency to line up. And third, they're all attracted to each other, but they try to keep a small distance apart. And when you build those three rules in, automatically you start to see swarms that look very much like fish schools or bird flocks. Now, fish like to stay close together, about a body length apart. Birds try to stay about three or four body lengths apart. But except for that difference, the rules are the same for both.Now, all this changes when a predator enters the scene. There's a fourth rule: when a predator's coming, get out of the way. Here on the model you see the predator attacking. The prey move out in random directions, and then the rule of attraction brings them back together again, so there's this constant splitting and reforming. And you see that in nature. Keep in mind that, although it looks as if each individual is acting to cooperate, what's really going on is a kind of selfish Darwinian behavior. Each is scattering away at random to try to save its scales or feathers. That is, out of the desire to save itself, each creature is following these rules, and that leads to something that's safe for all of them. Even though it looks like they're thinking as a group, they're not. You might wonder what exactly is the advantage to being in a swarm, so you can think of several.As I say, if you're in a swarm, your odds of being the unlucky one are reduced as compared to a small group. There are many eyes to spot danger. And you'll see in the example with the starlings, with the birds, when this peregrine hawk is about to attack them, that actually waves of panic can propagate, sending messages over great distances. You'll see — let's see, it's coming up possibly at the very end — maybe not. Information can be sent over half a kilometer away in a very short time through this mechanism. Yes, it's happening here. See if you can see those waves propagating through the swarm. It's beautiful. The birds are, we sort of understand, we think, from that computer model, what's going on. As I say, it's just those three simple rules, plus the one about watch out for predators.There doesn't seem to be anything mystical about this. We don't, however, really understand at a mathematical level. I'm a mathematician. We would like to be able to understand better. I mean, I showed you a computer model, but a computer is not understanding. A computer is, in a way, just another experiment. We would really like to have a deeper insight into how this works and to understand, you know, exactly where this organization comes from. How do the rules give rise to the patterns?There is one case that we have begun to understand better, and it's the case of fireflies. If you see fireflies in North America, like so many North American sorts of things, they tend to be independent operators. They ignore each other. They each do their own thing, flashing on and off, paying no attention to their neighbors. But in Southeast Asia — places like Thailand or Malaysia or Borneo — there's a beautiful cooperative behavior that occurs among male fireflies. You can see it every night along the river banks. The trees, mangrove trees, are filled with fireflies communicating with light. Specifically, it's male fireflies who are all flashing in perfect time together, in perfect synchrony, to reinforce a message to the females. And the message, as you can imagine, is "Come hither. Mate with me."(Music)In a second I'm going to show you a slow motion of a single firefly so that you can get a sense. This is a single frame. Then on, and then off — a 30th of a second, there. And then watch this whole river bank, and watch how precise the synchrony is. On, more on and then off. The combined light from these beetles — these are actually tiny beetles — is so bright that fishermen out at sea can use them as navigating beacons to find their way back to their home rivers. It's stunning. For a long time it was not believed when the first Western travelers, like Sir Francis Drake, went to Thailand and came back with tales of this unbelievable spectacle. No one believed them. We don't see anything like this in Europe or in the West. And for a long time, even after it was documented, it was thought to be some kind of optical illusion. Scientific papers were published saying it was twitching eyelids that explained it, or, you know, a human being's tendency to see patterns where there are none. But I hope you've convinced yourself now, with this nighttime video, that they really were very well synchronized.Okay, well, the issue then is, do we need to be alive to see this kind of spontaneous order, and I've already hinted that the answer is no. Well, you don't have to be a whole creature. You can even be just a single cell. Like, take, for instance, your pacemaker cells in your heart right now. They're keeping you alive. Every beat of your heart depends on this crucial region, the sinoatrial node, which has about 10,000 independent cells that would each beep, have an electrical rhythm — a voltage up and down — to send a signal to the ventricles to pump. Now, your pacemaker is not a single cell. It's this democracy of 10,000 cells that all have to fire in unison for the pacemaker to work correctly.I don't want to give you the idea that synchrony is always a good idea. If you have epilepsy, there is an instance of billions of brain cells, or at least millions, discharging in pathological concert. So this tendency towards order is not always a good thing. You don't have to be alive. You don't have to be even a single cell. If you look, for instance, at how lasers work, that would be a case of atomic synchrony. In a laser, what makes laser light so different from the light above my head here is that this light is incoherent — many different colors and different frequencies, sort of like the way you clapped initially — but if you were a laser, it would be rhythmic applause. It would be all atoms pulsating in unison, emitting light of one color, one frequency.Now comes the very risky part of my talk, which is to demonstrate that inanimate things can synchronize. Hold your breath for me. What I have here are two empty water bottles. This is not Keith Barry doing a magic trick. This is a klutz just playing with some water bottles. I have some metronomes here. Can you hear that? All right, so, I've got a metronome, and it's the world's smallest metronome, the — well, I shouldn't advertise. Anyway, so this is the world's smallest metronome. I've set it on the fastest setting, and I'm going to now take another one set to the same setting. We can try this first. If I just put them on the table together, there's no reason for them to synchronize, and they probably won't.Maybe you'd better listen to them. I'll stand here. What I'm hoping is that they might just drift apart because their frequencies aren't perfectly the same. Right? They did. They were in sync for a while, but then they drifted apart. And the reason is that they're not able to communicate. Now, you might think that's a bizarre idea. How can metronomes communicate? Well, they can communicate through mechanical forces. So I'm going to give them a chance to do that. I also want to wind this one up a bit. How can they communicate? I'm going to put them on a movable platform, which is the "Guide to Graduate Study at Cornell." Okay? So here it is. Let's see if we can get this to work. My wife pointed out to me that it will work better if I put both on at the same time because otherwise the whole thing will tip over. All right. So there we go. Let's see. OK, I'm not trying to cheat — let me start them out of sync. No, hard to even do that.(Applause)All right. So before any one goes out of sync, I'll just put those right there.(Laughter) Now, that might seem a bit whimsical, but this pervasiveness of this tendency towards spontaneous order sometimes has unexpected consequences. And a clear case of that, was something that happened in London in the year 2000. The Millennium Bridge was supposed to be the pride of London — a beautiful new footbridge erected across the Thames, first river crossing in over 100 years in London. There was a big competition for the design of this bridge, and the winning proposal was submitted by an unusual team — in the TED spirit, actually — of an architect — perhaps the greatest architect in the United Kingdom, Lord Norman Foster — working with an artist, a sculptor, Sir Anthony Caro, and an engineering firm, Ove Arup. And together they submitted a design based on Lord Foster's vision, which was — he remembered as a kid reading Flash Gordon comic books, and he said that when Flash Gordon would come to an abyss, he would shoot what today would be a kind of a light saber.He would shoot his light saber across the abyss, making a blade of light, and then scamper across on this blade of light. He said, "That's the vision I want to give to London. I want a blade of light across the Thames." So they built the blade of light, and it's a very thin ribbon of steel, the world's — probably the flattest and thinnest suspension bridge there is, with cables that are out on the side. You're used to suspension bridges with big droopy cables on the top. These cables were on the side of the bridge, like if you took a rubber band and stretched it taut across the Thames — that's what's holding up this bridge. Now, everyone was very excited to try it out. On opening day, thousands of Londoners came out, and something happened. And within two days the bridge was closed to the public. So I want to first show you some interviews with people who were on the bridge on opening day, who will describe what happened.Man: It really started moving sideways and slightly up and down, rather like being on the boat.Woman: Yeah, it felt unstable, and it was very windy, and I remember it had lots of flags up and down the sides, so you could definitely — there was something going on sideways, it felt, maybe.Interviewer: Not up and down? Boy: No.Interviewer: And not forwards and backwards? Boy: No.Interviewer: Just sideways. About how much was it moving, do you think?Boy: It was about —Interviewer: I mean, that much, or this much?Boy: About the second one.Interviewer: This much? Boy: Yeah.Man: It was at least six, six to eight inches, I would have thought.Interviewer: Right, so, at least this much? Man: Oh, yes.Woman: I remember wanting to get off.Interviewer: Oh, did you? Woman: Yeah. It felt odd.Interviewer: So it was enough to be scary? Woman: Yeah, but I thought that was just me.Interviewer: Ah! Now, tell me why you had to do this?Boy: We had to do this because, to keep in balance because if you didn't keep your balance, then you would just fall over about, like, to the left or right, about 45 degrees. Interviewer: So just show me how you walk normally. Right. And then show me what it was like when the bridge started to go. Right. So you had to deliberately push your feet out sideways and — oh, and short steps?Man: That's right. And it seemed obvious to me that it was probably the number of people on it.Interviewer: Were they deliberately walking in step, or anything like that?Man: No, they just had to conform to the movement of the bridge.Steven Strogatz: All right, so that already gives you a hint of what happened. Think of the bridge as being like this platform. Think of the people as being like metronomes. Now, you might not be used to thinking of yourself as a metronome, but after all, we do walk like — I mean, we oscillate back and forth as we walk. And especially if we start to walk like those people did, right? They all showed this strange sort of skating gait that they adopted once the bridge started to move. And so let me show you now the footage of the bridge. But also, after you see the bridge on opening day, you'll see an interesting clip of work done by a bridge engineer at Cambridge named Allan McRobie, who figured out what happened on the bridge, and who built a bridge simulator to explain exactly what the problem was. It was a kind of unintended positive feedback loop between the way the people walked and the way the bridge began to move, that engineers knew nothing about. Actually, I think the first person you'll see is the young engineer who was put in charge of this project. Okay.(Video) Interviewer: Did anyone get hurt? Engineer: No.Interviewer: Right. So it was quite small — Engineer: Yes. Interviewer: — but real?Engineer: Absolutely. Interviewer: You thought, "Oh, bother."Engineer: I felt I was disappointed about it.We'd spent a lot of time designing this bridge, and we'd analyzed it, we'd checked it to codes — to heavier loads than the codes — and here it was doing something that we didn't know about. Interviewer: You didn't expect. Engineer: Exactly.Narrator: The most dramatic and shocking footage shows whole sections of the crowd — hundreds of people — apparently rocking from side to side in unison, not only with each other, but with the bridge. This synchronized movement seemed to be driving the bridge. But how could the crowd become synchronized? Was there something special about the Millennium Bridge that caused this effect? This was to be the focus of the investigation.Interviewer: Well, at last the simulated bridge is finished, and I can make it wobble. Now, Allan, this is all your fault, isn't it? Allan McRobie: Yes.Interviewer: You designed this, yes, this simulated bridge, and this, you reckon, mimics the action of the real bridge?AM: It captures a lot of the physics, yes.Interviewer: Right. So if we get on it, we should be able to wobble it, yes?Allan McRobie is a bridge engineer from Cambridge who wrote to me, suggesting that a bridge simulator ought to wobble in the same way as the real bridge — provided we hung it on pendulums of exactly the right length.AM: This one's only a couple of tons, so it's fairly easy to get going. Just by walking. Interviewer: Well, it's certainly going now.AM: It doesn't have to be a real dangle. Just walk. It starts to go.Interviewer: It's actually quite difficult to walk. You have to be careful where you put your feet down, don't you, because if you get it wrong, it just throws you off your feet.AM: It certainly affects the way you walk, yes. You can't walk normally on it.Interviewer: No. If you try and put one foot in front of another, it's moving your feet away from under you. AM: Yes.Interviewer: So you've got to put your feet out sideways. So already, the simulator is making me walk in exactly the same way as our witnesses walked on the real bridge.AM: ... ice-skating gait. There isn't all this sort of snake way of walking.Interviewer: For a more convincing experiment, I wanted my own opening-day crowd, the sound check team. Their instructions: just walk normally. It's really intriguing because none of these people is trying to drive it. They're all having some difficulty walking. And the only way you can walk comfortably is by getting in step. But then, of course, everyone is driving the bridge. You can't help it. You're actually forced by the movement of the bridge to get into step, and therefore to drive it to move further.SS: All right, well, with that from the Ministry of Silly Walks, maybe I'd better end. I see I've gone over. But I hope that you'll go outside and see the world in a new way, to see all the amazing synchrony around us. Thank you.(Applause)

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I was trying to think, how is sync connected to happiness,

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:21.958
and it occurred to me that for some reason we take pleasure in synchronizing.

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:24.958
We like to dance together, we like singing together.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:29.958
And so, if you'll put up with this, I would like to enlist your help

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:33.958
with a first experiment today. The experiment is --

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:36.958
and I notice, by the way, that when you applauded,

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
that you did it in a typical North American way,

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:42.958
that is, you were raucous and incoherent.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:47.958
You were not organized. It didn't even occur to you to clap in unison.

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:51.958
Do you think you could do it? I would like to see if this audience would --

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:53.958
no, you haven't practiced, as far as I know --

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:56.958
can you get it together to clap in sync?

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:06.958
(Clapping)

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
Whoa! Now, that's what we call emergent behavior.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
(Laughter)

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:15.958
So I didn't expect that, but -- I mean, I expected you could synchronize.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
It didn't occur to me you'd increase your frequency.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
It's interesting.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:23.958
(Laughter)

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:27.958
So what do we make of that? First of all, we know that you're all brilliant.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:31.958
This is a room full of intelligent people, highly sensitive.

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
Some trained musicians out there.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
Is that what enabled you to synchronize?

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
So to put the question a little more seriously,

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:43.958
let's ask ourselves what are the minimum requirements for what you just did,

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:46.958
for spontaneous synchronization.

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:50.958
Do you need, for instance, to be as smart as you are?

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:57.958
Do you even need a brain at all just to synchronize?

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:02.958
Do you need to be alive? I mean, that's a spooky thought, right?

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:07.958
Inanimate objects that might spontaneously synchronize themselves.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:14.958
It's real. In fact, I'll try to explain today that sync is maybe one of,

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:18.958
if not one of the most, perhaps the most pervasive drive in all of nature.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:24.958
It extends from the subatomic scale to the farthest reaches of the cosmos.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:28.958
It's a deep tendency toward order in nature

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:31.958
that opposes what we've all been taught about entropy.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
I mean, I'm not saying the law of entropy is wrong -- it's not.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
But there is a countervailing force in the universe --

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:41.958
the tendency towards spontaneous order. And so that's our theme.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:45.958
Now, to get into that, let me begin with what might have occurred to you immediately

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:49.958
when you hear that we're talking about synchrony in nature,

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:55.958
which is the glorious example of birds that flock together,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:59.958
or fish swimming in organized schools.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:03.958
So these are not particularly intelligent creatures,

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
and yet, as we'll see, they exhibit beautiful ballets.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
This is from a BBC show called "Predators,"

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:15.958
and what we're looking at here are examples of synchrony that have to do with defense.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
When you're small and vulnerable, like these starlings,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:26.958
or like the fish, it helps to swarm to avoid predators, to confuse predators.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
Let me be quiet for a second because this is so gorgeous.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
For a long time, biologists were puzzled by this behavior,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
wondering how it could be possible.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
We're so used to choreography giving rise to synchrony.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
These creatures are not choreographed.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
They're choreographing themselves.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
And only today is science starting to figure out how it works.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:12.958
I'll show you a computer model made by Iain Couzin, a researcher at Oxford,

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
that shows how swarms work.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
There are just three simple rules.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:21.958
First, all the individuals are only aware of their nearest neighbors.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
Second, all the individuals have a tendency to line up.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
And third, they're all attracted to each other,

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
but they try to keep a small distance apart.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
And when you build those three rules in,

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
automatically you start to see swarms

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
that look very much like fish schools or bird flocks.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:45.958
Now, fish like to stay close together, about a body length apart.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
Birds try to stay about three or four body lengths apart.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
But except for that difference, the rules are the same for both.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
Now, all this changes when a predator enters the scene.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:07.958
There's a fourth rule: when a predator's coming, get out of the way.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
Here on the model you see the predator attacking.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
The prey move out in random directions,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
and then the rule of attraction brings them back together again,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
so there's this constant splitting and reforming.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
And you see that in nature.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:46.958
Keep in mind that, although it looks as if each individual is acting to cooperate,

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:50.958
what's really going on is a kind of selfish Darwinian behavior.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:54.958
Each is scattering away at random to try to save its scales or feathers.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
That is, out of the desire to save itself,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
each creature is following these rules,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
and that leads to something that's safe for all of them.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
Even though it looks like they're thinking as a group, they're not.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
You might wonder what exactly is the advantage to being in a swarm,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
so you can think of several.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:34.958
As I say, if you're in a swarm, your odds of being the unlucky one

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
are reduced as compared to a small group.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
There are many eyes to spot danger.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:48.958
And you'll see in the example with the starlings, with the birds,

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
when this peregrine hawk is about to attack them,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
that actually waves of panic can propagate,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
sending messages over great distances.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:04.958
You'll see -- let's see, it's coming up possibly at the very end -- maybe not.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
Information can be sent over half a kilometer away

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
in a very short time through this mechanism.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
Yes, it's happening here.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
See if you can see those waves propagating through the swarm.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:23.958
It's beautiful. The birds are, we sort of understand, we think,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
from that computer model, what's going on.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
As I say, it's just those three simple rules,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
plus the one about watch out for predators.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
There doesn't seem to be anything mystical about this.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
We don't, however, really understand at a mathematical level.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:39.958
I'm a mathematician. We would like to be able to understand better.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
I mean, I showed you a computer model, but a computer is not understanding.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
A computer is, in a way, just another experiment.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
We would really like to have a deeper insight into how this works

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:53.958
and to understand, you know, exactly where this organization comes from.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
How do the rules give rise to the patterns?

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
There is one case that we have begun to understand better,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
and it's the case of fireflies.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
If you see fireflies in North America,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
like so many North American sorts of things,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:09.958
they tend to be independent operators. They ignore each other.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
They each do their own thing, flashing on and off,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
paying no attention to their neighbors.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:18.958
But in Southeast Asia -- places like Thailand or Malaysia or Borneo --

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:23.958
there's a beautiful cooperative behavior that occurs among male fireflies.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
You can see it every night along the river banks.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:31.958
The trees, mangrove trees, are filled with fireflies communicating with light.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:36.958
Specifically, it's male fireflies who are all flashing in perfect time together,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:40.958
in perfect synchrony, to reinforce a message to the females.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
And the message, as you can imagine, is "Come hither. Mate with me."

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:51.958
(Music)

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:56.958
In a second I'm going to show you a slow motion of a single firefly

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
so that you can get a sense. This is a single frame.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:04.958
Then on, and then off -- a 30th of a second, there.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:08.958
And then watch this whole river bank, and watch how precise the synchrony is.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
On, more on and then off.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
The combined light from these beetles -- these are actually tiny beetles --

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
is so bright that fishermen out at sea can use them

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:30.958
as navigating beacons to find their way back to their home rivers. It's stunning.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
For a long time it was not believed

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
when the first Western travelers, like Sir Francis Drake,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:39.958
went to Thailand and came back with tales of this unbelievable spectacle.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
No one believed them.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
We don't see anything like this in Europe or in the West.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
And for a long time, even after it was documented,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
it was thought to be some kind of optical illusion.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
Scientific papers were published saying it was twitching eyelids

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:56.958
that explained it, or, you know, a human being's tendency

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
to see patterns where there are none.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
But I hope you've convinced yourself now, with this nighttime video,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
that they really were very well synchronized.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
Okay, well, the issue then is, do we need to be alive

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
to see this kind of spontaneous order,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
and I've already hinted that the answer is no.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
Well, you don't have to be a whole creature.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
You can even be just a single cell.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
Like, take, for instance, your pacemaker cells in your heart right now.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
They're keeping you alive.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:28.958
Every beat of your heart depends on this crucial region, the sinoatrial node,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
which has about 10,000 independent cells that would each beep,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
have an electrical rhythm -- a voltage up and down --

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
to send a signal to the ventricles to pump.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
Now, your pacemaker is not a single cell.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
It's this democracy of 10,000 cells that all have to fire in unison

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
for the pacemaker to work correctly.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
I don't want to give you the idea that synchrony is always a good idea.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:55.958
If you have epilepsy, there is an instance of billions of brain cells, or at least millions,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
discharging in pathological concert.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
So this tendency towards order is not always a good thing.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
You don't have to be alive. You don't have to be even a single cell.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
If you look, for instance, at how lasers work,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
that would be a case of atomic synchrony.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:16.958
In a laser, what makes laser light so different from the light above my head here

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
is that this light is incoherent --

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
many different colors and different frequencies,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
sort of like the way you clapped initially --

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
but if you were a laser, it would be rhythmic applause.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
It would be all atoms pulsating in unison,

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
emitting light of one color, one frequency.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
Now comes the very risky part of my talk,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:40.958
which is to demonstrate that inanimate things can synchronize.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
Hold your breath for me.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.958
What I have here are two empty water bottles.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
This is not Keith Barry doing a magic trick.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:56.958
This is a klutz just playing with some water bottles.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
I have some metronomes here.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
Can you hear that?

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
All right, so, I've got a metronome,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
and it's the world's smallest metronome, the -- well, I shouldn't advertise.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
Anyway, so this is the world's smallest metronome.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
I've set it on the fastest setting, and I'm going to now take

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
another one set to the same setting.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
We can try this first. If I just put them on the table together,

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
there's no reason for them to synchronize, and they probably won't.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
Maybe you'd better listen to them. I'll stand here.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
What I'm hoping is that they might just drift apart

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
because their frequencies aren't perfectly the same.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
Right? They did.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
They were in sync for a while, but then they drifted apart.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
And the reason is that they're not able to communicate.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
Now, you might think that's a bizarre idea.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
How can metronomes communicate?

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
Well, they can communicate through mechanical forces.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
So I'm going to give them a chance to do that.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
I also want to wind this one up a bit. How can they communicate?

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
I'm going to put them on a movable platform,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:26.958
which is the "Guide to Graduate Study at Cornell." Okay? So here it is.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
Let's see if we can get this to work.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.958
My wife pointed out to me that it will work better if I put both on at the same time

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
because otherwise the whole thing will tip over.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:43.958
All right. So there we go. Let's see. OK, I'm not trying to cheat --

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:48.958
let me start them out of sync. No, hard to even do that.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
(Applause)

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:10.958
All right. So before any one goes out of sync, I'll just put those right there.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:11.958
(Laughter)

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
Now, that might seem a bit whimsical,

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:18.958
but this pervasiveness of this tendency towards spontaneous order

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
sometimes has unexpected consequences.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
And a clear case of that,

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
was something that happened in London in the year 2000.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
The Millennium Bridge was supposed to be the pride of London --

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:34.958
a beautiful new footbridge erected across the Thames,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:38.958
first river crossing in over 100 years in London.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
There was a big competition for the design of this bridge,

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:45.958
and the winning proposal was submitted by an unusual team --

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
in the TED spirit, actually -- of an architect --

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:52.958
perhaps the greatest architect in the United Kingdom, Lord Norman Foster --

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:57.958
working with an artist, a sculptor, Sir Anthony Caro,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:01.958
and an engineering firm, Ove Arup.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:06.958
And together they submitted a design based on Lord Foster's vision,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:10.958
which was -- he remembered as a kid reading Flash Gordon comic books,

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
and he said that when Flash Gordon would come to an abyss,

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
he would shoot what today would be a kind of a light saber.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.958
He would shoot his light saber across the abyss, making a blade of light,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
and then scamper across on this blade of light.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
He said, "That's the vision I want to give to London.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
I want a blade of light across the Thames."

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
So they built the blade of light,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:36.958
and it's a very thin ribbon of steel, the world's --

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
probably the flattest and thinnest suspension bridge there is,

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
with cables that are out on the side.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
You're used to suspension bridges with big droopy cables on the top.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
These cables were on the side of the bridge,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:52.958
like if you took a rubber band and stretched it taut across the Thames --

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
that's what's holding up this bridge.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
Now, everyone was very excited to try it out.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:01.958
On opening day, thousands of Londoners came out, and something happened.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:05.958
And within two days the bridge was closed to the public.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:10.958
So I want to first show you some interviews with people

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
who were on the bridge on opening day, who will describe what happened.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:18.958
Man: It really started moving sideways and slightly up and down,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
rather like being on the boat.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
Woman: Yeah, it felt unstable, and it was very windy,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:28.958
and I remember it had lots of flags up and down the sides, so you could definitely --

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
there was something going on sideways, it felt, maybe.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
Interviewer: Not up and down? Boy: No.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
Interviewer: And not forwards and backwards? Boy: No.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:38.958
Interviewer: Just sideways. About how much was it moving, do you think?

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
Boy: It was about --

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
Interviewer: I mean, that much, or this much?

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
Boy: About the second one.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
Interviewer: This much? Boy: Yeah.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
Man: It was at least six, six to eight inches, I would have thought.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
Interviewer: Right, so, at least this much? Man: Oh, yes.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
Woman: I remember wanting to get off.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:55.958
Interviewer: Oh, did you? Woman: Yeah. It felt odd.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:17:01.958
Interviewer: So it was enough to be scary? Woman: Yeah, but I thought that was just me.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
Interviewer: Ah! Now, tell me why you had to do this?

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
Boy: We had to do this because, to keep in balance

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
because if you didn't keep your balance,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:14.958
then you would just fall over about, like, to the left or right, about 45 degrees.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:18.958
Interviewer: So just show me how you walk normally. Right.

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:24.958
And then show me what it was like when the bridge started to go. Right.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:28.958
So you had to deliberately push your feet out sideways and --

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:30.958
oh, and short steps?

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
Man: That's right. And it seemed obvious to me

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
that it was probably the number of people on it.

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:41.958
Interviewer: Were they deliberately walking in step, or anything like that?

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:45.958
Man: No, they just had to conform to the movement of the bridge.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:48.958
Steven Strogatz: All right, so that already gives you a hint of what happened.

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:52.958
Think of the bridge as being like this platform.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:55.958
Think of the people as being like metronomes.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:58.958
Now, you might not be used to thinking of yourself as a metronome,

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:02.958
but after all, we do walk like -- I mean, we oscillate back and forth as we walk.

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:05.958
And especially if we start to walk like those people did, right?

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:09.958
They all showed this strange sort of skating gait

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:12.958
that they adopted once the bridge started to move.

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:15.958
And so let me show you now the footage of the bridge.

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:19.958
But also, after you see the bridge on opening day, you'll see an interesting clip

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:24.958
of work done by a bridge engineer at Cambridge named Allan McRobie,

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
who figured out what happened on the bridge,

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:30.958
and who built a bridge simulator to explain exactly what the problem was.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:34.958
It was a kind of unintended positive feedback loop

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
between the way the people walked and the way the bridge began to move,

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
that engineers knew nothing about.

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:41.958
Actually, I think the first person you'll see

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:45.958
is the young engineer who was put in charge of this project. Okay.

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:48.958
(Video) Interviewer: Did anyone get hurt? Engineer: No.

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:51.958
Interviewer: Right. So it was quite small -- Engineer: Yes. Interviewer: -- but real?

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:54.958
Engineer: Absolutely. Interviewer: You thought, "Oh, bother."

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:57.958
Engineer: I felt I was disappointed about it.

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:01.958
We'd spent a lot of time designing this bridge, and we'd analyzed it,

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:04.958
we'd checked it to codes -- to heavier loads than the codes --

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:07.958
and here it was doing something that we didn't know about.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
Interviewer: You didn't expect. Engineer: Exactly.

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:12.958
Narrator: The most dramatic and shocking footage

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:15.958
shows whole sections of the crowd -- hundreds of people --

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:17.958
apparently rocking from side to side in unison,

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:20.958
not only with each other, but with the bridge.

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:24.958
This synchronized movement seemed to be driving the bridge.

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:27.958
But how could the crowd become synchronized?

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:31.958
Was there something special about the Millennium Bridge that caused this effect?

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:35.958
This was to be the focus of the investigation.

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:41.958
Interviewer: Well, at last the simulated bridge is finished, and I can make it wobble.

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:46.958
Now, Allan, this is all your fault, isn't it? Allan McRobie: Yes.

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:48.958
Interviewer: You designed this, yes, this simulated bridge,

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:51.958
and this, you reckon, mimics the action of the real bridge?

00:19:51.958 --> 00:19:53.958
AM: It captures a lot of the physics, yes.

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:56.958
Interviewer: Right. So if we get on it, we should be able to wobble it, yes?

00:19:59.958 --> 00:20:02.958
Allan McRobie is a bridge engineer from Cambridge who wrote to me,

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:05.958
suggesting that a bridge simulator ought to wobble

00:20:05.958 --> 00:20:07.958
in the same way as the real bridge --

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:09.958
provided we hung it on pendulums of exactly the right length.

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:12.958
AM: This one's only a couple of tons, so it's fairly easy to get going.

00:20:12.958 --> 00:20:15.958
Just by walking. Interviewer: Well, it's certainly going now.

00:20:15.958 --> 00:20:18.958
AM: It doesn't have to be a real dangle. Just walk. It starts to go.

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:21.958
Interviewer: It's actually quite difficult to walk.


00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:24.958
You have to be careful where you put your feet down, don't you,


00:20:24.958 --> 00:20:27.958
because if you get it wrong, it just throws you off your feet.

00:20:27.958 --> 00:20:31.958
AM: It certainly affects the way you walk, yes. You can't walk normally on it.

00:20:32.958 --> 00:20:34.958
Interviewer: No. If you try and put one foot in front of another,

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:37.958
it's moving your feet away from under you. AM: Yes.

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:39.958
Interviewer: So you've got to put your feet out sideways.

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:43.958
So already, the simulator is making me walk in exactly the same way

00:20:43.958 --> 00:20:45.958
as our witnesses walked on the real bridge.

00:20:45.958 --> 00:20:48.958
AM: ... ice-skating gait. There isn't all this sort of snake way of walking.

00:20:48.958 --> 00:20:50.958
Interviewer: For a more convincing experiment,

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:53.958
I wanted my own opening-day crowd, the sound check team.

00:20:53.958 --> 00:20:56.958
Their instructions: just walk normally.

00:21:05.958 --> 00:21:09.958
It's really intriguing because none of these people is trying to drive it.

00:21:09.958 --> 00:21:11.958
They're all having some difficulty walking.

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:15.958
And the only way you can walk comfortably is by getting in step.

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:18.958
But then, of course, everyone is driving the bridge.

00:21:20.958 --> 00:21:25.958
You can't help it. You're actually forced by the movement of the bridge to get into step,

00:21:25.958 --> 00:21:27.958
and therefore to drive it to move further.

00:21:31.958 --> 00:21:35.958
SS: All right, well, with that from the Ministry of Silly Walks,

00:21:35.958 --> 00:21:38.958
maybe I'd better end. I see I've gone over.

00:21:38.958 --> 00:21:41.958
But I hope that you'll go outside and see the world in a new way,

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:44.958
to see all the amazing synchrony around us. Thank you.

00:21:44.958 --> 00:21:46.958
(Applause)

title: Taking OLPC to Colombia
transcript: It's amazing, when you meet a head of state and you say, "What is your most precious natural resource?" — they will not say children at first. And then when you say children, they will pretty quickly agree with you.(Video): We're traveling today with the Minister of Defense of Colombia, head of the army and the head of the police, and we're dropping off 650 laptops today to children who have no television, no telephone and have been in a community cut off from the rest of the world for the past 40 years.The importance of delivering laptops to this region is connecting kids who have otherwise been unconnected because of the FARC, the guerrillas that started off 40 years ago as a political movement and then became a drug movement. There are one billion children in the world, and 50 percent of them don't have electricity at home or at school. And in some countries — let me pick Afghanistan — 75 percent of the little girls don't go to school. And I don't mean that they drop out of school in the third or fourth grade — they don't go.So in the three years since I talked at TED and showed a prototype, it's gone from an idea to a real laptop. We have half a million laptops today in the hands of children. We have about a quarter of a million in transit to those and other children, and then there are another quarter of a million more that are being ordered at this moment. So, in rough numbers, there are a million laptops. That's smaller than I predicted — I predicted three to 10 million — but is still a very large number.In Colombia, we have about 3,000 laptops. It's the Minister of Defense with whom we're working, not the Minister of Education, because it is seen as a strategic defense issue in the sense of liberating these zones that had been completely closed off, in which the people who had been causing, if you will, 40 years' worth of bombings and kidnappings and assassinations lived.And suddenly, the kids have connected laptops. They've leapfrogged. The change is absolutely monumental, because it's not just opening it up, but it's opening it up to the rest of the world. So yes, they're building roads, yes, they're putting in telephone, yes, there will be television. But the kids six to 12 years old are surfing the Internet in Spanish and in local languages, so the children grow up with access to information, with a window into the rest of the world. Before, they were closed off.Interestingly enough, in other countries, it will be the Minister of Finance who sees it as an engine of economic growth. And that engine is going to see the results in 20 years. It's not going to happen, you know, in one year, but it's an important, deeply economic and cultural change that happens through children. Thirty-one countries in total are involved, and in the case of Uruguay, half the children already have them, and by the middle of 2009, every single child in Uruguay will have a laptop — a little green laptop.Now what are some of the results? Some of the results that go across every single country include teachers saying they have never loved teaching so much, and reading comprehension measured by third parties — not by us — skyrockets. Probably the most important thing we see is children teaching parents. They own the laptops. They take them home. And so when I met with three children from the schools, who had traveled all day to come to Bogota, one of the three children brought her mother. And the reason she brought her mother is that this six-year-old child had been teaching her mother how to read and write. Her mother had not gone to primary school. And this is such an inversion, and such a wonderful example of children being the agents of change.So now, in closing, people say, now why laptops? Laptops are a luxury; it's like giving them iPods. No. The reason you want laptops is that the word is education, not laptop. This is an education project, not a laptop project. They need to learn learning. And then, just think — they can have, let's say, 100 books. In a village, you have 100 laptops, each with a different set of 100 books, and so that village suddenly has 10,000 books. You and I didn't have 10,000 books when we went to primary school.Sometimes school is under a tree, or in many cases, the teacher has only a fifth-grade education, so you need a collaborative model of learning, not just building more schools and training more teachers, which you have to do anyway. So we're once again doing "Give One, Get One." Last year, we ran a "Give One, Get One" program, and it generated over 100,000 laptops that we were then able to give free. And by being a zero-dollar laptop, we can go to countries that can't afford it at all. And that's what we did. We went to Haiti, we went to Rwanda, Afghanistan, Ethiopia, Mongolia. Places that are not markets, seeding it with the principles of saturation, connectivity, low ages, etc. And then we can actually roll out large numbers.So think of it this way: think of it as inoculating children against ignorance. And think of the laptop as a vaccine. You don't vaccinate a few children. You vaccinate all the children in an area.
