00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
Interestingly enough, in other countries,

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
it will be the Minister of Finance who sees it

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:08.958
as an engine of economic growth.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:12.958
And that engine is going to see the results in 20 years.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
It's not going to happen, you know, in one year,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
but it's an important, deeply economic

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
and cultural change

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
that happens through children.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
Thirty-one countries in total are involved,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
and in the case of Uruguay,

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
half the children already have them,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
and by the middle of 2009,

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
every single child in Uruguay will have a laptop --

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
a little green laptop.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
Now what are some of the results?

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
Some of the results

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
that go across every single country

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
include teachers saying

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
they have never loved teaching so much,

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
and reading comprehension

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:56.958
measured by third parties -- not by us -- skyrockets.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
Probably the most important thing we see

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
is children teaching parents.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
They own the laptops. They take them home.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
And so when I met with three children from the schools,

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:12.958
who had traveled all day to come to Bogota,

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
one of the three children brought her mother.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
And the reason she brought her mother

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
is that this six-year-old child

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
had been teaching her mother

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
how to read and write.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
Her mother had not gone to primary school.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
And this is such an inversion,

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
and such a wonderful example

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
of children being the agents of change.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
So now, in closing, people say,

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
now why laptops?

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
Laptops are a luxury; it's like giving them iPods. No.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
The reason you want laptops

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:49.958
is that the word is education, not laptop.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
This is an education project, not a laptop project.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
They need to learn learning. And then, just think --

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
they can have, let's say, 100 books.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
In a village, you have 100 laptops,

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
each with a different set of 100 books,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
and so that village suddenly has 10,000 books.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:09.958
You and I didn't have 10,000 books when we went to primary school.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
Sometimes school is under a tree,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:15.958
or in many cases, the teacher has only a fifth-grade education,

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
so you need a collaborative model of learning,

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
not just building more schools and training more teachers,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
which you have to do anyway.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
So we're once again doing "Give One, Get One."

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
Last year, we ran a "Give One, Get One" program,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:31.958
and it generated over 100,000 laptops

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
that we were then able to give free.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
And by being a zero-dollar laptop,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
we can go to countries that can't afford it at all.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
And that's what we did. We went to Haiti,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
we went to Rwanda, Afghanistan,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
Ethiopia, Mongolia.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
Places that are not markets,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
seeding it with the principles of

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
saturation, connectivity, low ages, etc.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:59.958
And then we can actually roll out large numbers.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
So think of it this way:

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
think of it as inoculating children

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
against ignorance.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
And think of the laptop as a vaccine.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
You don't vaccinate a few children.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
You vaccinate all the children in an area.

title: The hunt for General Tso
transcript: There are more Chinese restaurants in this country than McDonald's, Burger King, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Wendy's, combined — 40,000, actually. Chinese restaurants have played an important role in American history, as a matter of fact. The Cuban missile crisis was resolved in a Chinese restaurant called Yenching Palace in Washington, DC, which unfortunately is closed now, and about to be turned into Walgreen's. And the house where John Wilkes Booth planned the assassination of Abraham Lincoln is also now a Chinese restaurant called Wok and Roll, on H Street in Washington.(Laughter)And it's not completely gratuitous, because "wok" and "roll" — Chinese food and Japanese foods, so it kind of works out. And Americans love their Chinese food so much, they've actually brought it into space. NASA, for example, serves thermostabilized sweet-and-sour pork on its shuttle menu for its astronauts.So, let me present the question to you: If our benchmark for Americanness is apple pie, you should ask yourself: how often do you eat apple pie, versus how often do you eat Chinese food?(Laughter)And if you think about it, a lot of the foods that we or Americans think of as Chinese food are barely recognizable to Chinese. For example: beef with broccoli, egg rolls, General Tso's Chicken, fortune cookies, chop suey, the take-out boxes. For example, I took a whole bunch of fortune cookies back to China, gave them to Chinese to see how they would react.[What is this?][Should I try it?][Try it!][What is this called?][Fortune cookie.](Laughter)[There's a piece of paper inside!](Laughter)[What is this?][You've won a prize!][What is this?][It's a fortune!][Tasty!]So where are they from? The short answer is, actually, they're from Japan. And in Kyoto, outside, there are still small family-run bakeries that make fortune cookies, as they did over 100 years ago, 30 years before fortune cookies were introduced in the United States. If you see them side by side, there's yellow and brown. Theirs are actually flavored with miso and sesame paste, so they're not as sweet as our version. So how did they get to the US? Well, the short answer is, the Japanese immigrants came over, and a bunch of the bakers introduced them — including at least one in Los Angeles, and one here in San Francisco, called Benkyodo, which is on the corner of Sutter and Buchanan. Back then, they made fortune cookies using very much the similar kind of irons that we saw back in Kyoto.The interesting question is: How do you go from fortune cookies being something that is Japanese to being something that is Chinese? Well, we locked up all the Japanese during World War II, including those that made fortune cookies. So that's when the Chinese moved in, saw a market opportunity and took over.(Laughter)So, fortune cookies: invented by the Japanese, popularized by the Chinese, but ultimately consumed by Americans. They're more American than anything else.Another of my favorite dishes: General Tso's Chicken — which, by the way, in the US Naval Academy is called Admiral Tso's Chicken.(Laughter)I love this dish. The original name of my book was "The Long March of General Tso." And he has marched very far indeed, because he is sweet, he is fried, and he is chicken — all things that Americans love.(Laughter)He has marched so far, actually, that the chef who originally invented the dish doesn't recognize it; he's kind of horrified.Video: (In Chinese)Audience: (Laughter)He's in Taiwan right now. He's retired, deaf and plays a lot of mah–jongg. After I showed him this, he got up, and says, "mòmíngqímiào," which means, "This is all nonsense," and goes back to play his mah-jongg game during the afternoon.Another dish, one of my favorites: beef with broccoli. Broccoli is not a Chinese vegetable; in fact, it is originally an Italian vegetable. It was introduced into the United States in the 1800s, but became popularized in the 1920s and the 1930s. The Chinese have their own version of broccoli, called Chinese broccoli, but they've now discovered American broccoli, and are importing it as a sort of exotic delicacy.I guarantee you, General Tso never saw a stalk of broccoli in his life. That was a picture of General Tso. I went to his home town. This is a billboard that says: "Welcome to the birthplace of General Tso." And I went looking for chicken. Finally found a cow — and did find chicken. Believe it or not, these guys were actually crossing the road.(Laughter)And I found a whole bunch of General Tso's relatives who are still in the town. This guy is now five generations removed from the General; this guy is about seven. I showed them the pictures of General Tso Chicken, and they were like, "We don't know this dish. Is this Chinese food?" Because it doesn't look like Chinese food to them. But they weren't surprised I traveled around the world to visit them, because in their eyes he is, after all, a famous Qing dynasty military hero. He played an important role in the Taiping Rebellion, a war started by a guy who thought he was the son of God and baby brother of Jesus Christ. He caused a war that killed 20 million people — still the deadliest civil war in the world to this day. So, you know, I realized when I was there, General Tso is kind of a lot like Colonel Sanders in America, in that he's known for chicken and not war. But in China, this guy's actually known for war and not chicken.But the granddaddy of all the Chinese American dishes we probably ought to talk about is chop suey, which was introduced around the turn of the 20th century. According to the New York Times in 1904, there was an outbreak of Chinese restaurants all over town, and "... the city has gone 'chop suey' mad." So it took about 30 years before the Americans realized that chop suey is actually not known in China, and as this article points out, "The average native of any city in China knows nothing of chop suey." Back then it was a way to show you were sophisticated and cosmopolitan; a guy who wanted to impress a girl could take her on a chop suey date. I like to say chop suey is the biggest culinary joke one culture ever played on another, because "chop suey," translated into Chinese, means "jaahp-seui," which, translated back, means "odds and ends." So, these people are going around China asking for chop suey, which is sort of like a Japanese guy coming here and saying, "I understand you have a very popular dish in your country called 'leftovers.'"(Laughter)Right?(Laughter)And not only that: "This dish is particularly popular after that holiday you call 'Thanksgiving.'"(Laughter)So, why and where did chop suey come from? Let's go back to the mid-1800s, when the Chinese first came to America. Back then, Americans were not clamoring to eat Chinese food. In fact, they saw these people who landed at their shores as alien. These people weren't eating dogs, they were eating cats. If they weren't eating cats, they were eating rats. In fact, The New York Times, my esteemed employer, in 1883 ran an article that asked, "Do Chinese eat rats?" Not the most PC question to be asked today, but if you look at the popular imagery of the time, not so outlandish. This is actually a real advertisement for rat poison from the late 1800s. And if you see under the word "Clears" — very small — it says, "They must go," which refers not only to the rats, but to the Chinese in their midst, because the way that the food was perceived was that these people who ate foods different from us must be different from us.Another way that you saw this antipathy towards the Chinese is through documents like this. This is in the Library of Congress. It's a pamphlet published by Samuel Gompers, hero of our American labor movement. It's called, "Some Reason for Chinese Exclusion: Meat versus Rice: American Manhood against Asiatic Coolieism: Which shall survive?" And it basically made the argument that Chinese men who ate rice would necessarily bring down the standard of living for American men who ate meat. And as a matter of fact, then, this is one of the reasons we must exclude them from this country. So, with sentiments like these, the Chinese Exclusion Act was passed between 1882 and 1902, the only time in American history when a group was specifically excluded for its national origin or ethnicity. So in a way, because the Chinese were attacked, chop suey was created as a defense mechanism.Who came up with the idea of chop suey? There's a lot of different mysteries and legends, but of the ones I've found, the most interesting is this article from 1904. A Chinese guy named Lem Sen shows up in Chinatown, New York City, and says, "I want you all to stop making chop suey, because I am the original creator and sole proprietor of chop suey. And the way he tells it, there was a famous Chinese diplomat that showed up, and he was told to make a dish that looked very popular and could, quote, "pass" as Chinese. And as he said — we would never print this today — but basically, the American man has become very rich. Lem Sen: "I would've made this money, too, but I spent all this time looking for the American man who stole my recipe. Now I've found him and I want my recipe back, and I want everyone to stop making chop suey, or pay me for the right to do the same. So it was an early exercise of intellectual property rights.The thing is, this idea of Chinese-American food doesn't exist only in America. In fact, Chinese food is the most pervasive food on the planet, served on all seven continents, even Antarctica, because Monday night is Chinese food night at McMurdo Station, which is the main scientific station in Antarctica. You see different varieties of Chinese food. For example, there is French Chinese food, where they serve salt and pepper frog legs. There is Italian Chinese food, where they don't have fortune cookies, so they serve fried gelato. My neighbor, Alessandra, was shocked when I told her, "Dude, fried gelato is not Chinese." She's like, "It's not? But they serve it in all the Chinese restaurants in Italy."(Laughter)Even the Brits have their own version. This is a dish called "crispy shredded beef," which has a lot of crisp, a lot of shred, and not a lot of beef. There is West Indian Chinese food, there's Jamaican Chinese food, Middle Eastern Chinese food, Mauritian Chinese food. This is a dish called "Magic Bowl," that I discovered. There's Indian Chinese food, Korean Chinese food, Japanese Chinese food, where they take the bao, the little buns, and make them into pizza versions.(Laughter)And they totally randomly take Chinese noodle dishes, and just ramenize them. This is something that, in the Chinese version, has no soup. So, there's Peruvian Chinese food, which should not be mixed with Mexican Chinese food, where they basically take things and make it look like fajitas.(Laughter)And they have things like risotto chop suey. My personal favorite of all the restaurants I've encountered around the world was this one in Brazil, called "Kung Food."(Laughter)So, let's take a step back and understand what is to be appreciated in America. McDonald's has garnered a lot of attention, a lot of respect, for basically standardizing the menu, decor and dining experience in post-World War II America. But you know what? They did so through a centralized headquarters out of Illinois. Chinese restaurants have done largely the same thing, I would argue, with the menu and the decor, even the restaurant name, but without a centralized headquarters. So, this actually became very clear to me with the March 30, 2005 Powerball drawing, where they expected, based on the number of ticket sales they had, to have three or four second-place winners, people who match five or six Powerball numbers. Instead, they had 110, and they were completely shocked.They looked all across the country and discovered it couldn't be fraud, since it happened in different states, across different computer systems. Whatever it was, it caused people to behave in a mass-synchronized way. So, OK, maybe it had to do with the patterns on the pieces of paper, like it was a diamond, or diagonal. It wasn't that, so they're like, OK, let's look at television. So they looked at an episode of "Lost." Now, I don't have a TV, which makes me a freak, but very productive —(Laughter)And there's an episode of "Lost" where one guy has a lucky number, but it's not a lucky number, it's why he's on the island, but they looked and the numbers did not match. They looked at "The Young and The Restless." It wasn't that, either. It wasn't until the first guy shows up the next day and they ask him, "Where did you get your number?" He said, "I got it from a fortune cookie." This is a slip one of the winners had, because the Tennessee lottery security officials were like, "Oh, no, this can't be true." But it was true. Basically, of those 110 people, 104 of them or so had gotten their number from a fortune cookie.(Laughter)Yeah. So I went and started looking. I went across the country, looking for these restaurants where these people had gotten their fortune cookies from. There are a bunch of them, including Lee's China in Omaha — which is actually run by Koreans, but that's another point, and a bunch of them named "China Buffet." What's interesting is that their stories were similar, but different. It was lunch, it was take-out, it was sit-down, it was buffet, it was three weeks ago, it was three months ago. But at some point, all these people had a very similar experience that converged at a fortune cookie and a Chinese restaurant. And all these restaurants were serving fortune cookies, which, of course, aren't even Chinese to begin with. It's part of the phenomenon I called "spontaneous self-organization," where, like in ant colonies, little decisions made on the micro level actually have a big impact on the macro level.A good contrast is Chicken McNuggets. McDonald's actually spent 10 years coming out with a chicken-like product. They did chicken pot pie, fried chicken, and finally introduced Chicken McNuggets. And the great innovation of Chicken McNuggets was not nuggifying them, that's kind of an easy concept. The trick was, they were able to remove the chicken from the bone in a cost-efficient manner, which is why it took so long for people to copy them — 10 years, then within a couple months, it was such a hit, they introduced it across the entire McDonald's system in the country.In contrast is General Tso's Chicken, which actually started in New York City in the early 1970s, as I was also started in this universe in New York City in the early 1970s.(Laughter)And this logo! So me, General Tso's Chicken and this logo are all karmicly related. But that dish also took about 10 years to spread across America from a restaurant in New York City. Someone's like, "It's sweet, it's fried, it's chicken — Americans will love this."So what I like to say, this being Bay Area, Silicon Valley, is that we think of McDonald's as sort of the Microsoft of dining experiences. We can think of Chinese restaurants perhaps as Linux, sort of an open-source thing, right?(Laughter)Where ideas from one person can be copied and propagated across the entire system, that there can be specialized versions of Chinese food, depending on the region. For example, in New Orleans we have Cajun Chinese food, where they serve Sichuan alligator and sweet and sour crawfish. And in Philadelphia, you have Philadelphia cheesesteak roll, which is like an egg roll on the outside and cheesesteak on the inside. I was surprised to discover that not only in Philadelphia, but also in Atlanta. What had happened was, a Chinese family had moved from Philadelphia to Atlanta, and brought that with them.So the thing is, our historical lore, because of the way we like narratives, is full of vast characters, such as Howard Schultz of Starbucks and Ray Kroc with McDonald's and Asa Candler with Coca-Cola. But, you know, it's very easy to overlook the smaller characters. For example, Lem Sen, who introduced chop suey, Chef Peng, who introduced General Tso's Chicken, and all the Japanese bakers who introduced fortune cookies. So, the point of my presentation is to make you think twice; that those whose names are forgotten in history can often have had as much, if not more, impact on what we eat today.Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:03:26.561 --> 00:03:28.002
Another of my favorite dishes:

00:03:28.026 --> 00:03:31.183
General Tso's Chicken --
which, by the way, in the US Naval Academy

00:03:31.207 --> 00:03:32.735
is called Admiral Tso's Chicken.

00:03:32.759 --> 00:03:33.765
(Laughter)

00:03:33.789 --> 00:03:34.941
I love this dish.

00:03:34.965 --> 00:03:38.026
The original name of my book
was "The Long March of General Tso."

00:03:38.050 --> 00:03:39.737
And he has marched very far indeed,

00:03:39.761 --> 00:03:42.804
because he is sweet, he is fried,
and he is chicken --

00:03:42.828 --> 00:03:44.586
all things that Americans love.

00:03:44.610 --> 00:03:46.269
(Laughter)

00:03:46.293 --> 00:03:47.837
He has marched so far, actually,

00:03:47.861 --> 00:03:50.026
that the chef who originally
invented the dish

00:03:50.050 --> 00:03:52.193
doesn't recognize it;
he's kind of horrified.

00:03:52.891 --> 00:03:54.891
Video: (In Chinese)

00:04:01.494 --> 00:04:03.353
Audience: (Laughter)

00:04:03.377 --> 00:04:04.934
He's in Taiwan right now.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.379
He's retired, deaf
and plays a lot of mah–jongg.

00:04:07.403 --> 00:04:10.672
After I showed him this, he got up,

00:04:10.696 --> 00:04:13.689
and says, "mòmíngqímiào,"
which means, "This is all nonsense,"

00:04:13.713 --> 00:04:16.664
and goes back to play his mah-jongg
game during the afternoon.

00:04:17.156 --> 00:04:20.668
Another dish, one of my favorites:
beef with broccoli.

00:04:20.692 --> 00:04:23.854
Broccoli is not a Chinese vegetable;

00:04:23.878 --> 00:04:26.599
in fact, it is originally
an Italian vegetable.

00:04:26.623 --> 00:04:29.598
It was introduced into
the United States in the 1800s,

00:04:29.622 --> 00:04:32.499
but became popularized
in the 1920s and the 1930s.

00:04:32.523 --> 00:04:35.972
The Chinese have their own version
of broccoli, called Chinese broccoli,

00:04:35.996 --> 00:04:38.415
but they've now discovered
American broccoli,

00:04:38.439 --> 00:04:42.324
and are importing it
as a sort of exotic delicacy.

00:04:42.348 --> 00:04:46.437
I guarantee you, General Tso
never saw a stalk of broccoli in his life.

00:04:46.461 --> 00:04:48.664
That was a picture of General Tso.

00:04:48.688 --> 00:04:49.934
I went to his home town.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.411
This is a billboard that says:

00:04:51.435 --> 00:04:53.451
"Welcome to the birthplace
of General Tso."

00:04:53.475 --> 00:04:55.670
And I went looking for chicken.

00:04:55.694 --> 00:04:57.140
Finally found a cow --

00:04:57.164 --> 00:04:59.910
and did find chicken.

00:04:59.934 --> 00:05:02.894
Believe it or not, these guys
were actually crossing the road.

00:05:02.918 --> 00:05:05.882
(Laughter)

00:05:06.564 --> 00:05:09.050
And I found a whole bunch
of General Tso's relatives

00:05:09.074 --> 00:05:10.359
who are still in the town.

00:05:10.383 --> 00:05:13.146
This guy is now five generations
removed from the General;

00:05:13.170 --> 00:05:14.376
this guy is about seven.

00:05:14.400 --> 00:05:17.226
I showed them the pictures
of General Tso Chicken,

00:05:17.250 --> 00:05:18.420
and they were like,

00:05:18.444 --> 00:05:20.707
"We don't know this dish.
Is this Chinese food?"

00:05:20.731 --> 00:05:23.158
Because it doesn't look
like Chinese food to them.

00:05:23.182 --> 00:05:27.438
But they weren't surprised I traveled
around the world to visit them,

00:05:27.462 --> 00:05:29.676
because in their eyes he is, after all,

00:05:29.700 --> 00:05:31.440
a famous Qing dynasty military hero.

00:05:31.464 --> 00:05:33.958
He played an important role
in the Taiping Rebellion,

00:05:33.982 --> 00:05:36.606
a war started by a guy
who thought he was the son of God

00:05:36.630 --> 00:05:38.220
and baby brother of Jesus Christ.

00:05:38.244 --> 00:05:40.534
He caused a war that killed
20 million people --

00:05:40.558 --> 00:05:43.811
still the deadliest civil war
in the world to this day.

00:05:44.656 --> 00:05:46.852
So, you know, I realized when I was there,

00:05:46.876 --> 00:05:49.853
General Tso is kind of a lot
like Colonel Sanders in America,

00:05:49.877 --> 00:05:52.405
in that he's known
for chicken and not war.

00:05:52.429 --> 00:05:55.921
But in China, this guy's actually known
for war and not chicken.

00:05:56.585 --> 00:05:59.086
But the granddaddy
of all the Chinese American dishes

00:05:59.110 --> 00:06:02.030
we probably ought to talk
about is chop suey,

00:06:02.054 --> 00:06:05.172
which was introduced
around the turn of the 20th century.

00:06:05.899 --> 00:06:07.824
According to the New York Times in 1904,

00:06:07.848 --> 00:06:10.711
there was an outbreak
of Chinese restaurants all over town,

00:06:10.735 --> 00:06:13.654
and "... the city has gone
'chop suey' mad."

00:06:13.678 --> 00:06:17.371
So it took about 30 years
before the Americans realized

00:06:17.395 --> 00:06:19.934
that chop suey is actually
not known in China,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.875
and as this article points out,

00:06:21.899 --> 00:06:26.486
"The average native of any city in China
knows nothing of chop suey."

00:06:26.510 --> 00:06:29.895
Back then it was a way to show
you were sophisticated and cosmopolitan;

00:06:29.919 --> 00:06:33.590
a guy who wanted to impress a girl
could take her on a chop suey date.

00:06:33.614 --> 00:06:36.067
I like to say chop suey
is the biggest culinary joke

00:06:36.091 --> 00:06:37.778
one culture ever played on another,

00:06:37.802 --> 00:06:39.921
because "chop suey,"
translated into Chinese,

00:06:39.945 --> 00:06:43.061
means "jaahp-seui," which, translated
back, means "odds and ends."

00:06:43.085 --> 00:06:46.458
So, these people are going
around China asking for chop suey,

00:06:46.482 --> 00:06:49.331
which is sort of like a Japanese guy
coming here and saying,

00:06:49.355 --> 00:06:52.099
"I understand you have
a very popular dish in your country

00:06:52.123 --> 00:06:53.427
called 'leftovers.'"

00:06:53.451 --> 00:06:55.663
(Laughter)

00:06:55.687 --> 00:06:56.838
Right?

00:06:56.862 --> 00:06:59.014
(Laughter)

00:06:59.038 --> 00:07:01.236
And not only that:

00:07:01.260 --> 00:07:02.903
"This dish is particularly popular

00:07:02.927 --> 00:07:05.019
after that holiday
you call 'Thanksgiving.'"

00:07:05.043 --> 00:07:06.045
(Laughter)

00:07:06.069 --> 00:07:09.151
So, why and where did chop suey come from?

00:07:09.175 --> 00:07:12.372
Let's go back to the mid-1800s,

00:07:12.396 --> 00:07:14.308
when the Chinese first came to America.

00:07:14.332 --> 00:07:17.739
Back then, Americans were not
clamoring to eat Chinese food.

00:07:17.763 --> 00:07:22.406
In fact, they saw these people
who landed at their shores as alien.

00:07:22.859 --> 00:07:25.492
These people weren't eating dogs,
they were eating cats.

00:07:25.516 --> 00:07:27.899
If they weren't eating cats,
they were eating rats.

00:07:27.923 --> 00:07:30.273
In fact, The New York Times,
my esteemed employer,

00:07:30.297 --> 00:07:31.921
in 1883 ran an article that asked,

00:07:31.945 --> 00:07:33.096
"Do Chinese eat rats?"

00:07:33.120 --> 00:07:37.470
Not the most PC question
to be asked today,

00:07:37.494 --> 00:07:39.905
but if you look at the popular
imagery of the time,

00:07:39.929 --> 00:07:41.345
not so outlandish.

00:07:41.369 --> 00:07:46.325
This is actually a real
advertisement for rat poison

00:07:46.349 --> 00:07:47.556
from the late 1800s.

00:07:47.580 --> 00:07:50.238
And if you see under the word
"Clears" -- very small --

00:07:50.262 --> 00:07:53.048
it says, "They must go,"
which refers not only to the rats,

00:07:53.072 --> 00:07:55.049
but to the Chinese in their midst,

00:07:55.073 --> 00:07:58.126
because the way
that the food was perceived

00:07:58.150 --> 00:08:01.222
was that these people who ate
foods different from us

00:08:01.246 --> 00:08:02.500
must be different from us.

00:08:02.524 --> 00:08:05.902
Another way that you saw
this antipathy towards the Chinese

00:08:05.926 --> 00:08:07.415
is through documents like this.

00:08:07.439 --> 00:08:09.110
This is in the Library of Congress.

00:08:09.134 --> 00:08:11.197
It's a pamphlet published
by Samuel Gompers,

00:08:11.221 --> 00:08:12.959
hero of our American labor movement.

00:08:12.983 --> 00:08:15.590
It's called, "Some Reason
for Chinese Exclusion:

00:08:15.614 --> 00:08:19.298
Meat versus Rice: American Manhood
against Asiatic Coolieism:

00:08:19.322 --> 00:08:20.473
Which shall survive?"

00:08:20.497 --> 00:08:22.274
And it basically made the argument

00:08:22.298 --> 00:08:24.331
that Chinese men who ate rice

00:08:24.355 --> 00:08:26.737
would necessarily bring down
the standard of living

00:08:26.761 --> 00:08:28.546
for American men who ate meat.

00:08:28.570 --> 00:08:30.008
And as a matter of fact, then,

00:08:30.032 --> 00:08:33.132
this is one of the reasons
we must exclude them from this country.

00:08:33.156 --> 00:08:34.934
So, with sentiments like these,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:40.934
the Chinese Exclusion Act
was passed between 1882 and 1902,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.934
the only time in American history

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.866
when a group was specifically excluded

00:08:44.890 --> 00:08:48.301
for its national origin or ethnicity.

00:08:48.325 --> 00:08:50.718
So in a way, because
the Chinese were attacked,

00:08:50.742 --> 00:08:53.891
chop suey was created
as a defense mechanism.

00:08:53.915 --> 00:08:55.934
Who came up with the idea of chop suey?

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.256
There's a lot of different
mysteries and legends,

00:08:58.280 --> 00:08:59.753
but of the ones I've found,

00:08:59.777 --> 00:09:02.682
the most interesting
is this article from 1904.

00:09:02.706 --> 00:09:03.997
A Chinese guy named Lem Sen

00:09:04.021 --> 00:09:06.228
shows up in Chinatown,
New York City, and says,

00:09:06.252 --> 00:09:08.219
"I want you all to stop making chop suey,

00:09:08.243 --> 00:09:11.773
because I am the original creator
and sole proprietor of chop suey.

00:09:11.797 --> 00:09:13.178
And the way he tells it,

00:09:13.202 --> 00:09:18.191
there was a famous Chinese
diplomat that showed up,

00:09:18.215 --> 00:09:20.826
and he was told to make a dish
that looked very popular

00:09:20.850 --> 00:09:22.588
and could, quote, "pass" as Chinese.

00:09:22.612 --> 00:09:25.284
And as he said --
we would never print this today --

00:09:25.308 --> 00:09:29.055
but basically, the American man
has become very rich.

00:09:29.079 --> 00:09:32.350
Lem Sen: "I would've made this money, too,
but I spent all this time

00:09:32.374 --> 00:09:34.667
looking for the American man
who stole my recipe.

00:09:34.691 --> 00:09:36.793
Now I've found him
and I want my recipe back,

00:09:36.817 --> 00:09:38.944
and I want everyone
to stop making chop suey,

00:09:38.968 --> 00:09:40.841
or pay me for the right to do the same.

00:09:40.865 --> 00:09:44.530
So it was an early exercise
of intellectual property rights.

00:09:44.554 --> 00:09:47.934
The thing is, this idea
of Chinese-American food

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.062
doesn't exist only in America.

00:09:51.086 --> 00:09:54.087
In fact, Chinese food
is the most pervasive food on the planet,

00:09:54.111 --> 00:09:57.086
served on all seven continents,
even Antarctica,

00:09:57.110 --> 00:10:00.066
because Monday night is Chinese
food night at McMurdo Station,

00:10:00.090 --> 00:10:03.209
which is the main scientific
station in Antarctica.

00:10:03.233 --> 00:10:05.284
You see different varieties
of Chinese food.

00:10:05.308 --> 00:10:07.366
For example, there is French Chinese food,

00:10:07.390 --> 00:10:10.339
where they serve
salt and pepper frog legs.

00:10:10.363 --> 00:10:14.350
There is Italian Chinese food,
where they don't have fortune cookies,

00:10:14.374 --> 00:10:15.662
so they serve fried gelato.

00:10:15.686 --> 00:10:18.460
My neighbor, Alessandra,
was shocked when I told her,

00:10:18.484 --> 00:10:20.416
"Dude, fried gelato is not Chinese."

00:10:20.440 --> 00:10:24.446
She's like, "It's not? But they serve it
in all the Chinese restaurants in Italy."

00:10:24.470 --> 00:10:28.160
(Laughter)

00:10:28.184 --> 00:10:30.000
Even the Brits have their own version.

00:10:30.024 --> 00:10:32.275
This is a dish called
"crispy shredded beef,"

00:10:32.299 --> 00:10:35.475
which has a lot of crisp, a lot of shred,
and not a lot of beef.

00:10:35.499 --> 00:10:38.592
There is West Indian Chinese food,
there's Jamaican Chinese food,

00:10:38.616 --> 00:10:41.694
Middle Eastern Chinese food,
Mauritian Chinese food.

00:10:41.718 --> 00:10:44.440
This is a dish called "Magic Bowl,"
that I discovered.

00:10:44.464 --> 00:10:46.934
There's Indian Chinese food,
Korean Chinese food,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.442
Japanese Chinese food,

00:10:48.466 --> 00:10:52.435
where they take the bao, the little buns,
and make them into pizza versions.

00:10:52.459 --> 00:10:53.574
(Laughter)

00:10:53.598 --> 00:10:56.775
And they totally randomly
take Chinese noodle dishes,

00:10:56.799 --> 00:10:58.007
and just ramenize them.

00:10:58.031 --> 00:11:01.245
This is something that,
in the Chinese version, has no soup.

00:11:01.269 --> 00:11:03.232
So, there's Peruvian Chinese food,

00:11:03.256 --> 00:11:05.711
which should not be mixed
with Mexican Chinese food,

00:11:05.735 --> 00:11:08.708
where they basically take things
and make it look like fajitas.

00:11:08.732 --> 00:11:09.734
(Laughter)

00:11:09.758 --> 00:11:11.818
And they have things
like risotto chop suey.

00:11:11.842 --> 00:11:13.914
My personal favorite
of all the restaurants

00:11:13.938 --> 00:11:15.525
I've encountered around the world

00:11:15.549 --> 00:11:17.589
was this one in Brazil,
called "Kung Food."

00:11:17.613 --> 00:11:21.224
(Laughter)

00:11:21.248 --> 00:11:24.497
So, let's take a step back and understand

00:11:24.521 --> 00:11:27.093
what is to be appreciated in America.

00:11:27.117 --> 00:11:32.376
McDonald's has garnered
a lot of attention, a lot of respect,

00:11:32.400 --> 00:11:37.950
for basically standardizing the menu,
decor and dining experience

00:11:37.974 --> 00:11:39.524
in post-World War II America.

00:11:39.548 --> 00:11:40.788
But you know what?

00:11:40.812 --> 00:11:43.952
They did so through a centralized
headquarters out of Illinois.

00:11:43.976 --> 00:11:47.188
Chinese restaurants have done largely
the same thing, I would argue,

00:11:47.212 --> 00:11:49.760
with the menu and the decor,
even the restaurant name,

00:11:49.784 --> 00:11:51.651
but without a centralized headquarters.

00:11:51.675 --> 00:11:54.016
So, this actually became very clear to me

00:11:54.040 --> 00:11:56.799
with the March 30, 2005 Powerball drawing,

00:11:56.823 --> 00:11:59.934
where they expected, based
on the number of ticket sales they had,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.979
to have three or four
second-place winners,

00:12:02.003 --> 00:12:04.223
people who match
five or six Powerball numbers.

00:12:04.247 --> 00:12:06.886
Instead, they had 110,
and they were completely shocked.

00:12:06.910 --> 00:12:10.271
They looked all across the country
and discovered it couldn't be fraud,

00:12:10.295 --> 00:12:13.777
since it happened in different states,
across different computer systems.

00:12:13.801 --> 00:12:17.166
Whatever it was, it caused people
to behave in a mass-synchronized way.

00:12:17.190 --> 00:12:21.291
So, OK, maybe it had to do
with the patterns on the pieces of paper,

00:12:21.315 --> 00:12:24.221
like it was a diamond, or diagonal.

00:12:24.245 --> 00:12:27.185
It wasn't that, so they're like,
OK, let's look at television.

00:12:27.209 --> 00:12:29.138
So they looked at an episode of "Lost."

00:12:29.162 --> 00:12:30.351
Now, I don't have a TV,

00:12:30.375 --> 00:12:32.577
which makes me a freak,
but very productive --

00:12:32.601 --> 00:12:34.728
(Laughter)

00:12:34.752 --> 00:12:38.645
And there's an episode of "Lost"
where one guy has a lucky number,

00:12:38.669 --> 00:12:41.367
but it's not a lucky number,
it's why he's on the island,

00:12:41.391 --> 00:12:43.632
but they looked
and the numbers did not match.

00:12:43.656 --> 00:12:46.854
They looked at "The Young
and The Restless." It wasn't that, either.

00:12:46.878 --> 00:12:50.163
It wasn't until the first guy shows up
the next day and they ask him,

00:12:50.187 --> 00:12:51.716
"Where did you get your number?"

00:12:51.740 --> 00:12:53.745
He said, "I got it from a fortune cookie."

00:12:53.769 --> 00:12:55.589
This is a slip one of the winners had,

00:12:55.613 --> 00:12:57.949
because the Tennessee
lottery security officials

00:12:57.973 --> 00:12:59.894
were like, "Oh, no, this can't be true."

00:12:59.918 --> 00:13:01.081
But it was true.

00:13:01.105 --> 00:13:03.934
Basically, of those 110 people,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:07.243
104 of them or so had gotten
their number from a fortune cookie.

00:13:07.267 --> 00:13:09.070
(Laughter)

00:13:09.094 --> 00:13:11.936
Yeah. So I went and started looking.

00:13:11.960 --> 00:13:14.580
I went across the country,
looking for these restaurants

00:13:14.604 --> 00:13:17.532
where these people had gotten
their fortune cookies from.

00:13:18.042 --> 00:13:21.195
There are a bunch of them,
including Lee's China in Omaha --

00:13:21.219 --> 00:13:24.000
which is actually run by Koreans,
but that's another point,

00:13:24.024 --> 00:13:26.581
and a bunch of them named "China Buffet."

00:13:26.605 --> 00:13:29.934
What's interesting is that their stories
were similar, but different.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.934
It was lunch, it was take-out,
it was sit-down, it was buffet,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.215
it was three weeks ago,
it was three months ago.

00:13:35.239 --> 00:13:38.359
But at some point, all these people
had a very similar experience

00:13:38.383 --> 00:13:41.247
that converged at a fortune cookie
and a Chinese restaurant.

00:13:41.271 --> 00:13:43.867
And all these restaurants
were serving fortune cookies,

00:13:43.891 --> 00:13:46.337
which, of course,
aren't even Chinese to begin with.

00:13:46.361 --> 00:13:49.901
It's part of the phenomenon
I called "spontaneous self-organization,"

00:13:49.925 --> 00:13:55.773
where, like in ant colonies,
little decisions made on the micro level

00:13:55.797 --> 00:13:58.083
actually have a big impact
on the macro level.

00:13:58.107 --> 00:14:02.500
A good contrast is Chicken McNuggets.

00:14:02.524 --> 00:14:06.061
McDonald's actually spent 10 years
coming out with a chicken-like product.

00:14:06.085 --> 00:14:10.371
They did chicken pot pie, fried chicken,
and finally introduced Chicken McNuggets.

00:14:10.395 --> 00:14:14.400
And the great innovation of Chicken
McNuggets was not nuggifying them,

00:14:14.424 --> 00:14:15.922
that's kind of an easy concept.

00:14:15.946 --> 00:14:19.721
The trick was, they were able
to remove the chicken from the bone

00:14:19.745 --> 00:14:21.033
in a cost-efficient manner,

00:14:21.057 --> 00:14:24.116
which is why it took so long
for people to copy them -- 10 years,

00:14:24.140 --> 00:14:26.336
then within a couple months,
it was such a hit,

00:14:26.360 --> 00:14:29.651
they introduced it across the entire
McDonald's system in the country.

00:14:29.675 --> 00:14:31.441
In contrast is General Tso's Chicken,

00:14:31.465 --> 00:14:34.228
which actually started
in New York City in the early 1970s,

00:14:34.252 --> 00:14:37.787
as I was also started in this universe
in New York City in the early 1970s.

00:14:37.811 --> 00:14:38.813
(Laughter)

00:14:38.837 --> 00:14:39.988
And this logo!

00:14:40.012 --> 00:14:43.263
So me, General Tso's Chicken
and this logo are all karmicly related.

00:14:43.287 --> 00:14:46.255
But that dish also took about 10 years
to spread across America

00:14:46.279 --> 00:14:47.958
from a restaurant in New York City.

00:14:47.982 --> 00:14:50.756
Someone's like, "It's sweet,
it's fried, it's chicken --

00:14:50.780 --> 00:14:52.153
Americans will love this."

00:14:52.177 --> 00:14:56.133
So what I like to say,
this being Bay Area, Silicon Valley,

00:14:56.157 --> 00:15:00.300
is that we think of McDonald's as sort
of the Microsoft of dining experiences.

00:15:00.324 --> 00:15:03.080
We can think of Chinese
restaurants perhaps as Linux,

00:15:03.104 --> 00:15:05.350
sort of an open-source thing, right?

00:15:05.374 --> 00:15:06.376
(Laughter)

00:15:06.400 --> 00:15:10.045
Where ideas from one person
can be copied and propagated

00:15:10.069 --> 00:15:11.290
across the entire system,

00:15:11.314 --> 00:15:15.161
that there can be specialized
versions of Chinese food,

00:15:15.185 --> 00:15:16.336
depending on the region.

00:15:16.360 --> 00:15:19.958
For example, in New Orleans
we have Cajun Chinese food,

00:15:19.982 --> 00:15:23.752
where they serve Sichuan alligator
and sweet and sour crawfish.

00:15:23.776 --> 00:15:27.037
And in Philadelphia,
you have Philadelphia cheesesteak roll,

00:15:27.061 --> 00:15:30.400
which is like an egg roll on the outside
and cheesesteak on the inside.

00:15:30.424 --> 00:15:34.150
I was surprised to discover that not only
in Philadelphia, but also in Atlanta.

00:15:34.174 --> 00:15:35.325
What had happened was,

00:15:35.349 --> 00:15:39.912
a Chinese family had moved
from Philadelphia to Atlanta,

00:15:39.936 --> 00:15:41.563
and brought that with them.

00:15:41.587 --> 00:15:43.284
So the thing is,

00:15:43.308 --> 00:15:46.096
our historical lore,
because of the way we like narratives,

00:15:46.120 --> 00:15:49.149
is full of vast characters,
such as Howard Schultz of Starbucks

00:15:49.173 --> 00:15:51.429
and Ray Kroc with McDonald's

00:15:51.453 --> 00:15:53.934
and Asa Candler with Coca-Cola.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:58.081
But, you know, it's very easy
to overlook the smaller characters.

00:15:58.479 --> 00:16:00.789
For example, Lem Sen,
who introduced chop suey,

00:16:00.813 --> 00:16:03.190
Chef Peng, who introduced
General Tso's Chicken,

00:16:03.214 --> 00:16:06.934
and all the Japanese bakers
who introduced fortune cookies.

00:16:07.388 --> 00:16:10.735
So, the point of my presentation
is to make you think twice;

00:16:10.759 --> 00:16:13.197
that those whose names
are forgotten in history

00:16:13.221 --> 00:16:15.308
can often have had as much, if not more,

00:16:15.332 --> 00:16:17.227
impact on what we eat today.

00:16:17.251 --> 00:16:18.402
Thank you very much.

00:16:18.426 --> 00:16:24.577
(Applause)
